text:
It has been on my bookmark place for a while. We think the best time to visit is lunch. When the price of the food is more measured up to food is served. I like it they are across to the parking garage which make it easy to park. 

This restaurant chef do have good skill. The food that served is well thought out. Sauce and ingredients are well balanced to each other. We start with white asparagus soup. It has touch of aioli and bread crumb. It was good to have. My wife has the buttermilk fried chicken. The sesame bun that accompanied it has great taste. The honey sauce in the chicken is delicious. 

My entrée is the salmon with curry cous cous. It also has the sautéed shiitake mushrooms and the Brussels sprouts. This dish is amazing.  The service is a bit slow. Our waiter did not check on us regularly. However, other waiter did come to pick the empty plate quickly.

Another excellent dinner by Stephen Starr's restaurant. The ceviches are amazing. I tried 3 samplers: Thai young coconut, shrimp, and yellow tail. Cobb salad is really good, the dressing is not drenching, it's just perfect. I also ordered guacamole with plantain chips which is not on the menu. I dad tuna with sugar cane which is excellent too. I tried my husband's scallops with quinoa, crab and Serrano ham. It's good too but in the salty side. For dessert, get the signature cigar dessert, you won't be disappointed.

What can't you find at Mazzaro's.  It's always busy so plan your visit accordingly.  Every area of this place is packed full of goodness and you can't go wrong with any food or drink option here.  There's a bakery for all your sweet tooth or bread needs, a coffee bar, deli, butcher, wine room, and fresh cheese area.  I'm sure I've missed something, but you get the jist.

Food options from the deli are limitless and everything I've had is generously portioned and flavorful.  There are also refrigerated and frozen take home meals that are ready to go and priced very reasonably.  All of the staff in every area of this place are pleasant and always willing to help.

Great meal here again.   We ordered the soup with crawfish and andouille.   The pub nachos which we had never had before were great.  Home made chips, cheesy sauce, great garnish.   The foie gras burger is to die for - still.  If you need occasional hit of foie gras, this is the place.

It's not the best, but it's not the worst. It's just...Philly.

It's true that I used to fly way more in college than I do now, but there always tends to be some sort of hassle involved with any trip out of here. 

I can't remember the last time I thought anything along the lines of, "Oh, how nice. No issues with checking in bags. No issues with long security lines manned by surly agents. No issues with flight delays. What a smooth trip! Wahoo!"

I love traveling and yet hate flying with a passion, so I loathe spending time in airports and planes for the most part. But at least Philly has good restaurants and bars, unlike some airports.

I feel like three stars is fair. Generally average with a special dose of aggravation.

On Swann is a nice addition to the Hyde Park area. We went on Sunday evening as a party of 4 for my birthday dinner. We were seated promptly upon arrival (we had a reservation). The restaurant is LOUD, so not a good option for a business meeting or those who are hard of hearing or don't like screaming to converse. Started with some cocktails and all were tasty. The complimentary bread and butter are delicious. We started with the zeppoles and marinated olives, both of which were very yummy. The beet salad was simple but very yummy. Hubs and I shared the pork belly steam buns, fig flatbread, and scallop entree. Mom had the meatballs and dad had the roasted chicken. All of the dishes were tasty and well executed, but there was nothing mind-blowing that I'd be dying to have again. The scallops were a bit of a disappointment as there was just too much going on for me - 2 or 3 different sauces, brussel sprouts, crispy kale, etc. Just too much (but each component was very good by itself). I found a hair in my pork belly steam bun and the waitress brought us out another order, but it arrived well after we had finished eating all the rest of our food (and they did not comp the dish, which surprised me). They were having issues with the lights so most of the lights were all flickering like strobe lights, and they eventually turned a lot of them off so it was very dark to eat. The manager said this has been a consistent issue, so I'm surprised it hadn't been fixed yet. Our waitress was very friendly and kind. Overall, it was a nice experience and I know I will be back. I can't say it's my favorite meal I've had, but I was impressed, especially given that On Swann has been open for a short period of time.

Someone brought me a cheesesteak from here and it was good but I'm not inclined to seek out another one of these."  The quality and amount of beef was ok but I was impressed with the amount of cheese.   The roll is particularly soft- no real chew- and that's not what I personally like hence the "nothing special" rating for me.

* I know this airport extremely well as I've passed though it over 100 times in the last two years.  
* As a frequent traveler I compare it to other airports all the time.
* As an area resident I've seen the changes over the last 15 years.
* Many folks would consider me a Philly Airport EXPERT.

As I think about my many experience here, two phrases come to mind every time-"Behind the times" and "Getting better but not fast enough!"  Years ago this airport was abysmal.  Now it's just barely OK.

In and out primarily on Route 95 is fine.

Parking has gotten better but is still marginal.  Pulling up to the garage for your terminal and seeing a flashing "FULL" message is what I would call a high stress experience.

Arrivals or Departures is complete insanity!  It's Demolition Derby time!  The top airports have figured it out and the difference is amazing.

Restaurants/Bars have gotten better but still need work.  People want to see the same names they see outside the airport and that's starting to happen.  The top airports have started to add fine dining and they are a long way from that here.

Wi-Fi is critical at an airport and it's a joke here.  The person in charge of it should be terminated and then shot.

Power outlets and USB ports are getting much better however the top airports have figured out how important this is and will blow Philly away with convenience.

Security here can be very bad with waits sometimes as long as an hour.  However the new TSA Pre Check program is amazing.  With it I often blow through security in less than two minutes!

Architecturally the place is boring.  When they went looking for a designer it feels like they hired a 2nd tier firm.

First impressions are important and the airport is it for many tourists.  I love Philly and it saddens me to give our airport just barely 3 stars.

Great BBQ place. Closed on Sunday. You walk in and immediately know you're in a bbq place! The aroma is amazing. You walk up to place your order and can see all available sides in front of you. Let me suggest the green beans and corn! Oh my are these yummy! They have a kids menu as well which is what I typically order from given the serving size fits me better. 

They are reasonably priced and a good spot for some good bbq. Sauces are on the tables. Soda and teas are self serve. To go boxes are also self serve and typically located by the drink station. 

They also have a separate dessert counter with some amazing desserts although I've never tried any.

I'm certain that I'm not the first or last person to walk from Irish 31 after a solid drink to Goody Goody for dinner and be chased away by the inevitable lengthy wait for a table.

That's when we headed to Bartaco and our night improved significantly based on that move.

We had our choice of seating inside or out upon arrival, ulimately taking the air-conditioning option at the inside bar where were immediately introduced to a hard-working bartender named Zack who did a superb job for us.

Zack made a fresh and strong margarita for us and I had no problem ordering from one of the many canned beer options in the cooler, which are served in a Bartaco coozie as a nice touch. There is no draft beer offered here with twice as man cans than bottles in the beer selection.

Guacamole and fresh chips were ordered and served quickly. The chips are light and crisp for breaking up and dipping as another unique representation of the restaurant. Guacamole was "fine" as in we ate it, but probably wouldn't order again. 

We tried a half-dozen different tacos, all of which price at $2.50 or $3.50. They were served perfectly, quickly and with ultra fresh taste.

Of the six, we probably would eliminate the pork belly next time as the pork pastor satisfied that craving without the extra fat. I personally would love another handful of the other five with special mention of the chorizo, ribeye and even the duck. (You can look elsewhere here on Yelp for a review of the oyster taco. I'd rather skateboard at a Charlie Belcher live shot than eat anything involving an oyster.)

The tacos initially look small, but deliver the flavor in about 3-4 bites each because there is a good amount of protein packed in each one. 

Those additional sauces available are very good and deliver a nice finishing kick, although it isn't necessary with the kimchi already part of the fine ribeye version.

And then there was the gazpacho, always a favorite of mine virtually anywhere as long as it isn't the pineapple version. 

Bartaco's gazpacho offers a huge amount for just $5 with huge croutons already floating on top. This isn't as hearty and red as what I'm used to, but the more orange and creamy interpretation still delivered and showed another unique touch from this restaurant.

I'm a huge sports fan, so I notice when any restaurant now days offers absolutely zero TVs anywhere including above the bar. It seems rare, doesn't it, and Bartaco not having any fits the atmosphere and decor perfectly. (Besides, it is summertime and there is not a primetime sporting event worth watching until college football starts on Labor Day weekend. No, the Rays games are less exciting than a blindside eviction on Big Brother and Julie Chen looks a lot better on TV than "The Big NO," Mr. Destrade)

Bartaco has a rather odd yet effective choice of music for a place with this menu. Especially since the sound system is way above average for a dining spot. This is not nonstop Mexican music at all. As a matter of fact, it is a little bit of everything and reminded me of when I visit the wonderful Pink Taco restaurant and bar in the Hard Rock Hotel Las Vegas. 

My only regret, based on the quality review of fellow elite Diana A, was how we did pass on this supposedly memorable tamale.

Of course, we did order almost ten different items so something was going to be left out.

Besides, I was proud and rather happy with our duck choice as it ranks right up there with my other duck favorites such as Marcus Mariota and Ryan Getzlaf.

We had lunch catered by DiBruno Bros., and the food is very solid.  The sandwich platter comes with the chicken pronto (mozzarella, pesto, greens, and chicken on a baguette), roast beef, turkey and brie, and caprese.  I loved the caprese, as it came with plenty of fresh mozzarella, a great pesto spread, and sliced tomatoes.  The garden salad was very standard but the creamy, oil-based roasted vegetable vinaigrette was fantastic.  The pasta primavera with white fusilli and vegetables tossed in a white wine vinaigrette was also very good and not overly tangy.  The dessert tray of brownies and cookies was also a hit and I was definitely a fan of the rich fudge brownies.  Overall, a great gourmet catering option for a small to medium group.

You haven't had the true Philly sports experience until you've been to CBP. I'm a life long Phillies fan and had a hard time letting the Vet go. After I got past the initial adjustment, I've grown to love this great stadium.

For one, there's not a bad seat in the house. I've sat in variety of locations over the years, and while they've mostly been nosebleeds, I've always had a good view of the game. 

Speaking of views, the stadium was ingeniously structured with gorgeous views of Center City Philadelphia.  I have more stadium sunset pictures then I know what to do with, but I can't help taking in the sights. Slightly obstructing the city view is the high tech, digital scoreboard. Ice cream shuffle or Septa race anyone? I always look forward to the in between inning entertainment. 

For a 10 year old stadium, its also pretty well maintained. Bathrooms at athletic venues normally skeeve me out, but they keep the bathrooms pretty clean. The rest of the stadium follows suit.

Of course they sell overpriced stadium food and drink. However the selection and variety is actually pretty good. Last night my section was conveniently located near the Alley Brewing Company and was able to quickly get myself a Goose Island IPA. The stadium is also home to local favorites such as Federal Donuts and Chickie and Pete's. I just object to spending most of my ballpark experience waiting in line for food I can get at their flagship locations.

So I'll root, root, root for the Phillies and if they don't win its a shame....but at least I'll know that I'm going have a great time at the ball park.

Why 5 stars? Because you can't walk in here without saying "WOAH!"

   ---   ---   ---

What.... is this place? How did it get here? Does the British mob own it? Why is it the size of six restaurants? What's upstairs? How did they hire so many people, yet keep it a fairly unknown secret? Do the employees have their own Publix somewhere inside? Is there a state income tax here?

If you find yourself asking these questions, don't worry, these symptoms are normal. And if you're asking if the food matches the ambiance... the answer is YESSIRorma'am!

I had no idea what I was getting into, so my first visit found me arriving around 4:00. I was very much unaware that from 3-5pm, they have an abbreviated "Afternoon Tea Menu" which consists of small bites and tea only. My chicken curry sandwich was really tasty, but it was $8 and consisted of only four small bites. 

I quickly made a return trip for the regular lunch, and I had very high expectations for the food. I convinced myself that I would definitely be disappointed because the entire existence of this place seemed too good to be true.

I went with the steak sandwich and Ms. Shanna D grabbed the Club. This was the perfect storm, these two sandwiches were the top two of each of our wish-lists. That steak sandwich was serious business. I would go as far as to say it's the best I've ever had. The Club was phenomenal as well. 

On the side, the roasted sweet potato rounds were the very obvious choice...and WOW. Wow. I have nothing else to say -just order these and be thankful for Yelp. What a lunch!

So a strange moment was that when we walked in, we were told that it would be a 5-10 minute wait... which didn't make a lot of sense because about 60% of the tables were unoccupied. I chalk it up to the staff still working out the kinks of a restaurant that opened a week before my two visits. This minor inconvenience was completely forgotten when our food came no more than five minutes after we put our order in. It was shockingly quick.

Now one more thing: tea. I have never been a tea drinker, but Oxford may be converting me. I have had the coconut, the cherry coconut kiwi, and the banana. They were so perfect, they have me craving tea for the first time in my life!

To summarize, you absolutely must visit Oxford Exchange. Even if you are underwhelmed with the food/tea (but you won't be if you get the steak sammie), the ambiance is like NOTHING in Tampa Bay... so it's worth a trip for that alone. Megan W said it best, "we're not in Kansas anymore."

Johns is truly something special in Philadelphia. If you've never been here, you should go! I've had just about everything on the menu and it never disappoints.

Today I stopped for a quick lunch. This is your typical Philly sandwich joint, they offer outdoor seating. Ordering can be overwhelming especially if you've never been there. They have 2 different lines for grill and just pork. They are known for their pork and cheesesteaks. Without a doubt some of the best in the city. Today I went with the chicken parmigiana sandwich and it was fantastic! The roll was spot on. The chicken was moist and flavorful, not dry like most cases. The sauce and cheese were perfect as well. I went with sharp provolone and it's the only way to go.

The staff could use some help. Most guys are miserable and cut you off mid order. As I said it can be a bit overwhelming. The line is always out the door. They do accept credit cards now. Overall it's a great spot to get a solid sandwich. Everything else can easily be overlooked.

Let me start off by saying that my review will not impact the fact that we love this place and are part of their wine club.  However I was in fact disappointed with today's visit.  My hubs and I came here today for a day date while our daughter was at a kids birthday party.  We had a coupon for their Summer treat for members whereby club members get either 1 free bottle of wine or pitcher of sangria to enjoy at the table during a visit. I opted for the pitcher of sangria and tried the passion fruit today which OMG I would highly recommend and this will be my go-to for my monthly bottle for a while.  Not overly sweet and not very strong which is great for me since I'm a lightweight when it comes to drinking. :)

Made reservations for 12:45pm for lunch -- arrived and checked in right on time.  We were sort of dismissed by the hostess who told us someone would seat us soon....so we went and sat on the side bench.  2 other parties were seated before we were, which ok, perhaps they were a bit behind on seating people.  We were sat in the back corner and it was so cold that even my hubs who typically isn't cold said something and was sitting on his hands.  We were greeted by our waiter who took our drink order and let us review the menu.  He came back with our water and pitcher of sangria, took our appetizer order and said he'd be back with bread.  We sat for another good 10 minutes before we got bread and he came to take our food order.  We were busy talking and having a good time, already ate our appetizer, before we noticed that we hadn't gotten our entrees.  Other tables that sat way after us had their food and were actually wrapping things up.  Looked at my phone and it was already 2pm!!  Say what!?  Our waiter was nowhere to be seen -- then when he did appear, sped past our table to service the table behind us and never came to see us.  Received our food around 2:20pm and not once did our waiter come by to see how the food was.  A totally different person other than our waiter brought the food  and originally sat the wrong entree in front of my hubs -- he ordered the short ribs but she delivered a fish entree.  I immediately said something to her and she looked puzzled.  I had to repeat that he ordered short ribs and that surely didn't look like short ribs.  She took the entree and came back out about 3 minutes later with the food he ordered.

My Dana's Parm Chicken did not look like the picture at all -- chicken was dry and green beans & chicken were not really hot.  I think it was sitting there for some time before our meal was actually brought to us.  When we were done eating, we sat there for a long time before our waiter decided to come and ask if we needed a box.  He did pack up the food very fast and brought us our check.  This turned out to be almost a 2 hour lunch.  WOW!  Went out to the front area with the thought of stopping at the register to get my 4 bottles that I need to pick up but the line was so long that we decided to just come back another time.  The line was backed up all the way to the entrance to the restaurant!  I think every time we visit we always seem to struggle with the service here -- and one would think that since you're paying a premium for the food and dining experience that they'd do a better job with service.  Maybe our server was serving various areas today however I'm not going to make up excuses.

El Vez is one of those Philly restaurants that has remained constant for well over a decade. Its one of the first restaurants Jose Garces worked at before he won Iron Chef, saw his own restaurant empire start to rise, gradually disintegrate, and become rebuilt in a new way.

That is one way that the Philly restaurant scene has evolved since El Vez has remained a solid constant. But another way exists directly outside of it where restauranteurs like Marcie Turney & Valerie Safran, Michael Schulson, and the restaurant group behind Zavino have developed a growing restaurant empire within the same area. Meanwhile El Vez might not even be the best Spanish influenced restaurant under Starr so long as El Rey remains an incredible spot that leads to a not that hidden cocktail bar in Rittenhouse Square, and Stephen Starr gets ready to open a new Mexican restaurant in Fishtown (https://www.phillymag.com/foobooz/2020/02/18/stephen-starr-fishtown-mexican-restaurant/).

All of this said above is to not so successfully summarize the reasons why El Vez often gets overlooked in today's Philly restaurant scene. I don't even think I would have come to rediscover over my past couple of visits if it weren't for spots like Charlie Was A Sinner and Sampan being so crowded when my crew set foot in them first. And really that's kind of a shame, because even though it's usually far from my first choice for bar/restaurant to hit up on the block, and its especially far from my first choice for Mexican/Spanish food in the city, the constant that it delivers does always hold up as a good one!

I've covered many times over how I tend to prefer the more traditional Spanish restaurants over the more trendier TexMex varieties. But even though El Vez does appear to stand at the top of the trendy pile when you walk in and look at it, it does also tend to dish out some pretty impressive food! Favorite of mine include:

"Bazooka" Limon Guacamole: I normally prefer my Guacamole to be the tried and true original flavor! But with goat cheese, chile flake, pistachios, and roasted tomatoes added in, this one really knows how to stand out for the better!

Queso Fundido de Hongos: Otherwise a fun and more appealing way of saying cheesy fungus. But with this one having truffled wild mushrooms and huitlacoche (a more fun way of saying corn fungus which is actually pretty good) inside a melted blend of cheese, its a very fun guy fungi!

Taco Arabes: Slow roasted lamb mixed with morita chiles, cucumber salsa, and lime yogurt for that refreshing win with just a tinge of spice.

Short Rib Enchiladas: Served perfect and simple with chocolate mole sauce!

With a tequila list like theirs you know that El Vez does some pretty impressive flights and margaritas. But I'm not that weird in finding their Knockout Margarita with vodka to be a stand out one. But ultimately my favorite cocktails are their refreshing Guava Mojito, and their boozy bit of spicy bourbon decadence in El Viejo!

While it may always be far from my first choice when I'm in the food centric neighborhood that is the Midtown Village Gayborhood, El Vez does always manage to have a few standout things that make me McThrilled when I do show up!

The roof deck at Continental Mid-Town is the place to be for happy hour. With a roof deck and great specials, it's really a no brainer that it is a great spot. 

Any time the weather is warm, expect to find a packed roof. The seating is first come, first served so keep that in mind when planning a visit. 

On my last visit the Friday before Memorial Day, the crowd was no exception. My husband and I were lucky enough to get an outdoor table and the rest was history.

We ordered a round of drinks and an appetizer each, and had a great time. I went with my Continental staple, the Astronaut, and the BBQ chicken quesadilla. The BBQ sauce was tangy and not overwhelming. It blended nicely with the melted cheese. The drizzle of sour cream and the side of salsa were a good touch. The salsa consisted of fresh chopped tomato and corn, and was very light and refreshing. The quesadillas were tasty and a great size for $6. The drink was fab as always.

The service was a well oiled machine.  Prompt and accurate. Due to the crowd, we didn't get a real one on one experience with our server but we weren't there to chat. 

When the weather is nice, I always look forward to my trips to Continental's roof deck.

Back again for a wonderful $11.50 Honey Fried Chicken Tossed Salad lunch with that exquisite buttermilk dressing.  LOVE it!

Service is always great - and the Fish of the Day was Trout served with a delicious roasted asparagus and quinoa salad.

Kudos to Wendy, Jackie and the wonderful team at Day by Day.
We love it!

Had our monthly dinner with friends, taking turns showing each other best or new places in Hillsborough and Pinellas by turns.   Yummy South was top of the line for Chinese.  The exterior is a bit odd with painting all over the building but interior is elegant with mostly black with wood and concrete accents and Asian wall art.  The classy bar is devoid of booze due to waiting for license ...so flower vases fill th. liquor bottle niches.  Nice arrangement of tables facing on Dale Mabry.   Professional service and prompt delivery.
The menu is dim sum for lunch and two diverse menus for dinner, one offering Cantonese specials.  Their apps are nice and we had the small egg rolls (unexceptional) and marvelous salt and pepper calamari...a signature dish.  Of course they could not offer beer or wine even.  For entrees with tried pork with veggies, tangerine shrimp, honey walnut chicken and unique fish cakes.  Strange for a Chinese restaurant, but you have to order rice separately.  All dishes were delicious, with the shrimp and chicken notably tasty....and filling the gap of not having any desserts. 
 We hope to go back when the offer drinks....and hopefully desserts to avoid losing sales.

Always excited to visit Erin Rose while visiting NOLA! It's a little bit of a dive bar and the service is what you'd expect. Order a drink and the bartenders will take care of you! Be nice to them and they will be nice to you. During this last visit, I had a beer spilled on me accidentally by another customer; let's just say, he wasn't looking and bumped into me! Needless to say, I needed a new shirt! The bartender was quick to recommend a t-shirt for me to change into and now I have a souvenir shirt with the Erin Rose logo! 

Be sure you order their famous frozen Irish coffee if you visit! It's a tasty treat at the end of a long day. Also, be sure you visit Killer Po-Boys located in the back. Oh, and if you are looking for the bathrooms, they are directly across from the bar against the wall. You will likely need to ask for people to move out of the way to enter though; it's a tight squeeze! 

Go here if you are looking for a low key bar right off of Bourbon Street. It can get crowded, but trust me, it's worth the visit!

What an incredible 79-acre oasis is the Missouri Botanical Garden -- in the City of St. Louis. And how wonderfully it has been preserved and brought to new heights.

There's nothing that compares to it. The history, the beauty and the investigations of plants  . . . all create an amazing amalgam of beauticify.

My girlfriend and I went on a Wednesday, when entry is free before noon. This was helpful, since my membership had lapsed.

It was late April, yet still cool and nippy. We walked around a lot, through the Climatron then went to wait to take The Tram that takes passengers through the entire Garden.

The Tram costs $4/person, and the historic narrative throughout is worth a million.

And the narrative is a real person, not a tape.

It was a great way to get around the grounds and hear why things are where they are. Just amazing.

I'm flabbergasted at the foresight of Henry Shaw and how he created this amazing place for all things growing.

Do you ever feel like having a nice, upscale Mexican dinner? There simply aren't many places in STL that offer that option. In fact, I can only think of one... Milagro! 

The place is a bit difficult to find if you don't know the area. It's at the back of a strip mall in old-town Webster... behind the San Sai. 

Milagro is one of the few places that will make their fish tacos with grilled fish instead of breaded fried fish. I always get them. They're so good. Ask for a side of creamy aioli sauce.... it's perfect for dipping. I also tried the lamb this time. I'm glad I tried it. The lamb was very tender, and the side of squash and corn were good too. However, I was looking for a dish that packed a bit more punch. Someone else at the table ordered the chicken mole dish and it looked really good with lots of mole sauce. I think I'll try that next time. 

Adam, the owner, was on hand and was kind enough to discuss the STL restaurant scene over after dinner drinks at the bar. It's clear by his restaurant and his passion that he's in the right business. It was also nice to hear an owner speak highly and recommend other restaurants in town. Right on Adam... we'll be back soon.

I'm not a good cook. I just buy things from Di Bruno Bros and somehow all of my meals turn out great.

The butcher is awesome. He gave great advice on how to prepare some steak tacos, made meat recommendations, and then cut up my steak into beautiful pieces, ready for a marinade. Long live Di Bruno Bros.

Mai Lee is pricier than most of the Vietnamese restaurants in town, but it is more upscale than most in terms of decor and food presentation.  They have a HUGE menu with many options, and I am rarely disappointed.  The food is slightly Americanized.  You will find a diverse crowd here, but it isn't exactly a hub for the Vietnamese community.

 I was a regular at the old location and I get to the new location from time to time.  Parking is a bit more inconvenient at the new location, since it is a parking structure and many of the spots are reserved.  It is conveniently located next to a Metrolink station near the Brentwood Promenade.

A MUST during a day trip to downtown Philly!  The Reading Terminal Market has a cornucopia of dining options from Italian to 50's style diner to mediterranean to Japanese to gourmet cheeses and candies.  My personal favorite is the falafel but I am not exactly sure of the name of the stand where I got it from.  The market has a couple small shops but I never had enough time to explore them.  If you're a Philly area resident like me and have out-of-town guests visiting from far away (try California, where I am from originally and have many relatives who still reside there), make it a point to bring them here!

I'm on team Trader Joe's. The pricing is extremely reasonable and they have products I really want to buy.

I'm lucky that this location is now a convenient stop for me. I'm even learning the times to visit...and the times to avoid it. If you don't want to wait in a line that wraps around the store, the after work rush isn't for you.

I wish they'd ban shopping carts in this store. There's not enough space to start and then you throw in dazed and confused shoppers into the mix. 

As much as I love TJ's, this particular location is like that friend you have to walk on eggshells when talking to. Timing and temperament is everything. 

With that said, the convenience, price and products will keep me coming back time and time again. This may just be the review of the future Duchess of this location.

Where can you find upscale designer shops, upscale department stores and a bustling nightlife?  International Mall, that's where. 

We love coming to this mall for Dillard's, Mac, Johnston and Murphy and the various restaurants. 

It's conveniently located near the airport, so if you have a long overlay, you can definitely burn time here and grab a good meal. 

To watch the games, Bar Louie is the best. For food, nothing compares to Capital Grille (go at lunch too for a fantastic deal) and for dessert you can hit up the Cheesecake Factory or the gelato shop.
Great service. Solid burgers. Good spot to grab a drink and have some comfort food. Would also recommend their calamari.

Oh, Zahav. What can I say about you that hasn't been said hundreds of times before? ...Likely nothing. This entrance-statement has probably even been said before.

I *can* yak about your wonderful Restaurant Week deal. I can tell everyone that I had one of the best meals of my entire life here. I can even reiterate the fact that when I got home last night, I didn't move an inch for a good hour.

Last night was like Yelp-night at Zahav, I tell you. There were several of us spread around the restaurant without actually planning it out that way. At our table, fellow Yelper Ashley S. and I were mind-blown by the amount of food given to us -- despite seeing the reviews ahead of time. This may have been the longest meal of my life, having clocked in at 2.5 hours.

First there was the salatim and hummus and laffa bread. I loved the beets especially. Then came the cauliflower, chicken that tasted like Christmas, grape leaves, and haloumi. After that, I had the ribeye -- medium rare, as they suggested. Chocolate mousse for dessert.

Oh, and also a Desert Rose (gin) cocktail. Always the gin.

Servers were super professional and ready to swoop in with fresh plates and silverware (and also boxes...) when we were done each course. The manager was also very friendly. He asked me where I purchased my change purse since it was clearly Turkish. When he said, "I hope to see you again," I awkwardly replied, "You too," instead of "Thank you," and I'm not even ashamed, because I must go back. They even gave a $10 off return coupon. 

So really. I will return. Who wants to go? I'm serious.

I still love me some parkway and when I'm not in the mood for fried, I still enjoy the caprese, but my last time...the love just wasn't there. 

The tomatoes were not ripe and were cut way too thick to be eaten in between french bread. Plus it felt like the whole joint needed a thorough scrubbing.

Next time I hope they show me the love.

Iron Hill redeemed themselves tonight with truly stellar service from Bob and Ashley who gave my 8 year old an impromptu brewery tour in the middle of a Sunday Night dinner service.

French onion soup was SPLENDID and not a bit too salty.  Wonderful and worth the close to $7.  Nacho platters are huge but one suggestion - cheese is needed throughout - not just on the top layer of chips (The end is naked chips)..  DD loved the pasta carbonara with shrimp added ($4 more) and had her sauce on the side so she could decide if she liked it or not.  She did.

A real winner tonight.

We'll be back again.

Awesome décor and tasty tacos.

I found this place super cute. I really liked the laid back yet trendy atmosphere of the place. We came at noon on a Tuesday and it was moderately busy, but not super full. There were three tables with babies (and therefore strollers) so this place is extremely family friendly. 

They say 3-5 tacos will make you full. I definitely agree with that assessment. The tacos are on the smaller side, but they are also on the cheaper side (less than $3.50 each) so it evens out. I rather have smaller tacos to I can try more!

I got a duck taco, a shrimp taco, and a cauliflower taco. Surprisingly, the cauliflower taco was my favorite. I have no idea what they put on there, but it is really flavorful. The shrimp taco was my second favorite. Mainly because I found the duck taco a little spicy for my taste. It was still good, but I'm terrible with spice. I got it on lettuce since I was avoiding carbs and the lettuce leaves were substantial and crunchy. It's a random thing to compliment a place on, but they choose good lettuce leaves!

Our server was really sweet. I felt like I was in good hands. She left us alone enough so we could chat, but checked in enough times to make sure we had everything we needed.

I enjoyed my lunch here. I'll definitely be back.

I am happy to say, Cassy the owner and executive chef at HWK has contacted me and was in shock that I had the experience that I did. She assured me that was not their policy and was going to use this situation as a teaching moment with her front of the house staff. 

I appreciated her outreach and will attempt to dine at HWK again. Once I do, hopefully you'll see another increase in stars.

I had not been back in over 2 years - so 2 ladies from my office and I had lunch here.  Good but not great.  It also took a long time (15 -20 minutes) for the lunch to come out (nobody ordered apps nor drinks and we were on a strich time frame).

My fried-green-tomato blt was great!  But the side of green beans with tomatoes was nearly inedible.  I chose green beans as a healthy alternative to fries, but they came swimming in oil and loaded with a salty spice blend.  NOT what I was expected.  Next time I'll order them steamed or plain.

Also they gave each of us a $2.50 up charge for subbing a different side for fries.  Not the end of the world, but it would have been nice to know that before we ordered - and not as an added "bonus" when the bill came.

Meanwhile, I'll be back but I won't rush back.
Years ago I loved it here - but over the years it seems less thrilling.

Review for the dessert room.

My sister is a huge dessert person and wanted to try the dessert room while she was in town.  Even though I've lived in the Tampa Bay area for four years, I have never gone before.  It seemed a little weird to me to go to a place just for dessert.  However, I was game since I had such an enthusiastic dining partner.

We went on a Thursday night at about 7:30 p.m.  Since it is first come first serve I was afraid the dessert room would be full, especially because the main dining area was packed with people waiting for their seat.  Luckily I didn't have to be worried, because the dessert "room" is huge!

The dessert area is a whole other section of Bern's.  It is upstairs, while dinner dining is downstairs.  Each table has its own little "room", which is essentially a table surrounded by roof touching rounded wood.  It is pretty private, but not what I would call a room.  It's less than a room, more than a booth.  You can choose your music for the room by pressing a button.  They have choices like Broadway, Jazz, etc., but why listen to other music when there is a live pianist playing.  We first chose pop and it seemed so out of place.

We decided to go with two different cheeses and the Taste of Bern's.  I would recommend the Taste of Bern's to everyone, because now when I go back I know exactly which dessert I want (the Macadamia cake, if you're wondering, but the banana cheese cake ranked high on my list too).  I love being able to try a variety of things.  The cheese plate was a great foil so we didn't feel like we were made out of sugar by the end.

There is no rush to the dessert room.  This really is a great place to spend a date night.  You have a large selection of alcohol and dessert, what else do you need for a date?

Lets hear it for the new summer time event, Sunset Celebration! Tampa's Lowry Park is an excellent  example of family friendly entertainment for ALL ages!

With the Sunset Celebration, You get excellent entertainment for your money! There are stilt walkers, tumble monkeys and hula-hoopers. There is live music and amazing magic, and that's not even including the delicious food to be had!

This happens Friday & Saturdays now thru August 8th.  Admission is free with your membership or $20.00 after 4pm

I'm going to mention the good, and the bad.  Then, I'm going to explain how the bad turned good making this experience roller-coaster from a 5 star, to a 2 star and back to a 5 star again.  =)

We arrive at 10PM and they've switched to their late night menu, which isn't a big deal because the item I want is on there; the STINKY BUNS.  You guys all remember the Stinky Buns food truck, right?  Well these are the same people.  The chica was eyeballing the COCONUT CURRY CHICKEN WINGS, so we order these items along with a MOJITO and a glass of red.  The hostess is super friendly and brought the drinks expeditiously from the bar; lightning fast considering there is a party of 19 in the corner and about 10 at the bar.  The stinky buns arrived about 10 minutes later, and they were toothsome indeed.  We had the beer battered shrimp bun and the pork belly with kimchi bun.  This is where the bad began though.  The server didn't notice that my drink was empty.  We waited around for another 10-15 minutes and she never bounced back over.  In fact, she was was chillin' in the corner eating with what I presumed was a friend.  The hostess, who I found out later was the owner, was loungin' at the bar having a drink with some guy.  No one to be found, my drink is empty for roughly 20 minutes and our chicken wings flew the coup.  At this point, I'm thinking 2 star at the most for the neglect. Then, like an angel from the skies of food heaven, a young lady named Erica stopped by and asked if everything was OK.  We explained everything, and she apologized 100 times over.  She brought us two more drinks, on the house, and corralled us some wings in less than 5 minutes.  The damn wings!  THE DAMN WINGS!  Fellow Yelpers, heed my word, order the damn wings.  Sweet and subtly spicy on the back end, and served with a soothing Greek cucumber yogurt dipping sauce.  THE DAMN WINGS!

We were impressed at the speed in which Erica moved things along.  We told her that she saved the day and that we would be back for the TRUFFLED TATER TOTS (because they're not on the late menu), and she would have non of that.  Eager to make up for the hiccups, she insisted on getting us some tots.  By this time, we were more curious than hungry, so we obliged.  They were 'tot-notch' too.  Easily the best tots I'd ever had.  Owners of Anise, please pay this woman double what she's currently making!  Needless to say, we have a new friend!

No, despite sharing the name Wright, I have no ownership stake in this buisness.

Yes, I wish I did.

Wright's Gourmet does our name proud and just never fails to impress me.

While I do not go in as often as I probably should (maybe all those delicious cakes and cupcakes as you walk to the cash register are just too intimidating), I visited again this afternoon and received exactly what I have come to expect: Excellence.

Employees are all dressed in white coats and offer terrific customer service. 

Sure, this place gets very busy at lunchtime, but employees do everything they can to keep things moving, while never sacrificing the quality that is expected on every food item.

I've had many delicious sandwiches here, but my favorite things to grab and take home are the cold items on the far left that are an absolute bargain when buying by the cup. Turkey pecan salad, three different potato salads, multiple pasta salads, cole slaw and, when I'm lucky, gazpacho.

Honestly, I'm not sure why Wright's Gourmet House is not mentioned more often with that steakhouse in South Tampa (you know the one) and that adult night club on Dale Mabry (yes, you've heard of that too) as the biggest names in Tampa to our out of town visitors.

Oh, I know why, because Wright's is actually better at what they do than those other two places and they just want us locals to know that.

I think we are lucky to have a local, fun, unique and tasty restaurant like this in the Tampa Bay area. Seriously, my only complaint is that there are too many good things on the menu. The yelp description, laughably, says "Soul Food, Vegan, Asian Fusion"

The real description is a "wide variety of creative, unique and awesome comfort food"! The Bacon Flight Appetizer! The Mac and Cheese! Duck Sliders! Truffle Fries! The Burger and other Unique Sandwiches! The Tasty Salads! It's all good!

My only heads up is the parking situation. Truly, there is plenty of parking down the side street to the right of the restaurant. Is it that hard to walk 50' to enjoy Datz? Not for me!

I went to Luke last month for lunch and really enjoyed my meal.  Even better my boss was picking up the bill; not that Luke is super expensive though.  I thought my blood orange hollandaise sauce (on shrimp farsi) was good enough to drink.  And I enjoyed a specialty cocktail but I can't remember the name, but it was light and perfect (and I was with my boss who doesn't drink, scandal!)  She had the crabmeat omelet and couldn't stop raving.  My only problem with the restaurant was that it was so loud.  It was difficult to have a conversation across a table and I'm generally considered...a high volume person.  Definitely looking forward to going back.

Top notch restaurant serving quality seafood. 

You must order the calamari appetizer-it's like no other. 

The bubbly berry martini is NOT overly sweet and quite the conversation piece.

Why 2 stars?  There's not a lot of excitement.

   ---   ---   ---

I'd always wanted to visit the Aquarium, and I was finally able to make the trip recently.  I don't think I was missing much.

Unfortunately, there was virtually nothing memorable from my experience.  I suppose the best part was the Ray-Petting tank.  But there's one of those at Lowry Park Zoo and at the Trop, so I don't really know what the advantage of going to the Aquarium is.

I believe there are renovation plans in the works, but they are not scheduled to be completed until 2016.  I'll check it out again then!

Hmm wonder if it's dinner that gets super pricey because brunch is very affordable at $13-$16 a plate. Lunch is pretty reasonable too. You're for sure paying for the service and views of the park. The brunch is nothing really out of the ordinary. It's your standard assortments of traditional American breakfast food with a little bit of French. Their breads are pretty solid and taste freshly baked. Service is very attentive and friendly. Coming here in the Spring and summertime is pretty awesome because they open up their large French windows. This restaurant is very large and sports views of Rittenhouse Park.

If you're looking for something quieter to grab a cup of coffee and something to eat, I highly recommend Metropolitan Bakery or Marathon on 19th and Spruce. Can also try Honey's on South street.

I would give it a 4 1/2 if that was possible.  The only thing keeping it from 5 stars is the strength of the tea I had, but I will get to that.

My boyfriend and I went for Saturday brunch with 4 other couples.  For a table that large, the service was efficient and speedy.  Our waiter informed us that although they would take things out of dishes, they recommended making as few changes as possible to the dishes, because Saturday was their busiest time.  Actually, they said Thursday, Friday, and Saturday they do not make many changes to the dishes.  I appreciated this, because it meant that the food would come out in a timely manner, since they were not catering to picky eaters.

I ordered the smoked salmon on an everything bagel (with fennel salad on top as well).  I could have gone with a tad less fennel salad.  It had a strong pickled flavor to it and a little goes a long way.  However, on a whole, it was absolutely delicious.  For $8.50 I felt completely satisfied.  My boyfriend got pancakes without the fruit topping and a side of bacon.  He loved it.  He talked about how much he enjoyed the pancakes the entire ride home.

As for the tea, I got the iced pomegranate blueberry green tea with honey.  It lacked flavor to me.  The tea was not very strong or very sweet.  I could have added sugar or sweetener that was at the table, but I thought the honey as a sweetener would have been enough.  The tea came first and I was initially disappointed with it.  However, after eating my meal, I enjoyed the tea more.  I think it had to do with the juxtaposition of flavors between my food and the drink.  Still, I would not buy that tea again. There was a lot more of it than I was expecting.  It came in a rather large glass.  However, I would have appreciated more flavor even if it was less tea.

I don't want to give up on the tea, because I keep reading reviews about how spectacular it is.  I may have to go back to try another flavor.

I appreciate that they have parking, which they share with the First Church of Christ, Scientist.  I hate parking downtown and this makes it so much more convenient to visit.

Upstairs, they have a commerce club.  It is worth checking out the space, because it is pretty magnificent.  It actually reminded me slightly of the Reading Room at the University of Michigan (my Alma mater), so I felt nostalgic up there.  Apparently for a fee a month you can pay to use that space if you have a job that you can work from anywhere.  Also, as a member of the commerce club you can rent the conference rooms they have up there.

Another tidbit, apparently they will rent out space to do weddings.  They are closed on Sundays and after five on weekdays so there is plenty of time for a wedding to happen.  

I definitely think this is a place you have to visit at least once if you're in Tampa.  It is almost an homage to older times where things were made to be beautiful and last instead of convenient and cheap.

Went there again!!!!  This time alone - no kid, no DH and ordered the $42 Omakase sushi/sashimi platter and nothing else (and I was stuffed to the gills - pun intended).

I poissoned myself with fresh lucious fish - hamachi, sea bass, salmon, tuna, 1 piece of buttery toro, a single sweet shrimp.  A small piece akimono (fish liver - the foie gras of sushi), a gently torched single scallop and some poppin' fresh ikura completed the mix.

A house-made piece of perfectly balanced tamago was my dessert.

And a roll - topped with chopped hamachi. (This roll changes based on your preference and the chef's choice.  TELL them what you like and don't like).  The chef here ROCKS.

Mmmmmmmmn.

Omakase heaven.

Mine, mine, mine, all mine.
Wish I had brought a split of Cava.

No kid!!!!

Bliss.

love this place but i always seem to order the wrong thing!

you can never go wrong with the lo mein here, best lo mein but i got it with the "spice" for the first time yesterday and i wish i didn't. it made the noodles kind of soggy and too salty.

the hot pot fish is my favorite, it's the perfect amount of flavor and the fish is cooked so well.

i tired to cumin beef for the first time yesterday and it was so salty and wayyy to much cumin, not a fan at all. 

i'm still finding my way through their dishes trying to find the perfect ones!
Great place with good food and service.  My husband and I come here all the time.   Love the crispy duck salad special, woo sen, pad Thai, and the basil fried rice.  Have not had a bad meal yet.

When: February 15
Why:    Lunch 

We can't wait to go back so we can give them their fifth star. The ambiance, chips & salsa, Margaritas, and the food were all excellent. 
However, the customer service was totally lacking.  I can only assume that the Valentine diners the night before exhausted the staff and the wind was totally taken out of their sails. Our service was basically; "what do you want" and "here it is". I know they can do better. 

This was kinda our VD celebration, Brad had to work cooking for all the romantic couples at his place of employment. So it is always fun to go out and have others do all the preparing. 

We started out with Blood Orange and Milagro Margaritas. The Blood Orange will be my Margarita of choice when dining at Milagro, it goes down so smooth. I'll just have to watch my quantities.  

The chips and salsa were a great lead in to a fantastic lunch. As many Yelpers have stated in many Mexican reviews, you can judge how the food will be by the salsa & chips and here they are top notch. 

We begun our feast with Tuna Ceviche and Traditional Quesadillas. Both were excellent, I loved the Tuna and raw fish is not my thing. It totally won me over. The Quesadillas filled with Mexican truffles, wild mushrooms and Chihuahua cheese, oozed with flavor.

We then experienced the Beef Enchiladas Rojas and Street Tacos. 
On the Street Tacos we tried the Barbacoa Beef and Cochinita Pibil. Both were good, but the Cochinita Pibil (pulled pork) would take the gold medal. It's flavors were more pleasing to the palate. 

The finale was the Tres Leches Cupcake, which I will never share again. It was so good and it's sauce was one of my favorite fruits Raspberries. Who knew a traditional yellow cake could be so good. 

I/we will be back soon, I 'm a fan.

ALDI is the parent company of Trader Joe's, and just like ALDI this store carries a variety of generic store brands at prices lower than Sweetbay and Publix.  Well, Sweetbay is no longer and Winn-Dixie has taken over, but you know what I mean.

As for differences between ALDI and TJ's, what one will find at TJ's are slightly more organic and natural options, as well as a larger beer and wine selection.  Personally, I've always loved the Trader Joe's peanut butters.  Every time I visit St. Louis, stopping at TJ's is a must to grab some of this stuff to bring back home.  It's nice to be able to get it in Tampa now. 

As for prices, they're very comparable to ALDI when buying most items.  Again, the only time you will get a little more expensive is when reaching for a natural/organic item on the shelf.  But even then, you'll pay less at TJ's than a common grocery store.

The parking is a little nightmarish, and will probably continue to be so until the hype subsides.  I mean, after all, it's just a damn grocery store, so I don't expect that traffic will be backed up around the corner for much longer.  One useful tidbit of intel that we got while shopping there is that the best time to go is 8 in the morning when they first open.  Apparently, there is hardly anyone around at that time.

The store was found to be a little smaller than the one I've been to in St. Louis, but was well-organized and staffed with friendly folks.  In addition, the prices were right for more items.  So I do plan on returning to get some specialty items, but ALDI will continue to be my primary hunting and gathering spot.  The food manufacturers are the same, and the prices aren't much different.

Not happy they no longer do OpenTable. I guess they use SeatNinja which I've never heard of and know nothing about. So I made reservations on their web page. 

Walked in and up to the host stand where we were ignored by the hotess on her cell phone. I was going to stand and see how long it took for her to look up, but my impatient husband had to make the clear your throat sound. She then looked up and sat us.

Our table had not one, not two, but three dirty water glasses on it. I heard the hostess say "That doesn't surprise me". If I were a host I would have been mortified and immediately would have let the MOD know. 

Food was good. Typical order of Chicken Parm and Four Cheese Ravioli. No complaints on the food and our server did an adiquet job. 

Email discount and gift card used and food for dinner tomorrow is in our fridge.

Met my girls here for a Pre-Christmas get together tea party. I'd never been to the OE, so I set my GPS and let it take me to the location right in the heart of Tampa.  

From the outside, the building is pretty Non-descript.  It's an older edifice in the middle of a split street across from University of Tampa. There's free parking down side streets or you can pay to park at the church. I found a free spot and made my way inside.  I had no idea I could enter off of the back street, so I walked all the way around to the front on Kennedy, which was fun, as I was dressed to the nines. 

Inside, I was STUNNED. This place is huge. There's a gift shop, a book store, a Buddy Brew coffee and a champagne bar. WOW!  We waited a bit for our reservation and then were seated around the fountain in the atrium.  Lovely, really, but loud.  Especially when one party of young women decided that we all needed to hear what they were excited about. Seriously everyone in the eatery turned to look at them. 

The tea menu and spirits menu was nicely appointed. I chose the silver leaf jasmine tea, and the regular tea service, as did my friends, though their tea choices were different.  Our waiter was polite and kind and when he brought the food, it was delightful. There were finger sandwiches of Peanut butter and jelly, Curry chicken salad, turkey . Scones with Clotted cream and jam and an assortment of pastries that were decadently delicious. 

Our experience was excellent and we'd come back any time!

This is a bustling SoTa taco and primo beverage spot. Definitely not a hole in the wall. I like the fried oyster taco. Everything was good. The guac was full of avocado. Trendy scene. Fun to try but I'm a hole in the wall kid so you'll see me at Loli's, Acapulco Grocery, and other indies. But they def have the party going here. The ceviche didn't do much for me. But the seasoned corn on the cob was tasty. Viva!

This local Tampa (Ybor) favorite never fails to deliver! We've been popping by for decades! Their happy hour is definitely legendary and the food is always amazing. Also, we've always had excellent service here in an impressive atmosphere. 

Personally, I like their martinis the best but you go with what you enjoy!

Life is good at Bernini's! Don't miss it!

I'm so happy that I found this place!  The food really is authentic Vietnamese! It's so delicious!  It's very inexpensive and the hours are great!  They're open 7 days a week until 10pm!  And their menu is huge!  It's located in what I like to refer to as Vietnamese town :) so many gems!

I've eaten here too many times. Today was underwhelming but it's usually better. It looks and feels like Paris. Sit outside with your pup. Check out the fabulous Rittenhouse Square crowd. Eat great bread and pretty good French food. Escargot is a must. Lots of celebrities, local and afar. See and be seen!

Yikes. This airport is stuffy and seemed to be under construction all over! Hopefully they are remodeling because it needs it. 

I went to the bathroom and one of the toilets was broken and had leaked a huge puddle of toilet water in the narrow passage way to the other toilets. There was barely enough room for a suitcase to roll by without getting wet. Gross.

The restaurant selections were limited in the terminal and the customer service I got at a coffee shop was not friendly. It was a meh experience all around.

Goody Goody was quite tasty - definitely a fun splurge meal. We had been eyeing up the NoWait app and it said there was no wait, but we weren't ready to go in yet. A few minutes later it went from no wait to over an hour wait! So we immediately put in our name and it said to arrive around 7:37. About 10 minutes later at 7 on the dot I got a text that our table was ready..which was great, except we hadn't even left yet. Fortunately, when I called they said they'd try to seat us when we got there, so they were accommodating. We were seated at an outdoor table (our preference) immediately when we arrived. Everyone was very friendly, and our server Andres was excellent. The staff there work very hard! I had the pox cheeseburger with fries and hubs had a hotdog with onion rings. We shared a chocolate shake. I really enjoyed the burger and fries - I was not a fan of the onion rings (they lacked flavor, in my opinion). The shake was delicious. Hubs enjoyed his hotdog but it wouldn't fit on the bun so it was an absolute disaster..so messy. The whole meal was under $30 with tip, which is amazing. Overall, it's a good little spot and I'm hopeful once they expand you'll be able to pop in for a bite without a super long wait.

My most recent visit here was much improved..but still with issues.

We had a reservation for four for a business dinner. Unfortunately the hostess could not find it. She offered us a high top table in the loud and crowded lounge...seats at the small bar by the dining room or seats at the outside lounge. When told this was unacceptable she begrudgingly got the manager who somehow found our reservation and we were led to our nice table by the window.

Our server took a bit to come over but was very cordial and professional. We ordered cocktails which too an extraordinary amount of time to get. In fact we got our bread basket...waited...and ordered appetizers before they came.

I ordered a half dozen blue point oysters which were nicely shucked.. served cold with all three accoutrements.

For dinner I got the twin lobster tails...broiled instead of steamed served with asparagus.
It was very very good!

For dessert we split a chocolate piece of yumminess.

Our server was in fact very good...very professional...the bartender made a perfect martini that was actually filled to the rim.

It's a good place to splirge but they always seem to have some kinks

Why 3 stars? Because I just didn't get the hype.

   ---   ---   ---

I have to say, this was one of the most skewed Yelp experiences I've ever had. When a business has hundreds of reviews and a 4.5 star average, it's generally going to be pretty solid at worst. Sadly, I think my 3-star rating is a bit generous based on my experience.

First off, the inside of the restaurant was possibly the hottest room I've ever been in. The five minutes we were inside ordering was about all I could handle. With that being said, had the cheesesteak been delicious, I would have considered the sauna treatment well worth it.

But then we got our food, and it was about as bland as it could possibly be. It tasted like stadium or bowling alley food. It was as no frills as it comes: a hoagie + basic-tasting meat + some light cheese. What's all the fuss about?

I hate to be harsh in my reviews, and I know that comparing something to ballpark food is probably a pretty big insult, but that's honestly what it tasted like. Had I been blindfolded, I would never have known the difference.

I wanted to skip the touristy places like Geno's and Pat's on my hunt for the best cheesesteak in Philly, but John's was not it, in my opinion.

Why 5 stars? Because lunch is just as awesome as dinner.

   ---   ---   ---

I have been to Ulele three times now - once for dinner and twice for lunch. All 3 times were really great experiences, but I think I liked lunch even better just because of the surrounding views in the daylight.

I will say this - there is no better place in Tampa to have to wait for a table than Ulele. You just take a stroll down to Waterworks Park and sit on a bench overlooking the Hillsborough River. Ulele texts you when your table is ready, which is so much more convenient than having to worry about a buzzer that might not be in range 100 yards or so away at the park.

I also happened to visit Ulele twice for lunch during a streak of about 3 consecutive weeks of perfect weather. Sunshine with temperatures in the 70's and a nice breeze. Ahhhhh... I love living here. 

But there's just no nicer place to sit either outside, or inside with the "barn doors" open than Ulele. I am in love with the look of the place, and everything that they did on the grounds and with the park. It's just perfection.

But in terms of the food - I ordered the lobster roll and the Ulele burger. Both are really great choices, and I would recommend letting your hunger level dictate your choice between the two. The lobster roll is not a ton of food, so don't order that if you're starving. The burger is absolutely delicious, as are the fries. 

As much as the burger is more filling than the lobster roll, it's not the kind of burger and fries that make you want to roll over into a coma afterward. I'm no food scientist, so I don't know exactly what it is in a burger and fries that make you feel like your energy is zapped afterward, but all I can tell you is that it didn't happen here. 

So to summarize - Everything looks great. Everything tastes great. And afterward, you feel great.

Ulele = *insert thumbs up emoji here*

Last night, I dreamt I went to a crazy, no-holds-barred, Jersey shore-themed party... only it took place in one of Philly's classiest, most heralded restaurants, Zahav. The large, bright space was cleared of its tables, and all of the staff members were transported from a late 80s Def Leppard concert, with big hair and stonewashed denim as far as the eye could see. When I glanced into the open kitchen area, I almost pinched myself (but didn't because then I would have had to wake up). There stood some of Philadelphia's most notorious chefs, elbow to elbow, preparing delicious renditions of Jersey shore staples such as juicy hamburgers, spicy pizza turnovers, garlicky fried clams and savory crab boils. To wash it all down? Miller Lite and Miller High Life pounders, sold straight out of a wheeled ice bucket, natch. The pièce de résistance? A Journey cover band that also dedicated plenty of play time to Jersey boys Jon Bon Jovi and Bruuuuuuce. 

This morning, after turning off the alarm and sleepily sitting up in bed, I noticed the blue stamp on my hand. The epic party from my dreams was real!!!

One word: Gazpacho. 

Finally. It is back. And hopefully they'll keep it around next month too.

Best $4.50 I've spent this month.

And for those of you who rip it as simply "cold soup," you just don't understand.

Reporting live from Han Dynasty on a pretty kick ass computer that sits bar side. I didn't originally intend to be here, or even really write a review update tonight. But when you run into Han randomly on the corner and he's incredible enough to remember you and invite you down for a beer its kind of how things set in motion!

Besides I did need to revisit and do a recap of the epic ARSE 2 event that I hosted here a few weeks back. From the get go of setting things up with Han it looked like it was destined to be a tasting event of epic proportions, and it showed how much he and his crew really work with a group to meet your expectations. As for the food if your looking for fried dumplings and General Tso's hogwash, this isn't the restaurant for you. But if you're looking for a unique and spicy kick in your cuisine then get ready to climb down the rabbit hole! Also don't come if you're expecting a normal humbug restaraunteur.  Han is a crazy in the good way kind of guy who has fun with his patrons, and saves the seriousness for the spice of the epic dishes.

For our tasting we were treated omakase style to somewhere around 23 dishes (mental note get the entree list from Sam's Facebook and add it!). Among them we were wowed by dan dan noodles, green bean noodles, spicy cucumbers, amazing sausages, spicy rabbit, strange taste chicken, pork belly, pork tenderloin, soft shell crabs, and then some! hungry already? the taste of spicy peppers and chili oil made the fabled and legendary name of full name of our tasting event really realistic the next day. But such is the thing to expect when you really step it up to try some real cultural cuisine of greatness. And for that Han Dynasty always manages to be a spicy and entertaining good time!

Wow, what a great place. We went on an off day and off time which meant it was not super busy. Walked through all the restaurants and shops and chose what we wanted. Huge open concept of an old school TECO storage building. Clean and well managed. Staff keep tables cleared and clean after people leave. Lots of food and bar choices. Loved our time here. Fantastic.

Oh hey guys, check it out, another five star review of Zahav! I don't think I can say anything that hasn't been said, but I'm still going to, because it was that amazing.
So first, let's talk about those starters. They are so plentiful, and delicious they could be a meal in themselves. There are about 6-7 little salads that are brought out to commence the feast, and each one is more delicious than the last. I especially loved the fennel salad and the carrots. Then, the bread and hummus happened. I have no words for that hummus. Simply phenomenal.  The hummus is served hot and has a smoky garlicy flavor that is just perfection. And that bread though. It is the perfect vehicle for sopping up all the delicious sauces of the numerous dishes to come in your culinary journey. 
I'm pretty sure we tried everything in this menu so I shall just extoll the virtues of some of my favorites.  The chicken pastilla is one of my favorite things I've ever tasted, ever. The sauce the little phyllo pastry was in was so exotic and flavorful, and the almonds set it off perfectly. This is a must. The haloumi was essentially a delicious hunk of exotic cheese that was toasted and served with various accoutrements. This was also perfection. Now my boyfriend's favorite was the duck hearts which he said were delicious. I have no doubt that they were, however having to gnaw my way through a pericardial sac like some sort of hyena turned me off a bit. 
For the main courses methinks the branzino was my favorite. The skin was perfectly crispy and the sauce had a wonderful dill flavor that was just right. We also tried the kofte and cremini mushrooms which did not disappoint either. 
I was stuffed to the gills but still had to sample some of these fabulous desserts. We sampled three things, the names of which escape me now. But they were all wonderful, the pear crumble type dessert being my favorite. Everything I tasted here was simply amazing and I can't wait to get back.

I have lost track of how many times I've visited Devil's Alley.

A friend suggested the restaurant during a day trip to the city in 2011, and it subsequently became my go-to place.

Never once have I had a bad meal here, the servers have always been accommodating and I never feel rushed. It's in a great location.

Make sure to try their whisky sour, too. And visit the basement bathrooms.

In all: not a bad word in this review.

I've visited Penang on multiple occasions.  Just to clarify the 3-star rating, on none of these trips was I truly dissatisfied.  However, not one could have me locked in as "a fan", and each left me with something to gripe about.  The Roti Canai is good.  I really enjoy the Nasi Lemak as you can really taste thte coconut in the rice.  The Coconut Nasi Goreng is good for the same reason.

As for the gripes: The servers have mixed up my order on at least one of my trips and weren't too happy as they tried to make it out to be my fault.  Another trip for dinner and the decided that orange slices would only be provided for those dining after a certain time, even though we could clearly see others had been given them.  Finally, another time the service was just ridiculously slow especially factoring in the amount of people in the restaurant.  Again, nothing individually to stop me from going back, but nothing there pulling me that way.  Given the options in Chinatown, it may be a while before I head back to Penang.

Goody Goody was no biggie biggie! I wanted to check this out because I had met an older couple who raved about the back in the day Goody Goody, and how the new one is excellent, and just as they remembered it! Thought maybe it was a nostalgic thing for them, and that's cool I can relate with other places like that. 

So I have decided to first mention the best part. If you decide to read the rest of the not so good stuff, that's up to u.

Come here strictly for the pie. Yes, the pie! They have banana cream, butterscotch, cookies and cream, chocolate cream, and coconut cream pie. 

Coconut cream pie was oh so perfect! It was just the amount of sweetness and I think there was flambé marshmallow fluff on top, I don't know. Nonetheless, the sole next purpose I'll be back when I'm back is for their pie!

__________________________________________________

We came and our first impression was that the hostess stand was very welcoming. There were three of them that we encountered. The odd thing was that I initially wanted either inside or outside, but afterwards I told them outside because it was colder inside than outside. If I wanted outside, I should have gotten it, but that didn't happen. I might have liked this experience a little better. Inside, besides the temperature, it is extremely loud. It was to the point I couldn't talk or think. There are speakers everywhere. 

The service was forever, like forever. It took a short bit of time to get seated with the No Wait app. Service after getting seated is AWFUL! Food, where do u come from, Egypt or the Orient?

The restaurant should be renamed No Biggie Biggie! I tried the cheeseburger POX. It was bland. Is there a such term as less than basic? It was that. Flimsy bread, tiny burger patty, cheese u could barely see. The POX sauce is like sloppy joe sauce from a bulk item bought at Sam's Club or Costco! The fries were unbearably salty and even tasted that way when you dip it in that POX sauce or ketchup. I had chili which lacked much flavor. Even the bottle of hot sauce I used didn't do much for it. They also need some type of crackers to go with the chili. 

In anyway possible this review needed to get better. See told ya u might have just been happy reading the top part of the review ;-)!

I stopped in here for take out after having eaten a competitor's sandwich yesterday.  The sandwich here is also very good but I prefer yesterday's pork sandwich.   John's sandwich is a bit larger and the pork is very tender.   The sharp provolone here did not seem to stand up to the pork as yesterday but there was plenty of it.   No broccoli rabe here - spinach instead.   Want peppers?  A small one ounce container is $1.   

Service is very fast here especially if you want a roast pork or hot roast beef sandwich.   There is no place to eat in but under the concrete awning they have tables and an outdoor heater assisted by heavy plastic awning enclosures.  There are also tables in the open air.

At lunch time, the place was mobbed.

I agree with Mitch, most malls make you feel like you're going to be mugged by a bunch of hoodlums on the way to your car. Tampa/St PEte doesn't have much to offer in way of nice malls but I like this one. Lots of upscale shopping and with Bay Street, lots of places to cocktail and/or eat inbetween shopping decisions. My hubby doesn't even mind being drug to this mall!

Came here for my daughter birthday. Made a reservation via open table and table was ready slightly after a 5 minute wait after we arrived. Masks required to enter and walk about the restaurant. The food bar area is open so you can fix your own plate at this time however have to sanitize your hands with the sanitizer provided upon going up to the bar area. Plenty of meat options come around and we were stuffed beyond our limits. Service was ok. Our waiter disappeared a few times after we requested drink refills so those took some time.  They did provide a dessert of my daughter's choice to her for her birthday which I thought was so nice. Overall good experience.

Private event review alert.

So you know when you are at an event and are in mid conversation and really want to try the food, but can't get away? No problem because the servers of Parc have you covered. I've never seen passed hors d'oeuvre service at such an A game. The selection was diverse and the service was both frequent and non-intrusive. 

I could have had the mini lobster Mac n cheese all night long. The tuna tar tar on a chip was also tasty. I also really liked the shrimp with avocado and tomato in a ranch-like dipping sauce. There was a table set up up with meats and cheeses, but I found it easiest to enjoy the passed hors d'oeuvres without breaking from my conversations. 

My group had an open bar and I received a recommendation from within the group to try the Sancerre since I'm a fan of Sauvignon Blanc. The recommendation was spot on and I was able to enjoy several glasses throughout the evening. The drink service was not as quick to make the rounds as the food service however they were still on top of everything. 

My group had a section of the restaurant that normally has tables. The area was cleared for us but still a little tight. The restaurant was festively decorated for the holidays. 

Parc did a good job and I would recommend checking them out for a small to mid-size event.

Classic French in Philadelphia.  I can almost imagine myself being in a little cafe somewhere in France when Parc has the windows open and the breeze blows through just right on a mild spring day.  Parc certainly has the atmosphere part down to a 'T'.

As for the food, highly respectable, although not the best I've ever had.  It is worth highlighting how all the dinner options are well portioned. They fill you up, but don't leave you feeling stuffed.  Well, at least according to me and my co-workers.

The wait staff are attentive, ensuring your water glass doesn't reach the bottom and offering suggestions if prompted.  They didn't do anything that put them over the top in my book, but they didn't do anything to screw up the meal either... and sometimes that is just as important!

Wow, the other reviews weren't kidding when they said this place was small. The sushi bar probably seats like 8-10 people max. I got a seating for two on a Friday night within 5-10 minutes. It's just really claustrophobic. They have a sweet $10 for 3 8 piece rolls deal. In addition, their sashimi is pretty decent quality. The service is really prompt and on-point, just not the most friendly. Will return in the future for the sushi fix.

Base on the affordable price, great food, and good service, this is considering 5 stars restaurant. 

We have yelp group enjoy our time and food here. Since we have 7 in the group, we have ordered the Family Dinner. It is a whole chicken with salad, fried yuca, and cilantro rice. The salad is fresh with vinaigrette dressing. I like the cilantro rice with spice in rice. The chicken is marinated and slowly roasted with the skin is crispy outside. We have added the tostones - the flatten fried green plantain for other member to experience the food. 

We also ordered the Cuenellis Special - Palomilla Steak with fried egg. The steak is well season and tasty, however, the steak may need to be tenderizing for better chewing. The dish also come with fried yuca, 1/4 chicken and fried sweet plantain. A lot food for affordable meal.

After a disaster at a neighboring restaurant, I looked up my yelp bookmarks and decided upon Saigon Deli. 

Located behind Zaxby's and next to a Filipino shop, you'll find this restaurant. Still busy at 4pm, I found a seat and ordered a bowl of pho. Within minutes the pipping hot dish arrived. The flavor of the broth was incredible. Definitely a best in Tampa. 

Service was quick and attentive and I would definitely come back when I was craving some hot soup.

The food and atmosphere at Datz is absolutely amazing!

Warning: the portions are HUGE!!! I can easily split a sandwich with my husband and still be stuffed, but I usually order my own sandwich because I prefer to not share my chips. The chips that accompany each sandwich are homemade sweet and salty kettle cooked chips with blue cheese drizzle and scallions. I haven't ordered a sandwich at Datz that I haven't liked yet. The Havana Hottie (Cuban), April in Paris, Dumb Cluck and The Iron Mike Tate Club are a few of my favorites.
