Datz has a great selection of craft beers on tap. On our first visit we ordered a Paulaner Premium Pilsner and a Magner's Cider after the bartender let us sample a few of the beers on tap. After your meal check out the deli for gourmet cheese or olives or grab one of the amazing baked desserts at the bakery. They also have gelato: my favorite!

I haven't tried the dinner menu yet, but I've had the pleasure of eating breakfast and brunch at Datz on many occassions. Everything from the eggs to the breakfast sandwiches are amazing on the breakfast menu. The French Toast is out of this world!!! If you love mac & cheese as much as I do then you must try the Mac n' Cheese Bites, made with crispy bacon jalapeño macaroni and cheese!

Nice atmosphere, very trendy and hip. Live bands play multiple nights of the week. Check out the classes at Datz; they host weekly cooking and food tasting classes.

On Swann is one of the most-spectacular new restaurants in all of Tampa, and a great addition to the foodie scene in Hyde Park Village. You'll find On Swann located at the corner of W. Swann Avenue and South Oregon Avenue, a little over a block away from Cinebistro and the Hyde Park Village parking garage.

Executive Chef / Co-Owner Chris Ponte and his circle of culinary friends have created a unique contemporary American bistro where you can feel free to sample small plates of food with craft cocktails, local brews, and wines by the glass or bottle. Or if you prefer, you can order a full meal from their selection of chops, roasts, and seafood.

My very adorable Yelp friend, Anna M. and I decided to enjoy dinner at On Swann now that the restaurant has been open for a few months, as that gave them the chance to work out any kinks in their system. Anna had already snagged a table for us, and was on a first name basis with Travis, our server for the evening. She had ordered a 1796 cocktail, and so I selected a barrel-aged Walnut-Maple Old Fashioned, made with Four Roses bourbon, Bitter Truth orange, and topped with an orange peel and a bourbon-rested Amarena cherry. YUM!!!

We looked over the menu, and picked out a couple of items to share, and then turned to Travis for help with our selections. We started with a great cheese board with four of the chef's selections of soft, semi-soft, and hard cheeses. That cheese board also contained fruits, nuts, breads, and other accoutrements.

Next we ordered a couple of small plate starters to share, including a tall basket of delicious pomme frites which were tossed with rosemary and sea salt, and topped with a harissa aioli. We decided that this was the grown-up version of French fries on crack, and we did our best to finish the basket. Next came a small cast-iron skillet of lamb meatballs which were served in a tomato-date sauce, over Anson mill grits with minted ricotta, and garlic.

Anna and I were busy taking pictures to document our delicious meal, and that caught the eye of Executive Chef and Co-Owner, Chris Ponte. Chris came by our table, introduced himself, and checked to be sure that everything was ok. We laughed and told him that we were foodies, and really enjoying our delicious meal. He very graciously stood there and talked to us for about ten minutes, telling us about the concept of the restaurant, and giving us some behind-the-scenes information about the menu and the training that the servers receive. Before the servers work the floor they must know the details of over 175 items on the menu, and be well-versed in customer service, how the menu items are prepared, and pairing of food and drink. We told him how impressed we were with Travis as our server, as it was obvious that this guy knew his stuff. Chris thanked us, and moved around the restaurant saying Hi to other diners.

Meanwhile Travis was back to clear the dishes and bring us our main entrées. Thankfully I had ordered something light, since I was getting quite full by this point. I had seared scallops, served over a bed of pureed curried carrots, with Brussel sprouts, kale, almonds, raisins, and bacon aioli. It was a fabulous dish, but I ended up taking home about half of my meal.

Clearly my eyes are bigger than my stomach, as I let Anna talk me into sharing a big dish of salted caramel ice cream to finish our meal. Creamy, and oh so delicious! 

Chris Ponte stopped back by our table to see if we enjoyed our meal, and just to chat a bit more. He pointed out Chef John Copponi who was managing his team of cooks in the open-air kitchen, and we're anxious to say Hi to John on our next visit.

Bottom line is that this is a superb culinary experience in a beautiful new restaurant. Be aware that the price tag matches the experience. The restaurant is busy and it can get loud. My recommendation is to go early so that you can enjoy a more-relaxed meal at this five star, bucket list facility.

Why 3 stars? Because it was average.

   ---   ---   ---

3.5 stars rounded down here. I do enjoy Kona Grill, but didn't find anything that wowed me enough to make a return trip. I heavily debated between Pad Thai or sushi, but with everyone else getting rolls, I didn't want to be the odd-man out.

I must have tried half the menu between all of the rolls on our table...and again...nothing was horrible or tremendous. I hate giving what's even considered a "neutral" review, but I didn't notice much of a difference between this sushi and what could be found at Publix. 

I would like to go back and try a regular entree, but until then...I apologize for the lack of stand-taking in this review.

Decor and ambiance is a 5, food was a 3.8, I'll give it a 4.

I appreciate the complimentary valet at dinner.  I read that there is street parking, but when it is dark, this isn't really an area where I want to go hunting for street parking.  

My husband noted that the building doesn't look like one that housed a restaurant previously.  It is very unique.  Our waiter told us stories about the wood from the table being from St. Augustine and that everything in here has a story.  They could probably make up half the stories, but it is fun to hear and believe.  It does make you take special note of your surroundings.

I love the atmosphere of this place.  It is all wood and warm tones.  There is a certain lack of pretension here.  I saw a couple people even wearing jeans.  My favorite restaurants are the ones that don't take itself too seriously.

We came for our one year wedding anniversary.  The waiter joked that since this was our first time, we were very trusting to come here for such a special occasion.  I heard from so many people that this was the perfect place for an anniversary that I hadn't even thought about that.  During our dinner, another table got engaged.  People definitely come here for special occasions.

I got a mojito.  It was very refreshing, but a tad too sweet for me.  However, there are so many amazing looking cocktails, that it wouldn't be hard to find another one to try.  They are priced at about $9, which I found very reasonable (even a little low) for a restaurant like this.  The waiter mentioned they are very deliberate about keeping their wine prices low.

We started with the crab mac and cheese.  It was good, but I wasn't blown away.  My husband and I make our own mac and cheese from scratch so it takes a lot to wow us on that front.  

I got the Deconstructed Seafood Pot Pie and my husband got the Filet Mignon.  I actually loved my choice.  It was basically a seafood chowder with puff pastry on the side.  It was chalk full of seafood.  It also came with wild rice and asparagus.  Weirdly enough, I liked the rice better the next day, cold.  I'm weird I know.  My husband enjoyed his filet.  The mashed potatoes came with popcorn in it.  It was a little strange.  I don't know what it added to it, but it was definitely memorable.  Overall, we enjoyed our meals, but weren't blown away.

Since we were celebrating our anniversary, they brought us a complimentary box of chocolate truffles.  They are divine.  Two are covered in coconut, and two are covered in sliced nuts.  I actually ate all four myself.  They are light and oh so chocolatey.

Great restaurant to go to at night. Even late at 9:20 before they close. The bar area has the live piano music. It is great if you on the business trip by yourself and seat on the piano bar. 

I have the southern style shrimp and grit. The shrimp count is at the large size. The ingredient include chorizo ham and bacon. It make the taste interesting. I would said this is average value. I like the piano music at the bar. It make the time pass quicker while you eat and listen. 

The signature margarita is average. The service of the bar is a bit slower due high volume customer during that time i. Overall is a good experience. I like the small plate menu at the happy hour. I will try that next time for the happy hour. I will be back.

Who doesn't love Missouri Botanical Garden? We went on Sunday 4/2 in the afternoon and it was absolutely beautiful. The tulips were at their peak. So colorful and springy! We went on a tour of the garden trees and then rode the tram to hear the narration. It was a perfect afternoon!

I haven't flown in years but a death in the family made car travel impossible.

Flew out on United , hired a car and driver to take us there as I dont' do airport vans that drive all over town. Went straight to the United entrance, upstairs to the shuttle tram and quickly through security. Security was a little icky, they don't have seperate lines for first class passengers which was a bummer, so every one gets herded together. It did go pretty quickly though and we were at Sam Sneads having a pre flight nerve calming drink before we knew it.

All in all it was pretty smooth and no unpleasant experiences. Oh, except all the people who decide to sit in the first class, upgraded class boarding section to try to get on the plane early and make you sit 50 feet away. Selfish

Big improvements this season at the concourse level.

Shake Shack: the cheeseburger is awesome . The sauce really elevates the flavor. The burger isn't greasy. The bun is soft and the lettuce and tomato are fresh.  The mushroom burger is super crunchy with oozing cheese in it. Delicious.

Ribs at Diamond club is delicious, nice size, and very tender. 

Build your own salad: the greens are fresh.

Warm pretzels are awesome. Soft and fresh.

Veggie burger is super greasy. That's why I took a star down.


Crab cake sandwich at Hall of Fame is a little bit greasy and salty.
Don't forget to get the Chickie's and Pete 's crab fries

I went again today.  As almost all agree, their que is good.  However, I think they're ribs are much better than the other menu items.  I ordered the Big Ben platter (as I have so many times in the past) and the items other than the ribs are near as flavorful.  In fact, they're a bit on the dry side.  

BUT THE RIBS ARE AWESOME

I think I'll start ordering just the ribs as they're so good and better than the other meats at Pappy's.  

The sides are always good.  I never tried the fried corn before today.  It was great.

I returned again in January for the chef's tasting menu. Unsure if I had the same server, but his name was Pat too... food wasn't as TASTY as before (there were different plates) but they were still outstanding and oozing with quality. Their ninja-like service (unobtrusive and QUICK) rocked too. I sat in the rear area, which has less of a noise problem than the front

I was working in Maplewood today and based on a friends suggestion, I stopped at "Home" for lunch. Typical of a wine bar, Home was small and intimate. A few hi-tops, a long wall of small tables and a medium sized bar is it. 

I sat at the bar since I was dining alone. The menu was very Californian. It had lots of vegetarian items, fresh seasonal fruits and several food combos with variations of fruit, vegetable, protein, herb and nut pairings. Everything seemed simple, low on seasoning, but very tasty.

I had the cold summer soup, which contained liquid from tomatoes, watermelon, and oil. It was seasoned with cracked pepper. It was not sweet as one might expect and it was yum. I ordered the lunchbox, which had a sweet potato, shrimp and corn hash, some crostini, a refreshing light green salsa that may have had cucumber and tomatillo in it (not sure), house-made lemonade, and some homemade marshmallows for dessert. Everything was fresh and tasty. 

My complaint is that the lemonade was VERY tart the portions were small and the prices were not. A $25 small lunch (including the sall soup add on) won't be a regular thing for me, but I enjoyed lunch, nonetheless and I will be back.

I love the food at the Cheesecake Factory. Every part of your meal tastes great and the service is incredibly good, which you pay for heavily. The place is always packed with people, but there are plenty of spots in this huge building, which keep it from getting over-crowded in a claustrophobic sense. Try the Vietnamese Summer Shrimp Rolls and of course some cheesecake. The bread they have also happens to be pretty good.

Lambert has stepped up its game, in my humble opinion! I recently made it through security in a record 14 minutes (what?) Also, the employees have been consistently having better attitudes and the cleanliness of the Southwest terminal seems to have gone up. This marks my fourth flight of Lambert in a row from which I have no complaints. That's definitely a record with any airport.

Aimee + Lambert = BFF. For now. But I'm happy to bump it to four stars!

Milagro is a bit hard to find. It's located in the Old Webster shopping plaza behind San Sai (former the location of Natural Fact Deli). The place is nice. The bar is encapsulated in mosaic tiles and everything is new and modern. 

On to the food... 

The salsa is good. Lots of flavor. I also tried the guacamole. Although it was fresh, I thought it lacked kick. I would have added some more lime & spices to it. No hot sauce or salt & pepper on the table, I guess I should have asked. 

It's hard to find good fish tacos in STL, but this place has them. And boy are they done perfectly. Grilled fish, chipotle sauce, & fresh cabbage. They taste so fresh. If you go, don't pass these up. They are for real. 

They were out of the lamb tips, so I tried the pork & potatoes. They were good and flavorful, but after a few bites, I was done with the dish and longing for some more fish tacos.

The service has really gone downhill here. Not that everyone isn't nice, it's just that they are so busy. I visited this Friday. The wait was only 15 minutes. Once it was our turn, we were seated at a table in the bar area. After seating, it was at least 10 minutes before we were greeted by our server. Again, It's not that she wasn't working hard, they were just so busy and a bit understaffed. When she did meet us, she asked us for our full order. No going over any of the specials, no recommendations, no drink orders and then come back for the entree orders. This place is so popular that expedited service like this is the norm now. That is the one downside of this place. 

But the food is oh so good. So much that I will still give them a 4 star review. 

I had #17... the spicy beef and noodle soup. It was good. It comes with a bunch of different raw spices to add to your liking. I did have to add some hot sauce since it wasn't as spicy as I prefer. My usual here is #179... meat & veggies on egg noodles. If you get that ask for extra sauce. 

2 dinners and drinks cost ~$30. 

Tip... If there's a wait, ask for a table in the restaurant. The bar tables aren't that quaint. The customers waiting for a table end up surrounding you.

I usually enjoy everything  I order here but I have to say I was a bit disappointed on this visit.  The boneless wings were delicious as usual.   Since it was Taco Tuesday, my dining partner and I decided to split the 7 tacos for $21.   Two of the tacos were one we have ordered from the regular menu and were quite good.  The others were ok but I would not order them again. Probably one of the reasons why is that the the first couple of tacos we ate were cold-not even tepid.  As a result, I don't think that I would order this again.  

This has not been our usual experience here and we have been here many times.

Pandemic update:
On the last work day of the year, the few of us who have had to be on site decided to celebrate the end of 2020 with some Parkway. Ordering online from their website was easy (dressed but on mayo, dressed + creole mustard, whatever). 

For pickup, you show up at a little booth next to their parking lot and give your name. Then you park in a numbered spot and await the golf cart delivery person. 

The menu is a little different too. The caprese isn't on there (permanently or just at the moment?) but they are now offering a beyond burger poboy for the vegetarians in the group. My fried shrimp was delicious as always. My coworkers got a variety of items and everyone seemed pleased. 

All staff was masked and from now on I want all things delivered to me by a decorated golf cart!

Love this place! This is our favorite place to go for Valentines Day or a special occasion dinner. Great atmosphere. Recommend a reservation as it can get quite busy. My family took me here for Mother's Day and was actually the first time we've EVER had an issue for as many times as we've eaten here. I ordered the Short rib gnocchi Bolognese pasta. The dish came out and looked good despite looking like the pasta was resting in watery pasta sauce. Once I took the first bite I couldn't take anymore because my food was not warm at all. Like it had been sitting at the pass for some time. My husband ordered the Churrasco grilled steak --- same with his dish....looked appetizing but his steak was very undercooked! It was bloody and too gooey to cut. He ordered medium not rare! We waited for a little while however finally called over another waitress to help and address our food issue since our waiter (Chris) was MIA. She immediately took the dishes and said she'd let our waiter know. Like 5 minutes later Chris comes by to check on things which we explain our entree situations and he says he will check on them. Shortly after new dishes arrive by a totally different waiter. Overall my pasta was just ok --- I do have to say that as good as Coopers Hawk has been in the past, it was very disappointing to have this happen especially on Mother's Day. And I sort of lost my appetite and asked for a to go box. The manager came over and said he'd comp our drinks which was appreciated and much more than we expected. 

Even our go-to must have appetizer is always the Asian pork belly tostadas. The chips were a bit stale this time. But still tasteful so we ignored the fact that the chips were not very crunchy.

They have a wine room where you can schedule tastings. Highly recommend their sweet red and sparkling Raspberry wine. We are actually in their monthly wine club because of this wine. Wine club is such a great idea -- pay a monthly fee and you get a bottle of wine a month. Really supposed to be their wine of the month that you get but if you find one that you like then you can choose that bottle every month instead. Wait staff is typically friendly and fast. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu unless your food arrives cold or raw -- even the kids menu is amazing. Highly recommend despite the 1 incident we had last night.

Honestly the best happy hour in the bay-both outside on their spacious patio and indoors by the bar. 

And the best part, it's all day!

We usually share sushi and a flatbread but tonight we are venturing off the happy hour menu and also ordering the kona chopped salad. It's sooo yummy. 

They got rid of the longboard lager but the are offering Sam Adams summer ale for $3

OK, here's the secret to having a 5 star experience at Amada - go on a slower night (like a Monday during the summer) so that you can be seated comfortably and the noise level won't be too deafening (this is a LOUD, busy place).

Go with a crowd - we had 7 ladies and ordered 2 plates each.  Sounds like not enough?  WRONG!!!  Many of the choices are heavy. (Even at tapas size.)

Standouts amoung the 14 different items we tried?

Gambas (your basic garlic shrimp - done just right), Flatbread with Artichokes (divine), Yellow tomato gazpacho (perfect on a summer night) was garnished with crab salad and avocado ice cream (Yes - a savory icecream pluche).

The crab-stuffed peppers were so incredibly creamy, crabby and tasty we ordered one more plateful.  (So I guess we had 15 dishes among 7 ladies).

The plate of veggies (can't remember the name) was simple and perfect - tomato, pepper, onion and a delectable eggplant dip.  It was accompanied by crispy-thin bread smeared lightly with a chive goat cheese.  HEAVENLY.

Lamb meatballs were too rare (nearly raw)  for most of the groups liking, but the sherry cream sauce and fresh green peas were tasty.

The salad with figs and blue cheese came literally wrapped in Jamon.  Weird and not my bag - but it, too, disappeared.

Meanwhile, they ARE heavy handed with the salt and the (salty) cheeses - so if you KNOW this (you, smart -yelper-who-pre-reads before you go, you!)  Ask for items light on the (salt) (Cheese) (Sauce) etc.

I can't wait to come back here - at an off time - with more than 2 other people.

2 dishes apiece for 7 people came to $280 (including tax 'n tip) including ONE sangria each.  (Well, not I, I had 2 virgin mojitos with a splash of pineapple juice).  

Jose, baby,  you live up to your hype.

And I have now been to all 5 Philly Garces joints.  Huzzah!

Oh - and if you don't eat pork or shellfish - you'll have a TOUGH time here.  And if you are vegan - fuggedaboutit!  (Dairy is hidden in things)

Friends and I met here for a late lunch. The restaurant's popular, so reservations are the way to go. Luckily, we only had a 20-minute wait.

Belgians sure must love to drink, for Monk's is known for having an extensive beer selection, one that fills multiple pages. Beer drinkers, this is your heaven. (Since I'm no beer expert, my eyes glazed over in confusion; I ordered a shot of tequila instead.)

Their Spanish Flies ($8.50) - chicken wings - were decent. The chipotle pepper sauce they're dry rubbed in was supposed to be "incredibly hot", but I only detected a wee kick. For my entree, I had the curry mussels ($9.95; small pot) which were simply wonderful: Rodenbach Red Ale, Thai red curry, basil, garlic, coconut milk, and tender mussels, all in a bowl. The string fries on the side were surprisingly crispy and went well with the dipping sauce.

I know they're a Belgian cafe, but if they tossed ramen noodles into the curry, they'd make a killing.

I was plenty excited when IKEA decided to open a store in the Tampa Bay area, and have made several pilgrimages even after surviving the Grand Opening Day bonanza.

For those not familiar with this temple of Do-It-Yourself furniture awesomeness, IKEA is located along Adamo Drive in downtown Tampa at 22nd street. It's kinda hard to miss the giant 2-story blue and yellow building with the swarms of people moving in and out of the parking lot.

As you walk through the front doors they hand you a map, a paper measuring tape, a pencil, and a sturdy, disposable bag for carrying "stuff", and then point you up the escalator.  If you don't know any better then you follow the crowds in front of you, like lemmings marching to the sea. Follow the yellow brick road, and all of that. Sure enough there is a painted line on the floor to guide you past every single showroom display and turn you all around like a walk through a haunted house. You might want to go faster, but you're trapped behind the people in front of you with their double-wide strollers and 37 family members all stretched out across the aisles. *shudders*

Thankfully there is a better way... a quick study of the map shows you "secret routes" for dodging the crowds and arriving though a back entrances into the showroom areas of interest. One 5-hour trip around the store on opening day in Tampa, and I was begging for another way. The concept is pretty simple......let's say you'd like to look at bookcases, or kitchen tables, or entertainment centers. You find that section of the store on your map, and then weave through the side entrances till you are there. 

I have a lot of IKEA bookcases scattered around my condo, but today I was looking for a new entertainment unit for the living room. I spotted a Hemnes 3-drawer TV unit that was the perfect height and width for the cubby hole along the wall. I've built the Hemnes bookcases, so I had a pretty good idea about the quality of the materials and the look of the finished product.

After copying down the item number and location I zipped downstairs to the warehouse area, located the carton, paid for my merchandise, loaded that into the back of my SUV and was off. It took just over 2 hours to assemble, but I'm real happy with my new entertainment center - and just in time for tomorrow's Super Bowl party!

Photos of the finished entertainment center sitting in my living room are attached.

Invited back to Luke after being contacted by management regarding my previous review I was privileged to a dinner out of this world. It began with huge raw oysters that were succulent and salty needing no additional condiments. My party then had the baked oysters which were again excellent, oysters on the half shell baked with fresh shrimp and crabmeat. Then we were treated to a chef's special called Flammenkuchen. The Flammenkuchen was a German style pizza with pork belly, caramelized onions and Emmenthaler cheese, that was unbelievable. The next course was a cup of gumbo which is always a staple for me anytime I come to Luke, a dark rich roux filled with seafood and sausage. The main course was their number 1 seller the famed shrimp and grits which was the best shrimp and grits I have ever had. The sauce was rich and full of flavor probably also made with a roux with huge shrimp, soft creamy grits and cheese. For dessert we settled on the bread pudding that was served in a soufflé dish served with a great pecan reduction sauce. Ask for Tristan if your going for dinner, he provided great service all evening long. This was from start to finish the best dinner I have ever had.

Fantastic brunch buffet.

I really enjoyed this brunch.  There is no unlimited drinks option, which is a shame, but they do have specials on mimosas and bloody marys.  A friend did the math and determined it was actually cheaper to order her mimosas by the glass instead of getting a bottle of champagne.

The brunch area is separated from the dining area, which is nice.  This ensures it's not super noisy in the dining area.  There is a great selection ranging from sushi to your everyday breakfast food.  I was surprised how much I enjoyed the sushi.  There isn't a huge amount of options, but what they have is pretty good.  They also are very small pieces so you can end up eating a ton without realizing it!  I also really enjoyed their biscuits.  I had to grab one after I saw so many people at my table eating it.  It was worth it.

Everything I got was good.  It has a good variety and you get your money's worth.  Make sure you come here hungry!

My wife was feeling under the weather the other night with allergies.  One thing that always seems to comfort me when I'm not 100% is some good Vietnamese food.  So I chose Mai Lee for dinner. 

We've been here countless times and the food is always good.  But ever since they've moved to this larger location, the service seems cold and uninviting.  I'm used to it and have come to expect it here.  However, to my surprise, this past visit we had a very friendly, on-top-of-it waiter.  It made a meal at one of my favorite spots so much better. 

He recommended the duck.  First of all, I've never had a waiter her 'recommend' anything here... we're usually greeted with a 'what do you want' attitude.  Secondly, this is one of the few dishes here I haven't had the chance to try, and when I did try to order it last time, they were out.  The meal was awesome.  The duck came roasted with a crunchy skin and the right amount of sweetness.  Plus the sauce they serve with it is so good.  The wife got her usual vermicelli with pork and egg roll and as usual enjoyed it. 

For once, the service matched the food.  My only gripe is that Jay works the bar area so you have to sit at one of those tall tables to get quality service.

I evidently reviewed the airport governing board last time oops.  So the Nashville airport is really clean and just about every time I've been in there has been live music somewhere.  Security and signage are good.

I do like that they have a by the minute chair massage place on the concourse.

It's a rainy Sunday morning and my family (party of 6) met at Southwest Diner for brunch. We had to wait about 30-40 minutes. They squeezed the 6 of us around a table for 4. This one has been on my list for a while so I was looking forward to trying it. 

I ordered the Enchiladas Platter (Stacked corn tortillas with cheese and chile sauce. Served with rice and beans) and was given the choice of red chile, green chile, or Christmas style (both.) Was there any other option? Of course I went with Christmas style. This was a delicious and flavorful plate of food. Everything on the plate was well spiced and the cheese was smooth and creamy. I didn't love the rice. My brother ordered the Carne Adovada (Red chile braised local pork shoulder, 2 eggs, home fries and tortillas.) I thought the pork shoulder was well seasoned, tender, and delicious. I would order it myself. My boyfriend ordered the Jonathan's Famous Fiery Scramble (Spicy, cheesy, scrambled eggs with sausage, home fries and biscuit.) He requested light spice and felt the food was still spicy but very much enjoyed his meal. Other orders were one of the egg combos, a breakfast sandwich, and the buttermilk cornmeal pancakes. The portions are generous, the prices are reasonable, and the service is friendly.

My issues were the long wait time and the fact that they squeezed our party of 6 around a table for 4. The host even commented that we were all very tall. I'm not tall (5'6"). I'm the short one but the rest of the party is 6'4", 6'2", and 3 women at 5'10". Also the place is crowded and loud. I'm sure this is a much different scene during the week and I wouldn't hesitate to give it another try then but as far as weekends are concerned I'm out.

Good food, but certainly not the best in Tampa. I ordered 3 tacos: chicharron, ribeye, and fish and a side of retried beans and horchata. 

It's hard to know what you're going to get with chicharron, this place did pork rinds. They were alright. Lots of toppings certainly helped. I would prefer pork belly. 

The ribeye was alright - not as flavorful as a carne Saad's or some other steak option. The taco was a little dry - I guess you could add toppings to fix that - but they were already a little pricey.

Fish taco was the better one. Solid fish and toppings. It was almost near the quality of Cali Tacos, but Cali Tacos in my past expedience is superior (it's been awhile so I could be wrong).


The tacos weren't bad - they just weren't that impressive either. The side of refried beans came in a tiny container - it was good, but a better portion would've been better.

Probably the thing dragging down this review the most was the horchata. I'm from California and horchata is really important to me. The horchata here was syrupy and didn't have a good flavor to it. It almost tasted like powder and I started coughing after drinking it.

Order total was around $14 which isn't that cheap for tacos and a drink.

Overall, Loli's is definitely not a bad place for Mexican food, but definitely not the best in Tampa. I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

This is a tough one for me.  Many moons ago, I was fortunate to have a close Brazilian friend before the masses knew anything about churrascarias with meat parades.  Back when if you wanted this type of meal, you had to hit up mom 'n pop Brazilian restaurants in seedy strip plazas.  Of them, Brasa Grill, reigned supreme.  However, once the big boys (Boizao and Texas de Brazil) moved in, the few smaller places we had closed down permanently.  Sad, actually.  It was a kin to watching the Scotty's on Gandy close because they couldn't compete with the allure and prices at Home Depot.

I'm digressing, and I apologize.  I'll try to stay on track here.

Bottom line, Boizao was better.  I don't understand how of these two mega Brazilian steakhouses, this one was left standing.  Poor management, maybe?  Not sure.  

The meats at TDB were too salty for my liking.  It was fine for some of the medium and medium rare cuts of meat, but if you got some of the outer edges of steak, you were gonna be reaching for s glass of water after each bite.  Same goes for the chicken and pork--too damn salty.

The salad and appetizer bar had some pretty amazing goodies though.  I'll give them that.  The options were far more extensive than previous Brazilian places I've visited.  I got for the meats though, so while it was an impressive spread, it's just not my steez.

The service?  This is a tough one.  It certainly could have been better, but they had a party of 95 to contend with.  It was some local ice cream company having their annual employee appreciation meal.  At one point, a manager stopped by our table and let us know that mega party was about to start eating, and that we might experience some delays in the arrival of meats, but honestly we noticed no interruption.  As soon as we flipped our cards to green, we were bombarded.  The missed service opportunity was with our actual server not removing dirty plates and empty glasses.  Worth mentioning, but doesn't take away a star.  

Had I been able to enjoy the meats without my taste buds engaged in trench warfare against the evil axis of salt, this could have easily been a 4 or 5 star review.

This is the nice new TBBC West have location with some cool wooden tables and long bar inside and an outside patio. Very tasty beer offerings as well as mixed drinks. Good service when we were there. Seems to be a well executed spinoff of a Tampa classic.

Haven't been here in years and the dinner date chose.. so here I was.

I have to say the service here is spectacular. That's the only reason they went up a star...to a mere 3.

We were seated promptly for our reservation and greeted by our two waiters...one was new and shadowing the other. Presented us a cocktail menu...wine list...and dinner menu.

Date opted for a bourbon drink..I forget what it was called and I got an elderflower martinish drink. My drinks was good..his was amazing. When the waiter asked and I expressed this he brought me a different drink... complimentary.. a martini with a frozen edible flower in it.  Just because I wasn't crazy over the first. 

We opted for a nice bottle of Alexander valley cab to go with dinner. For appetizer I ordered the blue point oysters and he got the shrimp sautee with a tobasco cream sauce. Both were excellent. Really good!

For dinner.i opted to get the grouper with lobster..gnocchi. peas and a lemon sauce. He got the crab meat cocktail...crab cake and au gratin jalapeno potatoes. Mine was ok..but swimming in water. obviously someone didn't drain the gnocchi properly. It was in face inedible. His crab cake was delish as was the crab cocktail..the potatoes just didn't get it for me but he liked it.

The waiter replaced mine with an appetizer of surf and turf.  Short ribs with scallops. Unfortunately by the time it came date was done with his meal and his dessert. I got mine to go.

We stayed for an after dinner drink while we got the bill. 

Extremely disappointing I basically had half a dozen oysters for dinner because they food was not properly cooked and replacement didn't come out on time. For $48 a expect a piece of fish to be edible.

Last chance for them. I'll stick to Eddie vs or capital grille.

This place is way over rated.

This place is a zoo, but it's worth a visit to buy things you can't get anywhere else in the Tampa Bay area. I had been wanting to buy guanciale to make authentic spaghetti carbonara and buccatini all'amatriciana.  No place in Tampa has it, so I've been making do with pancetta for  years. But now I know that Mazzaro's has guanciale, so I can drive over to St. Pete.

They also have a full deli, meat counter, pasta counter, bakery, and coffee shop.  And a ton of prepared foods. I'm not a huge fan of much of their prepared foods. Much of it is saltier than it needs to be. And I prefer to cook from scratch anyways.

But for raw ingredients, this is the place to shop for Italian ingredients.

Although this location is decorated beautifully, I wasn't all that wowed by the display of goodies. 

Yes their donuts looked interesting and yes their cookies looked moist, but I was hoping for some slices of pies or cakes. Unfortunately that wasn't what they offer here (if you want that, go next door to Datz).  Instead we both just got a scoop of gelato, and when I say a scoop I literally mean the smallest scoop of ice cream you'll ever order-it was more like a kid's scoop it was so small.

He ordered the Nutella, which tasted wonderfully. I ordered the vanilla bean and honestly I think Haagen Dasz is much better. 

Will I be back?  I guess, but I surely hope they bring over some of their delicious pies and cakes.

I can't possibly say anything about Pappy's that hasn't already been said. I was there tonight for dinner and had my regular order, pulled pork sandwich with vinegar slaw and sweet potato fries. Early dinner at the beginning of the week seems to be a fairly convenient time to go as far as not waiting in a long line and having plenty of seats available. YUM!

I have always been curious about the food at Bernini in Ybor City. The restaurant is named after Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini, of the late renaissance period (1598-1680) and founder of the Baroque art style. The exterior of the restaurant is beautiful in design and certainly makes me think Italy. During the Chevy Tapas Trail I was able to try two things from their menu. The item listed on the menu was "Slice garlic marinated duck breast with chianti fig compote on a toasted crostini". The duck was great, but what stole my attention was the crab and red pepper puffs with roasted corn mousseline that Bernini decided to add-on. Bernini was one of the first restaurants to open their doors and it was much appreciated as several restaurants on Chevy Tapas Trail were behind schedule and in a 3-hour trail you need all the time you can get. The attendants at the stand were helpful and explained the tapas to me. I left impressed.

Update: Also found out entrees and pasta dishes are half price from 4:00 to 7:00 daily and all Findlandia vodka drinks are $2. "The deal of the century" as my friend put it.

Creative menu, ample portion sizes and friendly staff make the refinery an excellent selection for a nice evening out. 

The dining room is on the small side so I would recommend reservations.

Everyone's looking for that perfect cheesesteak in Philly


This one is almost there but for me the bread didn't love up to my standards. The meat and cheese ratio is on point and the flavors great but the bread was almost stale but I've heard rumors that their bread vendor has changed since the pandemic so i'll blame it on COVID!

got mine with american and onions and usually i have high standards with my meat and cheese ratio on cheesesteaks and this one was perfect.

Consistent, authentic good cuban food. My family has been going here for years. It used to be like a snack bar with a line waiting to come in, it expanded quite some time ago. 
For the money not many places in Tampa that you could get as much food and have it be consistently good. One of my favorites is boliche. Beef with cuban sausage in the middle and, a very flavorful gravey. Love it, always fork tender and seasoned just right.
I think I have had everything on the menu several times.
I don't believe their cuban sandwich is up to Tampa's standard for this delight, I would pass on that here. Service is usually very quick and short turn around on receiving your food

When you first arive hot buttered cuban bread, sounds so simple and is simply delicious..
Black beans, rice, fried plantains are the usual fair and hefty good portions. I like raw diced onions on my black beans, yummy.
I really would not go the salad route here. It is small, basically iceberg and not many dressing choices. Salad isn't bad, just unremarkable.
I always have plenty for a people bag to go and don't forget to take the leftover bread.
Do youself a favor and leave room for some flan. Flan is like a creamy, stiffer pudding that is molded and covered in a brown sugar sauce. They do not have the best flan I have eaten, but again for the price great food.

Since my last update, we have been to Doma 3 or 4 times including New Year's Eve (amazing) and last night just me and my 6 year old.

She ate 2 orders of Shrimp Shumai. and a bunch of edamame.
And then she said, "Mommy, I don;t want any chocolate lava cake this time".

Smart kid.

I had the Naked Salmon roll (sans jalapenos) and it was so good, I ordered a second one.

And that was it.

2 rounds of Shumai 'n salmon.

And we were stuffed.

Dan & the guys are so great with my little one.  She loves to sit at the high-top tables in the back.  (I prefer the regular tables, but I was out voted.)

Oh - and if you go to DOMA - save room for dessert (if you can).  The mochi-coated strawberries dipped in fudge and chocolate lava cake (sounds trite - but they make a good one) are amazing.

Finally checked out Anise since I was nearby at the hilton downtown Tampa. I found myself really loving this place. I felt like I was at one of my favorite clubs that I use to go to in Chicago called white star lounge. The decor was beautiful and a great surprise. Had a nice lounge feel. The music also helped the ambiance from the amazing dj w music I would have loved when I was at the clubs. We tried some buns. The braised pork w kimchi, the Chinese BBQ, and the shrimp. Our faves are the latter two. The Chinese BBQ bun is what I expect a filipino siopao to taste w. It burst w flavor. The shrimp one was so good, i loved it. We also ordered the lobster Mac. I tasted the lobster w each bite, yet it was not overwhelming so my non seafood loving hubby liked it a lot.
Our server was ok, she was not out of this world. For the ambiance being so nice inside, I didn't get how the menus were pretty generic.. Oh well, we would be back, and we at least know a nice spot in downtown tampa w tasty food, not too bad prices that is dog friendly outside.

Armature Works is now in soft opening. You'll find over a dozen restaurants serving everything from juices and sandwiches to ramen and poke bowls/sushi burritos. This place is literally one of the most massive things I have ever seen in Tampa.

The space is beautifully restored and while there is still construction going on - once it's done you'll be able to sit outside and see the riverwalk. This is what it means to live on a bay and I've always wondered why Tampa's waterfront access is so underutilized. 

All the food I've had so far has been great and the coffee from Union Coffee is delicious (better known as Commune & Co.). Most of the places inside Armature are actually places you've tried before around town but now you have them all in one building instead of having to drive all over town to get to them.

There is so much potential here and I'm looking to seeing Tampa achieve that.

During Spring Break, the main thing I wanted to accomplish was trying Farmhaus for their blue plate special. I was lucky to have two of my favorite Yelpers, Steven B. and Tracey W., join me so I didn't feel lonely. 

I had a few issues with trying Farmhaus before then. One, I had tweeted them questions on two occasions and did not receive a reply. Two, I had tried to go there with a group of 6 and we were denied a reservation. They won't take groups of more than 4. And three, my sister had a bad experience with them. 

I decided that I'd tweet them one more time to ask if they could accommodate a vegetarian for a blue plate and this time, I received a reply, so I decided to go. After all, I wanted to try their mac n cheese and mashed potatoes, a carb lover's dream! 

We were seated right at 11 and I realized that I was with a "Farmhaus VIP," Steven, who was well known by the hostess. I mentioned that I was a vegetarian and it was again said that it was no problem. We were served the tea- YUM! I'm not a huge tea fan, but the sweet variety was perfect for me. Our salads came, and mine was twice as big as the other two, to compensate for not eating meat. It was HUGE. It had pickled veggies (I ate a few, but not a huge fan), hard boiled egg, and a hard cracker like thing. It had a sweet onion dressing but it didn't taste oniony to me. It was more sweet.

The main course came and I got the mac n cheese and mashed potatoes that I'd been dreaming of. They both lived up to my dream. The taters were perfectly creamy and flavorful, and the mac n cheese was as well. I only wish that I had gotten bigger portions of that instead of the salad. Hey, what can I say? I'm a carb-o-holic.

We decided to order dessert, which was a cake with candied oranges and orange sorbet. I wasn't a huge fan - I don't really like orange flavored things though, so it wasn't their fault.

I'd come back again for a blue plate, though I encourage them to have more vegetarian stuff on the dinner menu. So far, there isn't enough to lure me there for dinner, unless I can just eat a huge plate of mashed potatoes!

I cannot jump in joy wagon to give them five stars. Basically this place is a food court with trendy atmosphere. It is an high end food court if I have to classify them. 

Plus area - Parking is the best in the area. Plenty of the parking place. Variety of the food to attract people is very good. 

Down side - Giant food court. Line everywhere. The price of the food is not cheap. Restaurant level price. It is about 20% more than average. Only one water station. I don't like the table setting. A lot of share table. The table is not clean. We have to clean ourselves. 

This place is a big warehouse for a lot of food vendor. It is a new vibe for the area. I wonder what the summer like in this area. It is going to be hot for the design and set up of the building. I guess we will find out. 

I would pick a place has sit down and order the food. Not sure about line standing wait for your turn.

I've been very fortunate to attend all of the zoo's major annual fundraisers, which has also allowed me to appreciate the really good people who work here.

Unlike say the zoo in Miami, which gets about 50% of its annual budget from public funding, Lowry Park Zoo covers its budget without much public assistance.

That's why Zoofari, Wazoo and the annual golf tournament are so vital and I have not had anything less than a great time at any of these events over the years.

It is awesome what this facility does for manatees as I've sat in their seminars to get even more perspective on the research and assistance being done on this species. (I didn't know they had fingernails, either,)

While I honestly don't know very many places I can recommend to people with kids, this is certainly one of them. While the special events are adults only for fundraising purposes, I've walked the zoo during a summer weekday afternoon and see a lot of happy children running around the various exhibits...especially the penguins.

The happy hour only goes until 5 pm, but since I was early meeting my friends, I still managed to procure their version of a bellini; blood orange purée, Grand Marnier, and sparkling moscato, which was delightful.

Our party had reservations so we were quickly shown to our table, but there were still plenty of tables available at that time.  When we left a few hours later, the restaurant was much more crowded. Our waiter was efficient and hilarious, and easily one of the best parts of the dinner.

I think the food was fine, while nothing except dessert really "wow"ed.  The egg roll appetizer was tasty, and I did really like the slaw that came with it.  My potato-crusted scallop entrée was good; the 5 scallops were perfectly cooked, if a little bland.  The brussels sprout salad served with it was very good.

The star of the show, however, was very clearly the dessert special of lemon buttercake.  Served with a limoncello blueberry jam and lots of citrus cream (which almost tasted like sour cream), it was fantastic.  The tartness of the lemon, with the sweetness of the blueberries, all combined with the richness of the cream sauce made our entire table swoop in until the plate was entirely wiped clean.

While parking can be a hassle, that's pretty much the only downside. Food was good, service was great, and the atmosphere was warm and welcoming, so I feel like this is a place you can come to and consistently have a nice meal.

I think many of us in Tampa take our many venues for fun & pleasure for granted. I have been to zoos across the country, some better, but most are a whole lot worse than our very own Lowry Park Zoo.
Not only do they have a great zoo, with a wide variety of animals all in what appears to be close to their natural habitats. The animals appear quite content & happy. I can attest to the employees care & commitment to the animals wellbeing.
Not only is it a zoo, bit it has acres of wellanicured grounds that are spectacular and offer a beautiful  array of horticulture delights. Yup Tampa has so much to offer its residents. 
Lowry Park also has special deals for admission, as well as special events, for patrons to participate. A fantastic place to spend the day with your family & frienfs, or just go & enjoy a day on your own.
What's a girl to do? Always take advantage of you local facilities, parks & events, you can't loose.

On Swann is the newest addition to Hyde Park Village's slowly growing restaurant scene. This upscale contemporary American restaurant is located on the corner of West Swann and South Oregon Avenue.

On Swann has only been open for two days so we were expecting a few hiccups, but the food and service were flawless! Each plate was cleared mere seconds after we finished our food and we never waited for refills. Service might have been a little too attentive if that is possible. We had to grab a few plates that we were were still nibbling on back from the overeager servers. Our server, Leonardo, was so friendly and and informative. He walked us through the menu and explained that many of the dishes were designed for sharing. His menu recommendations were fantastic and we are so glad that we ordered the tomahawk pork chop that he suggested.

As my husband, sister and I browsed the menu it was hard to not get distracted by all of the restaurant's gorgeous decor surrounding us. French doors, exposed brick, wooden floors, charming light fixtures, antique chandeliers, and the stunning metal bar shelves add a rustic, yet modern feel to On Swann.

We started off with drinks. My sister and I ordered a bottle of Prosecco to share and my husband ordered a glass of Angostura 1824 rum. The charcuterie boards seemed to be a popular choice so we selected the Farm Board with an assortment of cheese, cured meats, duck rillette, and country pate. The aged gouda and the blue cheese were excellent. The third cheese was a mild white cheese that was a little ho-hum, but it paired well with the bread and jam, pickled cauliflower, and cured meats. We also ordered the Pork Belly Steamed Buns. Delicious, but there are only two buns so order at least two plates if there are more than two people at the table. 

Between the appetizer and the huge cheese board we were beginning to get full so our table decided to split the Tomahawk Pork Chop since the portions are so large. This thick cut pork chop was served with summer beans and Anson Mills cheese grits. This dish was absolutely amazing! We saved no room for dessert, but I'll definitely save room next time for the blueberry cobbler and lemon gelato.

I cannot wait to return to sample more of the menu at On Swann!

After too many airports our TIA is hard to beat. It is one of the best planned and laid out airports I have been to. The signage is clear and if you look and read it is very easy to navigate.
Where they are somewhat lacking is the security check points, everything is just too close. People behind you not having to stand back. The guy in front of me was being arrested for something and it was just too close for comfort.
Other than the hiccup I mentioned, I am always glad to see my home airport with plenty of bathrooms and amenities.  Once I disembark,  I usually head to a restroom to throw water on my face and call my ride in the cell phone lot. I grab my luggage, which is usually on the luggage mover when I arrive and step outside to a situation that is calm and not chaos.
Yes they keep the cars moving, seldom do you see a bottleneck.  Ah benches to sit if you need to wait a minute or 2 for your ride.
Yes TIA is a well organized and managed airport, one we that live here should be proud to call our own.
Have no fear, even though John is dead the food is still good especially the pulled pork with cole slaw as well a the standard roast beef. Parasols is still rolling with great poboys.

Still showin' the love for Doma - same great owners and some not-so-new faces on the staff (Yuli is an amazing server/hostess).

We enjoyed a plethora of uber-fresh sushi and sashimi delights including the ever-popular "Naked Salmon" and the not-to-be-missed Omakase maki.  We also shared a Bento Dinner with Salmon Teriyaki, Chicken Yakitori, a Yellowtail Scallion roll and more.

Korean Taco app is fun (also ask about the truffled-tuna nachos - we did not try but they look terrific).

The triple spicy double tuna roll is a fave with the men in my life.
Pachinko roll (not ordered this time) is a hit with the kids.

I truly miss coming here all the time and I make it a point to get a Doma-Fix whenever I am nearby.

P.S. - My now 13 year old kid scarfed down all the leftovers the minute I walkd through the door.  She has been coming here since she was 4 or 5 and it's her favorite restaurant EVER.

Pretty great barbecue.  Sweet Lucy's has been on my list to try for a while, I was glad to finally make an excuse to go.

I ordered the pulled pork, the meat was flavorful and pulled into small chunks.  The meat wasn't dry, it paired well with the sauce and made a good sandwich.  Quite a bit of flavor here.

There was only one style of sauce that I saw, it was a very traditional Texas style sauce.  It was pretty good.

My meal came with three sides.  I ordered the collard greens, the cole slaw, and the brussel sprouts.  The brussel sprouts were the best of the bunch.  Earthy taste with some sweetness from the caramelized onions.  I would have liked a little more of a crispiness to the sprouts, but I'm nit picking.  The cole slaw was pretty good too, a tangier slaw that paired with the meat well.  I don't think it is a slaw that I would really eat on it's own, but in my opinion, it matters most that the slaw works with the pulled pork.  The collard greens were good, they did have some meaty flavor to them, they weren't my favorite, but they were pretty good as well.

The corn bread was moist, only a tad sweet, pretty dense.  Better than other places that I've had.

Overall, a very good meal.  I came here hearing that this was the best barbecue in the area.  While I think it is excellent BBQ, there are a couple other well known places in the area that I like a little better.

This was one of the first places that everybody said I needed to go to when I first got to Philadelphia. The ice cream is overpriced and lines are often pretty long. My palette is pretty crappy, but honestly to me it tastes like regular thrifty's ice cream that is served in Chinese take out boxes.

So glad to see Southwest Diner is back on their A-Game. I will be honest, my last couple visits were less then stellar. I was there for their one year anniversary week,  a couple times later and witnessed a downturn in food and service. I loved SD so I didn't post a negative review, I just removed them from my Breakfast and Biscuits and Gravy list. I am now happy to say, they are being added back to both list after a very enjoyable morning. 

A friend who had never been to SD wanted to meet for breakfast and that is where she wanted to meet. I went with the flow, in hopes that they were back on track. We arrived early, just as they were opening and were greeted cheerfully. Two of us ordered Bloody Mary's and their spiciness was a great way to start the day. 

Our friend ordered, my favorite Jonathan's Famous Fiery Scramble. It's a spicy, cheesy scrambled eggs served with a choice of breakfast meat (sausage patty) and home fries. She liked it, she really liked it. Brad went with the Egg Combo Grande, a champion of breakfast. Two eggs, bacon, home fries and a short stack of buttermilk cornmeal pancakes. We also, shared a half order of Biscuits and House Made Sausage Gravy. Fluffy biscuit and a true milk gravy with huge chunks of sausage. 

My breakfast was the Southwest Slinger, it was so good I'm creating a new list for slingers. It may be the only one on the list for awhile, but I am sure it will hold the #1 spot even longer.  The serving was huge, two normal people could share a single order. The plate is first covered with home fries, which are cubed roasted potatoes, covered in melted longhorn cheese, then two beef patties covered in green chilies and topped with two fried eggs. I loved it!

Southwest Diner is back in to my breakfast rotation. 

When: 13 Jan 2014
Why: Breakfast with friends

The roast pork is full of flavor, too salty for me but so good. Very juicy and moist because they put the broth with the sandwich. Add the sharp provolone and spinach or broccoli rabe for a complete experience. You can add hot peppers too. Pretty expensive though, around $10 for sandwich with cheese. 

This place is featured on travel channel

Two words: Taco Tuesday.

My friend Greg & I made the genius decision to lunch at Farmhaus yesterday and I forgot they only offer one dish during lunchtime (blue plate special), but it ended up working in our favor. Because it was tacos. Taco Tuesday.

For ten dollars each, we got refreshing ice tea, a gorgeous mixed green salad with hard boiled egg, cucumbers, and a tangy but smooth mustard vinaigrette, and a heavenly plate of fresh tacos. It was the perfect amount of food, and the three tacos were nestled on some of the most soft, fresh tortillas I've ever encountered. The first was a roasted vegetable taco (my favorite of the group), the second was a chorizo taco, and the third was filled with tender pork and a ton of cilantro. They also brought out fresh pico de gallo and a green salsa. It was all served alongside spanish rice and pinto beans that were seasoned perfectly.

Between the eco-friendly table settings, friendly waitresses in plaid shirts, fresh tea and unbelievably fresh & flavorful food, Farmhaus makes me one happy lady.

I tried talking someone into going with me to Meatloaf Wednesday today, but it didn't work. I'm going to try again for Roast Beef Thursday.

I realize we were kind of off season but the gardens inside and out look bad from lack of care. Lots of weeds inside the dome and cute little mice eating bird seed from the bird feeder. The house with the camilias smelled amazing with the citrus trees and Jasmine blooming. The Saffron Cafe was expensive for what it is, a glorified sandwich shop, but the husband was getting hangry so we had to eat. 

I rember when we were here 10 to 15 years ago this all just looked better. 

Huge gift shop with tons of plants and bulbs as well as the typical postcards, jewelry and books etc...

What's not to love about TJ?  Unique food items at reasonable prices. 

This location has been open for some time. I waited until the initial craze passed and for me to have a few minutes to myself, without the little kiddo. 

I stopped in around 830 on a Thursday night. It was NOT busy at all, but there still was a decent crowd. 

I perused all areas...frozen, fresh produce, dry goods and snacks!

So what did I get:  frozen turkey meatballs, sauce to go with my meatballs, black bean/corn taquitos and enchilada sauce, a pre-made salad with chicken and cous cous, their DARK CHOC SEA SALT BAR (one of my long time favorites), less guilt Mac n cheese and salsa verde. I'm sure I'm missing some items. I felt as though all the prices were fair (not as inexpensive as Aldi) but by far cheaper than Publix. 

When checking out, I inquired if they were in talks of opening one in north county and was told no :(

Until they decide to expand, this will be the closest one for me. I can't wait to see what new items they have during my next visit.

Best damn smoked BBQ EVER! 

I highly recommend the pulled chicken, pulled turkey, tasty baked beans and fried corn on the cob.......I promise its finger licking good.

We stopped in tonight to grab a quick bite around 10:00 pm, and it was still very busy!  We were seated immediately, though, and our moo shu tofu, seafood and tofu casserole, and hong kong wonton soup were delivered within 10 minutes of ordering.  The moo shu was flavorful and made with sprouts, mushrooms, carrots, bamboo, and egg rather than the ubiquitous shredded cabbage or napa.  Plus, it wasn't greasy at all!  Same with the casserole, although that did have a bit of msg, fyi.  You can definitely request that it be prepared without msg, though, and they are great about making substitutions and going light on the oil, as well.  The wonton soup was delish, as always.  The service was absolutely lovely and our waiter even gave us a complimentary coconut and green tea ice cream dessert.  The best part: under $30, including tax and tip!  Love it here!

Terrific beer list.  I do wish they had more information on the beers listed, as a number of them I have never heard of.  I imagine this would make the "Beer Bible" much bigger, and I suppose that is what smartphones and the internet are for.  Plenty of interesting things on tap, but the true beauty here are in the bottles that are offered.  Many rare bottles and limited brews available, but you might find them to be out of brews listed.

Seating is reserved for those eating, which I never have.
This review is for Iovine. This is a great place to get fresh and cheap produce. How can you beat 99 cents a pound for organic tomato. They have a dollar a bag section.

Have you seen Wicked? No, not the Broadway musical, I 'm talking about the Smothered Fries at Shaved Duck. They are wickedly good. So good that your doctor probably does not want you to eat them. We've all learned the valuable lesson of what is GOOD, is always not GOOD for us. These fries are one of those things and I do not care. I will eat these every time I go to TSD. 

Smothered Fries are crispy hand-cut fries (I think they're fried in duck fat), topped with pulled rib meat and "smothered" in homemade cheese sauce. Paula Deen would love these fries, but now you can see why your doctor may not. 

We then shared a full slab of St. Louis Style Spare Ribs. I loved the dry rub so much that I only used a little sauce of the three they offered. Of the three my favorite was the Kansas City. Kinda funny putting KC sauce on STL Ribs. 

Our sides were Mac-n-Cheese, Cornbread and Jalapeno Cream Corn. 
The Cornbread was served in a little black iron frying pan with Honey Butter. It was true southern cornbread, moist and came out of that skillet clean as a whistle. The Honey Butter was so damn good, I wanted to do butter shoots. 

At Thanksgiving, I want a big bowl of Jalapeno Cream Corn. This has to be the best cream corn I have ever had and my Auntie use to make some killer cream corn. The jalapenos in this corn was damn hot. It was hotter then the hot sauce they offered for the ribs. Southern Belle Paula Deen would be saying, "yall I want this recipe". 

I haven't forgotten about the Mac-n-Cheese, oh wait I have forgotten it. 
It wasn't that memorable and will not reorder on my next visit. 

The service was friendly and attentive. We enjoyed a table outside and watched the colorful locals walk by

While I LOVE Trader Joe's because it reminds me of home in the Bay Area, this particular location is a tad confusing--I stopped in because I was in the area and just wanted a bottle of water because I was parched and didn't want anything too sugary...is that too much to ask?  I circled around the store multiple times trying to find a cold case with single bottles of water, and had no luck finding one.  However, they did redeem themselves with showtunes playing in the background.  A store's soundtrack always makes a difference!  Anywho, since this is the only Trader Joe's downtown, I will definitely stop by when I need to stock up on my favorite organic treats!

I don't think "more expensive" requires "more words" in a review, so here is the quick and dirty!

I had the STRIP STEAK, medium.  Taste was grand and was cooked perfectly.  Couldn't have gotten a better steak anywhere.  Collard green, carrots, baked potato and French onion soup, all good as well.  Get the blue cheese dressing for your salad; it's amazing and definitely not out of a bottle!

The chica made a crucial mistake and ordered some seafood and a "CHOPPED STEAK," whatever the hell that is.  Her food was good, but her eyes were green with envy after sampling the real steaks from around the table.

Ordered a bottle of wine from 1979 for a steal!

Had the KIND MIDAS (carrot cake) for dessert--very good.  Moist and served with macadamia nut ice cream!  But the dessert wasn't nearly as good as the CAPPUCCINO YBOR.  One of the best coffees I've ever had!

Do a kitchen and wine cellar tour!

Service was fantastic.

4 adults with a bottle of wine and an appetizer for $260.  What a deal!

Like many others have said before me, Erin Rose is a great place to seek refuge if Bourbon Street becomes too overwhelming. 

Erin Rose seems to be a non-touristy dive mere steps from the most touristy area in the city. The crowd seemed to be mostly service industry folks, a few tourists (that must read yelp), and me. While I didn't feel completely out of place, I did feel like an outsider. The bartender was friendly, but seemed more concerned with other orders than fulfilling mine. I assumed they were regulars so I understood, but at least try and make me feel welcome.

Prices were reasonable considering how close it is to Bourbon. I will probably be back the next time I am in the area and need a break. My normal bar for refuge is a block or so away, but sometimes only a dive will fit the bill.

Seems like an odd location at first, but it really is not that far from Westchase and all those other restaurants and hotels to the south and west on Tampa Road are not far away either.

No doubt I like this location significantly more than the one in Centro Ybor in every possible way.

Parking is more plentiful than it looks from the road although all those signs posted about not parking on the grass suggests they may not have enough when they attract a capacity crowd.

The interior is much larger than it appears from outside as well, and the design is very modern and comfortable.

Bar runs long, high-top table runs just as long right next to that and table seating fills the rest of the room.

Outside offers a modest size tiki bar with lounge/patio seating surrounding it.

As you would expect, there is plenty of craft beer to choose from and something they call a Mug Club to save regular visitors some money. There's also a bartender named Olivia who is good at making customers happy.

While I'm not a regular wine drinker, the fact that eight wines are offered "on tap" was a new and interesting thing to me.

From a menu standpoint, this TBBC features a good selection of apps, salads, burgers, pizzas, calzones and dinner plates. Portion sizes do justify the price.

As a soft pretzel snob, I am extremely impressed by the Moosekiller Barleywine mustard dip that accompanies this item. 

If they ever sold this by the growler, I might buy that to take home in bulk.

Delicious dinner with lots of food, but I prefer just coming for dessert.

I now have a theory that dinner is so expensive, because of everything you can add on to the meal.  The steaks come with onion straws, vegetables, French soup, baked potato and salad already.  But, let's say their standard salad doesn't tickle your fancy, you can get another one.  You rather have lobster bisque? Done, at a price.  All these changes are what adds on more money.  And then, of course you have to have wine.  That's when the budget is blown out of the water.  However, if you just go in for steak and the sides that come with it, you can walk out paying about $120.  That still isn't considered "affordable", but it sure won't break the bank either.

The steaks come with a ton of food as I mentioned earlier.  I loved the French soup.  I think that soup should always come in that little size, so I can try more.  I chose the macadamia vanilla vinaigrette and did not care for it.  It was too sweet for a salad dressing.  I tried my husband's Caesar and it was much better.  I went with the Delmonico, 8 oz, medium rare.  I first asked for very rare, but I was told that for the Delmonico I'd want to go medium rare, because the high fat content makes it chewy if it is not cooked long enough.  Fair enough.  I'm glad I took his advice, but I learned that I like rareness over fat (if that makes any sense).  Therefore, next time I'll probably go for a different cut and get it very rare.  I do love eating fat and they kept the fat on the steak for me.  The onion straws were my favorite part of the meal.  Perfectly seasoned, I'd be happy eating it every day.  The vegetable of the day ended up being carrots and green beans.  We were surprised that there were almonds in the green beans, since they didn't ask us if we had any allergies.  Luckily, my husband is allergic to pistachios, not almonds, but it was still kind of a scare.  The green beans were fantastically seasoned.

I couldn't finish all the food.  Normally I would never order a soup, salad and baked potato.  I ended up taking about half home.  You won't walk out of here hungry

The décor of this place is very dark and it is cold.  If this was any other place, it would be considered gauche, but it just kind of works here.  I'm glad I had a scarf to wear over my dress.

Our reservations were at 7:45 p.m. on a Tuesday.  We got there at 7:30 p.m. and were seating at 7:42 p.m.  No point in getting there early.  The valet is quick and efficient.

We did the kitchen tour and the wine cellar tour.  That was a one and one type thing.  I feel like I don't need to see their kitchen or wine cellar again.

Overall, I enjoyed my meal.  I do enjoy a good steak, but I still think the dessert room is what shines. (you can see my earlier review of the dessert room).

We were throwing a surprise "sprinkle" brunch for our friend. It was a party of 10. We wanted no lines and somewhere we can make reservations. That's a tall order on a Sunday in Philly. Talula's Garden was the place, a local farm to table. A STUNNING restaurant. A Steven Starr. From the valet guys chasing my hat that flew off and grabbing onto balloons we brought for her down Washington Square, and the hostess who was as sweet as could be to our adorable waiter that went above and beyond, the service itself was top notch all the way. The only thing that boggled my mind was that they were a farm to table that didn't have a salad on the menu. Hmm. That's crazy! My friends were ordering up their steak and eggs and pork belly with beet salads. Their gourmet cheese plates on classic slate trays (I asked our fantastic waiter where they were from...Brooklyn Slate. I bought a few for when we have company. I'm obsessed with charcuittere). Anyway,   I selected accompaniments from other dishes they serve and asked for them combine them on a bed a greens. Here's the custom salad they so graciously created for me. It was delish and I felt so special. Caramelized brussel sprout slaw with smoked honey crisp apples and roasted Kennet Square mushrooms in a sesame ginger vinaigrette. It was perfect! We dined at a big farmhouse table and laughed all afternoon. The drinks were flowing...I had a fantastic Rose', the Bloody Marys were perfectly spicy, fresh squeezed orange carrot juice and I ended my meal with the most delicious white peony tea in a perfect pop of neon tea pot while the girls enjoyed lemon cake, sundaes and dark chocolate salted caramels Eric, our handsome knight in shining armor waiter had specially made for the table. I cannot end this without taking about the decor. Clean and classic subway tiles, candles in over sized tins on the floor, live plants, books and pops of color. Completely rustic yet modern. The gardens is obviously what Talula's Garden is all about just check out the pics below. I'm excited to come back and sit outside at night. A five star, A plus experience all around. www.Talulasgarden.com

Really, really good food. Id recommend sitting upstairs though because the tables downstairs are very tight downstairs.

The bruschetta app was great, the veal lasagna looked really tasty and I personally can vouch for the shrimp orrichette pasta. Huge shrimp, great sauce and large portion. Do note that the entrees do not come with a salad though.

Penang is a long established and reliable Malaysian Restaurant in Chinatown.  It was the first restaurant in Chinatown with an open kitchen and a sleeker modern look.  However this look is beginning to fade a bit and a little paint and updating might be in order - inside & outside.  Fortunately the food is still very tasty.  The Achat veggie appetizer is extremely large and all good.  Share it or take some home with you.  Nasi Lemak (the national dish of Malaysia) is always a prime choice here.  Just make sure to get sambal to go along with it as you would in Kuala Lumpur.  I have never found service to be overly friendly at Penang ... but it's def competent.  Penang should be your go-to Malaysian restaurant in Philly!

OK, I just came from another visit to my new favorite local bakery.....paid $6.37 for a guava breakfast ring (8" diameter) a guava pastry, a large elephant ear, and 2 cafe con leches.  Incredibly low prices for wonderful breads and pastries.  This is part of the La Teresita mega-food complex,  with the bakery now in the building that housed the original lunch counter for decades.   It is a relatively small space so they cannot offer the variety available at Florida Bakery or Alessi''s but what they do, they do exceedingly well. The bakery also has a few stools and a walk-up window for coffee or food from the next-door take-out section of the main building.

The bakery is managed by Frankie, grandson of the founders and he nearly lives there.  So drop in, have a cafe, and chat a bit it they are not too busy, then take your delectables home.   Also look over their menu/list of catering packages with several bundles of nation favorites, sweets and savories ...Cuban, Colombian, etc.   And you can order custom-decorated sheet cakes with your choice of cake flavor, filling and icing.  They did a great caketop with a set of "Jump Wings" for an Airborne Vets meeting, based on an image I gave the cake maker.   Give them a try and challenge them with an order depicting the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.

The single most over rated restaurant in the city. I like the hot pepper chicken. That's it. I keep trying and I keep being disappointed . All hype no substance. He shouldn't believe his own press. Sad Dan Dan Noodles. Seriously , six times and always crushed by inconsistent Food.

I really wasn't that impressed. I admit, I only stopped by for a Hurricane and did not eat any food. The bar was very dark, had wood paneling and gave a warm feeling. I was expecting a true Hurricane glass, since I had read the story and understood how the name came about. Instead mine was served in a plastic tumbler like you'd get at a Saints football game for your beer. 

The flavor of the actual Hurricane was just a glorified Hawaiian punch. It was also the weakest alcohol drink I had during my entire weekend in NOLA. With all the  social buzz and popularity of this drink, I was expecting to be blown away. 

One positive note, I was able to sit along side a wall with a small rail for my drink and use an outlet to charge my phone. Also, it was very entertaining to watch a group of intoxicated men pick and organize their fantasy football teams. I saw more ass slapping then you'd see at a gay bar. They definitely were having a good time. 

Next time I'm in NOLA, I'll return to eat, but no more Hurricanes for me. For any type of Hurricane, once is enough. 

When: August 27, 2016
Why: Hurricane

I think everyone in Philly knows about Famous 4th Street Cookie Company in the popular and beloved Reading Terminal Market.  When you are a kid you beg your Mom to stop by this stand to pick up a few treats that are so tempting they never make it all the way home - you eat them right away!  Well Famous 4th Street Cookies are still as popular today as ever. Great cookies aren't inexpensive and these run about two bucks a cookie - much costlier than a nearby Beiler's doughnut. But still there are times when a tasty cookie is called for. My recommendation is the white chocolate cranberry or the white chocolate macadamia nut.  Hey and don't leave any crumbs behind!

SugarFire Smoke House is such happy place. Every time I visit, all the employees have smiles and true happy faces. Hell, even all the diners are happy. Why shouldn't they all be happy? They're serving and eating the absolute best BBQ not only in St Louis County, but they beat all the city places, too. 

I've put on some pounds, I like to refer to them as my "Yelp Pounds". To drop these pounds and get back to my "Pre-Yelp" weight I've gone low-carb. SugarFires' menu makes it easy to follow the low-carb lifestyle. Today I had an amazing lunch. I choose the Meat Daddy, which is two meats and two sides. As always, the brisket and turkey were fork tender and smoked perfectly. I've recently developed a love for Kale, so one of my sides was the Kale Caesar (I picked out the croutons) and Collard Greens was the other. I've always thought Collard Greens looked nasty, so I never tried them until today. I wish my mom was still here, so I could tell her I finally tried Collard Greens and liked them. Since they were my first, I can't say they are the best, but I can say they turned me on to a new vegetable and that is amazing.  

So glad SugarFire is spreading their "Ribs" and opening new locations. I wish them the best and I will continue to be a regular at the original location.

I just read my review from over 4 years ago and funny I see I had ordered the same flavor cheesecake as then. Oh wow time flies, but I swear I've become more a creature of habit. This time around again was the white chocolate raspberry cheesecake. A few weeks ago we went to the one in Sarasota.
