Remind you we hadn't been in years and I'm back again from a visit not too long ago. I tried their ghirardelli cherry chocolate cheesecake. That was a seasonal special and it was so good. How can anything here not be good. 

I love their passion fruit mojito here too. Anything passion fruit for that matter. I went on lunch time with my friend. We sat in the bar, but there were a bunch of booths open so it definitely wasn't the weekend packed that I always see it is.

I need to come back for lunch and eat something besides cheesecake and my favorite mojito. 

They also have a nice outside section for when summer finally ends lol!!

I can see why this place gets mixed reviews. 

First night, Thursday came for sushi and sat at the bar, Service was painfully slow with no personality whatsoever. Sushi was ok, to good, drinks slow to come.

Friday night came for dinner, sat inside at a nice booth in dining room, had great service, good wine and delicious dinner. Waiter made sure I got a free entry into the club so I could watch "disco inferno" Hilarious! Bartenders there rocked the drinks! Served in a plastic cup, excuse me I'm neither 23 nor drunk can I have a proper glass. OF course! And lots of bourbon was consumed.

Saturday back for sushi. Sat at table with different server, drinks and sushi. All was adequate. Went to the bar for a drink and saw said bartender from night before who remembers my drink, luv ya! Then midnight they start clearing out chairs. Huh?? Oh its turns into a college kid filled romper room apparently. Drinks in glasses Don't even think it. I quickly departed to my suite to enjoy client purchased champagne

Sunday, ugh, foggy, need food, crawl to the outside bar where brunch is just finishing. (Which I would have indulged in if I could) Ordered sushi, was the worst driest most horrible nasty thng to ever enter my mouth.  Returned it promptly when server recommended the jerk wings, trust me for a hangover you need bar food. OK, so a few wings later, couple coronas, I;m back in fighting shape. 

Definitely a great place to hang on a sunday afternoon, watch the games, have some drinks on the deck. Id avoid on a club night, good place for Fridays too though.

I was graciously invited to return to On Swann for a meal on the house, which was very much appreciated. This meal was truly wonderful - the food, the service, the experience, all top notch. Victor was our server for this visit and he was excellent (along with the manager whose name escapes me and business partner/owner Chris). Victor knew the menu front to back, and was very helpful in making our selections. And our favorite server Gary even came out to say hi, which was very nice. Every dish was delicious...we had the marinated octopus special, bacon wrapped dates special, zeppoles with ricotta corn dip, cauliflower, short rib pasta, cobia, and pana cotta. Our favorites were the cauliflower and cobia, but every dish was truly delicious. We are so appreciative that we got to return to On Swann and see all the restaurant has to offer. We will certainly be back in the near future.

Although I live in Philly, I can't stand baseball.  Far too boring for me.

However, this stadium is enough to keep me occupied for 3 hours.  Every seat is a good seat.  There is such a wide array of food & drink to choose from.

Over 4 years since my last review. My new review describes my experience here at dinner time on 7/21/2017. I waited in line for about 10 minutes with my 90 year old grandmother. When we got to the front I sent her to pick out a table because she was ready to sit down. I ordered a pulled pork sandwich with fries because the sides looked to be sitting around the steam trays for hours. I ordered my grandmother the 4 ribs plate with coleslaw. I delivered our food to the table and got the drinks. The place was so crowded we both had to sit on the same side of a 4 top because the other table was too close for anyone to make it in between. My pulled pork was so dry. I ate half covering it in the different sauces and then gave up. The fries were cold. There were so many flies buzzing around we kept swatting at them while we were eating. The majority of the lids on the BBQ sauce bottles on our table needed a wipe down. No one wants to see dried sauce all over the place. The majority of the tables needed a wipe down. It wasn't happening as the tables turned. The floor was slick between the tables. It was a 100 degree day but it was about 86 degrees inside here at 6pm. I was so hot I broke a sweat. You can read the thermostat while you're in line. Unenjoyable atmosphere and bad food.

We have seen many Trader Joes at different locations but never have a chance to go into one. The first Trader Joe's we have seen is at Atlanta near the Ah Ma Kitchen a year ago. We were curious what kind of the grocery store is that.

After the nearby UYE event, we have a chance to actually have the first hand experience in this grocery store. The people who has shop there are 70% skinner than me. That tell me the food there is organic, gluten free, or healthy food. My friend warns me about the parking space. It is better to go there at off hours to get a parking. At the entrance they already have some food taste. When you walk into the store, the herb plants are on the side of the entrance. I like mix herb plant because they are the fresh ingredient for cooking. You just need to plug a few of them when you need it for cooking.

The grocery store is not as big as Publix or whole food. But they do carry enough material for cooking. We have bought the Seasoned Rack of Lamb (all natural), Rice drink, Seasoned Kale Chips and the Bacon end tip. The price is reasonable here compare to many place. The end tip bacon is 3.65. After remove the fat, we still have a lot left for the lean meat. The dessert tasting is provided at some time. Some good some tasteless due to too organic ingredients. 

I would recommend this place due to the quality, pricing, and healthy living.

Have been meaning to get here for a while, and now i will definitely return.    This is probably tied for best of BBQ in Tampa.  The smoked flavor of the burnt ends almost was good enough to skip the excellent sauce.  The well-sauced baked beans were the best i can recall anywhere, ever.  Biscuits and slaw fine as was my wife's pulled chicken and cornbread salad.  The fried pickles were the only ho-hum item, and they even gave us a free sample of holiday peppermint cake to entice further indulgence.  We resisted but the many optons in their open bakery were wonderful.  Fast service and short line on a weekday afternoon and plenty of seating options in the airy dining room.

Four stars for outstanding customer service. Manager reached me and apologized for the service. I went there today around 5:30 and greeted with super friendly staff and manager who gave very efficient service. The people on the evening shift is different than the morning crew. The service is like day and night. I feel like I was at different store.   The manager again apologized for the previous service.

If you go there around 5:30 and you are lucky you can get cookies for $1 each. Maybe I should change my visiting time to afternoon

I'm glad that our visiting Portlanders wanted to go to Happy Hour here and partake of those 50cent oysters. It helped erase the memory of my last meal here (see previous review). We were seated in the overflow back room which was lovely...and much quieter than the main space. (Seriously, Luke, consider some sound reinforcement; your main dining room is beyond "lively" and into painfully loud when it's busy.)  I enjoyed my 1/2 price old fashioneds and as I'm not so big on the raw oysters, I ordered a delicious beet salad. And shared fries with the group.

Our server was lovely and handled a capacity crowd on Ash Wednesday with ease and grace. Our orders came out in a timely fashion and if there was a delay (with our 2nd batch of oysters), we were given more information. And of course, the company, Merilou, Melvin, Lindsay & Vicky was outstanding.

Stopped in here after an 8 month hiatus.

Hostess seemed annoyed with us asking for a table.

Ordered the gumbo.  Tepid but tasty. Onion soup also was not hot.

Meatloaf was good and a large portion.   Mussels were well done.  There were 20 of them.  Fries were tasty but the aioli was made with cheap commercial mayo.

Service was fine.  

I am disappointed that this place has taken a downward trend since it first opened and we would come here every two weeks or so.

I returned to Prohibition Taproom for some pre-concert eats and drinks.  Happy hour was from 5 - 7 but since everyone in my group was drinking bottled beer, we did not benefit from the specials.  Still, the beer selection is very fairly priced.  The bartender was friendly and effortlessly handled the entire bar on her own, which was no small feat as mostly all of the stools were taken.  

Between four of us, we had the hummus plate, deep fried green beans and onion rings.  There was more than enough food and we didn't even come close to finishing everything.  The hummus was very good, as were the green beans, which came with some sort of garlic dipping sauce.  I highly suggest investing in some Altoids if you plan to order either of these plates.  The onion rings were really thick-cut and almost a little too onion-y.  The dipping sauce seemed like a cross between ranch dressing and vinegar.  It was pretty potent and I'd probably lean towards ketchup in the future, but that's just me.  

I shall return.

First of all, after over 2,600 reviews here, I'm not sure I can tell you something new. 

But I'll say this. While eating brunch here this past Sunday, I debated whether this was 5 stars or not. 

I mean, everything was truly excellent. But I think I could find more creative brunch offerings out there. Nothing struck me as overly creative here. 

But it hit me as I was eating my sandwich. I went with the basic chicken club. And every ingredient seemed to be perfectly fresh and made just right. No flaws whatsoever. 

That's when I realized. It didn't need to bowl me over with creative flavor to be 5 stars. Basic food executed perfectly got that distinction this time. 

I mean, I spent over $100 on brunch for two after tip. And I absolutely feel like I got my money's worth.

That's not easy to do. But they did it.

Neil Sedaka use to sing a song about, "Breaking Up Is Hard To Do" and he was  so right. Ted, we've been together so long that it breaks my heart that I have to tell you that there is now another custard in my life. I've tried to see both of you, but after our last outing I just can not do it anymore. I am leaving you for Mr. Wizard. 

While I was seeing you both, I admit I was doing comparisons ordering the exact same thing to see which one would satisfy me the most. Mr. Wizard was slowly taking the lead and when I compared the Cherry Chocolate Chip Concretes,  he knocked it out of the custard ballpark. However, what really pushed me to the Wizard was the melting, or the not melting. 

My drive from Mr. Wizard to home is 2.5 miles and his custard is still firm, thick and ready to be enjoyed in the comforts of my own home. My home from you Ted is 1.2 miles and with  the air conditioning blasting, your custard is soup when I get home. We can drink our concretes. Also, Mr. Wizard is blending my ingredients better and the finished product has a better presentation. 

We were together 35 years Ted, so I'm still going to give you 3 Stars. Plus, you are an institution on Route 66 and all the tourist coming to STL need to experience you. However, Mr. Wizard is now my Custard Man.

Mmm...street tacos. 

After stalking this place thanks to my fellow yelpers, I made a mental note to visit on a Friday. While out and about doing errands, I stopped in to give it a try. I'll be honest, I'm all for hole in the wall places, but if I hadn't read such great things on yelp, I probably would have kept on driving. It is nothing from the outside. 

The inside is small, but clean. The reason why I wanted to visit on a Friday was because they have tamales on Friday and Saturday. When I got there a little after 1pm, they informed me they had 1 pork tamale left and 3 chicken. I snatched up the pork before they could sell it to anyone else. I also orders a carnitas taco and a ribeye taco. 

Everything was great!  The carnitas was my favorite and I plan on going back to get their chicken taco and try a sope. 

I really liked this place and it's simple, yet perfect menu.

Stopped by on a Monday evening to have a pre-dinner cocktail with Erin and Tim G. I really wanted to come to try the Dark & Stormy they raved about and also the summer salad, which Erin raved about. 

I was seated quickly and offered a menu. It isn't that big, but there area  couple things that were of vegetarian appeal. Since this was just the first stop of the night, I decided to try everything the G's recommended: Dark and Stormy, salad, and rice & beans. They came fairly quickly and they were all delicious. The drink definitely tasted like ginger ale. Yum! I was offered more but stuck to one so I could drink more at our next stop and be safe. The salad was fresh, full of fruit and cheese, and with yummy dressing. The rice and beans were spicy, but not too much. Good recommendations! 

The place wasn't busy at 5:30pm on Monday but more people were trickling in as we were leaving. Got the check when we asked and we were off to our next spot!

I might as well add my review of this New Orleans staple to the pile.

Pat O's is the place that every tourist wants to go because they have heard about the legendary hurricane, how strong it is, and how it goes down easy.  You already know that.

Easily, my favorite part of Pat O's isn't the hurricanes, it's actually the people.  Yeah, like you!  Whenever I go here I always make a bee line for the piano bar.  Two players banging out requests as the crowd sings along with them. Oh, the hurricanes might bring 'em in, but the piano bar will bring 'em back.  I don't think I have ever seen them stumped.  You could probably request a Lil Wayne song and they'd play it by ear for you.  

The Christmas party that happens every Christmas night is legendary.  Everyone is there.  You better dress to impress, because you are guaranteed to run into old friends (and enemies, and exes) that you haven't thought about in years.

The bartenders are the best in the biz and they are always friendly.  After all, they get to work at one of the most famous bars in the country.  Years ago (right after Katrina), I briefly dated a bartender at Pat O's.  He explained to me that working there was a privilege and you can understand what he meant as soon as you walk in the door.

So I had to return to this over rated place due to a business associates staying nearby. Oh where to start. I guess I should be uber impressed I'm sitting by some football player everyone knows (except me who couldnt' care less) and eating a $15 shrimp cocktail, followed by a $32 piece of tuna, but I'm not. Nor was I impressed by a bathroom attendant at 7:00 on a Tuesday hovering around for tips. The $14 margarita was good, but was it worth $14??? NO. My associate ordered the $40 rack of lamb ordered medium that came out still bleeding to death. When she brought it to the servers attention he had the nerve to say "well really that's how it should be served" I thought she was going to blow a gasket! Of course the steaks are al a carte so she had the $8 baked potato on the side, rolled in so much salt you couldn't even cut into it without covering the inside in salt. So $250 I got a mediocre meal, an overpriced drink, a fairly well disappointed associate and the floor show of ass kissing the unknown football player to my right. You can guess if I'll return!

My husband's family and I had fun at The Florida Aquarium, but the ticket prices are outrageously expensive.  The aquarium is not that big so it took less than two hours for us explore the entire aquarium.  For $175 you can dive with the sharks.  I understand scuba diving is expensive, but this is ridiculous!!! Normally when you go scuba diving you get to spend an afternoon on a boat and get fed lunch for this kind of fee.

Overall, our visit was nice and we saw some beautiful fish.  The exhibit that stood out to me the most was the coral reef.  We took some realy cute pictures in this area.

Would I go back?  Maybe if I had kids.  I would probably go to the zoo instead since you get a longer experience at a much cheaper price.

Talula's Garden has superb ratings for a reason. It has the whole package of exquisite food, polished service and perfect atmosphere.

For an anniversary celebration, my husband and I made a reservation and were able to get a garden table. 

We took an untraditional approach to our meal by splitting everything and not paying attention to course conventions. For example, we shared the cocktails in order to try more. We also shared the summer tomato soup, two pasta dishes, a chicken dish and dessert. It was the perfect amount of food for two, gave us a good sampling of the menu and didn't break the bank. Had we each ordered an appetizer, pasta, entree and dessert, it would have been way too much food and cost a pretty penny. 

The atmosphere was rustic classic meets modern elegance. Between the garden and serve-ware, the themes pulled through. Everything about the meal and experience were top notch, and Talula's Garden is a Philly special occasion must-do.

Looking for amazing Mexican food and margaritas in Center City? Look no further than El Vez! Seating is available outside in nice weather as well as inside the restaurant at booths, tables, or at the bar.  Came by for food and margaritas one night after work with my boss and his partner and I was very pleased!  Started out with some shareable chips and guac and a frozen blood orange margarita, followed by a Granada margarita and the open face chicken tinga quesadilla (from which they kindly omitted the onions for me; I was very grateful!).  Tends to get crowded especially in the evenings and on weekends, so there may be a wait upon your arrival, but there's a photo booth where you can pass the time taking fun pictures!

What problems!  What hassle - the cecutiry lines are miles long.
Better allow for lots of extra time.

The parking costs a bundle (as with all airports) and once inside the shopping is mediocre and over-priced. ($3.00 for bottled water???)
They have you TRAPPED.

Supposedly an airport "spa" is set to open.  Maybe that will help.

The bathrooms also need more frequent cleaning.

And don't even get me started about holiday travel.  Ugh!!!!!

I'm so obsessed with Han Dynasty, the authentic Sichuan spot!! This is by far their most striking location, as it's housed in historic Olde City in a converted bank! They leave just enough original details for you to get that feel. 

The food is incredible!!! All items on the menu are rated on a spiciness scale from 1-10, but they are always willing to adjust to your preference. Seriously, don't be afraid if spice isn't your thing. We bring our children here and have never had an issue "dulling down" the kick for them. If you do like spice however, you will be a kid in a candy shop here! 

Their signature dan-dan noodles are a MUST!! They are perfectly spicy and peanut flavored. They're really quite outrageous!! 

We absolutely love the garlic eggplant, the mapo tofu and salt and pepper shrimp also. Can't go wrong with any of those!! (Just a heads up, They will deliver the minced pork, which comes atop a few meals on the side if you ask) 

They offer super reasonable lunch specials and some neat cocktails, too. I recently had the 'Empress' and enjoyed it thoroughly. It was lighter and refreshing. 

I will say service is never real friendly but the food is ready rather quickly. 

We most recently visited for my parents 45 wedding anniversary, and while there were no reservations on Open Table, I called and they accommodated us without issue. Don't hesitate to call if you don't see availability!!

Portions are decent and the plates are delivered family style. It's a great, fun spot for larger parties! 

This is one of the places Anthony Bourdain hit up while he was in town. Although a chain, the food is apparently as close to that offered in the city of the same name as you'll get here in the states. 

YUMMMMMMM!!!

Hope you have saved your appetite from your meal at Datz to walk next door to Dough. After all, in my world, dessert is the most important.

Dessert consists of various cupcakes like the salty caramel cupcake, to various donuts such as a fruit loop donut, to gelato like black cherry whiskey, or my favorite lemon lavender basil. Or smokey popcorn(weird, but yes) 

Are you parched from the Florida heat? Pick a coffee or a tea, or a shake, or a boozy alcohol filled shake. Satisfy your sweet tooth here.

On your birthday, get a free cupcake. Check in on Yelp and get a free gelato.  That's how I got my gelato. I picked the lemon lavender basil, and my hubby got the cookies and cream.

This place is pretty, super feminine, and comfy. Reminds me of Victoria Secret decorations. There's a table or two outside in the back if you have your precious furry doggy family member with you.

Trader Joe's has finally come to Tampa, and after all of the waiting I can assure you that the store is worth the hype. Yeah, it's gonna be crazy crowded for the next several weeks, but once the initial frothing-at-the-mouth-must-have-cookie-butter mania subsides we still have a pretty phenomenal marketplace located a few blocks south of Kennedy off of Dale Mabry. 

The store can be found about half a block off of Dale Mabry on Swann Avenue, in a refurbished space that used to house a health club. There is a small parking lot adjacent to the store that holds about 70 vehicles, and once that's full you're on your own to find a space. Many of the enterprising neighbors are renting parking space on their front lawns for $5, or you can park in the lot at the Christ the King Catholic Church about a block away and say a few "Hail Mary's" as you walk back towards Trader Joe's. I would imagine that the parking issue will settle down in a few weeks, and it'll be just like any other business in south Tampa.

You'll feel the vibe as soon as you walk through the front doors at Trader Joe's. There are a lot of staff members roaming the aisles, restocking the shelves, answering questions, and helping people find various items -- and they are all laughing, joking, and having a great time. In addition to everything else, this is a FUN place to shop!

Down the right side of the store is the produce section with lots of all-natural and organic fruits and vegetables. I picked up a bag of kale greens for $1.99, along with an assortment of mushrooms, leeks, and peppers before moving down to the back right corner. Today they were demo'ing how they manufacture Speculoos cookie butter which is an insanely delicious spread made from crushed cookie biscuits that tastes just like gingerbread. I forced myself to have a sample so I could report on the creamy texture to my good friend, Chris W. After one small spoonful I was saying "OMFG!!!!!" (which means "Goodness but that is mighty tasty, I think I shall have another sample just to be sure")

Around the corner and along the back wall are the deli meats, cheeses, dairy, seafood and butcher cases, and after that you start weaving up and down the aisles -- just like a trip to IKEA. You'll find cereals, grains, nuts, breads, pastas, tomato sauces, salsas, chips, cleaning and health & beauty items, pet foods, a big assortment of wines, and their legendary collection of canned, boxed, and frozen entrees. Here are a few examples from today's shopping trip:

TJ's brand organic marinara sauce @ $2.29
Frozen entrée - Indian Paneer Tikka Masala @ $2.99
Frozen entrée - Lamb Vindaloo @ $3.99
Frozen fried Japanese-style vegetarian rice with tofu @ $2.99
Frozen box of wild salmon burgers (4-count) @ $5.99
Frozen Thai Shrimp & Vegetable Gyoza @ $4.79

Add to that their legendary Charles Shaw Cabernet Sauvignon and Sauvignon Blanc wines (better known as Two Buck Chuck) @ $2.99 each, some natural cleaning supplies, and a few cartons of their TJ-labeled soup, and I was out the door for under $70.

Insanely good prices on lots of healthy food options. Most everything carries their private Trader Joe's label, so don't expect to find the big name brands. You're not paying for brand-name advertising, and so you'll find items that are a lot less expensive. Based on a quick reading of the food labels, they have minimal hidden sugars, salts, preservatives, and other experiments-gone-wrong from your sophomore Organic Chemistry class.

The folks working the registers knew that the place was mobbed today, and they helped make the best out of an agonizing situation. One of the cashiers climbed up on a ladder and hollered out "Hey look everyone I can see the end of the line! Wave to me if you're paying attention!!!" and other sorts of silliness. Everyone was so gosh darned friendly that it was tough to feel frustrated even when you stood in line for so long.

One word of caution, if you're not fond of screaming children then I would suggest going in the middle of the weekday when the little bambinos are locked away in school and the aisles are cleared of double-wide strollers. Oh, and watch out for roaming food bloggers who feel the need to artfully arrange the products so they can get a better photo while rudely holding up everyone else. Grrrrrrr!!!

Bring lots of patience and have fun at Trader Joe's.

I like Devil's Alley.  They have a nice, casual atmosphere, good service, and good food.

I had a half rack of ribs done dry-rub with BBQ sauce on the side.  My two side orders were the mac n' cheese and broccoli(so that I could claim a vegetable serving).  It was very, very good.

Their burger is edible but did not impress me.  

This is a very good place to go if you are in the area and are seeking reasonably priced, tasty bar food.

About 3.5 stars. Since the service measured up beyond the standard, 4 stars is given. Cooper Hawk has good wine collection. We did not try their wine because it was business lunch and need to get back to work. We were here for lunch and surprised the dining hall is almost full. Service is excellent even with so many customers. This is a plus. 

We started with their pretzels bread. This is great bread to have. When you hear the name of pretzel, you may think this will be tough bread to bite. But it turn out very good. 

My entree is the carne asada taco with tortilla soup. I think they need to work on this dish. The steak feel like cut and sit for some time. You can see the steak is dry compared to fresh cut steak. The soup is good. My friend has the Ellie Chicken Piccata. His dish is better. It accompanying with pasta and asparagus.

This airport mostly low ceilings terminals nothing fancy about it. It is functioning as terminals to connect. My visit mainly is for terminals 2 which is only delicate to Southwest Airline only. 

During arrival, it take a few turns to get to the exit and baggage claim. Design is not friendly for arrival. The luggage service take a while before it come out. 

The departure is better. From the gate to security check is not a long line. Since it is delicate only to Southwest Airline, the security do not need to share the line with other airlines. 

The concourse has many type typical store. Such as newsstand, kid world, and more. Restaurant is fast food and local breweries. Not bad. They have St. Louis Tap room. Local breweries.

This became my favorite barbecue place ever since Zeke's closed down in Overbrook some years ago.  My credo when it comes to good barbecue is that it shouldn't need the sauce to be good.  This definitely passes the test.  But, the sauce here is so damn good that you want it anyway.  Order anything and you'll be happy.

I'm SO glad this awesome bar is in my 'hood! 

My dad and I came here a few days ago for some post-workout eats. We were both STARVING, and The Post seemed like the best bet, and I've been wanting to try it for a while anyway!

The place is spacious, with tons of tables and flat screen TVs with every sports event imaginable on it. 

We seated ourselves, and a waitress quickly came over to take our drink orders. 

I appreciate that they had a nice variety of beers on tap, including Schlafly Oktoberfest, which is what I ended up ordering. 

Foodwise, we started with the wings. We ordered 20 wings; half with hot sauce, the other half with BBQ. I took the advice of my fellow Yelpers and requested have them baked for 50 cents extra. 

I also ordered the Philly Cheesesteak of the day, which happened to be a cheesesteak with cajun seasoning. 

The wings were delicious. I loved that they weren't super messy. They were super flavorful, even though the 'hot' variety barely registered on the spicy scale. 

The cheesesteak was also tasty, but I actually enjoyed it better as leftovers the next day; a quick zap in the microwave transformed the too-hard bread into something softer and more palatable. 

I checked in on Yelp for 20% off the bill. What a sweet deal! 

I will definitely be back.

Came here today for lunch so had to update my review since today's experience was just top notch and more than stellar thanks to Brandon and his staff!  If you recall, we had a slightly bad experience the last time we dined here due to some technology failure, however as I said in my past review that it wouldn't stop us from enjoying this wonderful place.  This is one of our favorite spots to dine although it's not close to home.

While on the way, I logged into the app and added our party to the waitlist.  When we arrived there was a line out the door to get in but appeared as though they were seating very quick today.  Waited in the line and once we entered they took my name, checked us off the waitlist and showed us to our table.  We were immediately asked by the hostess if we wanted waters which we agreed and they were fast to our table.  Brandon also came over to greet us and welcome us back in which was very nice.  Placing our orders was a breeze -- we are on Keto and we were happy to see that they had options available for us to dine here.  They brought out our chips and guacamole appetizer which I asked for cucumbers so that we could still enjoy the guacamole and salsas.  I ordered the chicken verde rice bowl with no rice and extra veggies and my hubs ordered the pork belly rice bowl with no rice and extra meat and veggies.  My daughter had the kids cheese quesadilla with a side of pineapples.  The waitress was VERY attentive despite how busy the place was (which they always are).  She made sure our drinks stayed topped off and checked in routinely to ensure we had everything we needed.  Very appreciative for the experience today and even stopped on the way out to let the manager know how wonderful the experience was and how great service was today.  We definitely left with full bellies and very satisfied.

The food here is just so full of flavor and the vibe of the staff and the way they clearly care for their customer's experience will now definitely keep us coming back here!!  Thank you Bartaco for the wonderful experience and great service.  If you've not come here before, you're definitely missing out on a Tampa gem!  Highly recommend; you will definitely not be disappointed.

My friend and I had brunch at El Vez on Sunday.  The prices on this menu are pretty reasonable, but after ordering one drink each (a bloody mary for my friend and a mimosa for me), plus an order of guac, things added up quickly.  

The guacamole was delicious as always.  I find it interesting that many people complain about the price or compare it to what you would get at Distrito.  Yes, it's expensive, but it's only a few dollars more than Distrito's version and they give you twice as much at El Vez.  I will continue to pay the inflated prices for what is easily some of the best guacamole I've had in the city or elsewhere (my mom holds the title of #1, though).    

For my meal, I had the huevos and chorizo, which is a build your own breakfast taco deal that comes with warm, soft flour tortillas, nicely portioned sides of guac, sour cream and pico, a large side of black beans and a generous pot of scrambled eggs with (surprise!) chorizo.  I never really got the whole breakfast taco thing but I'm starting to dig it lately.  I loved my meal and had more than enough food (I would suggest ordering two totally different things and sharing with your breakfast buddy).  

When my friend pulled a 15% off card out of the dregs of her purse, our bill dropped drastically and we felt that we got some major bang for our bucks.

Best airport ever. This airport is so organized and quick for being an international airport. Everytime I have friends come in, they say the same thing too.

In addition when waiting for friends and family to arrive, the arrival area is very organized, making sure all the cars waiting are in order so there are no gaps, etc. You can wait there as long as you need to, and just stand by your car. 

The security and traffic people are very helpful and cordial.

Lambert STL is not the most world class airport, but they just adopted a non smoking policy (about time) and following the 2011 tornado that blew out much of the airport, many improvements are being made.  Lambert is not an airport with great food choices, but  is small and simple  and easy to navigate through.  Lambert is also part of the MetroLink rail system that makes getting to downtown STL and other popular areas in the City easy.

Beautiful romantic candlelit restaurant. Came here for restaurant week. Tapas style so you get small, dense, and flavorful snack size bites. Great for sharing and if you like variety. Gotta try the ham croquettes. They were absolutely delicious. Hanger steak a la plancha was beautifully seared and tender on the inside. Madre e hijo was alright, a little bit too earthy and musty for me. Tocinillo de cielo was foamy and strong in pistachio flavor. Overall, the highlights were the croquettes and service. In between courses, servers would bus our table, and constantly keep the drinks pouring.

Service was pleasant and reservations were on-time. Overall, it was a tasty experience but would not go out of my way to come back. Each entree was around $35 and not a whole lot of food. We went with the scallops, salmon, a side of biscuits, and a chocolate overload cake. Everything was cooked well, but portions were pretty small and left still feeling hungry.

I have been to Kona Grill's happy hour on multiple occasions and enjoyed the sushi, hamburger sliders, and cocktails. The sushi rolls are on the skimpy side, but my expectations were low since the rolls were only $3 on the happy hour menu.  The food isn't anything special at Kona, but since they have daily happy hours and the restaurant is stumbling distance from our apartment the restaurant is a convenient place to grab drinks. 

I had no complaints on the restaurant until we had dinner at Kona Grill.  Our waitress was super friendly and attentive, but our meal was a huge disappointment.  I have never had such a terrible tasting and overpriced dinner! The steaks were poor cuts and overcooked and the seafood was mediocre at best. We ordered the lobster macaroni... $12 for a side dish that was bland and boring and had hunks of flavorless lobster thrown on top of the dish. Dessert was ok, but forgettable and very expensive.

My recommendation: Check out the happy hour specials in the bar, but don't waste your money eating dinner here.

Alma, you never disappoint me.  I hade my birthday party here in March (11 women with mucho mojitos, caipirinhas and many apps.)

Tonight however was a simple evening - executied perfectly.  A close coleague and I shared the divine thinly-sliced scallop ceviche - bright with tangy acidity.

We also shared (gotta have 'em) the tuna tartare tacos and royal palm dates.  A heavy but delicious bowl of duck confit fried rice - brimming with umami goodness, topped with poached egg and studded with currants and edamame beans.  And of course, a sweet side of maduros with a drizzle of crema.  (Who needs dessert?  Heck, who needs entrees? We were stuffed.)

Instead of dessert she had a Mighty Leaf tea and I got a delicioso cafe con leche.

What a meal!  What a night!

And fabulous service from the lovely lady who served us.   I wish i could remember her name, but I just can't.

Oh - and I had 2 virgin Clasicos and my friend had a black cherry caipirinha and a Clasico Mojito.

Still on top of its game.

Love you Doug-y baby!  Even though you beat my sorry a$$ on "Ready Set Cook" in 1996.  Poor me - I was paired with a wimpy pastry chef from California.

This place looked really solid for Sunday Brunch so I had it bookmarked to try with the lovely wife.  Low and behold a friend and business associate invited me to lunch on a Thursday.  

We showed up as they opened (11:30) and grabbed a two-top in the window. I would call seating here normal.  Not spacious, not tight, just regular.  Our waitress was quick to show up for our drink order and quick to deliver them. BTW; no alcohol here, just softer drinks. Throughout our stay the CUSTOMER SERVICE was excellent.  No problems at all.

There is a giant blackboard on the wall with specials and most of the usual small menu. Your waitress will also hand you a hard copy.  I would call the food here lighter fare.  You don't come here for a cheesesteak, or pasta with red sauce, or a jumbo carnivore pizza.  You do come here for delicious sandwiches and sides.  There is a burger on the menu and they will even add a fried egg and call it a Brunch Burger ($12).  Don't expect fries with that here.

I ordered a Turkey, Avocado, Bacon wrap with Chipotle Mayo for $9.  Instead of potato salad I paid an extra buck and substituted a small green salad.  It was all delicious!

My friend ordered an Avocado & Havarti Sandwich with cucumbers and tomatoes on black bread for $8.50.  It looked incredible and he declared it exceptional.

Just a note on the popularity of these folks- By 12:30 PM on a Thursday it was packed solid with people spilling out the door.  LESSON LEARNED; go early or be prepared to wait.

This is a great place to grab a lite very fresh tasting lunch and not need a nap afterwards!

Frozen custard is delicious! When I first moved to St. Louis Ted Drewes was on my list of places recommended by many locals. I can understand why. This is a touristy spot and even the locals come here and wait in line for their sweet treat! 

I remember my first visit very well. I had no idea how to order or what to order. I was so overwhelmed with the choices. While waiting in line I was reading the menu and asking for tips on what to order;  however, instead of trying to try something different I simply asked for a M&M Concrete; it was that simple. Thank goodness! I was nervous I was going to order incorrectly. 

Now that I have gone back a few times I have tried their Great Pumpkin and I also tried some kind of cherry concrete with dark chocolate. Both were really good, but I'll stick with my traditional M&M concrete since it is simple and sweet. 

If I ever have friends come to town I know I can take them here-I explain that the lines will be long and we just have to be patient. What's really funny is that even in the cold winter months people still wait in line-no way! Not me. I prefer to eat my concretes during the warmer months. 

Ted Drewes, I will come in the spring. Keep up the good work!

I guess Im destined to be happy with Piada about half the time. First time back in about 3 months. Ordered my typical Tuscan Piada and a pepperoni stick...out of pepperoni sticks once again before dinner rush? Thankfully they did have panchetta for my piada or we would have left. Sad, but they do have good food when you can get it. Once again I think their processes need tweaked or they need to follow the ones in place. You start running low on something you get more cooked asap. Maybe in three months they will have pepperoni sticks again but be out of pancetta.

This is the 4th different Thai place that has opened up at this location in the last 5 years or so.  From Thai Elephant to Buppha Thai to Nooddi Thai, this place seems to have bad luck.  

It just seems like we can't have nice restaurants in Delco.  Let's hope these new guys stick around for a while.  

So I ordered up some take out tonight to give them a shot.  I asked the gentlemen running the establishment a few questions.  They said the previous owners sold the place because they were running a lot of different places and having trouble keeping up with all of them.  (Translation to me meant that it wasn't making as much money as the others, but who knows?)  They also told me that they came up here from DC, and owned restaurants down there.  

Now, the important part.  I got the wife and I some spring rolls (3 for $5), myself some wonton soup (a pint for $5), her some Chicken Pad Thai ($11) and me some Massaman Curry ($15).  

So let's have some fun first off.  Since the menu for the previous owners is still online, let's compare prices.  Nooddi Thai used to give you 2 spring rolls for $4.25.  They had no wonton soup on the menu, but their soups for dinner were in the $5 range.  Their Massaman Curry was $13.95.  The Pad Thai was $10.95 for chicken.  so these guys are in the ballpark for what you used to get at this place with a slight bump up in price.  Not sure how that will affect them.  But they are a little cheaper than Heng's Thai who charges the same price for their Massaman, and $16 for their Pad Thai.  

Taste-wise, they did just fine.  I thought the Massaman Curry was tasty and creamy, but actually could have used just a little more kick.  The wife enjoyed her Pad Thai, and I enjoyed my tastes of it too.  The wonton soup was pretty basic stuff in my mind.  I did enjoy those spring rolls.  Just the right amount of filling.  

If I could, I'd be giving it 3.5 stars.  I need another meal or two to give them 4.

Everyone including me raves about the cookie butter but... I'm here to tell you they have other items just as tasty. The wild arugula, for example, is unbelievably flavorful and peppery. We buy it every time we come here and enjoy it on salads, pasta, and sandwiches. What is your favorite thing to buy at Trader Joe's?

Great restaurant.  Great beer.
 
This is one of those restaurants that can satisfy everybody so it's great for a group.  Don't let "Brewery" dissuade your friends that don't drink suds.  There are plenty of menu items that go well with other drinks.  Also there is a wide range of prices.  You can go cheap with an appetizer or two or high end with crab cakes at $25. 
 
Tip- Always make a reservation.  I suggest Open Table.

Jilly's is a famous lunch stop and cupcakery located at Delmar @ 170.  

It is set up like a fast food order at the counter eatery.  Once you figure out which door to enter, trying to figure out where to stand in line is no less confusing. The decor is sterile, but the cupcake display makes up for some of the design deficiencies because it is full of HUGE cupcakes  that come in many flavor combos and they are a work of art..  

 I haven't tried anything from the food menu at Jilly's, but I've had my fair share of the famous cupcakes.  Unfortunately, they are entirely too rich and over the top for my tastes. The cake that I have had was dry and the icing is crazy sweet and there is so much of it!  Overall, I find the place to be somewhat chaotic and pricey.  But, the cupcakes are pretty and there are lots of choices.

One of my favorite sandwich shops in South Tampa!  The sandwiches are huge so come with an appetite or a friend to share with.  Love the Golden Gate Sandwich and the Cuban Sandwich.  Good, quality lunch meat and the menu offers everything from creative and adventuresome sandwiches to classic favorites.  My favorite side dish: dill potato salad.  Favorite dessert: a toss between the cream cheese brownies or the lemon squares (yummy!).

Ella, Ella, Ella can you forgive me? I sure hope so, because I can't forgive myself!  I bookmarked you over a year ago, forgot about you and finally got to enjoy you and all you have to offer.
I went to this establishment with a group of about 30 people. We were ordering drinks and food at different times, moving around to greet old friends and still everything went off with out a hick up. Our server was the best, I am so sorry I can't remember her name, because she was phenomenal. 
Ella's is located in Seminole Heights on Nebraska Ave., just south of Hillsborough.  It is an old 2 story house that has artfully been refurbished into a great restaurant. They have a beautiful outside patio area, lit up with small white lights and plenty of seating, it looks so inviting. Inside it is decorated eclectic and is really quite fascinating if you take the time to explore.
I ordered the bacon wrapped meatloaf, what a treat. It was seasoned superbly,  moist and almost reminded you of a steak. The bacon was well done and added a bit of different texture and taste and it was topped with tempura with chives in the batter coated onion rings, totally delicious! 
This was accompanied by REAL garlic mashed potatoes and a medley of FRESH vegetables.  I must adress the vegetables as they were perfection! Most chains give you the frozen medley.  Here you get a bit of this and that, all fresh, all seasonal, all perfectly seasoned and cooked. The seasoning was fantastic and had the meatloaf not been so good, the veggies would have been the star of the plate.
Others got wedge salads of romaine that were fresh and delicious.  Pizza was a big hit with many and I heard no complaints about any food.
On to desserts,  here is the only mistake of the evening, besides very limited parking. I ordered the peach cobbler,  in keeping with have a great home style meal. It was served in a jelly jar warm with a small bit of ice cream. What a let down after a great meal. The small amount of crust was very doughy and undercooked and even worse the peaches certainally did not taste fresh. Their went the 5* review I had planned to give.
Ella's is a must try for one & all. Once you go, you will definately want to return.
What's a girl to do? Isn't dessert part of dinner?

I stopped in on Friday for another serving of the fish tacos.  I also tried the shrimp tacos this time as well. 

We started with the queso fundido.  It's yummy.  It comes out on one of those small fajita plates with warm tortillas for dipping.  This dish was gone in seconds.  Then to the entrees... The fish tacos are really all that and more.  I order an extra side of aioli sauce because it's so good.  The shrimp tacos were good too... but I'm not a big fan of the mango salsa, and it's used with this dish.  

Odd comment, but I like their glassware and dishes.  They're all odd and modern shaped which adds to the charm.

Great time on a Saturday at noon with carts. 

I hate waiting. I called about 11:45 a.m. on a Saturday to see if they were on a wait. We'd come before when it was packed and I didn't want to be stopped when I wanted to get my chow on. The woman on the phone said no wait so we hurried on in. When we got there, it was only moderately full. This is my favorite amount of people, not too many that I feel rushed, but not too few that make me question if this place is going to go out of business. 

When the first cart came around I panicked. I thought it would take forever to try the second so I got a ton of dishes, some I probably wouldn't have gotten. Don't be like me, know that the second card will be around shortly. Yes, there are only two carts so there is a limited dim sum menu, but you can order off the regular menu too, which is what we did. 

I always get something salt and pepper, usually the salt and pepper calamari. As always, it was delicious. I love the seasoning - it even has a kick to it. 

We always get egg tarts to end the meal. They are delicate and flakey. 

There were tons of parking spots open when we went. We will keep going on Saturday since there are less people there! Staff told me that there are more dishes on the Sunday carts, but I rather have less dishes and no wait.

Let's talk about the awesome experience I had at Zahav last night. 

It may have been Restaurant Week, but it was still business as usual at Zahav. Everything was seamless, from our party of six being seated as soon as everyone arrived, to our service, to the drinks and the food. 

I've dined at Zahav before, but after dining with a group of friends, I can easily say the experience is heightened when you have more to share. Our table was covered with food at all times, but these are the bites I tried for myself: 

-salatim and hummus with laffa (Delicious. I even enjoyed beets and fennel. Impossible!)
-fried cauliflower 
-fried potatoes with shishito peppers
-figs with feta and crispy eggplant
-crispy haloumi
-grape leaves
-kofte (ground beef and lamb meatballs)
-branzino served over rice and tzatziki (Fantastic!)
-chocolate konafi

I would order any and all of these items again. The food was spectacular! My server was also able to suggest a wine that would pair well with everything I ordered (a dry riesling). 

After everything, we were given ten dollars off cards for a future visit to either Zahav or Percy Street Barbecue. I can't wait for my next Zahav tasting. With friends.

This time around, the food was mediocre at best. 

I've always liked Tampa Bay Brewing Company in the past, as evidenced by my past reviews, but this time it really missed the mark for me. This was a shame, because I brought my sister with me who was visiting from out of town and this was not a meal I wanted her to think was representative of Tampa Bay.

I'll make this short and sweet for people who are reading this to learn what not to order - the lobster roll had too much sauce and the bison burger was overcooked.

LOBSTER ROLL - I've been on a lobster roll kick. For $18, this is a pretty inexpensive lobster roll. Now I know why, they rely on the aioli to try to make it tasty. I like the lobster to shine in my roll. Even though there was a good amount of lobster, it was overpowered by the sauce. I wouldn't order it again.

BISON BURGER - The burger was overcooked. My sister asked for it medium rare and it came well done. She sent it back and although they were fast at bringing out a replacement, there was still no pink to be seen. It was bizarre that they brought out another overcooked burger to compensate for the original overcooked burger. 

I like the atmosphere of the place. On a Friday at 12:30 p.m. it was a 15 minute wait inside, but outside was first come first serve. I've had issues with service outside in the past, but this time it was pretty speedy (even though we also had problems with our server forgetting to bring my sister her beer). 

Overall, I will come back because I've seen this place do better, but I won't make this a place to bring out of towners if I am limited on the number of meals I have to showcase this city.

Yeah, it's true.  I'm that girl who never got excited about a trip to Monk's. My first experience was so-so and one subsequent trip for a quick beer during last winter's snowpocalypse didn't win me over, either. 

For me, Monk's was a Philly fixture that blended with the urban landscape.

Why I heard myself suggesting the place as a lunch option the other day is still a mystery. Divine intervention? Perhaps. Because the pot of Ghent mussels, bathing in a Saison Dupont broth filled with bacon, leeks and blue cheese, were life-changing.

Also, it appears my previous gripe is null and void. Burgers are now served with a choice of greens or - wait for it - frites. Reunited and it feels so gooooood!

What can I tell you?  My partner loves Thai so we again have found ourselves at the best local Thai place.   For $45 with a 20% tip we enjoyed our favorite crispy duck salad along with a nicely spicy panang chicken and I tried a new entree, the soft shell crab with spicy chili sauce.   The panang is consistent in terms of the level of heat and portion size.   

The soft shell crab entree consists of two soft shell crabs, perfectly fried, tempura style, served with a spicy chili sauce, over a bed of mixed asian vegetables and a few broccoli florets, and of course, some white rice.  The sauce is served mostly below the crabs, but some is artfully spooned over them, which causes them to lose a bit of their crunch.  Nonetheless, a great value at $17.

I think the best value is when they run the soft shell pad thai special.   Also $17 for two deep fried soft shell crabs plus pad thai.  It's too much for one sitting so eat the crabs, some of the pad thai and have the pad thai for lunch tomorrow.

The only negative about this place is that they keep playing the same soundtrack and we go there often enough to notice.   Tonight they changed up the background music so it was fabulous.   

It is BYOB!

We are starting to see a bit more takeout business and hope that this place can sustain itself.

We came in here one night when we didn't want to wait out in the cold for ramen down the street.  I thought that it was well worth it.  

The Peking Duck was very good, crispy skill and juicy duck meat with scallion and plum sauce on soft buns.  I think that it typically comes with pancakes, but that you can ask for buns.  Make sure that you ask for buns, it's so much better. 

The Pork with Green Beans was so much better cooked that what I am used to.  This wasn't slathered with sauce.  It had little bits of pork in what tasted like roasted green beans.  Very meaty and tasty flavor. 

The Pork Buns were just okay.  Not a whole lot of flavor there.  I would recommend elsewhere for dim sum.

Service was a bit lacking.  We found ourselves waving repeatedly to ge the attention of servers.

After going to the Mad Decent Block Party that proved to be, for lack of better words, Mad Decent, my friends and I were craving some food and decided to seek out a brunch that was mad decent to go along with the flavor of the afternoon. Since I knew Cafe Lift was the closest spot it was my first to recommend. But alas it proved to be just decent.

I definitely see the potential that can lift this place higher. It does brunch six nights a week (closed Mondays), and it doubles as a nice coffeehouse, albeit a La Colombe which by now you know I find to be a mixed bag. But with bottomless cups during brunch it's something I can live with. It's also owned by the people behind Prohibition Taproom which I enjoy.

But the main area where I found Cafe Lift to be lacking was food prep. While I definitely found the potential to make it's menu excellent, there was something about the result that was more than a little inconsistent. The middle portion of my mushroom fritata was divine, especially the parts where you could really taste the gorgonzola. But the crust of it was so dry and bland that I found myself ravaging the center. The home fries style potatoes were excellent when they tasted like potatoes. But too many of them were overcooked to the point that they tasted like rubber!

So it goes without saying that the bar wasn't lifted very high. But it did have enough to merit curiosity. To be continued?

I'll start by saying the food is good, which is no light accomplishment in my mind.  Yet, immediately you'll ask why only three-stars for a place with good food.  I've said it in other reviews, but it is something I call the value proposition.  Its a combination of quality, portion, and price.  The prices are high, which is fine for high quality, but mix it with (extremely) small portion sizes, and I can't go beyond three-stars.

Distrito is Tapas style and I've heard great things about their drinks.  If you are in the mood for something light or want a stop before a serious dinner, go for it.  If you are hungry, either come ready with your wallet or make plans to check Distrito at a later date.

This review is for the what I tried: 

Mango mochi: the sticky rice dough is very thin and breaks apart, filled with refreshing mango sorbet. Not wort it.

Canele: pretty good, nice custard filling but lacks the crunchiness 

The assorted dessert: my favorite is opera cake, the others are meh.

You gotta love this place.  The unique selection, the Amish, VietNamese, Asian, Italian and American stands all crammed in together.  Sure it's a bit grimey and can get mobbed at lunchtime, but give me Iovine's Produce, Och's Chicken Breasts, Some Tom Kha Gai from Little Thai Market and a hot fresh macadamia nut cookie from 4th St and I am good to go.

It is a blessing to live nearby.

How could I have skipped my review of Trader Joe's. Trader Joe's is AWESOME, and it is on a special pedestal of awesomeness. Customer Service is awesome above and beyond. The store is smaller, and I like that in my opinion, bc you do not have to endlessly walk around looking for stuff. The food selections are different, and I feel like getting food here is like picking up food at some fancy dancy restaurant, but spending less money.
Lastly, Mocha Coconut my little doggie could sit in the cart, not disturb anyone and be able to be there taking in the Trader Joe's Awesomeness.
I can't forget the fact that Trader Joe's Dog Treats are the only dog treats he likes, and I am so serious of that. 
So happy to have finally gotten Trader Joes in Tampa. Thank you for  not making me truck to Sarasota spending tons of money and only getting to go a couple times a year.

I love this ballpark! Every time I'm here I have a great time. There really isn't a bad seat in the place, even if you sit up high. There are amazing views of the city but at the same time you enjoy the game from every angle.

We went for a game Friday night and it was beautiful weather wise. The staff is always friendly. As any other stadium, the concessions are really high. They do offer a sit down restaurant at Harry K's. They also offer Chickies and Petes, Tony Luke's etc. There is also an ample amount of parking. You can also take in small coolers, we took in 6 bottles of water and some snacks. 

If you're a baseball fan then this is a ballpark you shock check out. Solid 5 stars. Go Phils!!

OK, was in Phila.sunday.After having brunch my Good friend & I decided to walk off some of the food. Saw Di Bruno's, had to go. It seemed quaint, till I realized how Ginormous this location was, it stretched all the way to back, & around, plus upstairs-holy****!! Loved it. Had such more space then original in S.Philly, the cheese Guy was very knowledgeable, got some Gruyere cheese, he was personable, think his name was Dan. Anyway, great cooked, not cooked foods, salads, sides, if I worked in PHila, this would be one of my spots to get food for lunch, or anything. So much variety, there was bakery, then breads section, coffee , gelato-OMG!! Your just so overwhelmed!! Definitely go back!!

This is a great Italian restaurant in Indianapolis.  Although it is technically a chain (albeit a small one that originated in Chicago), it does not feel (or taste) like one at all.  All the food is extremely rustic and honest.

The head chef is a master at this craft and does several cooking classes a year.

This location also has a cool outdoor seating area and several banquet rooms.

Absolute best Vietnamese I've ever had! This is 1 of my favorite lunch/dinner spots. The location is great, garage for parking, good service, nice ambience for conversation & of course excellent food.

Besito describes themselves as a little kiss from Mexico, and that's definitely the ambiance you'll feel as you walk up to the front courtyard of this new restaurant in the Westshore Plaza area. Besito occupies the space that was vacated by The Palm steakhouse, though the entire restaurant has now been transformed into a high-class Mexican cantina.

Unlike most chain Mexican restaurants, Besito does not smother you with cheesy pictures of a cat wearing a sombrero, or the piped-in music stylings of 101 Strings playing your Mariachi favorites. Instead, the restaurant is classy and elegant, with a warm, romantic vibe. The wait staff was quick to our table with some very tasty salsa and chips to enjoy while we spent a moment studying the drinks menu.

I started my dinner with the Besito Patron Margarita, made with Patron reposado tequila, cointreau, pomegranate-tangerine juice, fresh, and freshly-squeezed lime. Happy Happy Happy! We decided to pair our drinks with the tableside-prepared guacamole, which was a fabulous show to watch, and even more delicious to eat.

I ordered the Iron Skillet Mixtos Tacos for my dinner, which was grilled skirt steak, chorizo, chicken, melted queso Chihuahua, nopales salad, avocado salsa verde, and chile de arbol salsa. This was a very delicious entrée, and there were oodles of leftovers to take home. They brought us some complimentary churros at the end of our meal, but I was honestly too stuffed to eat another mouthful.

After this delicious meal, I was most intrigued by the little "prayer doll / worry doll" that they gave to each of us. This tiny little figure was supposed to adsorb all of your cares and worries, and leave you free to enjoy the rest of your day. I have no idea if this actually works, but it was a unique end to a terrific meal.

Kalila beat me to this review! I was one of the people who camped out of IKEA last night so i pretty much slept all day yesterday after finally going through the store. The store was extremely nicely designed. The greeting from the workers was great and service at every part of the store was top notch. 

The first thing we did once we were inside was eat because our two in the morning snack was long burned off by then. We all ordered their meatballs with mashed potatoes and loved them. Though breakfast looked very convincing for only $1.99. 

The beds and couches were all very comfortable. We were trying them all out since we were so tired. The furniture looked nice as well, and some of the art pieces we saw downstairs were pretty cool.

On our way out, I saw even more food, a jumbo hot dog and drink special for $1.99 (normally what just a soda costs you), and plenty of other deals on food. The place really is enticing with its prices. 

My friends are IKEA fanatics so I'm sure I will be back even though I don't have my own home to furnish, but when I get my own place I'll be sure to stop by here and see what I can find.

I was surprised that I haven't written a review of the original Columbia since I've been quite a few times over the years.  This past weekend was one of my most recent visits.  Saturday nights are packed so reservations are suggested.  

We were seated in a side room and our server may have been having an off day as he had drink orders wrong, seemed very short when taking orders and finally delivering and collecting checks.  Food was great and in usual Columbia fashion.  Complimentary La Segunda Cuban bread is served for each guest along with butter.  Something new that I tried was the Rose Sangria, which seemed to be a blend of the white and red.  I had the Chicken Salteado for my entree and that is my staple dish when at the Columbia.

Cheap furniture and cheap food. Woo-hoo!

The money you spend on food goes towards the total of your same-day purchase.  So eat first!!!  There were 7 of us and we had a $48 food bill.  Unfortunately, we ate after we made our purchase, so I learned the hard way.  Some lucky couple got a $48 coupon though.

Why 5 stars? Because I was dumb originally rating it 4.

   ---   ---   ---

When I first visited Mazzaro's, I honestly had no idea what it was. I went straight to the hot sandwich counter, and just kind of walked through the rest of the market with my eyes closed.

In reality, Mazzaro's pretty much has everything edible that's ever been created. There's a great beer selection, they roast their own coffee beans, there's an entire room of cheese, it's a meat market, and they have all kinds of niche items like fancy olives and local honey.

This place is a Tampa Bay treasure, and I am ashamed of my original 4 star rating.

Last night I returned to Han Dynasty with a fellow fan and a newbie. We wanted to induct the new girl right, so we immediately suggested the dan dan noodles and cucumbers. Then she raised the stakes by ordering the dumplings in chili oil. Well played, rookie!

We each ordered a different entree and by the time our food arrived (pretty much all at once with entrees dropped just after the starters), we could have invited our respective men along and still had plenty to go around. I finally ordered the crispy rice with shrimp that I had long lusted over and it did not disappoint. The dish announced its presence with sizzling noises and the crunchy rice was incredible. I thought the shrimp were slightly overcooked but overall, I really enjoyed the dish. Kung pao chicken (the newb) was pretty standard although obviously far better than any take-out joint, and another chicken dish with hot peppers would have been really great if it hadn't been way too salty. 

Everyone's entitled to an off night and I've had so many great experiences at Han that I can't take away from them just for a couple missteps. Service was better than in the past, although I probably would have ordered another beer had someone stopped by after we received our food. No big, I just had more room in the tummy for some Franklin Fountain deliciousness.

I like Busch Gardens, but the park is pretty small compared to other amusement parks so that is why I would only rate it three stars.  That said, Busch Gardens has vastly improved over the years.

While Disney ticket prices have increased Busch Garden tickets have decreased dramatically.  You can now get a season pass for practically the same price as a day pass!  Busch Gardens most recent additions have been the Shiekra roller coaster, Cheetah Hunt roller coaster, Rhino Ralley, more shows, and more animals.

My favorite roller coasters are the Kumba and the Montu so I always try to ride them at the beginning of the day so I can avoid the long lines.  As I get older the Shiekra gives me panic attacks and I can no longer ride it, but if you are a thrill seeker you will love it!  The Cheetah Hunt is one of the more tame roller coasters and I can usually convince my mom to ride with me.  AVOID THE GWAZI!!!!  This is the worst ride in the park and will toss you around until you either get a headache or throw up.  Chiropractic adjustments are required after you ride!!!!  If you must ride this roller coaster save it for the end of the day or you will feel terrible for the rest of the day at the park.

For the 21+ adults there is a fun Busch beer class.  The class is about an hour long and you get to try a ton of free beer samples.  

I only think Busch Gardens will get better over the years.  They own a ton of land that they haven't developed yet so they can easily double the size of the park when they are ready.

Beautiful place.  I would recommend sitting outside. It's a lovely view. It is less loud. There's beautiful music playing in the background. The menu is quite diverse. The wine menu is even better. My friends from Chicago love this place and it has been around there a lot longer than here. Glad we finall6 have here to enjoy some greT wine flights and good food.

Friday evening birthday celebration with friends. We had a party of eight and our table was up front and in the center of things.  Our waitress (I didn't get her name) was attentive and very knowledgble of EVERYTHING. Any question we had, she didn't hesitate to answer anything. 

I was happy to have checked in on my YELP ap because I scored a free Appetizer (or sushi roll value of $14 or less) so I chose the Chicken Satay. It was well done and the cabbage salad beneath was amazing. The dressing was complex and very, very tasty, though the chicken was thicker than I'm used to having for Satay cuts. 

My entree was their pork loin, served with bok choy and mashed potatoes, and a sauce. I'd asked for the sauce on the side which they were very happy to do.  The bok choy was light and flavourful, the potatoes were a bit on the thick side but very tasty and the pork was seasoned perfectly. There was more than enough for me to eat on for the meal and to take home. 

It was a lovely location but sadly a bit too loud for our table set up. I wasn't able to comiserate with everyone, and that's on us - since we chose to sit the way we did. But all in all it was an excellent experience.

I know that i have reviewed Commander's Palace two times before, but my opinion hasn't changed and each time the experience is top notch.

David took me here for our anniversary dinner. We knew we wanted to the evening to be special, so he chose this spot to make it a night that we wouldn't forget. As you do, he called ahead and made reservations. We arrived about 20 minutes before our reservation and we were seated upstairs at a lovely table by a window.

Lorenzo was our waiter, and since he knew it was our anniversary, he made sure that our experience was special. When I told him that I wanted to drink a cabernet, he picked one out specifically and it just happened to be a wine that is made in France just for Commander's Palace- it was delicious.

For my appetizer, of course I got the turtle soup. The turtle soup at Commander's Palace is probably the best in the city and it never disappoints. For my entree, I got the redfish topped with crawfish tails. This was great! It was a nice portion of fish perfectly cooked and topped with crawfish tails in a sauce that was a little spicy. It was perfect without being too heavy or overly filling. David had the filet and mashed potatoes, which looked incredible. If I return, I just might have to get the steak.

For dessert, I ordered the pecan pie ala mode that David and I had planned to share, but Lorenzo was so sweet, he brought out some extra ice cream, since it was a special night. He was also kind enough to send some complimentary shots over to the table- I think they were made with champagne and they were really good.

Our experience was perfection and Lorenzo made sure that we had a wonderful dinner. From beginning to end, we felt really special and I am excited to return.

I was disappointed with Doma, I have had better sushi at numerous places.  I tried the snowcrab california, cucumber, eel cucumber, salmon skin, hamachi verde, island, and spring garden rolls.  The biggest disappointments were the eel cucumber and salmon skin rolls.  Both lacked the flavor that I have come to expect from these rolls, the eel was downright bland.  The hamachi verde roll was very good though, the sweet fruit mixed well with the savory fish and it had a nice texture to it.  The island and spring garden rolls were pretty bland as well.  

Miso soup was some of the better that I've had.  

The bulgogi steamed buns were pretty good.  The bulgogi was nicely spiced, but the buns were a bit dense for my taste.  

It's a small, posh looking place.  I'd be interested in trying more of their Korean over the sushi.

I've never eaten a meal here but when you just gotta have some cheesecake, they have a stupendous selection! For $8 a slice, you can get your choices of cheesecake to go and enjoy them in the comfort of your own home! Is there anywhere better than this for cheesecake in the Tampa Bay area? Not to my knowledge!

Their cheesecake is not as dense as the traditional New York variety but it's still quite good and they are happy to pack it up, label each slice (in case you order many like we did), and send you on your way!

Mmmmmmm.... Cheeeeeese Caaaaaake.... Mmmmmmm.

This is one of Tampa's newest and greatest restaurants.  It challenges the traditional restaurant concept by offering a wine gift area and tasting room as you walk in.  I'll start off by saying I'm not a big wine connoisseur, but the wines they offer are amazing.  

I've been here a couple of times already and have tried the wine tasting.  For $7 (or $10 with the souvenir glass) you get 8 tastings, enough to pay for themselves twice over.  I was very impressed with their Happy Hour specials which included drink specials and appetizer specials.

The food is decent and they even offer a lower calorie option.  The tortilla soup is to die for and I make sure to get it whenever I go.  Their dessert options are also amazing and for those of us that are watching our weight, they offer a varied chocolate covered strawberry assortment.  

Service has been hit or miss each time I've been, but I guess that can be expected of a new establishment as they try to ramp up to demand and get their processes in order.  I have definitely found one of my new favorite places in the Tampa Bay area with Cooper's Hawk.  Now if only they would open up more locations!

Parking can be a zoo. They charge $5 at the lot, but they give you a voucher for $5 off anything within AW. Good strategy!

It's definitely a cool looking space, and it fun to have so many options. However, it gets really crowded during the weekends, so it is not necessarily friendly to families with young kids.

I was wandering around the streets of Tarpon Springs to walk off my lunch at Mama's, when the incredible scent of intoxicating Greek pastries seemed to draw me into the bakery at Hella's. The place was full of tourists on a Sunday afternoon, and I passed the time by trying not to drool as I looked up and down the glass display cases and imagining which dessert I would attack first. I resisted the urge to order one of everything in the left-hand display case followed by two or three of everything else - their pastries are seriously that good! In the end I got a little sampler box with four different pastries - an amazing-looking fruit tart, a Greek cannoli, strawberry cheesecake, and somethiung resembling Death by Greek Chocolate. Since I knew I'd never make it back to Tampa without ripping the top off that box and inhaling everything inside, I took a seat and ordered a piece of baklava and a strong Greek coffee. Hella good pastires, and worth the short drive from Tampa!

As I sit here to write an updated review for Southwest Diner, I am staring at a stack of receipts from all of my visits. Honestly, I have close to two dozen. SWD is close to my home, they offer a quality breakfast and lunch at very affordable prices. They also have a frequent diner punch card, that rewards you for being a repeat diner. 10 punches and your 11th entree is FREE. 

If I had to pick a favorite from SWD, I would be hard pressed. However, I can say my go to is their, Jonathan's Famous Fiery Scramble. It's scrambled eggs that are served; spicy and cheesy. Along with your choice of a breakfast meat, home fries and toast. Even though the home fries here are tasty and well done, I do an even swap for Calabacitas. Since I'm losing weight, a side of Zucchini is more diet friendly then potatoes. Occasionally I cheat and enjoy the home fries.  Another favorite is the Greek Omelet and I have been known to add bacon. We all know everything is better with bacon. 

My favorite spot to sit is at the counter, right at the corner on the end towards the front door. 
It's comfortable and gives me a great view for people watching. Some of the other entrees that have graced my plates at the counter are: Medio Egg Combo, Desavuno Skillet, Rocket to Bacon Land, Bat Out of Hell and my own created omelet. If you're doing lunch, you have got to do the Double Green Chile Cheeseburger. You'll think you're in diner heaven. Also, always check out specials, during the summer I loved the Fried Green Tomatoes. 

Before I wrap it up, telling you that the service is always spot on and friendly. That they serve Kaldi's coffee and you'll never feel guilty enjoying a Bloody Mary on weekday. I gotta tell you about, Tamale Tuesday. Yes, you can get tamales for breakfast and lunch from the famous Tamale Man here at SWD. That my fellow Yelpers, is a double win. 

So glad Ian Froeb put Southwest Diner on his STL 100 List for 2016, it is well deserved. 

Would I come back? I do, time and time again. 

When: Too many times to list.......
Why: Mainly breakfast, but lunch too.

Our visit tonight was to celebrate my girlfriend's birthday with our husbands and she chose Maggianos. They dine here occasionally but it's been 14 years for us. We did make reservations for 6:30 and notified the hostess of a birthday celebration. We arrived minutes before our reservation and were seated immediately in a large oversized booth. Star One earned. 

The restaurant has an old world Italian decor with comfy seating, subtle, low lighting and perfect for a date night, family dinner, birthday celebration or a business meeting. The restaurant is quite large, has a nice bar area, patio seating and at least 2 large private party rooms. Maggianos can easily accomdate large groups, private events or just a romantic dinner for two. Star 2 for ambience and our big, comfortable booth.

I have to admit I'm the odd man out with tonights experience and this review. I'll preference this review with the info of having dimished sense of taste lately but I do believe this didn't impact my decisions as much as others believe. But then again, maybe.

Our server, who's name nor 95% of his evenings conversation did I hear, was promptly at our table for beverage orders. Drinks quickly delivered, he expected our orders next but I was the only one requiring a few more minutes. He was kind enough to take the others order and revisit my order in a few minutes. Two of the four have food allergies so they had basically one choice, Spaghetti & Meat Sauce while the other always orders the same entree, Angel Hair Lanagoisto Lobster. Pressure on, and trying to listen/visit/decide I selected the Angel Hair Primavera expecting it to be similar, if not better, to my favorite dish at Sal's Italian Restaurant. And then to my surprise, we had buy one take one of the Classic meals home for the next day. Excellent!! But again, I hadn't heard this while the server was at the opposite end of the table. 

The salads and bread arrived quickly followed by the entrees minutes after the others salads were devoured. I heard nothing but rave reviews over the Lanagoisto Lobster flavors and the perfectly cooked Angel Hair Pasta, (which I debated over, damn), and how excited he was to have again tomorrow for lunch. Both the others found the Spaghetti and Meat Sauce very flavorful, nice selection of spices in the meat sauce and would definitely order again. Star three earned. The Angel Hair Primavera had large chunks of cauliflower, zucchini, carrots and squash which were crisp-tender served over a large portion of Angel Hair pasta. I felt the pasta was under seasoned and slightly overcooked. Again, this probably was no fault of Maggianos but it sure put a damper on my meal. I needed some type of crushed red peppers, quickly, and now was visually searching for our server. 

He disappeared and unfortunately didn't return for some time and only after everyone else's meals were devoured. He returned with our bogo orders, which I wanted to change immediately after tasting my meal 3 minutes after he sat it down, and then he returned with our peppers. His long absence put a damper on my meal for sure but he obviously hadn't taken a breathe during his absence so I felt horrible saying anything.
