But you would expect a quick follow-up after dropping off our entrees, right?

I put a small dent in my entree and when he returned with peppers asked if we wanted dessert. The three of us passed but expected the birthday girl would receive hers. Didn't happen and by the time he returned she had lost all interest after the heavy pasta started to settle. 

All in all, everyone else enjoyed their dinner, would go again and other than the server disappearing for quite awhile, would dine here again in the near future. Star Number Four earned.

As hard as I tried not to spoil the evening, I'm sure I put a damper on the evening. All because the waiter waited 20 minutes to return from the kitchen after dropping off our entrees.

My source for specialty food products - especially the fabulous selection of balsamic vinegar, a good cheese counter and swanky (pricey) prepared foods that taste as great as they look.

A small coffee is $1.99 - so not too bad.
Fresh OJ for $2.99 in the AM with a carb-laden pastry?  (Try the flaky cinnamon stick - like dessert for breakfast).
Catering, too!

Lines can get long but the move quickly.

Thank goodness we have Di Bruno's.

Oh my, Mai Lee. Color me VERY impressed. 

I was craving Vietnamese food today (more specifically, Pho), so after doing a little research and ruling out my other choices (Pho Grand - too far, Kim Son - not impressed, Lemongrass - too far), I decided on Mai Lee. 

I started with the eggroll appetizer, and it came out SUPER fast. It was nothing short of AMAZING. Hot, crispy, flavorful...everything you want in an eggroll. SO tasty.

I ordered the spicy beef pho (#13), and it was to die for. The flavors were magnificent, and the spiciness was just right. I didn't even have to reach for Sriracha! That poor rooster sauce felt neglected. :)

To top it all off, the food was CHEAP. All of that food, plus tip, came to 13 bucks. Not bad! 

I would definitely come back here. DEFINITELY.

As a local to Philly, I'm pretty embarrassed to say this was only my second trip to the Reading Terminal Market. Wow. Just wow. I'm glad I didn't come hungry or I would have been quite overwhelmed. I was meeting my girlfriends for the start of a big day of eating. One of my friends suggested Reading terminal and based on what I've heard about the variety, it was the perfect pick,

We did a lap of the building before anyone purchased a thing. I wish I took notes to make my next trip easier. Things that stood out included the sushi, DiNic's, a stand with bacon, a fresh fish stand, a juice/smoothie place and the list goes on. 

We were able to grab a table with 5 seats and took turns getting our lunch. I love the variety at the table- sesame chicken, a turkey sand which, char grilled eggplant sandwich and a falafel. Since I was fresh off brunch, I decided to just have some ice cream. I was intrigued by the abundance of Amish vendors so picked Miller's Twist. After sample a few flavors, I decided on a small cup of banana ice cream. Perfect! Creamy and delicious.

If this wasn't the start of the day out, I'd probably go on a produce shopping spree. I can't wait to return hungry and ready to bring any purchases promptly to a fridge!

I've never had gefilte fish this good. Zahav's Passover Mesibah is so great that it is worth that time we had the Angel of Death kill a bunch of Egyptian babies. 

I'm sorry if this offends any member of the Egyptian community. Too soon?

What's not to love about modular Swedish furniture?  I got all my outdoor furniture from Ikea because the prices beat most other places, and it's cheap enough to replace after a couple years if I need to.

Also, my dear Swedish fried said that Ikea's Swedish meatballs are pretty authentic.  For $5.99 (if you have the free Ikea family card), you get 15 meatballs in cream sauce, a scoop of mashed potatoes and lingonberry preserves.  That's not a bad deal.

My wife and I dine here often.  We love their food.  And if you're a regular, the service is sometimes frustrating.  They don't come to your table until you've been seated for 7-10 minutes.  This is normal.  We were there right at opening at 11 AM today and that was the case once again.  But if you've not been here before, you'll need all that time to figure out what you want.  They have over 200 items on their menu, and that doesn't count the Chinese section on the last few pages.  

We ordered spring rolls without cilantro.  My wife doesn't like cilantro but you can withhold it from many of their dishes.  For my entire I wanted the duck curry soup, but they were out.  So I chose #21, the anchovy based soup instead.  This was the first time I tried this dish.  It was packed with seafood, pork, vermicelli, and the broth was wonderful.  I always blown away that they have so many food options and everything is great.  

If you can get over the odd, cold feeling of their service, and instead focus on their food, Mai Lee will leave you wanting to return.

The fall wedding season rolled on for me last Saturday with the reception of my newly married friends, Shannon and Ed, at Citizens Bank Park.  Everyone was totally stoked about this one because it was so different from the norm.  Parking was a cinch in the special events section, and there were plenty of staffers to direct everyone to the appropriate places once we were inside.  Cocktail hour was held in the Hall of Fame section, which I was familiar with already.  The passed hors d'oeuvres and cheese boards were perfect for taking the edge off.

Everyone was then instructed to take the elevators to the Diamond Club, where dinner and dancing would take place.  The fun level of this room was out of control.  A huge dancefloor was situated to the left, with high-top tables and a large bar in the back, and all the guest tables were to the right, with food stations on both sides of the room.

The newlyweds took Philly pride to a whole other level when, instead of clinking champagne glasses to initiate a kiss, guests were instead asked to wave their Phillies rally towels, which were placed at every setting.  I'm pleased to report that only one towel caught on fire and it was stomped out quickly.

The food was a highlight for many, with one side of the room offering traditional wedding fare such as pasta and chicken, and the other side of the room offering ballpark style food like hot dogs, sausage and peppers and, of course, a build your own cheesesteak station.  Always the classy one, I opted for a whiz wit, extra ketchup, and a Flying Fish which was on tap along with many other selections.

After dinner, we danced nonstop for the remainder of the night and had a great time.  The staff was abundant and mostly everyone seemed friendly and helpful.  I would love to attend a special event at Citizens Bank Park again.

The brunch here is "wonderful, smarvelous" (sorry, I just watched Funny Face this week so I'm in old movies mode).  We always split the stuffed challah French Toast and latkes, and get some of the muffins to go (once we received complimentary ones because we waited for a bit).  Everything is fresh and delicious, and the portions are generous.  I did try the latkes benedict last time, and it was a nice combination of lox, latkes, eggs, and hollandaise - a nice change from your typical eggs benedict.  I think that, despite my school's compulsion with the annual latkes vs. hamentashen debate every year, the latkes win, hands on, at least in my book.    

Service is very amiable and fast...once you get past the wait on weekends.

Honey wheat crust....Mmmmmm...

I got the opportunity to try their pizza at Taste of Maplewood, and the cheese and dough were tasty, so I ordered a small pizza to go shortly thereafter, and it was pretty good!

Talking pizza only...there are about 5 or 6 dough choices, and the honey wheat was very tasty although it seemed the honey was brushed on instead of baked into it, so it made the pizza a little sticky and oily.  But the honey flavor was an interesting balance to a tangy sweet red sauce and generally tasty dough.

That aside, I had beef, sauteed mushrooms, and sauteed green peppers for toppings.  A small is still good-sized.  2 people could split it if you maybe tack on a side salad for balance.  Or get a medium and bring home some left-overs...And the toppings mushrooms and green peppers came sauteed or not sauteed, according to the menu, which was different.

Ohh!!! And I want to give kudos to the management.  After an odd visit my first time here (see original review) when a cook had quit and the kitchen was extremely backed up, I did a review for AAdvantage Dining Network (American Airlines) to get miles for my frequent flyer, and The Post management actually took the time to respond personally to my review/comments, explain what had happened that day, and also address some of my other comments in regards to how they are in the process of improving the sound dampening.  Truly kudos for management caring enough to take the time to write me back.  I will return!!

I love this place!  I just love everything about it. First, you have the super cool atmosphere: great chandeliers, fun wallpaper, hip, happy vibe. Second, the service: servers are friendly and efficient. Third, the food: oh, the food... And finally, the cocktails: interesting, unique, and very well executed.

Every visit I have their truffled tator tots with lemon crème fraiche.  Crunchy exterior, soft interior, crazy good. Seriously - do not leave here without trying these.

For my meal I have tried a variety of items. Favorite: ramen - 5 stars.  Followed closely by the pork belly stinky bunz - 5 stars. Lobster BLT - 4 stars.  Last night I had the Jap Chae: gluten free noodles and sautéed vegetables topped with seared tuna - 3.5 Stars. Friends of mine swear by the burgers, but it's very hard for me to try something other than the ramen.

Dessert rocks - I had the S'more dessert which was a huge toasted marshmallow served with a rich chocolate torte.  The marshmallow was amazing - it actually tasted like it had been roasted over a camp fire.  So good!

Cocktails are 5 stars every visit.  I keep trying different ones, and have loved all of them.  Current favorites are the Kurrant Bramble which is gin, fresh berries, crème de mure & cassis and the Moscow Mule which is vodka, house ginger syrup, lime & ginger beer.  Both of those are only $6 during happy hour - sweet!

Final note - they don't have private parking, so you will have to park at a nearby meter or parking lot and pay.  It's worth it, though, so give it a try!

Yummy chain has extended to the south Tampa area. The new building is beautiful and nice. However, the parking is a nightmare. It take a lot of time to circle the neighborhood before find a spot to park. 

The food is very similar to the chain menu. Since they just open, not all items may be served due to availability of the ingredients. We were there for duck raisins fried rice, but they are not available. We got the Hong Kong style sweet and sour pork and the scallops fried rice. The dried scallops need a bit crispy. However, the taste is there. 

The portion is normally match the chain standard may be a bit smaller. The service need to pick up. We have to wave to get attention. They are still new and try to work out their bump. May be give them another month.

Seriously disappointed in Maggianos lately. We went Friday night for dessert. Decided to sit in the bar area since almost every seat was empty. Our server was also the bartender. We told her we were having dessert only. Service was very slow took too long for drink refills and way too long to pay our bill. She was chatting up two guys at the bar and had no other tables but ours. She did have drink orders to fill from the dining room but those were few. While waiting to pay I saw her eating spaghetti, maybe she didn't get any kind of a break or her dinner dont know. I know when I was a server you served your guest and ate when your shift ended. As far as the dessert. I got strawberry shortcake. It had very few strawberries but tasted good except for the lemon peal. Other dessert was chocolate cake and it's always a hit.

Not going to lie. I have no idea what I ate most of the night. 

It was Friday night in Philly's China Town and every place was packed. We arrived just before the crowds came in and got seated immediately.

PRO TIP: I called earlier and they mentioned for just two people, no reservations were taken on busy nights.

We started with the must have roti, which we loved. It came with a chicken curry sauce, which I could have slurped on its own. The roti was hot, fluffy and honestly - FUN to eat!

I ordered a noodle soup which came with a beautiful broth. Researching it later, I found it was called "Curry Mee With Young Tau Foo * noodles served in a spicy lemon grass coconut curry with vegs, & tofu stuffed with minced shrimp & fish meat."  Not a fan of tofu, so I left most of that behind but enjoyed everything else in the dish.

My friend ordered "Nasi Lemak * coconut rice flavored with cloves & screw-pine leaves. served with chili, anchovy, curry, chicken & hard boiled eggs" - just because it said screw pine leaves which neither one of us had heard of.  She didn't really like whatever side it was that had the anchovy, but I loved it.  It was a very unusual dish that we liked, though we weren't quite sure why.

Bottom line - you can't be a foodie if you don't at least try food that you can't pronounce once in a while.

Service was fast, ambiance was loud but friendly - a great girls night out!

This place is phenomenal.  It really might be the best seafood in Tampa.

Everything about the place is tasteful.  The decor is understated.  The service is attentive without being obsequious.  The views are phenomenal.  I'm not sure that there's much I'd change about Oystercatchers.

They make pretty good cocktails.  I tried the strawberry basil mojito, and it was very tasty, although I think it was a little weak.  They have an extensive wine list, but many are pretty young, which explains their reasonable price.  If you bring your own bottle, the corkage is a bit steep, although they have very nice decanters.

We started out with the stone crab claw.  Singular, because the darned thing was over half a pound, the size a salad plate.  It was perfectly sweet and succulent, everything that you'd want in a stone crab.

The caesar salad was fine.  The bread they bring out is a perfect sourdough, and I swear it took a lot of self restraint not to eat the whole loaf.  They served it with sweet butter and smoked sea salt, so darned good.

For our main courses, my husband had the gulf shrimp, which he said were perfect.  I had the grilled grouper, and I swear that was the best grouper I have ever tasted.  My husband said that Oystercatcher's grouper tastes exactly how grouper was meant to taste.  It was clearly very fresh without any fishy taste, and the meat was sweet and mild.  Just a tiny bit of lemon juice made it perfect.

For dessert we shared the seasonal cheesecake.  It was mango, and it tasted like a little piece of heaven.  What a perfect way to end a wonderful meal (and to finish up our bottle of wine).

This place isn't cheap (expect to spend $100/pp if you want three courses and drinks), but it delivers an exceptional experience.

Once again, I have died and gone to foodie heaven after eating at Farmhaus. This place is so worthy of its #4 ranking on the famous Ian Froeb's STL 100 List. It truly is one of the best places to eat in the Lou. 

Tonight, surprise-surprise, I sat at the bar since I was dining alone. When asked if I'd like anything to drink, I responded, "It depends, can you make a good Old Fashioned?" The young lady who asked me, kinda hesitated. However, your co-worker spoke up and told me how she'd make and the gauntlet had been thrown down. She went to work and when she presented it to me, my breath was taken away. It was the same caliber of masterful cocktail mixing that I expect at a bar that specializes in classic cocktails. It went down smoothly. 

Also tonight, I thanked my lucky stars that I do not have a peanut allergy.  As an appetizer, I enjoyed the Chicken Wing Lollipops. They were made with a Thai peanut sauce, compressed cucumber and carrot, ponzu mayo and roasted peanuts. The flavor was incredible, best way to describe it, is dipping a wing in peanut butter instead of blu cheese  or ranch dressing. They were so juicy and tender, you could suck the bones clean. Every morsel was enjoyed. 

My entree was my second favorite seafood next to sea scallops and that is, Soft-Shell Crab. I've lived in Boston and traveled a lot in Florida and this by far is the best Soft-Shell Crab I have ever had. It was Corn Flour Fried and served on a bed of lemon anchovy aioli and tomato and corn salsa. The glass of Pinot Grigio was a refreshing beverage for this seafood entree. 

I went total hog wild and blew my diet when I saw French Toast listed as a dessert. It was house made brioche, maple meringue with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. WOW! You've heard of a foodgasm? This dessert will give you multiple ones. 

Staff is incredibly knowledgeable of the menu. When each of my dishes were served, they'd explain what it was and how it was prepared. It was like a verbal menu, explaining to you what you had ordered and what you were about to enjoy. 

The only negative I experienced, is that they did not keep up with my alcohol needs. Which I guess could be a good thing. I wasn't over drinking, I only had the Old Fashioned and a glass of wine. However, an after dinner liquor with my sensational French Toast Dessert would have made for an incredible finale. 

When: August 13, 2016
Why: Dinner & STL 100 List

Good fortune took me to Vic's Sushi Bar, a diminutive BYOB near Rittenhouse Square.

There's little room at this eatery, putting their sushi bar front and center. Eating at the bar is an intimate experience; don't be surprised to find yourself passing soy sauce or water from one person to another. If you're lucky, you'll score a seat right away, otherwise be prepared to wait. (We waited a bit. Another group chose to sit at the tiny table by the door.)

Sipping bowls of miso, we chatted with the humble sushi chef, Vic himself. Toiling behind the counter, he worked his magic. The rest of the staff were on point that evening, met our needs, and were happy to provide separate checks for us.

Sushi presentation was outstanding. Everything we tasted was delectable. We started with the Sansom roll ($14) - that's shrimp tempura, crab stick and avocado roll, with fresh tuna, salmon, avocado, eel sauce, spicy sauce, masago, and scallions. Next, we had the Black Dragon roll ($11) - eel, avocado, in a cucumber roll, topped with more eel. We finished with the Alaskan roll. Rolls weren't skimpy; we barely finished what we had.

Despite being smaller than a frickin' bread box, Vic's delivers personal service, reasonable prices, and quality sushi. After hearing so much about Vic's, I'm glad I finally got to stop in.

OMG, talk about a spread of food, it is everywhere. This establishment is tucked in with  other high class restaurants, along restaurant row on Boy Scout Blvd. 
They will not seat you until your entire party is present, so the first few of us wrangled a seat at their very tiny bar.
Let's talk about the bar first. It is small, the bartender was obnoxious (sorry lost a star for that). One lady spilt her coke, honest accident and was not even drinking. She was totally embarrassed and the bartender had utter disdain all over his face, like it was some disaster. He was moving at a snails pace and finally accomplished the task and she got another soda & jokingly said it wouldn't happen again. The bartender turned around, looked her in the eye and rudely said it better not or you will be cleaning up your mess. I was appalled and horrified for this poor lady. Not a great first impresion. 
I watched several people that arrived after me getting served. I basically had to be almost be rude to get the bartenders attention. Once I had his slow, uncaring attention, I asked if they had a happy hour. His response was it ended at 7 PM and it was 2 till 7, so I missed it. I informed him that both he, my friend and myself knew I had been sitting their patiently for 20 minutes, 15 minutes longer than I should have, without being asked if I would like something to drink. He reluctantly poured me a glass of wine at happy hour price.
DO NOT, I REPEAT, DO NOT STOP IN HERE FOR HAPPY HOUR WITH THE GANG OR YOURSELF, YOU WILL BE SONY DISAPPOINTED! 
Enter the restaurant,  nice upscale restaurant, understated furnishings and wall decor... beautiful chandelier.  The hostess explained about your meat cards green side up for meat, red side up for no meat. She was very nice and examined the set up, for those who had never been there.
All of a sudden you are flocked with the waiters bearing meat of beef, sausage  and chicken. It took us multiple requests to get tiny, tiny lamb chops and pork  ribs, and we never saw them again.
The salad bar is magnificent.  It beholds a wondrous array of beautiful food to include smoked salmon and boiled shrimp.  Behind the salad bar is a hot station, with rice, soups, etc. On the table are small rolls & mashed potatoes with no butter and a Brazilian banana dish.
The waiters with the meat are so fast, it is hard to get a picture of them. I think only 2 of them had a personality and appeared to like their jobs. The rest of the waiters were very abrupt, expected everyone to know which meats they needed their tongs for... I am sure they get some good tips at this establishment and would want to be a bit friendlier or fake it to try and increase their tip.
The place was packed. I think the gig is fill up on salad and cheaper meats quickly so you get full and forget about things like the pricier ribs and lamb. The meal comes with several fantastic dessert selections that tasted as good as they looked.
We had a Birthday celebration and could not find anyone to talk to about this, to see if they had something special for our birthday guest.
I left with very mixed feelings. Most of the meat I tasted was very good and I would have again, same with the salad bar and hot station.
I won't tolerate rude or indifference from servers, I don't care where I am dining, it is not acceptable and inexcusable in the hospitality industry. At an establishment like this I should not have to request any type of meat, let alone multiple times.  Can't say I will be returning anytime soon, really sorry to say that, but Tampa has too many great restaurants to deal with bad attitudes and inattentive service. We  had to apologize to my guests, inexcusable. 
What's a girl to do? Stick to your guns and demand appropriate service.

They are now cash only (except for large catering orders).
Still a great "safe" choice for lunch or brunch.

The crispy honey fried chicken salad is my favorite, and any "fish of the day" is great (Salmon, mahi mahi).  For dessert don;t miss the delicious chocolate cake with buttercream frosting.  So good!

Nice salad and hot specials.
Friendly service from Wendy and the crew.  (The cashier lady is lovely - I can never remember her name, though.)

And the support my child's school!

We love Day by Day!

I'm glad that there's a Yummy House closer to me, but it is the same, oily food as any Yummy House. 

It is in a busy location, and they have valet parking to deal with crowds. The restaurant itself has high ceilings and feels new and clean. 

The fried rice is fine. Beef chow fun is pretty good, although I like China Yuan better for it. Veggies are always grease bombs with too much garlic. The salt and pepper dishes are a little too swwwt to me, and on my last visit, the calamari wasn't crispy. Sigh. 

Tampa Bay doesn't have many real Chinese restaurants, so this is one of the better ones of a bunch of mediocre choices. I'll come here if I have a huge craving, but I'll likely leave unsatisfied.

Why 4 stars? Because you're greeted with live music as soon as you exit the plane.

   ---   ---   ---

How could you get more Nashville than that? But I think live music alone is the primary factor for the 4-stars. Outside of that, the airport is mostly unmemorable. It's not super renovated, and it's not super out of date. I do like the funky carpet... and as we know... carpet at an airport is super important.

I wish I had more detail to add here. But I couldn't resist noting the live music that's offered in the music city airport. I think every city should offer an over-the-top experience based on their reputation, at the airport. 

As soon as people land in Cleveland, hit 'em with rock-n-roll.

When they land in New York, have golf-carts shaped like cabs driving people around, honking their horns relentlessly.

As you exit the tarmac at SFO, have folks approach you for early funding for their app.

I've only laid over in Nashville twice. I've never gone through security, which I'm sure could sway me either way.

My first thought was, "Oh god, this is way too sweet to finish."

As a first-time visitor to New Orleans, I felt it was necessary to order a Hurricane from Pat O'Brien's, even though I'd regularly much prefer basically anything else other than a crazy sweet cherry cocktail. The one-size-only glass was larger than I had hoped and it came with plenty of ice.

You'll also receive your own bag of addictive complimentary popcorn with a drink order. If you finish it, you may be awarded with a second bag. Or maybe our friendly and chatty bartender was just feeling extra generous that day!

My friend and I stopped in on a chilly January day. Pat O's had the heat kicking, and it felt like a balmy tropical oasis at the indoor bar. Since it was early in the day, we easily found bar stools and camped out for a while.

Later, we walked across the hall, into a dueling piano room (pretty cool!), and used the fresh and clean bathroom. While there, I chatted with another patron from Philly, which was pretty random, but I guess we do really like to flee south!

I wouldn't recommend ordering more than one Hurricane, unless you want to feel like you had some hand grenades, but trying this cocktail is definitely part of the NOLA experience.

I finished every last sip of cherry.

--
HEY THERE, REVIEW 800.

This is a fun and folksy decor restaurant that is a social center, popular eatery and live music venue in the thriving Seminole Heights bungalow hipster community. 

Beards aren't essential, but you will fit in better if you have one. The food is New American comfort and quite good. 

There's a bar, table and booth area as well as an upstairs. Art of local artists is on display and landscape art and sculptures are also featured. You can also eat outside along the side of the restaurant. 

Ella's is a hip spot that delivers very good vittles in a fun, artsy and social atmosphere. Mermaid Tavern up the road is cool too. Both get busy.

Do not fill up on the salad area, or else you won't be able to enjoy all the meat!

My fiance and I went for brunch on Sunday.  They have brunch until 3 p.m. and then start dinner at 4 p.m.  I think it is totally worth it to go for brunch, because it is about $25 per person then instead of $40+ and you still get a great selection of meat coming around.

Do not be fooled by the word brunch.  This is not your average brunch with breakfast foods.  Instead it is basically lunch.  The salad area has a great selection of things that are not salad.  They had lobster bisque, asparagus, prosciutto, shrimp salad, smoked salmon, Italian sausage, just to give you an idea.  My absolute favorite was the potato au gratin.  Next time I will just grab that and go back to my seat to prepare for the meat.

I'm really appreciative of having a card that you flip to green when you are ready for people to come around with meat.  I almost never flipped mine to green and instead ate a bite of every meat my fiance got.  They also bring you mashed potatoes, cheesy bread, and cinnamon plantains.  The cheesy bread got an oh my gawd it was good.  They were like little nuggets of heaven.  I was completely full by the end and still managed to eat two more.  They are small, round, and deliciously cheese filled.  

You really need to pay attention to which meats you like, because they do a good job of asking you if there is something in particular you want more of.  Unfortunately, I did a horrible job at paying attention to all the names.  Just know, you really can't go wrong.  I love that it is all medium rare.  However, my fiance asked for some medium well and they brought it over.  Do not be afraid to ask for what you want.

Make sure you are hungry when you go, because you will leave absolutely stuffed!  We will definitely be back.

Sugarfire Smokehouse is delicious! I think it's up there with the very best BBQ in St. Louis and I have been to them all. The pulled pork is tender and delicious. The brisket is amazing.  They have a great soda selection and the French fries are cooked to order. It's quick (they do not wait on you) and delicious. Also the selection of BBQ sauces is great.  My particular favorite is the mustard sauce.  If I had any complaints it would only be that you move through it cafeteria style instead of getting waited on but that system does kind of work for this place. It's less annoying at lunch but at dinner sometimes you just want to sit down and be waited on. Either way you should make it your priority to go here.

Consisently high quality fish and friendly service for take out lunches.
The 3 roll combo is a filling meal and a good value.

Tuna Dumplings are delicious.

MUCH better than Jay's favorite.

Village Whiskey is one of those places I should have visited years ago, but somehow didn't. One of the Garces greats, if it's also good enough for Marc Vetri to dine at, its good enough for me. You have to give me so much credit for not fan girling when my visit overlapped with Mr. Vetri's visit. 

Visit number one in January was for brunch. I love a traditional egg-oriented brunch, but their cobb salad intrigued me. Paired with the crab bisque, I didn't miss the omelet at all. The crab bisque was rich with large pieces of crab. The salad was just large, with large pieces of everything: romaine, avocado, bacon blackened chicken and bleu cheese. I even had leftovers. 

During my second visit in January, I was finally able to try the Whiskey King. This legendary 8 ounce burger consists of maple bourbon glazed cipollini, rogue bleu cheese, Applewood bacon and foie gras. If I thought the salad was big, that's before I had the burger. I feel I needed more than a napkin to keep me clean while trying to eat this thing. I ended up cutting it in half, which caused it to fall apart a bit. Which was unfortunate. Everything was top notch quality, but it was almost too much of a king to enjoy. Maybe the trick is taking it to go and eating it in private. I wish I was able to enjoy all the fixings together, so that did ruin the experience a bit. I've heard all the hype of this burger for so long, but I can't put it on the top of my list. 

Village Whisky isn't a huge spot. During visit one, we sat at the bar because there weren't any tables available. During visit two, way too many people crowded into a booth with tables pushed together. 

Don't get me wrong, I'd got back in a heartbeat, but there were a few too many things keeping it from being a new favorite and a 5-star view.

Okay, it's been more than a year since I've been here and I'm going to downgrade my rating by a star.

We ordered a cheesesteak and a roast pork sandwich, then split the two so we could have a little bit of both.  

Yay - the two sandwiches and a bag of Herr's sour cream and onion chips came to under $15.

Boo - both tasted surprisingly underseasoned this time around.  I mean really, really bland.  Normally the sandwiches here are so good that you don't have to season anything with ketchup or salt, but this trip had me scrunching my face and going, "Why are these both so bland and boring?"

Hope it was just an off day for them.

It is obligatory to visit and review this Tampa historical institution. Have eaten there multiple times with family & friends, including first anniversary in 1970 when they still placed pillows under the feet of lady guests when seating them.  The food is very good, if not always the best version of Spanish/Cuban standards.  Paella, their 1911 salad, yellow rice and chicken are exemplary, as are skillfully crafted cocktails like mojitos.  The menu has stayed consistent for decades, and the decor/ambiance lends an air of luxury and old-fashioned elegance.   Prices are appropriate for the upscale presentation by waitstaff in formal black wear.   Reservations are needed due to popularity with both locals & tourists, but drop in the wonderfully ornately carved  bar for a drink any time.   Also you can enhance your appreciation of the experience by doing a bit of historical research into the origin and evolution of the classic restaurant under the guidance of the Gonzmart family, but with some colorful touches by local Mafia notables like Santo Trafficante.
Ok so FINALLY they have oysters back on the menu BUT only on Mondays!!!  Geez Louise BP is long over and there are good supplies of oysters now so c'mon do them all the time please!

As usual John Besh never disappoints, the best crab bisque I have had in a long time in a restaurant. Not too rich and full of crabmeat, a great treat for supper served with hot french bread for dipping.

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time. I finally had time to go today, and I was PUMPED. I had pored over the online menu in advance, I knew exactly what I was going to order, etc. 

So we get there. Middle of the afternoon on a Sunday. Not crowded, so parking was super easy. 

We found a table right in the middle of the tiny restaurant, and looked around. I LOVE the atmosphere. There was a clear democratic theme (lots of pictures of JFK, etc.) which I loved! Everything was really neat. 

The food? Well, I ordered a Royale with Cheese (god, I've always wanted to be able to say that! LOVE you, Tarantino!) with sweet potato chips. 

The burger was good, and cooked exactly as I ordered it (medium). Juicy and flavorful. Being the barbeque sauce lover that I am, I requested some to go on my burger. They didn't have any. What kind of respectable place doesn't have BBQ sauce somewhere?!!? Minus half a star. I know, I'm picky. 

My chips were pretty terrible. They were very very...done (read: BURNT). If our waiter came back to our table before I had completely finished my burger, I would have said something. But by that point, I was just about finished with my meal, so I didn't say anything. I was very disappointed, though. Minus one star. 

Service was spotty at best. I can tell this is the sort of place where hipsters hang out for hours at a time, because our waiter took FOREVER to bring the check. We had to flag him down. 

All in all, my burger was pretty solid, and the atmosphere was cool, but I don't know if that's enough to bring me back.

Yes, I am a fan and a loyal fan at that. I have been here numerous times and keep getting the same constant good service and food. Here are some of the highlights of some of my  most recent visits:

Carne Adovada - A daily special that was amazingly good. I enjoyed pulled pork from the shoulder that was braised in red chilies from Mexico for five hours. It was topped with two eggs over easy and a side of home fries. I stuffed the flour tortillas they provided and had a perfect late breakfast. 

Slinger - A foundation of Home Fries, which are topped with either red or green chilies, (I've done both) and the two eggs.  Their home fries are the best in the city. I wish other dines would take lessons from SWD on how to prepare good and true home fries. The red chilies make it a spicier dish, but flavor wise I prefer the green. 

Malted Waffle - A good waffle, but for my personal taste, I want more malt flavor. 
I do love how they serve their maple syrup. They have it in a squeeze bottle which makes it so much easier to add to the waffle. 

Burrito - Fat, stuffed to the maximum and full of flavor.

Service is always friendly and I never feel rushed as I have been at other diners in the city.

I was really excited to finally try Farmhaus so I ordered curbside takeout during quarantine for my daughter and I. We got the fish special which was absolutely delicious. I didn't expect my two year old to really want any and she ate nearly half of my lunch it was very good. It came with a side of Mac and cheese and crispy green beans. We also ordered the focaccia with feta and peppers which was a really good appetizer. The only thing about the lunch I didn't particularly love was the wedding cake slice. It was pretty dry in my opinion but the flavor was good. I can't wait to try Farmhaus again when dine in becomes available again.

So there are times where working in Tacony feels like I'm surrounded by a a suburban and industrial land of devastation. aside from a couple awkward looking parks there's nothing but housing, highways, and factories; and it spans on to the endless reaches to the point that I thought it spanned on into nevermore. But then I found out that my wrongness was tinged with the flavor of barbecue tang!

When I first heard my co-workers say they where going out to Sweet Lucy's for lunch I thought they were pulling my leg with a cruel and twisted joke. But then I realized that they didn't know me well enough to do so and I jumped upon that lunch call in a erratic fervor. and as unexpected fate would have it, I soon found out that being so close to nothingness put me literally blocks away from the best barbecue in Philly. Talk about odds that I'm happy to gamble on. especially since I could smell the aroma of special sauce the moment that we pulled into the drive way!

my first order was a no brainer since I had pulled pork on the mind. and it was smothered in so much juicy sauceeeeeeeeeeemmmmmmmm *drooling Homer moment* that it goes down in the annals of best decisions that I've ever made. The sandwich by itself is plenty of food. But of course they make it better with the meal deal by piling on two sides and a piece of corn bread. So I went with their delish mac & cheese, and a helping of their spicy collard greens (and I might have added on some pickles, hot peppers, and extra sauce from the fixings bar for good measure). in normal areas lunch this good is by far an impossible thing to come by!

So long story short I've still come to the conclusion that I'm working so close to nothingness. But so long as that nothingness is bizarro enough to lead to an all you can eat barbecue buffet every Monday, I think I can deal!

Manager: "How is your meal?"
Me: "SO GOOD!"
Later.
Server: "How's your meal?"
Me: "SO. GOOD."

Eloquent, I know. But that adequately describes my experience at Parc for Sunday brunch this morning. It may just have been the brunch to top all brunches. The brunch master. The brunch empire? I don't know. It was just a really, really great meal all around, and I'm still so happy about it. And I think the word "brunch" is so cheesy, too.

I loved my chicken club, the mimosa and the bread basket. I loved the wood floors and the light fixtures and the glass windows and all the happy people sitting around us. (Aside: I didn't love the prices, but expected them walking in.) 

I loved walking out of the restaurant and right onto Rittenhouse Square to see people dancing, playing instruments, walking their little dogs, and enjoying the first glimpses of warmer weather. They really do have THE prime real estate.

Parc was a perfect addition to this Sunday indeed.

Visited the Cheesecake factory with a friend who'd flown into town and let me choose where to go. I'm used to waiting up to an hour for seating, but at lunch, I was able to walk right in. Color me impressed! Granted, it was lunch, so that probably had something to do with it, but I digress... Service was excellent! Our waitress was chipper and cheerful and very helpful with ideas for what to order. 

My friend and I perused the extensive menu while we chatted and caught up and then placed our orders. I ordered one of the lunch specials, a 1/2 sandwich a "cup" of soup and a salad. I didn't realize how much food that was going to be.  LORDY! There was a lot of food and that CUP of soup was really a bowl.  I wasn't able to eat all of it and ended up taking much of the food home with me. 

My companion chose a meal of Salmon and asparagus which was both light and looked delicious. The meal was served quickly, along with some tantalizing fresh bread.  We really enjoyed everything that we tasted.  

And because this is the Cheesecake factory, we did have to buy dessert, but not the namesake, we went with Tiramisu. Wow. i've not hat something so good outside of Tarpon, it really was 2nd to none. Yummy!

I went here with a group of about 30 people and we had the entire second floor. Did you know they have a third floor, complete with a bar and tables? Back to dinner, we made it in time for Happy Hour and I have to say I was skeptical of a $2.00 martini and now I know why. The base is pre made and in insulated cocktail shakers, then they add apple, dirty, chocolate...... Well the start of the evening was bad, as the martini was nothing and I mean nothing to speak of or remember, except the price and to save the two bucks if there are future visits.
Then came the bread and bread sticks. The bread was warm, that is the best I can say about it and the whipped spread, had no real flavor, I could not even recognize what it was, except it wasn't butter. I suppose because we were in a group, we didn't get the half price meals and appetizers everyone has raved about. If you are like me you can be a bit more forgiving if you feel like you are getting a good deal, but the bottom line is good is good and okay is okay.
I have to say that Bernini"s missed the mark with my group. The service was stellar, but not 1 of us could say we loved our meal and could not wait to come back. I will get to my order in a bit, but with a group this size I had the opportunity to taste most of the menu. Let me also mention it was hot, I don't mean warm, the rooms tempreture was hot, I even requested that some windows be cracked, to get a breath of fresh air. This restaurant had the chance to make a hit with 30 foodies and fell flat on their face, OUCH. I am talking Bloggers, Yepler's, Urbanspoon foodies, not just good palates, people that love to eat and many get paid to do just that, not the right night to fumble, let alone drop the ball.
I ordered 2 appetizers the beef carpaccio  and eggplant rollitini.
The beef arrived first and looked beautiful, I wanted to dig right in, but waited for some of my fellow dinners to receive their food. When I tackled the beef carpaccio it was totally void of any seasoning and the promised white truffle balsamic drizzle was no where to be seen or tasted.. A beautiful dish ruined that could have been revived with some salt and pepper and the promised drizzle. I added what I could and ate it, only because I hadn't eaten all day. My second small plate the eggplant coating was falling off, it was way overcooked and there was NO goat cheese,sundried tomatoes, basil, spinach pesto or marinara sauce.  This was truly a dismal dish, if I had not been with so many people my food would have been returned to the kitchen, along with many of my friends..
The person seated to my right also got 2 small plates and asked me to taste them, as he was unsure they were edible. The lamb lollipops were very overcooked, which made them rubbery and chewy and had no seasoning including the mint basil pesto,  so the dish was inedible. The second was the famous calamari which was tough and overcooked, chewy and missing the marinara.
My friend to my left ordered the shrimp orrichette pasta. The shrimp was cooked perfectly, the pasta was beyond overcooked, soft and mushy. Across from me another shrimp orrichette pasta with no sauce, he wondered what was missing, LOL there was no sauce and even after being asked several times we never got anyone to add cheese to the dishes that were supposed to receive cheese on top.
I also tasted a risotto that was bland, not creamy tasting at all and should have never left the kitchen. There was a burned ( I mean black spots) pizza and Bruschetta, also sorely lacking in flavor and appropriate spices. I will just mention one last dish in this dismal review the crispy duck whose skin was not even brown, let alone crispy and it was missing the vanilla and dried cherry Chianti sauce.
I can only imagine what caused all of these problems and a host of others: lack of kitchen staff, no one to expedite the orders, sauce chef out to lunch, lack of leadership in the kitchen, help me out here I am grasping. There is no excuse for food like this to leave the kitchen of any caliber restaurant....NONE.
The reviews I read, my friends and peers recommended Bernini's and I respect their opinions and know they had good food and dining experiences.
As the saying goes in the world of food, you are only remembered for your last bad dish.
What's a girl to do? I tried to make excuses, until it became clear, there was NO excuse to serve inedible food and plates missing key components, so I made no more excuses.

Still love TJ's - the prepared Medditerranean Pasta salad makes a great lunch (and for $3.49 - whoo-hoo!). Also for $1.99 the frozen bowties with spinach and 4 cheeses is great (rich though and 390 cals.).  To say nothing of the divinely fattening shells with asparagus and brie ($3.49).

I come in very frequently now that I am working 1 block away.

We arrived on a Saturday night around 6pm and would have had a wait to be seated had we not spotted a table for 2 near the bar where it's seat-yourself.  Always a good sign how busy they are this many months after the move to the new location.  Closer to 7pm, the waiting area was jam-packed.

The service has always been overly friendly, and I have been here several times now.  The Beef hot pot in the bean sauce gives you plenty of food.  My leftovers filled a large Chinese take-out box, and my reaction prompted the server to say, "At Mai Lee, we make sure you get both dinner and lunch."   When I first heard of a bean sauce, I was hesitant, but while there are black beans, the sauce tastes more like a rich beef brown sauce.  The sauce makes this meal.  But in addition to the strips of beef, this meal is just packed with vegetables - celery, carrots, broccoli, green peppers, mushrooms, baby corn, bamboo shoots, watercress, and onions.  All of it cooked/steamed just right and all of it for only $12.95.

Many successfully tasty meals so far and watching the bartender whip out several unique and tasty-looking drinks makes me look forward to our next visit.

Why 5 stars? Because this is my favorite banh mi in Tampa Bay!

   ---   ---   ---

I could eat banh mi every day of my life, and this is probably the place I'd prefer it from, above all others.

Thinh An Kitchen is bright and modern. There's a counter for to-go orders, a dine-in area with tables, and a bakery section with plenty of pre-prepped goodies to take home. Although I've only been twice, and gotten the banh mi each time, this is my new go-to Vietnamese restaurant in the 813. The boba smoothie section is as good as anywhere, as well.

I haven't had the courage to try the durian during either of my visits, but maybe one day I'll work up the strength. After Chris W's experience, I might just keep putting it off until I forget durian exists :) For those of you who don't know, durian is a fruit with a very strong odor and taste. Some love it, and some... do not.

Cute little place.  Difficult to maneuver through when people are sitting at the tables in the middle sometimes.  Service was ok.  Looks like it has a nice outdoor area, but the weather didn't let us use it today.

Menu had some small plates, sandwiches, burgers, salads, and a couple taco choices (brisket, fish).

We all had burgers but a variety of kinds, all huge 1/2 lb-ers.  The Kingshighway was Angus $8.  The Royale was Kobe $10.  And I had Bison $10.  Cheese was extra for each one (my cheddar was 75c).  Each came with choice of 1 side.  You can sub a garden salad for $1 instead of the other sides.  My group liked the sweet potato chips.

Overall, the burger was good, and service was just ok.

This used to be one of my favorite places in town, but during my last two dinner visits, the food has not even been three-star worthy, so I think their kitchen needs to re-think what they have going on.

I love that they have updated to the Nowait app, however, it wasn't accurate the night we showed up; even though it showed 'no wait', there was about a 15 minute wait.  No biggie - we got the last seats at the bar and had a cocktail. They discount their cocktails for happy hour, and have an excellent variety.

We got shown to a booth when our name was called, and our server was outstanding.  She was completely on the ball, with drink refills, telling us about the specials, etc.

Once our order went in however, it was completely downhill. We waited about 15 minutes for the edamame appetizer. This is so good - it has roasted garlic seasoning sprinkled on it, and came out perfectly cooked. Then we waited, waited, waited, waited, and waited some more for our meal. They had three specials that night, and we got 2 out of the 3. When our meal finally arrived, it looked delicious. Sadly, it did not taste delicious. I choked down half of my mushy, overly-spicy vegan fried chicken sandwich (maybe they thought they could hide the terrible texture with a lot of hot sauce?) and filled up on my excellent fried green tomatoes.  After waiting for SO LONG, I did not send it back for something else, because I just couldn't stand the thought of waiting another hour. 

I'm sure I'll be back for Soul Food Sunday, but Ella's, you have lost me for dinner until you get your food and your system back on track.
Excellent selection, friendly staff, quant location

My good friend and I came for lunch August 2. Our strategy was: arrive at 11 a.m., just when the place opens.

I got the right door this time, and I was the first to arrive. But I let others in when the doors opened, because my good friend wasn't there yet.

My friend came virtually on time, but he had gifts I needed to put in my car. A beautiful zucchini, a fabulous home-grown tomato and a great book to read.

The line hadn't expanded exponentially, so we were in good shape.

We both got a combo meal -- two meats, two sides and a beverage (~$17).

He got turkey and ribs (four bones), potato salad and baked beans. He opted for water.

I got ribs (four bones) and brisket, cauliflower salad and green beans -- and five pickle spears. I cannot do without those dang dill pickle spears! I opted for diet cola.

We both enjoyed our food. The ribs were toothsome, tangy and tasteful. I ate them naked. My friend tried a couple sauces and liked them both.

These are not fall-off-the-bone ribs, thank goodness. Those are backyard barbeque or crockpot ribs.

He liked his sides. I didn't taste them.

The cauliflower salad was ingenious: a greenish vinegar-based thin dressing with red onion, white onion, black olive, green pepper and a small-dice white cheese (but it coulda been tofu) along for the ride with the cauliflower.

This was such an amazing amalgam, and it was perfect!! WHO thought this up?!?!

The green beans were beautifully tender-crisp and well-seasoned.

The pickles were perfect, as always.

He took home his meats. I took home all my couldn't-eat-it-here, including two pickles. I got two more meals out of this outstanding array.

And I refilled my diet cola on the way out.

Great wood-fired, thin crust pizza. 

My husband calls this an appetizer pizza, which makes me roll his eyes. I told him he better not mean that this is the type of pizza he would eat before a main meal because that would make him exceptionally obese. Nope, what he meant was because it is thin crust it reminds him of a flatbread. This is the type of pizza he would like to share with a couple of people (ok, he said one person, but I'm saying couple) before a main dish. I disagree (which is why I usually don't include his opinions in my review, but I just really liked the phrase "appetizer pizza"). This is exactly the type of pizza I like. The size was perfect if I was pretty hungry (although I would also love to share one so I can try something/someplace else). I also love thin crust and wood-fired pizza. The marinara sauce really hit the spot. We got a Margarita Pizza and the cheese was nice and gooey. 

We got the pizza quick! We all split up, Brandon went to Ava, I went to Hemingways, and two friends went to Graze. Brandon got the pizza about ten minutes before my food was ready and we were both sitting and waiting for a long time before my friends got their food. This is based off of one experience, but I'm pretty impressed! 

This pizza definitely hit the spot for me. I will be back.

This is a neat aquarium that also has a large bird exhibit (the exhibit is large, not the birds themselves).   The aquarium focuses primarily on the marinelife that is found in the Gulf of Mexico (naturally).

It's a little pricey, but if you buy your tickets online you save a couple bucks.

It's the cheesecake factory, standard chain restaurant. I am very excited that they rolled out a skinny menu. The CF has always made the naughty list when it came to nutritional value. 

I'm a big fan of their lunch portion salads. Plenty big and full of flavors. I love the Carlton Salad.

This is by far one of the best places I've ever been to for a chain.  Regardless of what city I have been in and dined here it has been a great experience.  Their waitstaff is always on top of it and the variety of their menu alone gives me a food coma.  I've never had a bad item of the varied items I've tried and I'm truely impressed by the advancements they have made to offer more nutricious and health conscious offerrings.  

Their beverage menu is also varied and has a lot of specialty cocktails to fit any mood you may be in.  Not to mention if you're not into drinking they have Coke Zero, so they pretty much sold me at that.  Now as far as their desserts, I don't think you have to look very hard to find something that will satisfy your sweet tooth.  The hardest part is narrowing down your pick to just one item unless of course you are with others who will indulge with you!

We had a group of 4 at 11:45am on a Friday and were seated w/o any wait, but I'll say it picked up immediately after, and it was packed.

Very nice decor and atmosphere, and the service was nice.  The meals arrived quite quickly.  From being seated until leaving, it took all 4 of us only 45 mins for appetizers and meal.

We split #34 Goi Cuon pork & shrimp spring rolls ($3.25) and #46 crispy rolls ($3.95) that came w/ lettuce, cilantro, and cucumber to wrap them in.  Both were delicious, and it would be hard to choose which one I liked better.

For my meal, I had the Bo Xao Tao ($12.95 off the dinner menu) beef and vegetable in a brown stew sauce that came in a hot pot.  They brought a huge bowl of white rice as well and a large extra plate.  You could mix the rice into the bowl or mix the rice, beef, veggies, and sauce on the plate.  Either way, I had more than 1/2 of the bowl and rice left over to take home.

Others in our group felt that the prices were a bit higher for Vietnamese and Chinese food.  Not many entrees under $10/plate.  So that's the main reason for 3 stars instead of 4, but as I get more familiar w/ this location and try other things on the menu, it's possible I'll raise that to 4 stars.

DiBruno's carries Isgro's pastries now. The peach cake is my favorite although now it's not soaked in liquor as it used to be.

Tiramisu is ok. I don't taste the coffee or mascarpone.

We decided to order lunch and cupcakes from Jilly's on a Sunday. While they do offer online ordering, it was actually a tricky process and I kept getting an error message saying that the order did not go through. I appreciated the menu online and the option to order online, but I was a little disappointed that it was not working correctly. I decided to call their cafe and place the order over the phone. The girl who took my order was super friendly and let me know that their internet was down which is why the online ordering wasn't working. I placed my order and paid over the phone. 

When I arrived, there was a line (naturally), but since I was picking up an order I just let the girl by the register know my name and she had my bags of goodies ready to go. It was s super easy and painless process. While I could have asked for curbside, I knew that on a Sunday it would be busy, so I opted to go inside. 

All of my items were correctly labeled and the cupcakes were safe and secure in their individual cupcake holders! By the time I made it home to plate our food; I was so hungry! I ordered the chicken salad sandwich which came with chips and my hubby ordered a brisket sandwich also with chips. We also ordered some chili and some mac and cheese. We basically split the meals so that we had lunch on Sunday and lunch on Monday with the food we ordered. Both of our meals were good, but we both agree that they aren't anything special. I honestly don't know if I would ever crave a meal from Jilly's. A cupcake? Yes. But not a meal. The cafe menu is just A-Ok. 

I think the main treat for us were the cupcakes! We split the Crown Candy Apply cupcake and the Jack and Coke cupcake; they each had a shot in them...but I am not sure if the cupcakes themselves were actually made with any liquor? Either way, we enjoyed the cupcakes and split them into 4 slices each so that we could enjoy them in smaller portions. There is no way I could eat a whole cupcake or even half a cupcake in one sitting. I definitely recommend splitting them into 4 slices and taking 2-3 days to enjoy the bites. 

Will I go back to the cafe for a lunch or dinner? Probably not. But I will go back a few times each year for a cupcake of the month! And let me not lie, I do purchase cupcakes from Dierberg's or Straub's whenever I need a special treat.

Let me tell you a story about how some meatloaf saved my life last night.

I haven't exactly had the best week of my life, and around 4pm yesterday evening, I started feeling funny. "What the hell is the matter with me?," I kept thinking. It suddenly occurred to me that oh, hey, I totally haven't had food yet today. Luckily a friend was able to meet me at The Shaved Duck in less than 15 minutes, and even MORE luckily, there were two open seats at the bar. By this point I was starving.

Enter the meatloaf with a rootbeer glaze, served with a side of the best BBQ sauce I've ever tried. I don't think I've ever eating something that fast AND liked it just as much! It was so satisfying without being too heavy, and I can say with ease that I'd eat that on a weekly basis if I could manage it. The carbs also played a role in the life-saving, as I was able to sneak in a creamy, crunchy bite of macaroni and cheese between the meatloaf bites. I also switched the carbs up as my friend so kindly fed me bites of her garlic mashed potatoes. 

As for a wine choice? The red blend on the by-the-glass menu. OMG.

I'm going to end this review before I get even more dramatic, but seriously Shaved Duck... thanks for putting a smile on my face and your stellar meatloaf and perfectly prepared carbs in my stomach. I owe ya one.

The meat eaters have all the fun at Lolis Mexican Cravings.  While I am grateful that Lolis includes a vegetarian taco and sopa option, I wish that the beans weren't pureed.  If Lolis were considering adding soyrizo or jackfruit to their menu board, I would shout "YES! YES! 1000 TIMES YES!"

Pleasantly surprisedby the quality of the food.  Small Plate option of a single Salmon Spring Roll ($5.50) was perfect.  Quinoa Salad was nice but thank goodness I got the cloyingly sweet dressing on the side.  Loaded with sugary fruit puree too.

It's close by - so we'll be back.

Let's get one thing straight: like all of Jose Garces' establishments, Village Whiskey is not for the faint of wallet.  With that said, what you will get is an excellent cocktail that should make the hefty price tag worthwhile... if, you choose wisely. 

Example #1: Good Choice
I enjoyed an old fashioned that had somewhere in the neighborhood of 2.5 ounces of bourbon.  I was surprised at the lack of muddled orange and cherry garnish and when I questioned the bartender, he said that a true old fashioned is made with bitters, sugar and lemon only.  The muddled cherry and orange is actually a more modern take on the drink.  I always enjoy a little history lesson with my cocktail and I will certainly keep this knowledge in my back pocket for a later date.

Example #2: Not-So-Good Choice
For my second drink, I went with the bartender's suggestion and tried the corpse reviver 2.5.  This fancy pants drink was tasty for sure, but definitely not something I would invest in again when I could be sinking my teeth into a gigantic burger for three dollars less instead.  See what I mean about choosing wisely?

Next time, I will be more conscientious about my drink selection.  I will also be tearing up the dinner menu.  The burgers that surrounded me on this visit looked fantastic, and I loved the interesting selection of toppings that are available as add-ons.  Oh, and duck fat fries with short ribs and Sly Fox cheddar sauce?  Yes, please.  

Jose, you da man.

I've been to Datz on a few occasions and I've always been quite happy. Once, When I showed up with the lovely Tiffany, we had the 2nd tier to our selves.  

The food was delivered quite quickly, and served up by a friendly waitress. Granted all I ordered was a salad, so it's kind of hard to make that take a long time.. but I'm sure some could. 

Over all, I think Datz is a solid place. I'd go more if it were closer.

I see a lot of bad reviews for this place but my experience was actually quite nice. 

Went on a Monday evening about 9:00 and waited about five minutes for a table for two. Ordered a couple Stellas, why yes we will have the 22oz size! Took a few minutes to come but server was really busy and very appologetic so no biggie, it took me that long to figure out the menu anway.

 Then ordered some chicken nachos. Wow, that plate was huge! More then two could eat, Although we did prove formidable opponents. 

My friend had a monster burger for dinner, don't know what it was called, but it was huge. I had the banh mi tacos, delicious little critters with some nice crispy/spicy/sweet pork and uber fresh toppings. Quiet noshing from my friend tells me he enjoyed his meal as well. 

I don't know what the total bill was as my friend grabbed the tab but the food prices looked really reasonable, especially for portion size. 

Don't forget to hit the cheesecake counter for a slice on your way out (Where I found my friend drooling over the case when I returned from the ladies room) 15 different cheesecakes enough for you? Is there such a thing as too much cheesecake? I'd have to argue that point.

Would I come back here? I'm already planning on it!

The food is delicious.  The portions are too small.

Yes, I know that the portions are supposed to be small at a tapas restaurant, but that still doesn't mean I agree with the idea.  Paying more money for less food is a concept that turns basic economics right on its head.  I do not think it is cute to fork over 8 dollars for a two-bite burrito.

That being said, the food is very good.  We had two enchiladas, ceviche, and chicken tacos.  The ceviche was the absolute winner of the bunch.  The margaritas were less impressive than I had been led to believe they were on yelp.

The decor comes straight out of the Steven Starr manual.  Bold colors and interesting furniture lined the room. I liked it.  

This place is not for everyone.  I am a very tall man with a huge appetite so it is not cost-effective for me to eat here unless its a really special occasion.  If you are a small person who is less gluttonous than I, you will really like Distrito.

I always enjoy Cheesecake Factories.  You get a lot of food for the price.  I like to joke that the Cheesecake Factory is the epitome of American food, big portions!  Like other reviewers say, it gets crazy crowded at night.  I was there on a Friday night with a group of about 10 and our first person got there an hour early to make sure we could get a table.  I don't think it is worth that wait, so I would suggest going at a time that is less crowded.

I love the bread that comes to the table.  I'm one of those diners that always manages to ruin his/her appetite by snacking on the bread.  Although I'm not a big fan of sour dough, I like the other bread that they serve.

I've gone to the Cheesecake Factory in Sugar Land, Texas a lot, so I can say with confidence that the cheesecake here is probably just as amazing as in Texas.  It is the variety that is so amazing.  At this Cheesecake Factory, I had a spinach and cheese omelet (yes I know it was dinner, but I'm a huge fan of breakfast for dinner).  It was delicious, fluffy, and of course, huge.  I'm sure I'll be back.

Had a lovely dinner with friends here for New Years Eve.   Very, very expensive since we shared two bottles of highly marked-up champagne, but certainly worth it to treat ourselves once a year.  The atmosphere at Oystercatchers is an elegant, subtle posh, which makes it a great place to dress up and go to celebrate a special occasion.

We started dinner with calamari 'fries'. Lightly breaded, flavorful, and moist, with an unusual dipping sauce that elevated the flavor from good to great.  For my entree I had the Seared Scallop Romesco, which came recommended by our server.  3 perfectly cooked large scallops with a red pepper pesto on top, and a small garnish of grilled artichokes.  Served on a creamy bed of ...something..not sure...risotto maybe?  Anyway - delicious!

Desserts were the only real dissapointment of the night - out of four that we ordered, the key lime pie was the only one 'loved'.  My red velvet lava cake was not served even a bit warm, and did not have a lot of flavor.

Our server was excellent, and even though you could tell she was busy, she always took her time with us.  She was also completely on top of making sure our champagne glasses stayed full.  Nice experience, now I'll start saving my pennies for their brunch.

Oh wow!!!!
Went here for a private event 4 course lunch yesterday and it was phenomenal.

The pastry chef did a baking demonstration for our group and the owner is a class act!

We started with the incredible humus on fresh baked bread.
4 types of delectable veggie salads: Carrots, beets & walnuts, red peppers & tabbouleh.  All were yummy.

Next the haloumi (fried) cheese with fig compote arrived along with crispy fried cauliflower & an heirloom tomato & sable salad.

For the entree we had either grilled eggplant (infused with pomegranite) or salmon.  Both were super tasty.

The desserts included a home-made cashew baklava with white chocolate pannagotta and fresh peaches.  Also a labneh semi-freddo (I did not care for it's tang) garnished with cucumbers and fresh diced summer melons.  The garnish tasted better than the dessert (to me).

FABulous service and a great, great meal.

G-d, I love it here.

We definitely had a blast at the grand opening! The mayor of Tampa, Bob Buckhorn, the local news channels, print media, and a large crowd of people were in attendance which was amazing for 6:45am! First, they performed the official ribbon cutting ceremony. Then, when we entered, we were all provided gift bags including signed and numbered art! Luckily a table for six was no problem as we got there right as they started seating guests! Shortly after, the line started.

Our waitress did a great job with all the photographers and videographers around, working our table and others. Richard Gonzmart came by to greet us and thank us for being there for the opening. He's so enthusiastic, sleepless, fun and professional. He's great for Tampa! Thanks Richard!

Once we were settled and drinking our coffee, espresso, and/or cafe con leche, step one was to get our Breakfast Club badge! Success! Woohoo! Mission accomplished!

Then we enjoyed our very affordable and properly prepared breakfasts. Nobody ordered pancakes but we dared one particularly bold member of our party to take a picture of a huge pancake at someone else's table. No problem! 

We were stuffed at the end so we all ordered pie to go! I can't wait to try it tonight!

Why 4 stars? Because the Greek salad was worth an update.

   ---   ---   ---

I visited Hellas several years ago and have always had it on my list to return. I originally rated it 3-stars due to a very average gyro, but I know that Hellas is a treasured staple of Tampa Bay and Tarpon Springs, so I wanted to give them a second chance. I don't live anywhere near Tarpon Springs though, so it took me a while to make my return visit.

I had been craving a greek salad and the Hellas version of that absolutely did not disappoint. I'd recently settled for a Greek salad from a fast casual spot near my house and it was a "you get what you pay for" situation. But the Hellas Greek salad hit the spot for everything I wanted it to be. 

However, I stand by my 5+ year old rating of the gyro. My wife opted for one and it was as pedestrian as I remembered it to be. In addition, I asked for a side of gyro meat for my salad, and it was barely room temperature, which was a bit off-putting.

We also hit up the bakery afterward, where I scored a Mil'fe and a Coconut Pasta, which is basically just a Coconut pie/custard concoction. Both were just ok. I also had a Greek coffee, which was a shot of espresso with sugar, but they leave the grounds at the bottom of the cup. They're compacted so it's not like you're tasting ground coffee bits throughout. It was pretty tasty, actually!

One shoutout I wanted to give is to our server. I screwed up by not getting her name, but she was amazing, despite Hellas very crowded and loud. I commended her ability to act like we were the only customers in the restaurant.

So to sum it all up...

Greek Salad: 5-stars.
Gryo: 3-stars.
Baked Goods: 3-stars.
Service: 5-stars.

A round 4-star average!

It's really good Malaysian but it's never great. I like Banana leaf around the corner better. The food is solid especially the noodle dishes and the satay tofu. The Roti is s must! I just never leave and feel I had a great meal.

Yelping 1100

My kid will paid for the dinner, why not select a good one. My kid also want to experience the local famous restaurant after he has moved away from home. Bern definitely is well know outside of Tampa that make him to choose this restaurant. 

I have been to Bern for several occasions. One time is by my own and many time are power dinner with the clients. Since then, I have not been back for about five years. Since then, they value of the meal has changed to better. Before it, the side is paid as a la carte. Now they include as part of the meal. It make the value of the dinning improve. 

We were seated at the Bronze Room. I like open room with bronze statues on the wall. It is elegantly decorated. We order the 14 oz chateaubriand for two and a chop steak. Each meal come with onion soup, salad with dressing of your choice, fried onions, zucchini and carrot. The French onion soup is amazing. 

My steak was perfectly grilled. I would said if you come here, chateaubriand is the way to order your steak. No other place do better than here. The chop steak is well presented over the mash potatoes. I like the waiter prepare the whole potato to added all ingredients on it including the bacon bite. 

After the dinner, it was a pleasure to visit their kitchen and the cellar. I saw many famous post of pictures are in this cellar. The dessert room is like a maze. We have the taste of the Bern with five Bern's signature desserts. I like the King Midas and the banana cheese pie. 

Everything is good here. Service- check; food delivery - check; ingredients quality- check; ambient-check; taste-check; chef skill- check. 5 stars.

They have a great happy hour with $5 Sangria, discounted well drinks and half off the lounge menu.  You can look on their website to figure out specific happy hours.

This place is unexpected in its location and it is a testament to how good it is that it is still busy.  There is parking in the back, but it was completely packed at 6 p.m. on a Thursday, so I parked across the street, which ended up being a flat rate of $2.  Honestly, if this was located in a more desirable place, parking would not be that cheap.

Inside it is super noisy, so we opted to sit outside, which was still pretty loud.  Do not expect to have an intimate date here.  

I thought the Sangria was pretty good, but it is not a normal Sangria.  They only use apples and oranges to make it and it has a less fruity taste.  It seriously looked like the color of blood to me.

I tried the mac and cheese and I honestly felt like it could use more truffle.  It was good, but I was expecting better.  I think if they added more truffle it could be great.  

When we left about 8:30 p.m., there were spaces in their free parking lot.  So if you're driving to get here, try going a little later if you want it to be emptier, because I bet a lot of people go here straight from work.

I often wonder where all the younger professionals are in Tampa Bay and now I know, they are all here.

This dive bar has excellent food - much better quality than I ever would have expected! I've been here a few times and each time we got a burger. I can't remember what else we've gotten, but it's all been pretty good. Definitely a good go-to place if you're in the area and want tasty, good quality bar food

What a unique experience here... The menu and the decor! So inventive and original! Who doesn't love a place with fuchsia uplighting, gymp covered chairs (yes like the kind you used to make things out of in camp), tons of Mexican wrestler masks, and a eating in car?  

We went around 8 pm on a Friday with no reservations and didn't even wait 5 minutes. We were seated and presented with a bowl of spicy chilli peanuts with cilantro... So yummy! We started with margaritas of course (I had a virgin pineapple because I'm preggers for only $3 and my husband had a honeydew which was $13. They were delish and only served on the rocks, no frozen ones here). 

I wasn't too hungry which was great because this is a small plates place. I had a fabulous soup, possibly one of the best soups I've ever had. It was sugared pumpkin and was offered with lump crab and roasted crushed walnuts on top! It was amazing!! Different and I would never think to put those ingredients together, but it really worked! Then I had the Mexican city style quesadilla filled with mushrooms and pure yumminess! Don't think big cheese quesadilla this was small and more like a tostada, but really enough food and really tasty. They do have some great vegetarian options!! My second choice would have been the grilled cactus, black bean, crispy quinoa and salsa tacos. 

My husband had a pot of refried beans and the skirt steak tacos which came 3 to a plate and were smaller, but he still wound up taking one home. 

Compared to those around us, we barely ate! The plates just kept coming for everyone! The salads, flatbreads and veggie nachos looked great too! Everything looked so interesting! Everything on the dessert menu looked good too! We were tempted by the flan with caramel, gala apples, toasted hazelnut with roasted apple sorbet, but we went with the classic churros to keep it traditional. They were so perfect soft, hot, and sugary! They came with two dipping sauces and were so moist I kept checking to see if there was cream inside. Yum! 

The waiters were very much in a rush and the hostesses weren't super friendly, but the food made up for it and the music was real good! 

Street parking was fabulously easy! Tons of spots, tons!  

It was a very mixed crowd... Older couples, college kids, even families, but mostly groups of young professionals. 

We intend on going back and will even bring our two year old to sit and eat in car which looked so fun! 

A really great time was had! We surely recommend it!

My girlfriend and I went for the Monday $10 fried chicken blue plate lunch.

We arrived at 11:30 a.m., and got a table right away.

The only thing you have to select is sweetened tea or unsweetened tea. This day it was mango tea. I prefer plain iced tea.

The salad was the same as last time, but a little over-dressed. The quick-pickled vegetables (red onion, cucumber, radish) were so good with the greens and hard-boiled egg slices.

My girlfriend couldn't eat much of her salad, because the dressing was too sweet for her. (It's a medical thing, not a taste thing.) So, I took her salad home with me.

The main meal was one huge starch party. Mashed potatoes, fried chicken with gravy on it, and macaroni and cheese.

We each got two pieces of chicken (leg and thigh). The thigh was boneless, so I ate it with knife and fork because of the gravy. The chicken was not particularly seasoned.

I do not believe the gravy added any flavor.

The mashed potatoes were luscious. The macaroni and cheese was OK.

Our waters were not refilled. And we were asked if we wanted iced tea refills. Well, we were sitting there still eating. So, yes, iced tea refill, please, since we're out of water and tea. Why did she have to ask?

I took a little of everything home.

I have never had a bad sandwich at Wright's so I decided it was time for me to update my review and give Wright's the 5 stars that they deserve.  Recently I discovered the California Reuben.  I am not a fan of corned beef so I love how they use roasted turkey on the sandwich instead.  I have never had coleslaw on a sandwich, but it is delicious and I wish I had tried it sooner.  I am also pleased to say that the red velvet cake rivals my mom's.  A true southerner would agree that this is some of the best red velvet cake!

This airport kind of sucks...

CONS:
- PHL TSA is very inefficient and unfriendly= bound to make you late for your flight and put a frown on your face.
- Disgruntled workers- guards, baggage handlers, etc.
- Not many outlets which is very inconvenient when you need to recharge something
- Gross bathrooms- don't use them!
- Not enough seating
- Needs renovations- dark, drab, disorganized.
- not enough outlets
- no pet relief areas
- only Bank of America ATMs
- wifi is not free

PROS:
- There are clocks on the walls- not many airports provide this, which is very nice if you are in a hurry (because of TSA) and don't have time to check your cell phone.
- They are in the process of renovating

I would give this place 3 stars, but TSA is so incredibly unpleasant!

Ashley is right about the technical mis-placement of many reviews due to confusion about the Teresita/CapdeVila megaplex of restaurants.   The seminal grocery store & original lunch counter on the corner have always been La Teresita.  But when the founding Capdevila family built the larger 2-story building, the new, more elegant table & chairs restaurant on the east side was named for the family.
