Later the smaller former lunch counter building which was a gas station in an even earlier career became La Teresita Bakery.  And the family enterprise expanded east on Columbus to open an evening dance hall/club and catty-corner across Columbus to create La Teresita Beauty Salon............But by any name, the food offered at the several La Teresita eateries still rates 5 stars & repeat patronage in my opinion.

Enough history and untangling of nomenclature?  Our next lecture will cover story of how the cigar factory capital of the US, namely West Tampa faded and Ybor City stepped up to glory.
This is an iconic St. Louis thing to do and fun if you have family or friends visiting from out of town.  Tons of flavors and always a crowd enjoying their frozen custard.

This place is recommended by a spice store clerk for Killer Po-boy in French Quarter. Louisiana is the place to try Po-boy if you come to visit. We were determined not to eat the Po-boy at restaurant but at the food stand or bar. 

Erin Rose is a little bar with a small kitchen at the back. The front is the full service bar with TV and stool for sitting. When we arrive around 12 noon, the bar section already fill with people. Wow!!!!  The drinking starts this early. Of course some of them have order the Po-boy and drink. We have to walk through the crowd and order the Po-boy through a small window. This is a small and warm little place when you have so many people. 

I can see the waitress bring out ton and ton of Po-boy to bar area. This is good sign if a lot of people order Po-boy. We have order the gulf shrimp and the meatloaf Po-boy. The wait for the food to be cook is 25 minutes. No wonder those people have a drink while waiting for the food. 

The meatloaf is grilled and accompany pickle and vege. This is a good sandwich. The gulf shrimp is my favorite. The shrimp is seasoning and seared to cook. It added the slaw in the sandwich for the taste. Yap! This is a killer Po-boy. Got to try.

3.5  Perfectly fine for fast and cheap.

You have to ask for water.

You have to ask for sugar if you'd like some for your hot tea.

There are no utensils at the table, so if you are terrible with chopsticks, raise your hand.

The hoisin sauce had no chopped peanuts in it - a staple at almost every other Vietnamese place I've been to.

The other condiment sauce that is slightly sweet yet tart also was missing little piece of pepper or slivers of carrots, something else I normally see in that bowl.

The summer rolls were inexpensive - two for about $3.

I order my standby dish, the grilled pork with noodles, which come with a nice serving of chopped lettuce and carrots.  Generous serving for about $8.

Having experience nearly every airport every constructed, I would rate this one as "better than average". 

My issues...
 The long term parking gets full at inconvenient times
 The food choices in the gate areas is uninspired
 The direct flights to the west coast are extremely limited
 The direct flights to Europe and beyond are non-existent
 
However, this is offset by
 Free internet
 Clean facility
 Shoe shines available in the main terminal
 Reasonable logistics

So, there you go. It works. It's an airport. Better than most but, not without its flaws.
Still a great place after all these years.  Plenty of vendors and plenty of variety.  Definitely a Philadelphia institution and a good place to stop for a fast lunch or great groceries.

El Vez has all of those things you'd expect from a Stephen Starr restaurant: trendy atmosphere, polished service, killer beverages. However, the one thing that sadly didn't blow me away was the food. 

As many have pointed out, the portions are super small. Don't come here hungry or plan on dropping a lot of money to satisfy that appetite. Aside from being on the smaller side, the carnitas tacos and red chile & chicken enchiladas didn't have that wow factor. They both came out hot and fresh, which I definitely appreciate, but they were fairly basic otherwise. We started with the Tito Santana guacamole (mango, red bell peppers, jicama, habanero and serrano chiles) and that was great. 

The true star of the show would be the margaritas. My first pitcher was of the classic margarita. While a classic margarita is typically no frills, this one was pretty solid in execution. It was strong but mixed just right. The second round of margaritas was the Granada. It was made with gold tequila, triple sec, fresh pomegranate juice and lime. Now that's not a ton of ingredients, but they just worked so well together to create a refreshing and strong margarita experience. 

I probably won't come back to El Vez for dinner unless it's a group thing, but there's no doubt I'd return for a strong margarita and guacamole excursion. What better way to experience the atmosphere, service, beverages and guacamole?

The roast pork here is excellent; it is cooked in spices for hours until the flavors are imbued in the tender meat that almost melts in your mouth.  Get it with provolone and greens.  The other offerings are decent but I only come here for the pork because the area is a bit difficult to travel in, which is the reason why I am subtracting one star.

If only this place was closer to where I live and/or work.  

I have been missing banh mi for a long time, so I found this place on yelp.  I had to do a lot of street driving to get here, but I was thrilled to find this place.  The bread was crispy, the veggies were crunchy, and the boba (try the avocado smoothy -- not to sweet and super creamy) was fluffy.

English might be an issue here.  I ordered the combination meat banh mi and received a BBQ pork banh mi, but it was still tasty.  I'll have to go back another time to try out their pate and headcheese.

$5 for a 6" sub and boba drink.  Sure, the sandwich is smaller than one gets in southern California, but the boba is a great price.

I remember when this place opened, oh so many years ago. I can't believe it took me so long to visit!

I've got a friend staying with me this week and since we didn't have anything planned for today, I asked if she wanted to check out this hot spot on the water.  She had worked there in the past, so we opted to see what had changed in the years since she had been employment. 

Upon arriving, we found out that parking was going to cost $6.00, it wasn't something I planned for, but it's less than the cost of parking at any of the theme parks.  The walk from the lot to the actual building can be quite a hike if you've got kidlets, so be sure you're wearing comfy clothes and keep them on the inside of the side walk. The trolly cars pass very close to where you're walking. 

I was surprised to find that they'd moved the "Chicken" from off of Kennedy to the center traffic circle right in front of the Aquarium. Not that I should be, but I had been wondering where the piece of modern art had gone, now I have my answer.

Admission was $21.00 for each adult. There had JUST been a Groupon for 2 for one, but I missed out on the deal.  So it's good to check to see if there are any specials for getting in.  I hadn't thought about it, but it's mid-week, any other time of year it probably wouldn't have been so busy, but it's summer vacation. Every summer camp that has a camp in session had a group of loud, unruly kids there. I was pushed, shoved and yelled at by more 8 year old's today, than any other day in my previous history.  Thankfully they thinned out after 3:30 pm.

The place is well themed, I loved seeing birds in "natural" habitat, being able to see fish up close, seeing how large some of our fish are that inhabit our mangrove swamps can get. And of course I love the rays!   I also had no idea they had PENGUINS! OMG! Now these were African black footed penguins and they were absolutely the most darling things ever. I really wanted to take one home, but I don't think my cats would like it. 

The 3' wide Manta Rays were beautiful to watch as they glided through the water, and seeing their under bellies with their human-esque lips always makes me smile. Flip, the sea turtle is a beauty to behold as well. 

The only "complaint" I have is about the dive show.  Jessica- the announcer was a delight. She was articulate and interacted with the audience well. She truly represented the aquarium to it's fullest. But the diver, Lillian, I could not understand a word she was saying. It may simply be a bad sound system, or it may be that she does not speak clearly. I would have liked to have understood the program though interaction.
Still enjoying our favorites of crispy duck salad and soft shell crab pad Thai..    New dessert of mango cheesecake was a nice finish.    Enjoyed a great Thai iced coffee as well.

Amazing chocolate chip cookies with chunks of chocolate chips. I follow them on Instagram and on chocolate chip day you can get the chocolate chip cookies for $1 when you mention it at the register. Normally it's $2.50 a cookie.

Always a five star experience.

Let's get their one negative out of the way. Parking, it's a pain, we all know it, we all love this place enough that we don't care. 

The good. It is a lot larger than it looks. With upstairs seating it can hold a pretty good amount of people. At 11 a.m. on a Tuesday I definitely did not need my reservation. Even when we left at about noon it was still only moderately full. There's no reason not to go here on a weekday for lunch if you dislike crowds.

FOOD - major reason why you go is because the food is impeccable. My dad got the Porkfection and my jaw dropped when it appeared. It. Was. Huge. Also, the chips were to die for. Next time, I'm ordering a side of chips for myself. It has a hint of sweetness to the seasoning and the drizzle of sauce is perfect. I would come back here just of the chips. My dad said the bread was delicious. Since I don't eat pork, I'll have to take his word for it. I tried the BBQ Jackfruit Tacos. It is completely vegan - it even uses lettuce leaves instead of taco shells. It is delicious. I didn't feel deprived at all. 

The cocktail menu looks incredible. I will have to come back to try it. 

There's a reason why Datz is so beloved in Tampa Bay. You have to try it. It will live up to your expectations.

Super yay!  Love the turkey burgers here.  They are NOT dry and so tasty.  I pass on the big bucket o' fries in favor of their YUM-CITY mac 'n cheese.  I order mine sans the tomato "jam" garnish.

They also have kickin' sides like greenbeans (crisp and studded with tomotoes) and sweet potatoes.  (Grilled with butter and cinnamon suger - like dessertm baby!).

It can get crowded and crazy - which is why it is not 5 stars -but the price is right and this spot ROCKS."

Amazing lunch selection!

Sadly there is no dock right in front of Jackson's, but you can dock in front of the Convention Center and walk over the bridge.

There are really cute Cabana style seating outside.  Even on a hot muggy summer day, it was cool enough in the shade to eat outside.  There is a beautiful view of the water so I would suggest eating outside.

Our friends always order the Conch Fritters and say it is the best they've ever had.  I tried one and it was delicious.  

The Harbour Island Tea (basically a Long Island Iced Tea) and the Red Sangria are both delicious!  I don't think you can go wrong with any of the cocktails. 

I got the Chicken Penne Pasta and it was to die for!  It came in this amazing Pesto Sauce and I've never enjoyed broccoli more than that.  My fiance got the French Dip Sandwich and it came on a pretzel roll!  That was unexpected, but in a good way.  It was fantastic.  The fries it came with were nice and crispy too.

I really enjoyed this place and I plan to come back as much as possible!

Why 5 stars? Because this is my favorite new discovery in 2013.

   ---   ---   ---

As someone who eats out more than the average bear, sometimes the meals can begin to run together. Anise was like a spiritual experience.

The stinky buns were utterly phenomenal. I definitely had a favorite, but now I am confusing them in my head and can't remember which one that it was. Oh well, I guess I'll have to return and try them all again... for research. And science.

The looks of the place made me feel like you're at a a high-end joint too classy for myself... but the prices are incredibly moderate. $11 for 3 Stinky Bunz? My friend and I split some truffle tator tots. Um... yeah. They're other-worldly. 

I'd go as far to say Anise might be in my top five restaurants in Tampa Bay. That's after one visit. And I haven't even tried the duck tacos or the cocktails yet... two of the top staples.

What a gem.

Felt like I was back in Sante Fe! The decor from outside in reeks of a little Mexican-inspired retreat. Picture colorful decor, cactus, mirrors, carnitas, salsas & such. 

Before you read any further...Delicious breakfast Monday-Sunday!

Service was awesome. The servers work well together; creating a cool dining experience. Very laid back, atmosphere at the bar but if you're looking for an engagement take a seat at the community table. 

The Cornmeal Pancakes come in a short stack (2) however 1 is more than enough. A couple can easily split a short stack and order separate side dishes to enjoy.  The pancakes are hearty, thick & splendid with their berry compote. I ordered 4 scrambled eggs with red onion, goat cheese & spinach that was so amazing I thought I made it myself. They also have great cocktails; namely the Crispin. I highly enjoyed SW Diner's great food & service.

Fyi, it'll probably be packed early to mid morning. Fret not seating is plentiful and available both indoors & out. I returned within 3 days. 

~Christy

I always think of it as a treat to learn that I'll be venturing to this spot for any meal day or night.  They have a very convenient text reservation system or you can always call ahead.  I would definitely recommend reservations as space is at a premium when it comes to this place.  Parking seems to be as well so pack your patience.  

If you're the indecisive type, stay away from the drink menu.  It is pages and pages of goodness and creative concoctions that will appeal to every side of your drinking persona.  They creatively publish all of their menus in a newspaper like flyer and all of their menu items appear to have a unique Datz spin on them.  You can't go wrong with any of their items.

If you have a sweet tooth, beware of their cakes, cupcakes, and unique dessert treats.  Check out Datz Dough (located next door) for more on that.  This is a great place to grab brunch, a casual lunch, or low key dinner.  You won't leave disappointed or hungry!

This is a little bit of California for me.

One of the things I missed the most about living in California was Trader Joe's.  Imagine my delight when Trader Joe's finally came to the Tampa Bay area.  

The parking lot is inadequate during busy times.  Half of the parking spaces are for compact cars, so leave your Suburban at home and take your Prius.

I love Trader Joe's for its collection of organic foods, for its bargain wines (no, not just 2 Buck Chuck), and its munchy foods.  The salted chocolate almonds are heaven on earth, and if you mix some chocolate chips with the sweet and salty trail mix, that's just plain addiction in a bag.  They have great prices for Parmesan and diced pancetta.

If you are every in south Tampa during odd hours, visit this place and buy up.

I went mid-September with my girlfriend. We both got 4 bones. She got porto fries as her side. I got corn chowder.

I cannot say how much I LOVE that they offer more sides than the standard, oh-so boring barbeque sides.

And there are the pickles!! I got three spears, and they're just so good!!

The ribs were great, chewy, no fall off the bone here. I ate most sans sauce, but I did try the coffee sauce and the mustard sauce.

The coffee sauce was great. The mustard sauce was too totally mustardy.

The corn chowder was creamy good with snappy kernels of corn, and appropriately hot. It had a bit of a kick to it. It was earthy, so I would say cumin.

My girlfriend's porto fries were Portobello mushrooms cut like steak fries, breaded and deep-fried. They were made ON THE SPOT, exactly when she ordered them, and brought to the table.

She shared one with me, and they were fabulous.

A lot of interesting sides were available this day, and I had trouble selecting just one.

I took home half of the corn chowder, two ribs and three pickle spears, which made for another glorious meal.

TO NOTE: There is now a BIG sign over the appropriate entrance door. The sign reads: ENTER. So, I got it right this time.

Evenso, we did witness many folks entering through the exit door and making their way backwards through the cafeteria line to get to the order area. Arghhhh!

I would like to patronize other Sugarfire locations, as I understand the sides are different, depending on the location and the chef's flair.

Nam Phuong personifies good Vietnamese food on the east coast.

Family and I brunched here some time ago. This is a popular Vietnamese restaurant in - surprise, surprise - South Philadelphia, with decent parking lot (street parking too), large seating capacity, and a conservatively tacky decor. It's not refined, but their true claim to fame is their delicious food, not their interior design.

Service was fast and efficient, taking our orders without issue. They sure dished out a tasty bowl of pho and the we enjoyed the rest of the dishes (shared family-style), including a plate of lotus root salad (totally killer) and a beef cube dish with lettuce and a sweet sauce - the bo luc lac. Recommended if you need a Vietnamese fix!

I have since been back to Talula's 3 more times - including last night.  Each time was a true 5 star experience.

But not last night.

Service was still great.
Food was not 5 star.  (The cheese plate was still 5 star - best bites of the night including Délice de Bourgogne and a fantastic onion-y Abbott's Gold Cheddar.  (Had that last time and swapped it into the "World Travel" cheese plate.)

The cavatelli app was superb.  But tiny.
TINY!
Yes, I know it's an app - but they presented it in a huge, deep "pasta" bowl and it made it look even smaller.  Maybe serving it in a more propotionate vessel?

My friend ordered the spring foraged salad which sounded heavenly on paper and in real life was just OK. The ramps were over powering and the foraged lettuces were a bit bitter and odd tasting.

The beets and ricotta side still rocks my world.

It was a strong 4 for food, 5 for service but...
...here's the BIG but...

The cocktails have somehow gone awry.
Even my Arnold Palmer was just "meh. (Did they change their iced tea??)
My friend ordered a "The Painter" - a champagne cocktail and it looked like a watered down mimosa with lemon juice instead of orange juice ($12 - FEH!)
And the enormous wine glass that the rose came in (Reidel crystal??) made the skimpy less-than-6-oz. pour look positively puny.  ($10 - FEH again!)

I am deeply saddened to have to downgrade Talulas as it was one of my absolute faves.

So sad.
So sad.

Meanwhile - come have a cheese plate here - but be wary of the new barkeep.

An incredible addition to Hyde Park!

I love how the village is being revitalized. This area has such a wonderful vibe and great potential. Unfortunately it has gone through some rough patches but it seems to be on the upswing. 

I made reservations over a week prior and they only had 6pm or 930pm available. We arrived at 6pm to a BEAUTIFUL space-it reminded me of a sherwin Williams catalogue mixed with Pottery Barn or Restoration Hardware. The coloring was gorgeous and the "farm to table" rustic feel was welcoming. 

We feasted on some house made sourdough bread, a meat tray, and some wonderful pillowy fried dough balls to dip in a corn/ricotta cheese mixture. 

Next we shared the Brussels sprouts/kale salad and then finished it off with sharing the pasta/short rib meal. 

For the price and the quality of the food, it was a wonderful date night. We both agreed it was a perfect pick and we are excited to try it again.

This review is for Beiler's bakery particularly the prepared salad. My favorite is the cranberry walnut salad and the buffalo ham which is spicy. They sell it by the pound in different sizes of containers. It's right next to the donuts

Location and atmosphere are huge contributors to the success of a restaurant and this place has both in spades!  Add some seriously decent pub grub and you have a joint that has some staying power.

The atmosphere incorporates two floors. I would call it classy lite.  If you are having dinner you'll be on the first floor and the bar is on the second.  Both floors are deep and narrow and when it's busy it can get a little tricky to move around.  The trees growing through to the second floor are a wonderful accent as is the second floor window wall that opens in good weather.  On a nice summer evening the bar would be a great place to bring out-of-town guests.  One negative note; the bar stools that are also used at the upstairs high-top tables are very uncomfortable.  If you are there for any length of time they will literally be a pain in the butt!

The upscale pub grub menu is not particularly big but all of it will be decent.  My fellow Yelpers are correct in that this will be 3 or 3  1/2 star food.  There is one exception.  The hand-cut fries are INSANELY GOOD!  A large portion served in a metal bucket for $4 is a hell of a deal and they are completely addictive.  It should be a crime to visit here and not order them.

Adult libations are priced fairly.  There is a decent craft section and a solid list of specialty drinks.  Expect plenty of Happy Hour deals.  I'd happily return here any time for a solid 3 star or better experience.

Fancy place to dine. It has a good decorations and great entrance. The salad bar is impressive. With beautiful center decorations arrangement. It is very busy in week day. 

We got into second seating. Our dinner start at 8 pm. Which is perfect for all you can eat. I like the salad bar many item including hearts of Palm, shrimp salad, grill pineapple, and more. I have the lobster bisque at the end of meal. But not impress on it. No shrimp or lobster. 

The meat went on when they bring it to the table. The sirlion and the skirt steak are the best. That all. The rest are too salty. I could not taste the meat. If you pay $$$$ money, the steak or lamb should be better. No fireworks. 

Service is great, meat are below average, salad is good. Been here done that.

Pretty cool concept.  What better way to sell your wine than to entice people thru the front door with the prospect of delicious food?  Well played, Cooper's Hawk Winery.  Well played.

There were 4 of us with reservations for 7.  My broski and his wife are the prompt ones in the family, so they were there at 6:45 and seated 4 minutes later.  By the time me and la chica arrived, not only did we find them seated, but they had already defiled an entire loaf of pretzel bread.  So we sat down, asked for some more bread and ordered up some wines to sample.  Chardonnay for me and the sparkling wine flight for chica.  She prefers reds, so I'm not sure what she was thinking.  At this point, an ordering gaffe when dining out is almost obligatory for her at this point.  She liked 1 of the 4, which was the ALMOND SPARKLING.  I liked my CHARDONNAY, but it wasn't the best I'd ever had.  Still, no gripes from me.

After the wine came, we placed our appetizer orders: PORK BELLY NACHOS and AHI.  Both came out super quick, 5 minutes maybe.  The ahi was OK, IMHO.  I certainly wasn't wowed. However, I was wowed by those nachos.  Jesusfreakingchrist they were descrumptious.  So cheesy and meaty, and the little pieces of dices avocado were perfect on top.  If they weren't so expensive, I probably would've ordered two and called it a day.

For dinner, I ordered the CHICKEN SALTIMBOCCA because saltimbocca it's becoming my favorite Italian cooking style.  It literally means "jumps in the mouth," and is usually made with veal, so I was surprised AND excited to see a chicken variation on the menu. It  didn't come with a salad, so I requested a CAESAR, which came out almost as fast as it was ordered.  This was a full blown dinner salad though, not a side salad, so I shared it with chica.  I loved that it was a chopped salad, and loved the thick shards of parmesan cheese, but the dressing was unremarkable.  Not sure what we paid for the salad, but I'm certain it was too much.  As for the main dish, it was really good.  There were 3 chicken breasts of moderate size, served in saltimbocca sauce with capers, provolone and prosciutto on a bed of fresh asparagus with mashed potatoes.  It was good and plenty for sure.  There was an odd tartness to the sauce flavor that I couldn't put my finger on though.  Not sure what it was.  Either way, it was better than the saltimbocca at Zerillo's, but not better than Fratelli's in Oldsmar, so I have to give it a 3.    

Great service + tasty wine + fair prices + slightly above average food = I would return if asked, but probably not on my own accord.

Side note: Parking is tight because there are 3 restaurants competing for spaces, so if you plan to avoid the valet service and park yourself, be prepared to get a little flustered.

The Cheesecake Factory is not my favorite restaurant, but it is a great option when no one can make up their mind of what they want to eat!

My number one gripe is the wait to get a table.  A 25 minute wait at 2:30pm on a Saturday seems excessive...especially when it is not lunch rush.  Because the restaurant is always packed the service is always slow at one point in the meal.  Whether it's waiting on the check or waiting on dessert you will be searching for your waiter at one point or another.

The food is really hit or miss.  The menu is huge so can you really believe that the restaurant serves good burgers, salads, pastas, sushi, chinese, steaks, and home cooked meals???  If they would simplify the menu the kitchen would run so much faster (and their would be fewer let downs on the menu). 

On my last visit I ordered the BBQ ranch chicken salad and got four piece of chicken on my salad.  I was lucky if there were 2 oz of chicken on the salad.  I do love their bread, but I surprisingly am not a fan of the cheesecake.  How can you call yourself the Cheesecake Factory and offer the worst cheesecake?!?! That's right, 30 +/- different flavors of poorly flavored cheesecake.  The texture is just off.  Reminds me of one of those no-bake Jell-o cheesecake mixes.

The food isn't terrible, it just isn't great.  The restaurant is covered in strollers which is great for families, but not so great for single couples. For the prices and the lackluster food I would skip Cheesecake Factory.

We got in yesterday, arrived a tad early for lunch and had no trouble getting a table in the front window. I noticed there's no salt or pepper on the tables.

I got grilled cheese ($10) -- Sharp white Cheddar, Fontina, mushrooms, truffle and arugula with homemade chips. Both the sandwich and the chips were a little greasy. Together, it was too much grease for one sitting, so I took more than half of both home.

My dining companion got the cheeseburger ($12) -- Missouri grass-fed beef, roasted garlic aoli, bacon, Cheddar and a fried egg. He subbed a fresh spinach salad for the slde, and asked for no bacon on the cheeseburger. That burger looked fabulous.

Service was great. I wish the water they served was a little chilled; it was tepid.

We came here for an evening event and the patio, as always was a classy, hip venue.  Some of the food highlights:
1. mushroom flatbread - very thin crust topped with plenty of romano, mozzarella, shitake, portobella, and caramelized shallots.  It is very cheesy!
2. grilled Thai chicken skewers - decent with a creamy drizzle of peanut sauce and sprinkled with chopped peanuts
3. red pepper feta dip on pita - this was very good and had a perfect balance of feta, pepper, and thyme, all drizzled with EVOO and served on a crispy chip
4. BBQ chicken quesadilla - decent although very cheesy
5. seared tuna tartare with mushroom risotto - the tuna was nicely seared with a beautiful red interior but the risotto, while savory, was a bit too salty.  The rice was also a bit on the al dente side.
6. pan roasted steak with red wine reduction and mashed potatoes - the steak was cooked well and paired well with the creamy, buttery mashed potatoes.  The reduction was salty but the mashed potatoes were a good foil for that.
7. sauteed spinach - decent but still a bit too salty

Overall, the food was good, albeit salty, and the service attentive.  It's a great event venue and option for a evening business function in Rittenhouse.

Major reverse discrimination and average food = Eek! Methinks not.

I arrived at this place one evening at the same time as a Hispanic family of three.  We were seated next to each other.  The waitress spent a great deal of time being friendly and speaking with the family in Spanish.  It seemed like everything was going to be all good, but when she came to our table, she pulled a complete Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.  Rude, short with her answers, frustrated to be speaking English (presumably) and almost refused to make eye contact.  I had a similar experience years ago at the old Hanley location as well, BTW.  Must be something in the water.

The Cuban sandwich was tasteless.  No pickles, thick slathering of mayonnaise, decent ham and an unremarkable, very thin slice roast pork.  A Cuban shouldn't be stuffed with meat, but if a place goes extra skimpy like La Teresita, it had better be flavorful.  Major fail.

Also, the place is dirty.  Take a close look around, and think about how it looks in the kitchen (see pics).

Would never revisit.

CUBAN SANDWICH REPORT CARD:

Bread: Fresh, La Segunda Bakery
Ham: Baked ham
Pork: Roast pork
Salami: Yes
Swiss: Yes
Mustard: Yes
Pickles: No
Pressed: Yes
Lettuce/Tomato/Mayo: Yes, by default
Rating: 2.5 / 5.0

I haven't been here for a while and although my review stated I enjoyed it I barely remember the experience. This one I will.

Although it was during their famous happy hour (only at the bar and patio) we wanted a more intimate dining experience and chose the dining room where we were tucked away in a nice booth with a terrific server. 

We opted for a couple saki martinis to go with our appetizers of a tuna tower and some of the best sashimi I've had. All of it was delicious. 

Moved on to dinner..the teriyaki glazed rib eye for him and the sea bass for me. Paired with a nice bottle of Alexander valley cab of course. Both dishes were extremely impressive. The rub eye done perfectly with just the right amount of glaze. My fish nice and flaky and not over or under done.

We had to pass on dessert as we were quite full. 

The service was impeccable. ..the atmosphere was lively. .busy even but never felt hectic or crowded or rushed. 

I'll definitely revisit.

As with the prohibition movement, the Prohibition Taproom can be considered a leader in beer bar excellence in Philadelphia. Thankfully it's the opposite of the prohibition and beverages are flowing.

Since my last review, I've been back a handful of times. I've now got some major learnings under my belt:

1) Their draft list and bottle list is always great. There's a variety of local, regional and national brews. 

2) Their beer events are great, whether it be for beer week or other times of the year.

3) The food is also great. Unfortunately, due to the size of the space, it's a little hit or miss to get a table. Bufad is down the street if you don't mind forgoing the bar for a BYOB. 

4) When it's crowded, it's crowded. I actually like the place a little better during off times. 

While a little off the beaten path, it's worth the trip once you get there.

Meh....not horrible but nothing I'm dying to return for. 

Between the 3 of us, we ordered the following:

Shrimp stinky bun
Pork belly stinky bun 
Jap chae noodles with shrimp 
Shrimp tacos 
Oysters-which were returned because of them not being fresh 
Duck tacos 


Everything was ok- nothing stood out as a complete deal changer. 

The stinky buns wrote different but a little overpriced. 

The atmosphere inside is trendy, yet dark. The severs are on the alternative side with visible tats and body piercings, which goes along with the atmosphere.

I got the cheesesteak.  I was surprised at how many people were getting the cheesesteak and not the roast pork.  I think an employee called out sick because they were very slow and even if they were fully staffed they need a new system for getting people in, ordered and out.  The lady at the counter yelling at everyone is endearing but annoying.  Anyway don't expect a quick trip to John's and don't go on Monday (closed) and bring cash.  With all of that said, a very good CS.  Outsideish seating and where it is located I guess you can say it has parking.  Very good 'philly experience' cheesesteak.

I wish this place wasn't so crowded all the time.  I wish it was bigger.  And I wish I could go there more often.  But when I have gotten in there, I did find one of the best burgers in Philly.  Although Rouge makes the best in my mind, I like this burger almost as much, and in some ways I like it more.  Sounds weird, I know.  But if Rouge is #1, this is #1a.  I definitely like the atmosphere here better.  And I like the fact that they have my favorite scotch, Lagavulin, on hand.  I found the duck fat fries to be good, but not the best I have had.

Cookie company? Say no more. Seriously. Just. My mouth says thank you. 

I was giving my mom a tour of Reading Terminal earlier today, and a friend suggested we stop here. My mom bought a sugar cookie. I bought a snickerdoodle, white chocolate chip and a fresh dipped chocolate chip.

They are all gone now - a few hours later. I wish I knew their recipe, as I would make them all day every day and become morbidly obese and induce advanced stage heart failure, but it would be OK, because if you're going to go out of existence, might as well be from eating too many heavenly cookies.

Or something like that. Go there, and you will understand.

Cafe Lift on North 13th Street just south of Spring Garden, occupies the first floor of an old factory in this almost up and coming neighborhood south of core Center City. It's decor is all early 20th Century post industrial.  This has it's charm with high ceilings and exposed pipes and ducts, and large photos of the local buildings in black and white that are strong suggestions of it's history. 

On Saturday morning it was packed with a 20 something crowd enjoying Rival Bros Coffee and a short, but tasty breakfast/lunch menu. Hard walls make for poor acoustics, and the din was several decibels above comfortable. But, everyone was friendly and dealing with the racket. Even the queue to the single restroom had cool people who understood the situation and willingly chatted with their line mates.

Our table wait was about 25 minutes, but we made it to a small deuce in the middle of the room, with people on either side. It was tight, but the ambient noise allowed for privacy. The menu was divided into brekkie and lunch on either side of the document. I went with the chicken salad wrap, and DT opted for their burger. Both we're good. The burger seemed hand packed which gave it a softer texture and more retained juices. I prefer a more chunky chicken salad, but had no negs about theirs. We were drinking the house java, which was hot and kicky, but served in small white cups that needed refilling after a couple of gulps. Larger joe vessels would have been more efficient for the staff and felt more generous to the customers. 

Cafe Lift is a very interesting place to hang out. The room is really humming and the staff works hard to please. The harshness of the sound makes the experience not completely ideal, but that is overcome by the quality of the people and the kitchen, not to mention the enjoyment of just being in an old urban factory that has been so well repurposed.

It's been a long time since Tampa Heights has had ANYTHING to be proud of.  It was odd to me that investors in the 90's skipped right over downtown's suburb and went right for Seminole Heights.  Now, it seems the tables are turning and maybe, JUST MAYBE some revitalization will come to this forgotten part of town.  So far, we're off to a good start.  First, there was the purchase of the old Rialto Theater.  Then came the building of Waterworks Park, and now we've got Ulele.  I like where this is going!

On my first visit, 6 of us rolled up on Ulele on a warm and rainy September Sunday night as part of an ad-hoc pun and food crawl.  The wait time for us was about 20 minutes, so we bellied up to the bar and ordered some beers and cocktails.  I naturally had an old fashioned.  Only one though because the bartender was heavy-handed on the pour, which is definitely not a problem.  We all became familiar with the menu while sitting at the bar, so we were ready to order as soon as we were seated.  First, I ordered up some jalapeno muffins since they do not offer any complimentary bread. For my meal, I summoned the PORK CHOP with mashed potatoes and got the Ulele side salad.  Not everyone can successfully cook a thick-ass pork chop, but I saw them cooking a few of them on the grill, so I had to give it a whirl.  Glad I did too.  Not only did it look great with its cris-cross grill marks, but it tasted fantastic.  The mashed potatoes were decent, but nothing to write home about.  They were, however, better than the collard green and lima bean mixture.  The side salad was equally as delicious.  Not sure what all of the greens were, but I'm certain there wasn't any actual lettuce in there.  Definitely worth a try.  

On a return visit, I discovered my favorite Ulele dish: Pompano with rice and fried carrot shavings!  I know it's difficult to order fish with the smell of grilled steaks and chops looming thick in the air, but trust me, the pompano is better than their land animals.

Staff is always ultra friendly and the decor visually stimulating and the outdoor area next to the park is a pure paradise.

Definitely doesn't need another review to build the hype. This is a very beautiful and intimate restaurant with phenomenal service. We were here for restaurant week, which I'm pretty sure is the Tayim (salads and hummus, 2 small plates, main dish, and dessert) normally priced at $45 per person. With 4 people, we literally tried everything on the menu. 

Highlights: lafa served with hummus, lamb tartare, grilled duck hearts, and fried cauliflower.  

No need to read more reviews, just get a reservation and come here.

Although a great addition to Tampa bay, I hate coming here. Just like any other ikea, this is NOT an easy in, easy out process. Even if you know exactly what you came for, allow 20-30 minutes. 

People aimlessly wander the aisles oblivious to who is around them and act like they're in a trance. 

The checkout area is horrendous and takes way too long. 

Avoid at all cost unless you enjoy crowds and people ramming their carts into you.

Best. Meal. Ever. Talula's Garden was just phenomenal from start to finish. We started with a glass of sangria and a strawberry/gin/basil drink. The sangria was our least favorite item of the evening. The gin drink was fantastic. We then moved on to the lamb belly followed by a camembert cheese special. The lamb belly was melt in your mouth delicious. The cheese and accompanying bread was fantastic, too. In between those dishes, we were offered delicious brioche rolls with basil butter - INCREDIBLE. For entrees, we enjoyed the scallops and the chicken. We fought over which was better, but I can tell you the plates were clean. If it weren't taboo, we probably would've lifted up the dishes and licked them. We finished our meal with the ricotta doughnuts. The server was kind enough to comp our cheese because it took a while to come out and he offered us complimentary house cookies because we were patient with the chaos of the bar area. We were disappointed to be placed in the loud, bustling bar area (supposedly there was a lot of overflow from the garden when it started to rain), but we would still return in a second. Our server Corey was fantastic, the experience was great, and the food was one of the very best meals of my life. Can't wait to go back!

I have been so excited to try Anise...I love steamed buns (or as they call them, stinky bunz), so I knew I had to try those. I went with a friend who suggested we share a few things, which was great with me. We got 3 stinky bunz (crispy chicken, Chinese pork, and beef). The bun itself was good, but I wasn't a huge fan of the fillings. I'd say my favorite was the beef and least favorite was the pork (I was expecting a different texture). We also had the truffled tator tots, which were delicious but a fairly small portion and I had to ask twice for ketchup and it didn't come until we were almost done. We had the cucumber, tomato, and feta salad and the shrimp tacos. The shrimp tacos had great flavor, but i was not expecting a fried shell. The cucumber salad was good, but a small portion for the price. The service left a lot to be desired - our waitress was absent most of the meal, didn't bring things when requested, and it took forever to pay our bill. Upscale prices without upscale quality or service. I'd much rather go to another restaurant with similar food in the area than go back to Anise.

Another local favorite we finally visited.  We also love Bella's for Italian food, but now regard Bellini's as comparable.  And it is among the classiest interiors in any restaurant in Tampa....with high ceilings/windows, elegant furnishings and art, an open bar with linear kitchen and huge ceramic pizza oven and a  secluded nook upstairs for more romantic dining. 

We took advantage of the extended happy hour special prices, with $2 martinis and half-price entrees.  Best duck with non-sweet cherry sauce I can ever recall having and we both enjoyed a fine eggplant/cheese app.  My wife liked and shared the fresh grouper with pistashios. We passed on desserts but they looked great. 

Service was highly professional and high-class without snootiness.  Also learned that the same owners also run Green Iguana and the new Chophouse at the entrance of Centro Ybor.  Based on the quality here, the Chophouse has now been added to our list of destination eateries.

We went here for dinner with two other couples last night.

I found the outside confusing.  There were too many doors, each with separate signs.  The inside was fine, but nothing spectacular.  Staff was friendly.

The wine list is small.  It's very reasonably priced, but I would have liked a few higher end options.  I don't think that the most expensive bottle on a wine list should be the same price as an entree, there should be a couple bottles that cost a bit more.  The beer list, however, is impressive.

To start, I had the "liver and onions" (foie gras terrine and pickled onions).  Yum!  It was on the rich side, but that's part of eating foie gras, I guess.  It went nicely with the wine we chose.

For my entree, I had the mushroom ragout, which was also great.  I was stuffed from the small plate, so it was nice to have a lighter large plate.  The mushrooms were nicely cooked, and I loved the freshness of the tomato sauce.  I didn't think the beans were necessary with the polenta, but that's just my opinion.

My husband had the pork cheek agnolotti and the pork chop.  He liked everything but left the restaurant saying things were too rich.  My brother in law had the soup and the hangar steak.  They undercooked the steak (rare instead of medium rare), so he had to send it back, but everyone seemed gracious about it.  

We didn't try dessert because we were too full by then.

I liked this place, but I didn't love it.  I'm not sure why, maybe I had heard too much hype and expected too much.

I just don't care for Busch Gardens. Probably because I'm so spoiled as disney passholder, but maybe not. 

Gwazi, as others have said, will beat the hell out of you during the ride. This is really shotty workmanship. Shiekra, I don't do, I'm too scared and Yes I will readily admit it.

The animal exhbits are always nice to see but the politcally correct side of me screams out "what are those poor cheetahs doing out at 11 at night under a roller coaster of screaming people?!" "how many antelope died during transporatation here?" Oh..the horrors to be found when one looks.

So put that aside, the food is disgusting here, The drinks limited, although better then they used to be. 

The price, way too much for a small adventure like this. I suppose if your a coaster fanatic and want to ride them all day it might do, but really not more than that.

OMG, everything that I had here was sooooo damn good!  The guac & salsa were sooo darn tasty.  I had fish tacos for the very first time, & let me say it was deeeeeellllliiiiiishhhhhh!  I had foodgasms throughout my entire meal.  The apple cinnamon empanadas were good & very much fulfilled my one fatty meal per diem.  Service was top notch & ambience as well.  The bathrooms are outside of the restaurant but inside of the building.

This review has been many years in the making. C'mmandahs (in my best approximation of the regional dialect) is the standard bearer for food, service, environment, and an overall dining experience. It simply doesn't get any better.

I first came to Commander's the day I was sworn into the Bar. I was living in the Lower Garden District, working as an associate for the biggest law firm in the state and my parents had planned a visit to town (without knowing about the Bar ceremony). I kept things quiet because I didn't want to face the potential humiliation of my parents facing my failure but Praise Be, I passed. I was sworn in. My parents saw. We ate at Commander's to celebrate and lounged about the rest of the day, not talking or eating so as to fully concentrate on what we'd experienced. I was younger and, largely, inexperienced in the world of finer, experiential dining. The experience, while grand and extremely memorable, was somewhat lost on me.

Fast forward years later. Back in New Orleans. More traveled. More experienced. More ready for the night I had before me. I was ready to take the full Commander's experience in as a cognizant adult. This was my time. I donned my coat (it's nice to dress up to go to dinner), bow tie (apropos of the occasion) and glasses (form AND function) and made my way to the gem of the Crescent City. Walking in, we were immediately greeted (warmly) and walked throughout the building to a private dining room on the second floor. 

Incredible.

The room was ornate without being gaudy... done up without being off-putting... perfect. The lighting made everyone look like models. The chandelier glistened, sparkled and set the mood for dinner. Before I could take it all in, our service team entered the room, lead by Lorenzo. You don't know service until you have dined in some of the nicer (older) New Orleans restaurants. Galatoire's, Antoine's, Arnaud's... they all know how to make you feel special. Yes, there are newer. Yes there are shinier. Yes, there are more expensive. But none match that the stature and legacy of the old guard. You might not remember every dish but you'll always remember how you were made to feel. Lorenzo made me/us feel like royalty. From the stories to the descriptions of the plates to the suggestions to the coordinated service... I was swept off my seated feet. With every course made into a tasteful spectacle and every beat choreographed to perfection, it's hard not to be smitten with the dance.

If top-notch service doesn't press your buzzer, the food/drink should definitely ring your bell. As with most meals, I started with a cocktail. The Sunset on the Patio was a seasonal offering I was quick to try despite the base spirit (I am a rum/bourbon man). The drink was an attractive mix of El  Jimador  Reposado tequila, lime, Mandarin  Napole, and finished with pomegranate grenadine. Patio on Sunset. I paired this with too much bread (can't be helped; so soft, fresh and delicious with the butter) and the crawfish bisque. Exquisite. No more description is needed. Sparking wine bridged the gap between starter and entree -- which was paired with red wine. Keep up. My Gulf shrimp risotto was a decadent specialty item and a savory masterpiece. Even though the tastes didn't necessarily go together, I couldn't help not eating some of the goat cheese thyme grits that were being shared. The calories were worth the decadence. Since I was going all in, I finished up with strawberry shortcake and port wine.... and a cappuccino. 

I didn't want to get up from the table. A meal like this should be savored... drawn out for as long as possible. The evening ended with a quick tour of the property and - just like that - we were back into the sticky, sweet pecan-crusted air of the Garden District. With my belly full, clothes tight and brow sweaty, I felt like Big Daddy. I didn't want to leave. Commander's made me fall in love again with the New Orleans I left behind over a decade ago and long before that damn storm. Without question, it's as good as it gets.

Why 2 stars? Because my impression has changed after a few layovers here.

   ---   ---   ---

My first visit to BNA consisted of me getting off one plane, walking to another gate, hearing live music on the way, and boarding a new plane. I may have stopped at the restroom and possibly grabbed a snack, but it was a pretty limited experience.

I've since laid over here 3 times, and I've been in complete shock at the quality of eateries. I can confidently say that this airport has the worst collection of restaurants of any major airport in the U.S. Try this exercise... 

1) Pull up a list of the restaurants at BNA: https://www.flynashville.com/dine-and-shop/Pages/eat-and-shop-at-bna.aspx

2) Look up each eatery on Yelp.

3) Find nothing rated above 3 stars.

And from the places I've patronized, the Yelp reviews don't lie. This airport is just completely void of a decent eatery. It's shocking, considering how many restaurants there are. I've never seen anything like it, anywhere that I've ever been.

As an added bonus to my recent experience here, I unfortunately had a 3.5 hour layover here. I assumed there would be a lounge that my priority pass has access to, but sadly I was wrong. I eventually settled on eating at Berry Field Bistro, which was the final straw for me.

I've never been through TSA here or utilized the parking. I've never rented a car or gone attempted to navigate the public transit at BNA. All I know is that it's my least favorite layover in the U.S. and I will go out of my way to not return in the future.

The mussels here are still as amazing as ever.  $16 will get you a large pot cooked in your broth of choice.  I highly recommend the provence or classic brussels.  The provence is creamier but both are incredibly savory.  While the mussels themselves are on the small side, they are very flavorful and tender.  Use the accompanying bread to soak up the last drops of broth!  The burgers here are very standard and I would head to Devil's Alley or Village Whiskey.  The vegetable curry over rice pilaf was also just passable, although i did like the buttery pilaf.  Just go straight for the mussels and you'll be in good shape.  We also tried the Deschutes Black Butte Porter, which was a slightly bitter, dark brew with a hint of chocolate.  Will definitely be back to try the Christmas Ale!

The service was great and the ambiance is fun and busy, as always.  Still a Philadelphia institution!

Ya gotta take the extra trek down south if you're trying to get a solid steak. Tony Luke's blows Pat's and Geno's out of the water. Nice slivers of steak with each bite housing a good amount of onion and cheese. Bread was a little bit of a bummer. Seemed like it wasn't warmed up enough before coming off the the griddle. 

The real gem was the gentleman wearing kneepads outside helping to clean up tables and make sure the pickles and peppers and stuff were restocked. Please give this man a raise lol. He was so awesome in cleaning off the tables and making sure everybody had what they needed with a smile.

I'm not sure how I've passed by Prohibition Taproom so many times before and never stopped in. Last Friday night my friend's birthday party prompted my first visit. My experience was for drinks only, but other members of the party had food and seemed to enjoy themselves. 

The bar was hopping. The bar seats were occupied, most of the tables were full and people were standing in just about every open space. With so many bodies in not too huge of a space it did get pretty hot. Once another group of people left it got a little better. 

I don't recall if there was music or not as the place was pretty loud with conversation. All in all, the vibe of the place was good so I don't really care if there was music in the background. 

I thought the beer list was pretty eclectic. Feeling adventurous, I had sampled my first Nitro Boulder Mojo Risin'. I've never heard of it before but was glad I tried it. 

I look forward to returning and diving into the food menu.

After reading the glowing reviews of Anise Global Gastrobar I was expecting to have a "come to Jesus moment" so I was a bit disappointed when the my experience was just so-so.

My husband, sister and I visited Anise this past Sunday around 3pm for a late lunch. We decided to order a variety of appetizers so that we could sample a variety of the menu. Here are my thoughts on what we ordered:

Duck Confit Lettuce Wraps: You can order these with taco shells instead, but we opted for the low carb approach. This was the best item we ordered.  My sister thought they were a bit bland, but she had removed the jalapenos from hers. *****5/5

Truffled Tator Tots: I'm not a fan of mushrooms or truffle oil so I did not indulge in the tots, but my husband and sister thought they were great. *****5/5

Chinese BBQ Pork Stinky Bunz: They were good, but next time I'd try the pork belly instead. ***3/5  

Spicy Beef Tartare: The diced apples on beef was a different approach, but I didn't love the flavors or textures in this dish. The wonton chips served with this dish were super bland and overcooked. **2/5

Spicy Tuna Tartare: This appetizer was horrible!!!  The dish had a very off taste.  I don't know if the tuna was soaking in something to help prevent the fish from oxidizing, but the tuna did not taste fresh and we only ate a few bites before pushing it to the side. If Anise cannot turn over tuna quickly enough they should really consider removing this item from the menu because nobody wants to eat old tuna. This dish was served with the same bland, overcooked wonton chips.  0/5

I'm on the fence if I'd return to Anise Global Gastrobar.  Overall, the food did not impress me so maybe I'd just stop by happy hour to grab a few cocktails.

I had a taste of Anise Global Gastrobar at the Best of Tampa Bay. They had Korean Noodles. They were quite tasty, and the ones serving it were quite helpful and nice. They stated they had outdoor dining and they were pet friendly . I will be sure to check them out and see all the great eats they offer.

Great dinner once again.  Love the crispy duck salad appetizer (FYI - it's not on the menu).

Tried the mahimahi with mango.  Very interesting combination of flavors with lemongrass, ginger, and julienned mango.

The panang curry is one of those standards for us.   Always a bit spicy but tasty.


Good service and nice atmosphere.

Huge store where you can walk through various rooms to view furniture and appliances, etc. they also have various household items and kitchen utensils you can purchase as well. To me, I hate how you have to walk through the rooms to finally get to the area where you have to then grab a cart and pull your own inventory. I am still not completely sure if they have staff available to help individuals that cannot pull their own inventory. They do have drive up areas to make loading of items into your car easy however they have railing that are in the way. So you really can't push your cart directly up to your car for loading. You have to park at the railing then carry over the railing to load your car. Such a hassle. Nobody around to assist in loading either. The people that shop this store tend to be rude, taking up the full aisles, walking in front of you while trying to get a cart from the cart area. There is also really no cost savings going here. The only reason we visited is because they had the desk my daughter was looking for. 

Not really a place we routinely visit.

Repeat visits to the Oxford Exchange have been very positive. I regularly visit for business meetings and also am in love with their Matcha Green Tea Lemonade. Between the new market down the street and this location, OE has become a staple of Tampa Bay and I am always happy to show off the Oxford Exchange to town visitors or people who just have not had the experience yet. 

The menu has been solid and the service has been satisfactory in subsequent visits and the gift shop and bookstore are always fun to peruse. If you haven't had lunch at the courtyard at the Oxford Exchange yet - you must!

Di Bruno's is kinda like the Philly version of Citarella or Agata & Valentna in NYC.  It's a gourmet & specialty food market with a vast catering arm and now an upstairs lunch-only weatery.  It also has a cafe/espresso bar with a small selection of artesenal gelato.

The pastries are good - but pricey.

The cheese counter is a good place to investigate a world of cheeses.  (I, of course, hjave been forever spoiled by Murray's in NYC -but this is a good Philly alternative.)

They also carry sushi, spreads, and pricey prepared dishes.
Fresh produce is a plus - but the selection is limited.
I got the cheesesteak.  One of Philly's stand outs.  They got my order wrong.  Very good meat and roll.  Very good cheesesteak and under bridge semi outdoor experience.

The service was a disappointment this time. We were never served with water and tea. Our waitress didn't smile at all.

As usual roti canai is always delicious, thin and crisp.

Chicken satay was perfectly flavored and cooked.

The long-awaited 4 Rivers dream finally came true.  I've been trying to eat this food since our CM told me about these guys a few years back.  Unfortunately, the only time I was in the Winter Park area was a Sunday and they were closed.  But now they're just a few miles from home with their new Carrollwood location.

Upon walking in, this place is impressive.  It's vast, and very well-equipped for some high volume traffic.  The ordering process is a kin to a cafeteria line, which works surprisingly well for this type of food.  Why sit down and wait for food that is already prepared?  So they get props on a speedy an efficiency setup.

Where they fell short was with the taste of the food.  I ordered burnt ends and some Texas sausage.  For sides, I ordered some beans and potato salad.  Of these 4 items, the sausage was by far the best.  It was slammin', actually.  The burnt ends, however, were misleading, and the flavor was just okay.  Misleading, you ask?  How so?  Not sure how to explain this, but I will try.  When I've ordered burnt ends in the past, all I got was burnt ends.  The top charred portion of the brisket from being slow smoked.  What 4 Rivers served me ($6.99 for a 1/2 lb.) was a few scattered burnt ends mixed up with a bunch of shredded brisket.  I counted 5 burnt ends amongst my shredded brisket.  F.I.V.E.  Not a half pound. Very disappointing.  As for the sides, the potato salad was damn good, but the beans were just meh.  There was also a hiccup with La Chica's order, but that's for her to type up and tell.  Either way, it took from my experience because she had to sit there and watch me eat my food.

What I did like though is that there is a hand washing station next to the trash bins.  Nice warm running water, soap and hand towels, so no need to hit up the restroom before leaving.  Just dump your trash, wash your hands and hit the road!

Would I go back?  Not sure.  I'm not convinced that this is better Que than Big Mike on Sheldon or Hungry Harry's in LOL, but I might give them a second opportunity to sway my opinion.

You can get with this, or you can get with Datz, I think you'll get with this, cuz Datz is where it's at.

Okay so I haven't been in far too long, but Datz is a Tampa institution. In the heart of South Tampa it's a foodie and partier paradise. They do comfort foods and fun spins on items. Siracha popcorn. Nueske's bacon. Bloody Marys. It's a South Tampa Social scene. So get your American Apparel, David Bitton, Athleta, Lululemon or what-not on and make an appearance.

When they redecorated the entire restaurant exterior as the Refinery in Seminole Heights for Halloween 2015 that was the ultimate. And they are great friends to Yelpers near and far. And Datz Dough is next door. I'm a fan.

Mai Lee doesn't need another review but it's one of my favorite restaurants of all time and I have eaten here too many times to count.  I was here in between lunch and dinner on a Friday afternoon.  Great time to visit Mai Lee because as you know it's often packed, the servers are rushed, and there's nowhere to wait for your table.  I have a few regular dishes that I order here.  On Friday I ate Bun Bi Cha Gio, vermicelli noodles w/shredded pork and egg roll w/peanuts.  Its light yet filling and perfect anytime.  I get it without the shredded cucumber.  My other favorite is Muc Chien Gion, crispy salt & pepper calamari with no green pepper.  This is the food I wake up in the middle of the night thinking about.  It's always perfectly cooked and the flavors are spot on.  It won't take a lot of convincing to get me to go here!

Postscript: A lot of reviews complain about the service here. It's one of those places you just go knowing the service isn't that great but you overlook it because you like the food.  Also, not sure why we're even having this debate when some of the entrees are as low as $8 or $9.  Clearly we shouldn't be expecting the same service we would get at Kreis' for $50+ per person.

I always like what Yummy House puts out. And this location is no different.  A few of the friends got together for an Unofficial event and met here on a Weeknight, at 7:00 pm there was NO parking, and the line, quite literally, was out the door. 

Thankfully, one of us arrived early and procured a table! Once we started filing in, the conversation flowed and the catching up began and a lot of that had to do with the food.  We all are familiar with the food, so we ordered our favorite dishes and shared amongst ourselves.

I personally love the Salt & Pepper Calamari, I've never been disappointed with it. Their Hong Kong Style Won Ton soup was absolutely magnificent with the baby bok choy as the garnish.  Other entree's I tried were the Salt & Pepper tofu - which was very tasty as well. 

The service, while not 5 star due to how busy they were, was good, attentive when the other large tables weren't calling him away. 

I would certainly come back to this location.

Tony Luke's does all of the Philly staples, they have made their name taking all of the food that Philly is known for and putting it all under one roof.  Sometimes they do it better than the originals, sometimes not.  Whatever, it is good greasy food.  

Lately I have been preferring roast pork to cheesesteaks, and while I like DiNic's roast pork with broccoli rabe and provolone better, Tony Luke's still makes a great sandwich.  

I think that 3 sandwiches split between 2 people is the way to go.  I usually don't get fries or any sides, it's all about the sandwich.  

Make sure you make good use of the cherry peppers.

I was so happy when they decided to build an upscale mall in Tampa, and this mall has lived up to my expectations.  It has everything you could want in a mall - lots of parking, plenty of great stores, and a wide variety of food options.  There is valet parking offered, as well as car washing/car cleaning service while you shop.  

Most of the restaurants for the mall are lined up outside on Bay Street - the pathway that leads into the mall.  There are plenty of food options, from a casual deli, to a pub, all the way up to an upscale steak restaurant.  There are also a couple restaurants located inside the mall, and a food court if you are looking for a quick bite.

So many of my favorite stores are located in this mall:  Apple, Sephora, Fit2Run, Nordstrom, Free People, MAC, and Kate Spade, just to name a few.  I feel like they have something for everyone.

I love that there is a beautiful Renaissance Tampa Hotel attached to the mall - when my boyfriend's holiday party was held at one of the restaurants on Bay Street, it was great to have a really nice place to stay overnight.  And then so convenient to have breakfast at Too Jay's on Bay Street the next morning.  Plus - bonus - the mall opened early as it was on holiday hours, and we got to finish our Christmas shopping before anyone else was there.

A must-visit when you are in Tampa - great shopping in a fun environment.

The food is mediocre, and the place is insanely loud, but it's a Tampa institution, and the old building is worth visiting.

I wouldn't come here for excellent Cuban food, try any place on Columbus over the Columbia.  I also wouldn't come here for a romantic date or any meal where you want to have a conversation.  Every room is very loud.  I've been to their flamenco show, and it's really not great.

Their drinks aren't bad.  I do like their mojitos and sangria.  They are all well priced.

I don't especially like any of the appetizers available.  I've tried the chorizo (greasy and salty, don't get who'd like the insanely dry crackers served on the side), the croquettes (mostly too fishy or mushy), the shrimp (not bad, just not great or worth the price).  The salads are all too vinegar-y.

I had La Completa Cubana on my last visit.  It was a salt bomb.  I've had the rope vieja in the past and thought it was pretty good, but what makes it (at $19) different from the ropa vieja at Arco Iris (about $9)?  Nothing.  The paella is always a mushy mess.  I've tried their sirloin steak, and it was utterly unremarkable.  However, my husband always gets the Picadillo steak, and he always loves it.

I've had catering from the Columbia, and I've been to the (now defunct) St. Pete Pier location.  For all of my complaints about the food here, it gets worse as you go farther from the mothership.

Don't come here in a rush.  I have never been here without reservations, and yet I always have to wait at least 20 minutes, usually more.

I'm so happy to have a place like Armature Works (AW) near downtown Tampa now. The renovated building is absolutely gorgeous. Plus, there seems to be plenty of parking, which they share with local restaurant favorite, Ulele.  

AW appears to market itself as a spot to have meetings and weddings at, and they have a variety of gorgeous spaces both inside and outside available. The also offer a co-working space for rent. I have been to the Indie Flea Market here on the weekend, and this was an excellent space for that event. I think the highlight of the place, though, is a great food hall called the Heights Public Market. 

There seems to be quite a lot of 'satellite' restaurants in the Heights Public Market, i.e. smaller versions of local favorites.  For example, I love Ichicoro in Seminole Heights, and they have a smaller version called Ichicoro Imoto here, that had ramen equally as delicious as at the main restaurant. Local restaurants Ava and Cru Cellars have spots here. There is also a produce market, cocktail bar, sushi spot, butcher/deli, ice cream shop, steak house, and Cuban food place.

I love that Armature Works has a general hand washing area, plus a drinking water station, set up for everyone to use - it's a nice, useful touch.  One final tip:  make sure you wander out to the back of the building in time to catch the sunset - there is a great outdoor space, complete with games, tables and chairs, and the setting on the river is gorgeous.

I don't particularly like dining here because it is a bit cramped, but I stop in to grab some roast pork and duck every time I'm in Chinatown.  They are great about giving me the slightly charred ends (they tend to be crispier and more flavorful) of the pork when I ask and the duck is probably the best in town.  In terms of entrees, I like the wonton noodle soup and sizzling triple delight, but the one thing that I would truly recommend is the duck.  And here's the thing: I don't usually like duck!  Enough said.

We went to this place tonight with some friends. They had been there several times. I like Vietnamese, so I figured why not?

I was disappointed. 

I started with vegetarian egg rolls. They were standard for the most part. The sweet & sour sauce they came with was pretty flavorless and really thin. Usually sweet and sour is thick and has a sweet kick to it. She brought a whole plate of greens seperately - garnish maybe? I have no idea what the point was since it wasn't on the plate. It was a waste of lettuce and a plate in my humble opinion. I can't even imagine how many greens they waste a night! 

I ordered a fresh squeezed lemonade as well, which came cloudy with sugar. It was way too much! But it was cold and freshly squeezed as advertised.

I got #147, which was clear noodles with stir fried veggies. It came out almost immediately after our appetizers - we weren't even finished with one egg roll. It was noodles with cabbage, some kind of green, peas, and carrots. It had almost no flavor. I couldn't taste any hint of stir fry sauce. It was very bland. I ended up with a huge plate left of cabbage, since eating a bunch of cabbage with no sauce on it isn't very appetizing.

The service was ok. Our server had some communication issues, which I feel badly for saying, but it made it hard to ask questions about the menu and bar. I wanted to order an alcoholic beverage, but they only had a wine list so I didn't end up doing so.

I might try it again if friends really wanted to go but I'd definitely order something else. Til then, I have to give Mai Lee  2 stars.

Here's the thing Pat O's is a staple. It's not great, except for the piano bar...that is. Do not get a hurricane here, they are yucky. Make yourself a fresh fruit juice one at home instead. The bathrooms are generally stocked and clean.

I mean my parents went on dates here 50 years ago, how can I not give it 4 stars.

Random facts about Pat O's from my life: 
My SiL's step-grandmother was a piano bar performer in the 50s. So she has one of the original bar tables.

A friend from HS somehow got hooked up with Andy Gibb's entourage in the mid80s. The stories are pretty epic.

My youngest brother watched the superbowl hear and everytime the Saints did something awesome, a patron left the bar and sprinted up and down an empty Bourbon Street.

Yeah you know all that stomach lining you have sitting around just chillin'? Well put it to the test, now...at Han Dynasty.

This has become one of my top spots for bringing people from out of town who want the spice. Since eating here the first time, I've come back no less than one million times and my intestines are now lined with fucking iron.

If you are going for your first time, here is your standard order - spicy cucumber, Dan Dan noodles, Three cup chicken. If you don't like this, then it is because you are a coward.

Now, I've been exploring more of the menu and I have enjoyed the following items:

Dry Pepper Style fish.  It is perfectly spicy and crispy. If cannibals ever eat me, I want them to prepare my body in this way. Dry Pepper style Brad - It will be my greatest moment.

Fish and beef hot pot. This is advanced eating for practiced pros. The vegetable medley in the hot pot serves as a welcome addition to the meats and not just an afterthought. It is so great.

Cold pork belly - Very interesting. Think of it like thicker, better, colder bacon in a great sauce.

This is my favorite all-around Philadelphia restaurant.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is Robocop and Terminator 2 playing on two screens next to each other and the building is on fire.

Definitely my significant other's favorite place and it never disappoints.   Ordered the crispy duck salad (as usual -a special not on the menu) and spring rolls (just for a change). The crispy duck salad is always a winner.    We ordered the soft shell crab pad Thai and the woon sen with chicken, glass noodles with subtle spicing and veggies.    Both plates were enough for two so there was plenty to take home.   

Service always positive and not overbearing.

Decor is better than most Delco places.   If you like Thai, it is worth the detour.

We came for a dinner event in the upstairs lounge and the food and service were fantastic.  The mushroom flatbread/huarache and plantains stole the show, though.  The flatbread was paper-thin, crispy and topped with the perfect balance of cheese, trumpet mushrooms, and herbs.  And don't forget the caramel cheesecake!  Just get it.  Trust me.

I have been to Prohibition TR twice now, and both times had a much different experience.  My first visit was after a show at Union Transfer, and PTR was hosting the official afterparty.  That will go down as one of the most fun nights of my life!  The band along with tons of adoring fans were present, the juke box was playing, the beer was great, and the overall atmosphere was just awesome!  I have never eaten here, so I can't speak to the food.  While the beer list isn't as extensive as some other craft beer bars, they always have a great, varied selection & always something on nitro as well.
The last time I went was on a Thursday night, so obviously it was more subdued than my previous adventure.  The beer was still good and the ambiance was more intimate, so I was good!  My only complaint is the bizarre music they play when not utilizing the jukebox.  After last call they blasted some crazy head banger music that I'm pretty sure was meant to send us remaining patrons on our way.  It worked!

I don't get the love everyone has for this place. I have tried time and time again, to feel the same love, but I just don't have it. My friends love this place, for me it's just okay and I have to stretch it to give it 3 Stars. 

I've tried numerous dishes; Com Chien Duong Chau, Bo Xao Chau and Ga Xao Gun. I've tried two soups; Thap Cam and Bun Bo Hue. I've also tried; Cha Gio, Crab Rangoon and Goi Cuon. 
Those  of you who go often and feel the love, am I ordering wrong? Ian Froeb placed them at #24 on his STL 100 List for 2016. I just find the food to be bland with little flavor. 

I also, find the service to be less then desirable. I've always sat in the bar area or actually at the bar. The service is basically the same as ordering at a counter restauratnt. They take your order, bring you food and that's it. After listening to the young man working the bar, make fun of professional athletes and local political figures after they left, saying they didn't know how to order or eat Vietnamese food. I can only imagine what he would say about me, because I most likely gave him enough material for a comedy routine. 

Would I return? I do, I'm trying to feel the love.

When: June 22 and November 1, 2016 (most recent visits)
Why: Ian Froeb's List

I just had Sunday Soul Food Brunch this past Sunday w/ my awesome Naples friends Paul H. & Arlene H. 

They were looking for a artsy fartsy industrial vibe w a hip, trendy, chill environment. This happened to be the place inside and out.

Outside consisted of a huge wrap-around patio with a great amount of tables to sit at, as well as a lounge area, just to talk with friends. 

There were pretty cool metal decorations that you would probably find at an art fair, farmers market, or art show that proved that be quite original like mariachi metal bands, & different types of human like figures. There was shade and sun and a cover to protect from rain if needed. It was also a pet friendly environment which fit in with the homey comfy feel of the place.

Ella's doesn't accept call ahead seating until about 12:45pm for parties of 8 or more. Brunch starts at 11, and people start lining up around 10:30am ish. These people wait forever. It's that good.  They just drink & socialize to pass the time. They have great flavored mimosas including guava, mango, watermelon to name a few & a full bar.  

After they had waited for a while, we finally got a perfect outside table on the patio.

We had an awesome waiter who helped us with our options. I ordered side of shrimp & grits w/ chicken & waffles. My hubby had a rib combo w brisket, ribs, & fried green tomatoes. Our friends ordered bacon, mac & cheese, nutella, banana waffle, HUGE biscuits & gravy w chorizo, & chicken and waffles with fried green tomatoes.  We all tried everything and seriously everything was good, and was rich from lots of flavor. It definitely hit the spot.

We hung out there for a bit. Took our time since I had a large mimosa ($10). It made for a perfect brunch. I look forward to trying their dinner sometime & as well as their live music.

Service is slow outside on Sundays, but fantastic food. 

I have a feeling that TBBC is going to become one of the spots we go to on the reg. It's close, the food is great, and outdoor seating is perfect to bring fussy babies when the weather is nice. Ok, fussy baby, singular, my friend's baby was a perfect angel laying in his stroller for most of the meal. Mine had to be walked around the outdoor area by one parent for almost the entire time. So, five stars for that outside seating area. 

I got the Ahi Tuna Salad and my husband got the BeerBQ pizza. Both were amazing. When we got home I was dropping the food in the fridge before going out and I ate one of his pieces before returning to the car. It is that good. The cheese is baked to a crisp on the crust and the sauce is deliciously sweet. The Ahi Tuna Salad is delicious as well. It probably isn't the healthiest salad in the world with the heaping of fried won ton strips, but you only live once and I still felt healthy(ish) eating it. 

Service was definitely slow. When my baby was losing It because of nap time I would have appreciated if our server had a little more pep to her step, but I bet everyone else was here for a lazy meal. Just don't expect to get in and out if you sit outside on a Sunday. I also think most people come here to watch a game, so they aren't looking for efficient service.

Outstanding!  Everything was outstanding!  I've been a fan of this business for a long time, but I'm even more of a fan now with this second location practically in my damn back yard.

No matter what kinda beer you drink, they've got you covered.  If they don't, ask about their seasonal options.  If they have the tripel, GET IT!  If they have the Summer Days, GET IT!  Ask questions later.

Hungry?  No problem.  From pizza to burgers and pasta entrées, again they've got you covered.  During this most recent trip, La Chica and I split the following and left STUFFED.
