Ale Cheese Dip - Hands down the best beer cheese dip I've ever had.  Lacked the awkward bitterness of most beer cheese dips.  Just smooth and light, like an American lager.  Comes with what seems like a whole damn loaf of bread.

Butcher Burger - Very, very good, but very, very busy!  With 3 meats in the burger, it's a lot for my taste buds to take in.  And then with all the toppings, forget about it.  It should be called the sensory overload burger.  And with a $14 price tag, I'd suggest sticking to one of their regular burgers.

I saw someone order a calzone, and WTF?  Who is eating that thing?  It was the size of a small child.

Service was fantastic.  Bathrooms were extremely clean, and they have a system in place that catches waste water, and they use it for irrigation.  Being green makes green!

Will definitely be returning, and sooner than later.

I must admit that I'm not much of a quarter rat these days, but Erin Rose is a solid, neighborhoody-type bar...despite it's location just off Bourbon. It's small enough to feel intimate but with high ceilings that make it seem more spacious than it is. 

My most recent visit was with a bunch of our fellow yelpalistas.  When our bartender, Molly, heard who we were she told us about a review that named her specifically...to her detriment.  As we all wandered out into the night we promised to mention her in our reviews.

So I highly recommend you go see Molly & buy her a shot and if you're lucky, she'll call you a pussy...and she says that with love, of course.

I have quite the sweet tooth so I can't pass up the opportunity to stop by when in the area.  They have tons of varieties of donuts, cakes, and ice cream.  The ice cream flavors are revolving and it may depend on the timing of your visit as to what they have available.  The few time I've been I've never been disappointed with my ice cream or sweet treat choice.  Definitely a must if you are in the area and have a sugar addiction like me.  Bring plenty of money though, as it's not cheap if you decide to splurge and get more than one item or are with a group.  Also, its so convenient being located next door to Datz that any visit there wouldn't be complete without stopping in to see what Dough has to offer at the same time!

If you don't like Doma, go fuck yourself.

Their omakase maki is superb. The chef will create 6 little planets of flavor on a plate for you to enjoy. Each piece of maki will have a different fish, sauce, and style. I wish I could convey to you the diversity of this one plate with words(but I can't so I won't even try).

The smelt roe bi bim bap is my favorite item at this restaurant. Get two hot sauces and smother that shit in sauce. The clay bowl perfectly cooks the rice to a nice crispy texture. The tiny fish eggs add an unmatchable little crunch to each bite. I could eat this every day.

Sadly, the desserts here are weak.

I used to refer to Doma as "Morimoto lite" but I've really become quite enamored with the establishment. The food is creative and really tasty.
A lot varieties of olives at olive bar

I hereby update my review, adding a star.

Ok, so prices are still outrageous, but on a hot day, this place is a necessity. Yesterday, I drifted out of my  comfort zone and chose a cup of blueberry ice cream, mainly because, well, I like blueberries.

I'd definitely recommend! Service was great, too, AND there was no line. I was amazed, being that it was at least 95 degrees out at the time.

So, on the advice of friends, I came here for dinner last night.  The verdict:  tooo salty.  The sauce was great, but the meat was way tooo salty for my taste buds.  I got the burnt ends sandwich.  Looked great, but after a couple of bites ---- :(  Major disaster.  The baked beans tasted great. The ambience was great.  Tiny place.  The one thing that I am majorly hooked on is the Lucky Brand Cola that's made with cane sugar.  Seriously good stuff.  Even way better than Coke.  And it's locally made.  No Coke or Pepsi products at this place.  Maybe I'll come back here & try the ribs.  So, easy to miss.  It's right in that plaza with the Starbucks & the cooking school.  Sort of across from Chevy's & CVS.

You can return anything that you don't like. I mentioned to the cashier that I didn't like the mango mochi and she gave me refund without bringing the merchandise back. That's amazing service . Now I am not hesitant to try any of their products.

Why 4 stars? Because this might be the best seafood in Tampa Bay.

   ---   ---   ---

It's so odd that the seafood is so lacking here in the Bay Area. I mean... we are called the BAY AREA after all. And last time I checked, the Bay is a body of water. You'd think some decent tasting fish would be swimming around in there, but I've been very underwhelmed with the selection in the area.

That being said, when someone asks me what my favorite seafood restaurant in the area is, I always say Oystercatchers. It's an ideal atmosphere, especially for a date... and the views are really great.

The only reason for limiting my rating to 4-stars is that it's a bit pricier than I'd like... but I would like to visit again and possibly upgrade to a perfect 5. I really want to try out the famous brunch.

Came here a few times and just don't know what the rave or hype is about.  Everything is a la carte, so keep that in mind when choosing to come here.  The décor is very old and vintage, sort of reminds me of Dracula's house or just an old creepy castle. LOL

They have a wine room and tours available.  In 1 visit, I came with a company outing in which we had a tour of the wine cellar and meat aging cooler.  If you're a meat lover, then perhaps this is for you but I was so completely grossed out by the smell and look of the meat that was aging that I've not eaten steak or read meat since that visit.  Definitely a way to turn you vegetarian LOL.  They also have a dessert room which is okay as well, depending on what you order.  At least I can say that I've experienced the place but not on my list of places I want to return and spend that amount of money on food.  I've had better places for a lot less money.

I've had togo from here, and today we ate in, and both times the Pho Ga has been delicious. The broth is what pho is all about, and their broth is so flavorful and tasty, I can't seem to get enough. Add in the incredibly generous sized portion, and the ridiculously low prices (only $6!), and it comes as no surprise that this place was full on a Sunday at 12:30 pm.  

My companion raved about his Bánh mì, also.  Warm soft fresh bread, spicy jalapeños, and just the right amount of meat-for only $3!

Great food, great prices, plenty of tables - our new favorite!

My friend was celebrating her 40+ Birthday, & she wanted Penang. My mom was able to get us reservations, since my parents frequent there alot!! We had 10 people, for 7pm, then ended up being 7:30pm...one person didn't show. Our waiter was quite the character!! He was funny -good guy. Got little difficult since everyone wasn't used to Malaysian cuisine or the heat -in it. But they were willing to try it out. We had our wine, her cake, All in all-GREAT Time & food!!!! Always a pleasure going there, closest thing to my homemade stuff or mom's.

Armature Works is a unique experience, but at the end of the day I would rather go to a sit-down restaurant. Basically this is a trendy food court located on the Hillsborough River. I love dining on the water, but unfortunately this isn't possible when there aren't enough tables and you get stuck sitting at the only table that you were able to snag inside.

I don't enjoy standing in long lines and I definitely don't enjoy standing in long lines for food. It's even more frustrating when you realize that this was just the line to place your order and that you have to wait another ten to fifteen minutes to receive your food. Once you finally receive your food you realize that there aren't any tables available so you wait again and grab a dirty table as another group leaves. At this point you have waited almost thirty minutes for a mediocre meal that you paid too much for that was served to you on a tray with no waiter service. To make matters worse you realize that you have finished your beverage while waiting for your food so you just have to eat your food on a dirty table with no beverage!

I'm not sure what the deal with the parking is. On our first visit we parked in the lot for free, but our second visit we had to pay $5 to park and were given a voucher to get $5 off at any purchase at Armature Works. What is the point of paying to park if you're going to immediately be reimbursed?! There aren't any other businesses nearby so there is ample parking and it slowed down the process of parking.

Great concept, but just not for me. I doubt I'll be back unless I am going here for an event.

Fresh, delicious Mexican food with quick service!

I have had a hard time finding nice restaurants that can get us in and out in 40 ish minutes.  I hate taking more than an hour for lunch and I had started to feel like every place would take forever.  Not anymore, Besito has me covered! 

Parking can be a beast at lunch.  We ended up having to park way back by Seasons 52 and walked in the sweltering heat.  I know, valet is only $3, but I hate paying for things that should be free.  

It is dark inside, or maybe that is just because it was incredibly bright outside.  My eyes had to adjust when I walked in and when I walked out of the restaurant.  However, once my eyes adjusted, I liked the ambiance of the restaurant.  

They bring you chips and salsa to the table.  The chips arrive warm.  They are thin and beautifully salted.  The dip is absolutely superb.  I loved the salsa.  I usually forego the chips and salsa, but I was noshing away.  We actually ate the entire salsa dish!

I ended up getting the Carmarones Ensalada.  The chips must have filled me up, because I only ended up eating half of the salad.  The shrimp was delicious.  I don't know why they call it baby shrimp, because they seemed pretty good sized to me.  I was expecting itty bitty shrimp.  The tortilla crust added a great crunch. 

My husband got carne asada tacos and loved them.  He kept talking about how much he liked them.

They bring you churros and Mexican worry dolls at the end of your meal.  The churros were very good.  They tasted like they fry them in house.  It is almost like you can taste the love of the food.

I really enjoyed this place.  It is one of my new favorite lunch places.

Why 5 stars? Because that brunch of RIDICULOUS.

   ---   ---   ---

The brunch at Oystercatchers had been on bucket list for a stupid amount of time. I recently proposed to my girlfriend, and while I was planning out that weekend, I knew that the OC brunch had to be a part of the festivities.

The verdict? Absolutely worth all of the hype. The only negative was the price of $55 a person. And that's not to say it wasn't worth every penny, but it's just definitely not something you can do every weekend. This is a special occasion destination, for sure.

But let's talk about the components of that brunch, shall we?

-Carving Station
-Pasta Station
-Omelet Station
-Other pasta fixins
-Typical breakfast items: bacon, sausage, benedicts
-Mimosas
-Steak Salads
-Oysters (of course)
-Shrimp
-Giant cakes
-Banana Fosters station
-A table of nothing but various forms of sugars/candies

The service was top notch, and the views are really great. Of course, the food is unbelievable. I've never been to a brunch like this before. It was fairly mind-blowing.

But again, it just can't be done on a regular basis. My bill after tip was $140 for two people that just drank soda. 

So it's easily the best brunch in TB, but you're definitely going to pay for it!

The office four went for a celebratory lunch. The nitwit driver (me) had temporary navigational dyslexia while everybody's yelling, "Go the other way! Turn around!" Well, we got there. I KNOW where it is, now!

We had an energetic, friendly and funny server, who helped us through the menu.

The chips and salsa were splendid. Everyone agreed the salsa was a "keeper."

#1 got the grilled vegetarian burrito: grilled chayote squash, roasted corn, cilantro rice, spinach, black beans, jalapenos, cilantro pesto, chile guajillo sauce ($8.95).

#2 got the wild mushroom quesadilla: roasted portabella, spinach, pico de gallo, caramelized onions and melted Jack with guac, crema and chile de arbol salsa ($9.95).

#3 got the mushroom enchiladas suizas (2) with jicama slaw: portabella, spinach, Mexican cheese, creamy tomatillo sauce and crema ($8.95).

I got tacos al pastor (2) and subbed the Mexican street corn "off the cob" for an upcharge: citrus chile marinated pork, cilantro, grilled pineapple and roasted tomatillo salsa ($7.95).

Everybody was astounded at the fresh, flavorful food that tasted so out of the ordinary from the standard "Mexican" fare.

My tacos (of which I could eat only one) were such a tasty blend of flavors beautifully balanced. And I was a bit trepidacious about the pineapple -- this was a major go-out-on-a-limb order for me! But that sweet crunch of fresh pineapple with lovely grill flavor was an unexpected taste treat!

The taco shells themselves were rather thick and rustic -- a wonderful textural change from the "norm."

The Mexican street corn was indescribable with creamy sauce, lovely corn crunch and kinda sassy flavors.

Everybody else truly enjoyed their dishes. Our service was fabulous; beverages were refilled quickly.

We all agreed a return trip is in order to sample other dishes!!

Thanks to TJ for putting this event together! Sadly, even with arriving at 2 pm on Sunday, the restaurant was still packed.  Finally we were sat, and our waitress was right on top of things, taking our order super quickly.

Most food came out surprisingly fast, I thought, even if at all different times. That's fine with me-I like my food to be really hot.  My veggie & tofu pho was fabulous. I'll definitely be ordering that again.

Unfortunately, the durian for the durian challenge was brought out midway through the meal, and I had to suffer smelling it's rotten odor the rest of my meal. The repulsive smell even came through the styrofoam container we stored it in! Nasty!

RJ actually liked it-it was very anti-climatic.  I would have to say Chris W and I were the biggest "hell no-ers!" Make sure you check out TJ's video of Chris smelling-correction-tasting it-truly hilarious.

I was pleasantly surprised when I took my 10mo old to the Florida aquarium on a rainy Sunday afternoon. 

The ticket lines were a little long but we were able to get through quickly. Once inside, we made our way to the large plate glass aquarium and my daughter was instantly in awe. She loved watching the fish, turtle and sharks swim around. It's well laid out and gives way for you to spend time here and for the kids to get extremely close to the fish. 

Since Elliot is still in a stroller, I appreciated the fact that most of the tanks were at her eye level, which was great and allowed her to get a birds eye view of her surroundings. 

We enjoyed the day so much that we bought annual passes and we look forward to more trips to come.

Fabulous restaurant which is rich in local history, the Cloumbia in Ybor City totes itself as the oldest restaurant in Florida. The food is a wonderful blend of Spanish and Cuban with terrific table-side prepartaion for many of the items.

The Columbia is located in the historic Ybor City section of Tampa, just north and east of the port and the Channelside districts. The restaurant takes up the entire block at 7th Avenue between 21st and 22nd Streets. You can't miss the big white building covered with decorative Spanish tiled artwork on the outside.

Inside, the restaurant is a mixture of smaller dining areas, ranging from the lovely garden room with it's central fountain, the wine cellar room where the nightly flamenco dancing show is held, the bar area with its huge hand-carved wooden bar, and then numerous private dining areas for smaller groups.

If I'm there for lunch, I enjoy their famous 1905 salad which is mixed up table-side (Iceberg lettuce with julienne of baked ham, Swiss cheese, tomato, olives, grated Romano cheese and their famous garlic dressing) with a cup of thier Spanish bean soup (garbanzo beans simmered with smoked ham, chorizo sausage and potatoes in a chicken broth). Oh, and let's not forget the warm Cuban bread, served as small, individual loafs for each diner and piping hot.

For dinner, I always take a date and some friends so that we can sample a variety of choices off the menu. We'll usually start with a pitcher of homemade Sangria (red or white), and then follow that with 1905 salads, and our choices of entrees. Over the years I've tried many selections, and never been disappointed. My personal favorites are the Snapper Alicante, the Mahi Mahi "Cayo Hueso", the Filet Mignon "Chacho", and their wonderful Paella.

A great place for your out-of-town guests, and a fun night out with a date or a business client.

My grandparents used to drag me with them when they came here about 40 years ago to buy fresh ingredients to make a particular pasta dish.

That meal was always one of my favorites, so I knew I could grab something good for lunch here on my way to play an afternoon round at St. Petersburg Country Club.

What I wasn't prepared for was the insanity in front of the deli counter at 12:30pm on a Monday. It was like the Soup Nazi episode of Seinfeld if you included a late afternoon selloff on the New York Stock Exchange.

This isn't made any easier when the majority of customers are of that "Traditional St. Pete demographic" who have absolutely no awareness of other customers.

Memo to that demographic: When you are in a crowded public space, you do not move sideways or backwards without looking to see if you have actual room to do so. This isn't the NBA and you are not trying to create position for getting an offensive rebound. By doing so, you are simply running into others who are being patient and trying to stay out of your way.

Rather than fight my way to the front to get a number, then fend off locals waiting in the same area for my number to be called to then approach the counter again to place the actual order and then go through the same process to receive the finished order, I took the path of least resistance (literally) in grabbing something appealing from the refrigerated case and headed for the cashier.

Besides, I'm still a Chicken Salad Snob on occasion despite the near fatal fallout from eating it at Lenny's in Clearwater a couple years back. (Please check that review, because they obviously never did.)

I'd always heard the chicken salad at Mazzaro's was worthwhile and their cranberry version inside what appeared to be a sun dried tomato wrap was definitely top notch.

Would have loved to try a couple more things, but I'll have more of a gameplan next time. Perhaps even wearing elbow pads as if I was vintage Bill Laimbeer attacking the offensive glass.

Great neighborhood bar for awesome burgers. I bounce back-n-forth between two for my visits; The Royale (Wagyu Kobe) or Bison (MO raised). 
Keep in mind both of these type of burgers can not be cooked over medium. I get mine done medium rare and they are just perfect. 
Your burger comes with one side, and french fries are not available. I just love it when a restaurant gets creative and doesn't offer them.  I'm a big fan of our home town Billy Goat Chips, but when at The Royale, you've got to experience their house made Sweet Potato Chips. As a child I hated sweet potato's, now I can't get enough. 
Sometimes when I/we visit it's for their taco's. We'll order two each of their Smoked Brisket and Fish then share. These are the only fish taco's that I like.
Save room, and I do mean room for dessert. You've gotta have "The Boozy-Q". Devil's food cake, Irish cream, Chambord whipped cream......
plus more chocolate toppings. Don't ask about the calories.

Very solid bahn mi sandwich and noodles soups. The "market" is small, but a very nice touch. I like to chow down on some eggrolls while waiting for my grub. 

Staff is hard to communicate with though, especially when having to order gluten free foods. 

There are like 70000 reviews already, so that's all I've gotta say.

I always end up getting number 179... Mi Xao Don... stir fry meat and veggies on top of egg noodles with a touch of sauce at the bottom to soften the noodles. It's always good... and it's enough to split if you want. 

This last visit I also tried the sampler appetizer platter and was impressed with the presentation (a flaming platter) along with the volume of different items. 

All in all, Mai Lee is a favorite of mine. Service does seem a bit rushed. I'm not sure if it's due to their popularity or if that's just how they operate. But I've never had bad service... It just seems that all the employees are in a hurry. 

The restaurant is literally steps from the MetroLink station. So it would be a good meeting point before or after an event.

Why 4 stars? Because the layout was nice, but mostly because of Ted Drewes.

   ---   ---   ---

I'd only been to St. Louis one other time and it was with a friend who was from the area. He introduced me to the beautiful thing in life that is Ted Drewes, and I never forgot about it. 

When laying over recently in St. Louis, I did what I always do on a layover - I scour through Yelp to find the best restaurant in that airport. Unfortunately, I didn't find anything that jumped out at me, so I just settled on grabbing a coffee and a snack. But then... I saw it. A freaking Ted Drewes vending machine. Immediately changed my plans and carefully chose a flavor. Spoiler alert: it doesn't matter what flavor you pick, they all taste like heaven reigning down on your mouth.

While I thought Lambert had some aesthetically pleasing concourses, my 4-stars is really because of the access to Ted Drewes. Genius. 

Now, if we could step up the inner-airport restaurant game otherwise, we'd be golden.

Good and big tacos in a very small shop.

I have been meaning to try out Loli's for a while.  I love tacos, and I'm always on the look for a better taco place.

The food was good, but it wasn't the best Mexican I've had in the greater Tampa area.  The tortillas are handmade and good.  They are big and delicate and yet strong enough to hold the taco fillings even with lots of lime juice and salsa.  I had the lengua taco.  It was awesome.  I tried the ribeye taco.  Also awesome, although I wish they put a little more cilantro on it.  And I tried the campechano taco.  It was good, but I wish it had chicharones in the mix for that crunchy texture.  Horchata was okay, a little under-spiced.

The location didn't feel very clean.  There is limited seating, but the turnover is fast.  Service is very fast.

I don't know that I'd drive out of my way for this place when I can find better tacos closer to my home and work.

Logic? Forget it!
Shopping list? Forget it!
Mazzaro's happens to you while you're busy making other plans.

Every time we come here, we end up experimenting, procuring an item or three we never knew we needed, until that very moment! Years back, it became our secret tradition to drop by on a Saturday, navigate the crowds, and have a blast!

Their biscotti are to freaking die for. I don't need them, I don't plan for them, but it happens, every time, I must have them!

I'm updating my review to just comment on how Han Dynasty has kinda gone down recently since becoming popular.

Yeah, right. I'm kidding. This place still rules and every time I eat here it is like Zeus and Loki have a crazy keg party in Valhalla and decide to open up the heavens and send peppercorns into my mouth via lightning blast express.

I'd like to take this moment to give props to the Taiwanese sausage and dry pepper style shrimp. The dry pepper shrimp has a nice, subtle sweetness to it that is unexpected at Han Dynasty.

The chicken with garlic sauce and salt&pepper shrimp are delicious dishes for your less spice-inclined companions(who you shouldn't be hanging out with anyways because they are weaklings).

Also, no review is complete without mentioning the Dan Dan noodles. I have mentioned them.
Shopping mall. Same as the rest. The best part is restaurant row. Go there and wait for the shopper of your family.

At around 12:45 a.m. on a recent night out, it was decided that one more drink was necessary, along with some bar food.  Since I was the driver that evening (cue shock and awe), our fate was in my hands.  I tried to think of a location that would have both ample street parking and a quick and easy route to the bridge.  Prohibition Taproom came to mind.

The bar and furnishings were dark and mostly made of wood.  A string of old-fashioned looking lights hung above the bar, and they would dim a little on occasion, which I loved.  A DJ played some serious jams that were heavy on the gangsta rap.  It had been a while since I'd heard Easy E, Dre and Ice Cube and I was digging it wholeheartedly.  Everything flowed perfectly with the old school, moody vibe.  

We sat down at the bar and asked if the kitchen was still open.  It was maybe five after 1 at this point, and the bartender took a look at the clock and told us that everything in the kitchen gets turned off at 1.  There were no ifs, ands or buts, and no offers to see if there was anything that could be done.  For a new bar trying to make it in a recession, I found this response to be pretty off-putting.  I got over it when I looked at the beer list, though.  One glance at the words Blanche de Bruxelles, and I knew that Prohibition Taproom would soon become one my spots.  Next time, I'm coming earlier so I don't miss the kitchen cut-off.

The Nashville International Airport is really a great place to travel.  And the MNAA is only doing more to improve it.  

In the near future, they plan to add a terminal and acquire more land to expand further.  The could improve on dining and shopping options.  And they could improve certain amenities, but its overall pretty good.  

You can send comments or suggestions but visiting their comments page: http://www.flynashville.com/contact/Pages/commentsandquestions.aspx

Had about a 30 minute wait for Sunday brunch during the peak hours. Good assortment of different types of menu items: burritos, Eggs Benedict, sweet potato hash, omelettes, breakfast platters, etc. Ordered the Reuben Benedict. Quality cut corned beef, sauerkraut, runny eggs, and perfectly crafted hollandaise sauce on rye. Service can be a little spotty during peak times.

Why 3 stars now?  Because I've found better.

   ---   ---   ---

After trying Arco Iris earlier in the week, I have a new Cuban home.  Last night, La Teresita did not match the deliciousness of the food or the quickness of the service from my trip a few doors down.

Don't get me wrong, La Teresita is still a good place, but Arco Iris takes the crown.  According to Google Maps, the distance between the two places is 0.2 miles.  I think it's worth the journey.

We came for brunch and were seated by the window on the wooden benches on top of the gravel, which was great, especially since it was no beautiful outside and we had a prime view.  Service was very attentive, prompt, and friendly, and the food itself was phenomenal!  We wanted to order everything but decided on a smaller selection due to stomach size constraints.  They were also great about separating items since one of my friends had some food allergies.  We had:

1. smoked salmon with egg salad and creme fraiche on toasted thick bread: Pretty good although the salmon was very salty by itself.  The combo of bread, creme, and salmon together was perfect, though.
2. potatoes bravas: The tried-and-true classic and yes, we ended up ordering seconds.
3. mixto cheese plate of truffled lavender and honey, fig and dried cherry, and pistachio: Fantastic, especially the truffled lavender and honey, which was the unanimous favorite.
4. lemon ricotta blueberry pancakes: Great but the creme fraiche makes all the difference.  Without it, the pancakes are just solid.
5. black cod: Okay, this was TINY but INCREDIBLE!  The fish was buttery, silky, and melted on your tongue.  I could eat this for days.  And you might want to get 2 orders...per person...minimum.
6. chorizo: Very flavorful and grilled to perfection.
7. chorizo with roasted potatoes and poached egg: This was a great rendition of a standard breakfast classic.  Mix it up bibimbap style!
8. grilled mixed mushrooms: Buttery and decadent.  A must-try for vegetarians.
9. chocolate cake with pistachio ice cream:  This was delish but to be honest, there was only a faint hint of pistachio flavor in the ice cream.
10. caramel flan topped with candied cherries and pear pieces: This was a very good custard but I felt that the additional candied fruit toppings made it overly sweet.  It actually would have been perfect on its own.

As expected, Garces delivers.  Make sure that you make reservations as the wait can be long on weekends but the ambiance is great so it isn't a bad thing to have to wait by the bar for a little while.

The office went for a celebratory lunch -- yes, again! We were seated right away in a nice booth in the back and were served chips and salsa right away. I think we ended up going through three baskets of chips . . . they're chip-alicious!! And the salsa is just right and clings well to the chips.

Our server was extremely knowledgeable. I asked what the difference was between tacos and street tacos. He explained that most people think of tacos as having ground beef. Street tacos are pulled meat -- chicken, beef, pork.

So, I got the street tacos ($7.95) -- two to the order with a choice of chicken, beef or pork. I selected chicken and beef. For choice of side, I opted for the charro beans. Other choices were Mexican rice, cilantro rice pilaf, black beans, sweet potato fries or jicama slaw.

#2 got the grilled vegetarian burrito ($8.95) -- grilled chayote squash, roasted corn, cilantro rice, spinach, black beans, jalapenos, cilantro pesto, chile guajillo sauce. That thing was huge, and she enjoyed it thoroughly.

#3 and #4 got the chicken milanesa torta with sweet potato fries and jicama slaw($8.95) -- a toasted ciabatta bread filled with crispy chicken breast, melted Monterey Jack and Chihuahua cheeses, avocado, black bean puree, garlic mayo, and cilantro serrano pesto. They both liked the sandwich

And we all got the Milagro house salad ($5.95) -- greens, tomato, panela cheese and pepitas (pumpkin seeds) tossed in a cilantro lime viniagrette. The salad was divinely refreshing, and the pepitas gave it such a nice textural crunch.

I tasted a sweet potato fry, and it was crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside. Yum!

My tacos wer the smallest tacos I've ever seen. Three bites. If I had a bigger mouth, each would have been just two bites (or less). And my side choice (charro beans) was not right for me. They were OK, but I just had a few bites.

Good, fresh food. I'll get something different next time.

I need to return for a full experience of The Royale.  I was so inclined to try it out that I opted for take-out.  I ordered a house salad with goat cheese; I love goat cheese.  The salad was large and packed great flavor drizzled with a balsamic vinaigrette. 

The bar tender took my order and was super nice.  Although I didn't have a drink I recognized the alcohol options and can tell you this place would be a great happy-hour or date night out.

They had tall booths for a private seating feel.

The restroom was nostalgic and clean; but tiny.  Two turns inside the closet size relief area and your dizzy.

I'll be bach

Whenever I have visitors come to Philadelphia, they frequently insist I take them to get cheesesteaks. I will laud the qualities of other Philly restaurants in a futile attempt to change minds. In the end, the response is always the same "I can't come all the way to Philly without eating a cheesesteak."

Even though my eyes roll in my head so hard that I see my own optic nerve, I frequently indulge them. If I have a choice, Tony Luke's or Jim's are my cheesesteak places of choice.

I like Tony Luke's hot sauce and the Papa Luke, a horribly gluttonous cheesesteak with cream cheese and tomato. When you add some hot peppers and onions to this,  you have quite a creation. Every time you eat one, a healthy person dies.

Their regular cheesesteak is good, and worth trying once.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is Rambo: First Blood.

If it's dark outside & probably in the daylight, if you blink at the wrong time you will miss this tremendous little eatery. I observed no sign, but it was dark & there was a tiny "open" sign in the window. I blew right past it with GPS & had to turn around. This stretch of Benjamin could use some street lights.
It had been a very long day and I was flat out hungry. I was greeted as soon as I arrived at the small hidden restaurant. It was almost full & quite busy while I was there. It seems from what the girl at the counter explained, they have had a steady  increase in business, recently. She was very pleasant and explained the limited menu to me, as it was my first time. They only have tacos, tortas, sopes & toastadas. Tamales are only made and served on the weekend.
I ordered 2 sopes. The Pastor which is marinated pork and the Campechano, which is a blend of rib eye and chorizo.  Both were perfectly fried, had a nice amount of bite size meat topping, followed with shredded lettuce & crumbled Mexican cheese, not sure if it was Queso blanco or Oaxacan, either wsy it works. Add all of this together and you have some mighty fine, rib sticking comfort food.
I was impressed ( and that is hard to do) with the overall pleasant and knowledgeable service. Food service was quick, hot and hit all the right flavor notes. I had asked if they had coconut water, which they don' carry, but was offered free samples of hibiscus water and Horchata ( rice water).
It was a cool, rainy evening & the food had such dynamic flavors, I would have to challenge the best palates to try and proclaim all of the spices and seasonings. It was a very, very pleasant surprise and an explosion for my tastebuds. Everything appears to be homemade, down to the Horchata and hot sauce. LOL, don't let that Lil old cup of hot sauce fool you. The sauce is fabulous, if you like it hot & by hot I mean from the first taste to the after glowing embers it leaves, I think it hits every hot sensation on your tounge. Just remember if you are a crowd of people call & get your order to go, it will still taste incredible. 
Once again I must mentioned judging books by their covers. This humble small house, off the beaten track, barely noticable served me some of the best prepared, seasoned and cooked simple Mexican food, I have had in a very long time. Props on the Horchata,  that was brand new to me & you can bet I will be ordering it again.
What's a girl to do?  Continue the pursuit of excellent food, wherever it takes you.

I like this place. I actually prefer this location to the other location in Tampa. I do have to complain that the parking is rather cramped and scared me though. 

Love that they have Dim Sum options that you can other along with your lunch items. The food is always fresh and great tasting. They do not have a fried tofu option if you don't want rice. The dishes are but enough to share also. Check this place out. You won't be disappointed. 

Keep in mind they open at 11am and close daily staring at 2:30,  opening back at 5 for dinner. And that's daily, even on weekends.

I've been to this establishment a couple of times over the past few months.  I can say I was pleasantly surprised to find a restaurant of this caliber in the area it is located in.  Parking isn't always easy depending on when you go, but once you step inside you are sure to find food and beverages aplenty.  Their entrees and pizzas are something you can't go wrong with and their specialty cocktails are the perfect pairing to a great meal.  My personal favorite is the Cherry Mojito made with Bacardi Torched Cherry Rum.  They usually have live bands playing on Fridays and Sundays, which is always a plus to accompany a great meal.

Apprehensive but wanting pepperoni sticks we went to Piada for dinner. After parking I looked thru the window and almost left becsuse there were no pepperoni sticks in their designated spot. We went inside and asked about them. This time instead of saying no they were out they called to the back to fire some and out came a tray. Yes I am making a huge deal about these. They are my number one reason for eating at Piada. They are so good with the parmesan dipping sauce. The SpicyTuscan Wrap with bacon and crispy chicken was great as always.

Well, it is a good thing I do not possess much of a sweet tooth nor live in the neighborhood.

My first visit to Dough was only because I was gifted $20 of store credit that was going to expire, so I went to grab sandwiches late weekday afternoon at a strategic time when they shouldn't have been very busy and parking was not an issue.

They were not busy at all and Jess at the front counter went out of her way to make sure my first visit was a good one. She also did not break stride when I handed her my $20 CL Deal and applied it to my order faster than any other time I've ever used one at any local business. (You know and I know some employees HATE these things, which is too bad because they almost always bring in a new customer.)

Didn't realize how far $20 goes in a place like this, so I took home quite a few things.

The highlight for me was clearly their hot melt called The Sound of Music and I added turkey with the other ingredients for a modest extra two dollars. On the first bite, I realized what I had created. Anyone else remember that glorious hot Turkey O'Toole served on the pretzel bun at Bennigan's? 

Honestly, everything I walked out of there with was quite good. With no sweet tooth, even I broke down and had a single buckeye, which speaks to my Ohio roots and is very tough to find around here. (No, I did not attend Ohio State and I root against them every Saturday as long as Urban Liar is head coach.)

I really appreciated the creativity and selection of all their sandwich offerings (including all the cheap ways to add/customize as I did with my Sound of Music/Turkey O'Toole) and the colorful presentation of all the different donuts, cupcakes and other treats. Some sandwiches are on display and clearly made in advance, which is why a little customization always gets you something made fresh. 

Occasionally, we all have those days when we need a box of sweet treats to make an impression on a group of people. Dough will be my destination the next time I need to do this and I'll grab my old school Bennigan's sandwich again to see if it rings true one more time.

One of the best breakfast in the city. Lemon ricotta pancakes are great. Crespelli  was wonderful. Eggs Benedict special with Speck and asparagus was  very original . Good service, cool hipster vibe. Prices are reasonable .

I was on my way somewhere else and happened upon the famed Trader Joe's.  I didn't have the time to devote to it that I would have liked, but I wanted to see what all the commotion was about.
I only had 20 minutes and that is not a thorough search of a store for me, but what I saw I have no idea what the commotion is about. 
I saw many distinctive products, all at an unrealistic price. Parking was scrambled and an overall mess, difficult to get into and out of
In my limited time, I saw no major sales and plenty of high prices. 
Check out was another joke and I ended up ditching my cart, with its few items, as I had no more time to waste. 
I gotta say I was looking forward to this visit and wish I had, had more time to explore
 As it ended up I estimated I had a hood 10-20 minute wait in line and just did not have the time today. I put the p erishables back and left my cart. Yes, I am guilty,  I admit I didn't have the time to waste on some frivolous items I was buying.
It is a specialty store that offers some unique items, but I don't see myself becoming a regular, ever.
What's a girl to do? So many stores, so little time.

I love this tiny yet delicious sushi bar with the amazing tuna dumplings app (must try!) and the 3 rolls for $10.95 combo special.  It's almost impossible to beat.  Okay, I will admit that the special rolls are definitely pricier but they are worth the cost.  Between my own orders over the years and my incessant "mooching" off of everyone else's plates, I've tried a pretty wide range of the menu and have yet to be even mildly disappointed.  

The quality of the rolls is almost Bluefin-level and the variety is amazing.  I love the birthday roll, which is filled with plenty of albacore, salmon, tuna, oshinko (love that crunch!), avocado, and cucumber, wrapped in soy paper, and topped with masago; it's a delcious combination and soy paper is a perfect foil for the crunchy oshinko.  The ocean brother roll is another fav with shrimp tempura, avocado, wasabi, and actual lump crabmeat, not "krab."  In terms of regular rolls, I would definitely try a white tuna/eel/spicy salmon trio.  It's fail-proof.  And don't leave without getting the tuna dumpling!  It's a "purse" made out of thinly sliced, fresh tuna wrapped around a filling of avocado and roe, and served on top of a checkerboard of sauce, and is a staple here.  Kinda like how the tuna sundae is a staple at Bluefin.  It even looks absolutely darling, like two little red lanterns.  The actual sushi here is fresh and tasty but the rolls are definitely their forte.  The fish, while good, didn't really stand out from that at the other surrounding sushi restaurants.

The party platters here are also pretty good and a medium will easily feed a family of 3-4 for under $60, which is fantastic considering the fact that they give you a good selection of sushi (salmon, eel, albacore, tuna, yellowtail) along with spicy tuna, salmon, red dragon, alaska, and california rolls.  Most other places usually just give you california rolls in the platters.  It was less than $60 for that and an order of the dumplings.  Plus, everything was ready when we went to pick up our food.  No wait time = happy dad (and me...and the rest of the family). 

The restaurant (not exactly a sit-down place) is tiny and seating simultaneously sparse and cramped, but bolsters a fun, relaxed atmosphere if you only have a small party (3 or less people).  Grab a seat at the bar, if there is room, and have fun chatting with the chefs while nomming on your rolls.

Well I have to admit that John has ruined what was my favorite Besh restaurant. I ventured to my favorite spot for oysters though early in the season for a friends birthday party. I was interested in the oyster special happy hour which is 75 cents not 50 cents as it used to be and that was a sign of worse to come. We ordered bowls of gumbo that is excellent but has gone from $8 to $10 per bowl since I have last been here. They used to have daily specials where you order get an entree and a cup of soup for about $20 and that is gone. The menu has been reduced a bunch of high priced items that you would have expected from August or any of his other places that you didn't get here. Luke was like a neighborhood kitchen that served really good food at a good price but now he has gone for the tourists instead of the locals and it shows in more ways than one. They have added more tables and crammed the small interior, the tables are now so small you really can't fit the oyster trays on them comfortably when seating a table of 3 or 4. The oysters themselves were the worst I have ever had from them with about 3 that were not opened that I had to open at the table. Gumbos normally come with hot french bread and they only brought one for a table of three where they are supposed to be given to each person not per table. The oysters have really turned into a lost leader to get you in the door and spend a check that you really were not anticipating. They have baked oyster not char broiled at a whopping $17.50 per half dozen. My friend though it was for a dozen and ordered the half not knowing the $17.50 was for the half dozen which made the situation even worse. To top it all off we were there for a birthday and notified the hostess and the waiter and there was no recognition with a dessert or not even a happy birthday from the waiter. From start to finish this was a miserable experience and one that I was not expecting from a John Besh restaurant and is not qualified as a TOURIST TRAP. In fact this place has changed so much they really should start over with their reviews because many on here were for the previous chef and menu.

I bought a loaf of the cranberry walnut $10 and profiteroles. The bread is the best nut bread I've ever had. The profiteroles is very soft and delicate perfectly filled with vanilla ice cream with chocolate sauce.

I prefer smaller airports, but MSY is really limited in its food and shopping options. I just wanted something light and easy, and the closest I could get was Subway - and it was the worst Subway ever.

We love IKEA. I have built so many IKEA objects I could be an assembler for them. Once you get used to their "directions" it's a breeze. Love the engineering and that you can put almost every item together without power tools. 

Only 4 stars because on our initial visit we signed up for their orange loyalty family card. It emailed us a coupon. We proceeded to spend the next 6 hours walking through their store. We purchased over $1200 worth of items. We went to use our coupon on the email, clicked the link, and it said it had already been used. ??? Ok, so we told them we definitely want to use the coupon and so we would like them to call a manager to make this happen. Manager came over, proceeded to try and tell us how to work our phone and get to the coupon, to not avail..... Manager went to the office and called the staff back and said 'this one time we will make an exception and for her to use another customers coupon. There is no way for me to override the coupon and enter it in as $25 off.' Hmmm, I am not sure I believe that but whatever. She scanned another customers coupon and gave us the discount. It was super frustrating having to do this to staff. It was an IKEA coupon, that THEY sent us via email when we signed up for THEIR card. We could not have printed it off as we have been in THEIR store for the last 6 hours. Ugh. We hated holding the line up and we hated being 'those people' but dang it, if you send us a coupon for $25 at least let us use it! 

So, we left and got home and proceeded to put together several shelving units and such. All went together smoothly and without issue. One of the shelving units (yellow one) was built slightly differently even though it was the same unit. Maybe a different manufacturing place or maybe it was a different assembly line since it was an unusual color? No idea but it was a bearcat to assemble compared to the other ones we bought which were black/white, green and gray/blue. When I slid the pegs in it managed to crack the surface causing the yellow coloring to come off. Frustrating. 

Other than that I noticed how the directions have gotten better since the last time I assembled these items (10 years ago.) And some of the items they have had long term (12 years old) are now made much better and are much more sturdy. I love that they continue to improve their items even though their old items still 'worked.' Well done IKEA. 

Thank you for keeping your prices reasonable. Thank you for thinking 'outside of the box' on a lot of your items. Thank you for NOT being Amazon and packaging your items smartly. 

We have since this visit been back once. We intend on returning yet again for our bathroom components. I have honestly thought about applying at your stores as I love your items, love your stores (clean), love your food and love the concept of well engineered items that are not over priced. Plus+ I can assemble everything we have bought thus far all on my own without using ONE power tool. 

Oh, one more downer... why do you send items out without mounting screws such as the toilet paper holders and the magnetic knife holders? I am stuck with them sitting on my counter because every single screw I have at my home is black and does not match the silver of the items. 

No matter, I still love IKEA. And you put this store in a wonderful location for where we live. The last home we owned we had to travel about 4 hours to get to a store.

You know, I'm kind of surprised that I didn't already write an update for Good Dog, considering the fact that I had the chance to revisit it way back when with a bunch of Yelpers after Carrie's office hours (I guess it really was that good of a gathering!). But since we took over it's upstairs area in style during Daria's birthday bash last night, I had the chance to experience it again to it's fullest potential.

First off I have to say how amazing the upstairs area really is. Even though I had an embarrassing number of Pool games where the only ball that I managed to hit in a pocket was the cue ball (I beyond choked!) I really did appreciate the table that it had. It also had a good dart board and a full sized Mega Touch that appeased my Photo Hunt addiction. But the coolest game related thing that it offered was by far it's arcade console. not only did it hook up Mrs. Pacman, it also hooked up space invaders, frogger, DONKEY KONG, and so much more. I doubt Namco, Atari, and Nintendo would like it, but it proved to be a old school gamers dream come true.

And holy freaking hell was the Good Dog Burger the stuff of legends. It hooked up at least a 1/2 pound of beef, carmelized onions, and a Roquefort sauce that was so good I was fingering it off my plate when I was done. and the fries were an amazing blend of regular and sweet potatoes. So while it is pretty hard to get a seat on any given day, Good Dog definitely has enough to keep you happy.

Why 5 stars?  Because holy selection!

   ---   ---   ---

The hardest part of going to Datz is deciding what to order.  It was much easier when they catered to my old job and I could sample several different kinds of mini-sandwiches.

Datz is about variety with the 3 main aspects of their menu - the sandwiches, the beer and the dessert.  They have all kinds of crazy beers- I even tried a Banana Bread last time I was there.  But the desserts...

***WARNING***

Do not come to Datz if your New Years Resolution is to lose weight and it's not your cheat day.  They have Blue Bell Ice Cream, which rings fondly in this Texan's heart.  They have a gelato bar, cupcakes, regular non-cup Cakes, and all kinds of random goodies.  It's good for your mouth, bad for your belly.

The problem I have with PHL is exactly the opposite problem I have with the Atlanta airport. 

At PHL the food options are great. There are lots of places to eat and shop, and it's pretty walkable. 

The problem I have here is that the security lines are outrageous, and the TSA agents they had here didn't seem to understand what a government-issued ID looked like.

Essentially, I got married (two years ago, might I add) and my last name changed. PennDOT won't print you a new license just because your name changed, so instead they send you a yellow update card with the new information on it. When I presented my ID, update card, and boarding pass, I was pulled to the side and made to wait for almost 20 minutes while the TSA agents tried to figure out why my last name didn't match. I had a ton of credit cards and a library card with my "new" last name on it, which they looked at. They then asked me for my health insurance card (seriously?). Then she asked me if I had my marriage certificate! Oh, yeah, because I just carry that around with me. I mean what did they want me to do? Whip out my phone and show them all of my wedding photos and my name on Facebook?

When I tried to explain to her that you can't get a new printed ID until it expires, and that the update card IS an official document, she said to me, "Oh, yeah, I know. I have one myself."

Are you kidding? 

Eventually they let me through.

Let it be noted that I got ZERO pushback in Atlanta when I was coming home. The TSA agent there looked at both documents, said "Oh, I see!" and let me go through.

My advice would be to add some extra time for the security lines because you never know when you're going to get stopped.

Parc is by far one of my favorite restaurants in Philadelphia. It's overpriced for sure (I swear that warm shrimp salad gets jacked up another dollar every six months), but for an occasional splurge I can deal. 

I've brought nearly every visiting friend or colleague to this place and everyone has enjoyed it. It's the perfect spot for a weekday brunch or lunch. As I said, the warm shrimp salad is where it's at, but when I arrive too early for the lunch menu I'm still pretty happy with the classic eggs Benedict. A friend had the poached eggs with mushroom velouté and asparagus recently and it looked fantastic. I may need to try that next time (which just so happens to be later this week!). Looking forward to it!

Good service, the burgers live up to the hype. Deviled eggs are also bangin'. Ours were cooked perfectly and tasted delicious. Solid draft list and lots of seating available. Overall, probably one of the best in the area to have a burger and beer.

Wi fi, really clean, but not a lot of shops.

I know, I know, I'm about to kill a string of 5s that the Tampa airport has gotten, but I have really high standards!  I've traveled to Australia, Paris, Hong Kong, South Korea, Canada, and all over the U.S. and the Tampa airport is one of my favorites, but it is missing the high end shopping other airports have.

I know that may not be important to some people, but I really do appreciate if I have a lot of time to kill in an airport to be able to walk around and window shop.  It might be that I have always been in the United terminal and there is more elsewhere, but in the United terminal, there is not many shops to look at.  Some airports have stores like Chanel, Gucci, etc., and it is like being in a mall!

The good is that there is a Green Iguana which is cool.  Also the free wifi is a major boon.  Not many airports have free wifi.  The tram is fast and security check in is speedy.  

I would give this airport a 4.5, but I cannot say it is as good as it gets.

Been here several times, most recent for my birthday in March, write it down for next year... Lol. But seriously, U.P.T. NOLA, in the Historic Garden District, across the street from the world renown Lafayette #1 Cemetery, steps away from the beautiful mansions of St Charles Avenue... Yeah, there she is Commander's Palace. 

I can care less about what used to happen when Heck was a pup, what I care about is good food & a good time when eating said food. 

Commander's Palace, while a staple in the fabric of New Orleans, is overkill for me. Way too stuffy... Hello this is New Orleans, Laissez-faire!!!!  

For starters, major renovations are needed. Or maybe that's part of the appeal, idk???  In particular, let's get some new paint & an updated sign on the exterior.  And how about we address those rickety narrow stairs leading to the second floor dining area, this is an accident waiting to happen. And then walking from the 2nd floor to the 1st floor through the dining room to get to the restroom. And hello, with the price you pay for a nice 3 course meal, could we get a dedicated parking area for the valet parked cars, I can park my car on the street myself; ughhhh, I'm over it. 

Hey, just go to go, heck it's New Orleans, Commander's is a staple, but in that this is a foodie's paradise with eateries all throughout the city, don't feel this is the only fine dining, good food eating experience #intheNOLAbaby.

What's to say about Ted Drewes? It's delicious. I like the Cindermint concrete and the Johnny Rabbit concrete. On Friday  night I had the Johnny Rabbit (cherries and chocolate chips). Yum! I took my grandmother and she had the Terramizzou. She was thrilled and hadn't been there in years. Go there. It's delicious!

This was just a pop in/pop out little trip but I can honestly say that It was lacking? 

Ok, so I arrived at 8:30 pm on a Sunday to the Southwest gate, this meant most things were closed except the Hudson's Booksellers. I was -hoping- that the shop that sold beignets would be available because who can make a trip to New Orleans without getting a beignet even if you don't step foot on Bourbon street. 

But I digress. The airport seemed small, clean and efficient, but lacking in personality and services.

Haven't updated my review in a long time. Parasol's is my go to spot of poboys. They have the best roast beef poboy in the city, way better than parkway or any other poboy joint in the city bar none. The heavy garlic flavor blows everyone else away with an always fresh toasted french bread that holds up to the gravy filled goodness. My other favorites here are the underrated pulled pork poboy which on its best day is the best sandwich in the city and the fire cracker shrimp. I always head to parasols for all of my poboy needs. We miss you John.

What a great visit to Southwest Diner with five fellow Yelpers!! We were at a table for 8, so there was plenty of elbow room -- always gotta have that!!

The menu is diverse and leans to southwest cooking, including biscuits and chorizo gravy, green chilis, red sauce, Mexican breakfast burrito, cornmeal pancakes, sopapillas, huevos rancheros, chile cheese fries and a green chile cheeseburger.

Breakfast and lunch are served all day.

The table was mixed on ordering breakfast and lunch. I was going to go for the huevos rancheros, but always make the mistake of listening to what everybody else is ordering . . . then I want that. I get myself confused.

So, I ordered the Medio ($6) -- two eggs (I chose sunny-side up.), sausage or bacon (I chose sausage once I established it was patties -- don't like links.) home fries and toast (I chose wheat.).

Stewart P. had the Medio, Steven B. had a burrito, Margie V. had a burger and onion rings, I couldn't see what Tracey W. ordered, and I totally wanted to slap Mary Kate A. and steal her Reuben with fresh-out-of-the-fryer skin-on fries that looked sooooo perfect. I DO love a Reuben and fresh fries.

This was a wonderful meal. The eggs were cooked perfectly, and I slid them uneventfully on a beautiful piece of buttered wheat toast. And then I chopped it all up to combine making fantabulosity!! That's how I grew up. Don't lose the yolk!! Yummy!!

The sausage was quite tasty, not greasy in any way. The home fries were chunks. I just wasn't a fan -- I like the shredded hash browns better.

Stewart ordered the chocolate pie and since we were sitting next to each other, I had to steal a little piece of the crust. It looked so different. My take was it was a graham cracker crust . . . a very substantial graham cracker crust. This was confirmed by our server. The chocolate part was rich-looking, thick and dark. There was no way I could try that. One little taste would have put me in a sugar coma. But it would be a good dessert to share among a table of 5 or 6.

Service was fabulous. Water and Diet Pepsi were refilled before they were gone and without my having to ask.

There were so many down-to-Earth offerings that sounded delicious, substantial and filling! No fluff stuff here!!

It wasn't too crowded, but we began at 1 p.m., so perhaps we were after the lunch crowd.

I didn't look around too much, but the atmosphere was comfortable and inviting. Parking was easy.

And I made my way out of there without a to-go vessel . . . I musta been hungry.

And I can officially say I am loving the vibe at Armature works. I've been here three times now, and it can officially remind me of my first glorious food hall experiences I had in Atlanta. 

The first time I was not feeling it but they had recently just opened. Now they have been open a little bit longer. Ive tried food from Graze 1910(diner-esque type food) Chismis(Filipino food vendor), Hemingway's(Cuban), and Zukku which has Poke Bowls and sushi. I've been loving my experiences there.

Just recently I stopped by since the Tampa Indie Flea Market is there once a month. It was a good set up at this spot.

This is definitely a great social spot close to the Hillsborough River, Tampa Waterworks Park, and Ulele!

I did place this as a four star because the parking which is not a big deal but $5 and u get a $5 eating voucher which I forgot to use.

B cause they want to make it like a central social hub and maybe even touristy, the prices can be a bit higher and you have to wait in line to order and get your food. Some places can text you when your food is done like Chismis and Ichikoro.

I'm a fan now and I'm glad it's here in Tampa! Good local food and drinks and a fun social spot with different activities. It's a super win win! 

They are dog friendly outside but quite a bit of people bring their dogs throughout even huge ones. Just saying!

Very cool spot, definitely a lively and bustling ambiance. Solid chips, salsa, and guacamole. They use the deep fried, greasy tortilla chips that are super tasty. Not a fan of the enchiladas, their mole or whatever sauce it is, is way too sweet. Great guava mojito. Orange flan is way too orangey. Service was okay, servers were hard to get a hold of. Good experience, more contemporary Mexican with an American flair.

We visited Besito shortly after The Taste of South Tampa this year where we received a card for a free table side guacamole.  While shopping at the mall, we decided to walk over and grab a snack, AKA our free guac.  Well, once we got in there and smelled the food, there was no way we were going to settle for just the dip, so we threw in an order of queso fundido as well.  Aye caramba!  The deliciousness is strong with this chain restaurant.  The guac was flawless, and the queso was only bested by La Plaza Leza in Mexico.  A+++

Also on point was the sangria.  Shortly after we started sipping, a gentleman donning a suit named Pablo visited our table to see how things were going.  After we told him how/why we came to visit Besito, he says, "I will be right back."  A few moments later, he returns with two drinks for us to share, along with a special bottle of Patron.  We take a shot of the Patron, he gives us the two drinks on the house and he thanks us for stopping in.

That is top-notch customer service right there.

Best ribs I've had in St. Louis bar-none.  The workers are all friendly and often handout freebies while you are waiting in line.  The only two drawbacks would be the ordering line that usually goes out the back door and the limited quantities of items.  But really, it is worth the wait and finding the time to go early enough to get what you want.  

I always get one of the super-combo platters for a family and take the majority of it home.  It's so good!

Why 5 stars? Because what's not to like?

   ---   ---   ---

So I am not big on reviewing chains, but IKEA is near and dear to my heart. Just about my entire house is made up of so many IKEA furnishings, I feel the only thing left would be for my hair to turn blonde. IKEA has great style, unbelievable selection and is practically big enough to be its own zip code. Every time I try out the competition, I always come away realizing it was stupid to even attempt it. IKEA is and always will be #1 and there's no close second.

I consider myself to be pretty stupid when it comes to putting things together, assembling things, or working with tools in general. But despite many IKEA purchases, I've never screwed up the building process of any furniture item. I may have realized an error and had to back track five-steps to correct it, but I've never had anything fall apart on me. As for the inconvenience of having to build your own furniture, I usually just use that time to catch up on my highly neglected DVR. I also find it very rewarding once I finish up, which is probably because, like I referenced before - I am a monkey when it comes to putting things together.

I used to complain about how they only have self check-out registers open, but the last couple of times I've gone, that has not been the case. I also used to bitch about the fact that you had to buy bags, but after picking up a few...those bags are about the best investment I've ever made. I use them all the time... I feel like they could support about 500 pounds of weight in each one.

Thank you IKEA for building one of your amazing facilities in Ybor, if the nearest location was still in Orlando, I don't know what I would do with myself.

This review is for their free child care.

Having two toddlers makes doing anything without my husband difficult. Being able to stick at least my older child in free child care while I navigate the Ikea maze made it possible for me to visit Ikea during the weekend.

Check in takes about a minute. My son happily ran inside to play in the pit of balls. After an hour, I picked him up. He happily ran to me, and the staff gave me his shoes and a picture he "drew" (read: scribbled). The whole time I was shopping, I felt like he was in a safe location (only children and the Ikea child care workers are allowed in the area), and I didn't have to worry about him knocking over a display of glass jars.

And after I picked him up, we were able to go shopping for some yummy organic boxed juices that he miraculously agreed to share with his little sister. Score!

So how much do I love Distrito?  Between the lovely wife and me, together and separately, including lunch and dinner, with and without guests, we have accumulated twenty (20) visits!  This was the first Garces restaurant that turned us on to Jose's inspirational cuisine.

In the interests of brevity I'll just focus on dinner.  Virtually every visit we have chosen the tasting menu and never regretted it.  Actually there are two tasting menus with $45 and $55 price points.  Your wait person will tell you that the difference is the emphasis on seafood.  We have always selected the $45 version.

Something we appreciate is the ability to tweak the choices.  We have always found the wait staff to be very accommodating with respect to likes and dislikes.

Our tasting menu journey usually begins with the amazing guacamole.  It's almost embarrassing to watch us fight over every last tidbit.  Next is often a salad.  Every time it's a delicious blend of fruits or vegetables and a unique dressing.  Many times we have enjoyed a flatbread often with delicious mushrooms.  Carne Asada is common and it has always been cooked perfectly for us.  A side of savory black beans and rice is routine.  One time my wife enjoyed a rabbit casserole.  She talked about it for days!  It just seems that the course go on and on with desert included of course.  It's an excellent value.

Some folks call the cuisine at Distrito modern Mexican.  Others call it Mexican fusion.  I just call it delicious!

Still the best Peking duck and roast pork on the east coast. It's an addiction. I get 2 lbs to last a week and 10 minutes later, a lb is gone. Part of it is gluttony and the other part is that the roast pork is simply that good.

I really didn't know how to take the news when I recently checked in at the Nashville Airport and my Yelp IPhone application told me that I was a "regular". 

I became quite the Carmen Sandiego for the last year of my life with constant flights and travel...sometimes up to 3 weeks a month! I just never thought that I would travel so much for business.

Oh sure... it was fun for a bit but soon enough, the hustle and bustle of airports left me with a feeling of dread. Everything was always so expensive and most airports are so expansive and cold. It just exhausts me to think about it. Maybe, it's pure sentiment but the Nashville airport always brought a smile to my face.

How can you not appreciate the Tootsie's with crooners playing guitars at anytime of the day. Believe me, they do bring comfort for a traveler who is coming and going. The BNA staff ranging from airline representatives to baggage claims and especially the security have always been pleasant. They even recognized this weary girl and asked how my trips were coming along! I really appreciate the simplicity of the layout and the comfy black chairs and business stations throughout. You can book a quick massage or a manicure and pedicure between your flights. The usual suspects such as Burger King and Starbucks are around but you can also catch more local flavor with Whitt's BBQ, Noshville, and Tootsie's of course! Sure there aren't as many shopping and dining options as some other locations such as Atlanta or Chicago but who cares? I would always rather save my cash and eat outside of the airport anyway! 

Thank goodness for those flight attendants who dole out those peanuts and crackers.....

Bern's lived up to and exceeded all the hype and expectations. Service is exemplary. The wine list is ridiculous. The place exhudes tradition, pomp, and grandeur. The experience is definitely 5 star if some of the food offerings aren't quite my jimmy jam.

I had a drink at the bar. When the the rest of the party arrived we were whisked past several dining areas to one of the intimate rooms. 

The menu is very large detailed and extensive They have wonderful appetizers which you can't enjoy because the steaks come with so much accoutrement, soup, salad, onion straws, and loaded baked potatoes. We got a couple anyway.. 

We loved to regret it but they were very tasty!!! Fabulous crab cakes. The kind that make you remember why you order them even thiugh they are nevwr good at any of the other places you go.

French onion soup rich and cheesy. Lobster bisque delicious, flavorful and some fabulous buttery morsels of lobster in ut  he steaks are charred. Cooked perfectly. I did surf n turf and the lobster came out of the shell. I would have liked drawn butter. No need for hollandaise b.s. Fillet not my favorite cut but was tender. 

Then we toured the kitchen.. Craziness. Felt like I was in the way but very cool. Then we toured the wine areas. More craziness. Cramped in places. Dusty. Over the top. Bottles from 1920s, 1940s, aisles stacked to high ceilings. They actually have some affordable wines by the glass which I found interesting. Of course my hot date didn't order those..

Then we did dessert room. Fun and intimate. Dated and classy old school. Broadway music piano playing. Never got to use phone or make requests but we heard Memories from Cats, Phantom of the Opera, "I'll do it my way", and other hits from Boon's Broadway era.

We did two dessert samplers. Sime delicious mini chicolate cakes. Caramel sauces. Oh and the coffees... Oh my God the coffees are good!!!!!!! Best ever? I did the mocha. Dear Lord!!!!!! Rich, wonderful, insane. Not a big fsn of the banana desserts. Ice creams were intersting flavors. I was so full at this point but the desserts still tasted grest so they must be AMAZING.

The whole experience is pretty over the top unforgettable. Is it all a little cray cray? Absolutely. Will I ever forget it? Not a chance. Thank you Bern's. You more than delivered. 

Thank you, thank you, thank you to my in-laws. They are the best. I am truly blessed. And the most beautiful woman in the world was there too. A jaw dropping stunner. She's the Best. I'm not worthy of the goddess. We could have had S.O.S. and it would have been great with her around,  but the lobster, chocolate, crab cakes, salad and steak tasted fine.. :)

We went to Hellas for an authentic Greek meal and we were not disappointed! I called around 6pm and asked if I could make a reservation for 4 at 7:30, which they took. When we walked past around 6:45, the line was so long to get in. It definitely started to wind down around 7:30-8, so I guess there are a lot of early bird patrons.

The manager (who greeted us when we entered) and our waitress, were excellent. Super friendly and helpful. We did not enjoy the house wine at all, but maybe it's okay for some. Our waitress was happy to allow us to try a few different wines, which was nice. We found one we liked well enough and ordered. For 4 of us, we had saganaki, Greek salad, broiled octopus, trio of dips, and lamb skewer. The trio of dips was great, as was the pita bread ($1.95 if you ask for extra, which always disappoints me, but I digress). The saganaki was fun and good, but not the best I've had. Greek salad was excellent, lamb skewer was very good, and octopus was delicious. Overall, it was a really good and fun experience. I'd go back.

Terrific restaurant.   A must-dine if you are in Tampa.  

The 1905 salad lives up to the hype.   Great Cuban sandwich.   Unusual, yet delicious,  gazpacho.

Service was impeccable.   There's something about servers wearing tuxedos that really makes your dining experience pop.    Sangria and salad are made tableside.

They should charge admission just to walk through the restaurant.   The building is beautiful and you can just feel the history here (Colombia is the oldest restaurant in Florida).

Everything about the experience from the moment you walk through the front doors (and are greeted immediately) feels special.

We came for lunch and later found out that during dinner there are flamenco dancers.   We will definitely return for that the next time we are in the area.

I've been coming here my whole life, and I'm old. In some ways I liked it better in the old days. Pre convention center. It's still amazing but it's mostly lunch places and I always like it for my daily shopping. If you don't got at 8:00 am on the weekends don't bother . It's a nut house after 10:00. If you have out of town guests this is a must stop. And I do like lunch. It overwhelms me with so many great choices. I miss the old butcher shops like Harry Ochk's . It's Philly at it's goody best.

I can't believe I've been to and taken away from Wright's so many times in the past years and never written a review.  This is one of Tampa's gems and it's obviously evident given how packed they are at all times.  The sandwiches (either breakfast or lunch) are amazing and the portions are humongous.  

The cakes from Wright's deserve mention as well as they are phenomenal.  Whether you get one of their larger cakes or a slice or a cupcake, you will not be disappointed in any of their varieties.  They are all excellent and always moist.  Cakes can be ordered via phone/internet and prepared for pickup for any special occasion as can any items on their regular menu.  Catering is also available and presented in just as good a quality as if you were dining there.

Absolutely delicious.

I came in with a friend last week and had a blast. I enjoyed an avocado boba smoothie, banh mi special combo, and an apple croissant for less than $10. The boba was made well and perfectly chewy - the smoothie itself had a good consistency and was way better than Green Island or other competing boba shops. 

The banh mi could compete with Saigon Deli - although they are both different animals - I like both. The noticeable difference was the bread - Thinh An makes their bread in-house (still have to say I love the crunch at Saigon though). The food was noticeably more healthy or fresher tasting than Saigon with similar pricing.

My favorite thing was definitely the Apple Croissant - it was one of the best baked goods I've had in Tampa and I could easily see myself stopping by all the time to try the different things on the menu. 

Overall, an excellent experience and it really shows with their huge lunch crowds. Thinh An is running at full capacity and it is a sight to see.

No happy hour specials? :(

Had the pulled pork sammy. Delicious, and served with a side of fried pickles. Pulled Pork shoulder, tang bbq sauce, and topped with cole slaw. Would I pay $12 for it again? No thanks. Was it tasty? Yes.

Service was attentive and wonderful.

Nice airport nothing super spectacular however, the area surrounding the airport is pretty awesome.  There's plenty of shopping and things to do that aren't far from the airport in case you have a lenghty lay-over or the itch to get into something Nashville after a flight in.

Starbucks right outside the gate was a winner for me.

There's a lot of Nashville history throughout the terminals as well.

Oh Tampa!  How I love how far you've come in the foodie scene. The Tampa Riverwalk is gorgeous and makes me incredibly proud to say this is my city!!!  At the end of the riverwalk, you'll find the Mecca of an adult food court. 

Next to Ulele lies Armature Works and It's a beauty. Check out all of the food stalls and you'll find some specials-I went with the Inside the Box Cafe toasted turkey sandwich and it was heavenly. My husband tried the butcher place and had their BBQ and we finished it off with a gourmet popsicle-coconut lime for me!

Five stars for their selection and hot deli sandwiches.

I can see how this place gets crowded. We went for lunch on a Wednesday. When we got there at about 11:45 p.m. there was space at the deli counter to order. By noon when we got the sandwiches it was turning into elbow people to get through territory. I can't even imagine what this would be like on a weekend! 

First of all, the deli section is CHEAP. My friend got some sides and I thought they were $11 for a small container, I misread it, they were a little over ONE dollar. Mind. blown. The sandwiches were $6 each. Anywhere else it would be over $10. Five stars for the price. 

I tried four sandwiches, the Caprese, the Reuben, the Philly, and the Meatball. My ranking is I liked the Caprese best, then the Philly, the Reuben and then the Meatball. My dad liked the Reuben, the Philly, the Caprese, then the Meatball. We both liked the Meatball so that tells you how spectacular the other sandwiches were. This also shows you that each person will have their particular tastes, but all the sandwiches are spectacular. 

I loved the Caprese because the mozzarella was so dang fresh. I wish I bought balls of it to bring home now. The Philly had a great amount of cheese. The Reuben slathered on the thousand island dressing and was super flavorful. The Meatball had giant meatballs. All the sandwiches are incredibly filling. The bread really put these sandwiches over the top. I eat a lot and one of these sandwiches would fill me up. 

The way it works is you grab a number at the deli, they call your number so you can order, then they call your number again when it is ready, then you take it outside to pay. You can't buy grocery items at the outside check out line. There is a covered patio with mist spraying where you can sit and eat.

The market itself is really impressive. They have so much cheese, wine, fresh pasta, etc.

I had gone to Fly Bar for drinks once before and it seemed like a club-isn feel. I never would have expected the food to be as good as it was when I returned for dinner! My husband was quite hungry so we ordered a number of items...the hummus and tapenade platter with lamb, braised rabbit tacos, truffle mac n cheese, fries, tuna tartare, and sliders. Everything was excellent. I couldn't say a single negative thing about the food. The drinks are very good, too. I have really enjoyed the craft cocktails I ordered there.  Highly recommend!
