3.5 stars really.

Day by Day has been a reliable lunch spot and catering go-to place for me and many people at my firm.

The fried chicke toss salad is delicious and they serve a "safe" selection of sandwiches.  In the summer-  the gazpacho is a refreshing and tasty choice.

The specials of the sday - often fish and omelettes are also really, really great.  They often sell out of the fish special - so come early for your lunch.  They don't do dinners - although last summer they briefly toyed with a "dessert cafe" concept which I wish had fared better.

Anyhow - it's a great place to grab a safe, reliable lunch.

Still one of my favorite places to eat in the Westshore area.

It's a little embarrassing that I haven't updated my review since 2015, especially when I love this place so much. Here are the main reasons this continues to be a staple in my restaurant rotation.

GUACAMOLE - The table side made guacamole is superb. The chunks of avocado give me life and it is perfectly seasoned. It's a good amount for 2-3 people, if you order it and think uh I think that feeds more than 3 people, Christina, I'm a fatty, what can I say. 

Pair it with the superbly thin and well-salted chips and it is a recipe for addiction. They do not hold back with the salt, and I am here for it. 

FREE CHIPS AND SALSA - It hurts my heart when I go someplace and they don't give free chips and salsa. Please always do this.

CAMARONES SALAD - Yes, I continuously get the same salad. When I have so much other turmoil in my life, I'm looking at you my one-year-old son, I don't like to branch out with food anymore. This salad is delicious and nutritious. I'm so happy to have a light option when eating at a Mexican restaurant, because I know I'm eating all my calories with those chips and guac. 

SERVICE - You can get in and out in less than an hour. They know how to get food out during lunch hours. You would think this would be standard at any business during the week, but you'd be surprised. 

ICE TEA - They bring out the ice tea and give you a little carafe (well, it actually looks like a Patron tequila bottle, but carafe sounds classier), so you can replenish your own tea. They even bring sweetener to the table. I love this.

DESSERT - Free churros to round out the meal. It's the perfect amount of sweet to finish lunch.

The one negative is the parking situation. It continues to be impossible to find parking in the lot in front! This is a mall so of course you will find parking close by, but you might have to walk a bit. I ended up sucking it up and valeting (which was $5 not including gratuity), because I circled the parking lot once and then said screw it. There's nothing you can do about this, but add in five minutes to your drive time!

We love to travel! We flew out today from
PHL and I cannot stand this airport. Security is miserable! I literally had to cut through and weave in and out of TSA employees waiting to clock in. It was ridiculous, seriously move the time clock. Do t out it at the end of a security checkpoint. There aren't any charging stations as in other airports. The ceilings are very low with narrow corridors. The restaurants aren't the best. The bathrooms are always dirty. The best thing about PHL is the lounge areas, and that's pushing it as the chairs are worn and outdated. 

If I could fly out of a closer airport I would, unfortunately that is not an option. 2 stars for this one.

Sadly, now that Vic is gone - the magic is, sadly, fading.
Want the old Vic's?  Try Jay's Favorite - Jay & Vic know each other and steal each others recipes.

Again, reminder:  sauce on the side if you don't want an over-glopped roll!

How have I not been here sooner? This is everything I wanted and more. I wanted a fun cute place with a cool Florida vibe, dog friendly, delicious food, and not too pricey. One also with a cool area to walk around was also on my list of ideal places to visit.  Bartaco has it all!

I tried the tamale, 3 tacos(two of my faves were the lobster taco not on the menu, and the pork belly taco). For a special birthday treat, I tried the churros and chocolate! 

Everything was amazing and to wash it down was the Arnold Palmer tea. I need to come back here ASAP. 

Our spot outside was so perfect and my pup Mocha Coconut loved the big fan that was blowing right in front of him. It also was perfect because it was nicely shaded.

Perfect perfect!!!

How does one with allergies give the Botanical Garden a 5? Let's see; this garden is beautiful and offers free music nights!!! Why would one not give a 5 start review? I have visited the Botanical Garden a few times now and this place is gorgeous! Now that the flowers are blooming and the the fountains are on, this place is definitely one of my new favorite spots in STL. I have had the opportunity to volunteer at the Children's Garden as well and this place is a giant playground with fun events and activities for the little ones. I am glad I was able to experience this. Most recently I was able to show up and listen to some live music (free) on a Wednesday night! I had no idea how big of an event this was until I got there. There must have been over 500 people at the park with chairs, blankets, and coolers. If you are looking for something to do check this place out!

I've never had a bad time here.  Monk's is a near flawless bar, with a fantastic beer selection and excellent food.  Every time I go to Monk's, I try a beer that I've never had before and that I think is awesome.  The crowds are a bit much on the weekends, but I don't hold it against the establishment.  The crowd is always friendly and if you pick someone up here, there is a higher-than-average chance that they are a good conversationalist.

I have a little criticism - The pommes frites are fantastic, but they are cursed with two major weaknesses - they are too small and soft.  When I dip them, they buckle, for their stiffness loses out to the surface tension of the spicy mayo dip.  As a result of this, I always end up getting spicy mayo on my fingers when I dip them.  I usually end up turning to using my fork to eat them halfway through the meal.  I don't enjoy doing this but I have no choice because they taste great.  If any Monk's employees are reading this, please make the pommes frites a little bit more resilient and longer.
I always get the German goodies from Trader Joe's especially the ginger bread cookies and stolen.
If you haven't had a donut and gelato from here yet, I suspect that you're a communist and that hate you hate all things good and fun in life.

Decided to come give this place another chance. I added our names to the waitlist while we were on the way and by the time we arrived our table was ready. They even text me to say that it was ready and allowed me to reply with a number of 1 - on the way or 9 - leave the waitlist. So it works very well. Props for that. 

They are enforcing distancing and have installed plexiglass between the booths. And they give you place mat menus now. Some of the items they had on their menu before are not listed anymore so appears to be a bit more limited although pretty good variety still exists. Upon being seated we were greeted and our drink order was taken. Placed our food order with ease and our food was out in a good time. The food was hot and good.  The staff were all wearing masks but no gloves. I was a bit taken back when a kitchen staff member exited the kitchen area not wearing their mask (draped down below the chin) and walked thru the restaurant and outside. Another kitchen staff member you could see from the seating area had his mask only covering his mouth and full nose exposed. 

Other than those 2 items the experience this time around was good.

PANCREAS - What are you doing, Brad?
BRAD - I'm about to purchase a chocolate-dipped chocolate chip cookie from Famous 4th St Cookie Co.
PANCREAS - Why do you hate me?
BRAD - I don't.  Why would you say something like that?
PANCREAS - Clearly, you do.  You have no idea how much insulin I'm going to have to produce to hav-
BRAD - Shut up.  Just shut up for just one second.  You never let me have fun.  You just sit there with gall bladder and duodenum and whine about how the decisions I make affect you guys.  When do I get something I like, huh?  These cookies are awesome.  They are freaking awesome and it is YOUR JOB to take care of the fallout.
PANCREAS - I hate you.  I will make you diabetic one day.
BRAD - Bring it on, you bastard.

I've lived in the Philly area for 15 years and have been visiting Monk's since year one.  I've been for lunch, dinner, happy hour, brunch, or just a quick beer in the middle of the afternoon.  I think I'm qualified to comment about this place.  I believe that Monk's success is due in large part to their ability to meet the needs of several audiences.  Let me explain.

The Beer Lovers- This is arguably the biggest group. Monk's is literally a legend in the beer world. Not just in Philly but across the country.  Their beer list is superb.  I once sat at the bar on a Saturday afternoon with a couple who had driven for hours from Maryland just for the beer.  Not to have lunch.  Not to visit the Philly historic sites.  Just to drink beer at Monk's.  

The Mussel People- At the moment they have six flavors and people go crazy!  I've seen tables where patrons order pots of all six.  Trust me; these people are devoted to this place.

The Foodies- You can be surprised here.  How about "Monk's Flemish Grilled Scallops" as a starter?  Follow it with Salmon Framboise and if you love seafood you have one heck of a meal.  There are also plenty of choices for carnivores.  

If you are a newbie you may be a little surprised by the physical space.  There is a short dingy hallway that leads from the street to the main door.  The rooms are quirky, homey, and just a little bit beat up.  It all adds to the famous Monk's charm!  I'm sure I'll be back again and again for another 15 years!

This is a bustling SoTa taco and primo beverage spot. Definitely not a hole in the wall. I like the fried oyster taco. Everything was good. The guac was full of avocado. Trendy scene. Fun to try but I'm a hole in the wall kid so you'll see me at Loli's, Acapulco Grocery, and other indies. Bit they def have the party going here. The ceviche didn't do much for me. But the seaoned corn on the cob was tasty. Viva!

Seriously disappointed in Maggianos's tonight. I ordered my favorite Chef Manns Country pasta. I have had this many many times. Tonight it came to the table with crumbled up sausage and not the chicken meatballs. It looked awful, like it had been scrapped from the bottom of the pan. You don't substitute something so different without asking. I got that replaced with lasagna ( not my favorite but eatable ) although presentation was very poor. The server was apologetic but a manager should have been by to apologize for the kitchen making the substitution.  The Peach Bellini I ordered was not great either.

Really 3.5 stars, but I rounded up since previous dessert experiences have been better - and this is JUST a review for the Dessert Room (too bad there is not a separate listing for that, since I know people go just to that).

We ate at SideBern's beforehand, so they called ahead for us and reserved us a booth in the dessert room.  Once at Bern's, you wind your way through the massive foyer & hallway, then up the back stairs.  Pleasantly greeted by the host staff up there, they led us right away to our personal booth.

The booths are so cool-four people could fit very comfortably into the one we had.  They have a tiny jukebox that puts out good sound, and gives you your choice of different types of music.  We chose jazz, and that made a lovely backdrop.  The server was very prompt, and friendly, and knowledgeable - plus we loved that she knew how to work an assortment of smart phones since we wanted a bunch of pictures. 

To start with, I had the Minted Chocolate Coffee:  Coffee, mint and chocolate liqueurs, topped with whipped cream and shaved chocolate.  Not too many ingredients - yet they forgot the shaved chocolate?  Very small glass, too.  But - very delicious.

Milk is not my friend, so that definitely limited my options for dessert.  I ended up going with The Roasted Pineapple:  warm pineapple upside down cake, roasted pineapple ice cream (which I substituted a nice, white peach sorbet) and rum sauce.

Unfortunately, the whole dessert sounded WAY better than it actually was. 1) Not warm 2) Where's the rum in the rum sauce? 3)  If they had actually cooked the cake a bit longer so that the sugar in the pineapple caramelized on the cake, it could have been 100% better.  As it was - it was just 'okay', but certainly not memorable.

The phrase "resting on their laurels" came to mind when we left - everything was 'fine', but for a restaurant with Bern's reputation, I expected better.

I love this place!  I went here today, & I must say that this place has a great design!  Even though there wasn't much greenery, the Climatron was the high point of my trip.  The Japanese & Chinese gardens were beautiful.  The staff were very helpful in answering questions about home gardening.  It was interesting to see the plants from which our foods come from.  There is a giant lemon plant in the Home Gardening House.  Beware though, there is construction going on in the parking lot.  So, you have to take a right at the stop sign before the entrance to the Botanical Garden.  I must must come back here in Spring.

Why 5 stars? Because it's a future Tampa institution.

   ---   ---   ---

While I awaited for the long-anticipated opening of Ulele, I thought that I would try and attend opening night, and be the very first to review. How cool would that be?!

I guess I'll settle for 75th to review.

As someone who has taken a recent interest in interior design and decor, I am in absolute awe of Ulele. They completely knocked it out of the park with this total re-model of the old water works building. Both the inside and outside are just as perfect as can be.

As for the food - it's also top notch! Here's everything that we ordered:

Wedding Beer - 4/5
Jalapeno Corn Bread - 4/5
Crab Mac-n-Cheese - 5/5
Deconstructed Seafood Pot Pie - 4/5
Flank Steak - 5/5
Candied Duck Bacon Maple Fried Ice Cream - 5/5
Toasted Coconut Homemade Ice Cream - 4/5

So as you can see, we either really liked, or loved everything that we tried. Ulele has really brought the big guns to Tampa Heights, in what will evolve into an all out revitalization of the area.

A couple of notes:

-Yes, there's outdoor seating, and it's glorious in the non-summer time.

-You can valet, or find street parking (not that hard) during the evening hours.

I had lunch with a client in Ybor City this afternoon and we chose to meet at Bernini's on 7th Avenue & 17th Street. It had been a while since I had eaten at Bernini's, and I had honestly forgotten about their excellent Italian food.

The restaurant sits right on the corner of 7th & 17th, and there is plenty of on-street and metered spaces to be found during the lunch hour. At night I usually park in the nearby garage.The Baroque-style of architecture and the artwork of Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini add a real touch of class to this establishment. Bernini's is a very elegant stop along the main street of Ybor, and the locals flock there for an excellent Italian meal. 

We asked to sit upstairs this afternoon since it was a bit chilly, and there was a breeze blowing through the open front door. Normally in our Florida weather the cool breeze would have been welcomed, but I certainly appreciated being able to sit upstairs along the windows and watch the people scurrying by below us. The pace of service was just right with our waiter offering several menu suggestions, and then letting us relax and have our business discussions without too much interruption.

My client ordered a delicious-looking Greco Roman wood-fired pizza which was made with green & Kalamata olives, red peppers, capers, grape tomatoes, Feta cheese, Mozzarella & plum tomato sauce. It looked great, and he seemed very happy with his choice. He boxed up some to take back to the office, but later confessed that he had a "late day snack".

I ordered the Cigar City Chop salad (affectionately known as "Bunny Chow") and this delicious leafy-green treat contained provolone cheese, marinated artichoke hearts, Romaine lettuce, shaved carrots, toasted almonds, artfully-sliced pieces of salami, red onions, asparagus and grape tomatoes with a drizzle of Italian vinaigrette. The salad was quite large, and I thoroughly enjoyed eating something a bit lighter for lunch.

The lunch menu has lots of Bruschettas, pizzas, salads, sandwiches, pastas, risottos, and full-on entrées for very affordable prices. The dinner menu has many of the same selections, but the entrées are meant to be enjoyed with an excellent glass or two of wine and some lovely company. (Great spot for date night just in case you need a recommendation.)

Parkway has been and is one of the top places for a fantastic po boy in the NOLA area.  The location is a classic New Orleans awesome dive joint next to Bayou St. John.  I usually prefer sitting at the bar (or at least I used to before COVID-19) and enjoying my meal, with a beer or iced tea, but they have also have a nice patio outside.  I don't have a single favorite thing here (as everything is great) and I usually rotate BUT one thing I really like (that most other places don't have) is the Surf & Turf that has roast beef topped with fried shrimp and roast beef gravy.  They also have a pretty respectable LOOKING burger but do yourself a favor and stick to the po boys as the burger isn't anything special.

Big Minus: Oyster Po Boy is ONLY available on Monday & Wednesday!!!  

This place during normal pre-COVID-19 times was getting more and more crazy crowded as the word has escaped to the masses so sometimes there could be a wait.  During the pandemic there are not many tourists around these days so I haven't had to wait very long at all the line is only a few folks.  There is also no more condiment station so you need to order everything you want on your poboy.  

My video review of Parkway Bakery & Tavern is here:

https://youtu.be/YsJZexicSqI

I really don't have much to say about Monk's.

I don't drink beer, but if I did, I might wait an hour for a table at this place.

Since I don't, I will not be waiting any duration of time again for a table to eat.

Also - service is not that great.

Belated birthday dinner review (#DamnYouWinter)!

For years Zahav is one of those restaurants that I've recommended to several people on good assurance based on YOUR reviews! After all when you come to know an unprecedented amount of people with such strong and differing opinions, who ALL come together to give a spot like Zahav glowing 5 star reviews, it becomes something that speaks volumes. So because of that I definitely decided that it was going to take a special occasion for me to experience it firsthand. And Zahav delivered with amazing results!

There really isn't to much to say about Zahav that hasn't already been said in its previous 874 reviews. From the bargain of getting the Tayim or Chef's Tasting menu's, to the expansive wine list and innovative cocktail list, then factoring in the plentiful selections on the menu that make both vegetarians and carnivores beam with happiness, and having it delivered by attentive and extremely informative servers; Zahav delivered on all fronts perfectly.

Since Tayim gives the dining party a selection of all the Salatims & Hummus, two Mezze per person, and a grilled over coals Al Ha'esh portion each at $39 a person; its definitely the best deal to get. Unless the Chefs Tasting Menu with a special entree steers you in that direction, which the lamb shoulder would have if it wasn't our first time. Savoring their incredible hummus at coffeehouses and at home thanks to Green Aisle Grocery has nowhere near prepared me for how incredible it was in person. whether it was beets, eggplant, black eyed peas, cucumber, and then some the salads were all refreshing and delivered just a hint of spice. The crispy haloumi and labne w/ chive sauce that came with the delicious fried cauliflower elevated Middle Eastern cheeses to unprecedented levels. The grilled duck hearts delivered the almost impossible result of being as unchewy as possible. And the marinated artichokes, squash konafi, and Yemenite soup were all winners. For my grilled portion I was beyond impressed by the lamb merguez and it squash, pumpkin seed, and harissa accompaniment. And the chocolate babka with marscarpone managed to tantalize my sweet tooth, as did the dark rum and chartreuse w/ honey combo that was my Man on the Moon cocktail.

Ultimately when it comes down to it Zahav has everything it takes to make it one of my top five dining destinations in Philly!.

This is a review of the bar and area during the St. Patrick's Day block party and parade.

For years I have heard how great Parasol's is. I have heard story after story of the legendary St. Patrick's block party and the area during the annual parade. This built up a huge hype and this was the year I finally took off of work and attended both events.

The bar itself is small and divey. This is a good thing in my opinion, but it doesn't work very well for giant events.

During the block party the party is in between Tracey's and Parasol's. The area near parasol's seemed to be better organized, more fun and less of a wait for the bathrooms. It was very crowded, but there were multiple beer vendors and everyone seemed to be having a great time. 

During the parade, the area around Parasol's was less fun. The bar itself was very crowded and service suffered.

If you are in the area for the block party, go to Parasol's and look for me. If it is parade time, the bar is too small to accommodate the crowds.
This review is for the Oxford Exchange Bookstore. It rocks!!! Lovely space and interesting choices. Very comfortable. Pleasure to browse.

I was so excited to bist the resurrection of my sear old frien. Goody Goody was a household word! Hearing about it closing, deeply saddened generations of my friends & family.  time to mourn the loss of a stable & consistent friend in your life.
Rumors started flying about the establishment re-opening, no this could ' be true, it was too good to be true. Alas, the rumors were confirmed & our beloved Goody Goody was being resurected. My heart, mind & tummy all let for joy, oh what a glorious day.
The time finally arrives when I can visit this loved landmark, the food institution that had won over so many of our hearts.
My first mistake was not understanding the wait ap. I sent a message through the yelp ap, no bueno, you can't text them. You must call them & when it is quieting down, they text you, they will hold your place for 10 minutes. It took 2 hours & 21 minutes for my text to arrive. Luckily I snagged a seat at the snack bar in 5 minutes, while the line of people waiting continued to grow.
I got the Hyde Park burger, w/ lettuce, tomato, onion, mayo & hold the pickles, onion rings & a chocolate shake...the excitement & anticipation grew. I waited.
The onion rings are da bomb, quite possibly the best I have ever eater. Light, crunchy exterior with the perfect onion ration, & a generous serving...too bad the dipping sauce was a mediocre version of thousand island dressing
The burger was nonexistent, the toppings were fresh & it tasted like a salad on a burger bun, though smaller than usual, way too big for burger & just an egg white, bland bun. I like Steak & Shake, but this burger was paper thin & you could not even taste it with the toppings, so disappointed. At least Krystal steams it's buns & it proportionate.  The milkshake I ordered & asked about three times never arrived, except on my check.
I was sooooo let down, disappointed & truly sad. Forget the muffins & pies to take home, pay the bill & get out of dodge. The hostesses are a bit rude, but the waitress was great.
I will return to try a meal. I am truly baffled, there are reviews on here by people who's opinion & foodie status, I really respect....all I can think is hype. I realize there are different burgers & we all have favorites, but this was not even adequate protien for a child. Everything being a side to your enter burger can add up quickly
Wait in line, no never, definately  not woth me wasting my time over. Wake up Tampa, we want more of the original Goody Goody.
What's a girl to do? Call me very disapointed & looney tunes to think people will wait in line for hours for brash greeting & insufficient food.

Jackson's Bistro, Bar & Sushi has been a consistent favorite for great sushi, an amazing view of Downtown Tampa, and some mighty terrific nightlife. You'll find Jackson's right across the Franklin Street Bridge from Downtown Tampa on Harbour Island. It's in close walking distance from the Convention Center and the Tampa Marriott Waterside.

We've been here several times, usually for a weekend lunch when we can sit outside on the balcony looking back into Downtown Tampa. We've also sat at the sushi bar in the evenings if we're planning to go Downtown to see a concert or a even a play at the Performing Arts Center. And, for the last two years in a row we've been there for the big New Year's Eve celebration.

Each experience has been completely different, ranging from a calm and romantic luncheon to a complete zoo on the dance floor for the big party nights. If you're there for a nice meal, then I recommend sitting on the balcony (weather permitting) because the view cannot be beat. The lunch menu has plenty of soups, salads, sandwiches, and small versions of their regular entrees. There's also a full sushi menu with nigiri, sashimi, and a wide variety of rolls.

At night you have the option of the sushi menu, or high-end cuisine served in an elegant atmosphere. Service can be hit or miss, which is a shame since this is such a showcase restaurant for the Tampa area. The dance club is a lot of fun, but some nights it can get insanely crowded.

This has always been one of my favorite spots for a business luncheon or a fancy dinner for an out-of-town client who wants a view of the Tampa skyline.

I'll freely admit I have had a few good experiences at the Cheesecake Factory. They definately have something for everyone on the menu....a vast variety.
Service is never really good. It is like the employees have an air of entitlement & you are lucky to be getting their time. This isn't once....it's pretty much across the board. I don't know maybe they had a meeting about being pretentious.
This in & of itself is more than enough to keep me away. Unfortunately friends, etc. always want to meet there, so I end up back there, not by choice.
Gotta admit I love the unique & quirky interior. That is the 1 thing I always find enjoyable about this establishment.
I have had so many different & varried dishes from the menu, details are unimportant. Overall, it is obvious it's a chain restaurant.  They definately are not happy with you when you try to change up a dish, just a little, it really has thrown more than 1 server into a complete tailspin. I have learned to just stick to basics, keep my expectations low & concentrate on the company I am in & the ambience.
Truly, I am at a loss as to why so many people love this place.
What's a girl to do? Go with the flow, enjoy the company you are in & have an extra cocktail!

We went here for my Mom's 40th birthday party. I have never been before, so I was excited since I have heard really good things about the restaurant. I'm not a big fan of Cuban food, but I eat it every once in awhile.

I ordered the chicken and shrimp "barcelona", which the menu says comes with lobster bisque in the sauce. I love lobster bisque, but I was slightly disappointed when the sauced tasted nothing like lobster bisque. Either way, the meal was delicious, there was nothing to really complain about since everything was cooked to perfection. The bread was great, the house salad was great...but of course I have yet to discuss the best part.

The SHOW. That is the best part of Columbia and makes it worth anyones time. The dancers have intense deep looks on their faces that display confidence and looks right into your soul as they make music with their hands and feet. It was a great experience and I think everyone should go to the Columbia, at least once in their life, to see it.

I went back Sat.morning,was waiting for friend , some time had passed, I was starving.We ended up going in there, wanted something light, so we split the Lemon Ricotta pancakes!! Wow, not thick, thin, just slightly thicker then a crepe, fabulous, just what I needed. Definitely want those again!! Course the coffee was great-as usual, the waitresses are always pleasant.

This airport is home so I hate to complain too much but when you travel out of Lambert and end up at modern airports with free WiFi that haven't fallen by the wayside you realize it's substandard. Sorry Lambert.

Summer rolls: chicken and shrimp. So far it's the best I've ever had. The rice wrap isn't too chewy, the vermicelli isn't dry. The chicken is tender. The dipping sauce is really good. It's a mix of peanut butter and hoi sin sauce with some chopped peanuts. Definitely get this.

Vietnamese crepes: it's like omelette but crispy filled with pork and shrimp. It's really good. The flavor in the egg and the fresh veggies comes together. It has some greens on the side and I believe pickeled carrots.

Lotus salad is really refreshing.

Wet ho fun aka flat noodle with seafood is disappointing, lacks of flavor the dry version is a little bit better but it's still meh. Not recommended.

Best cookies in the city!!  While the chocolate chip is phenomenal, I got a full-size chocolate chip with peanut butter and it was incredible; just like eating Reese's cups melted into a cookie!  I'm eager to try their other selections, including the black and white, especially since it's a chocolate chip cookie underneath :)

My business associate and I have spent a few jam-packed days meeting with clients and working on presentations during this week in Philadelphia, and he promised me a break from all of the work with a driving tour of the city and a stop at one of his favorite places to eat. So we bundled up against the cold weather and criss-crossed through various neighborhoods as he told me the history of Philadelphia, and shared some stories about growing up in the Italian neighborhoods of South Philly.

During our journey we drove past both Pat's and Geno's, and no telling how many other famous emporiums of cheesesteak goodness as we cruised along the major thoroughfares. Finally he parks the car on a side street, under the highway, and we march around the corner to find ourselves standing in front of the original location of Tony Luke's. Now Frank has not led me wrong all week with his recommendations for places to eat, so I was certainly psyched to try a real Philly cheesesteak.

I was freezing my niblets off in the very cold weather (after all I'm from Florida, and this frozen tundra crap is someone else's idea of fun), but sure enough we stood in line - OUTSIDE - while waiting for our turn to place our order. The menu is pretty straight forward... you have roast beef, roast pork, veal cutlet, chicken cutlet, chicken steak or rib-eye sandwiches along with a couple of other options for vegetarians and seafood lovers. At Frank's urging I ordered a Roast Beef Italian with Provolone and grilled onions and a side of onion rings.

HOLY WOW!!!! I'm not the kind of guy to say that one South Philly cheesesteak is better than another, and then have some sort of fight-to-the-death over bragging rights. I'm just going to say that this food was awesome -- tender, tasty, and flat out amazing.

Yeah, it's touristy and gimmicky, but when the food tastes this good I'm not going to complain.

For some reason we were reluctant to try Piada. The lack of other ideas for dinner inspired us to give them a try tonight. 

Interior brings to mind  Qdoba, Noodles and Company and Subway. Ordering at a counter with your choices i n front  of you. 

Easy menu to order from or create your own dish. The pepperoni bread was great as was the garlic dough. The Chicken Pesto Pasta was really tasty and filling. That did not stop me from getting Gelato. 

They had a nutritional menu available to check food allergies and they have a few gluten free items. 

The price is right, service great, food very good.

With Village Whiskey coming up on so many people's list for best burger and fires in the city, its ALWAYS been inevitable that I'd be coming here so that I could add it to my lists for both on Yelp! And both along with the service and pickles more than exceeded my expectations!

Village Whiskey is one of those places that I've been trying to get into for close to 2 years now. But for just about every single occasion that I've previously tried I couldn't bear to wait for the 30-60 minute wait that  would have been involved to get in. But it finally took the good karma of a lunch bonding session with my dad to get in, and as soon as we did I understood the reason behind the waiting. Between the few marble tables, and classic wooden barscape, the interior of VW is pretty freaking tiny and packed uncomfortably together; which is the only reason that it gets 4 stars.

Other than the packed interior the first thing that I noticed was the attentive service that comes with every Garces establishment. From filling water to giving good suggestions and information they never missed a beat. And from the start of sampling the house selection of pickles which was Salsify, red onions, and a fresh kalamata olive spread to go with the bread; we quickly noticed the excellence of the food.

From the get go my intention was to savor a burger and their incredible duck fat fries. But I didn't start things off with their legendary Maple Bourbon Glazed Cipollini onion and foie gras topped Whiskey King just yet. Instead I took full advantage of the customization that the Village Burger yielded by adding applewood bacon, Rogue Bleu Cheese, and truffled portebello mushrooms to created the perfect bacon blue burger. And the end result added up to my 2nd pick (Still undisputed champion - http://www.yelp.com/biz/sketch-philadelphia#hrid:zKSocBqhJvj7N4N_17qn0A/src:self) for best burger in Philly.

Add in one of my top 5 contenders for best Philly fries, an awesome raw bar selection, and a killer selection of whiskeys and cocktails; and you have a Garces destination that's worthy of a visit!

Oh my freaking goodness. 

Last night while we were eating here, Andy and I were discussing how many stars we would give this place. Andy was at a solid 4, where I was waffling between a 4 and 5. 

However, after giving it some thought, I've decided that anything less than 5 stars for the Shaved Duck just wouldn't be fair! Everything about our experience was fantastic. 

Let's just start with the service. Our server was bubbly (but not overly so), helpful, sweet, and fun! We walked in a little after 7:15 on a Monday night (they're NOT closed on Mondays, despite what the Yelp listing says!) and it was practically empty, which didn't bother me at all -- we were able to be seated right away! Score. 

Our server went over the specials of the day. Half-off smothered fries, double order of wings for the price of one, and $3 draft beers. SWEET!

The smothered fries sounded AMAZING, so we went with those to start. Hot crispy seasoned fries in a creamy rich cheese sauce, topped with MORE cheese and rib meat? How could anyone resist something like THAT? Bring. It. On. 

They were delicious, of course...especially dipped in the 3 yummy BBQ sauces that the Shaved Duck offers. I don't remember the exact names of the sauces, but there was one sweet one, one spicy one, and a smoky one. All three were delicious (BBQ sauce IS my fave condiment, after all), but the sweet one stole my heart. 

For the entree I went with the duck flatbread, which was DELISH! Thin crispy flatbread topped with duck, tomatoes, some sort of sweet cheese. 

Andy ordered the beef brisket sandwich with a side of mac and cheese. WOW! The brisket was so tender and juicy, and the croissant that it was on was perfect! Soft and warm. The mac and cheese was creamy and rich. Not the best mac I've had, but close! 

I was so stuffed by the end of the meal, but when I found out they had bread pudding on the dessert menu, I HAD to go for it. I'm glad I did! It was almond brioche bread pudding, with a rich amaretto sauce. It was delicious, and tasted a bit like a cinnamon roll and a LOT like heaven. Perfect way to end the meal. 

I was impressed by the flatbread, but I'm going to have DREAMS about their brisket. Andy said it was better than Pappys (!!!) and I think I might have to agree!

We had a lovely dinner here although a bit pricey we never let that hinder us! THe freshest coldest seafood we've had in years. It really is hard to find decently done seafood in the Tampa Bay area.  Service was spot on. A nice wine list added to the experience. One appetizer, two dinners and a bottle of wine was close to $200 but who cares when it's so good!! The view is to die for and I think we had the best table in the house. We went rather early and were treated like VIP's the entire evening, and we took our time about it.

Upon arriving we were greeted by friendly staff. Our waiter was really nice. He made sure our food was ok. However I didn't get any refill on my water. That's why I took a star down.

Lobster Mac and cheese is very good. There are chunks of lobster in it. What is unique about it is that it uses orzo instead of elbow pasta. Not too cheesy but enough so that it doesn't become a heavy meal.

Tuna with mushroom risotto is really good. It's a medium size meal. Tuna is crusted with sesame rare in the middle. Risotto is perfectly cooked with balanced flavor of soy sauce underneath it.

Calamari salad is huge. Calamari I lightly breaded. Perfectly cooked, tender, and not rubbery at all.

Overall there's nothing negative I can say about the food

AND WAIT!  AND WAIT, AND WAIT....you will meet Godot before you get your food.
SALES TORCHED because the understaffed kitchen and register can't keep up;
BEST PO'BOY in the city, I actually walk 1.5 miles from the Quarter on a binge.

Why am I only giving 3 stars to the best shrimp po'boy in New Orleans?  Because Parkway Bakery is so poorly managed!  

At most universities there is a basic Business course usually titled "Production & Operations Management".  In short, it is the study of one of the biggest reasons for opportunity losses: bottlenecks.  Parkway, with the best po'boy product in the known universe, is one of the worst production operations.

Here's why: 
1) Usually efficient counter-style service is slowed because there is only ONE register, by 11:15 AM un-roped lines wind around the minuscule vestibule and then spill out onto the street, visible to those trying to find parking and they usually say "screw it" and move on (I know I do: locals don't wait in lines). 
2) If you are a martyr for the cause and stick it out to an actual completed order, the wait for food is ridiculously long.  Why?  Because the kitchen is too small and understaffed.   
3) And worse: because the inside seating area is tiny most of the hungry wait outside in a humongous eating area.   This underutilized "beer garden" is often more desolate than planet Arrakis because NOBODY has their food yet!  
4) Bottlenecks are bad for hungry customers and worse for restaurant sales.  Ya might as well just empty the cash drawers into the frying grease cher.

LAGNIAPPE: it is truly the best po'boy in the city that created the po'boy...dammit!

In all honesty, I really do like Continental Midtown. There are just a few things about it that irk the nerves sometimes. Like the issues I have with their rooftop bar that I pointed out in my previous review. 

The premise is slightly upscale continental dining, but every time I eat there I feel like I've spent significantly more money than I intended. That said, I'm always thoroughly happy with the food. The Continental salad, just a basic Greek salad chopped up with some wonton wrappers thrown in for extra flavor, has always been a favorite. Same with the seared ahi tuna with sprouts over mushroom risotto and a small puddle of soy sauce. Recently, I tried the french onion soup dumplings and found them to be quite delicious. 

The decor for me is starting to get a little outdated, and in certain areas it feels a bit cheap. Seated on the second floor a couple weeks ago, I leaned back in my quasi-booth and found it tipping backward. Huh? Also, I dislike the bathroom, with black toilets and a two-way mirror that any (Peeping) Tom, Dick or Harry can peer through on his way to the John. A covert teeth-check becomes impossible.  

Another peeve is the seating policy. Even when the place was empty on a random weeknight, the hostesses were hesitant to seat me without my dining companion. They did, but what was there to think about? Understandable on a busy weekend, weekday lunch or with a larger party, but not one solitary woman weighted down with the bags of her Walnut Street revelry.

Will I return? You bet. The food, service, and swingy basket chairs outweigh my minor grievances in the scale of Starr.

Why 5 stars? Because THIS St Louis staple lives up to the hype!

   ---   ---   ---

Night and day from my experience at Imo's as a "must-try" while in STL. The marshmallow was thick, creamy, and flavorful. Giggity.

Anytime you can combine the two phenomenons of marshmallow and ice cream, you have to do it. I loved my life while I was indulging this cup of heaven and now I want more. I just might have to find myself in middle America again.

Very friendly and helpful staff. Don't forget to stop by at the sampling station near dairy section.

There are a lot of varieties of gourmet cheese. Much cheaper than DiBruno's but you get almost the same quality. Perfect pairing with their crackers such as the fig olive.

Bamba snack is very addictive, only 99 cents. Also good is the seaweed.

This airport could use some significant improvements, but it's all we've got. 

Traffic

Despite the name, this airport is located in Kenner (brah). That means at least a half hour commute from the city proper, but it will likely be far longer depending on traffic. Once you actually arrive at the airport you are greeted by additional traffic if you plan to drop off or pick up passengers. Don't even dare stop unless your passengers are in sight. The police working details here are quick to tell you to move along. 

Image

Visitors to our city are treated to a very dreary first impression when arriving here. While the concourses aren't all bad, the airline desks in the common area are bland and have an almost institutional feel. Surely the airport board could jazz it up with some artwork or something. Heck, they could hire Blaine Kern to make the desks look like Mardi Gras floats. 

Food

There are no restaurants except on the concourses. That means that if you're bringing people to the airport you will be unable to eat with them. If you're flying out, you're in luck. I recommend stopping at the Lucky Dog cart as this is one of the only sanitary places to have one. 

Security

The TSA doesn't really seem much better than the private security contractors they had in the past. The uniforms have changed, but not much else. The employees run the gamut of friendly to downright mean so good luck. 

Memories

This is the airport I flew out of for my first solo flight. I was about 14 and flying to Houston all by myself. I was super nervous, but made it with no issues. That experience helped me significantly on my next solo flight which was halfway around the world. This is also the airport I flew into with my entire family when they returned from overseas. I still have such vivid memories of my brothers and I all arguing which bag was ours (they were all the same) while a shocked crowd of tourists looked on. 

Despite the issues, this is our airport.

Third time I've been here now. Tried different restaurants out or different items from the menus. Came on a Sunday around 3:30pm so it had a nice crowd but finding a table wasn't an issue. Service was quick at all 3 places we ordered from. Nice to have options when you have a party of people and not everyone wants the same to eat. There are a number of local restaurants to choose from, various restaurants in a food court type theme but fancier. Outdoor and indoor seating available. I decided on the Ropa Vieja from Hemingway's which came with 3 sides which I chose the white rice, black beans and garlic green beans. All were very good. We sat indoors at a table -- which was quite noisy today given the crowd. There's also a large lawn area with lawn games available outside as well as the Riverwalk right across the way where you can rent scooters or just take a stroll. The staff at all the locations we ordered was friendly. Water machine available that's self serve as well as a large sink where you can wash your hands before and after eating. Nice clean place to bring the family and hang out. Be prepared to spend money though because the food is quite pricey for what you get! My Hemingway's meal with a $9 glass of sangria cost a total of $27 today! My daughters pizza which was an individual size was $15! And my hubs bbq $20! Especially because you are not getting table service here. So definitely not a place we will frequent but a nice place to come once in a while. The crowds vary -- so you'll have people dressed up to people dressed for casual, so you shouldn't feel out of place no matter the attire. I actually hate the concept of searching for a table when we come here -- it truly stresses me out!

We returned to Ella's for dinner and much preferred it to Sunday brunch! We put our name in around 6:45 on a Friday night on the No Wait app as we headed up...we arrived expecting to wait, but we were taken right to our table outside (per our request). We started with the wings and then shared the veggie burger and curry. Everything was delicious. The wings could've used more of a kick, as could the curry (I would not classify either as "medium" heat - closer to mild in my opinion). But the flavor on everything was quite yummy. The rast-a-far fries were good, but not as great as I had hoped and I'd probably go with sweet potato fries next time. Our server was excellent - I do not remember her name, but she had brown hair with bangs and did a fantastic job. Only complaint is that there were a lot of people smoking right around the outdoor tables - I wish Ella's would prohibit that because it's really unpleasant if you're a nonsmoker trying to enjoy dinner. We will definitely return for dinner!

Been eating here since I was a toddler, been around so long, The BEST Peking duck EVER, Had it in other Chinatowns, not same flavor. Their Roast duck won-ton soup -great, too. When its available, crunchy roasted pork..OMG!! the best.. prices are very reasonable!!! 

2 can eat for $12.00-16.00 best prices around!!

We formed a gaggle and hit up Kona during the summertime storms this past Sunday to take advantage of the happy hour deals at and around the bar.  Tons of items for $6 and awesome drink specials.  The AVOCADO EGGROLLS and ROASTED CORN and GOAT CHEESE FLATBREADS were the best items we ordered, hands down.  Very tasty!  Lots of people at our table ordered up various sushi rolls, but no one was really amazed.  I personally ordered the gyoza, which places seem content with calling "potstickers," and they were terrible.  I can't even begin to explain all of the flaws, so I won't.  Just don't order them if you're into a traditional type gyoza because you'll be pissed.  

I would definitely go back because there really were a ton of discounted items to choose from, and as Art F. stated below, happy hour is all day, everyday, so long as you're around the bar, either inside or out.

Tampa International is one of my favorite airports! You don't appreciate a clean bathroom stall until you fly through other airports and you realize "Boy, we got it good at TPA!".

Depending on what terminal you visit dining options include Shulas, Green Iguana, Carabbas, Starbucks, Sam Sneads, Tequileria, Chilis, and Casa Bacardi. Some terminals are better than others. There are better dining options at JFK, BWI, Boston and Houston, but the food selection is decent in TPA.  

The Tampa airport is not as large as the major hub airports which makes getting around the airport an ease. Despite the airport size, the shuttle, security and baggage have always run smoothly. The ease of parking or getting around the airport is priceless. I can't count how many times I have almost missed my flight in Atlanta... never the case in Tampa.

Airport security will flag you down if you park outside baggage claim while picking up friends and family so park in the cell phone parking lot if you arrive early.

I've enjoyed food from Sang Kee's somewhat posh suburban bistro in Wynnewood, and its West Philly noodle house. And I loathed trying its horrendous stall inside the Reading Terminal Market. But it took forever and my friends birthday for me to finally get out there and sample some of its original Chinatown fire. And while part of me saw a glimmer of why it has earned such praise and recognition over the years, there was also part of me who found it to be just decent.

As many have alluded to before its cash only so come prepared. There is an ATM on sight if you need to swing otherwise, but be forewarned since its a rather shady looking one (http://www.philebrity.com/2012/05/02/places-we-dont-understand-the-atm-at-sang-kee-peking-duck-house/). For a spot with two floors a number of the tables felt rather cramped together. While part of could be due to the fact that we were a 2 round table birthday group, ours was compacted closely to another rather large group which gave off the feeling of dueling conversations at times. The lightening fast and attentive service did make up for it though.

While the menu DEFINITELY yields a number of impressive sounding entrees and starters, it can also be a massive and overwhelming ordeal to sift through. I also couldn't help but notice that things like pork belly in chili oil, and Dan Dan Noodles were suddenly added to a new specialty menu. I wonder what influenced that decision (http://www.yelp.com/biz/han-dynasty-philadelphia)? being in the house of Peking duck I knew that I at least had to get it as an appetizer. But for its signature item, it left me feeling rather underwhelmed and really didn't offer up anything that made it stand out from the many other Chinatown options that have it on the menu. The triple seafood delight of shrimp, scallops, and squid was a spicy and plentiful step in the right direction. But I've had several seafood dishes at similar spots that I do consider to be equals.

If I were to compare Chinatown restaurants to cheesesteak places, I certainly won't go as far as to call Sang Kee a Pat's or Geno's. But it does add up to a somewhat better than Jim's equivalent, and if you take a good walk around it won't be long before you come across several other options that are better and more accessible.

I have been wanting to try Loli's ever since I saw it as a new business on Yelp. My husband and I were craving a "light" dinner tonight, so we thought Loli's would be a good option because we could order individual items. We ordered a beef tongue taco, fish taco, carnitas sopes, and chicken tamale. Everything was SO good. The flavors were excellent and the meat/fish was all perfectly cooked. I don't think I had a favorite, but I probably wouldn't order the fish taco again just because I thought it had the least flavor out of everything we ordered (but it was still really good!!). We walked out with a bill right around $20 - unreal! My husband's first words when we got in the car: "Can we have this like once a week?" The girl working the front was friendly and helpful as well. We will definitely return soon!

I went here for lunch the other day with a few other people and the meal was very good. My boyfriend and I shared the pad thai and the chicken curry. I didn't think the chicken curry had much flavor - I definitely didn't even taste a hint of curry. But the pad thai was very tasty, and my bites of everyone else's (especially the roti canai and tofu with cucumber appetizers) were good too. I will go back!

This is one of the best places in Tampa for Happy Hour or a place to grab lunch or dinner that can usually accomodate you quickly.  The location is the best as it's near a lot of the Tampa area hot spots, but away from the congested I-Mall or Westshore eateries.  

Happy hour specials are great and varied.  I also like the late night happy hour as not many people know this place has this and it's a great deal.  You can find a vast selection of menu items or sushi if that is what you're into.

We stopped in on a cool Friday. We were hoping there would not be a ton of people here since spring break was over. We paid our $20 for parking (ouch) and were flagged down to parking lot C. Easy parking and polite attendants. Some people were driving all over the place being super picky about where they parked but given it was a high of 70 it did not really matter where we parked. 

Walked up to the shuttle and it took us straight to the front doors. Our tickets were marked Gate C so off we went. Walked through the metal detector and zapped our tickets and in we went. 

There were maps of the park so we grabbed one and we took the left avenue for our day's adventure. Most people were going right so we figured why fight the crowds and go the other direction. 

Some of the restaurants were not open yet (11 AM) weird so we had to walk a ways until we located a place that was open. We opted for the BBQ place which turned out to be very good. 

Walked throughout the park all day and left by 6 pm. It was a great day. Not too busy and the weather could not have been any better.

We finally tried this popular BBQ spot due to the slight push from Steve E., who scheduled a casual friendly afternoon Yelp event here. We enjoyed our BBQ but I took most of mine to go, to savor on the next day. Honestly, I was already stuffed from the first stop on the day's Yelp journey. 

The ribs as well as the brisket were properly done, in what I consider to be Texas-style. They were not swimming in sauce so we could savor the flavor of meat, meat, and more meat. The contrast between lean and fatty brisket is quite startling! I'm glad I ordered a mix and I recommend you do the same. 

The sides were generally quite yummy although the Mac and Cheese was pedestrian and very disappointing. The okra, on the other hand, was properly fried, crunchy, and tasty. My biscuit, even though I'm told the corn bread is better, was clearly homemade and had a great consistency, moist, salty, savory, and crunchy at the same time. All of the sides were equally tasty the next day!

I was quite surprised to find out their bakery is ultra-creative, cranking out fun and unique cupcakes. The manager kindly came by and let us try a few creations! The margarita cupcake, with both salt and sugar, was outstanding! The nacho cheese snicker doodle cupcake was clearly created by a twisted mind. My favorite kind. Delicious!

Thanks Steve E and thanks 4 Rivers!

This is a reliable place to hold a happy hour for a large group. They always provide excellent service and they have an awesome long table for 20+ made out of one huge tree. 

You can sit inside or outside, depending on the weather and your whim. As for drinks, they have a full bar and solid assortment of beers. 

While the atmosphere is nice, it's the service that encourages us to return.

They have outdoor seating for COVID, and it's a segmented area of 13th St. that is pretty spacious. Cafe Lift also takes credit card, huge plus. The service was really solid and I would recommend their steak on a pretzel roll, it's super delicious and make sure you get their house hot sauce. Additionally, their traditional breakfast items like french toast are some of the best in the city. BYOB.

This place is pretty good, but not quite great.

The gimmick is that everything is under 475 calories.  And, honestly, I'm amazed that you could get so much food for so few calories.  Or that it could taste so normal.  But be aware that they try to sell you on multiple dishes, so before you know it, you've ordered 1000 calories of food.

Ambience is very nice.  Staff is friendly and helpful, but not flawless (my husband was served the wrong steak).  Service was quick for most things but a little slow on water service.

We started with the Cuban flatbread (really good but nothing groundbreaking) and the special shrimp and lobster spring rolls (fine, not extraordinary).  For my main, I had the venison (on special).  It was mildly gamey.  The venison and mushroom ragout was only okay, I felt that meat in the sauce was a bit overcooked and rough.  The truffle mashed potatoes tasted off, maybe they used canned truffles or slightly off truffle oil?  

Desserts were fine but tasted a little generic.  They do make it hard to reject dessert by bringing the shooters to the table to "sample."  As shot sized desserts, they really are just a taste, but that's full-sized for Seasons 52.  I had the key lime pie, which was good.  My husband had both the tropical cheesecake and the Valentine's dessert (something with chocolate and raspberry).

Overall, I liked the setting, and certainly the food was very edible.  However, it wasn't especially remarkable, and for the price, I expect more from a restaurant in Tampa.
When they're hot - they're HOT - and sooooooo delectable when fresh out of the oven.  these pricey, large, thick, butter-laden cookies scream with flavor and taste sublime.  Oh, my hips!!!!

Four and a half.stars, but Brett won't let me refine my reviews in adequate ratings detail. 

This is one of the hipper and hotter downtown Tampa institutions. It's a fashionable crowd and a fun setting with bicycle spoke & chain / industrial decor, as well as some impressive works of art. They serve up gastropub style Mexican fusion cuisine and popular music. 

It's generally pretty busy and loudish here and the servers and bartenders are energetic and hard working. There's an outdoor deck above the backdoor and a all outside seating patio are in the front. 

Parking is off the side street in a lot and some very limited street parking. Do NOT park in the lot next to the restaurant or you will be towed. 

They have a GREAT happy hour and the food is fun and pretty first rate. They also have some cool specials like Thursdays after 10. Definitely one of the more fun and happening places in Tampa. Just not a quiet or romantic experience.. More boisterous and hip-hopping.

We arrived just before Happy Hour (5 pm) officially starts and what an amazing evening of food, drinks and stellar service we experienced.

We began with expertly mixed drinks, tasty devilled eggs and always terrific pickled beets. Service from Katelyn was just perfect, but what really stood out was when Candace presented us with those delightful pickled beets, served in a mason jar on a beautiful wood platter accompanied by delectable whipped ricotta and olive tapanade.

We also sank our teeth into a well cooked yet juicy burger on a potato roll with cheddar, lettuce, tomato and house made dressing.  Recalled that backyard barbecue from childhood.

I am not a burger person, but Village Whiskey after 10 years, is still nailing it.

We love you, Candace!!!! Clearly, after 21 years in the biz, you KNOW what you're doing.  Brava!!!

Dough is a cute place to be. I like the interior decoration. They comfortable in space and great distance to next table. It is good romantic night or big crowd in a group. 

Pink interior design with red chandelier almost like fairy tale. The store have comfortable chair to enjoy the dessert they serve. They also have a walkway connect the next door Datz restaurant. If you cannot find the parking in the front, try their behind building parking lot. It great place to hang out with friend or family. 

The store serve the bakery and ice cream. They have donut, cake in different topping, cupcake and more. The ice cream include gelato with very smooth and creamy taste. I have the double cherry whisky and it is good to enjoy. They also serve the coffee and drink which is late for my wife to try it. She will not able go to sleep if she have caffeine after 12 noon.

The hardest small business you can possibly run is a restaurant. What makes it hard is that people's expectations are the same every time you walk in the door and meeting those expectations is near impossible. That being said, I love Parasols because they strive for perfection every day. From the innovative soups, excellent pulled pork and the best roast beef in town, this is the place you go for a real New Orleans poboy. Quality is number 1 here and that is no tired cliche or slogan. They are better than ever and I am back at the table.

YELP REVIEW #1100

Busch Gardens has been a 5-star experience for me ever since I was a little kid and visiting the Tampa area during summer vacations with my family. My grandparents used to live in the small town of Wildwood north of Ocala, and our summer vacations consisted of trips to see them followed by days at the beach and days at Busch Gardens.

The park opened way before my time in 1959 as a special hospitality area for Anheuser-Busch of Tampa, with it's famed tasting room and bird sanctuary. In 1965 Busch Gardens opened the area known as Serengeti Plains, and stocked the Plains with African wildlife which were allowed to roam freely. Over the years, Busch Gardens has continued to focus on its tropical landscape, exotic animals, and thrill ride amusements to draw visitors.

Busch Gardens is a relatively small park with 335 acres inside their fences. That includes 25 total rides, of which 8 are classified as roller coasters, and 3 are water attractions. The park hosted well over 4 million people last year, placing in the Top 20 of the most-visited theme parks in the US and in the Top 25 worldwide.

Florida Resident annual passes cost $156 for Busch Gardens, and that includes free parking, discounts on dining, shopping, and special admission events, and no blackout dates. In my book this is THE best value for any amusement park in Florida, and one of the best amusement park experiences in the country.

Yes, it has changed a lot over the years -- fan favorites such as the Anheuser-Busch tasting room and Rhino Rally are long gone, and the Park has confirmed that the Gwazi wooden roller coaster is coming down soon. In their place, new attractions such as SheiKra, Cheetah Hunt, and Falcon's Fury have sprung up around the park. Today Busch Gardens is a combination African wildlife exhibit, thrill ride / coaster junkie experience, and some high quality song / dance / ice skating / acrobatic production shows.

Busch Gardens has over ten different themed areas within the park, and more than a dozen animal attraction spots. There is now an Animal Care Center on the premises, and park visitors are welcome to watch the veterinarians as they perform exams and medical procedures on the wildlife. The park has some behind-the-scenes tours which allow visitors to venture out onto the Serengeti on specially-built Busch Gardens vehicles, and feed some of the animals.  

As for the thrill rides, hang on to your seats because Busch Gardens is one of the best coaster-junkie meccas in America. Rides such as Kumba and Montu, are now joined by Cheetah Hunt, SheiKra, and Falcon's Fury for screaming good times by all. Busch Gardens still has the Skyride and the Serengeti Railway for those who enjoy a slightly tamer ride.

If you prefer live-action shows then you'll find a constantly-changing number of family-friendly productions featuring costumed characters, live animals, singing, dancing, and acrobatic performers. The shows change by season, so make sure that you check the daily schedule to see what's happening.

Throughout the year Busch Gardens has a number of special events for their guests, and those include Christmas Town, Howl-O-Scream, the Real Music Series, Bands, Brew & BBQ, Viva La Musica!, Summer Nights, and a Food & Wine Festival to name a few.

Busch Gardens has been incredibly generous to the Tampa Bay Yelp community for the past several years, offering us a limited number of free VIP admission tickets and front-of-the-line passes during the Holiday season, and for Howl-O-Scream. They are class people, running a fantastic home-town amusement park.

Finally tried The Refinery, and we were very satisfied. We sat upstairs on the outside patio. It is covered, and they have fans, but the hot and humid of our summer was still dreadful. We had our little dog with us, so we suffered and survived.

We had a Sirloin Steak Sandwich on sweet Hawaiian bread with pesto and onion rings on it. It was pretty big so it was good for two people. We also tried their sweet biscuit debris. It's like funnel cake. It was served with blackberry preserves. Both were delicious. We are dying to try their dinner too sometime.

Wow! This place is a bit overwhelming! I really don't even know where to begin. My parents and I went for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon and the place was packed! When I first walked in I thought they were taking me to a grocery store! Well, they were...but this is so much more than a grocery store. 

Upon arriving I stopped by the olive bar to sample a few olives. Then I made my way to the back where we needed to order sandwiches. Again, the place was packed; I could hardly move! My dad took a number near the deli to order our sandwiches and then my mom and I took a number to wait for the desserts! When they called my number at the dessert counter I was so excited to ask for their strawberry gelato and the Italian rum cake and an eclair. I had to pay for the gelato at the counter, but the rum cake could be paid for with lunch. They had so many wonderful pastries to choose from so you can definitely find something wonderful. 

The sandwiches took a bit longer to prepare so my mom and I were waiting on my dad to join us for a while, but we browsed the store in the meantime. I also noticed they had a large coffee bar! How cool. By the time my dad found us we were making our way outside and then we had to wait in line to pay and find a place to sit and eat. I grabbed some chips and a few drinks as well. The cashier rang up our goodies and then we found a table to sit at and enjoy our lunch. 

My turkey sandwich was really really good! They had some kind of Italian seasoning they put on top with peppers and onions and other toppings as well. I really enjoyed it all; especially the bread. Freshly baked. My parents also enjoyed their sandwiches and we shared our desserts and enjoyed everything; however, we could not eat all of our food so we wrapped things up and planned to eat the leftovers for dinner. My dad went inside to ask for a to go box for the desserts and I asked for a bag for our sandwiches (that we wrapped). 

After eating we went inside and browsed the wine and cheese section; they had so many wonderful cheeses and wines! I wish I lived closer because I know I would buy a lot of things here for parties. They even had wine sampling upon request. 

This place really does have everything and it is quite an experience! 

The only reason I am knocking a star is because it really does seem to be very dis-organized and confusing. I know they probably function this way and they enjoy it, but as a customer it is quite overwhelming to figure out how to order and pay.

I've been 3 times.

Each time I have had the following:

Poor Service

Poor Food

Over-priced bill for the items listed above.

I'm sorry to all the people who enjoy this establishment, I have been three times and I have not enjoyed my experience.  

I want to be proven wrong...I REALLY do, please someone show me the light!

Still amazing after all these years.
My now 11 year old kid and I had a whopping $85 lunch including a Pachinko Roll (delicious), the Tartare Trio ($15), Naked Salmon roll and JUMBO Ebi Shumai.
Also Nigiri and sashimi a la carte (Salmon belly, salmon, REAL home-made tamago and more).

We love this place SO much!
We miss you!

Wow, was our experience here amazing!  We went for an early dinner on New Year's Eve. First stop - the bar, to try the cucumber gimlet every Yelper raves about. 10/10 - this might be my new favorite gin drink ever.  Cool, refreshing, and delightful. The bartenders were superb: friendly, efficient, and funny, and made some very helpful dinner suggestions.  Tip:  don't get started on the complimentary truffle popcorn, because it is addicting!

For dinner, we were sat at high top table for two, in what seemed to be the more casual outside bar area.  The table was wobbly on the tile floors, so I went to ask the hostess if we could be moved to a regular table. She was instantly accommodating, with no hesitation or eye roll, even though I know it was a busy night with seating planned well in advance.

We were moved to what very well may have been the best table in the house - outside dining area, right next to the beautiful pond, with a full moon overhead.  Stunning!  Even though it was a cool night, they had heaters overhead which made it perfectly comfortable.

Our server, Cole, was completely on the ball; I feel we had better service here than I've ever had at my other favorite restaurant in the area. We started with both the ahi tuna tartare and beef tartare. The tuna was some of the best I've had, stacked on crunchy noodles. Generous portion of tartare, served with delicious crostinis.

Yikes, this is getting long, so I'll just say that I loved my blackened snapper, even though it was a touch overcooked, and the side dish of tater tots stuffed with cheese was crazy good, although could have been served hotter.

The one and only disappointment of the night was the dessert of carrot cake.  OP - how could you fail me here? Get yourself a new baker, or order it from a local place, but don't have this as your featured dessert! It was not moist, served too cool, with not nearly enough frosting on top, side, or between layers. And what was with the odd pineapple sauce on the plate? Anyway, it was a fail. Our server instantly removed it from our bill, once he could see how bummed we were.

Great evening from start to finish and we will definitely be going back for my birthday dinner!

I really hope this airport can shuffle some funds or do whatever it needs to do and quickly improve its space. It's such a depressing environment all around, whether you're arriving bright-eyed in New Orleans or forcing yourself to go home.

It's NOLA, so where are good meal options? It'd also be great if they'd think about revamping bars or installing new ones.

The TSA line was okay, but they randomly selected me out of the blue for an extra search, told me to hover by the side of the machines and didn't answer me when I asked what to expect from a search. I don't fly that often, so I was genuinely curious if there was a chance of missing my flight, or if they planned to search my luggage for whatever reason.

Nope, literally all they did was run some weird-looking machine thing over my hands, like in the pre-check line. Except that it wasn't pre-check. Maybe that's normal, I don't know -- I don't fly much, but they could certainly benefit from some transparency.

At least the airport is on the smaller side so there's less walking generally, but they should consider renovating themselves out of the 1980s.

We popped in before a football game because all the nearby spots had multi-hour waits. The interior is well appointed, a bit dark, and classy.  We were quickly seated as the place was less than half full.

Starting with my traditional martini, they brought it in a stainless container that essentially yielded two drinks. +1 star.

The server was friendly and professional, joking around with us repeatedly. He took the time to explain our options. We ordered some flat bread, which turned out to be tasty and huge (while thin - it is FLAT bread).

Our meals were healthy, tasty, and worth the reasonable prices. The portions were perfect. If you are expecting giant quantities of food suitable for the next day's meals, you will be disappointed. Instead, you get flavor! My tuna salad entree was really excellent, although the amount of tuna included was a bit underwhelming.

Please note, a portion of the menu changes every season so you can return repeatedly, and experiment with new options.

I'd be happy to return. Recommended for the light and interesting pregame meal! If you prefer to tailgate, please proceed.

Why 2 stars?  Because there are 2 good rides.

   ---   ---   ---

I'm probably spoiled from growing up in Houston (Six Flags Astroworld) and spending many summers in Cleveland (Cedar Point.)  Astroworld was unfortunately closed down in 2005, but they had about 12 big thrill rides before going under.  Cedar Point is the #1 park in the world with 17 roller coasters and a handful of other thrill rides.  Busch Gardens has 5 roller coasters, and 3 of them are either boring or just painful.  

Gwazi: 1/5 *****

Do not ever ride this.  It hurts.  It is not fun in any way, shape or form.  There is a sign outside of the ride that says, "New smoother track installed for 2011."  I don't want to call this a lie, but it's completely untrue.  Is that a nicer way of saying it?  The track feels like it was installed in 1968 and has never once even been sprayed with an ounce of WD-40.  I would actually give this ride a negative rating, because you will need a deep tissue massage when you're done with it.

Kumba 2/5 *****

It's not painful, but it's a ride that you could fall asleep on.  It's incredibly boring as there are no feelings of "G-Force" at any point.

Montu 2/5 *****

Similar to Kumba, but slightly more exciting.  There are no G-Force moments, but it has the slight edge over Kumba.  We'll officially give Montu 2.2 stars.

Shiekra 5/5 *****

Shiekra is a great ride.  Being suspended at the top of the hill as you stare down at your death is awesome.  It's even at about a 110 degree inverse angle to add to the horror.  No matter how many times I ride it, I am nervous waiting in line.  That's when you know the ride is good.  I got a couple of butterflies just thinking about it.

Cheetah Hunt 5/5 *****

Cheetah Hunt is a pioneer in the new generation of roller coasters.  As we move forward, the days of the 200, 300 and 400 foot hills will slowly dissolve with new thrill rides.  Cheetah Hunt does not have any huge hills, but the ride is all about precision of the turns and placement of quicker, smaller hills with speed boosters built in.  The G-Forces are plentiful in this ride despite its biggest drop only being 130 feet.

Animal Exhibits 4/5 *****

The Lion area was definitely the highlight of any animal sightings.  There was a large window into one of the Lion's den that was gathering a huge crowd.  One of the Lions was standing on the ledge trying to directly interact with the people watching.  He/she was standing upright and pawing at the window in a non-aggressive manner, and it was a sight to be seen.  

The animal exhibits are a nice touch to the park, but they definitely create an incredible amount of walking space to get from one attraction to the next.  Be prepared for a ton of walking.  In terms of any animal related attractions, Lowry Park Zoo is a much cheaper alternative.  LPZ is only a couple of miles from Busch Gardens and has just about everything you would find at Busch.

The bottom line is that Busch Gardens is essentially good for two roller coasters.  You could walk in, ride Cheetah Hunt, ride Shiekra and leave.  Unfortunately it's a pricey ticket for a couple hours of line waiting and four minutes of coaster riding.

STL BBQ was once a mystery and a misnomer.  All over the country you'd find menus that offer "STL Style BBQ".  But here in St. Louis, a good BBQ joint was nonexistent.  Super Smokers was about the only decent offering.  

...but alas, the pit masters were just in hiding.  

There are now a good selection of great BBQ joints in town.  SugarFire slips in line with many others... Pappy's, Bogart's, Shaved Duck... take your pick.  The great thing about SugarFire is they aren't as well known as the other.  You don't have to stand in a line around the corner.  You don't have to get there at 9am to ensure they aren't out of ribs.  

We tried some smoked turkey, and a brisket/sausage sandwich called the Big Muddy.  Both were very good and the accompanying sauces are diverse and interesting.  Beans and potato salad were just ok.  

Bring a bib and wet wipes.  You're going to be elbow deep in deliciousness.

I like The Shaved Duck, I really do. The food is delicious, the space is nice, but the service needs some serious attention. I won't name drop because I think the young lady may have been having a bad day or she was simply ready for her shift to end. I arrived around 3:10pm to grab some late lunch...specifically the Shrimp & Grits. Once I walked in the young lady stood behind the bar and said nothing. We made eye contact for a few seconds in silence (which made it feel like a 30 second stare-down lol.) Finally she says take a seat whenever you like. I obliged.

She dropped off a glass of iced water and walked away so fast I didn't have a chance to tell her I hate ice in my water. Anywho, when she finally returned I asked if I could order the Shrimp & Grits...she said, "That's after 5pm" 

Welp, moving on...I ordered the House Salad & Crab Cakes instead. I sat for what felt like 30+ minutes unattended. She totally disappeared, never to be seen or heard from again. I got up to leave and saw a gentlemen walking in my direction with food so I sat back down as not to be rude and leave my order uneaten. 

Again, no one ever came by to make sure my order was satisfactory, if I needed more water or needed anything additional. I waited and waited for someone to come by with the check; I was clearly finished. A different gentleman came by to grab my dishes.

Waiting....waiting.....waiting.... I got up to find someone! ANYONE! to settle my check. At this point I just wanted to get out of here. I spotted to gentleman who picked up my dishes and asked if I could please have someone check me out, he politely said yes. 

The same guy who dropped my food off returned to the table and sat the check down. Ummm sir, I'm over here....standing at the bar....

After this experience I highly doubt I'll be returning to the Duck, much less recommending it to others. 

~Christy

I just love this market. I'd likely stop in nearly every day if I lived in the area. There hasn't been a single time I've walked in and walked out without buying something from one of the merchants. Yesterday, a lunch at Olympic Gyro followed by some Amish cakes was just a great start to the day.

Plus, there's always interesting characters floating around outside.
RIP Owner John Hogan. You brought Parasols back with great passion and great food. We officially adopt you as a New Orleanian and we send condolences to your loving wife.
