Anyone else remember the stellar episode of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" where Larry David and Jeff discover the greatest chicken ever in a place where they would never be found by friends and family?

Ok...probably just a few of you know what I'm talking about and why the episode was so good.

I thought about that episode as I made my way into this restaurant. While things didn't turn out as well for me as Larry David, the delicious chicken itself was worth the visit. (I enjoyed the yellow sauce more than the green sauce if you're keeping score.)

Honestly, I spent more money than I should have because I wanted plantains and yuca instead of the rice, fries or salad that comes with the usual combo meal. C'mon, I had to have plantains at a place like this.

Oh, and then I added a couple empanadas as well. Yes, I was hungry and had been curious about this place for months, so why not?

The food was fresh, prepared quickly and I truly enjoyed every bite of it.

Service was friendly, unfortunately just not quite as friendly as in the Curb Your Enthusiasm episode. (Yes, I highly recommend checking it out online.)

I think this is my favorite Yummy House location.  The one on Waters has minimal ambiance with tables too close together, and the one on Hillsborough is too loud with consistently bad service. This one seemed just right.

Our waiter was good, not great. He had two large tables, and a few smaller ones, and I think it was more than he could comfortably handle. That being said, he did get our orders correct, and everything came out in a relatively timely manner.

Food was delicious, and with our large group swapping dishes, I got to taste quite a wide variety of offerings.  My favorites were my Kung Po Shrimp (not too spicy), hot and sour soup (very spicy), salt and pepper calamari, and dried scallop fried rice (new to me - delicious!).  My least favorites were their crispy egg roll app (not enough filling; just fried flavor), chicken corn soup, and spicy seafood tofu pot (it was way too greasy).

Just a heads up:  their parking lot is not big enough for the restaurant to hold a full crowd, so that was the number one complaint I heard. Good luck, and if you find parking, it will be worth it!

Good service. The pasta in my dish was over cooked and their was gnocchi in my dish and there shouldn't have been. Drinks were kept full and service was a good pace. Always helps to have a coupon from their email club too.

If you haven't been yet, it's time to go!  Thinh An does so many things right, and has so many options, all I can really do is provide an overview of what I have tried.

Drinks - they offer a wide variety, sodas, tea, etc., but I always end up with the honeydew slush with boba. Sweet, tart, perfect.

Pho - it is crazy good. I've had the pho with chicken and the vegetable pho, and I am slightly addicted to both. Now when I crave pho, I only want to come here.

Pastries - oh geez - they are amazing, and I've eaten enough to be an expert on the matter. My favorites are the ones with fruit in them, but I had a meat-filled one, too, which was awesome.

Bread - I'm sure you've heard they bake it fresh - have a bahn mi and see for yourself how fluffy and fresh it is.  Or - order the curry and it comes with a loaf to dip in the tasty sauce. I bet your bread will be gone long before the curry is.

Tofu - multiple flavors, multiple preparations. It's the star of my veggie pho. It is also served as a weird, but oddly delicious dessert, where fresh tofu is mixed with a ginger sugar sauce.  This is a must try!  You can also bring some home with you as they sell it in the to-go section.

To-go Section - everything your little heart desires, and more.  You could feed your family on different things every night of the week from the quantity of items they have pre-wrapped and ready for take out.  Rolls, curry, tofu, pastries, sausage, milk, etc.

Dessert - while there are many offerings, the thing to have is waffle cone with ice cream. It is a puffy, freshly made waffle cone, and if you combine it with the green tea ice cream, it is a delicious cold contrast.

Every time I've been the place is hopping, but service is friendly, management plays an active role, and check-out is quick due to servers using an iPad at your table.

I can't say that I am loving 4 Rivers at this time. I can say that the biscuits, not the ribs are the best part in my opinion.

Coming here on a Thursday night, I was warned about a line wrapped around the building. Good thing I was talking to Dianna, or I probably would have left.  Paper menus were available so we can scope out the endless options while we waited. The menu was honestly quite overwhelming to me even with looking at the reviews and pictures on Yelp.

I picked out the burnt ends bc I do like food a little tiny bit charred. With that I picked out the macaroni and cheese, baked grits, and the banana bread pudding.  I was also able to try one of the ribs, and the pulled pork from my other family members.

My option, burnt ends, I disliked it the most with it being soooo DRY. The ribs were so salty, & mediocre. The pulled pork was the best of the three(thanks Erin P. for that suggestion). 

The service is great here. Very nice efficient.  The prices are pretty good for the amount of food you get. 

Food is served cafeteria style or food court style. I don't love that because I tend not to go to places like that in the evening feeling unsure of how long the food has been sitting there. I also did have some not-so-warm sides.

I will try 4 Rivers again sometime because there are endless options on their menu of entrees and sides, & their desserts. Hopefully in time, I will find that menu item that I love.

It's big - it's (relatively) new, it's fairly clean.

Pretty nice as major stadium venues go.

As always, wish there were more ladies bathrooms (and cleaner) and healthier food choices.

Big plus for the burger.  Slight minus for the fries that come with it.  

I'm not a fan of any fries that don't let out a very audible crunch with each bite.  Good Dog's fries do not perform in this regard.

Their burger, however, is succulent.  It is worth getting.  Also, if you're going for a darker pub environment with cute dog pictures on the walls, this place is for you.

First time at Penang was for a friend's birthday celebration.  They have quite a menu, with the selections ranging from super cheap to relatively pricey--however, for what you pay, you do get a lot of food.  I believe I ordered chicken noodle soup with chicken and shrimp--a huge bowl for only $6.00?? Count me in!  Also had a watermelon juice--if they had peach I would've ordered that.  But anyway, it was the perfect place for our kind of party, and the waiter was very friendly and accommodating.  Would definitely consider it as a future go-to for dinner in Chinatown.

This is one of the better U.S. airports with a nifty little tram system and good restaurant offerings, sculpture, and stores. Convenient. Free shirt term parking to pick peeps up. Cell phone lot. Post office out by the airport with a passport office. Some international flights.

Very impressed with the service and food for our group of 8 (supposed to be 12 but 4 people bailed) on a busy Saturday night.  French Onion Soup was perfect - not too salty and not too greasy.

Others enjoyed burgers, veggie quesadilla (loaded with 'shrooms) and guacamole (very good).
Fried calamari is not my thing but the table enjoyed it.

Prices seem to have risen a bit - but it was never "cheap" here.
A great selection of beers of all sorts.  Decent (but pricey) cocktails  ($9 - $13).

I came to Bartaco on their first Friday night open with a group of 10 people. We called ahead (you can call 30 minutes ahead to be put on their waitlist) and it was early (around 5:30ish) and were fortunate enough to snag a table before they got slammed. I definitely want to go back now that they have been open for a few weeks, but my first impression was as follows:

Tacos are good, but tiny and pretty plain. I felt like the tacos were basically meat and tortilla. The pricepoint is fair, but they are SMALL. Upside is that you get to try a lot of them in order to get full :)

Margaritas were really yummy. So were the guac and the corn.

It was HOT. As in, left dripping in sweat hot. And even the water they were serving us was room temp so we were dying. Service was pretty good. The whole "order on a sheet" thing was a bit confusing, and then they brought our group of 10's tacos out on big metal trays without any description of which was which, so it was hard to separate out for everyone to get their own.

I would definitely go back, especially for drinks and chips/guac. They handled the insane crowds pretty well, so I'm hopeful the service will continue to be good and get even better.

Definitely a place worth checking out.

I'm probably in the minority when I say I won't be back unless I'm taking people. The atmosphere is really cool and I love the idea of people ordering from different vendors, but I'm the type of person who values food over atmosphere. I rather go to a hole in the wall that is amazing than a trendy place with solid food (not even bad food, but solid food). Now, some of these places might have spectacular food, but until I discover that, I won't be seeking out this place (and I will rely on Yelp reviews in half a year or so to determine whether there is a place I really need to try).

That being said, heck yes if I have a visitor from out of town I will take him/her here. I have friends visiting and this was my first thought for food. It's different and when I want to showcase the best of Tampa Bay, I will come here. The view of the river is gorgeous and the décor of this place is beautiful. Also, I don't have to worry about people finding something they like because there are so many options.

We came at about 7:30 p.m. on a Saturday which is prime eating time. Luckily we were still able to find a table. We wanted to eat outside and those were all taken. This place does parking so well! It could have been a complete hassle, but instead it was smooth sailing. Yes, some of the parking attendants didn't seem to care too much about directing traffic, but the lot is so huge that once I was pointed in the right direction I didn't really need anything else. 

There was a live DJ spinning and it added to the trendiness of the place. My husband commented that he's never seen so many hip people in his life in Tampa Bay. They all come out of the woodworks to come here. 

This is a must see when you're in Tampa and I am glad that we have this new addition to the city.

I used to go to a Stawberry Shortcake store in the spot where Cuenelli's Rotisserie Chicken now stands. Intrigued by it's appearance when my family took me there, I was excited to try their food and see what it had to offer.

They have some dishes that made my mouth water just at reading them such as Bisteck a lo Pobre, but since it was around lunch time and my appetite wasn't too large I decided instead to try ordering a burger with french fries instead.

It was delicious! The burger was nice a juicy, the bun they use on it tastes great, and they don't overload the burger with too many toppings. The size of the burger was pretty big too, though it's not as cheap as say McDonald's or Steak N Shake. You pay for quality though. The french fries were tasty as well, more like homemade fries than the kind found in fast food places, yet tastier than those made by places such as The Cheesecake Factory or Ruby Tuesdays. 

My parents ordered Papa a La Huancaina and devoured it upon receiving it, my Mom citing it's excellent taste, and she's has tons of experience with Peruvian food so I'll take her word for it. 

The waitress was friendly and quick to pick up drinks and get our orders in. The place is small, but exactly what you would expect an authentic startup restaurant to look like. I'll certainly be back to try the Bisteck a lo Pobre in the future. 

Also: They have Inca Kola! Yum.

Cool space with lots of parking, but I wasn't too impressed with the food I tried there, and they need to figure out a way to standardize food delivery to customers so that groups can order from different vendors and not have to wait separately for it to be delivered. Maybe have pagers?  Or optional table service?

Vegetarians can have a great meal here. I loved the veggie tacos on a corn tortilla with grilled peppers, red onion, sweet potato & fresh avocado. Black beans were flavorful & complimented the tacos well. I came with an appetite and ravished the complimentary chips & salsa dip.

Todd's service was exquisite and Margaritas were a real winner! The space was group friendly with booths, table tops & full bar. Plenty of parking for your convenience. Sarah S. rarely disappoints; glad this location made the ISC cut before closing.  

~Christy

Phenomenal restaurant but I little pricey for the portion size-but if every menu item is under 500 calories, I wouldn't expect large portions. You definitely leave full, just not uncomfortably full and no leftovers. 

Their sea scallops are great and the pearl cous cous served with it has lots of flavor. 

The mini dessert shooters are perfect-just the right size to satisfy your sweet tooth.

Perfection.

I've been twice now. The first time was for a business lunch, and I spotted M. Night Shyamalan with a crew scouting out the interior for a movie. 

Every time I have been here, it's literally like a fairy tale. This is the kind of place that you want to bring out of town visitors on a beautiful spring day. They'll want to move to Philadelphia, seriously. The servers are on point and very attentive, friendly and oh so nice.

Even with a sort of large group, nothing was amiss. I started with a cafe Americano, segued into a coffee, and then tucked into my main dish - the chicken country club, which was just about superb. It just needed a tiny flurry of salt. 

PRO TIP:  Patco users need to get off the 15th and 16th and Locust stop (the very last one)

Bernini is such a beautiful classic place. We came here before our fun music event down the street at Ritz Ybor. We sat in a perfect spot on the 2nd floor which has a nice view of below as well as the decorative classic painted ceiling. It is a work of art. 

It worked out perfect because we were there during their 1/2 price pasta & entrees & $2 martinis time. That is every day between 4 and 7pm. We ordered a veal chop and the pork osso buco. I also tried three martini flavors - coconut, mango, and chocolate. All had outstanding flavor, and was a really good size serving with risotto.  Coconut was definitely my most favorite martini. Our server suggested that, and she was absolutely right.  Lastly our dessert which was tiramisu was the best, and a perfect cherry on top!

Bernini is one of the places on Ybor that reflects the history of the city. It was built in the early 1900's and the second floor shows off the old Bank of Ybor vault, and the bar area is where the teller line was. It was also a floral shop in the 1950s. Hard to believe.

So happy we tried Bernini. It's a fun place for any occasion!
Was dragged here by in-laws. Have very little to say except, dirty, rude servers, mediocre food, your basic cuban place unfortunately.

Mother's Day madness, at the newest Yummy House. They took some reservations & left some open tables for walk in customers. Parking is tight, but they had valet for the occasion & all women got a rose, nice touch.
I was amazed by the bright exterior of the building! Inside is industrial, minimalism meets a bit of Chineese.
White tablecloths & napkins, chopsticks, a fork & even a modern condiment holder.
The menu is huge with so many entrees, I have not seen them offer before, like frog, dinnerr bowls & a wide array of desserts along with the usual suspects.
They handled the onslaught of people with perfection & professionalism. Our waiter TY was personable, knowledgeable & a great server! 
Pot stickers were great as usual as was the house fried rice. The duck was a bit disappointing: between fighting the bones & grease, it had no real flavor. The Mongolian Beef was good, but not enough green onions & the sweet & sour pork was spot on.
So happy to see another Yummy House, been missing Waters Ave. location.
What's a girl to do? Gotta support your local fave spots!

A nice bar to go to in the warmer months, the entire front of the building opens up on the second floor, giving it a porch like quality.  The bar was pretty small, but we were able to find a seat quickly.  I like the look of this place, its very comfortable and I like the tree in the middle of the room.  

We were only there for a quick drink while we were waiting for our table elsewhere, so I can't say anything about the food.  Their draughts were good enough, I didn't particularly like the pumpkin beer that I ordered, but there were a couple things that I hadn't tried before.  

I'd be interested in going back and staying for a bit longer, for now it gets a solid 3 stars.

Listed below are the items that I have consumed at Village Whiskey, from least amazing to most amazing, done in the style of a horoscope.

Duck Fat Fries - You will find yourself too thick cut to appeal to some people today.  Beware, for your trust in your house made ketchup may not be able to salvage your texture.

Soft Pretzels - The stars are moving and you struggle to keep up.  Understand your place as a damn good serving of soft pretzels but don't try to steal the limelight from your compatriots.  Bide your time until improvements can be made before trying to tackle your enemies.

Herb Cherry Tomatoes - Approachability is a double edged sword.  Though people find you easy to approach, they may find you too delicious if that is even possible.  Stay away from people who will die if they find something very delicious because you will kill them.

Truffle Lemon Artichokes - You are less approachable than the Herb Cherry Tomatoes but everything else in its horoscope applies to you.

Tater Tots - You've finally achieved your goal of making people rethink what a tater tot should taste like.  Take the time to appreciate this but don't get caught up in self-admiration.  Apathy will breed contempt and you must move on to the next life challenge.

Spicy Popcorn Shrimp - You must move quickly because everyone will want a piece of you.  You are served with a delicious buffalo aoli that has made you a prime target for attack.  Keep your head down, lest you be ravaged by the horde.

Village Burger with Caramelized Onions and a fried Egg - You are served on an ideal sesame roll and are probably the best tasting burger in Philadelphia.  Take time out today to revel in your greatness, but remain humble.  Arrogance will breed strong competitors.

--
Seriously, Village Whiskey gets 5 stars based on the basic Village burger alone.  The only burger I've ever had that is better than this was at Burger Bar in Las Vegas.I will probably go back one day and splurge on the Whiskey King, an 8oz. burger with maple bourbon glazed cipollini, rogue bleu cheese, applewood bacon, and foie gras for $24.

I have driven past this TBBCW a few times and wondered what it was. Was it just a brewing company, or was it food too? Since the husbeast and I were both out and about, we decided to stop in and check it out.

The evening was absolutely mild, so we opted to sit outside in the bar patio area. With the fire tables and the over head bulb lighting, it was fun and festive. And of course, it was just beautiful at sunset.  Our waitress was perfect, she was quick, friendly and informative, and I especially loved her backward written tattoo. Great message to one's self. 

We ordered our drinks and placed our order for Hummus and Lebeneh with naan. It's been AGES since I've had Lebeneh - a tangy goats milk cheese with a yogurt like consistency, that's absolutely decadent to the tongue. I was Thrilled that they had some and even happier that it was well made and came with a really flavorful hummus. The naan was crispy perfection. 

The husbeast ordered a steak and bacon chop salad, and I ordered the Rat something shepards pie, with a side salad,  the side salad... I should have stopped there, it was HUGE. A meal in itself.  I couldn't finish it, so it went into a box.  The meals themselves were tasty and good. Both portions were large and yes. VERY VERY yummy. 

Will we be back? Sure will!
Easy to get to from the freeway. Lots of cabs around if you need them. Can also use Uber or Lyft if you'd rather. Easy in and out. Check in was efficient. Decent airport all in all.
The staff is very friendly and helpful. Of course don't forget to stop by at the sampling tables near cheese area and another one by the dairy. The line can be very long but it moves really fast.

Dear Trader Joe's:  My love affair with you is over.  You've become too much hassle for not enough payoff.  

It starts with that ridiculously small parking lot, in one of the most congested areas of Tampa.  Seriously - Dale Mabry and Swann?  I think the only busier area you could have picked would have been Malfunction Junction.  Just the thought of dealing with that traffic nightmare is what keeps me away most days.  

You used to at least have produce & fresh flowers as redeeming qualities, but even that is not a sure-thing now - my flowers bought on Thursday were dead by Sunday, and selling your apples, tiny plums, etc. for $.79 *each* is crazy.  And don't even get me started on your blueberries - which I found at Whole Foods for quite a bit cheaper. 

And yet, I still have addictions to feed, like your Wasabi Roasted Seaweed Snacks, pork dumplings, and your ginger & lemon cookie thins.  So, occasionally, I will brave your tiny store, overloaded with pushy people and their demolition derby style shopping cart steering, maneuver my way through your narrow aisles with your partially stocked shelves, in search of my few must-haves.  And then I will battle my way to your awkward checkout lines, fingers crossed that this will be the one time a manager won't have to be called over to ring up alcohol for the person in front of me, and I'll get through the line quickly.  Fortunately, your cashiers remain a shining star in an otherwise mediocre experience. 

Then finally, I will spend five minutes trying to exit your insane parking lot after being trapped in it by cars from both directions trying to enter - all the while vowing to drive down to the Sarasota store next time.

Have been there lots of times, and just did not review.  Like other reviewers, love the store, many unique items, and usually low prices.  Also agree that the single largest negative is the inadequate parking.  Having staff directing parking helps show they care but cannot create more slots.  So my answer is to time visits with low traffic, mostly weekday mid-morning or afternoon and/or acquire a handicap and blue tag.

Datz has few thing on their sleeve that attract the customer to come back. We were here at the Wednesday night, the place still pack at 9 pm. We have group of Yelpers gather here that night. The place is jam packed. 

Datz label themselves as a pokegym. You can score point for your team when you check in here for Pokemon catch. 

I have the beer with nitro  (forgot what name) and the Pork Shank Redemption. The beer come with right temperature not too chill but cold enough. The meal come out about correct timing. My dish is huge. It is a big Shank and decorated the Rosemary on top of the bone. It was braise properly with maple bourbon glaze out side. Very tasty on the exterior of the meat. Ii accompanied with the mash potatoes that make this dish filling. 

We have good time there,  food is good, service is good. Close out and paid bill is quick.

There are a lot of reviews for this restaurant. We were here because of popularity. Pappy started since 2008 and get a lot of attention Nationally. Food Network has rank them number 1 in US. 

They are using Apple wood smoke with dry rub ribs. This rib cook for long time and you can see the rib meat fall off the bone. We got full slab with with sweet potatoes fry and the ear of corn. The sweet potatoes fry is crispy and good flavor. The rib is fantastic. Although is is most popular but not need to kill over it. 

The restaurant move the line quick by taking order and the seating after order. The entrance is strange from the back. The service is good considering this is busy restaurant. They are not the best to my opinion but still very good in St. Louis.

Not only did I go in the wrong SugarFire door for our UYE organized by Sandy -- first, I went into the wrong establishment. Whoopsie, Dumbo!!

So, I went into the wrong SugarFire door. Whoopsie, Dumbo!! But it was an accomplishment, even though the door was clearly marked EXIT ONLY -- but I saw no other door. 

Then I sat at the table for a number of minutes before I realized everybody in our UYE group was just getting into the cafeteria-style line to meet up at the table. Whoopsie, Dumbo, again!!

So I got in line, somewhere close to the soda machine. Many people were getting their beverages right there. I didn't do that, 'cause I didn't know if I was getting a meal that included beverage.

The line moved fairly quickly. I was amazed at the number of offerings, especially sides, that weren't on the website. So, I was stupefied and needed at least 90 minutes to figure out what I was getting.

While in line, a sign on butcher paper was posted that they were out of brisket. The woman behind me was getting a carryout for brisket, and she was devastated.

But, as we approached the front, it was clear that they still had brisket. But only 10 pounds, so they were anticipating being out. That sign should be posted much earlier in the trek through the cafeteria line . . . as should all the additional offerings, so people can make up their mind what they want.

I ordered half a rack of baby back ribs. Comes with two sides and a beverage for $14.

The woman in front of me was curious about the truffled root veggie salad, and so was I. She asked for a sample, and was gladly offered a generous sample. She said it was too mayonnaise-y for her. I was in.

For my other side, I got the much-proclaimed macaroni and cheese.

So this total cafeteria style thing works like a conveyor belt. Order your meat first. It's put on a butcher paper lined baking sheet. Goes on top of the sneeze guard and moves down to the "sides" section. That's where you get your red-and-white containers of sides.

Then you pick up your tray and go to the pay station. I had to ask if this was where you pay. And I was so ensconced with paying for my meal that I totally didn't see the pickles, onions and peppers.

I got my beverage at the beverage station in front of the store. So there are two, and I didn't have to battle through the waiting crowds to get the Lucky Club Zero-Calorie cola, which was divine. And I must have gotten at least six refills.

It looks like all the beverages available are local. Lucky Club is from Breese, Illinois. YIPPEE!!

The Food:
The ribs were fabulous; I ate two and took the rest home.

Sandy offered a piece of her brisket, and it was great. Smoky tender. Moist (not a word I use, 'cause it's my most hated word). Pull-away good.

The truffled root veggie salad was OK. BUT I took it home, and it was MUCH, MUCH better appropriately chilled. It was simply white potatoes, sweet potatoes, celery, green onions, white onions and mayonnaise. I do not claim to understand the truffle concept. But this was a GREAT salad CHILLED.

The macaroni and cheese was small shells and gloopy. BUT I took it home, and it was MUCH, MUCH better appropriately heated.

I had hefty to-go vessels. And I asked for pickles. She put four in a container. I ate two, then went back for more to pack into my container. Those pickles were AWESOME!!

Message to SugarFire: CHILL your salads, HEAT your sides appropriately. You must know how good they are when managed well!

And thanks, Sandy, for organizing this UYE, and getting a table reserved for us all!

Why 5 stars? Because how did I wait so long?

   ---   ---   ---

Bernini is one of those places that I'm shocked I had never written a review for. While I hadn't visited recently, I definitely had a few experiences here when I used to work in Ybor, pre-Yelp.

After discovering the magic of the Tortolleni Carbonara at a recent Yelp event, I could not wait to indulge on a full portion, and it did not disappoint.

I would definitely like to return to Bernini to try out a ton of different items, but it will definitely be tough to avoid just resorting to that dish every time :)

My old company had a private party on their 3rd floor, which is like a secret room, and I have to tell you - it's so amazing up there. If you ever have a chance to book an office outing, you need to call Bernini and give that a shot!

One of my favorite dim sum options in Tampa Bay.

I would even go so far as to say this was my favorite dim sum restaurant in Tampa Bay, but I have to preface that by saying I am not a fan of dim sum in Tampa Bay on a whole. Both my parents were raised in San Francisco so all my extended family lives there. I would visit multiple times a year growing up and now my sister lives in L.A. so I still travel at least once a year to the West Coast. I wouldn't call myself a dim sum expert, but I do have a bar set that might be a little above the average person. Do not come here expecting San Francisco (or New York, or Shanghai, or even Sydney, random fact, Sydney has fantastic dim sum which they more often refer to as yum cha) level dim sum, but do come here expecting a rather tasty meal.

Like the other Yummy House (not the one that burned down, but the one on Hillsborough), even though there are carts coming around, you'll want to order off the menu. You will starve if you think you can wait for the carts. We ended up seeing maybe a total of three carts the entire time we were there. Unfortunately, the only dishes you can order off the dim sum menu are the special dishes at the bottom. Otherwise, you have to wait for the cart. This is why we never got shumai (pork dumplings), we never saw it on the cart! There were four of us and this is what we got.

Salt and Pepper Chicken wings (off the menu) - Yummy House does salt and pepper dishes very well. I've always been a fan of their squid and tofu and their chicken wings are no exception. They have a sweetness to the seasoning that complements the saltiness really well. This was one of my favorite dishes.

XOXO noodles (off the dim sum menu) - I enjoyed the noodle texture, but there wasn't enough sauce. This was my husband's favorite dish, so to each their own. I would have really enjoyed it if it had more sauce.

Chinese broccoli (off the dim sum menu) - I thought this dish was done well. It was crunchy, tasty, and had just enough oyster sauce drizzled on it. I'd get it again.

Seafood Congee (off the dim sum menu) - This dish was very bland. I had to add salt and pepper to give it some taste. There were good chunks of fish in it. I probably won't try it again.

Chinese doughnuts (off the dim sum menu) - One of my dining companion loves eating this with congee. I thought it was good, but can you really screw up fried dough? (Don't answer that because sadly the answer is you can really screw up anything.)

Shrimp dumplings (off the cart) -  Same dining companion as above said the skin was too thick (he grew up in San Fran, recently lived in Shanghai, and would probably call himself a dim sum master). I really liked it. I've had some bad shrimp dumplings recently and this one was a welcome relief. The shrimp was cooked well.

Crab and shrimp dumplings (off the cart) - Same thoughts as the shrimp dumpling. The crab gave it enough of a different taste from just shrimp. I would get it again.

Pork buns (off the cart) - Couldn't try it since I don't eat pork, but my husband said he could eat three of these himself.

Tripe (off the cart) - I thought this was really tasty. I'm a huge tripe fan. It wasn't cut too thick or chewy. I would get it again.

Egg tarts (guy walking around with it) - It was nice and flaky. It had a good flavor. I would get it again.

Everything above came out to about $64 not including tip. I found that reasonable for Tampa Bay Dim Sum (this isn't the dirt cheap dim sum you can find in San Fran). Huge tip, make a reservation. Shocking, I know, that they take reservations, but that meant we were seated right away even though there was a 20-minute wait.

This Airport has certainly improved its Security screening area. That combined with the fact that its always pretty clean makes it better than many of the airports I've been to in the US. There is plenty of dining before your flight too. The gate areas are really where its most inefficient, requiring long hikes to your gate, down long hallways. I feel like I'm always leaving from gate Z-99.

I discovered after my last visit to "Saigon Deli" that it had moved, and I accidentally went to the imposter store.

I corrected this mistake and went to visit its new location.  I have to say, the new place is bigger and has easier parking, but getting there is a bit of a pain, and the new location has nowhere convenient to wait for take-out that doesn't interrupt the flow of the waiters in and out of the food prep area.

I went with my standards: the combination meat banh mi and the avocado boba.  I also tried the egg rolls for the first time.

The egg rolls are crispy but sort of blah.  If you want something fried, go for it, but if they aren't fresh (mine clearly had been sitting out for at least 20-30 minutes), don't bother wasting your fat calories.

The sandwich is as awesome as ever.  So is the avocado boba smoothie, which is still made from fresh avocado.  This place honestly makes the best boba I have ever had.

Sadly, I found that the service is not as good at this new location.  I ordered take-out, and I had to wait quite a while for my boba.  It didn't help that the woman makes two orders of boba at the same time, and when she made mine, she immediately delivered it to the wrong table, so I had to wait for her to make yet another serving of avocado boba (I didn't want the powdered taro boba the guy who drank my drink originally ordered).  I know this place prides itself on fast service, but it's better to check your orders and be right (and take an extra 10 seconds per order) than to get the wrong food to the wrong person quickly.  I ended up late for my meeting because of that serving error.

I had such a lovely lunch at this gorgeous French cafe when I was in Philadelphia, and I'm so glad we chose this charming spot. It was a freezing cold December day and this place served as the perfect place to catch up, drink great coffee, enjoy a relaxed atmosphere, and also score some great food.

As far as the coffee goes, I don't think you can lose -- I went with a cappuccino and it was really well done. 

For lunch I ordered the curry chicken salad sandwich that's made with avocado, green grapes, and toasted almonds. It was one of the best sandwiches I've had in a long time, and the portion size was perfect. The brunch menu also looked amazing and I would love to come back and try that on my next trip!

Don't pass this place up... you won't regret your visit.

For meat lovers, this is heaven....and hell for vegans.   This is  very fancy, high-priced meat palace of the Brazilian/Argentinian parrada mode.  We waited for a Groupon deal and finally visited.  Highly impressive interior decor, elegant modernistic.   Service was extremely attentive but they honored the red/green signaling devices given to each patron.   And if you have the "green side up" you get a constant flow of varied grilled/roasted meats...many cuts of beef, plus chicken, pork and sausage.  All were well seasoned & prepared and you could get some variation in the degree of rare/well-done by directing the slicing.  The top sirloin was the best to my taste, but filet mignon and parmesan pork were also notable.

 They also offer a salad bar only option at a lesser price, and the selection is also impressive...many cheeses, unique greens, hams, sausages, shrimps, salmon,  potatoes, pickles, heart of palm, and about 4 soups, including a marvelous lobster bisque.  So even with the salad bar you get a full range of dishes, including plenty of meat & other protein. Special South American/Tropical  drinks were available & delicous, including several caprinhas (sp?), a Brazilian specialty.

This outlet is located on Boy Scout, which is the wiggle between W. Columbus and Spruce headed to the Airport......the same stretch that houses Outback Headquarters and several of its chain restaurants....Selmon's, Flemings & Roy's.  So it is a bit of an "in your face" challenge of fine foods at premium prices for tourists & upscale diners (or those temporarily upscale due to Groupon).  That is OK, since neither my wallet nor arteries could handle frequent visits.

A second meal at Talula's Garden was enjoyable, though I still believe four stars is appropriate. While some items soar, others leave me wanting. And at prices like Talula's, I'd hope for my socks to be knocked off. That said, the place certainly doesn't hurt for business. We saw a two top get turned away for not having reservations on a notoriously slow night. So people are clearly loving the place. 

As was the case last time, the restaurant's decor was warm and comfortable, and service was perfect. We started with a fall cheese plate, which was really nicely done. The mushroom soup looked beautiful, but the creamy broth lacked the rich flavor I expected. 

My skirt steak entree was very good, with vinegary cipollini onions, broccoli and crispy potatoes. One thing I will say about Talula's is that the portions are generous. I couldn't finish my entree. 

For dessert, we shared the fig pudding, which is topped with butterscotch sauce and served with goat cheese ice cream. It's not the prettiest dessert, but on first taste I was absolutely hooked. One of the better desserts I've had in a while.

This is a very charming establishment with a variety of clever ways to show their ice cream.  They go to four stars from three because of the server's excellent moustache.

Go for the ice cream, stay for the 'stache.

I've been to Talula's Garden twice so far and the food has been nothing short of [fancy-descriptors-for-"wonderful"-insert-here].

I shamefully have not yet dined in the pretty outdoor section yet, however, due to rain and cold. Two good reasons to sit inside, yes? Plus, an excuse to return someday!

Highlights since TG has been reviewed many times over already:
- USA cheese plate. Geeeet a cheese plate... any cheese plate! You will not regret this decision. Oh my goodness, delicious.
- Chicken. Sounds boring, but their take is so tasty. This is some juicy stuff, and the accompanying sides are usually quite good too. Last visit, they were olives and potatoes.
- Peppermint tea. What a great way to end a meal! Cozy atmosphere + a cup of hot tea. So nice.

TG is expensive as heck, but it owns up to its rep, that's for sure.

Florida Aquarium is located nearby to the Tampa Bay cruise port, so I can see how it can be convenient for those travelers. It looks quite beautiful from the outside. From the inside, this aquarium is one of the smaller aquariums I have been to. 

This aquarium is quite organized and in sections depending on the environment each sea animal is accustomed to. I think this place is a pretty good place to go when one also has to be inside due to either the extreme summer temperatures we may have, as well as when it is super rainy out. 

When it is beautiful outside, my favorite space is outside where they have a nice tropical place to hang out and an area for the kids to play.

They often have different events going on throughout the year. For example, they have a New Years Eve party that I'd love to go to one year. Just check out their website.

They also often have discount days so check that out as well. For example, they often honor our military with discount family days.

Call 314-647-3800 now and make your reservation for dinner. You will be totally amazed. 

Kevin continues to amaze me and the entire city with his creations. He was totally deserving in his Food & Wine Best New Chef 2011 honor. 

Last night three of us were dining and sharing. I love sharing small plates, it allow you to experience so much more. Last night the menu had 14 featured items and we shared 9. Some missed their photo opportunity, because we just begun eating soon as it arrived. 

Blue Plate Salad - their standard house salad. Always a hit. Hey, Kevin let's bottle that dressing to sell. 

Grilled Asparagus Salad - I love asparagus and when combined with mixed greens, goat cheese and grilled ramp Caesar dressin' you have my attention. 

Roasted Mushroom Salad - The best salad of the three. Greens, goat cheese, toasted pecans and warm bacon vin. We were all scrambling for the last bite. 

Conch Fritters - So good we did it twice. 

Beet Risotto - I'll remember it always from the stain on my shirt. 

Escolar - Dill and butter poached, grilled Pacific Blue prawns and asparagus. The fish melted in your mouth like the butter that it was poached in. The asparagus was two green & one white - I grabbed the white - best ever. 

Grouper - My surprise - best entree of night. Slow roasted with mashed potatoes. We told both tables next to us, to order it. They did and agreed. 

Bacon Wrapped Meatloaf - Bacon, Meatloaf and sweet & yukon gold potatoes smashed. Enough said. 

Dry Aged Ribeye Grilled - meat was perfection. Again smashed potatoes and asparagus - hot damn. 

They offered five desserts, we shared three. By this time I was in food heaven and wine bliss. I remember the basil ice cream taking my breath away and wanting to not share the chocolate. Katie what are you going to dream up next? 

On my Yelp profile I have changed my last meal to "dinner @ Farmhaus".

Why 5 stars? Because the hype was big, but the product delivered.

   ---   ---   ---

Is this the most hyped a restaurant has been in my near-decade in Tampa? If it's not #1, it's at least on Mount Rushmore. And sometimes hype can lead to over-hype, which is no fun for anyone involved.

But over-hype didn't happen. Goody Goody delivered. Big time.

I moved to Tampa Bay in 2007, a couple of years after Goody Goody closed down. To be honest, I'd never even heard of it. But I think the idea of resurrecting of an old, beloved brand is absolutely amazing. That being said, I knew nothing about Goody Goody, before my visit this weekend. I actually thought it was primarily a burger place. Boy, was I wrong.

It's hard to truly classify Goody Goody. It's like an upscale diner, but still very casual. When I say upscale, I strictly mean in quality of food. This is far from Waffle House. But the menu is wide and varied - they did a great job creating a menu that tempts me to come back at least a dozen times to try everything. 

But on our first visit, we ordered two POX Cheeseburgers, fries, onion rings and mac-n-cheese. For dessert I grabbed a slice of butterscotch pie and a cafe con leche to help me awaken from my food coma.

Everything ranged from good to great. In terms of the burgers, I think Goody Goody will be Tampa Bay's version of In-N-Out. It's not like an In-N-Out burger, but it's very addicting in its own way. I could definitely see these burgers having a cult following. 

I actually didn't want onion rings, but my fiance thought they looked great in the photos, and decided to order them. This was an excellent choice - they were the best I've ever had. Sometimes onion rings are so heavily breaded/fried, that they sit in my stomach like a rock afterward. Not the case with these bad boys!

The fries were far from basic - thick and seasoned, just like I like 'em! And the mac-n-cheese had little bits of ham in it. It tasted simple but delicious.

The butterscotch pie was indeed sweet, but that's what dessert is supposed to be, right? The cafe con leche (from Naviera!) was as amazing as expected.

The interior of Goody Goody is exactly as you'd expect - the classic diner look, revamped and modernized. It's not a a very large place, which definitely leads to some long wait times. But I have a solution for you!

*****Here's the most crucial PRO TIP I've ever offered*****

Download the No Wait app (just recently purchased by Yelp), put your name on the list a couple hours before you want to eat, keep tabs on the wait time, and show up when it tells you to. You can completely bypass all the craziness and waiting!

I'll be back here. A lot. Thanks to the Gonzmart family and everyone else involved for bringing this local treasure back to life!

The Good Dog burger is definitely the burger to order: stuffed with blue cheese and topped with caramelized onions on a toasted brioche bun.  The cheese leaks through so be sure to soak it up with the accompanying fries.  The only downside is that the burger itself can be on the dry side but the cheese filling helps to mitigate some of that.  They were more than happy to give me all sweet potato fries rather than a mix, which was great since the sweet potato fries here are very good: crispy, slightly dense, and a bit sweeter than the other versions in Rittenhouse.   It's packed on the weekends but service is very quick.  Just be cognizant that the music can be VERY loud.

I have been enjoying Busch Gardens since the early 60's...when it was mainly just a brewery tour with bird show.  In my college years living nearby, buddies and I used to enter through the bird cages and get some free beer in the hospitality area...and then the beer was still brewed there. Then after the Serengheti Plains with more animals and rides were added, we took our kids there and it was a major thrill, but now quite equaling Disney for them. Adults appreciated the nature/animals emphasis more than cartoon characters and relentless promotion of Disney products.   
More recently we have not visited after kids have grown...and prices have sky-rocketed.  Nice you can get an all-year pass but not if you only want  to go once for old times sake.  So overall it is tops in memories and great as a Tampa tourist draw but not so much for repeat visits.

I had the pleasure of going to brunch with two HWK newbies a few weeks ago, and we were all blown away, so I have to update. First of all, I was dying to go after seeing the brunch menu had changed and had cornmeal pancakes on it. I love savory pancakes, so I just had to try them! I love how they change their menu. It really can hook you in when you see something that you HAVE to try. They keep it updated really well on their website, and you can also sign up to get the dinner menu in your inbox every week (it changes more often than brunch or lunch).

We started with mimosas (which also change seasonally). They had pear flavor and were some of the best (maybe THE best) that I had ever had. YUM. I should've ordered another. Dang. We also got the cinnamon bread. When it came out, I took a bite and realized that it was their version of this mythical "monkey bread" that my husband had talked about for years but I tried for the first time last Christmas. Rich and cinnamony, sugary, it melted in my mouth. I tried to contain myself as I shoveled it into my mouth and considered ordering a second order that I didn't have to share. Wow. So good. 

Then I got the pancakes. They were HUGE. After all those carbs with the bread, I could only eat one (and barely). Very yummy if you like cornmeal, which I do. It came with a cranberry butter, which made a nice sweet addition to the dish. All the while, my dining companions were raving about their food, which looked great.

Service was perfect, and as always, I greatly appreciate the visibility of Josh, the co-owner, who is so nice and makes the experience even better. Our meals took awhile to come out so they brought us a little taste of something we were admiring on the menu to tide us over (as if the cinnamon bread wasn't enough!)

Brunch is a good value for what you get. Make reservations, because it is popular!

If you haven't been there for brunch, and want to go, let me know because I'll go with you! But I will NOT be sharing that cinnamon bread - it's all for me!

CONSISTENCY!!!
I am blessed. I have finally become one of those stereotypical little old men in a Brooks Brothers blazer and Cole Haan penny loafers that has the good fortune to lunch at Commander's 2 or so times month. 

And it is always a delight. 

My biggest complaint with all these new bourgie self-entitled restaurants is that they don't have a consistently superior, competitively priced product delivered by an exemplary staff comparable to Commander's. And yet they demand its respect.

COMMANDER'S PRIX FIXE LUNCH IS THE GOLD BAR
by which my friends and I compare all newcomers. If a place can't consistently meet the quality for the value and festive experience at 1403 Washington, then pragmatically they shouldn't and don't get a second chance.
Good French Food & People Watching at Ritten House Square.

Line was moving a bit slow till Chef Kyle took over the first station. He was kicking butt filling orders and still being very friendly and charming. After the line was down he was out cleaning tables and checking on each table to make sure everything was great. Tuscan Wrap with crispy chicken and bacon is great. Pepperoni sticks are awesome always. Also love the Italian Lemon Tea. I think their prices have gone up a bit from last time. 2 wraps with chicken, two pepperoni sticks and 2 drinks close to 28$.  It is filling beats going to Fridays where everthing is fried not fresh and service is non existent.

Love this place! This is our favorite place to go for Valentines Day or a special occasion dinner. Great atmosphere. Recommend a reservation as it can get quite busy. They have a wine room where you can schedule tastings. Highly recommend their sweet red. I'm actually in their monthly wine club because of this wine. Wine club is such a great idea -- pay a monthly fee and you get a bottle of wine a month. Really supposed to be their wine of the month that you get but if you find one that you look be you can choose that bottle every month. Wait staff is always friendly and fast. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu -- even the kids menu is amazing. Highly recommend but not cheap.

I was happy to be able to enjoy a Ted Drewes cup of custard earlier today. While I did not visit Ted Drewes directly, a friend was able to find a few at a local shop and purchased a few of their cups to go to bring to our picnic today. Such a nice treat during a hot day! 

Pro-tip: If you are unable to visit the custard stand; you can certainly purchase these treats at some local retailers as they offer their 3 basic flavors; strawberry, vanilla and chocolate. All are portioned out and packed separately so they are easy to pass out during a pandemic. There is even a vending machine at the airport! 

The chocolate custard was so creamy and delicious; now I can't stop thinking about visiting Ted Drewes to pick up a concrete.

Omg!  Why haven't I been here before?  What took me so long?!?!  

This place is incredible. Moist, flavorful rotisserie chicken full of flavor. I do like YaYas but I'd take Cuenelli's any day. 

And the spicy yellow sauce served with it?  Out of this world. 

This restaurant is extremely clean and brightly decorated inside. The waitress was extremely helpful and gave me some guidance when ordering. I appreciate that I was allowed to sub my French fries for the cilantro rice. 

Now I know what all the yelp hype is regarding this place....I've experienced it and will def be back.

Lowry Park Zoo is so spectacular that it deserves it's own review -- separate from yesterday's Yelp event. The Tampa zoo has once again been voted #1 in the country by Parent's Magazine, and it's easy to see why. The zoo is quite large, and able to hold a number of visitors without seeming to be too packed. The walkways are wide enough to easily handle those double-wide strollers, and there is a great variety of wildlife on display in very natural settings. Lowry Park Zoo offers a number of animal interactions throughout the park, as well as special areas designed to amuse the happy little children.

Now I have to confess that I'm very jaded with my zoo reviews since I grew up with the National Zoo in Washington DC, the National Aquarium in Baltimore, MD, and spent several years enjoying the San Diego Zoo and Wildlife Preserve. That being said, Tampa's Lowry Park Zoo ranks right up there as one of the very best.

There must be something in the water at Lowry Park Zoo, because there sure were a lot of Zoo babies! We saw a brand-new baby African elephant born December 23rd, a baby Pygmy hippo born November 15th, two baby white tiger cubs, baby monkeys, and even a nest of baby egrets that were settled in a tree near a group of Duiker and Lesser Kudu. 

Our group of intrepid Yelp Elite explorers wandered past all of the primates, the aquatic center with manatee and stingrays, the s-s-s-s-s-s-snakes, Asian Gardens, African Safari, and the Florida Wildlife area. We manged to see the majority of animals, except for those that were enjoying an afternoon nap, and those we missed by taking a wrong turn here and there.

Single day admission to the zoo is about $25, or you can be smart and buy an annual pass for $60 per Adult. Children 3 - 11 are $20 per day or if they cry to much you have the option of feeding them to the lions (just kidding.....)

Terrific place to spend the afternoon!

Maggiano's, you are my husband's favorite restaurant in Indy. He is obsessed and is your biggest fan. I've therefore visited a handful of times and I'm not mad about it. 

Let's dish about the dishes: 

On the House Classic Pastas- They have a list of house pastas that if you order from, you also get to choose another entire dish from the menu to take home with you. Seriously awesome. This is the only restaurant I've been to that does this and it's definitely memorable. 

Lighter Take Chicken Parmesan- My absolute favorite. It's healthier than the normal Chicken Parmesan dish, and honestly is even more delicious. Win win! The chicken is only slightly breaded and the the sauce on the pasta is light and has fresh tomatoes mixed in. So wonderful. They have 'lighter takes' of several dishes which is nice to see health taken into consideration. 

Chicken and Roasted Pepper Flatbread- It was good, but it was a lot of one thing. I'd definitely get this more as an appetizer with a large group next time instead of my full meal! 

Lasagna- The dish my husband comes back for and thinks about in his dreams. Thanks for being his favorite dish in America so far! 

This place is well-run, huge and does efficient catering and pick-up as well.

My girlfriend needed to take a dessert to a dinner party that night.

Since we had just lunched at La Pizza Friday, May 13, we hauled west on Delmar to Jilly's.

She got two mini-cupcake packages for the dinner party. It was an assortment of small cupcakes -- perfect for a dinner party.

I went BOZO. Five cupcakes:

Space Monkey: cake is banana heath, filling is toffee dulce de leche, topping is caramel and cream cheese, topping is astronaut ice cream and chocolate bark

Strawberry Pie: cake is strawberry vanilla cake, filling is fresh strawberry pie filling, topping is strawberry buttercream with whipped cream and graham cracker crumbs

Chocolate Thunder

Reese's Chunkage

Turtle Cheesecake

They were all delicious. I had one bite of each, and I was done. Cupcakes don't need to be this big.

My favorites were Space Monkey and Strawberry Pie.

And I would have appreciated additional seasonal flavors, i.e., lemon or orange or blood orange. The flavor profiles offered were incredibly chocolate-forward.

Yippie! I get to give The Shaved Duck their 5th Star back. I'm a big fan of Burnt Ends and TSD has the best ones in the city and county. They smoke for hours, so they're only available after 5 PM. So I highly recommend that you get there right at Happy Hour, because chances are they may sell out. After hours of being smoked, they then toss'm in my favorite sauce - Black Isle. Pair these Burnt Ends with an ice cold craft beer and you've got the perfect start to a BBQ feast. (For some, it could be a meal) However, on this night, I pigged out and continued to eat. 

Seriously, I skipped lunch so I could totally pig out here at The Shaved Duck. After devouring my entire order of Burnt Ends. (I was dining alone, so no one to share with and I kinda liked it that way). Next I ordered the B.O.S.S., it was the "must order" recommendation from Ian Froeb on his STL 100 list this year. I couldn't wait to sink my teeth into the thinly sliced Tri-Trip, smothered in bacon swiss sauce and topped with onion rings. The sandwich came with one side, I choose the Hand Cut Fries. Being a huge fan of Brussels Sprouts, I also ordered a second side of them. In my old age, sprouts have become one of my two favorite vegetables. 

I sipped my Charleville Tornado Alley at the high top table in the front window of the bar area and waited patiently for my food. Soon I saw a young man different from my original server approaching with a tray of goodies. He first sat down my Sautéed Brussels Sprouts, then Hand Cut Fries with a Little Cup of Ketchup and finally my BIG sandwich. He smiled, told me to enjoy my food and walked away. When I took a closer look at the sandwich, there was no meat on it. It was a vegetarian sammie. Did I mistakenly order the wrong thing? I couldn't have, or did I. The young man re-entered the room and I waved him to him. When he came over, I told him I had ordered the B.O.S.S. and he quickly corrected the error. 

My server was going on break after she placed my order and was also ordering her own dinner to enjoy. It was a simple absent minded error, she ordered her sandwich as mine. They box up the mistake and let me have it as well. It made an excellent lunch at the next day work. The Brussels Sprouts, tomatoes, red pepper with a smoked habanero sauce was still full of flavor. 
When my server came back from break, she apologized deeply. I told her no worries and we had a good laugh at how it happened. 

Back to my original sandwich, The B.O.S.S. is totally the boss. The Tri-Trip was tender. The Bacon Swiss Sauce was finger licking good and the crispy onion rings gave it a crunch and additional flavor. My Sautéed Brussels Sprouts were done to perfection. They were done to the point that they were just soft enough, but still had a little snap to them. Then the hand cut fries, crispy coating and a hot meaty potato inside. If you follow my reviews, you know I love my ketchup served in little cups. So seeing it served that way here, made me smile. 

My "must order" is the Burnt Ends, so next time you are at The Shaved Duck - order them and enjoy. 

When: May 17, 2016
Why: Burnt Ends and Ian Froeb's STL 100

I experienced a super memorable Saturday night.  I started off at The Silver Ballroom, then off to Royale for a couple of drinks, then to Taste.  I've been to all three numerous times before, but have to add a few highlights because these places really deserve it.

I've never left this place sober... never ever.  Not that I've tried that hard to stay sober here.

The service has always been good for me.  The only downside is that the place can fill up and it's tough to find a seat.  Seating is more available in the summer when the patio is open.  Also, if you drink here before dinner, you're more apt to find a table or place at the bar.  

They have one of the best drinks I've ever tried... and it's so simple.  The dark and stormy. Gosling's Black Seal Rum, and Ginger Beer.  

Pulp fiction was playing on one TV and a Clint Eastwood movie on another.  With those visions in your head, how can you not walk around and think your a big shot?

The crowd is eclectic here.  A mix of hipsters and yuppies.  Not really in a bad way.  But people are more apt to keep to themselves here than other places.

I gotta admit this is a magical & beautiful spot for a wedding.  It was decorated in understated elegance and was the perfect backdrop for a marriage ceremony.  I always thought a beach wedding was the only way to go, but I am forced to rethink this after what I just participated in.
Truly a lovely, romantic and enthralling venue for this special event. Personally I am not a big fan of attending weddings, but I must say this event kept me captivated from being to the end. A special event, anyway you look at it.
What's a girl to do?  When you have to go to a wedding make the most of it.

The Refinery is a spectacular farm-to-table dining experience in Seminole Heights, and I am embarrassed to admit that I had not been there sooner.

A business associate and I made reservations for a mid-week dinner this past week, and we spent some time previewing the online menu before our visit. We knew that The Refinery changes their menu each week in accordance with whatever is fresh and available to the chef. As a result, my foodie friend Brian and I had a few choices in our back pocket and we were eager to give this place a try.

The Refinery sits along N. Florida Avenue a few blocks south of Hillsborough Avenue and across the street from Mauricio Faedo's Bakery. The Refinery looks like a typical Seminole Heights home with a downstairs kitchen and dining room, and upstairs full-service beer and wine bar and outdoor rooftop deck seating. We chose to sit downstairs, but next time I'd like to sit out on the balcony.

Given the eclectic and cozy nature of the restaurant, the menu is actually printed as your placemat on a wooden table. They make no apologies for chipped plates, mismatched silverware, and drinking from Mason jars, and go on to explain that they prefer to put the focus on the food and keep the prices reasonable. A meal here feels like a quirky dinner party in someone's home, and not a highfalutin white tablecloth / stuffy maître d' experience. 

Chef Baker talks about setting the bar high when it comes to what they put on the plate. If it wasn't grown in Florida or produced using ethically sound methods, you probably won't find it at The Refinery. They make sure each ingredient is of the highest quality and comes from folks who take great pride and care of their processes, employees, and earthly footprint. That mission statement is the essence of The Refinery.

Brian and I each had a glass of wine - his was the Estampa Chardonnay and mine was the Argentinian La Yunta Torrontes (excellent red wine!). We followed that with The Refinery's house salad made with very fresh mixed greens, braised radish, sliced strawberries, Cuban croutons, and a lime / shallot / tarragon vinaigrette.

For the main courses he ordered the Massaman lamb curry, and I had the roasted chicken which turned out to be half of a seasoned and roasted chicken served with a side of diced ham, collard greens, black eyed peas sitting atop halves of a buttermilk biscuit, and then covered with caramelized sweet onion jam and chipotle sawmill gravy. The meal was absolutely spectacular, and very much lived up to our expectations. Total bill was well under $100 for the two of us.

The Refinery is open 7 days a week for dinner starting at 5pm, and on Sundays they are also open from 11am - 2:30pm for brunch. Add this place to your "must try" list for Tampa!

I've been here six times, and I feel like I'm finally able to write a review. The problem has been that while there have been some big hits, there have also been some big misses. I was between 3 and 4 stars, but rounded up because I feel like service is usually good, cocktails are consistently great, and desserts have been a win every time.

I have had items here that are so amazing I can't stop talking about them - for example, they had a corned beef pho for St. Patrick's Day (which is now on their regular menu, I think) which was SO incredibly delicious, I could not stop raving about it.  Ditto on the s'more brownie they had the other day-outstanding.  The buffalo cauliflower was surprisingly excellent (it's bad for you, yet good for you!).  And I loved the Dachos - their version of nachos with chili, cheese, sour cream and onions on homemade potato chips-yum!

In the 'miss' column however: the other night they had a salad special-I don't have the exact description, but it was described as a salad with crabmeat, bacon, onions, etc.  Sounds great, right?  And it had an awesome presentation with the filling scooped into two gorgeous small heads of lettuce. I had filled up on the Dachos, so I only ate one lettuce head, and saved the other for the next day. Opened it up the next day, and was surprised to see the actual amount of crabmeat/bacon/onions filling - at most there were 2 teaspoons splayed across the top and inside the tiny crevice in the middle. No wonder all I tasted was lettuce the night before! I wish I had taken a picture of the salad once I had deconstructed it - I think I was just in shock that they would serve something like that.

I do love that they are constantly updating both their food menus and their cocktail menus - so it's pretty safe to order most things on their menu; they are the tried and true winner items. I would just show some caution with the specials of the day - some obviously still need work.

Final thought:  Datz - crank up your air conditioning - our entire party was fanning themselves with their menus the other night- not cool! (pun intended)

I finally had a burger at Village Whiskey. 

It was delicious. It was super expensive. I may have to keep a piggy bank to save specifically for my next lunch there. Allow me to elaborate: 

Village Burger [served on a sesame bun with lettuce, tomato and homemade Russian dressing (on the side for me) and a pickle] - $11
add Jasper Hill cheddar - $3.5
add smoked bacon - $2.5
add pickled long hots - $3 
add about ten miles on the treadmill - (free, with membership)

My burger quickly amounted to a whopping twenty dollars, and that was before adding on an order of duck fat fries with Sly Fox cheddar sauce on the side, shared with my dining companion. The meal, naturally, was over-indulgent and delicious. 

Lunch at Village Whiskey is definitely a splurge, not a once-a-week occurrence. Service is top-notch all around, and you'll feel like a baller with an expense account for an hour or so. You may even rub elbows with the likes of Gary Matthews at the bar, as we did the day of our visit.

Pro tip: All the single ladies should head on over around lunch time during the work week. The male:female ratio is approximately 10:1.

Excellent barbecue, but I would NOT brave a hour-plus long wait to dine there again.  Carry out is a possibility, because that line is shorter, but I've had barbecue in town I thought was just as good with less wait.

Busch Gardens is a great tourist attraction, with enough roller coasters and lines to keep you occupied for most of the day. The theme park experiences a very different number of visitors each day, so some days you may not have to wait at all for rides, then other days you may be waiting for an hour or maybe more time than that.

The season passes are a pretty good deal, but you will get tired of the rides pretty quick, and it's hot everywhere around this park, it's mostly outdoors. There's a big section for little kids to play in, the biggest playground I have ever seen. 

Service is pretty decent in the park and you really do not need to interact with workers too much, unless you are buying something to eat. The shows that they have are great for tourists or if you need to cool down under the air conditioning.

The food is delicious, but you'll have to fork over a ton of money for it. My favorite thing to get is the corn dogs and french fries in Timbuktu with a drink, which can total seven to ten dollars. They also have a restaurant inside this huge establishment that is pretty good, though still pretty expensive. They adopted an awesome buffet about a year ago.

The biggest attraction is the fairly new ride Sheikra. It is pretty exciting the first couple of times you ride it, especially the first time so don't miss it. Kumba and Montu follow in ride quality. The main thing people like about Montu is your feet hang so it feels different.

I'm bad, I just realized after all my visits to Pappy's that I haven't written a review on Yelp. Perhaps it is because of the saying, "nothing to write home about". I know Pappy's gets a lot of positive press and awards, but for me they are not consistent in producing their product. My visits have ranged from a stellar 5 star experience to a you should be ashamed of yourselves for even giving this food to a customer 2 star rating.  When Pappy's is good, he is damn good and that is what keeps me coming back hoping that they are on their A-Game the day I am visiting.

I was thrilled when Pappy's opened and was serving their Ribs as a Dry Rub with the sauce on the side. Many visits they have been done so well I haven't even needed to add any sauce, the dry seasoning was flavorful enough. 

My favorite things from Pappy's are the Beef Brisket and the Pulled Turkey. I have not experienced any other place that can beat the brisket here at Pappy's. When Smokin' Al's was open on Hampton many moons ago, I only enjoyed his pulled turkey. So I'm kinda glad Al is closed, because my loyalty would have flipped to Pappy. 

Now let's chew the fat about their sides:

Fried Corn on Cob - order it - eat it - it will wake up your Southern taste-buds. 

Potato Salad - As good as a New York Jewish Deli

Cole Slaw - Oil & Vinegar -  A healthy choice

Sweet Potato Fries - They still haven't mastered this side.

Baked Beans - Canned Bush's are better. Open a can and order one of the other sides. 

Green Beans - Good  & gets one of your daily green vegetables in for the day. 

Apple Sauce - Grandma smiles. 

When having a busy day at home or work our favorite E-Z Carry-Out is the #2. When doing a carry-out, there is no need to worry about the sauce, they give you plenty of all three. My personal favorite is the Sweet Baby Jane. I just hope she doesn't grow up to be like Betty Davis in, "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane". The Holly Hot Sauce, which is suppose to be Texas style would make any true Texan laugh. It is very mild. 

Patience is a virtue and it is one you need to have when visiting Pappy's. No matter what time of day I have visited, I have stood in a very long line. If a genie granted me an extra wish, I'd wish that Pappy's would expand so they could handle their large crowd of adoring fans more quickly.

My friend and I had never been to Alma De Cuba before so we decided to give it a try for restaurant week.

We were seated immediately at a table on the third floor. Our server was very attentive. My friend had brought up a drink from the bar but she promptly came over to greet us and check on my drink status. I went with the red sangria figuring it would go well with dinner. It was made with a brandy so a little stronger than the sangria that I'm used to. Nice!

So I went with the black bean soup for my starter. My friend went with the sea scallop ceviche. So my bowl of soup was large and filling and the ceviche was pretty tiny. The rice croquettes were a nice touch.

I went with the Vaca Frita as my main and it was fantastic! For one, the portion was huge. It was also flavor city. I'm not sure what the difference between Cuban oregano and regular oregano is but it did my steak wonders. The dish also included black beans, rice and tomato escabeche. Escabeche is apparently sweet and it gave a nice contrast to the meal. I would suggest going with a smaller appetizer, or skipping the appetizer altogether, with the Vaca Frita. I was quite stuffed by the end of my meal.

On the contrary, my friend ordered the Branzino and was disappointed by the size. Warning: the Branzino is not for the faint of heart. It comes complete with head and tail, which my friend so kindly hid from me behind her water glass.

For dessert I opted for the Alfajores, which isn't on their normal dinner menu. It consisted of dulce de leche, Mexican chocolate sauce and marshmallow ice cream. It was a very tiny portion and gave a nice amount of sweetness to end the meal. My friend finally got the larger portion with the Coconut Tapioca Pudding. She seemed to enjoy the enter thing. 

I'm really glad I finally got to try Alma de Cuba. I had a very solid meal and a good experience. For whatever reason, I wasn't absolutely blown away. I would absolutely go back but I'm in no rush.

Came here for a quick bite and drinks before heading to a show at the Underground Arts. For 7 o clock on a friday night it wasn't too crowded but we got the last table left. We started with the cheese platter which was interesting, there's some kind of fruit/nut chutney that was tasty; plentiful bread with the cheese. Then we got the fish and chips and for the price it was disappointing. There were 4 fish sticks and a couple fries. For the price I expected bigger pieces of fish and more fries. I would possibly come here again more for the drinks than the food

Am I the only St. Louisian who thinks Ted Drewes is just a little overrated? Just me? Okay. 

The custard is good -- not exceptional -- good. 

I'll give them credit for having exceptionally speedy service.

Why 4 stars? Because most of the food was fine but the service was great.

   ---   ---   ---

With each passing special occasion, my wife and I attempt to make our way through all of the higher end restaurants of Tampa Bay. We nearly came here for my birthday a couple months earlier, but opted to go to a place that we love instead. But this time around, we wanted to visit a new spot and both of us had always wanted to check out Ocean Prime

The meal started off nicely, as our table had rose petals scattered all over, as well as two complimentary glasses of champagne that ended up being quite delicious. I ended up ordering a second glass, I liked it so much.

We were both equally craving steak and seafood, so we opted to order both and our server was happy to make sure that the two items were evenly divided on each plate. We went with the 16oz ribeye and the dual lobster tails. 

For sides, many of them looked amazing, but we ended up going with the black truffle mac and the twice baked potato.

To be honest, everything was... fine. Nothing was bad, but none of it stood out as amazing. The steak was a bit unique with extra charr on the outside, but the flavor was just ok. The butter candle contraption was a nice touch, but the lobster just seemed a bit underwhelming. The mac-n-cheese and potato were on par with what you'd find at a Chili's.

But the 3-star review gets upgraded to a 4-star because our favorite part was the dessert and Ocean Prime comp'd it for our anniversary. Do not come here without ordering the Butter Cake. It was absolutely perfect.

The next day, we got a call from Ocean Prime, who just wanted to make sure we enjoyed our meal. That's certainly not necessary, but another nice touch on their part.

Grand total = $210 with tip. I think next time we have an occasion to celebrate, we'll head to another spot since the food did not overwhelm us (especially at that price) but it was an enjoyable experience, overall.

3.5 Stars

We visited on a Sunday for lunch, and were the first patrons of the day at noon.

I had the ceviche appetizer as my meal, and it was very good.  Nice and fresh tasting, with a hint of lime and hint of spice, and the red onions were not too sharp.  Served with the roasted salted corn kernels I love so much.

My BF had the 1/2 chicken with cilantro rice and spicy beans.  He loved the flavor of the chicken, although it was a bit greasy, but thought the beans were very 'boring'.  He said next time - he'll just have the chicken and be very happy.

Servers were very friendly, food came out quickly, and the Inca diet kola was a nice treat.

I had to raise my rating to 5 Stars after Friday nights dinner at Farmhaus.
Everything we had was totally off the charts. We had a blast sharing comments about our feast with the table of ladies next to us. 
Our table started out with Butternut Squash Soup, Roasted Mushroom Salad and Fish Chowder. I wish the bowl of Fish Chowder was bottomless, it was that amazing. The seared Tuna Steak Floating in the bowl was the best Tuna I have ever experienced. 
Our entree's were the Escolar and the Bacon Wrapped Meatloaf. Both melted in your mouth, with the Escolar getting the highest marks. I wanted to try the Blackened North Carolina Amberjack, but having a guest from Texas I wanted him to experience the "famous" meatloaf.
The desserts, let me just say I'll be doing extra laps around Tilles Park. 
Service at Farmhaus is incredible, they always friendly and make me feel special.
If you haven't gone to Farmhaus  I have only one question for you. What are you waiting for? When you go I recommend reservations, it's that popular.

The chocolate babka is awesome. Definitely get this. Loaded with chocolate goodness. Even better when it's served warm. The chocolate melts in your mouth as if you are eating brownies. 

There are a lot of varieties of gourmet cheese. Much cheaper than DiBruno's but you get almost the same quality. Perfect pairing with their crackers such as the fig olive crisp.

Bamba snack is very addictive, only 99 cents. Very light snack. It's basically a peanut butter version of cheese puffs. It melts in your mouth. You can easily eat the whole bag. Also good is the seaweed snack.

Why 4 stars? Because the consistency issues have been solved.

   ---   ---   ---

I think there was a rough time in the beginning where Ella's was somewhat new, and getting too popular, too quickly. As is the nature with many-a-hipster joint, it seemed that staff turnover was running a bit rampant, which is my guess as to why I had such a range of experiences at Ella's.

I've been back a few times lately, and seem to get generally the same solid quality each time. One of my favorite places atmosphere-wise, to eat in Tampa Bay, is the Ella's porch on a nice day. Ahhhh the zen.
Another great lunch here.  We usually end up with the burgers or the crab cakes.  They even have a rewards program for lunch.

It's been three long years (nearly four) since my last review of this place, so this is long overdue.

I went to Commander's for my birthday dinner last night and it was as amazing as to be expected.

Our main waitress was Evelyn and she was amazing and attentive. She made sure that we were taken care of and had everything that we could possibly need. The entire staff was on point and everything was perfect.

Looking over the menu, everything sounded so amazing and decadent. I decided to start with the turtle soup. Commander's is famous for their turtle soup and I have never had better in the city. It was full of amazing flavor and topped with sherry to add a little more kick. For my entree, I enjoyed the pecan crusted Gulf fish. This fish was cooked to perfection and topped with tender crab meat. It was served in a delectable cream sauce which complimented the flavors of the fish perfectly. For a side, I got the goat cheese stone ground grits, since I am on a tad of a grits kick. They were delicious, but I had to add a little more salt to them.
