I totally understand why they weren't salted and this wasn't a big deal. The grits were tasty and I really enjoyed them.

For dessert, I decided on the pecan pie- one of my favorites, topped with home spun vanilla ice cream. This sugary treat was the perfect end to this memorable meal.

At the beginning of the meal, I was asked if I was celebrating anything and when I told them it was my birthday, they added balloons to the table and brought me a chef's hat to wear. It was a nice touch and a lot of fun. They even put a candle in my pecan pie as part of the celebration.

There's a reason Commander's Palace is considered one of the best restaurants in New Orleans. From start to finish, you are made to feel special and you are given beyond the five star treatment. I will always return.

Moms.

I'd imagine that everyone who works in the kitchen is a mom at this restaurant.  I know that this is an absurd thing to imagine, but the food definitely tastes like it was made by moms.  They are all back there, talking about how proud they are of their kids, while creating good, wholesome food.

If you want a delicious brunch that tastes like it was made by a team of moms who really care about you(because you don't have one living with you anymore because you are a goddamned adult), then Day by Day is a great choice.

Their poached eggs florentine and potato pancakes benedict taste like they were made with a lot of care and you should eat them.  The stuffed challah french toast is next on my list of items to consume at this establishment.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is Under Siege.

Often when I start these reviews, I have to stop myself from writing lead-in sentences that say: "Oh, my goodness. This place is the definition of five stars." or "I'm in love."

This was one of those times. I refrained.

I made my inaugural Amada visit during this past Restaurant Week and thought it was a great deal. So, so much food! Let's see. What did I try...

White sangria: Ahead of my visit, Amada-veteran and my good friend Lindsay V. recommended I get this. Yep. On-point. This was one darn good drink. Whew.

Serrano ham: While this was a bit chewy, I think it was supposed to be a bit chewy. It was also very good and came on a huge plate. Wasn't it supposed to be a tapa? I guess a huge plate can be a tapa? I know nothing about tapas. Apparently "a tapa" isn't even grammatically correct, according to Yelp's spellcheck. So noted.

Manchego cheese with truffled lavender honey: I don't know what was better about this cheese. The actual amazing cheese (one of the greatest cheeses I've tried to-date), or watching Ashley S. lap up the lavender honey. Hers... and also my leftovers.

Goat cheese: Because one cheese was not enough. This was tasty.

Short rib flatbread: This mostly came home with me. It warmed up nicely the next day!

Chocolate torte dessert: Extremely rich and well-executed. Still not sure how I felt about the side ice cream, though.

Amada itself is beautiful and is tucked in a great part of town. I'm trying to think of a good closing line, but I'm going to instead just say: Go.

This is one of my favorite places to visit in Philadelphia.   Other cities have markets in their downtowns, but this is the gold standard.   Like other markets, there are a lot of food vendors here.   However, unlike other markets, it's HUGE and there are so many grocers here that you could actually do your weekly shopping here.

Sometimes, there needs to be a 6th star.

Is the joint extremely tiny and have a crappy dirt parking lot?  Yes, but they have an excellent carnitas torta that will keep your gut full for hours and tender & toothsome lengua taco.  Order them both.  Your life will never be the same.  Heed my words.

Now go!
The best roast beef poboy in the city.

Well hello there pulled pork sandwich.

I usually go here to just grab a glass of wine and hang out at the bar because it's such an oh-so-perfect spot on a cold day, but last night I went to Shaved Duck hungry. Very, very hungry. Like ready to eat two meals in one hungry.

My dinner started off with the Hush Duckies, and boy am I glad it did. These things are over-sized hush puppies but better... they are bacon & onion filled and served with a spicy dijon aioli. The sauce rocks! Get this app if you want something hearty... I think they taste even better when it's freezing outside.

My best friend got the duck breast for her meal, but to this day I still can't eat duck. I know, I know. The texture is just so strange to me and I guess I'm not adventurous enough, which pains me to say. I went with the pulled pork sandwich, and Shaved Duck definitely knows how to smoke some pork. The flavor and smokiness of the meat was so perfect that I barely needed the carbs that were underneath it. They smoke it for about 20 hours.

Aside from the pork, the real stars of this meal were the sides! I had the mac'n'cheese, and though I've had a lot of mac'n'cheese dishes all around St. Louis, this one is a runner up for the best of them all. The shell noodles were big and perfectly cooked, and the cheese was so rich and creamy. It was all topped with some delicious crunchy-ness, and was the perfect side for my pulled pork. My best friend had mashed potatoes with her duck, and we both wished we had more of them.

Moral of this story is that I'm completely satisfied after my meal last night! Head here for an intimate dinner with friends, some wine at the bar, or whatever you're in the mood for. They'll take care of ya!

I'm now fat and happy off of super cheap food. 

I'm pretty sure the most expensive thing on their menu is $8.50. Their banh mi sandwiches are $4 max! It's incredible. We got fried rice, Lemongrass Beef Vermicelli Salad, spring rolls, chicken noodle soup, two banh mi sandwiches, and two smoothies for less than $50 (not including tax and tip.) Insert mind blown emoji here.

You should know that the one thing I love more than good food, is good, cheap food, and here it is crazy cheap. The first thing I noticed when I walked in was all the older Asian customers. It's authentic, y'all. It was also busy at noon on a Friday and it got even more packed! All the seats were taken and there was a line around 12:30 p.m. that's when you know it's good. 

First we started with shrimp spring rolls. They were solid. It wasn't the freshest I've ever eaten, but it was a good start. Then, I got the Lemongrass Beef Vermicelli Salad. The beef was a little tough, but the taste was great. The salad "dressing", which I think was mainly fish sauce, had a kick to it that I was expecting, but I ended up really enjoying. Also, the vermicelli made this salad satisfying. I ended up leaving most of the salad part, but I still maintain that I ate a healthy meal.

I also got an avocado smoothie with boba and I thought it was delicious. It was sweet and creamy, just the way I like it. 

I would say the food is closer to four stars, but the price and atmosphere bumped it to five for me. Yes, it is a little rundown and small, but I love being surrounded by Asian customers. 

You pay at the cashier. The guy was fantastic. He saw me splitting our to go order and ran over to give me another bag. Five star service from him. 

Tables are in short supply so you'll want to study the menu and give your order fast. Don't worry, the waitress comes back quickly because she expects you to order right away. I can appreciate the efficiency in this.

I love this place and I'll be back when I'm in the area.

Pat O'Brien's was the first stop of the day on a day that quickly went downhill due to many, many rum concoctions and little food. Of course, we went to try the Hurricanes, which come to you in all their Hawaiian Punch-red glory through a serving device that fills several glasses at the same time from a seemingly endless trough. PRO TIP: There are several bars throughout the property and, if you can believe it, they all charge different prices for their drinks. The least expensive by a quarter or two can be found at the inside bars. 

The outside patio area is very pretty but also very hot (because, New Orleans). We opted for the cool temps of the inside bar, which had the smells and feels of just about every old school Irish bar out there. This is when we discovered the differing price structure of the beverages. Said Hurricanes were sweet. God only knows what possessed me to order a second after finishing that first. 

I think Pat O's is a one and done type of experience for me personally, but don't let that stop you from doing as the tourists do on your own trip!

Why 5 stars?  Because it's the staple of Tampa restaurants.

   ---   ---   ---

If you want to go to Bern's for the first time, here's the best advice I can give you:

1) On Friday, make a reservation for Bern's on Saturday at 5:00.

2) Sleep in as late you as you can Saturday.  Waking up at about noon would be ideal.

3) Eat a VERY light breakfast- think along the lines of a nutrigrain bar and maybe a piece of fruit.

4) Be very hungry by 5:00.

5) Order the Del Monico, and do not be tempted by anything else.

6) Maybe go a little light on the Baked Potato.  Everything else that comes out with your steak is amazing, but if you had to pick one thing out that isn't anything special, it would be the potato.  And you are going to need to conserve stomach space.

7) Pay your hefty (but well worth it bill)

8) Do the restaurant tour to let your stomach have a break

9) Order the Macademia Nut Sundae, or as they call it, "The Best Sundae in the World."

9b) If you're a chocolate fan, the "Chocolate-Chocolate-Chocolate" caused my non-foodie girlfriend to act in a way I've never seen before.  She completely loses her mind over that CCC.

10) Go for a post-game walk.  You'll need it.

Still a super solid place to meet friends.

Eight moms with babies under the age of one, you wouldn't think hey they should go to TBBC for lunch would you? Well, you'd be wrong because we did and it was great. 

Lunch on a Thursday is pretty light so our huge number of strollers didn't get in anyone's way. Especially since it was cool out so we were able to sit outside! They have umbrellas for each of their tables which is great for blocking the sun.

Our server was super courteous about serving eight moms with eight children. We were all over the map with our dietary restrictions, no dairy, soy, eggs, or nuts right here, and it was all handled with grace. To be on the safe side I got hummus with just vegetables. They just didn't add the soybean oil which normally goes on top.

The hummus was good, nothing fantastic, but it is hummus so I'm not going to judge a place mainly for the hummus. This update is to add that this is a super family friendly place during the day. 

Honestly, once my baby is older and I can eat and drink with abandon, this is going to be our new go to place.

What a refreshing addition to the Tampa restaurant scene.  Getting a reservation during their first few weeks being open was quite easy and it was great to be seated promptly once my party and I arrived.  Our server was top notch and made sure to explain all aspects of the menu for our entire group since it was all of our first time dining here.  

The Mango Margarita I ordered was a great blend of flavors and alcohol and is well worth a try.  The salsa and chips brought out within minutes of being seated are a great addition to the experience here.  The salsa had many fresh ingredients and the chips were lightly salted and light, which is a great combination.  I ended up trying the chicken tacos for my entrée and I was not disappointed.  I was quite impressed with how attentive the service at such a new restaurant was during our entire visit.  To top off the experience we were treated with complimentary churros and Mexican wishing dolls at the end of our meal.  I love this place and will definitely be back!

I woke up on Sunday morning, bleary eyed, tired, and HUNGRY. The first face I saw belonged to my cat, to whom I said quite matter-of-factly,

"I want breakfasttttt". 

Actually, it was more of a sleepy, raspy groan. In any event, my cat's response (it was 'mew', for those of you who are interested) signaled that he wasn't going to head into the kitchen and whip up pancakes and bacon for me. 

So off to Home Wine Kitchen I went.

I arrived a few minutes after their opening time of 10am, so I had my choice of seating. Since I was dining by myself (I believe my cousin very eloquently called this sort of thing a 'masturdate' -- bless him), I chose a table right by the window, for optimal people watching. Unfortunately, at 10am on Sunday, there wasn't much to be seen. 

On to the food. I've been drooling over HWK's brunch menu for weeks, namely their chicken and waffles. 

However, I was feeling especially hungry (or greedy -- choose your adjective), so I started with the cinnamon bread. Made with brown sugar, pecans, and buttermilk, it was pretty delicious and definitely worth the 15 minute wait. 

Next up? Chicken and Waffles. Consisting of 2 rosemary waffles, chicken confit, and maple balsamic gravy, this was definitely a savory dish (compared to the deliciously sweet version at Goody Goody). 

I absolutely LOVED it. The waffles were soft and delicious. The chicken was surprisingly flavorful and JUICY! And the maple balsamic gravy was fantastic and brought the whole dish together. My only regret is that after the cinnamon bread, I was too full to enjoy the entire chicken and waffles dish, and could only finish about half. 

Service here was excellent. My waitress was friendly and attentive, and the owner came by multiple times to check on me. 

I highly recommend HWK for brunch. I live ridiculously close, which means that I'll probably be back soon. 

Unless I succeed in my grand plan to teach my cat how to make waffles.

Slow service...again.

This was my 2nd time dining in.  We had slow service last time, but it was definitely understandable given the circumstances and our server constantly gave us updates and refilled our drinks.

This time however...it took 1.5 hrs for lunch.  4 of us ordered a pizza, 2 sandwiches, side salads, soda, and tea.  After placing orders, those ordering pizza found there were 6 options for pizza dough and were disappointed the server didn't mention it.  Our side salads arrived about 40 mins after placing orders w/ no word from the server as to what was delaying the order.  We had to ask twice to get boxes for our leftovers, and we had to send the bill back to remind them to apply the coupon.  I will say that our server was very nice, so perhaps she's still learning to give her the benefit of the doubt.

It did seem the other tables around us were looking a bit unhappy as well.

Based on the food alone, I'd give it 4 stars, but I'm moving to 3 on the lengthy wait time.  The pizza was very good - good dough and cheese but a little wanting on the sauce.  My friend said the buffalo chicken sandwich was very good, and I loved my philly cheesesteak.  So we were very happy with the food.  So far my call-in order has been my best experience here.

Had my first Ted Drewes visit of the summer season tonight and it felt good to be back! As Andy D mentioned, don't be phased by a long line. There were probably 30 or so people in line when we pulled up, but we really only waited about five minutes. I have no idea how they work so quickly, but there's gotta be a very specific process inside that glorious yellow building.

So why the knocking of a star? I'm probably against some secret St. Louis code or something but I don't think the custard is THAT good. It's just okay to me, but I have found out what I prefer more... it tastes better to me with yummy fruit inside like blueberries or strawberries, and they can spare me the Reeses and cookie dough. Fruit is the way to go, for sure. 

I love when it's fall and you can go by for a pumpkin pie concrete - now that I can give five stars to. Also, it's so cool to wander around and pick out a Christmas tree. I'm glad this place is in St. Louis, and I'm glad they have such amazing commercials!

That's just the way I feel, guys. And gals.

Brunch was good, but nothing blew me out of the park. 

I sometimes roll my eyes when someone goes to say a steakhouse, orders a squash dish, and then says well the squash was mediocre so don't go here. Don't go to an Indian restaurant and order spaghetti, don't go to a Greek restaurant and ask for sushi - you get the idea. However, I know there will always be people who are tempted to get the salad or the healthy dish. I will slowly raise my hand to being that person. So although I know you go to Ella's for their soul food Sundays, not for a salad, I'll still write the review for those green lovers out there. 

Jumping right in, I found the Southern Spring Salad good, but not great. It is a perfectly solid salad, there just isn't anything spectacular about it. That being said, I would definitely order it again and I would absolutely come here again. The fact that others can get their fried chicken and waffle fix while I nosh on greens makes it a perfect brunch place for me. My friend got the Funky Monkey Waffle. It is definitely on the smaller side, but it is also on the cheaper side so this is a case of you get what you pay for. If you're starving don't order it, or get it to split with a friend! Another friend got the veggie burger and said it was the best veggie burger she has ever had. That's a pretty strong statement so I might try the veggie burger next time.

Ella's uses nowait so you can put yourself in line before you even get there from the Yelp app! Nobody should have an excuse for waiting for a long time to be seated!

There is an upstairs, where we sat, so there is more seating than it looks like at first glance. At noon on a Sunday we didn't have any problems getting a table.

Since Yelp doesn't give half stars, I have to say that this is really a 3.5 star rating, but when push comes to shove, I'm giving 3 stars.

Here is what I had the chance to eat this past Saturday night, starting with my favorite dishes up top to my least favorite dishes at the bottom:

1. Tuna ceviche
2. Jalapeno corn bread
3. Grilled octopus

4. Chicken tacos
5. Carnitas tacos
6. Chicken enchilada
7. Short rib flatbread
8. Lamb tacos
9. Carne kobe tacos

10. Guacamole and chips
11. Rice and beans
12. Mahi mahi tacos
13. Plantains

I have to be honest, I was very skeptical of the ceviche as I had an extremely bad experience with ceviche in the past, but it ended up being my absolute favorite part of the meal. It was seriously so delicious I can't even describe it. The jalapeno corn bread was also amazing, and the honey on the top of the cornbread made for a sweet crystalized topping. The octopus was delicious as well, and perfectly cooked and tender.

The things listed 4-9 were all very good, but there's nothing special to say about them. The chicken tacos were much juicier than I anticipated, and the lamb tacos were a big, big hit at our table. I personally wasn't as obsessed as my friends, but that's OK.

The two things that I really didn't like were the Mahi Mahi tacos (which we all agreed tasted like a fish stick) and the plantains, which were extremely soggy and mushy, despite my friend asking for them cooked extra crispy. None of us finished the plaintains.

Now on to the other aspects of this joint...the service was good - but my one complaint was that the waitstaff looked pretty disheveled. One girl in particular looked like she hadn't brushed her hair for a week. 

Overall I think we ordered too much food for 4 people, as 8-10 dishes would have covered it. The tacos come in sets of 3, but they will make them in other increments so you can share easily with your table. We got 4 tacos for every order, and we shared every item. I liked that I got to try so many things, but the bill really added up. It was about $300.00 when all was said and done (there were two tequila flights in there). So, while on the surface things may seem cheap, the dishes are very small and you have to order at least 2 per person to feel full.

So I know you are saying to yourself, "how the heck does an airport get 5 stars??" Well, I have a couple of reasons. It's small but not tiny so a good number of airlines fly here (including my all time favorite Southwest), and I love that it's not huge and maze like. Plus they have multiple Starbucks, and that's always a must in my book!

The security lines are almost always reasonable, it's never taken me more than 15 minutes to get through line (unless it's a peak time of holiday season), however, I know people who have flown early morning during the week and it's a bit more congested because of business commuters. 

But what really makes the Nashville Airport above and beyond any other airport (besides it being my hometown and I love it) is that they have a Tootsies restaurant/bar with live musicians playing for customers who are locals or visitors so they can get a bit of the Music City Love, even if they can't make it to Broadway. How cool is that?

Zahav deserves each and every recognition it gets. I was reminded of that last night as I dined for their special "Lamb Shack" promotion. 

In short, the Lamb Shack special was offered in February 2015. It consisted of a prix fixe menu starting with hummus and pita & salatim as an appetizer, their signature lamb shoulder as the main and dessert for $36. Plus, you can BYOB at no charge during this promotion. 

Words cannot describe how amazing the lamb shoulder was. It was slow cooked with pomegranate juice and chickpeas and just phenomenal. It was served with a knife however the lamb was so fall-off-the-bone and so ridiculously tender that no knife was needed. Hands down the best lamb I've ever had and possibly one of the best things I've ever eaten.

I can't forget to mention the appetizers and dessert. I've dined at Zahav before so was familiar with the amazingness that is their salatim. Yesterday's dinner came with the twice-cooked eggplant, beets with tehina, Moroccan carrots, Tabbouleh, Cucumber Persimmon and cabbage with sumac onions. I won't go into detail about these six small plates but will say two words: Flavor Burst. 

It also came with a large portion of hummus and pita so hot it steamed. Needless to say, it was some of the best pita and hummus I've ever had. 

The dessert was the Chocolate Konafi. It was certainly different than anything I've had before and once I reached the chocolate ganache in the center absolutely hit the spot. 

I believe the lamb shoulder is typically available if you call ahead with a part of nine or more. It's worth it and I'm so thrilled to have been able to try it without the stipulations. I'm also thrilled that it was so huge and that leftovers are waiting for me at home. 

The service was professional and attentive. There were two seating's of the evening and it just felt slightly rushed. On another note, I heard one server tell a nearby table that they are doing some renovations in the main dining room/kitchen and that was one of the reasons for Lamb Shack. 

In any case, my meal was outstanding and I can't wait to wait for my next visit to Zahav. It'll be hard for anything else to live up to that lamb, but if any restaurant can do it I'm sure Zahav can.

As a sushi lover, I was sooooo pleased to see this placeopen.  Owned by the same people from Shiroi Hana, I went here with high expectations.

My 5 year old and husband also loved our first meal here last night.  My little one spent a long time looking at the live (huge) scallops and giant orange clams still moving in their shells.

We ordered the shumai for the child (who loved them) and an asoortment of tasty and inventive rolls.  DH liked the triple spicy double tuna roll, and I liked the Hamachi Verde - which I ordered without Jalapeno (I'm a wimp).

We can't wait to come back and try more.

I like our food here but not necessary we have best time. First the wait, the hostess tell us 10-15 minutes. It turn up another ten minutes. I walk around and found empty tables but they are not occupied by anyone. I went to check when is our turn, they lead me to the same empty table that I found 5 minutes ago. The seat is just below the AC vent. I can feel the drip of the water. They definitely need to check this vent on their off hour. Make sure water molecules is contained. 

The only thing I like about this place is the service on the table and the food. Which is the most important. My wife has the Thai Coconut-Lime Chicken. It a bit lime heavy at the end. The best is the Hibachi Steak. It is the hunger steak with shiitake mushrooms in slice, caramel onion and sprout. It also included the wasabi mash potatoes and tempura asparagus. This steak is cook with the ginger sauce which is a good match. 

Service is good over the dining time. Food come out the right time compare to my last visit. I would said the hostess need to paid attention to the empty table. Customers is less patient when exceed to the wait acknowledge time. The AC vent need to be clean and make not dripping water. Who know what dust has the water has collected.

OK, repeat after me.....

Kelleigh was right
Kelleigh was right
Kelleigh was right
Kelleigh was right
Kelleigh was right.....

Whew, I think that should serve as enough penance for one review!

I admit it, I have driven past Cuenelli's Peruvian Style Rotisserie Chicken on Hillsborough Avenue for months thinking that it was just another fast-food chicken joint.....and yes, I was wr-wr-wr-wrong.

Cuenelli's sits in a dinky little strip mall at the intersection of Hillsborough and Andersen Road. From the outside there's not much to see, but inside the place is spotlessly clean and decorated with a lot of Peruvian culture and pride. The waiter was super friendly, and gave me a lot of suggestions.

The menu is small, but packed with a lot of flavorful choices. In addition to the charcoal rotisserie chicken, they also have several appetizers, steak options, seafood, sandwiches, and vegetarian specials. 

My server recommended an outstanding House Special called Lomo Saltado which was tender grilled sirloin, sliced on the diagonal and served with grilled onions and tomatoes, and on top of French fries. Amazing flavors, and it came with cilantro rice and a bowl of black beans. He suggested that I try their two homemade sauces so that I'd know about them for next time. The first was made with cilantro, and it was perfect on the rice & beans. The spicy yellow sauce is designed to go with the grilled chicken, but it also tasted great with the sirloin. 

I'm anxious to go back and try the rotisserie chicken on my next visit.

Thanks Kelleigh for the suggestion!

Oh how I wish my pants had an elastic band.  Just finished brunch with 8 friends at Cafe Lift and it was gut-bustingly delicious.  Since they don't take reservations, I arrived early to see if I could get a table in the works for our large group.  By the time everyone arrived, we were seated without a problem and popping bottles of champagne for mimosas (it's byo, by the way).

Our server was efficient and kept the oj coming.  I ordered a fritatta with pancetta, sauteed onions, roasted red peppers and gorgonzola.  In an effort to curb calories somewhere in the meal, I asked for egg whites.  This was met with some hesitation (something about the fritatta not rising with only egg whites), so I asked for all the same ingredients in an egg white omelet.  When breakfast arrived soon after, my egg white frittata was indeed on the plate... so not sure what all the rising business was about, but it was fantastic!  Whole grain toast and potatoes were served alongside.  

9 people left absolutely stuffed for under twenty bucks a person.  I will definitely be back!

This is the best gastro pub in the city. Great bar food. Quality burgers and fun fried stuff. The tempura green beans are f..n great. Cool snacks and sandwiches. Great beer selection. Not an amazing cocktail selection. Very hipster place. And its run down and shabby on purpose. Fun time especially if you have a bunch of drinkers.

Mazzaro's Italian Market is Reason #13 my husband and I want to move to Saint Petersburg.  Come for pastries and coffee at 9 AM, and you'll find yourself making plans to return for lunch.  Trust me when I say that this is a do-not-miss experience!

Apps were great, noodles were not, and the roaches were not well received at all! Well to be fair it was only one roach. But a baby one, which tells me they've been thriving at Penang for generations. 
It seems that appetizers are where Penang really shines. If you decide to brave the infestation and eat here, the roti pancake with curry sauce is a must. I should have just gotten one for myself and made it my meal. Chicken satay was delicious too. Their peanut sauce is the best I've ever had. 
My friend and I both ordered Thai basil noodles. When it came out it looked amazing but remarkably had zero flavor. I'm not sure how something that looked so pretty and had so much mixed into it could have so little taste, but it did. I had to ask for sriracha to mix into it just to give it some kind of flavor. Then of course, our unexpected dinner guest decided to pop out after we eat all of our food. At least the roach wasn't in the food I guess? And logically I know that this happens, but I just don't want to see it when I'm eating. It was horrific. Unfortunately Penang will never happen again for me, but if you want to take your chances with vermin then just stick to the appetizers!

I have to update my review so future Christina knows what she tried and loved.

We ordered a variety of stuff during the COVID-19 quarantine so we got to branch out and try new dishes (#supportlocal). I'm happy to report that everything was delicious. 

Fried Chicken Eggrolls - my husband loved these and said he'd get them again.
Shrimp Spring Rolls - these were very fresh and a great starter.
Seafood stir fried soft egg noodle - I liked the soft egg noodle better than the pan fried egg noodle (tried both). The good news is if you get the pan fried egg noodle dish to go they separate the dish so your noodles don't get soggy. My son ate more of the crispy noodle sans topping so I guess in the future we will have to keep getting both. For the crispy noodle dish I got the tofu/vegetarian topping. Both were delicious, but I'll probably stick with the seafood next time. I love fish cubes.
Beef fried rice - their fried rice is amazing. It was seriously addicting. You know it's good rice when you love it the same eating it cold, because rice rarely tastes good cold. This will be a repeat order.
Banh mi - we got both chicken and tofu banh mi sandwiches. When I bit into it I remembered why I love it so much. For $4, it's an absolute steal. I get it without jalapenos because I dislike spicy things.
Avocado smoothie with boba - It's sweet and delicious. A small hits the spot and it's only $3.50.

Unfortunately, it looks like Thinh anh is closed for the near future as we get this pandemic sorted out. From friends I found out they deliver on DoorDash, but I couldn't find them on UberEats. I really hope they weather this storm, because they are amazing.

I like this place, but recommend getting everything BUT the BBQ. 

I visited yesterday. Second day with clients in town and I thought this cool little spot would be a great place to show off some STL cue. Plus... all my favs for guests are all closed on Monday (Sydney Street, Niche, Terrene). I've been here a few times before and like it's quaint atmosphere. 

They were out of everything liquid. My first two beer orders and my guests first wine order were not available. The waitress claimed that they get their liquor order on Tuesdays... which is fine, but I was amazed that they run out of so many things on a weekly basis. By the way, they were out of Diet Coke too. 

Frustrated, I just asked the waitress to bring out one of the draft beers that they did have. At this point I didn't care which. She brought out a vanilla porter. Yum. It was awesome. I'm glad I had her pick because I wouldn't have selected this and it was so good. My guests landed on a Pinot from Aquainas. It was ok... but they seemed pleased. 

We started with the smoked wings, and smothered fries. Both were on special. I really like these wings. They're some of my favorites in town. They come out charred black with dipping sauce. They're meaty, smokey, and good. The fries are smothered in a white velveetaish sauce and bacon bits. We were starving after a long day of work and both hit the spot. 

Service here sucked, actually. Don't get me wrong, our waitress wasn't screwing around, she simply was too busy. And due to her speeding around, she was super rushed at the table. We had trouble flagging her down to order dinner, and to request items like straws and extra napkins. I didn't really get it. There were two servers... but she had 8 or 9 tables while the other guy had one. Oh well... I hope this is an anomaly as I've experienced much better service here previously. 

For dinner we ordered the Big Jimmy's sampler. It consists of ribs, chicken, pulled pork, and brisket. It was just average. I know better than to order BBQ late at night. It's always dry and looses that juicy, fall off the bone quality. Again, my guests were fine with it, but I couldn't help but think that I could make better cue at home. Again, as I said before, I'll be back because I like this place, but next time I'll steer away from the smoked meat entrees. 

We loaded up with a bunch of sides. We tried the Mac & Cheese, green bean casserole, creamed corn, mashed potatoes, and the chili sampler. If you like butter and gooey cheese, you'll like this place. The mac & cheese, and creamed corn are so loaded with them that they start to harden after a few minutes. The sides were good. I liked the beans and duck chili (one of the 4 chili samplers) best. 

My guest lefts super pleased... which was my goal by going here. I left hoping my next time back will be better.

Still batting a thousand here!  Went on Friday around 6 pm and the place was hopping.    Still had some of our favorites:  pad Thai with soft shelled crabs fried tempura style, crunchy crabs with silken noodles and spicy and delicious basil fried rice, both served piping hot.   These were preceded by the crispy duck salad (always a wiinner) and the garden herb rolls.  Service is always great.   If you haven't been here yet and you like thai you must give Viman a try.

My friend and I found ourselves here on Sunday night in hopes that we could get seated.  As luck would have it, there were two seats available at the chef's counter.  Since neither of us was starving, we ordered 4 plates to share~ a serrano ham and fig salad, two different flatbreads and parmesan artichokes.  Everything was really nicely presented and full of flavor.  Our server was very attentive and pleasant.     

The seasonal peach sangria was delicious and probably one of the best I've had.

Our only gripe was that it was SO HOT in the restaurant.  And not just where we were seated, but everywhere.  We suspected the managers were probably trying to conjure the actual temperature of Spain to provide the full experience.  As we watched the desserts being prepared in front of us, the ice cream scooped on top started melting instantly.  I felt kind of sad for the people who had ordered them.

Overall, I'd love to try Amada again, but probably not until summer is over.  I loathe melty ice cream!

For lunch it is five stars. Cannot said much about dinner since we have not visited at dinner time. The value at lunch time is perfect for the price and the food selection. It definitely attract more lunch crowd. The scenery to eat lunch and enjoy the outdoors is pleasant during this time of year. 

We have order a sunomono salad to start. I thing this better than poke bowl I paid close to the restaurant. The dish includes cucumber with sweet vinegar and the protein includes raw Ahi tuna, salmon, Tilapia and cook octopus. It top with masago and sesame seed. This is best sunomono I have in Tampa since I have search the best similar to Miami. 

Our main dishes are grilled salmon and pan seared grouper. The salmon was grilled with sprinkles with herb and lay over asparagus. It serve a cream sauce at the bottom. The grouper is the best. It lay over the sautéed veggies and base with lime sauce. Both dishes is well decorated presentation. Taste is good. 

I like service and the speed of food delivery to your table. If come to enjoy the meal in Jackson, the parking below the restaurant is free for two hours.

Hubs and I have been excited to return for the calzones after we sat at the pizza bar on our first visit. They looked sooooo good! This last visit, we snagged a table outside (first come first serve, just FYI) when there was an hour-long wait for the inside tables. Our server was very nice and friendly. We ordered the chopped steak salad (same as last time) and a calzone. Our server kindly told us that they were quoting an hour-long wait for the calzones (which is understandable because the restaurant was at capacity and the pizza oven is not that big!) We were fine with that but asked to get our salad first. Lucky us, the salad AND calzone were done in less than an hour, and they were delivered to our table. Unfortunately, the appearance and the smell of the calzone was far superior to the taste. It just wasn't good. It was soggy, crust had no crisp to it, and the ingredients weren't great (the sausage was such tiny little pieces you couldn't tell it was even sausage). I took a bite that included a bristle (presumably from the brush they use to douse the thing with butter sauce, which was saw last visit). The salad wasn't good either. The meat was tasty, but the tomatoes were literally inedible, and the rest of the ingredients just weren't as fresh and tasty as our first visit.

We live around the corner so we were excited for this opening, but not sure whether we would return given the inconsistency.

Since it has been 4 years and one kid later, I figured it was time to update my review.

So my kid was five months when we went. Great age for visiting the zoo? Maybe not, but when you are trying to figure out something to do with him all day, the zoo is a great choice.

I love how you can buy an annual pass where you can bring someone. All the moms swap memberships. I have one to the aquarium so I bring my friend who can bring me to the zoo. Babies are free so you only need a two person pass if your friends are like mine and only have little ones. 

It was in December so the weather was perfect. It's pretty much all outdoors so weather is a huge factor into whether you will enjoy your visit. Parking is free and the lot is huge. 

We rode the carousel and the safari train. The carousel is pretty fast. Yes, I put my five month old on a stationary animal and hung on for dear life standing beside it. I will not be going on that again, but my friend had a seven month old and put him on one that moves up and down and was as stable as can be. This is why her tree pose is so much better than mine in Mommy and Me yoga. 

I still find the layout of the zoo a little confusing, but my friend knew exactly where she was going so I followed her. They have your standard awesome for kids animals, but we barely looked at them since my son wasn't that interested - not a budding zookeeper. Mainly we walked and talked. 

I like this zoo. I would definitely suggest getting a pass or befriending someone with one!

Have visited once with a family group, and tried drinks & apps.   This is an uptown/upscale place....very nicely decorated, offering fancy drink specials, uncomfortable but stylish furniture, eclectic appetizers and classy, if a bit snobbish service.  Enjoyed the visit, esp, the hummus, and noted the nice roof-top bar option.  This is a place to take someone to impress, and you will pay for that outcome.   Not likely to mistake this for a dive or comfortable neighborhood bar.

Lunch at Home Wine Kitchen in one word: Delightful.

At noon today, it was full of happy customers but still had a few tables open, and my mom and I were lucky enough to score one right in the window. My first thoughts went something like, "wow, Nosh was really cute, but somehow Home Wine Kitchen has made it look ten times better in here." Check out my photos, I really love the interior and it does, indeed, feel like home. A beautiful, warm, classy, extremely visually appealing home. I mean, I'd definitely move in if they asked me too.

Josh, one of the owners, took care of us today and was so welcoming and informative! He told us all about the menu and described how they pair the wine to go with certain dishes, and I was sad when I had to decline a glass due to too much afternoon work. My mom ordered one though, and it was a creamy chardonnay that went very well with the soaring temps outside. I just asked for a lemon with my water and Josh brought me TWO lemons... so generous!

For lunch we ordered the grilled cheese and the sausage & grape flatbread, and they both were perfectly prepared and rich in taste. The grilled cheese came with sharp cheddar, fontina, mushrooms, and greens (really nice truffle taste) and had a side of fennel & onion salad. My flatbread was topped with spicy Italian sausage, bleu cheese, carmelized onions and red grapes. The combination of the spicy, salty sausage, tangy cheese, and sweet grapes was dynamite! Not a bad thing to say about either dish.

What's next? Dinner. I can't wait to go back and see what they've got going in the evenings. And I'll definitely have a glass of wine next time.

How can you not love Di Bruno Bros.? They have fresh meats, fresh vegetables, baked goods, and cheese! Goodness, they've got tons of cheese. And not just cheddar.

Calling them a comfy, miniature Whole Foods is almost insulting, but you get what I'm trying to say, right? Just sit upstairs and have a cup of coffee and you'll understand.

Di Bruno Bros. may not necessarily be the best deal on the block, but you get what you pay for.

The other day, I went to Jilly's again when I had a longer lunch break and forgot my lunch. I decided to go because I wanted a salad and it came to mind as being quick and yummy.

I've read all the Jilly's reviews and some have struck me in how some people have said how rude the workers are. I again had a great experience - the gal working was very nice and friendly. The food again came out really quickly. I had the penguin which is chocolate with cream cheese frosting. Delicious! Of course, I had to share it since it is big.

I'll go back again because I like it and it's closer than the other cupcake places to me.

Peruvian food is one of my faves, and we were in the mood for chicken. I remembered how good Peruvian Chicken, and had to have him try something different. We decided upon Cuenelli's since we never been.

Chicken was very good and juicy. It comes with a yellow sauce and a green sauce. The green sauce is spicier. The yellow sauce is mayo based. It was okay sauce, but I have had better. The selected sides were cilantro rice and black beans which I didn't have. I tried both and the cilantro rice was good and diff, but a little dry for me.

My favorite was the ceviche with tilapia, lime juice with corn nuts and sweet potato. If you want the best ceviche, get it from the Peruvians! Yes I love it the most. I did say no onions and not spicy so if you love spicy just ask for it.

If you want to drink something yummy, try the passion fruit juice. I liked it better than the mango juice. They do have Chicha Morada which is the typical Peruvian drink as well as Inca Cola. Those are in bottles and cans.

I'll be back here for a great affordable Peruvian option when I'm in this area!

I finally made it to the promised land!!!

Not quite as bad as wandering in the desert for 40 years, this place does get busy in the snowbird season and can test your navigation skills. The upside is that they have a wonderful selection of breads, cheeses, chocolates, biscotti, pasta, olives, meats and other goodies at fairly reasonable prices.  

It's interesting to compare and contrast with the fancy gourmet market Locale  in Downtown St. Pete at the newly revived Sundial complex. This place is more my speed. Definitely worth a visit. Just not the most relaxing shopping experience in the world. :) They also have a coffee bar. 

Mangia!!!!!

Excellent rack of lamb appetizer today. ... Enough for a small dinner.
Crab and corn chowder - excellent
Still love the foie gras burger.
Not impressed with the duck entree.   Duck was overdone. Pumpkin ravioli that went with it were great.  The veggies that came with it were not well done (underdone pancetta) and the sauce that came with it was watery.  Will not order this again.

They have not lost their touch. I was invited to Cuenelli's on Friday by the owner after running into her at the grocery store for a complimentary dinner for my food blog. I wasn't disappointed. I started with the Papa a la Huancaina ($5.99). Normally I skip appetizers at restaurants and dive right into my meal, but this appetizer is hard to resist. The eggs and potatoes go well with the spicy yellow sauce. Normally my friend and I destroy it while we wait for dinner (which normally comes pretty quick at this restaurant).

The tough decision one always makes at Cuenelli's is: chicken or steak? Both are excellent and have their own, unique taste. My friend and I, being the smart two university students we are decided to order both and then mix and match. The chicken sandwich ($6.99) being well worth the cost. If Cuenelli's sandwiches were available to me -  I would certainly want one every week because they are just that good. I searched the streets of Seoul looking for some decent Peruvian food for four months without anything hinting to some of the great Spanish cuisine we have here in Florida.

The Bistec a lo Pobre ($11.99) was a delicious treat as well. The over-easy egg yolk went excellent with the rice, beans, and plantains. Cuenelli's homemade french fries are always a great hit to have on the side. 

The last entree we had was the Peruvian ceviche which was both spicy and tangy. It hit the right palate and was enjoyable. Packed in my favorite vegetable: onions. The pumpkin and corn on the side was a nice addition and it was my first time trying this dish. I consider ceviche to be more of an appetizer than an entree, but this portion was certainly an entree size.

Overall, great food is still to be had at Cuenelli's. If you haven't tried this Peruvian restaurant, you owe it to yourself to take some time and drive down Hillsborough for some delicious Peruvian cuisine.

Mai Lee is an STL fav.  Their menu is large, with lots of fun Viet and Chinese offerings.  I've tried numerous different things and the food is consistently good.  

On the other hand, service has significant fallen off at this place.  It's clear they're interested in serving volumes of customers and not offering any quality heart-felt service.  

When you are seated, don't expect a server to come to your table for about 5-7 minutes.  This is normal.  They want you to be ready to order when they come to the table... and the menu is long, so my only assumption is they want you to have time to go over everything first.  There is a lunch menu which leans heavily on their Chinese fare... but you have to ask for it.  Do it... the value is good... a decent sized dish with appetizer and soup for around 10 bucks.  I've come here countless times and had no clue they had a lunch menu until I brought my father and he inquired.  

This past time I tried an appetizer of Cha Gio Tom (mini shrimp egg rolls).  They were bite size, simple, and yummy.  For my entree I chose Com Dac Biet (crushed rice w/egg cake, shredded pork, pork chop & fried egg).  This dish was perfect.  A yummy assortment of vegetables, rice, meat and eggs.  

All in all, the stellar food is worth putting up with the cold service.

The historic, century-old Water Works Building in Seminole Heights has been transformed into the urban and hip restaurant, Ulele, that offers Floridian and Native American inspired dishes. Modern décor is showcased through the interior and exterior of Ulele. An intricate cogs-and-wheels front door made by Dominique Martinez of Rustic Steel Creations greets diners at the entrance of the brick building. Inside you'll find furniture made from reclaimed Florida wood, an open 10-foot barbacoa kitchen, a glass wine cellar, and an on-site brewery.

My husband and I booked a 7pm reservation on OpenTable for Ulele on October 18th. Our table wasn't quite ready for us at our requested time so we took the opportunity to explore the riverwalk and park. Once our table was ready we were led upstairs on the floating staircase and were treated to tranquil waterfront views of the Hillsborough River. 

The liquor menu included handcrafted beers from Ulele's brewery, signature cocktails, and domestic wines from family-owned vineyards. The wines range from affordable bottles under $30 to more impressive wines, such as the Opus One at a bank breaking price tag of $188. We opted for a red blend, "Baby Blue" from Blue Rock Vineyard in Sonoma, Alexander Valley. The wine was very unique and I would definitely order it again.

We started off our meal with the Ulele side salad with mixed greens, arugula, watercress, baby Swiss cheese, cranberry beans, fire-roasted peppers, onions, and a balsamic vinaigrette and the Florida Native Chili with alligator, wild boar, venison, duck, ground chuck, and cranberry beans. The salad was light and refreshing. My husband's chili was delicious, but very hearty so he was almost full before our meals arrived.

For our entrees I ordered the Seafood Risotto special of the evening. This dish contained generous portions of lobster tails, crab claws, scallops and shrimp. My husband ordered the Flank Steak with a Florida avocado "Jimmychurri". This dish sounded great on the menu, but we both agreed it fell a bit flat. The steak was too chewy and the Jimmychurri sauce was bland. We also didn't understand why popcorn was on top of the mashed potatoes. It didn't add any flavor or texture to the potatoes. 

Unfortunately we didn't save room for dessert, but the Candied Duck Bacon Maple Fried Ice Cream sounded amazing!

I remember when the plans for this shopping mall were first leaked to the press.  When the newscaster spoke about how the mall would have a more upscale vibe and feature 10+ restaurants connected to, but outside of the mall, I recall thinking it sounded dumb.  "No one wants to go to the mall and eat at a restaurant."  How wrong was I?  Kind of like when my pops told me in 2001 that MP3 files were going to be the wave of the future, and I just couldn't see it.

Today, some 14 years later, I find myself here a lot.  Though my shopping is limited to only a few stores, the eateries are common haunts for me.  Cheesecake Factory, commercial but good.  Zen, some of the best sushi around.  The Pub, incredible brew selections and fantastic Brit grub.  Bar Louie, them chicken nachos tho!  Rise Pies with their Subway style pizzeria.  And the hidden restaurant, Bazille is fan-freaking-tastic.  I could go on and on.

Wanna smoke a stogie?  Edward's has a kiosk right in front of Blue Martini where you can pick up one in a pinch.  That kiosk location has been clutch for me on quite a few occasions.

Parking can be a nightmare on the weekends, but I park in the cut.  There is a small shaded area between the Bay Street parking and the Renaissance parking.  It sort of looks like off limits, and I think that is why there is always a spot down there.

Anywho, as far as shopping malls go, this one is the best we've got. And I generally dislike malls, so heed my word.

This is a nice place to spend a hot day. It is cool and dark. There are a lot of exhibits that showcase both Florida aquatic life as well as the more exotic stuff. My toddler loved the whole place. 

It is not cheap, but it is bigger and more professionally set up than Clearwater or MOTE, and they are only a few dollars cheaper. The annual passes are good deals if you plan on visiting a few times within a year.

holy moly another incredible meal. the bf said his lemon ricotta pancakes were the best pancakes he's ever had. they were DELISH with awesome honey and homemade whipped cream! definitely one of the best brunch spots i've ever found....certainly the best in philly. i had the fried egg and spicy sausage panino sandwich (on the specials board) and it was very good. i explicitly told the waitress i wanted my egg yolk kinda runny and she assured me that's how i'd get it - and the yolk was solid. otherwise, a great meal and EXTREMELY well priced.

John Besh restaurants never seem to disappoint. Luke is one of his best because it is casual with great food at a great price. Ate here with some friends last night, we had the roasted chicken, the fried oyster and avocado salad, bread pudding and creme brûlée for dessert. All was top notch with flavor that is New Orleans own. Next time I go though I must try the seafood courtboullion which is Besh's version of a local classic. You just can't go wrong with John Besh.

Great place to stop for some good food, good beer, and good conversation.

I have to echo what my friend, Kristi S., wrote in her review. I completely agree that I'm open to giving this place five stars because I have the feeling this place will wow me. Maybe one day I'll look back at this review and think, I was an idiot, but my visit here was a solid four stars, which still makes me a fan!

It was a 30 minute wait for indoor seating on a Saturday night. They definitely double downed on the outside seating, since I would say the size of the indoor seating is the same as the size of the outdoor. I have a huge fear of mosquitos (hey we live in Florida!) so the day I decide I'm ok with getting Zika is the day I'll sit outside in the summer. (If I know I will have to sit outside I will bathe in bug spray and everyone dining with me has to deal with the smell.) Luckily, there is a long communal table that is first come first serve, so I didn't have to sit outside (which is also first come first serve) or wait the thirty minutes. 

My friend and I both went with the flight of four beers, deciding to share. This means we got to try a total of eight beers. We're dark beer drinkers, so this means we tried every porter/stout/brown ale they had on their menu (and then had to pull a couple non-dark beers to hit our eight). Honestly, I enjoyed them all. Some of the beers are seasonal and tbh, when I do beer flights unless the beer name is written down in front of me, I can't keep them straight. You'll have to come and try them yourself.

I got the Beer B Q Turkey Burger. Maybe this is my fault, since it is in the name, but I wasn't a fan of the beer b q sauce. I found it overwhelming. It also came with fried jalapenos which I picked out (I am not a spice person). The bun was perfectly buttered. I honestly planned to just pick at the bun, but I ate the whole thing! If you're on a diet and think you have willpower, you're wrong and should just order it without the bun. I got the cheesy mashed potatoes as my side and man they were cheesy! I loved it. 

I had serious food envy as I watched other plates pass by me. The calzones were ginormous! Seriously, that could feed a family. The pretzels looked huge as well! That's an entree size and then some. They don't skimp on portions here.

I definitely enjoyed this place. I'm a fan!

Milagro has been a favorite on Yelp since it first opened.  They separate themselves from all of the other Mexican restaurants by offering unique dishes that full of flavor.  

We wanted to visit Milagro on a Saturday night and I knew that was going to be an issue.  They're popular, so there was going to be a significant wait.  But I checked their website and found out that by downloading the NoWait app, I could put my name on the waiting list before I ever left the house.  I've never used this app before but it was pretty cool that I could see how long the wait was, and watch my progreess up the line of people before me.  I also noticed that a bunch of other of my favorite restaurnts were using this app (Taste, Mission, Rooster, etc.).  

We arrived and were seated at a very small table for two.  Service was prompt and she went over a bunch of different specials.  We had settled on the #72, and the Chili Relleno plate.  The #72 that my wife ordered consisted of a fish taco, a beef enchilada, and a super small quesadilla.  She liked the enchilada (and the side of beans) the best.  Although the dish was good, the quesadilla seemed a little mediocre compared to the rest of the items on her combination plate.  I had the Chili Relleno and it was the best relleno I've ever had.  It was a large stuffed pepper filled with cheese and mushrooms, and supposedly squash but I never tasted that.  The pepper itself was puffy and crunchy and topped with a very spicy and flavorful salsa.  My wife liked the pepper too, but the heat on top was a bit much for her.  It came with a side of really good street corn. 

Value was decent... together both entrees were around $33.  

After enjoying another great meal here, I was astonished that I hadn't been back in so long.  With the convenient check-in feature and consistently good food, I'm sure we'll return in the very near future.

Wow, their carryout is as good as a dine experience. I love how they double wrapped our 1/2 rack of baby back ribs and 8 oz of brisket. First it is wrapped in a saran wrap and then foil, making for a neat clean trip home. They also package each of the side dishes separately in plastic containers with lids. Our pie was simply put in a Styrofoam container with a flip lid. Boo hiss, Styrofoam not environmentally friendly. 

Back to the food - as last time the brisket was fork tender. I was able to break off my bite size pieces with a simple pressure from my fork. This time when I packaged up some sauces, I got some of the Coffee BBQ Sauce and I must say it is now my favorite. The 1/2 rack of baby back ribs were cleaned to the bone by the SO. He said they were "fabulous". 

We had to order our favorite sides from last time; Mac-n-Cheese and The Pasta Salad that has black beans and corn. Oh my, Oh my, I love this Mac-n-Cheese. As my second side, I expanded my experience and tried the cole slaw which is a creamy slaw. I prefer a creamy slaw over a vinegar slaw any day and this one is a winner. 

This time we got to experience pie and since I was the one picking up the carry out, I got to pick the flavor and I choose Pecan. My only regret of selecting Pecan is that I only bought one slice and I had to share it with the SO. Damn it! I love Pecan pie and this is the best I have had at any restaurant. It is even better then Art Smith's Pecan Pie at his restaurant Table Fifty-Two in Chicago and that is a serious compliment. 

Portions were large enough that I have a lunch for tomorrow at work. My coworkers are going to be jealous.

Like the Liberty Bell, cheesesteaks, and that pesky city wage tax, the Reading Terminal Market is one of those things that makes Philadelphia uniquely Philadelphia.

Yes, it's a historical site, but more importantly, it's full of vendors selling delicious food. There's something for everyone: Amish sellers are there part of the week, and you can pick up groceries or get your grub on if you're in the mood for a cheesesteak, Thai, Indian, ice cream, oysters - you name it.

If the Market was open past 5 PM, I'd be the happiest camper. And poorer, but who's watching my wallet?

PRONOUNCIATION: Remember, it's "Redding", rhymes with sledding. Don't ask me why.

this is my favorite place to get roti. it's always perfectly baked but i could always use more dipping sauce!

the spare ribs here are my favorite as well as the mango chicken. this place might be a bit more over priced than banana leaf which is down the street but it's worth it in my opinion.

I used to love this place.  We went here for years and it WAS great.  It's now okay but there is less of a draw.   The beer was and still is great.  However we miss the food now that it has resorted to mass production necessary with the expanded menu.  We miss the original crabcakes with corn relish, the seared tuna, and the old style meatloaf.  We still enjoy the calamari and the burgers.   The quesadilla is now 1/2 the size and the price has almost doubled ($13) probably due to the additional crab.  It was flavorless and disappointing.  Bring back the chicken quesadilla!

The mussels and fries were perfectly cooked but the broth was so salty it made my lips curl it could not be enjoyed.  The burger and crab cake sandwich we ordered were cooked as requested but were not exciting.  

I guess this is the cost of progress.  Time to find a new "local" place.

From tasty spring rolls and the most sacred broth of the gods that is pho, to slamming Vietnamese seafood and vegetarian dishes, Nam Phuong is a destination that  delivers a well rounded assortment of vibrant dishes.

I give a 4 because sometimes I have encountered a bit of a disconnect. Once when I ordered the amazing an action packed deluxe pho with slices of round steak, flank, brisket, tendon, tripe, and beef balls; I was devastated to find a bowl with just round steak due to the waiter getting the number wrong. But even with such foibles I've hardly been able to complain due to their pho being an easy contender for best in Philly at such a bargain price.

But even if your not into pho you can go there and savor everything from broken rice, pan fried noodles, congee, and more. some standouts that I've enjoyed when I decided to take a break from the sacredness have included, Vietnamese crepes with tofu & vegetables, seafood curry, and the spicy chicken w/ lemongrass; as well as plenty of their specials. No matter what you go with here its a win that will leave you fulfilled.

The International Mall. A great destination if you have cash to burn. 

it reminds me of the AlaMoana mall in Hawaii, only completely closed in and no Koi.  It has 2 of my favorite stores, LUSH and Sephora, and that's what keeps me coming back. 

I really am not one for big named products, so I don't care about the Vera Bradley, Coach, or even the Neiman Marcus. The stores that get me coming back are the unique ones: Art of Shaving & Bettie Paige Clothing.

This review is solely on pick up.

Everything was packaged well but I didn't get my pho spoon like I do in other places which kinda sucked. Pho spoon is so essential! 
The beef eye round here though is SOOO chewy. I was so grossed out I had to throw it out which sucked cause then I had no meat in my pho.
The summer rolls were okay, definitely could have had more fillings included, I hate limp summer rolls.

Fried rice here was a 1/10. Definitely could use more seasoning, soy sauce and eggs. 

All in all, not sure if I'd come back here but definitely good efforts.

I liked this restaurant a lot more this visit than my first visit 10 years ago.  I left hungry that last time, and had no desire to return. However, flash forward 10 years and this is where my girlfriends wanted to eat. I was very surprised at how busy it was on a Tuesday night. We had reservations though and were sat relatively quickly .

Their "thing", if you will, is healthy eating, so they put the calories of every item right on their menu.  They also, to my delight and amazement, had a separate menu showing items you could eat if you were Vegan or Dairy Sensitive.  Bravo!

I ended up ordering off of their new Hello Spring menu which consisted of a select appetizer, entree, and mini dessert for $30. I started with the black bean and bacon soup and it was excellent.  Thick and tasty with a small dash of crema in it.  For my main course I had the wood-grilled sea scallops and this too was delicious. Served on a bed of grains with asparagus spears, it had a slightly spicy and slightly sweet flavor. Plus the scallops were perfect cooked.  Dessert was a choice of mini-indulgences, and I went with the pecan pie option of vanilla bean mousse, whipped cream, and honey-glazed pecan.  Yum!  The perfect light dessert after a filling meal.

All in all a great experience especially since I did not leave hungry, and I would definitely return.

WOW, like seriously WOW. Like pick your jaw up off the tiled floor and quit drooling kinda WOW!!!!  Oxford Exchange is an absolutely amazing experience, and kicks off a breathtaking new trend for the Tampa Bay area.

Oxford Exchange is located along Kennedy Boulevard, directly across the street from the University of Tampa campus, and just down the block from the Tampa Theater. To get there, I would recommend driving along Kennedy and then turning south at the traffic light onto S. Hyde Park Avenue (directly opposite the UT front gates), and then turning right onto Grand Central Avenue. From there you can look for FREE on-street parking, or park across the street in the church parking lot. Oxford Exchange shares the block with the Tampa Theater, Mis En Place, and some kind of punch-your-lights-out boxing / gym thing.

Oxford Exchange is a refurbished 100 year-old brick building that now houses an incredible multi-use retail facility. If you park around back, then you enter the building through the intimate and eclectic bookstore. The tiled floor in this area is spectacular, and worthy of careful study before you move along. The bookstore is a collection of classic and rare books which are arranged not in the typical "mystery", "romance", "non-fiction" categories, but rather by themes such as Discovery, Solace, and "What Would Happen if Abraham Lincoln Had Lived". These books are more the hardback, collectible, and home library style. Really a beautiful spot, and I can imagine myself spending an hour or so pouring over their collection.

Continuing through the bookstore you meander down a long hallway which is paneled in dark wood, and move into the atrium which is a two-story gathering spot with a dramatic black and white tiled floor, high arched white ceiling and comfortable leather sofas, antique overstuffed chairs, and small tables. In this section of the complex you'll find a Buddy Brew fine coffee establishment and TeBella's boutique tea house. The idea being that you can buy your favorite non-alcoholic drink and visit with friends in a very posh conversation area. The walls in the atrium are covered with vintage photos and artwork.

Leading up the stairs in this central atrium area is the private "Commerce Club", where members can relax, read and work in a very classy, quiet, private office space. The lady I spoke with said that talking on cellphones is discouraged within the Commerce Club, and so if you need to make a call they will direct you to a private, leather-padded booth so as not to disturb those around you. (Hear, Hear!!!)

Back downstairs and out through the tall glass doors, and you enter the solarium with it's two-story glass-ceiling with white-painted brick walls and tables for eating or reading. The solarium plays host to the daily High Tea, served from 3 - 5pm, complete with a proper English tea service, finger sandwiches, scones, and sweets.

Moving back into the atrium and walking through the doorway towards Kennedy Boulevard, you enter the home-design retail shop with its collection of aromatherapy candles, cookbooks, spices, scents, fine stationary, quality gifts, and so much more. This is also the waiting area for the Oxford Exchange restaurant, and so the crowd wanders around the floor, delighted by these treasures as they wait for their table. My Dad would refer to this as a Cracker Barrel Store for grown-ups, with no noisy PA system!

After a good half-hour of walking around with a bad case of my eyes bugging out of my head at all of this splendor, I finally made it to the hostess stand of the Oxford Exchange Restaurant. Even though there is seating for about 100 people, the restaurant was plenty full. The lady offered for me to wait about 20 minutes, or they could seat me right away at the Chef's Table / Bar overlooking the open-air kitchen. Yes please!!!!!

The restaurant has polished marble floors, white-painted brick walls, metallic tabletops, and a vibrant "buzz" of activity and excitement. It's hard to believe that the Oxford Exchange has only been open since September, but the place was packed with a mixture of college students (and their parents), well-dressed downtown workers, and those of us who's jaws were still dragging on the floor.

I started my meal with a pot of Yuzu Oolong tea (scented with grapefruit for a very crisp and clean taste). I heard nice things about the Tuna Tar Tar, and ordered that for my appetizer. The diced tuna was served with avocado, Crème fraîche, crispy potato slices, and thin slivers of jalapeno peppers, all piled high into a dramatic little tower and plated with a light soy-based sauce. YUM!

For my main course I ordered the Wild Salmon Nicoise salad which was a nice 8 ounce filet of grilled and seasoned salmon, sitting atop a bed of Bibb lettuce with green beans, a quartered hard-boiled egg, Nicoise olives, thin-sliced potatoes, and dressed with a light Dijon vinaigrette.

(Part two to follow).....

A very good sandwich shop that specializes in an impressive collection of wonderful desserts.    They are creative and generous in their sandwich offerings....all the standards  like Cubans & Reubens, but also variations like California Reuben with turkey & slaw.   Made fresh and packed with quality meat.  But Crispers and Publix deli offer similar sandwiches with fewer variations.  Mostly takeout, but some tables available for eating there.

Wright's achieves superstellar altitude with its desserts.......cupcakes, cheesecakes, tall cakes, cream cakes, standards like red velvet and carrot-----all delectable and all the most popular flavors/ingredients, chocolate, fruit, peanut butter, nuts, coconut,  caramel, butter, and anything high-caloric .

I can live without frequent visits, but it is nice as an option when not on a diet.

Still a great place for sushi (don't miss the tuna dumplings) and sashimi.  Same friendly owners and wonderful service at a tiny bar that gets PACKED at lunchtime.

Great find!

Best Happy Hour in town!

If you sit at their bar or patio area after 3 p.m. they have a happy hour menu.

I would suggest sitting at the patio.  There is a nice view of the fountain and surprisingly it is kind of fun to watch traffic.  There is a good group of professionals who come here after work that give the area a good atmosphere.

The happy hour margarita is really good and only $4.75!  I also tried the Sake Sangria, which was good also $6.50.  Can you really beat those prices?!  

I got the crab crunch roll and the philly roll (both on the happy hour menu).  Honestly,even though it was good, I got food envy when my friend's apple and brie flatbread arrived.  It was huge!  Definitely a complete dinner and I got to try it and it was really good.  The happy hour menu has so many great choices that it will definitely make me come back for more.

The only downside is parking can get busy, even though they have a huge parking lot.  And when it is packed you have to be prepared to pounce on a table.

Come here for happy hour!  You won't be disappointed.

Ok so Ted Drewes is possibly one of the most iconic food establishments in St. Louis. It's one of those places you have to try and stand outside in line waiting for. They have a wall of celebrity pictures of people who have fréquentes their custard shop and in the summer it's not uncommon to see a wedding party roll through for treats and pictures. I enjoy grabbing a Big Apple and sitting in our truck bed with my family and dog enjoying a summer night. For me it's more of the experience that draws me more than the custard. I don't think it's the end all be all of ice cream joints in St. Louis there are plenty others worth mentioning. But as far as places in St. Louis that just scream summertime this is one of the places to be.

By now I'm sure you've heard how awesome Good Dog is. I'm here to reiterate this message and give my own take.  

As a dog lover, the photos of dogs on the walls were obviously awesome. The only thing better than eating dinner, having a beer and looking at pups would be if they had live dogs in the restaurant. I understand why that unfortunately cannot happen.

On my past visits I've always gotten the burger. I'm sure you've also heard how great their burger is. I wasn't in the mood yesterday and was feeling a little adventurous so went with the Lamb Meatball sandwich.

It was an excellent choice and I'm glad I ventured out of my comfort zone. It was prepared with cucumber, tomato & red onion salad, tzatziki mayo on a rustic French roll. There were about 4-6 medium sized meatballs that weren't overly seasoned so you could really enjoy the taste of the lamb. The tomato and red onion salad combined with the tzatziki did a great job of adding a little moistness to the sandwich. I know the fries are awesome, but I was trying to be good and opted for the vegetables. It's an even swap with no upcharge, which I always appreciate. The veggie of the day was bourbon glazed carrots. OH MY GAWD!  They were amazing and I could have had an entire dish of them. They were cooked to a perfect not too soft but not too hard state and the glaze tasted like cinnamon. I'd say I was happy with my choices for the evening.

Our server was everything we could have asked for at a pub type establishment. He was on top of his game, courteous and not overbearing.

Not feeling too adventurous with beer, I opted for the Firestone Walker Union Jack IPA. Sometimes a classic is just nice. 

Good Dog is a Philadelphia classic establishments which I wish I didn't overlook so frequently on the hunt for new and trendy. Good Dog. Great place.

Why 5 stars? Because this may have been the best pulled-pork I've ever had. 

   ---   ---   ---

Yep, worth the wait. Worth the hype. Worth the drive. Even worth the flight.

This pulled pork was absolutely heavenly. For the KC people that think STL doesn't do BBQ well... this is a spot I'd recommend visiting when you're across the Show-Me State. 

My only complaint is that I bought a bottle of BBQ sauce to take home, and I didn't feel like it was nearly as good with my own BBQ. Maybe they season the meat to match flavor profiles? Or maybe their BBQ sauce is much better when kept refrigerated? That's something I don't ever do.

I don't remember the sides being anything special, but I think they had Fitz's sodas in the bottle. That's another bonus point, but the meat alone is worth all 5-stars.

I came here for Wild Wonderland with my nephew and he had a blast! He was running around loving all the animals and decorations that they put throughout the zoo. They really did tons of things to keep kids entertained and make the experience really nice and memorable. Workers were really nice and they had a large number of volunteers from my old high school, all working hard even though they weren't being paid. They had plenty of animals to see, even as night fell and you would expect some of the animals to be asleep. Just a really cool place, and I'm happy that I could show my nephew a good time here.

How can anyone possibly add something new about Tampa's  iconic  Bern's  restaurant?  Let me start by saying, I would always recommend  making a reservation. This has been the standard for many years, but the last few years, I have seen people walk in and be seated fairly promptly without reservations. Another thing is customers used to always make an effort to dress up a bit, before dining  at this fine establishment. Now it is not unusual to see jeans & sneakers.
The above statements make me wonder, if the residents  of Tampa are being  complacent  or taking this superb eatery for granted? I certainly  hope we have better manners than to take this restaurant for granted.
There are various  rooms to the restaurant,  each unique, while maintaining the heavy & rich distinctive  decore, that does have a high class underlying  brothel feel to it, in a very good way. All of these rooms are not created equal & my personal favorite is the 2nd one on the left. It seems to be quieter, more room between the tables & it fits my personal tastes. Even their restrooms are ornate and upscale.
My rule of thumb when ordering steak, is to order it with several people, so you get a nice large, thick cut of meat. It used to be all od the sides were ala cart, but now the piping hot, cheesey onion soup, warm bread, fresh veggie, freh ( grown by establishment ) salad & potatoes or rice come with the meal. I love escargot  & their's  is spot on, so I usually begin my meal with the snails.
Bern's was locally sourced and field to table, long before it became fashionable. Never forget their tours of the kitchen, garden, desert  room & wine room, a must for any neubie & occasionally again as the years go by.
A visit to the second floor dessert  room is always a treat after dinner or on its own. Don't Fogel the great steak sandwich served in the bar. The bar is as ornate as the restaurant  and at times a very pleasant  refuge from the bustle of your fellow dinners. The sandwich is substantial & just downright  good eats. They also have burgers available in the dining rooms  and bar. You can usually  kind of make your own burger, by selecting your favorite toppings. These burgers are not for the faint of heart and are very substantial, juicy & delicious. 
I will mention the wine & service in passing, as I did the Desert  Room. The reason for this, it would take 3 more pages to give them their proper acknowledgements.  Suffice it to say from start to finish, this is a most memorable dining experience and one you will not soon forget.
You can depend on excellent  service, without them hovering  over your table.
What's  a  girl  to  do?  I still make reservations & dress for the occasion, I could never take Bern's  for granted.

Have been back 3 more times and I need to just stick to the items I like.  (Salmon Spring rolls - a greasy but tasty indulgence)  Love the Quinoa salad - dressing (sugar-fest) and puree on the side.

Pizza is AWFUL.  (We tried the whole grain crust and it was weird tasting.)
Pasta dish was swimming in a greasy sauce.  (Never again.)
No substitutions on specials.  (Oh, well.)

It's formula cooking and for a bar - 4 stars but as a restaurant it's more like 3.

Service is sporadic and server-dependent.  We've had it great and not-so-great.

Best thing about Good Dog: sweet potato fries with an aioli dipping sauce. I am not a french fry person, but these fries + their aioli is a winning combination.

I also like that they've got a few selections of hard cider, which plenty of places DON'T have. I know this because I don't drink beer, and I often check on the hard cider selection so I don't feel like an ass drinking wine or cocktails while all my fellow companions are slamming back beers. They've got Strongbow and Woodchuck available.

Other enjoyable choices:
-Mussels
-Salmon burger (omgsogoodseriouslyyum!)

I wasn't really a fan of the grilled cheese - they put apples on it. Not quite my style, I prefer my grilled cheese served in a more classic way, but I give them credit for being different.
