Also, a word of caution: the Good Dog Burger is STUFFED with bleu cheese. If that's your thing, order away. If it's not, just beware!

I haven't been here in a little while because I moved out of the area, but I do remember the bartenders being really friendly. This is the perfect place to check out after a long work day.

Back to 4 stars for me.  We came here for the Paraguay-Spain World Cup game.  Large beer selection in bottle and on tap.

I had the honey wheat pizza (less sticky this time), and it was very, very good.  I had a small for myself, took home the leftovers, and had em for lunch the next day.  My husband had the portabella cheese"steak" sandwich and loved it.

We were seated comfortably for the game, which was on a nice flat screen right in front of us, and the service was great.  This was our best visit yet!  They have a World Cup special $15 pizza and pitcher as well as daily shot specials for $3.  We had the $3 Zidane shots, and they were very tasty.

Why 5 stars? Because I have sinned by not trying Jackson's sooner.

   ---   ---   ---

Full disclosure: when I first started Yelping, I was very aware of Jackson's, but I was never in a hurry to visit due to the lackluster reviews. But I come bearing good news, friends:

EVERYTHING HAS CHANGED

We learned during our Yelp event that Jackson's went through a management dispute, that led to some tough times for the restaurant. At this time, that situation has been dissolved, and Jack himself has led a movement to totally transform every aspect of the restaurant. Do not base your opinion off of those 3 yellow stars - Jackson's is practically a new restaurant.

I ordered my 3 favorite items that I sampled at our recent Yelp event: the sexy ben roll, the sexy lobster roll, and the lobster mac-n-cheese.  The result?

These two rolls are the only two rolls I've had in Tampa Bay that compare to my #1 favorite restaurant in the area: Samurai Blue. Completely and totally amazing.

The mac-n-cheese might be my favorite in TB as well. I was recently asked where my favorite mac comes from, and I think the answer might have to be Jackson's. I believe it contains truffle, which is always a quick way to my heart. I guess if I were to be nit-picky, I would love a little more lobster, but at this point, I'm really grasping for straws.

If sushi or mac don't float your boat, there are a ton of great options on this very diverse menu. When you combine an amazing menu, great views, and add in spectacular service - it's tough to beat Jackson's. Whether you're looking for a romantic date, or a casual place to grab a bite with friends, you need to visit, or re-visit Jackson's. Do it, I implore you!

One of my very favorite clients invited me to join his staff for a Holiday party at Texas de Brazil, and I forced myself to strap on the feed bag and join them at this incredible Brazilian steakhouse. Yowzah, what a meal!

Texas de Brazil (TdB) is located along Boy Scout Boulevard in the "Restaurant Row" area near International Plaza. TdB can be found in the same area as Cooper's Hawk and Kona Grill with plenty of off-street parking in their private lot or valet parking for those who know they won't be able to waddle back to their car following the meal.

The steakhouse, or I guess more properly, the "Churrascaria" delivers a stunning array of grilled meats and an extravagant salad bar in a very classy setting. You have the choice of sitting inside at one of the white tablecloth tables, or outside on their patio overlooking the small pond. There also a large bar area with a huge selection of wines on display. The setting is just spectacular.

The wine started flowing early with our group, and the head waiter explained the drill to us. Start your meal with a trip to their elaborate salad bar containing more than 50 seasonal appetizers, gourmet vegetables, soups, and salads. I brought back a cup of their very excellent lobster bisque and then happily munched on marinated mushrooms, white asparagus, hearts of palm, and a cherry tomato, cucumber, and fresh Mozzarella salad to start.

After that it was time to turn our place cards to green and prepare to be swarmed by an army of Brazilian gaucho servers generously carving up various cuts of seasoned beef, lamb, pork, chicken and Brazilian sausage, all accompanied by traditional side items and house-baked Brazilian cheese bread. The meats were brought to our table on long skewers, and the guys just sliced off the cuts of meat onto your waiting plate. 

You can honestly have as much as you want, and they will keep bringing food to your table as long as your place card is turned to green. Flip it to red and you'll have a few peaceful moments to relax and digest, but before long you've flipped it back to green for more meat.

They brought some dessert sampler trays to our group, but I was honestly so stuffed......oh wait, is that cheesecake?

The regular dinner price is about $45, so I know that this wasn't a cheap outing, but I certainly enjoyed an excellent meal with some great friends in a very elegant setting.

Village Whiskey is a tight little place on the corner of 20th and Sansom.  It is amazing how much bigger it looks from the outside, which is why I felt to lead with that note.  

Like the name suggestions, they offer a selection of bourbons and whiskey drinks, along with usual bar fair.  I regret not having a burger after reading their praises here on Yelp!  The food I did have was average for the price and location, although I will say they do have some unique offerings (you can admit it, deviled eggs at a bar is unique).  Service is friendly - maybe to an extreme since I felt a bit awkward as the refills of water came often during mid-conversation.  It has a nice date atmosphere, but be warned the wait for a table can get rather long on weekend evenings.  I say give it a try if you're into more than just beer.

Yummy! Hellas bakery is the place for dessert if you are in the area! When you walk in they have so many cases filled with sweet treats from cookies, pies, cakes, pastries, etc. Making a decision is so hard! 

My family and I opted to order the chocolate and strawberry "lasagna" and the black forest "lasagna". I think they call it "lasagna" since it is layered like one. I loved it! 

For 4 people we enjoyed these 2 desserts and we had some coffee. I even tried a Greek coffee which was surprisingly tasty. 

The girls behind the counter were helpful and answered our questions (even though they were busy as "hell"as...see what I did there? Anyway, the bakery has lots of seating so it was easy to find a table. They also have a restaurant attached, but we did not need lunch as we just finished eating somewhere else. 

I do recommend the bakery for desserts and I can't wait to go back!

OK, I don't eat pork and even still (menu is pork heavy) this places ROCKS my world.

Hands-down best Mojitos (get the classico - don't fart around with mamby-pamby-fruities) and Caipirinas anywhere.  You could drink yourself silly.

The ceviche is fresh and lovely - if just a hiar on the salty side.
The chicken soup came with fresh peas that the ladies shelled that morning.  My husband (back then fiance) had the Lechon - roasted piggy - which I could not eat - but he loved it.  The Vaca Fritta was spot-on old-school style.  EVERY BIT was worth the elevated calorie count.

Yes, it's a "scene" (what Starr joint isn't?) yes it's uber-expensive and YES IMHHHO it is worth it.

Go for a birthday - or if you can expense it, or if a date will take you - but try it - at least once.  It is an EXPERIENCE and I loved every minute of it.

Such a disappointing experience, the only keeping it from a one-star is the COVID factor.

We called Talula's for a special night in and requested a 6:15 pick up.  We arrived and I noticed a 5:30 on the slip, but didn't pay much attention.  Unfortunately, every bite reflected that it had been sitting out for too long.

We got the Talula's Fall Fig "Pizza" and noticed only one side had cheese.  While unusual, not a big deal until we lifted it up to find the cheese clumped on the bottom of the box.  It was clear they had dropped it while setting it in the box and either didn't notice or didn't bother to correct.  I expect a lot more from a premium location such as Talula's.  I will give the pizze credit, even cold it had a decent flavor profile, however, it was also soggy.

The Line Caught Tuna Crudo might have been the only portion of the meal completely worth enjoying.  The mix of jalapeño, radishes, basil, and the syrup (black garlic) came together well.  The sizing was appropriate for the price as well.

Our mains were both letdowns.  The Seared Sea Scallops came with 4 nice sized scallops which is a fair portion. They weren't very good lukewarm and seemed to be a bit over seared. The Tuscan Sangiovese Glazed Beef Short Rib, also lukewarm at best at this point, was not at all tender.  The flavor profile was there, but being chewy just isn't what I was expecting.

Yes, it is COIVD times.  Yes, it is take out. Still, keep in mind this restaurant is high end and we paid a premium for what we felt would be a stellar dining experience. I've been inside on one or two other occasions and cannot believe the night and day change in experience.

I stopped into Devil's Alley for a lunch with co-workers. We had a reservation and were seated promptly. The service was good, and the food was tasty too. I was deciding between the artery-clogging buffalo chicken sandwich and the healthy grilled shrimp salad - I went healthy. The salad was very good with just the right amount of dressing. The shrimp were flavorful and perfectly cooked, though I would have preferred more than 4 shrimp. The portion was OK, but definitely not huge. The side of fries was really yummy and perfectly shared between two salad-eaters. My only complaint was how COLD it was in there when it was 60 degrees outside. I was cold enough that my nose was running but our server said the heat was on? Strange. Anyway, good lunch spot with lots of options to please everyone!

I do like La Teresita, it's just that there are so many excellent Cuban and Spanish restaurants in the Tampa Bay area, that the food and atmosphere here fall a little short. The main room is filled with tables inches apart, which is great for large parties, but a little loud for people who want to have easy conversation. Try and get a booth; better yet, try and get a booth in the quieter back room.

The servers are all males, and they speed about the restaurant, yet I feel like they are never around when I actually need them to take our order, get a drink refill, or get the check. This last visit, the waiter completely forgot our appetizer order (even though I watched him write it down), so when we got our dinner we had to tell him to cancel it.

Food was good, with huge portions, and almost everybody will have leftover dinner to take home. Spanish bean soup was fine, but it didn't have a very rich flavor - the flavors definitely needed to blend more together, plus the broth was very thin. The picadillo was okay, but needed more seasoning-it was pretty bland until I added some hot sauce. I was disappointed that they don't have the Cuban staple, ropa vieja, on the menu every night. Bread comes with every meal, and it was the flattest, most tasteless Cuban bread I've ever eaten.

Fortunately, the tres leches cake for dessert was delicious, even though it didn't look like their dessert menu picture with sauce on the bottom. The icing was super sweet, and I enjoyed every minute of it.  Way to end on a high note!

There are so many things wrong with this restaurant. It is very apparent that they intentionally quote you a much longer than accurate wait time, and I can't figure out why. Two visits ago, we were told it would be an hour and 45 minutes to get a table at 6pm on a Saturday night. Less than 25 minutes later, we got a text that our table is ready. WHAT??

Last visit, we came with 10+ people after work on a Friday. We wanted to enjoy the beautiful weather and intended to have some appetizers and drinks in the beer garden. We were informed that there was no service outside, which was fine...we'd order at the bar and take it out. Apparently, that wasn't okay either. After back and forth, we were told it is because smoking is permitted out in the beer garden. Still ridiculous...and they were rude about it rather than nice and gracious. We were also the only people...ONLY PEOPLE...in the beer garden for the nearly 2 hours we were there. They lost out on hundreds of dollars in additional revenue (and pissed off a group of valued patrons). We left and went somewhere else for dinner and drinks.

If this place didn't have such a great outdoor ambiance, I would never return. I know many others who have said the same. But until there is competition with a similar a waterfront restaurant, people keep going back to Ulele despite it being mediocre and a complete lack of customer service.

I recently read the article about Milagro closing and knew I wanted to get there one last time before it closed. I hadn't been there in a few years but used to really like it. I made it in on a weeknight in February by myself. I opted for a glass of water and ate a couple of chips with salsa while I looked over the menu. Their chips, to me, are perfect. Just the right thickness and amount of salt. The salsa is good but I like just a little bit more heat. I decided on the Guacamole appetizer and the Shrimp & Grits (Jumbo shrimp sautéed in a fiery chile de arbol sauce, served with green chile goat cheese grits and street corn "off the cob") entrée. The guacamole was good and I liked the sprinkling of queso fresco on top but I thought it could have used a touch of salt and little more lime than just the wedge that came on the plate. My entrée, the Shrimp & Grits, was really enjoyable. I loved the mild heat of the chile de arbol sauce and the subtle goat cheese flavor of the grits. It could have been overwhelming but it wasn't. Of course everyone loves the Tilford street corn. It's good. I ate every single bite of food on the plate! I'd rate this food at a solid 4.5 but the service I received was about a 2. I don't think I've ever called out a server by name in a review but Anna could not have cared less to wait on me. I never got a water refill, she never asked if I enjoyed my food, wanted anything else, etc. I think the table I ate at had more personality. My only other comment would be that this is a terrible location and the crowd was most definitely older. I hope they do find a new location, make some staffing changes, and breathe new life into the concept because this food is still really good. It's like they took a Mexican flavor that you love and infused it into a slightly elevated dish. Muy bien.

I didn't love it. I love the decor. I love the location by a spring and the renovated Warerworks Park and Armature Building in Tampa Heights along the Hillsborough River. The food just didn't stand out for me. Nice outdoor seating though and dog friendly! Also very cool and beautiful artwork and even bike rack. :) Also nice upstairs lounge views. Happy to see it thriving and bustling.

The parking is challenging here on weekends but  well worth the 4 or r5x drive around the block.
Food is fantasitc, service just as good. Easily accomodated our party of 20,-50 something diners. Was that what a previous review referred to as senior citizens? Hope not because we had a blast and thats a demographic that spends . Entree after entree was presented, sodas were flowing and the price was right. Our group for sure will be back and spending.

 Its good during the week too.

Think of everything that makes every Han Dynasty kickass.

Now toss on a special late night menu, and keep the place open until 2 AM. In Old City, this is a recipe for success, especially for partygoers.

Disclaimer: Many of their dishes pack a punch, so it helps if your tongue is made of asbestos.

Honestly, I have never reviewed an airport before. This seems a little strange...but I'll give it a try. I guess since I fly into Tampa at least 3 or 4 times a year it is only fair I share some of information about this airport. 
Arrivals-this is a crazy busy section! The attendants seriously will yell at you and blow their whistles if you are parked for more than 10 seconds without movement. They take their job very seriously and unless you are "loading" a new passenger from the pick-up you are not allowed to loiter. They do have an awesome cell-phone waiting lot though with a giant screen to display all the flight information. It's actually not too bad when you go to pick up someone. 
Departures-I can honestly say that every time I get dropped off at the airport it is very simple to find a spot to unload and check-in my bags. I don't thinks this area is ever too busy. 
Security-what can I say about security? It's necessary so I just deal with it. In order to get to the screenings though you have to board a tram! This is my favorite part because I love riding trams at airports! I know, I'm a dork! Take the tram to the security area. Then be prepared to wait at least a few minutes before being screened. The security there isn't too terrible. They do a good job. 
Other than that, the airport is clean and the terminals all have lots to do. My favorite part is grabbing some drinks before a flight. Usually I am sad when I am at this airport because I typically have to say bye to my family...so I have a drink or two and then I feel better. 
For an airport this place is quick and safe. I will be there again soon!

I just don't get it. I never did. It's not bad but I have never been blown away. The steaks are meh and they don't travel. The chicken cutlet is better, but last time it was very dry. The roast pork is usually solid choice. The roast pork with greens and sharp provolone is the way to go but it's messy and you need to eat it there. Skip the fries. If your around in the morning they make a bomb bacon egg and cheese on a long roll. Best thing I ever had there.

I know it's sacrilegious not to bow down to their mastery of hot roast pork and cheese steaks, but I just don't get it. It's not bad. It's often good . But I rarely crave it. The pork is just sliced in jus. It's not special. I make much better at home or I'd rather go to DiNics . To be honest the best ever was the original Shanks on 10th. The last cheese steak was a meaty mess which is unfortunate considering I ate it there. The way people gush bewilders me. I've been going here for a long time. Someone always says it's the best. I do dig the breakfast sandwiches.

After eating at Datz & seeing their generous sweet offerings, I was somewhat  dissapointment in Dough. Everything I had at Datz, was spectacular. Datz had a larger assortment of cakes, candies, cupcakes & sweets than Dough had to offer.
I understand  the difference in the restaurant  cocept, yet it feels redundant & overstated. The staff was not friendly, they were doing a job.
Love Datz, but really see no reason to return to Dough.
What's a girl to do? Sometimes  enough is enough & duplication becomes boring.

Many of the Parkway Poboys including the roast beef which I hadn't had from there in years is pretty bland but the new quick and efficient ordering program makes it a great option for a quick meal. The shrimp, catfish and the sneaky good corned beef are my favorites.

Wow, this TJ's is a lot bigger than the one I'm used to in Jersey. But being in the city means there are far more people to contend with. Even though I wanted to check out all the merch, I couldn't because I felt weird taking up time and space for more than five seconds in any one spot. But I'm guessing Friday evening around 5pm isn't the best time to swing by. 

Backtracking a bit, I knew there was parking but I wasn't sure where. I circled the block twice before I decided that yes, the parking lot with the line into the street was the free lot for Trader Joe's and not a paid parking lot. There was even an attendant at the front to let the next driver know when a spot opened up. We chatted for a bit and he said they mostly do this on weekends and before holidays. Nice. 

The selection of produce was far superior to the location I'm familiar with in Marlton. Actually, across the board, options were plentiful in mostly every area. I couldn't find croutons for the life of me, but I did find about three different styles of pistachios. 

Check-out was painless even with so many people in the store. It seemed like all the registers were open. A hand basket full of groceries came to something like twenty-five bucks. I was also able to get up to $50 cash back from using my debit card. That's more than any other store I've been to. Next time, I'll try to sneak in during the day to escape the masses.

10 years ago today the very first Yelp review was posted to the site by a guy in San Francisco, and so it seems appropriate that I picked today to post my 1000th Yelp review.

I can think of no finer place to spotlight with this milestone review than a restaurant which exemplifies the very best of Tampa's food, drink, architecture, history, and customer service -- and so, Review #1000 goes to... Ulele.

For those who don't know, Ulele Restaurant is named after Princess Ulele, the young daughter of the chief of the west Florida Tocobaga Indian tribe. In a story that seems eerily familiar, Princess Ulele threw herself over the Spanish explorer, Juan Ortiz, moments before he was about to be roasted alive. The Pocahontas - John Smith legend happened 80 years later. Hmmmmmm...

A group of local Yelpers gathered at Ulele about a week ago to enjoy a spectacular meal, and to say Bon Voyage to one of our favorite friends. Eric C has taken a two-year internship in Providence, Rhode Island and so we wanted to send him out in style. With a bit of cunning and deception, we all gathered at the bar at Ulele ahead of time before Eric & Robbie's arrival. The plan was to surprise them, and then all enjoy a wonderful dinner.

The restaurant is located in a refurbished two-story warehouse along the Hillsborough River just north of the Performing Arts Center and Waterworks Park. The weathered brick exterior combined with the modern metal works sculptures is the perfect juxtaposition for this fine dining establishment. Something old - something new - and something WOW! Through the front doors and to your right is the open-air grill and a beautiful bar area displaying colorful bottles and Ulele's house-brewed beers on tap. Keep an eye on the walls for some gorgeous modern artwork and stained glass windows.

While we were waiting for Robbie & Eric to arrive, Head Brewmaster Tim Shackton gave us a tour of the on-site microbrewery, and shared some secrets with us about the delicious Adult beverages that are produced back in his brew palace. Order the Wedding Beer!!!

The hostess snuck our group through the back patio and in through the open doors that face the Hillsborough River. Our group hid our faces behind our menus until Eric rounded the corner, and then it was time to yell "SURPRISE!" and have some fun.

Amid all of the laughter we ordered some very fabulous dishes off their unique menu. The food is an interesting mix of locally-sourced ingredients with Gulf Coast seafood, fresh-from-Florida Beef, fowl, pork, and vegetarian options. I started with a dozen charbroiled oysters and a dash of their homemade hot sauce, and shared my oysters with several people. Others ordered crab mac & cheese, pulpo carpaccio (shaved octopus in a spicy piri piri sauce), okra fries, Florida native chili (alligator, wild boar, vension, and duck), and a wide variety of house special salads.

I added the half-sized Ulele salad, which was mixed greens, arugula, and watercress with baby Swiss, cranberry beans, fire-roasted peppers, onions, and a warm balsamic vinaigrette. Excellent choice as a light precursor to a delicious dinner!

For my entrée I selected one of the specials for the evening which was a dry-aged, 14-ounce NY strip steak topped with sautéed shrimp, and served over Ulele's white cheddar mashed potatoes topped with popcorn & roasted garlic. That came with a side of perfectly cooked string beans. (I confess that half of my dinner came home with me for the next night).

I should pause here to give credit to our servers Sydney and Rodney. Both were extremely knowledgeable about the menu and the food preparation, and they did a fabulous job keeping up with everyone's drink orders and special requests. They remembered what each of us had ordered and helped make some very useful suggestions about pairing entrees with appetizers and so on. Two thumbs up for you guys! 

By now we had bestowed our gag gifts upon Eric including a palm tree tiara, palm tree table centerpiece, woolen hat and scarf, and a tastefully tacky Hawaiian shirt. (Be sure to check out the photos.)

It was finally time for dessert, and wow the choices were fantastic. I ordered a basic dish of their homemade very berry ice cream which arrived at the table as two scoops served inside of a hollowed-out coconut shell. Very whimsical and extremely tasty.

Our surprise dinner for Eric was a huge success, and the folks at Ulele treated us to some incredibly delicious food and home-brewed beers, and then dazzled us with their creative architecture and spot-on customer service. Thank you to Ulele for an amazing evening, and thank you for giving me the perfect spot to honor with my 1000th Yelp review!

The family and I took a trip up to 4 Rivers to check it out and see what all the commotion was about. 

It took us about 30 minutes to get through the line that was out the door. Once up to the counter to order, the meats and sides were on display, and all of them looked good. 

We went with the burnt ends and the sausage with a side of pulled pork. For our side dishes, we ordered the jalepeno poppers, southwest corn, Cole slaw, cornbread salad, and green beans. We both got a biscuit too. 

The southeast corn and cornbread salad were the winners. The green beans came in next and the Cole slaw was underwhelming. The biscuits were pretty tasty too. 

As far as meats, we liked the sausage the best and the burnt ends the least. 

We also got a bayou bar to go-shortbread crust with a cream cheese like center. Good, dense and rich enough to share.

Great good, great drinks, great deals!

Any place that has happy hour specials on drinks I actually want gets an automatic thumbs up in my book.  We came at about 5:45 p.m. on a Tuesday and happy hour had $2 off any cocktail.  I was planning on getting a cocktail anyways so this was just a cherry on top!

I was a little worried about how crowded it would be, but at 5:45 p.m. we got a table no problem.  By 7:30 p.m. when we left, there was a little wait.  You can sit inside or outside.  There are heating lamps outside, but I get cold really easily so we opted to sit inside.  There is definitely funky art and it has a very hip vibe.  However, it doesn't take itself too seriously, so I enjoyed it.

Back to the cocktail, I got the nutters and nanners.  If you can't guess, it tasted like peanut butter and bananas.  This is not a drink for someone who doesn't like sweets or is on a diet.  But since I love sweets, and my diet doesn't include drinks, I decided to go for it.  It was delicious and I would definitely recommend it.

For my entre I got The Roots.  Honestly, I thought it was going to be a salad.  It is described as "Grilled Sweet Potato and Grilled Feta over Parsnip Puree and Herb Vinaigrette".  Ok fine, now that I'm reading it again I have no idea why I thought it was going to be a salad.  Anyways, it turned out to be a whole sweet potato cut in half and a little block of feta cheese.  I did enjoy the little green salad that came on the side.  Overall it was good, but I usually don't eat that much sweet potato.  I ended up taking half of it home.  Still, it tasted healthy and good.

Even if you can't find parking in the back, there is a sign directing you to more parking.  I appreciated that.

I like this place and if I lived close by I would come more often.  Guess I'll just have to wait till I'm in the area again.

Decided to finally try this place recently and it was quite easy to get a reservation on Open Table for a Friday evening.  I was impressed at how quickly we were seated when arriving a few minutes early for our reservation despite the restaurant busting at the seams.  Our server was quick to take drink orders and very personable throughout our entire evening.  She offered excellent suggestions and remained engaged the whole time we were there.  

I ended up sampling the Olives off the starter menu and they were flavored very well.  For my entrée I decided to remain basic with the burger as I wasn't feeling too adventurous.  The burger was cooked to perfection and had a high end feel about it.  The fries it came with were also well seasoned and fresh.  Overall, I can see what all the fanfare is about after having experienced On Swann.  The only negative of the evening was a loud table of drunk, cackling women sitting nearby who were so loud the tables next to us were even put off by them as was our waitress.  The manager also went to them at one point asking them to quiet down, which was telling given how loud this place is in general.

If you live in STL and haven't been recently, you're missing out. This place is as much of a gem as the Science Center, Art Museum, and other favorite attractions. It's simply beautiful. Pack a lunch and have a picnic here... it would be the perfect date.

The food here isn't too bad.  I got the bison burger.  YUM!  I ordered it with the cucumber salad, which lacked taste.  It was crunchy but a bit bland.  The pickle was not as crunchy as I liked it.  The ginger ale was a bit flat.  It's a tiny hole in the wall.  Small space, & not sooo much parking available.  The dessert looked yummy.  The staff was kind, & the food came out fast.

I'm generally only in the Aquarium for adults-only special functions, such as the annual Seagrapes wine and food event last night.

This and the similar, yet more casual beer event in the fall are always extremely well done. 

The participating area restaurants always bring excellent samples of their fare and the silent auction is one of the best in the area.

One of my favorite things about these events is how you wind your way through the inside of the Aquarium eating and drinking while getting so close to all the amazing underwater sights.

Last night was my first time near their rays touch tank and it was amusing to see that a few of the rays actually come up near the edges as if they are craving human contact. (Just know WHERE to touch them of course)

The only thing more amusing at these things is always seeing a few ladies wearing inappropriate dresses drink a wee bit too much of the free booze. Yes, I don't just go to look at the sharks and turtles.

Some of the best Italian food in Tampa!  I would go more often, but carbs seem to go straight to my hips so I can only occasionally indulge.  During my last visit I had the Caprese Salad and the Ravioli Bolognese - both delicious!  The dessert menu is divine... I love the tiramisu and creme brulee so I prefer to split the sampler which includes a trio of flourless chocolate cake, tiramisu and creme brulee.

Parking is a pain in Ybor, I recommend parking in the garage.  The half priced pasta from 4-7pm and $2 martinis ease the pain of paying for parking!

I love the interior of the Royale. It has the vibe of a roadside joint, only its menu--both food *and* cocktail-- is that of something that is much more my speed (that is, decidedly *not* roadside joint). 

Sadly, I was nursing a hangover during my visit, so I stuck with club soda, but I ordered the large garden salad with Match Meat. I was pleasantly surprised by the abundance of fresh greens (mesclun/spinach mix) and cucumbers, tangy balsamic dressing (plenty, if that's what you like. Served on the side in a little pitcher) and the Match Meat, oh my, so so good. I am not normally a fake meat fan, but Match Meat is so tasty and I do believe it would even win over the most devoted of meat eaters. It's similar to a fake chicken patty, grilled with a bit of seasoning and crunchy coating. 

I'm pretty sure I'd be a Royalegular if I lived in St. Louis.

Trendy, unique foods, delicious drinks.

My friend and I stumbled upon this place.  We were planning on eating at Taps before a showing of the Lion King, but they were packed.  We quickly changed course and walked here.  It was also packed, with a 20 minute wait for a table, but they have a full service bar.  We sat on the couch with free standing little tables where we could put food and drinks and we couldn't have been happier.  There are waitresses that walk around to take orders at the couches, so it was perfect.

This place has a great atmosphere.  I could draw serious inspiration for additions to my wardrobe just by looking around this restaurant.  It is trendy without taking itself too seriously.

I got the blackberry sangree and it was amazing.  Super light and refreshing.  I also got the stinky bunz.  I'm glad they aren't actually stinky.  My friend and I were joking about what would happen if the name was literal.  I chose the chili beef and the curry chicken.  Both were phenomenal.  You can substitute lettuce for the bun, but I think that would take away a certain something that makes it so good.  The curry chicken has a sweetness to it that surprised me.  It is definitely unique.

I would highly suggest this place to anyone going to downtown Tampa.

I'll be honest-this is one of my least favorite airports.  It always seems dirty, and there is a distinct 'could care less' feel from the airport employees. Last year when I flew out there was no sense of urgency to get an extremely late plane unloaded and re-boarded.

Today had its own issues  We made it through security easily, even though they only had one person checking in 'regular' flyers.  We headed to our gate, stopping to get coffee on the way, only to be told that the coffee place was out of coffee, cups, and lids. Wait, what? How is that even possible? Managed to scrounge up basic coffee at another little shop, thank goodness.

Pre-boarding I went to use the restroom and my stall was out of toilet paper. It was 8:30 am, so I'm pretty sure the two huge giant rolls weren't all used up just that morning! Obviously, clean and stocked restrooms are not a priority.  Thanks again to the stranger in the next stall for doing the TP under pass.

Will I be back? Yes because I love NOLA, and have no choice of airports.

Stopped in for takeout and got a half chicken and lomo saltado. The lomo saltado was delicious. My husband saved the white meat chicken for me (it's usually my favorite) and unfortunately, it was inedibly dry. Hubs said the dark meat was amazing though, so hopefully my white meat dryness was a fluke. I would definitely go back for both the chicken and lomo saltado.

Why 5 stars? Because my order was simple but delicious.

   ---   ---   ---

I've had Saigon Deli on my bookmark list forever and I can't believe that I was just now finally able to visit. Even crazier, I've been getting massages every couple of months next door at Star Massage and never even put 2 + 2 together that this was THE Saigon Deli with over 500 reviews! But after my most recent massage, I figured it out and decided to stop in here.

I ordered the #2 Banh Mi sandwich and a mango boba slush. Both were as tasty as I could have hoped for. Not only that, but as I write this review the next day, all I want to do is go right back to Saigon Deli again. That's always a good sign when you're craving a repeat visit 24 hours later.

Now that I realize how close this is to my house, I will definitely be back many times!

Had a great experience checking out the new Heights Public Market/Armature Works.  Decided to try it out on a weeknight to avoid the crowds and there was still a good crowd gathered.  The space is ginormous and there are still places in the process of opening up.  I cant wait to see what it will look like fully done with all of the food offerings open for business.  

I ended up trying a pizza from Ava and it was a great portion and service was quick.  I'm a big fan of the original SOHO location's pizza fare and it was nothing less than what you would expect from that location.  A friend of mine had the BBQ and it was also served up quickly and with a generous portion.  The manager at the BBQ place also advised she would be one of the managers at the steakhouse opening soon and invited us to come check it out once it opened.  

I like how many various options there are for food and drink at this place.  The outdoor area is currently limited as the waterfront areas are still under construction.  The only downside is that even with a less than capacity crowd it is very loud inside and hard to hear when your order is called unless you are standing right by the vendor where you purchased your food/drink.

Excellent authentic Vietnamese & Chinese cuisine in Brentwood. Located off highway 64 & Hanley and within walking distance to Best Buy, Sports Authority, Revel Kitchen, Club Fitness, Massage Luxe and the Metro Link. The menu is ginormous with super large portions, samplers, Pho, rice, noodles, wontons, salads & more. They also have a full bar with television for your entertainment needs. The servers are very knowledgable of the menu and accommodating if you desire something be tweaked or specially made. Great for lunch, date night, large groups, solo or take-out dining. 

The dining room is an open space with lots of tables. There is a patio as well as high tops in the separated bar area. Free parking is available in either garage to the east & west of the building. I highly recommend the #121 which is a succulent shrimp dish prepared in a delicious garlic butter sauce with rice on the side to mix as you wish. You absolutely CANNOT leave without trying their Crab Rangoon. 

~Christy

This airport is a little sad, but it has its upsides too! 

Parking is easy to find without walking a lot. Lots of long term parking available at different price points too.

Usually fast to check in, lots of kiosks too.

No body scanners as the standard, at least when I was there.

Some food options.

They are remodeling some areas to make it look nicer.

Small enough to get around easily.

It'll do.

So we .had well-needed Girls night out, so El Vez was the spot. The hostess said bout 1 hour to hour 1/2 wait til table,so we went to the bar. .
That being said, it was packed so we got drinks & stood around, as people left, we were able to get stools , so we ended up just ordering food & more drinks at the bar..
Think there were 3 bartenders -girls, & one guy .The younger guy WAS about the only pleasant one behind the bar. I thought as bartenders -Isn't majority of their pay from customer service ** TIPS??!!!
Our food came out quick, exceptional & well made, everything they make is delightful..just the bartenders up to par.They were all very Unpleasant & attitude. First were at the bar, some people behind us ordering drinks , as they were handing their tabs to pay , she was enforcing a rule, like don't reach over the line, we were  talking & while they were signing & adding gratuity, she Rolled her eyes at them, guess for taking a minute longer then she wanted??! WTH!!?
Wow, never smiled, Don't think she or any of them did, until it was time to pay our tab!! 
Wow, do they need refreshers in customer Service/ Bartending etiquette!!?So Not good!!
Other then that, we had a great time there, couldn't believe what we witnessed.
Hope it gets better, maybe they were having bad night -something!!?
Still loving that $9 lunch special.   With take out, you don't get the soup, but the portions are incredible, and the food is great.

Ulele is one of those restaurants that you think there is no way it can live up to all the hype, and then you go, and it surpasses all your expectations!

I couldn't picture where this was even located, so when I pulled up I was pleasantly surprised at its location next to a park, near the water, with plenty of room to have tables outside.  Valet parking is offered, plus there is free street parking.

The building both outside and in is fabulous.  Made of brick, fitted with industrial-style pipe accessories and cool lighting, they have interesting sculptures scattered everywhere, and unique artwork lining the walls.  TIP 1 - there are at least 2 Picasso signed/numbered prints - find 'em!  I also heard rumor of a Dali, but didn't get to see it.  

At the small but efficient bar, I had one of their specialty cocktails - the Native Summer, a light refreshing Nolet's gin drink which was delicious.  TIP 2 - the unique pictures next to the bar represent their signature drinks - see if you can figure out which is which.  

We were lucky enough to get a behind the scenes tour of the brewery with the charming brewmaster, and you could just tell how passionate he was about this aspect of the restaurant.  There is even a beer garden courtyard area which would be great for hanging out.

Now, on to the food - it was so fun going with a huge group of people, and the passing of plates and sharing of food was a constant.  I was so pleased to taste so many different things.  My personal favorites - okra fries, roasted beet and poached pear salad with goat cheese, charbroiled oysters, Florida Native chili, and the special berry ice cream.  

Other items I enjoyed getting to try but wouldn't necessarily order (again):  white Lima beans and collards (too garlicky), corn beer quick bread (not enough flavor), the chocolate torte (too intense), and my dessert - the Guava Pie.  The pie sounded awesome, but it just had a very odd flavor that even the guava reduction on the side couldn't save.

Everybody we met working in the restaurant was welcoming and engaging.  Our two servers were spot on - friendly, efficient, and knowledgeable - although they need to recognize that when people ask for entree recommendations, they shouldn't list every item! 

So happy to have a place like this in town! Uh..la.la...

This is not just a meal; it's a dining experience.  There's no other way to describe it.  I'm glad we allowed so much time, because our dining experience was 3 hours long - not that you can't bypass some of it if you want, but if it's your first time, like it was for us, you won't want to.

Building:  Separated into rooms w/ names, unique-looking
Menu:  Huge but organized, they have quite a variety
Food:  Tasted the filet mignon - very tender but not nearly as flavorful and juicy as the Delmonico ribeye.  They will ask if you want the fat trimmed.  Wish I would have ordered a larger cut, it was so good!  You will cash out here if you're going to Dessert Room.
Kitchen Tour:  Yes!
Wine Cellar Tour:  Yes!
Dessert Room:  Yes!  Like a separate restaurant, you check in like you have a reservation, interesting use of wine casks to create private little capsules around tables w/ your own music choices, interesting use of wine casks on bathroom doors.  Again a huge menu w/ cake, pie, ice cream, cheeses, dessert-y cocktails, dessert wines, etc.  You pay a separate check in the Dessert Room.

Huge staff, very friendly.

Yes, this place used to be dirty, gross, but they have stepped up hygiene, non-smoking, all vendors have strict guidelines in cleanliness, Love , love the Amish cafe, sit at stool, eat whatever you want, breakfast, huge dutch apples, specials are on board, includes drink dish & side..for usually $4.95 -$6.95 can't beat it!! Wait for seating, but goes pretty quick. Love it there, whatever your heart desires, from Sang Kee , Thai food, Philly cheesesteaks,great places & vendors. Yes, for out-of towners, it can be Overwhelming ..but what a great place!!!

Yummy cookies like the ones they served at the deli on 4th Street.  Here you have many choices and you buy by the pound.  Today we bought some butter almond and chocolate chip oatmeal walnut cookies.  Six cookies were $13.50.  A bit pricey but the cookies are big, buttery, and chock full of chocolate and almonds.  The butter almond ones did not have a lot of flavor but the chocolate chip ones were quite flavorful.

TJ's is a fun place to shop with really friendly, quirky, tatooed and pierced staff.  I think a pre-requisite for employ is that you must let your freak flag fly.  But anyhow, if you go on a non-peak time, it is simply a PLEASURE to shop here.

At "peak" times (like after work or Saturdays) it gets a little crowded and the lines can be long.

But the selection of merchandise is what keeps me returning again and again.
Oh - that and that it's NEXT DOOR to my office.  SCORE!!!

Anyhow, this is not the greatest place for produce - alot of it is pre-packaged, but for FROZEN meals and appetizers, plus non-perishables from around the globe (Thai noodles, Indian curry kits, organic canned salmon, and dried fruits, nuts 7 trail mix.)

My ex-fiance SWORE by their coffee.  (And its a great value, too.)

I love Trader Joe's.

Now if only they' d figure out a way to have an entrance ON MARKET Street.

Fantastic Vietnamese sandwiches.

I wasn't planning to go here, but when I saw the name I remembered I read great Yelp reviews about this place. First of all, parking is a total nightmare. It could have been that I went at noon on a Friday, but there is a small parking lot in the front (all spots were taken) and a small parking lot in the back (all spots were taken). I ended up making my own spot and hoping that take out would be super quick. 

Even though the lot was packed there were still plenty of seats if I wanted to eat there. (I didn't because I kept thinking with each passing second my car was about to be hit by a driver who couldn't get out). I did a mad dash around the pre made food section and grabbed a tofu spring roll package. I wanted to try more, but their favorite meat is pork (I can't eat pork). At the counter I ordered a vegetarian banh mi and then thought about it and changed it to two. Each banh mi is $3.50 which is on the lower side of what I've found in Tampa Bay. 

I was sad that they didn't have a beef option. I saw on the screen that they have a new chicken banh mi, but I thought tofu sounded better. 

It took about five minutes for my sandwiches and then I sprinted out of there. Note that if you spend less than $5 they don't accept card. 

Once I got home I tore open my sandwich and dove in. The bread was crispy.  The tofu was seasoned perfectly. I definitely made a mess around the table. The pickled vegetables complemented the tofu well. The spring rolls were also very good. I made it through one sandwich and half sping roll and I couldn't eat any more. Although writing this review is making me want to go back for more sandwich. 

I am a huge fan of this place and I'm sure I'll be stopping by for more banh mis...possibly weekly.

Columbia is a good restaurant and the show is still amazing but in my last visit today I went without the show and it really is not the same. I ordered a palomilla steak and it came out cold and dry with the lime dried out. I only got a handful of french fries and two plaintains for $17.95. Really it looked like a lunch entree and I still felt hungry after eating it. The same thing happened at the Columbia in Sarasota, so I guess its a chain decision to cut back on the amount of food they are serving to guests. If they want to do that then they should lower the prices. Service was decent and acceptable though the waiter took forever to bring out the check.

I know I'm the minority here but I can't stand cheap furniture. Ikea is one step above Rooms to go. Particle board and plastic is their main themes. Want a lamp? Oh they have plenty of paper ones. PAPER? Really? I want to furnish my house with good solid classic pieces that last. Not some disposable college dorm crap.

Yeah, great, they have a cafateria, with darn good meatballs, but does that make up for the monster lines, the cheap furniture, the shoddy service (or lack theeof) No. not for me.

Sure, I can get some ideas from here to take elsewhere and sometimes I do find that one cute thing I have to get, but to furnish my house from here or buy kitchen cabinets? Forgettaboutit!

Absolutely horrible. We arrived and were promptly seated outside, but after 20 minutes of not being acknowledged by anyone, I went to the front table to request a server. 10 minutes later, someone came out to take our order. I ordered a side salad and my husband ordered the biscuits and gravy.

My side salad arrived, and my husband's meal didn't arrive until 10 minutes after mine. When it finally did arrive, it looked old, disgusting, and the gravy tasted like it had gone bad.

While we were waiting for our food, we saw the busser next to us dump all of that table's drinks in the grass as he was cleaning up. After seeing that, we didn't even want to take a chance with eating our food. 

Disgusting, gross, poor service. Never ever again. I would NEVER recommend this place to anyone.

This is a trendy bakery that serves things like doughnuts with fruity pebbles, salted chocolate chip cookies and red velvet brownies. They also have ice cream and make alcoholic milk shakes. 

Prices are higher than the average bakery, but nothing is expensive. This is a good place to treat yourself to a sugar high.

Apologies to those of you who had negative experiences at the Philly airport.  At least if you're departing from the city of Brotherly Love, you're greeted by Peet's Coffee (albeit the only location in PA...that I'm aware of), a food court, and a variety of restaurants and shops (including the Gap) after you make your way through security, which I know can be a daunting process for many of us.  If you're coming in for the first time from elsewhere in the country (or the world, for that matter), be assured that the city of Philadelphia is far more exciting than the airport and is easily accessible via train directly from each terminal.

I went back to Jackson's recently a few times for some shows and for my Aunt's engagement private party, the nightclub, and for their Mother's Day Sunday Brunch Buffet. All these experiences have been positive. The food selection at Jackson's has improved in the last few years and the DJs and acts they have brought through have also become pretty great. 

For private parties, the service was excellent for a catered engagement party and the price was right for what we received in food and drinks. The service staff was hospitable and the nightclub itself was lots of fun after we finished our family festivities. 

Jackson's has always been popular for their multiple music selection which have all reached some great sets. If you need somewhere to party on the weekends - keep Jackson's on your list.

The brunch buffets are truly excellent, but good luck trying to make it past one plate without getting full - everything looked and tasted good!
You can get the awesome Sarcone's bread. There are a lot of kinds of bread for your carbs need. From brioche to artisanal breads

Oh TIA, how I love thee. After a long 10 days away, there is no better feeling than pulling into the terminal. 

I must say that this airport is easy to navigate and baggage claim is quick and a breeze.

Seriously the most horrendous service ever. I don't know if entire staff was new or what was going on. It was just before dinner rush and they were out of pasta, bacon, steak and very low on other items. Customer in front of us wanted bacon. They told her they were out but there was pan of uncooked bacon waiting on being put in the oven but at this point noone put it in the oven. The young chef walked up  front she asked him about bacon. He did put tbe bacon in the oven and put a few pieces in the deep fryer so she got her bacon and in turn we got ours. The young ladies up front were very disorganized. The guys on the back line werent paying attention. We asked one of the girls to make sure he was getting crispy chicken ready since he was doing other orders ahead of ours. He didn't hear them the first time. We still got good food it just took 3 times longer then it should have or normally does. No need for anyone from corporate to reply to this. Really hope this was just a fluke.

This place is pretty good, but it could be better.

The place is gorgeous.  We were seated immediately in a booth, as requested when I reserved on opentable.com.  

They had an interesting cocktail list, so we started with cocktails.  Their wine list was pretty good too, but we took advantage to their free corkage and brought our own.

We started with the stone crab claws.  We got four large claws that were perfectly cracked.  It was $70, which was hefty but on par with most of the other restaurants of this level.  The crab was slightly frozen.

Then we shared a caesar salad.  It was very good and light, not drenched in sauce.  I liked the small croutons.

For my main course, I had the grouper.  I thought the fish tasted good, but it was a bit overcooked.  My husband had the Kansas strip.  He thought it was well cooked, but the meat quality was not as good as at Ruth Chris or Eddie Vs.  He enjoyed his baked potato.

All in all, it was a fine meal, but it wasn't extraordinary.

The Yelp Eats train stopped at the Duck tonight, and boy am I sure glad it did! I've written two reviews already (some of you have to be thinking, get over it...) so I'm going to keep it short and sweet. Here are the must-haves off the Yelp Eats menu:

-Hush duckies (fried carbs + bacony, oniony goodness)
-Gumbo sampler (because you NEED to try all three)
-Pulled pork flatbread (beyond satisfying and savory, and comes cut with the pieces pulled apart so you really have to do minimal work here.)
-Meatloaf with a side of mac'n'cheese (comfort food to the extreme.)

The best part of my dinner was seeing my fellow Yelp Eaters, Marjie and Lyn! The two glasses of a California red blend was the second best. The third was getting to listen to the live music while we waited out the rain.

I'm pretty sure after three reviews the whole world now knows how I feel about The Shaved Duck. My work here is done.

This airport, is OK, been to worst, but specifically American airlines Sucks! I consider myself computer literate/savvy. But they have those computers now, swipe your passport, check in on monitor. There is a person that mans the 5-6 monitors, but for those older , or not computer literate, how is that helping them?? Like my parents, or older generation who don't even have computers in their homes?? It's ashame they assume everyone knows how to use them. Let alone some had technical difficulties , didn't work properly. Our flight to Aruba was delayed, last year on vacation going to Miami-connecting flight was 18-20 hours delayed. WE had fog, so we stood were delayed 2 yrs, then we stand still on tarp, almost 9am..to take off..by the time we took off, only had 10-15 to get to other concourse in Miami. EVEN IF WE RAN, NO WAY WE WOULD OF MADE IT, OTHER SIDE, PLUS BOARDING 1/2 HOUR BEFORE TAKE OFF. We were done. We ended up getting later flight like 7:30 pm, then delayed till 9pm..so we didn't get in Aruba till almost 11:45pm..basically midnight. Miami was pouring down, so we walked entire concourse, really hate them. I do not like the fact we are victims , due to their errors, nothing we can do. At their demise.

Giant store with cheap offerings.

I love IKEA. The bright colors, the cheap prices, what's not to love. Granted, I am wary about buying furniture from IKEA. I once saw an article cutting into IKEA furniture and showing how everything is hollow. Seriously, for those prices, what do you expect. I tend to stick with buying their goods that are on the first floor (e.g. tupperware, dishes, etc.), but if you're furnishing your first place, IKEA isn't a bad choice.

They literally have everything you need for a home. They also know their audience isn't looking for massive furniture to fill up mansions, so they design accordingly. There are tons of simple, minimalistic designs. I was looking at desks and they have a variety of small desks that would fit in a Brooklyn apartment (I thank my lucky stars we live in Clearwater, so I don't have to go that tiny, however, the option is there). 

They also have a food court with a ton of food options. I haven't tried it, but there was a pretty decent line to get food when we were there. Like the furniture, the food is cheap.

To the far right of the check out lanes, they have an As Is section where you can get discounts on floor models/returned goods. Might as well stop by to see if they have a great deal.

The parking lot is massive, so you don't have to worry about finding a spot. Additionally, they broadcast bird of prey sounds so you don't have to worry about birds pooping on your beloved vehicles!

Morimoto lite with a very creative menu.

I really like what Doma is trying to do here. They have intriguing specials and a solid sushi lineup. They throw a bunch of Korean dishes into the mix which is great. Smelt Roe bi bim bap is something that intrigued me and I will have to go back for it. Anyhow, here is what I ate:

Korean BBQ Tacos - OK. They were nice and meaty but lacked the real kick that I was hoping for(like those at Meritage).

Salmon Flatbread - Flatbread with guacamole, tuna, and spicy mayo. It was wacky and I enjoyed it a lot.

The Island roll - Solid. This is a great concoction of salmon, spicy aoili, tempura crunch, mango, and wasabi tobiko. The mango and spicy aoli work very well together, like a set of twins in any fighting movie.

California roll with soft-shell crab - Tastes like a california roll with soft-shell crab.

The ice cream trio and Japanese waffle desserts are A-OK.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is Apocalypto.

The Royale is a cross between Sanctuaria and The Bleeding Deacon... if that's even possible. 

Every time I visit The Royale I tell myself I need to come back more often. This place is right up my alley. This bar features rockabilly bartenders, kick-ass eclectic and unique drinks, a hip but not trendy feel, and a comfortable patio. I've worked in a bar for most of my life and enjoy places that take pride in their drink menu and preparation. I could spend hours at places like this trying different drinks throughout the night. 

I've never eaten here but everyone says the food is good.

Reserving the right to update and potentially change my mind about this development when it is actually finished, I felt like I should have been wearing a hard hat on my visit.

I'm a little suprised this place is even open as so much of the building and surrounding area look, sound and feel like an active construction zone. 

There are others who have already said on this page that what is currently open feels too much like a food court and I have much the same impression.

That said, it has no cosmetic resemblance to a mall food court because it is all concrete and brick plus there is a huge bar at the south end that more resembles the stylish bar at Davidoff & Geneva across from International Plaza.

Still, it is basically food next to food next to food right now and I found it more like something you'd find at a Disney Springs, a modern baseball stadium or on the ground floor of a casino and hotel in Las Vegas. Of course, all three of those are connected to other obvious activities to have a built-in customer base and not exist as the sole destination.

Currently, a parking lot is designated for guests and it is free. However, the inside was not very busy and the lot was pretty much full. I'm guessing parking will become an issue as the project proceeds and there doesn't appear to be any plan for a garage, which is at least one thing that Centro Ybor got right when it first opened.

After people visit here once because they are curious or twice to take a friend who is curious, I wonder what the reason will be to visit a third time. Perhaps some of this construction will eventually answer that question and offer more options than just a place to get a casual bite to eat.

The husband and I decided to give this place a try and we were not disappointed. 

Reasonably priced, we decided to start with the pork belly nachos. With a wonderful mixture of Asian and Mexican, they were a great party in our mouths. 

We both went with a salad-I opted for the BBQ chx salad and he ordered the blackened chx Cobb. Both were relish!

Would I give CHW a second visit?  Why yes I would. Everything that we saw come out of the kitchen looked fantastic. 

If there is a little wait, they have a bar and a wine tasting area for your enjoyment.

The barbecue ribs here are good and everything else is just okay.  Service is on and off, depending on your server. Some can be off on the former planet known as Pluto and others are fantastic. Beer selection is decent.

I hate giving them 3 stars because I really, really wanted to love this place, but I didn't. 

We arrived around 7pm on a Saturday. Yes they were busy, but not slammed. We were seated outside after only waiting 10 minutes. Our server quickly greeted us, but that's where the quickness ended. 

We ordered the hummus of the day-spinach and feta. You would have thought we ordered a very complicated appetizer because it honestly took about 20 minutes to receive. It was good, but not worth the $8 nor the wait. 

For dinner I ordered the "roots" which basically had a really great arugula salad with pecans/balsamic dressing, parsnip purée with a semi cooked sweet potato on top. Like I said, the arugula pecan salad was really good but that was about it. My hubby ordered a chicken Cesar salad. Good but not worth the $17 price tag. Sadly this took about another hour to receive. 

All in all, a hummus app and 2 easy entrees cost us 2 hours!  I don't know what the deal was, but honestly we should have been in and out in a little over an hour considering the entrees we ordered. 

Would I go back?  Yes but to try their soul food Sunday experience.

International Plaza is Tampa's premier shopping experience, and hugely popular with out-of-town guests. The mall is located right near Tampa International Airport, and many of the nearby hotels offer free shuttles to this mall. If you're driving, then you'll find International Plaza at the northern end of Westshore Blvd, along Spruce Street / Boy Scout Blvd.

The mall is anchored by three primary department stores: Dillard's, Nordstrom, and Neiman Marcus, and there is now a Renaissance Hotel attached to the mall. Inside the two-story mecca to retail therapy you'll find over 200 specialty shops with just about everything you can imagine for high-end fashion, jewelry, accessories, electronics & entertainment, housewares and home furnishings, and on and on.......nice quality stuff!

Outside the mall is Bay Street which is an open-air plaza of fine restaurants, bars, clubs, and small boutiques. At Bay Street you'll find the Cheesecake Factory *insert singing chorus of heavenly angels right here*, The Capital Grille, Brio's Tuscan Grille, Ocean Prime, and Zen Bistro mixed with popular clubs such as Bar Louie, Blue Martini, The Pub, and more.

The mall is spacious with lots of natural lighting and comfy leather seats throughout the walkways, which is terrific in the event that your dearly beloved ducks into Victoria's Secret for some intimate shopping, and you're turning bright red with embarrassment as you follow her into the store. Why look, a nearby seat......yes, you go right ahead and keep on shopping....but please put down the see-through nightie before someone sees us!

International Plaza is a place where people dress up to go shopping. The ladies are dressed as nicely as the store mannequins, so it's a great place to people watch as you do your window shopping and power walking around the mall.

One new section at International Plaza is the play area for the little rugrats sponsored by Busch Gardens. This creatively-themed space allows the children to use their imaginations to imagine that they're spending the day with the live animals and roller coasters at Busch Gardens while their folks catch a quick breather in between pushing the double-wide stroller down the walkways.

Lots of interior shops for coffee and tea, along with a California Pizza Kitchen, a Bistro, and a full interior food court.

There's a lot to see and do at International Plaza, and it's a great way to get some exercise while walking around and enjoying all of the terrific shops!

There were things that I really liked about the Continental.  I liked the big gummy bear chairs on the second floor, the roof top bar was nice, the brussel sprouts were very good, and they had a bottle of liquor that I had never seen before (Plymouth Sloe Gin).  

I didn't like how slow the service was at the roof top bar (they could have really used another bartender up there.  I also didn't like that I was charged more for using a credit card than for using cash.  My friend and I ordered the same drink, We were both told $12, he paid cash and paid $12, I paid by card and was charged $13.20 or something like that.  I was told that this was due to "tax" but apparently the tax is only applied when you are using a card.

Overall, not a terrible experience, and it is someplace that could be really interesting.  For right now, it is good enough, but could be better.

Milagro is a new age Mexican restaurant located in the rear of a newer retail complex in Old Webster Groves. It's a great restaurant with fresh ingredients and food. 

-Parking-Ample 
-Decor- Upscale and nice, but monotone. Great metal chandeliers! 
-Margaritas - Fresh and homemade ($8) 
-Chips with both sweet and smoky salsas. Yum 
-Queso fundido -chihuahua cheese w/ poblano rajas and chorizo WOW! 

We were considering ordering the mole because we heard it was amazing. The owner was kind enough to bring out a sample of the sauce and it did not disappoint. We ordered it, but I wasn't thrilled with the squash medley and rice that accompanied the dish.  In addition, the chicken was difficult to eat. It was sauced up and on the bone. So, too messy to eat with hands and too bony to eat with a fork and knife. Still, it was VERY tasty. 

They ran a special for the night - barbacoa de cordero. HOLY BEJASHUSH!! Juicy, tender lamb seasoned with cumin and other nummy ingredients, served with crunchy Mexican squash and corn cut fresh off of the cob. I hope to see this on the menu again.  

I highly recommend Milagro. They put a spin on traditional Mexican fare and the restaurant serves fresh homemade food with all fresh ingredients. I for one appreciate fresh ingredients, which are truly hard to come by.

This is the place that made me believe that there were better cheesesteaks than Pat's.  And to top it off, they make a decent roast pork sandwich, and a good chicken parmesan sandwich too.  I have had a steak and egg sandwich in the past here which may not be for everybody, but it made me happy.  I tell all the out of towners to go here now.

Everyone said "Piada is like an Italian Subway", and it's true.   I would say it's more like Chipotle because the decor is a little more subdued than a Subway and piadas are more like burritos than sandwiches.

Piadas (burritos made with flatbreads) are very good.  First you decide if you want a piada, pasta bowl or salad bowl.  Then you pick a meat and a sauce.   Then you pick all your vegetables, cheeses, seasonings, etc.).   Pay at the end of the line.   Fill your own drink at the beverage station.    Sit down.   Enjoy.

There are definitely more people working here than at a typical Subway.   At Subway you'll find 2 to 4 people working.   At Piada, I counted at least 11 people behind the counter.    1 person is in the back constantly cooking the meats so you know it's going to be fresh.

I love the Vespa-themed decor here.   Very retro-cool.

It was packed when we came here for dinner on a Sunday night and I don't know if that's always true or if this place still has a buzz about it.

I'm not sure I will be coming here regularly because it's pretty pricey for a quick serve restaurant.   A piada will cost ~$10 and I can go to a chain Italian restaurant and get a bowl of pasta, garlic bread (maybe a salad), and be served by a waiter for about the same price.   Of course I'll have to drop a couple of bucks for a tip, but totally worth it.

Amazing as always, and with a great, lively yet classy ambiance.  It was very busy even at 8:30 pm on a Sunday.  

Some highlights from dinner:
1. Warm fava bean salad: Citrsuy with a sherry vinaigrette, peppers, onions, and lima beans.  Solid and great topped with the thin-sliced machengo.
2. Short rib flatbread: Amazing with flavorful cheese and the most tender, flavorful short rib.  A must-try.
3. Pan seared trout with browned butter: Very tender with the perfectly crispy exterior in a creamy butter sauce.  Delish.
4. Lamb meatballs: Flavorful and juicy in a spiced cream-based sauce with green peas.  A bit salty but very good.
5. Complimentary tuna salad with crispbread: Creamy and perfectly paired with the spiced and seasoned paper-thin flatbread crisps
6. Almond cookie: Great version of the standard almond thin cookie.

Service was great and the portions perfect.  Still a Philadelphia staple, for sure, and truly deserving of its reputation

Up until today, I had only experienced their steak sandwiches.  Today, along with the wife and friends from NY looking for a real cheesesteak experience, I decided to get the roast pork.  

After having the roast pork, I'm now ready to call this place the best sandwich spot in Philadelphia, by far!  And by the way, the New Yorkers are going to be dreaming of their cheesesteaks for a very long time, they tell me.  

The pork was just marinated perfectly, and sat on the roll with the spinach and provolone to create a perfect combination.  Not too much spice to it, just the right amount of juice, just wonderful!  And by the way, they make some pretty decent onion rings and fries to boot.  

And... oh yeah, having their cheesesteaks a few times now in recent years, they changed my outlook on the sandwich.  I now turn my nose up at places like Geno's.  And now I'll only go to Tony Luke's if John's isn't open.  I think it's the best cheesesteak I've had in my 40 years so far.  

And thank goodness they are open on Saturdays now.  I see a lot more business coming their way in the future.

They take credit card. One line for steaks and another by the register for roast pork. Best steaks in Philly, hands down. The sandwiches are all made to order. Steak is on a seeded roll, and the inside of the bread is taken out to maximize the amount of meat and cheese in there. It's all cut in nice ribbons and not running with juice, making for a sandwich that is amazingly seasoned and not soggy. The roast pork is also super tasty. Just like the steak, it's so well seasoned and the pieces of meat are super succulent. Worth the travel.

As with most Starr establishments, Parc is style over substance.  Many of the "French Bistro" touches are spot on - like the $10 French Onion Soup - which is EXCELLENT, down to the fixtures in the W.C.

Service was odd.  Great at first when we arrived at 6:15 and once we hit 8 PM it was spotty - we were sometimes ignored (like when the soup arrived with no spoons) and then at times hovered over.

In our party of 3 only one of us ordered a "true" entree - Branzino - which was delicious.

My friend and I decided to share the duck liver mousse (delicious and light - but small amount of mousse and HUGE amount of grain mustard - I mean, who needs THAT much mustard.)  It was also served sans cornichons - a sacrilege - but 3 small french pickles were brought right away (thankfully for no charge) upon request.

The seafood cocktails - shrimp, crab (2 legs for $18 - ouch) and lobster all were effortless to eat.  ($16 for 4 shrimp - eeek!)  My friend and I were still hungry so she got the French onion soup (and I helped!) which quickly killed our appetites.  (Heavy - but sweet and not to salty and delicious.)

Profiteroles for dessert were very good but not orgasmic.  (And I had been eye-ing them all evening.)

So would I return?  Hell, yes!  But will I run right back?  Heck, no!

Having lived in Tampa as long as I have, I haven't had the opportunity to actually experience the aquarium until recently.  I was a bit set off by the parking fee and the admission prices, but you only live once right?  I felt like a kid reliving my youth with all the kids around who were amazed by all the colorful fish, Florida wildlife, and various birds that we encountered.   My favorite exhibit was the lemurs.  I could watch them for hours as they seemed amazed by all the human visitors they had that day.  

It was very educational for me as well to see all the different fish species and the bios that were posted by each tank.  Despite it only taking a couple of hours to go through the whole aquarium, it was a very enlightening experience for me and to see something unique that Tampa offers.

Have I fallen down the rabbit hole? I feel like I have entered Wonderland! Upon entry I am in a bookstore and as I walk down the hallway there are treats in every corner. Scented candles and pretty journals are arranged decoratively in every nook and cranny. Buddy Brew coffee bar is located next to the atrium. As I walk towards the back, facing Kennedy Blvd., there is a restaurant packed full of diners.   

Reservations are strongly recommended. It appears everyone has found out about about this unique coffee haven! The restaurant decor is very modern. I loved the huge windows in the restaurant facing my alma mater, The University of Tampa.  I could not have asked for a prettier view while we ate lunch!

My husband ordered a drip coffee that was served in a beaker. It was good and strong!  My sister and I ordered a pot of the Jasmine Pearl tea and a pot of the Chai tea. The tea pot held about four cups of tea.

We started off our meal with the tuna tartare and the kale chips appetizers. I make my own kale chips at home and never thought about making dipping sauces for them. The spicy chili sauce was great! At $7.50 they were a little pricey so I would skip ordering these next time because they are not very filling. I would highly recommend the tuna tartare... so fresh and so tasty! I almost didn't want to eat it because it was decorated in the perfect tower of avocado, cucumbers, scallions. My sister and I ordered the steak sandwich with sweet potatoes after seeing the recommendations on Yelp. We loved the huge portions of steak and cheese melted between the most delicious bread!

Prices are a tad steep which will probably keep me from being a regular, but I will be back!

My girlfriend and I went for lunch. Snatched a booth up-front right away. Our server was very personable.

We both got cheeseburgers and fries. I got a double and ditched the bun ($7.50). She got a single ($6). All sandwiches come with fries, or you can sub onion rings for $1.

Great hand-pattied burgers with good beef taste. Lettuce, tomato, onions and pickles were fabulous accoutrements. 

The fries were abundant. We both left about half on our plates. They were good and hot -- crispy on the outside, soft on the inside.

We arrived relatively early and when we left, there were folks waiting.

I have been to the mountain and eaten the brisket. WOW!

That's all you would need to say to a die-hard 4Rivers fanatic, and that would earn you a fist bump and nod of respect.  However since most of us have not yet sampled Brett's favorite culinary mecca of smoked meat yumminess, let me elaborate for the uninitiated. 

4Rivers is a chain of BBQ smokehouse restaurants which started in Winter Park, FL under the control of Pitmaster extraordinaire John Rivers. John spent 20 years in the healthcare industry before retiring as president of a billion-dollar company. During that time, he had the opportunity to travel the country, honing his taste and talent for brisket perfection. 

4 Rivers Smokehouse began with the launch of the "Barbecue Ministry" in 2004, when John hosted a cookout fundraiser to support a local family whose young daughter was battling cancer. This one event resulted in a passion for supporting local schools, churches, and charitable organizations. He opened his first smokehouse restaurant in 2009 and has been slowly expanding his empire since then. This newest 4Rivers location in Tampa opened today at 11am, and I was one of the first people through the doors for the Saturday lunch rush.

According to a story in yesterday's Tampa Bay Business Journal, the 4Rivers crew started prepping and smoking 960 pounds of brisket last night. (Yup, that is nearly half a ton of moo cow!) They were also smoking nearly 500 pounds of pork, and major amounts of chicken, sausage, turkey, ribs and more for the grand opening celebration. Justin Clermont is the General Manager of the new Carrollwood location, and he was walking through the dining room and shaking hands with everyone as we were happily munching away on the smoked meat goodness.

You walk through the front doors and snake your way up to the front counter where the guys will take your "meat" order. Beef brisket is the king, along with pulled pork, burnt ends, sliced pork, smokehouse turkey, Texas sausage, smoked chicken, ribs, and wings. Your food is placed on a metal tray covered with a piece of butcher's paper. You can also order sandwiches and salads.

Your tray is slid over to the ladies scooping up the sides, and you have your choice of cornbread salad, fried pickles, mac n cheese, baked cheese grits, BBQ beans, potato salad, Smokehouse corn, Southern-style green beans, French fries, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens, bread pudding, sweet potato casserole, smoked jalapenos, and your choice of cornbread or a biscuit.

From there your tray is slid to the cashier where you can add on drinks, bottles of sauce, homemade seasonings, and gift cards. You gather up your metal tray and then walk past the Sweet Shop  where you'll be taunted by cupcakes, "cake bombs", wedge o' cake, fried Oreos, pudding cups, and Kolache which is a type of pastry that holds a dollop of fruit rimmed by a puffy pillow of dough. 

Assuming that you make it past the Sweet Spot without dropping into a frothing diabetic coma, you then wander towards the back of the dining room to collect your plasticware and fill your fountain drink cups. Then it's out to the main dining area where the long tables are set out to encourage Texas-style family dining. Don't plan on an intimate little 4-top dinner. You'll have neighbors to your right and to your left, whether you like it or not.

The 4Rivers staff was constantly circling the dining area to say hi to everyone, refill drinks, bring over to-go containers, and answer questions. They stopped to tell us about the Pitmaster loyalty program where you can earn points and free treats for being a frequent diner at 4Rivers.

For lunch I ordered a plate of their legendary brisket, and the guys gave me a generous taste of burnt ends on the same platter. That came with three sides, and I selected fried okra, mac n cheese, and baked cheese grits. And the whole meal came with either a biscuit or cornbread. I highly recommend the cornbread!
