The brisket was juicy and tender, and the homemade sauce was a perfect complement. 4Rivers has other homemade BBQ sauces, pepper sauces, and pepper vinegar out on the table. Very yummy meal, and well-worth a visit!

Most consistently running Happy Hour in the area.

The only time it is NOT Happy Hour at Kona Grill is before 3pm on a weekday. That's not a misprint. 

Sure, you must sit at the tables near the bar, the bar itself or the patio outside to get the specials...but what's wrong with that?

I can always count on Kona for these great daily specials on beer, wine, cocktails and plenty of really good menu items. Fire Rock on draft seems to only be available here and at Charley's, so that's a plus for both spots.

When the kitchen messed up recently and my ticket time was 30 minutes for a basic item, a manager immediately made it right with me and sincerely apologized. The guys behind the bar usually remember repeat customers, although they can get a little scarce near closing time when I'm trying to pay my check.

While I don't eat sushi, the friends I have taken here have all endorsed Kona's offerings and there's plenty of versions on that Happy Hour menu to keep them happy. I stick to the sliders, large flatbreads or those fantastic bulgogi tacos. You only get two, but they are surprisingly filling.

I'm giving this place 4 stars because of its uniqueness and the need for this type of establishment in Tampa. 

We arrived at 630 on a Sunday night and immediately checked in for your reservation. We waited about 10 minutes to be sat, which was great considering this place was hopping and quite busy. 

The menu is "floridian" and local. There was menu items with gator, cornbread, grits, pompano etc. 

We opted to place an order for the jalepeno cheddar quick bread muffins. There was 4 in the order and they were quite tasty and went will with our side salad. 

For our entree we ordered the pompano, the grouper and the flank steak. The winner was the flank steak, sadly the pompano wasn't all that great and I wouldn't order it again. The grouper looked pretty tasty. 

After dinner, our server walked us outside. What a lovely set up!  It's right on the water with a huge field. Big enough actually that you could host a private party on the grounds. There is also a Biergarten and a hidden roof top bar. So cool!  We took a mini tour of the brewery and had samplings of the wedding beer (get this!) and the pale ale. 

This is definitely a place to take out of towners and locals alike to give them a true taste of what Tampa has to offer. Well
Done, ulele!

This place is my favorite. The employees are super friendly and helpful, and the prices are excellent. If you like Indian food, you have to try their frozen saag, chana masala and whole wheat naan. YUM! I only wish I could make my coffee taste as delicious as their sample coffee. Parking is a bit of a pain, but that's to be expected in the city.

If I were a fan of brevity, here is how this review would go:

Go find Charles H.'s review and do exactly what he says. The end.

Since I am not a fan of brevity and love to hear myself type, I will elaborate on my experience. First, I must mention that had Charles not written his review, or explained to me that this is more than just a dive bar, I would have never been back here except during the block party. Now that I have, I can guarantee I will be back.

The restaurant at Parasol's is located atop the bar area. Enter from the outside if you're special, or be like me and enter through the bar. Ordering is pretty straightforward and is done at the counter clearly marked "Ordering". 

I followed Charles' advice and went with the BBQ Pulled Pork Po-Boy with the added grilled onions. The sandwich was jam packed with rich and saucy pork shredded like a debris roast beef. But this was no normal po-boy. This thing was damn near perfect. The way the pork, slaw and onion flavors merged together made me literally exclaim "wow" after each bite. 

The only reason I went with four stars instead of five was the speed of service. I know good food takes time, but the place was empty. I didn't time it, but I'd bet it was at least 20 minutes or more before the food arrived. Being that I have limited time for lunch, I would've liked more time to savor that pork. 

If you want an amazing sandwich in an old school New Orleans place, look no further than Parasol's.

When any business steps up their game, I update my review and so I shall do the same with Louis Armstrong New Orleans International AIrport!

I again like it. That's right. Suck it, haters. I've been to more airports in the world than I care to think about. I have those I hate (Midway, Laguardia, DTW), the ones I tolerate (SFO, JFK, Denver) and then there's the ones I like (Milwaukee, KCI) and now I'm going to add Louis Armstrong to the "like" list.

My issues in the past: scarcity of bathrooms. Improved! They were apparently doing renovations when I wrote the last review. 

Other than that, everything seems quicker than ever. Bonus points for the cute security guys who are really nice to you when making fun of your DL, too. Plenty of businesses (local coffee from PJs rather than sucky Starbucks gets major points, too). Food options could be better, I suppose, but I've yet to find decent food options in any airport

Plus, hello, it's named after Louis Armstrong. That alone gets it points above an airport named after, say George Bush, which I knew I'd hate just on principle and wow, did it live up to my expectations. 

And on that *note* (har) the piped-in music is back to greet you to this most glorious city.

Bern's is one of Tampa's most unique restaurants. The restaurant doesn't look like much from the outside, but once you step in it feels like you are in a rich uncle's castle. The walls are decorated with lavish paintings and the floor is covered in plush red carpeting. Most dining rooms only contain five to ten tables; creating a romantic and intimate setting. The waiters can answer any question about the menu and are super attentive.  

All of the steaks come with a complimentary cup of french onion soup, house salad, a baked potato and vegetable side dish. Depending on which steak you order your meal will run between $32 to $245. (The $245 steak is 60 ounces so bring your appetite!) *No substitutions are allowed, but you can order items a-la-carte at an additional cost.  I would be careful not to order too many appetizers and a-la-carte items with your meal or you won't have room for dessert.

After dinner enjoy a tour of the restaurant's kitchen and massive wine cellar. The wine cellar will impress wine aficionados and connoisseurs. Do not skip the Harry Waugh Dessert Room upstairs! The private, intimate booths are the perfect romantic spot to enjoy dessert and coffee or an after dinner drink. Everyone must experience Berns at least once!

TIP: If a steak dinner at Bern's isn't in your budget sit at the bar instead and order Tampa's best burger in town!

I enjoyed a recent team lunch here. 

The burger is very juicy and quite tasty. But the cheesesteak egg rolls were the real hit. I'd eat those in a meal alone. 

I didn't get a drink. Maybe next time.

I believe Tony Lukes is classic South Philly institution. One everyone must try! It's a no thrills take out only joint with a few tables out front. You'll be given a taste of that South Philly hospitality/'tude, and definitely a hearty dose of that unmistakable accent.

I remember coming here when I was just a little girl with my parents. We drove all the way down to the city just for these sammies! I of course as a young vegetarian was ordering broccoli rabe with a nice thick slice of perfectly sharp provolone and the 'rents would always go for the Chicken or Pork 'Italiano'. Both served on crispy Liscio's rolls which are baked fresh daily and thick enough to hold the generous amount of food stuffed into them. We would all split an order of cheese drenched fries and all leave totally satisfied. Worth the trek. 

Over the years I progressed to a vegan and really had no reason to go to Tony Luke's. Until last night that's is....I was with the extended fam bowling down the street. After a few pitchers of brews they were craving cheesesteaks to cap the night off. My brother informed me the menu over here now has a sammy called 'Uncle Mike' which is sweet and hot peppers, broccoli and spinach rabe (cooked in oil not butter), sautéed onion and red "gravy" which for those not from the area, that's tomato sauce. I made sure to ask for no cheese but it wasn't listed on the menu. The rabe was just as I had remembered it!! Tony Luke's hands down makes the best broccoli rabe in all of South Philly! Trust me, I've tasted my fair share. It's not bitter as it can sometimes be and it's not too oily. It's perfect. I ordered the 'Uncle Mike' with the "gravy" on the side thinking it may make it too mushy. Dipping was the way to go I believe. The sammy had a real nice kick from the peppers but the sauce cooled my mouth down. Perfect combo! I even had half leftover for lunch the next day! It was a big boy! The roll still wasn't soggy even then! Win! I will definitely be back for this bad boy again soon. This actually may not be the best discovery, but it's certainly nice to have a veg option when the fam wants steaks now!

Tony Luke's offers so much more than cheesesteaks. I guarantee there's something here for any craving you may have! 

Their meat is hormone and antibiotic free. Their veggies are grown in South Jersey and prepared in the Luke family's commissary in the city. I love that local love! Each sandwich and food item is cooked to order and takes the appropriate amount of time. Be patient. There will always be a wait on game day and especially after a home game of any kind. Fun atmosphere though. Well, if we win that is :) 

"Luke" is a pretty interesting guy which makes me like his joint even more. Check out their website for his whole story. Way too much to tell! In short, he's a CAPA grad who has produced music and films, acted in movies, and created and hosts the web series "Food Mashups". He has also been on many Food Network Tv shows such as "Throw-down With Bobby Flay". I always like a good Philly born and bred success story especially when folks stay true to their roots. Nice! 

*They now sell their sliced rib-eye at Acme for those interested in making sammies at home.

I am glad I found this little beauty!! I took a picture of menu because it describes the fried egg Cheesesteak better than I can. I went to their 2nd location on 13th near Hamilton. BYOB let's get that out there right away. This is the front runner for next year's best brunch cheesesteak. Great fun helpful atmosphere which is a direct contrast to the industrial architecture. Breakfast, home fries, cheesesteak meat, cafe lift special sauce and ability to bring my own booze!! Love you cafe lift!!

Milagro has some tasty items on their menu. Traditional Mexican food with a modern twist! 

What I like most about Milagro is that on a Friday night I can use the No Wait app when I leave my house and arrive just in time to check in with the host and be seated pretty quickly! They do get pretty busy on a Friday night so using the No Wait app has been helpful. The service at the host stand is quick and easy. 

My first visit was a while ago and it was a busy night. Our server came over to take our drink order (I ordered a margarita -obviously) and within a few minutes we had some drinks and some chips and salsa on our table (complimentary). We also ordered some guacamole for the chips and I am so glad we did! Our server that night was really helpful in explaining the menu and gave us some good recommendations. I opted for the fish tacos since it was lent and a Friday night. My meal came with 3 tacos and some rice and beans on the side. I can't remember what my husband ordered, but I do know that he also ordered a side of the street corn for us to share. Our food came out quickly and was all very delicious. We enjoyed the service and the food and were already talking about another visit before we left. 

My most recent visit was just last weekend. We visited again on a Friday night and used the No Wait app. When we arrived we were seated right away and our server was super friendly. She took our drink orders and made some recommendations. I asked if I should order the sweet potato tacos or the mushroom and spinach quesadilla. She told me that the sweet potato tacos had a nice heat to them which right away meant I should not order them since I do not enjoy spicy foods. It was settled. I ordered the quesadilla! Mu husband ordered the combo 72 which had a lot of items to try. It was a good choice for him. We each ordered a corona to enjoy with our meal which was a good choice! 

Once again, the service was great and the food was hot and delicious. I was unable to finish my meal and so our server boxed it up for me and I ate the second half at home the next day. 

Milagro is my go-to place for modern Mexican. Their tacos are tasty and the quesadilla was just what I needed. I would order it again!

I can't believe I have yet to review Alma de Cuba.

Let me say that I've only been here for drinks and dessert. I'd love to come for dinner as everything that I've seen come out of the kitchen looks and smells amazing, but I just haven't had the chance yet.

My favorite thing about this place: the black cherry caipirinha. Wooooo hoo, talk about a strong and tasty drink! It always comes out tasting the same, and it's always perfect. No matter how hard I try to replicate this at home it never works. I'll continue to go here just to quench my thirst.

I also had one of the best desserts of my life here. It was a chocolate peanut butter bomb. Given a name like that, I had high expectations. They were met. What came out was a chocolate graham with peanut butter mousse and chocolate ganache piled on top, and the whole thing was coated with chocolate. It came with a side of MARSHMALLOW ICE CREAM and a chocolate pretzel. When I was done eating it I did feel like a bomb went off in my stomach, but it was completely worth it to have this tasty confection.

Will return - for drinks, dessert, dinner, whatever!

Home Wine Kitchen is in the space previously occupied by Nosh on Manchester in Maplewood.  The interior decor is nice, and I particularly like the changes in color on the wooden wall.  And it looks nice how the chalkboard behind the counter shows their featured red and white wines.  Only thing we'd change on decor is the napkins - maybe a crisp white or brighter color to offset all the beiges and browns.

I started with the Greens Salad, which was outstanding with their spiced pecans, blue cheese, and maple vinaigrette, but it seemed pricey at $7.

Then I had the Shrimp Po Boy, and that was pretty tasty, too.  A little more reasonable at $11, it came with what seemed like roasted potatoes, which were also very good.  The sandwich had spices but was not what I would consider "spicy."  I can't handle really spicy-hot foods, so this was just right.

My friends salivated over the cheeseburger as it went by.  It did look good except for it was shaped kinda like a meatball in a bun - almost like they didn't flatten the burger patty enough before cooking it, and it puffed up to a nice meatball-patty.  Always worries me whether the inside gets cooked enough.  The toppings did sound interest though w/ garlid aioli, sharp cheddar, bacon, and a fried egg.

I'm looking forward to giving them another try and maybe increasing my rating.

came here for sips and they had great deals on drinks and apps!

- paloma: delicious and i can taste the tequila a lot which i loved!
- peach sangria: this was OK, i didn't taste much wine or anything else

-cheesesteak eggrolls: these were decent for the price! they're more like spring rolls, not like the heartier bigger rolls as a regular eggroll
- hummus pita: i really enjoyed this! the hummus was good and i was loving the little pita pieces, veggies and olives!
- wings: these were interesting, some of the wings were meatier than others but i enjoyed the rub that was on them. what i thought was interesting was the pickled cucumbers and veggies that were placed on top of the wing... why? i love pickled vegetables but not placed on top of my wing, this caused the wing to be a bit soggy instead of crispy

overall, this was a great place for some drinks and apps with friends! the inside is cute and they also have outside seating.

After not being in for about a month, today was a good day. Fast service and they had pancetta and pepperoni stick and the Lemon Tea was working. The "Chef" said welcome back and asked how his favorite customers were. I thought it was funny. You do get rembered when you are super nice or kind of a pain. I would be the second in this scenario. The dining area was clean and all the lids, napkins and utensils were filled. They do have good food and it's not expensive. The Tuscan Piada with panchetta and crispy chicken is our favorite wrap. The pepperoni sticks with the parmesan sauce is my number one reason for going there. Today at about 6:15 they werent at all busy so no huge line to wait thru.

I've been coming here for over 20 years. It is unbelievably consistent and an incredible treat every time. I mean, they have their own farm for gosh sake. Talk about attention to detail! Take the tour of the kitchen and the wine cellar and you'll see what I mean.

Also, don't be afraid to ask for recommendations on the wine. For example, we said, "We want a bold, old Italian red that is affordable". Bam! We're having incredible 30 year old Italian red wine for less than $50. Where else can you do this? Nowhere. Period.

Once, in a crazy attempt at a pointless achievement, we tried to sample every kind of liquor available in the desert room. I'm here to tell you, it is simply not possible.

An old building . . . like it used to be a house. The floors are scruffy old wood . . . and that lends to ambiance.

Heather was our server.

Miss C. and I went for lunch @2:30 November 9. Sat in a rounded booth -- really quite ingenious and comfortable. A number of them on the outskirts of the dining room. And the rest are four-person tables.

The bar's up-front when you walk in. The restrooms are unigender --  midway to the back.

We got a three-meat plate, choosing pork, tri-tip and burnt ends for $18.99 (other choices were chicken and meatloaf) and added three baby-backs for $6. The plate comes with one side. We chose sautéed Brussels sprouts. And then we added baked beans.

There were a lot of sauces on the table. We tasted them all and decided on a pass.

The meat was meaty, tender and flavorful, except the pork -- which tasted like nothing. How can pork taste like nothing? HERE, we had to use sauce . . . Carolina.

Burnt ends were charred on the outside and smoky -- the way they're supposed to be. Tri-tips were equally good.

Brussels sprouts were complemented with bacon (or some other pork), tasty and crisp-tender.

Baked beans are not something I like, but these were so generously infused with meat, and the sauce was hearty, they were keepers -- and I don't say that lightly.

I could say service was "spotty," if the word negligent wasn't in my vocabulary. We got water refills when water glasses were dry for a spell.

But WHY did the pork taste like nothing?
Best burger in the city. Don't get the fancy ones. Just get the naked. With some salt and pepper. Taste the meat people! Taste the meat!

John's Roast Pork makes the most amazing cheesesteak in Philly!

John's Roast Pork (aka: John's Lunch, The Snyder Avenue Lunch Bar, and The Shack) has been owned and operated by three generations of the Bucci family on the corner of Weccacoe and Snyder Avenue in South Philadelphia since 1930. Known for their roast pork, the business began serving cheesesteaks in the 1960s. John's is the James Beard Award-winning gold standard for the non-tourist cheesesteak. The secret to their success is simple, high quality ingredients. 

The elements of a John's Roast Pork award winning cheesesteak includes a half-loaf of freshly baked Carangi Bakery sesame seeded Italian bread, 12 ounces of thinly sliced tenderloin beef steak, sharp provolone cheese, and sautéed sweet spanish onions. After one bite of this glorious cheesesteak I was in heaven! Every bite was cheesy and beefy. The center of the bread is gutted (removed) to accommodate the generous amounts of beef, resulting in the perfect bread to meat ratio. I added some spicy peppers to the sandwich for a little heat. The juicy beef quickly saturates the bread so you'll want to dine on the picnic tables outside so you can devour this sandwich immediately.

You'll get some strange looks if you ask for your cheesesteak "wid wiz". Owner, John Bucci Jr., will never use Cheez Whiz in the John's Roast Pork cheesesteak because he believes it is gross, fake cheese. Instead, Bucci offers customers a choice of American, mild provolone, and sharp provolone. 

Next time I visit I'll have to try the roast pork sandwich although it will be hard to not order the cheesesteak. Maybe I'll order both?

TIP: Cash only! ATM available onsite.

Why 3 stars?  Because I just don't understand the hype for their sandwiches.

   ---   ---   ---

Both times I have been, my sandwich resembled something my grandmother would pack for me to take to a picnic.  I was in a group of 5  while there last week and no one at my table was very impressed.

Their desserts however, are (no pun intended) their bread and butter.  We ordered Red Velvet Cake and Peanut Butter Chocolate Cake - we all walked away in awe.  That was probably the best RVC I have ever had...and I'm not a chocolate fan, but that one was awesome.

As a bonus, we saw Rays GM Andrew Friedman coming in as we were leaving - he's a pretty smart guy, so he probably came just for dessert.

Their brownies will kill me I love them so much. 

I am a diehard chocolate fan. I once had a boss look at me and say you must work out like a fiend with the amount you eat. Why yes, I exercise an hour every day so I can eat my sweets. I also just ate half a cupcake from Dough so if this review is all over the place it is because I am wired. Sugar is my drug of choice. 

After a very satisfying yet unhealthy dinner next door at Datz, I decided to polish off my caloric feast with dessert at Dough. I'm pretty sure this place is heaven. Their display of doughnuts, pastries, and ice cream seems endless. The employee behind the counter said don't forget to go around and see the cake pops. 

We finally settled on a brownie (which is absolutely massive), a chocolate chocolate chocolate cupcake, and a slice of cheesecake. 

My favorite by far was the brownie. It's huge and it has icing on it which makes it even more sweet. It's a fudgy brownie that is almost pure chocolate. There's no way this brownie can get dry because it has so much chocolate. Trust me, I've been snacking on it for a couple of days now and it is still pure delight. The cupcake was great also, but I was disappointed to break into the chocolate dome on top and find chocolate fluff inside. I'm not sure what I was expecting, maybe pure chocolate? but I decided I like the brownie better. The cheesecake was also great, but I was ignoring it for the brownie so I can't really give a good description. 

Will you eat your days worth of calories with just this brownie? Yes. Will it be worth it? Hell yes. I will still try a doughnut one day, but you will have to pry the brownie out of my cold dead hands. I guess I'll just have to get a doughnut and brownie next time. There goes my post baby diet.

Relaxed and mod lounge-like seating with dim lighting and great service.  The food, of course, is amazing.  

Some highlights:
-The vaca frita skirt steak is very tender and flavorful
-The lechon asado was nicely done with a juicy interior covered by a layer of crispy pork skin
-The corn-crusted dorade was solid but didn't stand out compared to the other dishes.
-The smoked albacore fish tacos were a great starter - the fish to toppings ratio was perfect.
-The duck ropa viejo definitely stole the show: juicy, flavorful, and melt-in-your mouth tender.  This is the must-try entree.  
-The fried yucaa side is also a tried-and-true classic: crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, and covered with a nice thin layer of sweet dressing.
-And don't leave without the chocolate cigar!  It's small so there will always be room for a chocolate mousse cake that literally resembles a cigar!

Great outdoor dining for lunch.

When they say they open at 11:30 a.m. on a Saturday, they mean it. I tried to open the door at 11:29 a.m. and it was locked. They ended up opening it at 11:31 a.m., but whose counting. Don't be fashionably early for your lunch reservation if it's when it just opens.

They aren't doing valet due to COVID so you can park in the valet lot next to the restaurant for free. You have to follow the small signs to find the place or just follow your GPS. Don't go to the main hotel or else you are in the wrong place! I'm glad I read that before going. They suggest calling them if it's your first time to get directions.

Reservations can be made on Open Table, making the process super simple. I just wrote in the notes that we wanted outdoor dining. It's covered so even in the heat of the summer it's not bad. 

They have a fun cocktail list. I got a Sapphire Margherita (not that it went with my meal, but I wanted to try it). It wasn't very sweet and I'd try something else next time, but it was enjoyable. 

For lunch I got the Burrata Salad with Salmon added. Salmon is an additional $18 and came on the side. It was good and I think well worth the price. I find it funny that at places like this the scallops and shrimp are charged by the piece so you specify how many you want. My friend got shrimp last time and said they were huge, so worth the $3.50 each price tag. 

I really enjoyed my Burrata Salad. It had a good amount of burrata. The additional salmon was definitely needed, I wouldn't have been full without it. I enjoyed my entire meal.

The bread they bring out before the meal is very good. We devoured it. 

Overall this was a good meal with a beautiful view. It's expensive, but the quality is there. Service was also very good. I would absolutely do another meal here.

Let me first state that I've been to the Post before and enjoyed the food and atmosphere... however due to circumstances, this experience left me unimpressed.

In my previous experiences I remember that this place served food late.  Which is why I came back.  I was excited to stay close to home and watch some of the ballgames while attending to my late-night munchies.  Upon entering, I saw the reminder again.  The large menu posted by the front door says clearly in bold font at the bottom that their full menu is available until midnight.   However, this simply wasn't true.  At 11pm when I asked for a menu, the waitress told me the kitchen was closed.  Something about not being busy enough to keep it open.  I understand that if it's not busy enough to support having the kitchen open, then they should adjust their strategy.  But not nightly.  Change the posted kitchen hours.  And surely don't promote it so that patrons come back for that reason and are let down.

I'll be back to the post.  It's close.  They have good food.  Service has always been good.  And there are nice TV's everywhere.  This experience just pissed me off.

I stopped by this past Saturday to view their showing of orchids.  I believe they do this every year.  This year's showing lasts until 3/25.  If you're a grower or lover of those delicate little flowers, you have to check this show out.  They have a HUGE selection of orchids lovely arranged in a Chinese garden.  It is magical.  Bring your camera.

I would not consider myself a BBQ fan, but this place is stellar!!  The turkey & kielbasa are my two favorites, and I am yet to meet one of their sides I didn't like.  
The buffet is a good deal.  For $17 (last time I was there at least) you can gorge yourself on any type of BBQ emat you can imagine, various sides & baked goods...then wash it all down with some homemade sweet tea. 
Plus...how do you not love a place that throws a fist full of Tootsie Rolls in with your order?

Love love love. Can't believe I've not reviewed before. We have eaten here pretty much since they opened. My favorite is Chef Manns Country Pasta with a second being Four Cheese Ravioli. Mozzarella  Marinara is a great appetizer. We always get great service and plenty of food to take home for lunch the next day. Desserts...yes please. Chocolate  Zuccotto Cake and the Apple Crostada are our two favorites although...the lemon cookies are good..tiramisu is also really good. Best chain italian in town.

We finally got a chance to go to Besito and it was a perfect night for it. We just wanted to check it out and have a drink and dessert. We sat outside on a Saturday chilly night, but didn't feel the chill because they have heaters outside.

We had a nice waiter help us out with our drink options and desert.

My watermelon margarita was quite strong so it took a little while for me to drink. My hubby had a cappuccino which he enjoyed. We chose a tres leches cake to share, and it was quite enjoyable!

We look forward to trying lunch or dinner here. The outside is definitely our spot with the flamenco music playing and just chilling like we are on vacation. The inside would be too loud and dark for us.

There are several levels to this place. I have been both to the bar on the first floor, which kind of reminds me of a 70's pad, as well as the roof top lounge. The roof top deck is really romantic, and serves just cocktails. It's dimly lit, and it is absolutely wonderful during the summertime. There are potted trees surrounding the deck. During the winter, they have heating lamps readily available. Their Perfect Pair is really delicious, and literally tastes like a pear cider.

What? I've never reviewed Han Dynasty? It's only one of my favorite restaurants in the city, and THE destination for Sichuan cuisine. That's right, Sichuan. This is not your standard Chinese spot. "Chinese food" is in the mall, at the food court. The cooking at Han Dynasty (aka, handy nasty) is on another planet, in another galaxy far, far away, where there are no snowmageddons or other undesirables. Only perfection.

That said, go with an open mind. I personally don't get down with tripe or tendons or rabbit or what-have-you, but I do enjoy trying new flavors and combinations that are unexpected and different. Close-minded, stubborn folks need not bother.

Take last night, for example. My boyfriend and I were in the middle of our first course, spicy dan dan noodles with crumbled sausage and crunchy cucumbers in garlic chili oil. We hear the gentleman behind us tell the waiter he would like fried rice for dinner. The waiter makes a joke about how fried rice is on the kids' menu. The waiter returns to the kitchen and a few minutes pass before Han makes his way to the table. An awkward (but hilarious, to our eavesdropping ears) conversation ensues with Han explaining that the restaurant serves authentic Chinese, and that fried rice is only available for children. 

I think the guy eventually got his fried rice, but I was too busy focusing on my own perfectly sticky white rice with dry fry pork to notice or care. Despite being deliriously happy with my meal, I was already taking notes on what to order next time as I scoped out the neighboring diners' plates. Next up: crispy rice with shrimp and double cooked chicken with chili oil and black bean sauce.

This might be our new favorite Vietnamese spot in Tampa Bay! It's spotlessly clean and tastefully decorated, while still keeping prices in the very reasonable range. Now... about that Tofu... It's freaking delicious!

They had four flavors of fried tofu... original, scallion, mushroom, and chili lemongrass. All were spectacular as an appetizer! The chili lemongrass was my favorite.

We also scarfed down some pork spring rolls that were equally delicious. On to more pork and rice and a massive bowl of Pho. Yum!

Finally, we had no room for dessert but got numerous flaky croissants to go since they were like $1.50 each and they had mango, pineapple, blueberry, and almond beyond the normal plan and chocolate. When's the last time you had a mango croissant? For me, it was a first!

We can't wait to return!

I dined recently at Besito and it was a very positive experience. The place is buzzing with quite a happy hour crowd, but they were still able to seat us quickly. Our waitress was excellent and quick to refill drinks, place orders, and checked on us regularly to make sure everything was going well.

I ordered the tacos de carne asada appetizer which is abour $10 for 3 tacos. The tacos tasted fresh and although the carne asada recipe was different from what I am accustomed to, it still tasted great. It was quite filling although I do admit to poaching some of my fellow diners black beans and queso fresco. The fact that they had queso fresco should also be noted considering it seems to be off the menu at several Mexican restaurants in Tampa.

The complimentary tortilla chips and salsa were tasty and the complimentary churros for dessert sealed the deal at this place. I would recommend everyone to give Besito a shot.

Always love me some Yummy House and was so glad to see a location open up closer to home.  They've done a great job with the space as it appears modern and airy but doesn't lose the quality of food and service as one may have come to expect from Yummy House.  They do have early hours so if you're looking to stop by at a later time on the weekends, check to make sure they're open first.  The menu is customary Yummy House and rice isn't included with entrees so be weary before you place your order.
It's ALWAYS crowded here. The cupcakes are great, and the regular food is pretty amazing, too. Make sure to try the chicken and bacon quesadilla...it's GREAT.

What a wonderful dinner that Yelp suggested we go to for our anniversary dinner. This is definitely the place. Although, we were amongst a tropical storm, and could not sit outside, we still enjoyed our self.  

We ordered crab and corn soup that was quite creamy, but the warm bread complimented it very well.  My triple white fish ceviche with mango, pomegranite, and coconut served with plantains were quite memorable.  My mango mojito was great. I'm so love with them lately. it had the just right combination of mango, mint, and alcohol.  Our entrees of filet mignon and lobster tail with scallop were perfect. The scallop is a great size, and the lobster tail with the rest of the early sides were great, and we were very very happy.

Most of the service there was great, but I did not find our specific waitress extremely memorable. It was quite hard to find her, and she didn't quite ask us if we needed anything. she seemed to be quite serious and harsh and not outwardly friendly especially since we were there celebrating our anniversary.  Everyone else was great. That is the reason I docked one star.

Our view of the water was nice, but we were pretty close to be a big party, so the noise level was quite loud. I'll ask for a table not close to big groups next time.

At the end, they brought us two chocolate strawberries with Happy Anniversary written on it. That was a nice touch.

I will be back for sure and will be sitting outside, waiting for the sunset to fall.  in addition, we used a $50 restaurant.com. I have a bunch of credits for there, so that was an amazing bonus.  We were very satisfied, and agree with our fellow yelpers. Definitely a place to experience, love, and come back!

4 stars for atmosphere and concept, 3.5 for the food. 

We arrived for a date night without the Munchkin, and we were excited upon entering. The atmosphere is sort of Cape Cod-ish:  white washed walls, beach pics, navy Blues. 

Our server described how it works: basically tapas style and gave some suggestions on what to order. 

We started with the guacamole which was great. Lots and lots of chunks of avocado. We then got the Mexican street corn and that too was great. I ordered a side salad and really like it. It had a citrus vinaigrette so it was nice and fresh. We ordered a few tacos and the winner being the duck. The rest were good but not great. We finished with a rice bowl with boar and meh-not worth the $8.

Would I go back? Yes but I thought it was a little steep for what we got.

WOOT! My 750th review!!!

Visited with Rachel M and her family, (Thanks for the invite!) I was surprised at how long the line was! It was out the door and down the front of the building. 

Disposable, but not Menus are available as you step into line, giving you plenty of time to read over what they have, so you don't hold up the line any further. They have a lot of choices on the menu from pork, chicken and beef. There are a lot of Sides too!

I opted for my hands down favorite at any BBQ joint, Pulled pork, which was served on a tray, lined with brown paper. The serving size is moderate. Not huge but certainly enough. Three sides for a dinner is generous, I chose the Potato salad, the Green beans and cole slaw. Everything was tasty! The only thing I would have preffered would have been is that the slaw wasn't confetti cut. I like the texture of cabbage, and when it's cut so tiny, you lose that and sadly, a lot of the flavour. 

The biggest drawback is how loud it is inside. It's almost headache inducing. Everyone is talking and it's a big feedback loop if you're sensitive to sound. There is nothing to absorb the noise and it just bounces around.  When you try to order from the sweet shop, you can barely hear the girls behind the tall, tall glass. 

Over all, I'd visit again, but I don't think I'd make the special trip, unless it was a Yelp event.

Oh my gosh. Going to Mazzaro's should be on the must do list of visiting the Saint Pete area. How darling with all of the fun cute statues and murals of italy all over the place. Each area is so much fun with the wine, the cheese, the coffee bar, the desserts, the deli, all of the different foods.
There is a huge array of food to order whether it's the 20 something sandwiches, and soup options, or whatever is in the pretty clear glass case. They serve it up warm for you if you want. The food in the case ranges from salads, to pastas, to seafood and chicken. Served up either individual style or by pound. To me, the pound thing can get kind of tricky, but they will weigh it for you, and let you know how much it costs.  Hold off on getting your ticket to make your order until you choose what you want to order. Just making a decision is a fun project in itself. Once you are ready, grab your number, and wait to be called. 
The service working there are very nice and helpful, especially for the ones that are not versed on their system of ordering. Everything looks and tastes scrumptious, and I can not wait to be back. I can definitely bring friends and family here too so they can check out the goodness of Mazzaro's.

We ordered the jerk chicken and soup at lunch. It was all good. When we went to pay the waitress/bartender said "because they keep changing things and never tell me anything your soup will be $5 instead of $2." So we paid it because we hate to be 'those people' but in hind sight I should have asked for the manager. If something is in writing ON the menu you should give it to the patron for that amount. If it is the wrong price on the menu change the menu. 

I am growing tired of local restaurants raking me over the coals because they think they can. I was so upset when I left I could barely breath. What was supposed to be a nice lunch out with my husband turned sour quickly and never got better. 

TBBC? What will you do about this error? It seems so often we review places and no-one cares or attempts to fix something that went wrong on the restaurant's end of things. Like I said, the food was good. But the staff did NOTHING to remedy the discrepancy. We were there on Friday at 1ish and we sat outside at the bar area. A female was our bartender/server.

I stopped in to Vic's after not coming by in a long while.
The place was SO crowded that I ate in the window.
I had the Ocean Brother Roll (sauce on the side) and it ROCKED.

I still love it here - but it's just so tiny and cramped.

I sometimes go to Jay's now.

Why did I not hang out at this place when I lived in St. Louis? Failure on my part! 

My first visit to The Royale was over Christmas break when I stayed with a friend who lived in the neighborhood and although we didn't stay long, I had a fantastic time! 

The drinks are reasonably priced and the crowd (it was packed!) was a swell melting pot of interesting people. It reminded me of a highschool cafeteria filled with different subcultures, posses, cliques, whatever. However, the environment here allowed for pleasant mingling!

The back patio area is rather large and will be a spot that I definitely hit up when I visit when the weather is warmer. Lunch and dinner is also served up here.

Perfect spot for happy hour, to watch the game, or to bring a date.

TIP: Try the Ghostpepper Vodka!

After such a positive first experience at Ulele, I returned again, and had a less spectacular night.

It started from the very beginning.  I had reservations at 8pm.  I arrived, and they said it'd be "a few minutes."  45 minutes later, we were finally seated.  45 minutes!  We live in Tampa, not New York.  And if you're going to overbook like this, why don't you have adequate seating in the "waiting" area?

I will admit that the wine list has some pretty fantastic deals.  A bottle of 2011 Opus One for only $188?  Yes please!  2005 Silver Oak for $140?  Woo hoo!  I have not seen such bargains around Tampa.  Don't bother with the $20 corkage, drink what they have.  (Btw, they do have very reasonable mid-priced wines too.)

But the food wasn't great.  We started with the lobster cake, which had sweet and fresh lobster in huge chunks, but was overcooked with black seared streaks.  I did not think the cucumber ginger salad added anything to the actual lobster cake.

I had the grouper, and while the fish was mild and the sauce good, the meat was so overcooked, it was dry.  What a waste of a good piece of fish.  My husband had the pork shank, and he liked the meat but didn't love the chutney.

For dessert, I tried the guava pie, which was fine, and my husband had espresso ice cream.  They do make excellent ice cream.

Other than the great wine list, I am not sure if I'd return.  I think they overbook and that affects the quality of the food.

Love, love, love Bartaco!

I finally got the chance to check out Bartaco in Hyde Park last night and was not disappointed. Fellow yelper, Anna M., joined me for dinner and drinks at the bar. The crowd was pretty mellow before 6pm, but the bar and restaurant quickly got packed so call ahead for a table if you are dining during peak hours. We had another Yelper, Fabian, join us after 6pm and we had to hide a barstool until he arrived!

The décor at Bartaco is simply gorgeous. The wooden bar and booths and hanging baskets from the light fixtures gives the restaurant a relaxed beachy/west coast vibe. The cocktails are all handcrafted at Bartaco so you'll find the bar lined with a juice press and cocktail garnishes such as fresh thyme, limes, and watermelon wedges. Our bartender, Kate, was a total boss on the juice press and was whipping up cocktail concoctions all night!   

The tacos were so good and so innovative! We started off our meal with the homemade guac and chips. The small portion is enough for two, but I love guacamole so I'd probably order the large portion next time. I ordered the spicy chorizo taco, cauliflower taco, and duck taco. The freshly made corn tortillas on the tacos were to die for! All of the ingredients in the tacos were so fresh. The tacos are Cali-style so you won't find your Tex-Mex selection of shredded lettuce, cheese, and sour cream on the tacos. Anna ordered a side of crumbled Mexican Queso for the tacos. The queso was a nice touch on my spicy chorizo taco, but the duck and the cauliflower tacos were so flavorful that I didn't bother adding cheese. 

The tacos at Bartaco are cheap, but tiny so you'll want to order at least three or four tacos (more if you're a guy). The cauliflower taco was too spicy for Anna so I had hers, but had she not given me her taco I would have ordered a fried oyster or the sesame ribeye taco. We split a side of the grilled corn with lime, cayenne pepper, and cotija cheese. Whoa, loved this side dish!!! We asked the kitchen to remove the corn from the cob for us so that we could eat the corn in a more ladylike fashion.

Had I only ordered food last night my bill would have been under $15, but Anna and I were on a mission to sample every cocktail on the menu. The damage wasn't as bad as I would have thought for the four cocktails I had (~$35). I tried the "Bartaco Margarita" (my favorite cocktail of the night), the "Humo y Fuego" with sombra mezcal, muddled tomatillo, and jalapeno (packs a nice spicy punch!), the "Sashito" with Combier Liqueur d'Orange and a fresh watermelon garnish (perfect summer cocktail!), and the "Clarico" (similar to sangria).

A slightly more economical option would have been to order a carafe of margaritas or mojitos, but we were already on our third cocktail of the night when we considered that option. A carafe holds six cocktails and ranges from $43-$48.

I will definitely be back soon to try more of the menu and consume more of the amazing fresh guacamole at Bartaco!

The review is for the delicious tiramisu French toast. The bread is thick perfectly cooked and moist with delicious fillings. The fillings isn't a lot but it brings the sweetness to the toast.

Kouign aman is crunchy and buttery. The fig muffin is ok not much filling. You can pass this
Great and affordable food. Service is fast. Very friendly. Roti canai is a must here. Beef chow fun is delicious. Achat is very good too.

Came here for lunch and was disappointed that the sea scallops weren't an option for lunch but found the shrimp and grits so thought I'd give that a try. I'm so glad I chose this dish because wow absolutely delicious! So much flavor! The grits didn't even taste like grits. I cleaned my entire plate!! Their bread is also so fresh and good. The black salt they serve with it adds great flavor but be sure to not use too much as it can be quite strong. 

Oystercatchers is top-notch, upscale dining. Located in the Grand Hyatt hotel area. Staff is friendly and attentive. The view of the bay is breathtaking. You definitely won't be disappointed coming here.

Earning badges here on Yelp, takes me back to the days when I was a boy scout.  Except achieving a badge on Yelp is a lot more fun. I can not tell you how many Margarita's I have drunk or the number of tacos and burritos I've eaten to earn my Mexi-can badge.  I thought it was never going to happen. Then the other night while attending an International Supper Club gathering at Milagro, it did. Making it the most memorable badge I've earned. I was at my "favorite" Mexican restaurant and with 11 of my closest Yelp comrades.

I always feel like I need to go to confession after having a Margarita at Milagro, because they are sinfully good. The "featured" Margarita was Mango-Pear, which went down rather smooth. So smooth, that I had to have more then one and would of had more if I did not have to get up at 4AM for work. Still I am fairly certain I'll be doing several Hail Mary's for what I did consume. 

As an appetizer I shared Chorizo & Roasted Pablano Chili Queso Fundido with the SO. Their house made tortillas were perfect for dipping in and filling with the flavorful Queso. We both ordered the same entree which is unusual for us, but the Tacos en Cazuela just sounded to tempting. For me these were the perfect tacos to eat after earning my badge. The portions were huge, leaving me a little of each meat along with some Charro beans and street corn for the next day at work. I may not of had one of the corn tortillas left, but I still made my coworkers jealous at lunchtime. 

Praise Jesus for Milagro's Street Corn. If is not only off the cob, but off the charts in flavor as well. Friends have always said, that certain foods were their "crack" and I've never understood that phrase, but I do now. This street corn is so good that if need be, I'd work the "street(s)" to be able to have more. 

It is always a team effort at Milagro to make sure your dining experience is top notch.  Their kitchen staff is willing to accommodate special dietary needs when possible and the wait staff has a "no problem" attitude when it comes to separating checks on a large party. 

If you haven't been to Milagro, stop reading now and go. You'll be glad that you did.

I broke away from an event in the private room to meet friends at the bar for a drink and noticed immediately that THE PIANO IS GONE!

As much as I didn't mind the live piano and did not think it was at an overwhelming volume, the bartenders seem much happier now and the vibe of the bar itself is just better.

Seems even the lighting in the bar area is different too and the setting worked for us this evening.

Also, I must compliment Kim in particular as she is insanely good at recognizing repeat customers. 

Honestly, the entire staff here made a real good impression on me whether I was in that backroom, at the bar or out front near the host stand.

While I'm just not a fan of the menu and rarely eat here, the new feel of the bar and the professional attitude of the employees will get us back for drinks more often.

Ditto to what Lisa said, but add the beef brisket taco to the order list!  While I love the patio with outdoor bails of hay and fire pits, I don't like the lackadaisical approach to service and occasionally cool attitude stemming from staff.  I guess it's not cool enough to act like they care.

I really liked this place. It's a neat little hole in the wall off of Bourbon St. and a nice place to check out if you are trying to get away from the touristy crowd. It isn't anything fancy, but you can see that it's a nice neighborhood bar with a good group of regulars.

I've been to Parc twice now...both times for lunch. The first time my boyfriend and I shared the burger and country chicken club sans bacon. Both were very good, but the bread on the chicken club was super greasy and the fries were overcooked. The second time I went I got the warm shrimp salad, which was DELICIOUS! My dining partner had the onion soup before her entree and I stared at it the whole time - it looked amazing. The bread basket is so good...I could eat 5 of them! Definitely a good lunch spot, especially if you can sit outside on a beautiful day!

The office ordered in for a working lunch using 569.dine. There were 5 of us, and the orders around the table were:

Hawaiian pizza and small salad ($10.49 for the small pizza) -- she absolutely LOVED the pizza -- pineapple, ham and bacon. The salad was a lovely mix of fresh, crisp greens. No iceberg here.

Mushroom and tomato pizza and small salad ($11.07 for the small pizza with two toppings) -- she LOVED her pizza, too, and added a few more tomatoes. The pizza was truly brimming with lovely cheese.

Tiger Tamer ($8.99) -- grilled chicken breast topped with sautéed mushrooms and Swiss cheese. It came with fries that spread a massive aroma throughout our meeting room -- in a good way.

Blackened Tuna ($8.99)  -- 6oz. tuna fillet with lemon dill aioli. This sandwich came with fries, too. He liked it, but was disappointed he didn't get lettuce, tomato and onion for the sandwich.

I got the the Chef Salad ($9.99) -- Mixed greens, turkey, ham, black olive, tomato, green pepper, carrot, onion, crouton and cheddar cheese. I ditched the croutons and added grilled chicken for $2. AND they chopped up the chicken to truly blend into the salad. The green pepper was a nice and very tasty addition. I got bleu cheese dressing, and they sent two containers. YIPPEE!!

This salad was pretty darned massive and lasted two meals. It was soooo good. And lasted well to the second meal.

This was a successful delivery order. Makes me want to go to the restaurant. Not all do.

Busch Gardens is not like it use to be. I think the old gardens is nicer. They use to have the safari Jeep ride instead we have to paid extra to get into the safari. Now the safari is a train ride through the animal area. The use to have two free beer gardens. Now just one. And the beer only limit to two small cup. 

The show at Busch Gardens is still good. The animal show, singing show, popular Elmo show, ice skating show are attraction to the audiences. I like the cheetah run. They show a live cheetah at their top speed to go after the pray. 

If you go near the Christmas time, they have the Christmas town. The entire park lit up at night. It is beautiful to see from the sky lift. I still like the bumper car ride. They now has some crazy roller coasters. It definitely shake your stomach and brain.

I definitely think I have a new go to place in Philly.

Went there for the first time yesterday.  We used Yelp to find the place since we were in the area and in the mood to try something different.  

The wife and I sampled the summer roll with shrimp and chicken, I had the egg noodle soup with wonton, pork, and shrimp (which was a meal in itself), and the wife chose the Chicken Sauteed w/ Bell Pepper, Onion & Satay Sauce.  Everything was fresh and tasty, it came out promptly, and the whole meal was under 20 bucks.  And, you can park for free.  The cheapskate in me was very happy.

I flew in and out of PHL this weekend.   I don't fly much often spend time picking up and leaving folks off.  Signage is poor and it's easy to miss a turn.

My experience with PHL staff was positive and the restrooms were clean.

The Brontosaurus Beef Rib is a fatty, salty delight.

I have a confession to make, I've gotten a lot less adventurous with food in my old (ok I'm really not that old) age. Before, I used to always get something different when I visited someplace I've been because I wanted to try something new - I was always determined to see if there was something better. Now, when I find something I love, I tend to stick with it. It's the whole why fix something that isn't broken adage. 

I've always loved the brisket at 4 Rivers. I've only gone to the one in South Tampa, but I figured it would be the same. My husband mentioned his coworker got the Brontosaurus beef rib and loved it. I struggled internally with whether I wanted to try that instead, if it was bad my day would have been ruined because I could have gotten the brisket. I tried to convince my husband to get the brisket, but he wouldn't budge from his standard chicken sandwich. I slept on it, I thought about it some more, and then I decided I would do it. (Yes, this is what takes up most of my brainpower).

I've tried the Brontosaurus Beef Rib and I can't go back. (Although, since it is $25+ my husband warned me this can't become an every day thing. Thanks, hon). First of all, it is huge! I was pregnant and did a spin class that morning so I was starved and I could only finish half. I ate an additional quarter for snack a couple hours later. Moral of the story is two people could easily share this bone of meat. I'm a huge lover of salty, fatty meat, and this satisfied those two cravings. There is so much salt and so much fat that I was in heaven. However, if you do not like salt or fat (or an overabundance of salt or fat), this is not the meat for you. My husband, who likes lean meat, would probably only eat half the meat. 

For sides, I got the cole slaw and corn. I asked which vegetables don't contain pork and, unfortunately, both the green beans and the collard greens are made with pig. I can live with that because I loved the corn and cole slaw. They were the perfect accompaniments to my hunk of meat. I think the corn is cooked with onions so it gave it a richer flavor than just corn. 

This location is so much bigger than the one in South Tampa. They have a huge dessert section, which I will have to check out another day when I'm not filled with meat. We got there at 11:30 on a Friday and there was no line. My husband got his chicken sandwich right away and it was about a ten-minute wait for my Brontosaurus Beef Rib. Basically, we were in and out in twenty minutes. 

I'm glad we don't live closer or else I would weigh 20 lbs more. I will be back for another Brontosaurus Beef Rib.

I just had my 2nd meal at Farmhaus and I'm upgrading from 4 to 5 stars!  Today (Tuesday) was the Roast Beef Blue Plate Special Lunch (see picture).

We started with a Mango Leaf Infused Iced Tea that you can have sweet or un-sweet; the unsweetened version has a lot of flavor and a very smooth taste.  This was followed by a spinach salad with slices of cucumber and some sort of radish I think.  This came with a large cracker.  Everything was fresh and crisp.

Then our Roast Beef arrived.  The Mashed Taters are sooooo good!  I'm not usually a fan of Green Bean Casserole, but I liked this one a lot.  And the roast beef was tender with just the right amount of pink and seasoning.  Everything was portioned just right to satiate the appetite but not leave you feeling over-full.

All that for only $10.  What a great concept!  All in a laid-back, casual atmosphere.

We were enjoying the meal so much that we did something we never do at lunch, let alone at dinner - ordered dessert ($7).  I think it was called the Pecan Financier /fi NON see ay/.  I don't remember the exact description, but I do remember a moist pecan/maple cupcake atop creme fraiche with a sprinkling of pecans side by side with homemade (I think it was) vanilla ice cream.  We were not disappointed.  With the dessert, my husband had a tasty cup of Goshen coffee ($3).

Great meal!  We will be back!

Why 3 stars?  Inconsistency.

   ---   ---   ---

Of every place I have reviewed, Ella's is the number one enigma.  I have had 5 star experiences at Ella's and I've had 1 star experiences.

My first time at Ella's was probably my favorite.  I live in Seminole Heights and was unaware of the growth in the area of places like Ella's.  It's the type of establishment I would expect to come across in Ybor, so I was pleasantly surprised to find it in my back yard of the good ole' S.H.

I sat at the bar with my roommate and ordered a shrimp wrap.  It came out on an ingredient by ingredient basis.  There was the wraps, the shrimp, fried yams, some veggies and a typical sauce you'd find in a Po Boy.  This was a phenomenal meal!  

The bad news?  The next time I came in, it had been taken off the menu.  WHY?!?!

We also shared some Chef's Hummus, which flavor changes constantly.  This particular visit to Ella's was around Halloween, so we were given Pumpkin flavored.  Again, a FIVE STAR dish.  But because the hummus changes so often, I haven't had the luck of coming across it again since my first visit.

I've had the meat loaf.  It was good, but a bit on the rich side.  I felt like I ate a house after I was done.  The potato cakes that came with it were the best part of the meal.

I've had the filet and was not a fan because of the amount of goat cheese piled on.  I compare goat cheese to the taste I'd imagine you would get from walking up to a live goat and biting it.  So we will give Ella's a pass on the filet and blame it on me not paying attention to the menu.

   ---   ---   ---

SOUL FOOD SUNDAY:

Another reason Ella's is difficult to rate - Sunday's are a completely different animal.  Unfortunately, I have had the same rangy 1-5 star experience on these days.

The go-to entree is Chicken and Waffles.  Sometime's it's been really great, sometimes it's been average.  The chicken physically looks different sometimes, which is never a good thing.

I've gotten the KC BBQ Ribs and the Bayou Burger as well.  Both are ok.  The sweet potato fries are always pretty good.

A couple of times we have gone to Ella's on a late Sunday afternoon and they have been out of 50-80% of the menu.  I understand the challenge of having different menu options for one day a week, but it's pretty ridiculous that if you don't beat the lunch crowd, you may not have the chance to enjoy your favorite Soul Food dish that day.


Overall, despite the bad times at Ella's, I still recommend that everyone check it out.  The chance that you might be there on a good day makes it worth it.

I love Vietnamese food and was really excited to go to Saigon deli. My fellow yelpers have given that the highest marks of the highest compliment I expected super good food.

I don't know if I went on an off day or what was going on but it certainly was not the best Vietnamese food I've ever had in the Tampa Bay area or anywhere else for that matter. The Pho was not hot and had a very bitter taste to it. It wasn't a burn taste it was just a bitter taste like maybe too much lemongrass I couldn't quite put my finger on it but it was not a good taste at all.

I also ordered the pork ban mi. The ban mi was dry, and once again it had this odd bitter flavor to it. I wish I could really put my finger on what the taste of it was but I just can't say it wasn't burnt garlic it was just a very very strong unpleasant taste. I'm hoping they just had a bad day or a bad batch of something and the next time it will be wonderful. I know all of my fellow yelpers cannot be wrong and Saigon deli should be a must go. Wells on the day I went it was definitely a don't go. Yes I will try it again due to the great opinion of my fellow yelpers.

Needless to say there was no lunch that day, it unfortunately ended up in the trash.

What's a girl to do? When in doubt try, try again.

We came here for the University City Dining Days and Jose Garces definitely delivered.  I had the shrimp ceviche with spicy tomato salsa on crispy plantain chips and the tortilla soup for the app. course.  The ceviche was refreshing with the perfect touch of spice; it went very well with the fried plantain.  A great summer option.  The tortilla soup was savory and creamy, thanks to the avocado, although it wasn't the best that I have ever had.  Still, it was very good.  I also tried the esquite, which was fantastic; it's like a creamy corn pudding of a sort.  The guacamole is also great, and I kinda wished that I had chosen that as one of my appetizers.  Oh well, more reason for me to come back and gorge myself silly.  For the "entrees", I decided on the mole amarillo and the huarache with bbq short ribs, both of which were solid.  The rabbit loin was tender and served casserole-style with pineapple and tomato, which gave the dish a nice refreshing shot; the loin itself was flavorful and tender.  I think that I still prefer my rabbit prepared Moroccan style with fresh apricots but this was still tasty and a great option if you are looking for something different.  The costilla huarache was absolutely delish with flavorful, tender short ribs and a savory, spicy, and sweet bbq sauce.  No, it's not for those on a low-carb diet but it's a must-try if you come here.  I would describe it as a flatbread, of a sort, but it is much better and more flavorful than the flatbreads at, say, Uno's, by far.  Dessert was flour less chocolate cake accompanied by caramel, peanuts, and chocolate ice cream.  It was good but I have high standards/benchmarks for my flour less chocolate cake (Finale in Harvard Square, anyone?) so I didn't find it to be outstanding.  Overall, this was a great introductory meal to Distrito for us and it definitely lived up to Jose Garces' reputation.  Will be back to try more of the menu but 4 stars for now.  Plus, service was flawless: friendly, helpful, and not overbearing.

Three stars for tonight's food. I can't remember ever getting anything I didn't like at Maggiano's till tonight. I decided to order something different off their specials menu. I should have stuck with my favorites. Food seemed to take a super long time. When I got my dish the chicken was burnt on the bottom and the pasta over cooked. This seriously has never happened before. They did replace my food with another dish. I ordered my favorite Chef Manns Country Pasta. They did take my meal off the bill and I got a free desert. One of those off days everyone has. New kitchen staff? Short on staff? Whatever the reason they did everything to make it right. Still love Maggiano's but I think from now on I will skip the specials. 

Service great and manager great.

I don't have much beef with Lambert. 

Sitting at my gate this morning, I realized it only took a half an hour for me to get to that point from walking in the doors... I think that's pretty good. Granted, it's the week after a holiday, but it was still pretty busy and TSA seemed to move people through fast.

After I'm in I always head straight to Dunkin Doughnuts which this morning had ZERO people in line (I swear, flying after Christmas is the best) and get a veggie egg-white flat bread sandwich and a coffee. And maybe a couple donut holes if I'm feeling crazy...

There are several things that could use some improvement here... floors and chairs are often dirty, they could use much more seating, employees are not always the friendliest. This morning in the car we had a guy tell us that "the way to get to departures was to follow the departure sign." Ahh, thank you, wise gentleman.

One big fat star for a Mosaic Modern Fusion opening in Lambert! I hope to the high heavens that I'm never sitting in Lambert long enough to have to eat a long, drawn out (though tasty) meal, but if I'm gonna be stuck in that situation, I'll obviously be very happy to have Mosaic as an option.

Take-a-ways: Get there early, have patience in the security line, maybe wink at the guy doing the body scans to lighten the mood, and enjoy some DD coffee.

I hate giving this place 1 star but this is based on my last visit. And it will be awhile until I'm willing to give them another chance. 

We went there last Sunday around 930pm. Yes, it was busy but not ridiculous. We sat outside and ordered 3 drinks-1 diet coke and 2 beers. Mind you nothing fancy. No mixed drinks, no frozens, just 2 DRAFT beers abbas a soda. 

20 min later we are still sitting there without drinks. And I'm not exaggerating on the time. 

Also, this is not a one time incident for me...it's happened a lot. I just feel like this time it was very ridiculous. 

It's a shame, because I do want to like this place....(sigh)

Ok, after 2 visits I am ready to make an informed review
Brisket: 4 *, moist, tender and very flavorfull.
Burnt ends; see above.
Sausage:  4*not greasy, very flavorful & not too spocy.
Bread pudding:  4* great, unusual consistency,  but good, unusual banana combo, but not enough banana gooey goodness to go around.
Corn casserole, 5* excellent flavor and taste, quite unique. 
Baked beans: 5* well seasoned and baked.
Biscuts:  4* flakes and light, they even had honey for them.
Cornbread: 3* nothing special.
Potato Salad:  3* savory & well seasoned. I am quite sure it is out of a container, like Holly Hog, but is okay for container salad.
Sweets:
4 Rivers cookie, 1*very large and flavorfull,  but not fully cooked in the center.
Blondie:  3* quite tasty, cooked correctly,  but nothing to write home about.
Rivers Pecan: 3* same as the blondie.
I wish I could give it 5*, but it has a way to grow & earn that 5th star. I have no doubt they can do it. Get the sides and sweets up with the protien.... winner, winner, chicken dinner.
What's a girl to do? Keep looking for the best of the best.

I'm really shocked on the great reviews here. I heard it was Schulson recommended... kind of distrusting his judgement at this point. I would have to say Le Viet or Vietnam Restaurant is better.

PHO - broth needs more depth. i'm missing the beefiness in the stock and the layers of flavors. i would give this a 3/5. the actual beef was ok but i've had way better brisket at other places

Summer Rolls - these were disappointing. they were SOOO skinny and barely any veggies 

Broken Rice w/ Pork Chops - this was OK, pork could have been cooked better and the quality of the pork was 3/5, i've had better in the area. 

Overall, it's OK, I wouldn't be upset but definitely leaning more towards the others in the area.

Because we're not allowed to write a review based on a Yelp event, I eventually made my way back to Goody Goody because I wanted to try the signature burger itself and other lunch/dinner items not offered on my initial visit.

Strategically picking a down time to walk in the door and avoid the normal wait, I found a nice counter spot and a truly delightful employee behind it to wait on me.

She was terrific, unfortunately the kitchen staff did not properly prepare the item that I ordered to sample along with the signature burger.

However, upon hearing of my experience, there were multiple management folks at the ready to apologize and make things right.

I have honestly never gotten a faster response to something like this and told them how impressed I was with their swift attention to detail as it related to customer relations.

While I have not been back, I have been invited to return and plan to do so when I'm back in the neighborhood to give them a deserved second chance.

Sweet lucys is decent bbq for being in Philadelphia. Although the prices are a bit high. I'm also not a big fan of them doing away with the byob. It was great you could take a cooler, eat bbq and watch football. Sadly no more, should have stayed a byob...



Pros
-good food
-good service

Cons
- a little pricey for the amount of food you get
- depending on what day you go you could wait a while for the food and a table.
- starting nov 20 no longer a byob, which was one of my favorite reasons to go there.
- they have a parking lot but its poorly lit

I'm wondering if I was in a new wing of the airport because it was glorious. Restaurant after restaurant after restaurant with highly functional wifi and spiffy new bathrooms. This airport reminds me of many of the nicer mall-like airports in Europe. You'll find Gap, Brooks Brothers and all sorts of other stores. 

Last, but not least, hooks in the bathroom stalls.

I don't know what is happening to this Cheesecake Factory location at the International Mall, but my last few visits here have been plagued with bad service. One time I came in for lunch and the server took about an hour to come and take our order. He was nowhere to be found for half the time and we were seated in an area where all the customers were his. When he did appear he darted past our table faster than we could grab his attention. The food took forever to come out and I was left trying to explain to my friends who I had told Cheesecake Factory has excellent service what had happened. They are busy throughout the day, but it's no excuse for spotty service...The Westfield Brandon Mall location is just as busy and still manages to provide quality service on my visits there. A few other visits have had the same issue.

Today we came in at around 3pm and were seated near the bar area. They seated us right next to a birthday party of about eight people. The waitress came up to us to take our orders and we never saw her for the rest of our meal until the birthday party left. We never got our bread and we were starving. Just when I was about ready to just get up and tell them to cancel our order another waiter came out with our food and brought us some bread with our meal after we mentioned never receiving ours. It wasn't until this waiter saw the look on my face that our waitress decided to appear again.

The Monterrey Cheeseburger was pretty appetizing and made me feel a little better about the service. The Honey Mustard Mayo sauce and cheese were made well. The burger was cooked medium well as requested. There was a good amount of fries, but it looks like they served less than usual.  

The food was good, but the waitress simply wasn't making a good name for the Cheesecake Factory and honestly I'm sick of the bad service here. Probably won't be dining here much in the future. The Brandon one is closer anyway.

The customer service is outstanding. The owner reached me to resolve chocolate chip cookie day pricing issue.

The double chocolate chip cookies are my second favorite after the traditional chocolate chip cookies. It's crispy on the outside but soft on the inside. They are generous in filling the cookies with chocolate chip but the cookie itself it's not overly sweet so overall it's perfect sweetness.

Why 5 stars? Because good Mexican food is a rare find around here.

   ---   ---   ---

My fiance and I both hail from Houston where 14 great Mexican restaurants can be found in any given square mile radius of the city limits. In Tampa Bay, this is sadly not the case. Instead, we're blessed with tons of Cuban, Latin, and South American fare that Houston does not possess. So you take the good with the bad, but when you find a place like Besito, hope is restored.

Besito is far from your traditional Mexican restaurant. The menu consists of a large amount of dishes that I've never seen before. But different vs. familiar isn't important... the bottom line = deliciousness wins!

After visiting Besito for a Yelp event during my first trip, I knew I had to return and get a full experience. The guacamole is possibly the best I've ever had. And the queso fundido is one of the most addicting substances you can put on a plate. 

But the main dish was incredibly impressive to me - the Costillas al Piquin. I almost never enjoy short rib because it tastes a bit more like stew, than good ole' fashioned ribs. But these were easily the best short ribs I've ever had. I had almost sworn them off forever, until Besito saved the day :)

In my many trips to New Orleans the Erin Rose is always a must stop for me. Located right off Bourbon Street it's so not your typical Bourbon bar. More like a dingy Irish pub they serve an amazing frozen Irish coffee (order with a shot of whiskey mixed in) and you can't miss grabbing a Killer PoBoy in the back or a Jameson grilled cheese. If you're tired of the Bourbon scene walk about 100 ft down Conti to find the Erin Rose.

My bf & I decided to get ribs for Valentine's Day dinner.  Boy, it was truly worth the wait.  I was salivating & thinking about them all day long.  The ribs are truly one of a kind & absolutely delish!  They came with about 6 small tubs of BBQ sauce.  They are worth the money (approx $48 for a rack & a half).  The meat was tender & cooked about the right amount of time.

Why 5 stars? Because this was a very memorable experience.

   ---   ---   ---

Dinner with 5 CM's - though it took an inordinate amount of time to ultimately decide on Prohibition Taproom, we ended up at the right place. There's no better folks in the world to eat with. It's actually weird to NOT order a bunch of things and share them all. I can't even imagine one of them saying, "nah, I'd rather order my own dish... sharing weirds me out."

We sat down and promptly went through our selections with our very friendly server...

Roll Mops: Unique, and though the reviews at our table were mixed, I actually really liked them.

Mac-N-Cheese: Very solid mac.

Smoked Beef Fat Popcorn: You know how popcorn is generally really addicting? Imagine adding beef fat to it. Yeah.

Assorted pickled vegetables: Exactly what it sounds like. I could have done without this one.

Wild Mushroom Gratin: Another unique dish, and one that I would order again.

Pork Belly & Cheddar Potato Skins: Much like the popcorn, this was one of those things that seems simple enough, and it probably is, but it's also incredibly addicting.

Steak Tartare Sliders: Easily my favorite thing we ordered. The only bad thing about sharing food is that I wish I could have had at least 4 of these by myself. 

Overall, I really enjoyed Prohibition Taproom. It manages to combine grungy + modern in a really perfect way. But most importantly, the folks in the kitchen know, as the kids say, "what's up." 

I'm hip, I'm with it.

I like, not love, Phila International. 

It's a half hour flat from where I live, and easy to navigate. 

We had to take our shoes off, and get XRay'd, but everything moved rather quickly. 

I got my bottled water taken away - my bad. 

An overall good experience.

Omg AMAZING!! Casual fine dining restaurant located at Rocky Point near the Hyatt Hotel. Inside and outside seating available. Recommend reservations. Great views overlooking the bay while you dine. Great entrees and drinks. Entrees average from $22-$54 depending on what you order.  We come here at least once per year for our anniversary dinner and the food and service is always amazing. Wait staff is very attentive to refills and very knowledgeable of the menu offerings. Recommendations are on point and you definitely won't be disappointed dining here!

I ordered the Sea Scallops (pan seared) which was served with rice pilaf and broccoli. The veggies and starch are always chef selections and not indicated on the menu. They vary as well. I've had this same dish before with mixed veggies and risotto which was also amazing. My husband ordered the wood grilled snapper which was very tasty, flaky, and juicy. So much flavor. We ordered the potato crab stack as an appetizer and for drinks we ordered the strawberry mojito and volcanic sunset. For dessert we got the sticky toffee pudding to go. All very good. Cindy was our waitress this evening and she was absolutely amazing! The best waitress we've had over the years we've been coming here. So friendly and I really appreciated her recommendations. 

Our drinks and dessert was on the house tonight. Which absolutely surprised us! Cindy came over and told us that her manager was buying these for us tonight since The dining room was louder than usual and he was sure we were looking forward to a more quiet dinner.  We really appreciated this gesture despite the noise level not bothering us and the fact that we didn't complain about it. Just shows they are extremely committed to a positive dining experience and value their diners. We will definitely continue to come back here. Love this place!!

Finally got a chance to check out the infamous Bartaco earlier this week.  I was shocked that there was a 30 minute wait at 8pm on a Tuesday night, but it happens.  Once seated, the server we had was very attentive and explained the concept to us.  We had orders of the cucumber salad, black beans, chips an salsa, and I ordered the Chicken Rice Bowl for my entree.  The tacos on the menu are mini sized as are most items on the menu.  It makes for a great way to try a variety of different items.  Overall the flavors of my food were great and I will definitely be back!

Wow, wow, wow!  I am in love with The Refinery!!!  I admit I have not been to the Refinery sooner due to its location in Seminole Heights. I hang my head in shame for my poor judgment.  

I loved the charming and quirky vibe of the restaurant!  The menu prices were surprisingly affordable.  Usually "snobby" food gets snobby prices and snobby service, but the Refinery is quite the opposite and super laidback!  Be sure to reserve a table upstairs on the balcony.
