We decided to eat downstairs because there was a thirty minute wait for a table upstairs.  Our meal downstairs was fabulous, but the restaurant's atmosphere is so much better upstairs.  

Expect fresh seasonal items in all of The Refinery's dishes.  The menu changes weekly, but favorites like the burger and hangar steak are always present.  The sides and toppings will change depending on what is in season.

We started off our meal with the most amazing Pork Belly Bun. My husband got a bowl of the Butternut Squash Bisque...whoa, flavor explosion!!! I was torn between ordering the couscous and the pork chop, but decided on the pork chop after our helpful waiter, Peter, informed us pork was the chef's specialty.  Wow, was this dish the best pork dish I have ever had!!! The pork was stuffed with cheese and some other indescribable goodness...perhaps love?  We finished off our meal with a Blondie with Bourbon ice cream.  Also exceptional!!!  We unanimously agreed this dessert tasted like a "special" brownie.  Maybe the earthy flavor we detected was from the liquor infused ice cream?

This was one of the most special meals I have experienced in Tampa.  I will definitely be back soon!

Very good. There is a wonderfully impressive salad and antipasto bar that would be sufficient for a great meal in and of itself. Then there are the skewers of quality cuts of meats served up gaucho style tableside. 

Service was friendly and efficient. I was a lil nervous when I went to get salad bar seconds and saw.a.server refolding my napkin because (I stashed a partially chewed fatty piece of meat in there..) Faaaancy!!!

My quibbles were with the pacing of the meat service which is a little oppressive and rapid fire and also that the meats don't come out sizzling hot which I think is a related issue. Everything was cooked right but  timing is everything and I'd prefer if the meats were served up a little more staggered and piping hot. :) Of course then people would complain that they had to wait for their favorite cuts!!! :P  

The happy hour drink specials were also good and the drinks tasty. Overall a VERY enjoyable experience especially if you can get a discount on your meal via joining their email club.. :)  

The place is high ceilinged and quite beautifully designed with interesting architectural and design features as well as a MASSIVE floral display at the center of the buffet area. I had a lot of fun. Party on!!! Enjoy life.

Decent food, as before, but the service had improved and the upstairs seating is actually nice.  We had a table by the window overlooking Chestnut St and enjoyed the view while listening to Billy Joel classics.  My grilled shrimp salad was enormous and could easily feed 2, but it was mostly field greens with only a small scattering of toppings.  The corn, though, was freshly cut from the cob, which I did like, and the shrimp (all 5 of them) were nicely marinated and large.  The citrus honey vinaigrette actually went very well with the tortilla strips, but I did wish that there had been more avocado.  Overall, though, it was very solid.  The 1/2 lb burger was also solid, and you can substitute sweet potato fries for an extra $1, which I would highly recommend.  The sweet potato fries are well-cooked with a crispy shell and surprisingly symmetrical and uniform in length and width.  Service was pretty attentive and we did get our food in less than 10 minutes.  Plus, it is one of the few places still open for dinner at 9 pm on a Sunday!

Not inexpensive but high quality sandwiches and some pretty primo desserts. I would've liked more pickle on my Cuban. This is a cool spot. Tradition. Tampa. Monte Cristi and coconut creme pie were my fav. There's a patio and tables inside or you can get your grub to go. They also have some salad offerings although I wasn't blown away with the fruit salad or turkey pecan salads I got. But the experience is fun. You order and then pay cafeteria style. Definitely a Tampa institution and worth trying. :)

Visit this park to see how it's done right!  It doesn't get much better than this.

As many many have said there is not a bad seat in the house.  Sight lines are amazing.  Audio is fantastic.  Jumbotrons are state-of-the-art.   So experiencing the game itself is wonderful.

What about the food?  An incredible array of options.  Every kind of sandwich you can think of.  Multiple types of fries.  Several different types of dogs and other sausages.  You'll pay for them but they are very good.

Now for the beer.  Lots of the normal bottles and drafts.  As others have said if you look a little harder you will find a few craft beers. Most beers (bottle/draft) will cost you $7.25.

Finally let's not forget the stadium staff.  Kudos to management for hiring customer focused friendly folks.  It's such a pleasure to interact with them.  

Every time I visit I have a great time.  Last night was no exception.  I'm sure to be back again and again.

I flew out of the terminal with the rest of the airlines (minus Southwest)the other day, & it was slightly better than the Southwest terminal.  The food selection was a little bit better.  But still the same freaking restaurants as the Southwest terminal!  How is it that this terminal gets a USBank office & the other terminal doesn't????  Overall design is a bit better.

Just when I thought brunch at HWK couldn't get any better, it goes and amazes me again. 

I came here on a Sunday morning with Joselyn H. and Sarah S. We had rezzies for 10AM, which was an ideal time, because it started filling up shortly afterwards. Definitely make reservations! 

I started with the pear mimosa, which was one of the best mimosas I've had in my life! Light, sweet, and super bubbly. I loved it. 

Next up, we shared an order of cinnamon bread. Again, this was delicious -- it tasted more biscuit-like than the version I had last time. But it was great. 

I went with the pumpkin french toast, which was SO amazing. It was rich, and was topped with a cream cheese like topping, along with maple syrup. 

YOU GUYS. This was PERFECT. It tasted like pumpkin cheesecake bread pudding! I fell head over heels in love. Wow. Wow. WOW. The menu at HWK changes all the time, so it probably won't be on the menu for long, but geez...if it's on the menu when you visit, just order it. You won't be sorry. 

I'm so in love with HWK. So. In. Love.

They make the best ice cream in Philadelphia. I love coffee flavored ice cream, their lightning rod is my favorite. It is coffee ice cream with espresso beans, dark chocolate brownies, espresso, and pretzel rod. It is insanely good. The southern sympathizer (rum raisin, praline, pistachio) is really good too.

I'm sure this is blasphemous in some parts but I'm not the biggest fan of Leidenheimer bread. I hope we can still be friends. The good news (for me) is that Parkway's po-boys are made on French bread made on the premises! And it's dang delicious.

We all have friends visiting us in search of that illusive "best po-boy." I pretty much go by what my trusted cronies on Yelp say because I don't eat roast beef, nor do I eat oysters either. I like Mahoney's, though they always have that line plus it takes 20 min or more to serve you. So unless I'm willing to kill an afternoon (which is never), it's not happening. I'm also a fan of Freret Street Po-Boys. But, I also wanted to try something new, so I brought my friend who was visiting and in dire need of a roast beef po-boy, to Parkway.

There's several options for seating: inside the bar, which is dim, charming and tavern-like as the name implies, in the brightly lit side room or on the patio. We picked the bar, as it was a particularly muggy and buggy night.

The bartender here was extremely nice and really went out of his way to make sure we had all that we needed (I had figured it'd be a serve yourself kind of operation). I was pretty thrilled to see a dedicated vegetarian section of the menu and although it's not exactly thrillsville in options, you never can go wrong with a Caprese sandwich, right? Vegans can get a plain ol lettuce and tomato sandwich which makes me really glad I'm not vegan anymore, just sayin'. I think there is a French fry one, too and that's about it. I was just happy to see that I didn't have only one (fried) option!

The sandwich can be ordered in small (6 inches) or large (12 inches). I ordered a large, figuring I'd eat the other half for lunch the next day. I advise that you don't do this because the balsamic vinegar soaks through the bottom half of the bread and makes it a kinda gross mush, so it does not hold up very well. So suck it in and eat up both halfs. You know you want to.

The sandwich comes absolutely loaded with ingredients! The mozz is fresh, possibly Buffalo, not sure, but definitely not the low moisture stuff. It will come out cold, just like a Caprese salad. Oh and I recommend the potato salad, too. The perfect compliment to your po-boy.

So, yay, I have another notch on my belt of po-boy adventures.

Hubs and daughter brought me here for Mother's Day dinner.  Reading the reviews prior to going, I wasn't sure how the experience would be however it was WONDERFUL!  We started off with the Korean BBQ Beef Skewers which were just okay - they had more of a sweet flavoring and you don't really get that much, even the presentation of these wasn't eye popping.  On to the drinks -- my hubs got the Old Fashioned and I got the Lavender Honey Sangria.  His Old Fashioned was SUPER strong and mine was very light and refreshing.  I think next time, I'll try something else.  Now on to the important part -- the entrees :)

I ordered the lump crab cake with a side Caesar salad.  My daughter and hubs ordered the filet 8oz, he also ordered a side of scallops which we all shared. The crab cake was DELICIOUS and we LOVED the salad.  I loved that the crab cake wasn't encased in breading and deep fried.  It was very flavorful.  The scallops were okay, not the best I've had but I was satisfied.  Now the filet, WOW.  Seasoning was perfect...the meat cut so easy.....and it just melted in your mouth.  

We followed our dinner with some dessert.  Let me first say that we are typically not dessert folks, but since these were served in small individual sized cups, we just had to try a few.  I ordered the peanut butter pie and my daughter got the cookies and cream.  Both were very good and just big enough to hit the spot.

Service was AMAZING!  My hubs booked a reservation for 8:30PM, when we arrived we visited the hostess stand and were taken to a booth within 5 minutes.  Immediately upon sitting we were greeted by a smiling face of our waitress to take our drink orders.  We sat in the bar area and had a few folks wait on us that evening but they didn't skip a beat whatsoever.  Our drinks and food were out in no time!  We will definitely be adding Seasons 52 to our list of favs and definitely a place to come for a special occasion.

(4) ~ very good overall food & service

MENU:
** Fried Corn-on-the-Cob = (4.25) Very good
** Potato Salad = (4) very good
** Ribs = (4) very good flavor, didn't even need any sauce;)
* Fitz's Root Beer  = (3.75) Good

Not sure how famous Famous 4th Street Cookie really is, but I can say for sure that their double chocolate chip cookies are quite the treat, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, especially fresh. They're a good size, easily sharable with a friend.

If you take them home, they'll keep for a few days; microwave them and don't forget to pour a tall glass of milk.

Find them in the Reading Terminal Market.

Now I'm not a diehard Phillies fan but I am still in love with this stadium.  There is not a bad seat in the house and there is a plethora of dining and shopping options, including gluten-free offerings and healthy fare.  The gatekeepers are very friendly and kept me company while I finished my larger iced coffee (you can't bring in any opened beverages) by telling me stories of past games and incidents at the field.  We had seats in the Diamond Club, which was beyond awesome.  The lounge had bistro stations, which served every cuisine from stir-fries to sundaes to huge burgers.  There were also TVs everywhere so you don't miss out on the game.  The food is a bit pricey though but that's to be expected.  The in-seat delivery/dining sounds great but it took them about 2 innings to deliver our drinks so it might be faster to just grab food at the concessions stand.  The view from behind home was fantastic and the seats were very capacious and comfortable.  Overall a fantastic experience and it certainly didn't hurt that the home team won by a single run in the 11th inning.  Parking is a pain but if you get there early, it's not too long of a trek from the lots ($15 fee).

I came here with Cherie O. for the lunch special.  OMG!  This was toooo freaking delish!  The salad was soooo good!  The bacon wrapped meatloaf, mashed potatoes & glazed carrots were cooked to perfection.  Despite my medical condition (having no bile storage unit), I had just one bite of the mashed potatoes & thought I died & gone to mashed potato heaven.  Butter just makes everything taste good.  The amount of food was sufficient for me.  I loved the Pappy's BBQ reduction on the meatloaf!  The service was great.  The ambience was really warm & comfy.  It's a hole in the wall.  FYI, the lunch specials are $10 (doesn't includes tax) & comes with iced tea.  If you come here for the lunch special, come early (11 am).

I had been wanting to try this restaurant for a while, and while I'm glad I did, I'm not thrilled by the experience.

Everything about this place was "okay."  The setting is fine, very 2000s chic, high ceilings (read: loud), friendly servers.    But the place is a chain, and it showed.

The wines are wholly unremarkable.  Yes, they are inexpensive.  But after doing the Lux Flight (and tasting most of my mother-in-law's white wine flight), I can say that the wine isn't very good.  It's all too sweet with an unpleasant aftertaste.  My husband tried a cocktail, and it was full of very sweet juice and not much alcohol.

Food suffered from the same sweetness.  We tried the fried calamari and the drunken shrimp.  Everything was edible, but nothing was great.  Entrees suffered from the same mediocrity.  My father-in-law, who normally clears his plate, left half of his entree uneaten.  Dessert was fun, but again, nothing special.  Nothing on the menu was especially innovative, and I have a strong feeling that some of the stuff was pre-packaged, because why else were they out of the crispy shrimp but able to serve drunken shrimp?  This place was a fancy Chili's, fitting for its location by the airport.

The restaurant does allow outside wines with only an $8 corkage.  Maybe if I brought my own wine I'd return for a burger.  But I wouldn't return for their wine, and I'd keep the meal simple.

I've been so many times over so many years I can't even count them and ALL my experiences have been outstanding.  Commander's ranks as among the best overall dining venues ever with among the best service by the staff anywhere, anyplace, anytime that I've experienced.  I've heard stories of people that had bad service but I've never seen such a thing.  

I prefer lunch to dinner as they have the great 25 cent martini special that will quickly get you in trouble as they have some kick.  Commander's is also noted for a really nice Jazz Brunch.  I should also confess that I'm an extra big fan of Commander's as I can throw a rock from my house and hit it so that makes it very convenient.  They always have some amazing specials made with locally sourced fresh ingredients.  

If I had a complaint about the food it would have been a few times when I didn't love an entree and thought it was just ok but that has happened very few times considering (and not every dish is to everyone's taste).  I have also noticed a bit of a lack of change on the menu the last few times I've dined at Commander's and the dishes all seemed pretty familiar, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but generally I've come to expect a bit more rotation in what is offered from visit to visit.

There are few CIVILIZED dining establishments left these days where one is expected to dress properly and Commander's is one of those places!  I'm so very glad that Commander's has not given into the sloppy tourist's & newly arrived yankee "locals" demands that they be allowed to wear the nasty casual fashion trends of the moment (with their smelly hipster flip flops) so if you plan on dining here do remember to dress up!!!  Ladies I shouldn't have to tell you but obviously it needs to be said:  Please remember that blue jeans, no matter how much they cost, are NOT business casual for lunch and should NEVER be seen at night!!!  Dress to impress and live like a civilized local (and by civilized I mean dress up and look extraordinary as you drink and eat to excess!!!). 

I also want to give extra KUDOS to wait captain Mary's section as she really makes sure that you have an outstanding time with impeccable service!!!

I was waiting to write a review until I could rave about Bartaco, but after a year of random visits, it still is just average to me.  Most of my visits I sat at the bar, and the service was fine, with food and cocktails appearing in a relatively timely manner.

My most recent visit was a holiday, and the restaurant was dreadfully understaffed.  In addition to that, it had rained right before we got there, so all the people sitting outside had to be moved inside.  This, apparently, had caused the restaurant kitchen to get completely backed up, so they stopped seating people.  We waited for a table for 20 minutes - while we could actually see at least ten empty tables in the restaurant.  

News Flash Bartaco:  it rains in Florida!  So, unless you plan on having this issue every single day you need to a) cover your patio enough that people can remain sitting there when it rains b) have your kitchen organized enough that it can handle a full restaurant and c) hire enough staff.

The manager was bustling about, clearing tables, etc. and finally when we were sat, he brought us over free chips and guacamole.  (Which our server came over and said 'oh, they gave you somebody else's').  Our server was nice, but slow.  Cocktails took quite a long time to come out, and my friend finally had to ask for her coke.  The food was good, but also took a long time to come out.  My favorite item was the mahi ceviche, which had a nice flavor.  I had a pork belly taco and an oyster taco, both of which were served cold.  Each taco took about 2 bites to eat, for $3.50 each.  And that brings me to my final gripe - the food is very expensive for what you get.  If you plan to leave full, plan on spending at least $15-$20 per person.  For tacos.

Why 5 stars? Because Yummy House remains my favorite Chinese food in Tampa Bay.

   ---   ---   ---

Since the early days of the first location in West Tampa, I've been a huge Yummy House fan. They've come a long way since then, now with multiple locations all throughout the region. And unlike their original location that's more a dive/hidden gem, these other spots are bright, modern and sleek. 

We wanted to check out the South Tampa location because I believe it's the only one that offers dim sum. Unfortunately, I've had better dim sum just about any other time I've had it. It wasn't bad, but it just left a bit to be desired. The good news, however, is that our entrees were just as amazing as every other time I've patronized a Yummy House location. 

Fried Rice - A basic Chinese food staple but it just tastes like it's made with a little extra love here.

Sweet & Sour Pork - This probably wouldn't be something I'd typically order, but my wife was craving it, and I ended up partaking in many-a-bite. It was quite addicting! 

Beef Chow Fun - At first, we were confused when this was brought out because we didn't see any noodles, but it turned out that they were just hiding below the beef and veggies on the surface. We ordered the "wet" version of this dish, and it was quite wet indeed. As addicting as the sweet and sour pork was, these fat noodles were the thing I absolutely could not stop eating, despite being totally stuffed.

These weren't even my favorite things to order and I still loved every bite! As usual, Yummy House delivers!

Some may be surprised I'm giving this place 3 stars but we were not impressed. For the money, I was expecting more. 

Our server, although nice, lacked the finesse and attention to detail. 

We were sat at a nice table near the window, but as others have stated, it's really hard to see anything at night time. 

We shared the crab cakes appetizer and they were good. A little too much breading for the price, but they were good. 

For our entrees we chose the ahi tuna and the halibut, chef's special. We also shared a side of Mac n cheese. 

The halibut was good, but nothing great. My husband's tuna was a little over cooked. The Mac n cheese was lacking any big chunks of lobster and the cheese sauce had an unusual taste. To date, Capital Grill's lobster Mac n cheese can't be beat. The positive from my dish is that it came with one of the largest prawns I've ever seen. It was huge!

After we were done eating both our appetizers and entrees, our empty plates sat there a little too long. Even after our dinner was cleared no one came by and cleaned up the leftover macaroni that sat on the table. My husband's empty vodka rocks glass and his stirring straws, sat there was well.  For an upscale restaurant, I would expect the table to be de-crumbed and everything to be cleared away. 

Would we go back?  Probably not, although I would probably try their brunch.
Decent, small airport with just what you need and nothing more. Not the worst place to wait for a flight!

This review is for the Sunday brunch.

After Jilly's was voted best brunch in St. Louis and hearing so many good things, I was really looking forward to trying their brunch.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed.  We felt we should have paid $7-9pp instead of $15pp.

I made a reservation on a Friday and just barely got in with an after-12pm slot.  It was busy.  They also let me know that our "booking time" was (I think she said) 1 hour 45 mins (or was it 1.5 hrs?).  I guess seating is really a premium.

We entered through the new cafe entrance, checked in with the hostess, paid $14.99 plus tax per  person, and were guided to our table for two back where the original Jilly's Cupcake used to be located.

It was cramped.  The person behind continuously backed his chair into mine.  At one point, his chair caught mine and moved me over 3 inches while I was eating.  Diners seated behind our table (and not wanting to bother the large man behind me) would ask me to move my chair (already pressed up against the table) so they could get through.  So what I'm trying to say is that IT IS CRAMPED.

The line for the food required a wait each time I went up.  This was also a bummer.  You could only approach the buffet from one side, so everyone was single file, moving slowly.

Condiments were located at the front of the line, which we found awkward since we didn't know yet what we were going to get from the buffet in order to know what condiments we'd want.

Food we tried:
- Bacon Deviled Eggs - "fine" but weren't refilled during our visit
- Beef Brisket - not much available and never refilled during our visit
- Fruit medley - grapes, melon, strawberries were fresh and good
- Zucchini Bread - mini-muffins were tasty
- Asparagus - Grilled, w/ romesco sauce - tasted fine, tons of it avail.
- Bagel & Schmear - Broken pieces of bagel, lots of schmear, not really clear what schmears or sauces were intended or recommended for
- Waffles - carrot cake flavor was good, you had to spoon the syrup out right there w/ no little containers to put it in so no chance to put butter on before the syrup; syrup got all over the plate and other food   
- Scrambled eggs - strangely, my 2nd favorite item on the buffet (not sure what that says), my husband found them watery, which was probably true
- Rosemary Lemon Chicken - roasted and AWESOME, my favorite item
- Chorizo Egg Strata - Probably a 2/5 (I didn't finish it)
- Cinnamon Sugar Chips - ok
- Orange Juice - no pulp, yay

Came back to Parasols under new ownership. What was once the best roast beef in town is no more. The new owners changed the bread, they are using Gendusa's less crispy bread instead of Leidenheimer. The meat is the same, real roasted beef that is housemade not the sliced deli stuff. The gravy is also not the same as it was. I remember the big hunks of garlic and this one didn't have that same flavor.

Kind of a mixed bag. Pretty pricey. The guac made table side quite good  Some of the apps were pretty tasty. Our main courses were a bit disappointing. Overcooked meat. Too much sauce that wasn't appetizing. Chunky cheese accompaniment. They need to up the freshness and flavor. Less salt more quality ingredients attention to detail.
had the corned beef, it was excellent. Surprisingly one of the best corned beef in town

Worth a repeat visit and review.   If anything it has gotten better and more creative, as well as expanded options by taking over the next-door bakery (formerly Kalupa's)  So now they offer even more sandwich choices with a current push on bacon combinations.  Prices are a bit high bur portions have you taking food home.  The bakery now offers some bread but more pastries, cookies, candy, truffles and gelato to eat there or take home.  This is a lasting--quality place worth patronizing regularly.

Comparing Oxford Exchange to McDonald's,  is like Tampa & St. Petersburg  are the same. The king of the "Golden Arches", I would never affiliate with Oxford  Exchange & that is a posative  good thing. Personally  I have no use for fast food, but Oxford Exchange is on my list of must "dos", in Tampa.
I love poking and browsing around the OE, as much as I do eating there. Do I wish they served alcohol, of course, but it just shows it's  not necessary  to be sucessful. I love the buddy brew room, as I am a lover of people watching and good joe! 
The ambiance  to me is hip, yet casual, with a smattering of shylights. The bookstore was welcoming  and awesome, I could have gotten lost in their if we had not had reservations.
The staff was energetic, helpful and very welcoming. The fried Brussel sprouts with shaved parmesson  cheese & the lobster BLT, we're utterly amazing. Both were perfectly  prepared & cooked.... spot on. The last was luscious,  earthy, & exquisite  ( from me that is high praise).
I can't wait to return for high tea, oh yea, I am that type of girl". I will do that in the near future & report back. So far breakfast & lunch have been great!
What's  a  girl  to  do?  Always looking for perfection,  often surprised by what I find.

I've been to pretty much all of the Columbia locations. This one is quite charming with the original decor. It is also quite nice because they have the flamenco shows which I did get to see.  This location gets a 3 star for those specific elements.
However, if it weren't for that, it would get two stars. Why you ask?  Myself and the two other people in the group all got sick. So obviously, we all ate the same stuff but it all did not do us quite well. After that visit, we knew we would never be back. 
I like the Sarasota location the most, and the Clearwater(sand key) location second.
They usually have a 1905 day on their anniversary where they put the prices down to back in the day prices. Everything under $1.00.  They are not having it this year. That is a bummer. I sent a message to the Columbia facebook, and they let me know they are planning something super huge for next year. We will see what happens. It is usually around this time of the year (September).

I decided to catch the MNF Rams game here.  During the Rams games they have domestic draft beer specials (although they are served in shitty plastic cups), and they give away two tickets to an upcoming home game.  Plus there is typically a 10% off your food for checkin-in on Yelp.  

We got boneless wings and a pizza.  The wings were normal.  The pizza is good.  It consists of a thinner but not cracker-like seasoned crust.  Topping selections are diverse... I had meatballs and ricotta.  

Service was awesome... our server Amie was always around and offered recommendations.  

...and I won 2 Rams tickets for staying until the 4th quarter of the game.  All I had to do is like their facebook page and comment on a post to get entered.  Pretty cool!

I had been excited to try Texas de Brazil, and my first chance was going to be with my friends at a birthday celebration.  We were a party of 5 and seated near the salad bar. Our server was polite, and the bread that was dropped at the table was interesting. 

Our meat cowboys didn't seem to pay any attention to the red or green signs that our table displayed AT ALL. They simply were there, Ready to serve you meat. Some of which was very tasty, some.. eh. it was ok. 

The salad bar was good, I enjoyed the selections there in, and my friends love the bisque.  We had trouble getting the friends birthday discount applied to our checque.

I am now an official Garden Member! I do attend the garden for events throughout the year and so when I was there yesterday my hubby and I decided to sign up for the individual garden membership. We are true St. Louisian's now! 

I really had no idea how large the gardens were. We spent the day walking around (getting lost). Did you know they had a house to tour? I didn't. When walking around yesterday I saw this house and had to see what it was all about. According to the tour guides the house was built by the garden founder, Henry Shaw. We got to take a look at the house and tour the rooms. Right now they have it all decorated for the holidays and it is beautiful! I really can't wait to go back and see it in April or May when they have it decorated with the traditional items. It was really cool to look around the house and learn about the history of the gardens. 

We took our time exploring all of the gardens. My favorite location has to be the Japanese Gardens though! I can only imagine how colorful it is during the spring and summer! We found our way to the lake where people were feeding the fish. We even managed to find a nice spot on the water to sit and relax. It was amazing! There are also some mazes on the path which were pretty cool too. 

I'll have to go back again soon to see the Garden Glow exhibit because walking around in the day time did not do it justice. Lighting it up at night must be magical. 

Our main reason for attending yesterday was because we had tickets to see the Gardenland Express Holiday Flower & Train Show! On our way out from the gardens we stopped inside to walk around this exhibit and it was beautiful! The flowers were so holiday-rific! It's worth a look if you can make it before January 1. 

Now that I am a member I can't wait to go back again and again throughout 2018!

The Columbia in the cool Ybor City of Tampa is one of the iconic dining experiences in Florida. The crowds who flock to eat here do so not because of a lack of other choices, but because they want to experience the oldest restaurant in Florida. 

The bright tiles adorning the outside walls lead to an equally colorful and varied décor inside.  With 15 dining rooms there are several variations but the larger rooms may have a fountain or  crystal chandelier and will have many art works and photos on the walls.  Smaller rooms have some excellent tile and iron & woodwork.  Of course there's the occasional medieval knight to guard you.  Do make a reservation and if you don't, sitting at the friendly bar gives you the best chance of avoiding a wait.

There are many famous dishes on the menu such as the Spanish bean soup, the 1905 salad (where iceberg lettuce was first named), the deviled crab croquettes etc. etc. etc. The menu is large and consists mainly of Cuban and Spanish foods ... often with a subtle Tampa twist.  One dining room has flamenco dancing every night but you pay extra to eat there.  Don't.  Just walk in and view the dancing.  You see the staff is super accommodating and will let you walk all around this atmospheric culinary institution.  Hey there's even a museum and shop next door for those who want to take home some souvenirs.

I am going to say, I really didn't find the food to be mind-blowing awesome ... but I didn't care.  It was the experience that earned this place its high rating  .....and downing a couple of Tampa's Jai Alai IPA's helped enhance it. 

 The original Ybor City Columbia is a true classic!

The fish here is amazingly fresh and just melts in your mouth. The toro was among the best that I have had in the area. The slightly seared scallop was fantastic as well. I also tried the island roll and really loved the mango/spicy salmon blend. The soft shell crab roll, which is just one of my staples, was fried to the perfect crispiness without being overly breaded. Service was great and I will definitely be back to sample the Korean dishes. If they make a bibimbap on par with their sushi, I will be a regular here, for certain.

So I've never written a Sweet Lucy's review. Say whaaaa? From my first visit, after a football UYE with yelpers Jim H, Bill M, Dan C, Akshay M and Caroline L, to my experiences with their catering at First Person Arts events, one thing is for certain: Lucy is one smooth southern lady. 

Pulled pork, mac and cheese, spicy collards and corn bread - that's all you need to know. If you're planning to eat at the restaurant, bring a crew, bring some brew and grab one of the picnic tables. You're guaranteed to have a great meal and a great time.

Went here on a recommendation since I love me some Pho. Small shop and gets pretty packed. A little confusing upon entering as we didn't know if we order at the register or if we sit and order. We were eventually greeted by a waiter that led us to our seats. Don't let fort impressions scare you away....the restaurant is very small, cramped, and doesn't appear to be too clean. Ordered my Tofu Pho which was good. Would've liked to have some veggies in it -- but the flavor of the broth was good. Will I go back? Yea, probably. It's definitely not my favorite Vietnamese restaurant and Pho but it's close to work and will do for my Pho cravings. The Shrimp springrolls have mint in them so heads up. I hate mint and didn't even think to order without since the typical place I go doesn't put mint in theirs. 

Overall service was extremely quick. After ordering we didn't even wait 5 minutes before we had our food. Confusing after eating too. Nobody came to the table to tell us we go to the register to pay. Finally figured it out after we waited and watched what others were doing.

An update to my reviews:

Come for happy hour ANYTIME if you sit out on the patio or up at the bar.  Thei fountain drones out Boyscout Blvd traffic. 

Order these items-lettuce wraps, sushi rolls, BBQ flatbread pizza and avocado egg rolls.

Ted, it has been two years since my original review and figured I needed to give you an update. I am glad I waited till now and did not do it last fall. At that point, you were starting to lose me as a fan, but this season you are on a strong A-Game. 

Your custard is rich, creamy and can be turned upside down without any consequences. I have even been able to turn mine upside down after a 2 mile drive home.  I've tried other flavors, but I will always be true to my M & M's  being my favorite. 

I also want to commend you on your staff. Your front window employees are always friendly and know how to move the line quickly. Then  I wonder how those who make the sweet treats, how they can turn them so fast. Your custard truly is a treat of Saint Louis and Route 66.

Oxford Exchange is a place that you want to give 5 stars to. The place is simply amazing. Walking inside the building is a experience that you won't get anywhere else in Tampa Bay, guaranteed. I absolutely love the book store, I spent lots of time at bookstores before Amazon wiped them off the face of the Earth. The gift shop has plenty of interesting things for sale, many of them catering to my travel hobby obsession.

Lunch in the courtyard is an experience I never thought I would have in Tampa and reminds me of this incredible cafe in Seoul where you can dine on the 5th floor of a rooftop in a small courtyard - minus the rooftop - but still...definitely not something I ever imagined even finding something similar to in Tampa Bay. 

Oxford Exchange is a perfect choice for a business meeting - even if you're just meeting for some coffee and tea. I think the table space and rush wouldn't allow for large parties, such as birthday parties of family get-togethers though.

The service has been hit-or-miss so far. First time a major miss, second time was satisfactory, but not anything stellar. The bill put inside a book were a nice touch on the first visit, but was marred by our terrible first encounter - when it came around on my second visit I hardly noticed and that's why first impressions are so important!

The menu isn't very different from what you'll find at most cafes - mostly sandwiches and appetizers. The steak sandwich, recommended by Mr. Brett N. - Tampa CM was quite delicious. I do like the sweet potato fries.The Matcha Lemonade is pretty awesome. 

If the Oxford Exchange had better food options and a more consistent service experience than it would have 5 stars hands down. I'm definitely a fan of the place and I'm glad it came to town, but it's important if you have a restaurant to pay attention to your food and service quality and that is the weakness of the Oxford Exchange.
I'm here at least once a month.   Still good for sure.  Pineapple fried rice and soft shell crab pad Thai.   Yum.

So amazing mazing mazing. The service there was awesome and sweet and helpful. I don't know Pho, but I sure want to. It was sooooooo good. I found this place through Yelp, and it was worth the drive totally totally to the max. I ordered noodles with beef and It had the vegetables and the mint seasoning and the sauce with fresh spring rolls. Boy you are so good. I can't wait to eat your huge soups.
I was so not knowing what to get. They were so helpful in explaining everything to me without me feeling like a dummy. The price was really good too, like $5 for a huge huge take out.  She gave me her card and said that I could call ahead to order and not have to wait.
They were awesome. The thing that through me off is on the wall it looks like they would post the menu items but it was just blank. They should just spruce up the place a little bit and it will be to the max perfect. I sure don't care though. You guys are awesome, food is great, and service is GREAT!!!

Well, all good things must come to an end, right?

That now applies to the Kona Grill. 

Once the best happy hour in the area and maybe in all of Tampa, I was very disappointed to learn of all the changes made this summer.

It also did not help that the cosmo martini we ordered was more watered down than cheap drinks at a bad wedding. 

Apparently, my days of consistently inviting and meeting friends here at the bar or on the patio are pretty much over.

Too bad. But we did have a good run and I'm sure the quality of the food remains the same.

Pat O'Brien's was a pleasantly surprising tourist spot. Having not tried a hurricane over three days into our visit, my friend and I stopped in on a Sunday afternoon.

We took seats at the bar to front left of the St. Peter St. entrance.  There was a crowd of people watching playoff football at the corner TV and staggered bar seats open. It was freezing outside so a well heated room was a plus for sure. 

Our bartender was an older gentleman and had a southern charm. 

Of course, we both went for the Hurricane's. Considering I didn't really feel like drinking nor did I feel like a beverage of that size, I really enjoyed my Hurricane. While it was sweet, it definitely wasn't as sweet as the grenades. One Hurricane left a very pleasant buzz. 

I was impressed by the tasty and individually wrapped popcorn we were given. I never reach into this communal bowls so I really enjoyed being able to have a little snack with my drink. 

In order to get through the bathroom, we had to pass through the dueling piano room. The room was gorgeous and the pianists were playing a good rendition of a classic rock song. For a touristy place where people get hammered, the bathrooms were surprisingly clean. 

I think this review breaks my own record of most times using "pleasant" and "surprising." I'd recommend Pat O'Brien's to others and make a return of my own next trip.

What can I say about a place that hasn't been said in 353 reviews before this one?

Commander's is the best of the best.  It's where you want to go when you have a little extra money to spend and you want to not just have dinner, but have an EXPERIENCE.

Here the gourmet food is prepared by Chef's who were trained in their craft.  The waitstaff does this as a career, and isn't just a bunch of 20-somethings working their way through college.

This is a place where memories are made, laughs are had, and friends come together.  Engagements happen here.  Birthdays, graduations and promotions are celebrated here.  You are treated as if you are royalty, because from the time you walk into the door to the time you leave, that's exactly what you are, at this restaurant.

Sure, the place would be considered pricey by most standards but  you aren't just paying for the food.  You are paying for the privilege of dining here.

Stopped by here with the family one night a few weeks back. The place looks really nice inside. Decorations on the walls and an upscale feel to it. The prices are also reflecting that. I went with their sushi and was really disappointed (especially being so hungry) to find that it really wasn't that fresh. The sushi also lacked flavor and I didn't want to be rude after ordering so many rolls so I just picked at it and then left still hungry. 

The waitress was really friendly though and although that doesn't make up for their food, they did try to message me on Twitter after seeing that I checked in there on Foursquare and had a bad experience so I would say their service is top-notch. I hear their burgers are pretty tasty so maybe I will have them someday.

I've been wanting to try Zahav for the past year and am so glad that I finally did. We did the tasting menu, which I believe is the best way to go. It's definitely a good deal. We started with the Turkish hummus, salatim (salads) and laffa. We asked for a second laffa because we wolfed our first one down - it was all so delicious! The picked veggies they put on the table upon our arrival were also quite tasty. After the hummus and salatim, we had the fried haloumi (cheese), fried cauliflower, fried sweetbreads, and smoked sable on challah toast. The haloumi was my favorite of the night - it was absolutely incredible. The fried cauliflower was good, but the flavor was nothing special in my mind. The sweetbreads were also tasty, but it tasted like something was missing. The only thing thus far that we didn't like was the sable. I actually wouldn't finish it - the sable itself didn't have good flavor, and the Challah toast tasted stale. For our main courses, I got the mushrooms and the bf got the hangar steak. The mushrooms were really tasty - perfectly cooked, and the lamb bacon was AWESOME. I wish the lamb bacon had been cut into smaller pieces because I actually couldn't distinguish it from the mushrooms. We each ate a whole piece of the bacon in one bite, so we couldn't savor it with the mushrooms. The hangar steak was OK...the flavor was great, but it wasn't hot and it was a bit chewy. For dessert, I got the milk chocolate baklava and my bf got the rugelach. Dessert was nothing memorable - The baklava had a very strong peanut flavor and an orange glaze that I SWEAR wasn't listed on the menu (if it were, I would've asked for it without). The rugelach was good, but not like the Jewish bakeries in town. The pumpkin ice cream that came with the baklava had no taste of pumpkin whatsoever, and the Turkish ice cream that came with the rugelach was good but quite different with the flavor of coriander.

Overall, the food was a 4, but the service brought the experience up to a 5. I'm telling you, it was some of the best service I have ever gotten. The manager walked around and asked each table how the meal was, the server was attentive without nagging. Our water glasses were always at least 3/4 of the way full, and we were offered drink refills often. The ambience is great - classy and sophisticated, yet cozy.

I would definitely recommend Zahav to anyone looking for a tasty, special meal. The flavors of the food were different and overall we really enjoyed our meals.

Great Expectations is not only the name of a famous novel but also a description of my feelings as I visit a Garces restaurant. Last night the lovely wife and I kicked off Restaurant Week by visiting Amada and as expected, our meal was extraordinary.

Depending on the dictionary Amada translates to darling or beloved.  Whatever the translation, I am in love.  We are no strangers to Garces places and have visited Distrito and JG Domestic several times.  This is also not our first visit here.

Our Open Table reservations were honored perfectly and we were seated about five minutes early.  Our waiter was Harrison and throughout our meal he was competent and friendly.

The Restaurant Week menu included two appetizers, two entrees and a desert each.  So the two of us enjoyed a total of ten plates.  Note to new visitors; five plates each was the perfect number.  We were pleasantly full but not stuffed.

As we sighed and moaned over each delightful morsel we discovered we had a problem.  We would have a very difficult time deciding which dish or dishes were our favorites.  If you are visiting a tapas restaurant this is exactly the problem you want to face.

In the interests of brevity I'll mention three wonderful plates.  The Cana De Cabra cheese with fig and cherry marmalade was a perfect appetizer.  My wife's eyes lit up when she had her first taste and I agree.  The Costillas De Ternera Coca (beef shortrib flatbread with horseradish, parmesan and bacon) was beautiful to behold.  The kick from the horseradish worked well with the beef.  Finally the Madre E Hijo (chicken breast with truffles and fried egg) was plated beautifully.  I am a sucker for truffles and I was not disappointed.

At a Garces restaurant I've learned to expect at least a four star if not a five star experience.  Once again we were blown away.  Kudos to Jose for creating one of the best dining destinations in Philly.

Shaved Duck, you just kissed a star goodbye. I am beginning to think that maybe lunch is not for you. Perhaps you need to just focus on Happy Hour and Dinner. 
The reason I think lunch is not for you is because the last three times we've come in to experience your fabulous St Louis Style Spare Ribs  they're not available.  WTF, do you realize how disappointing that is. Once we were so disappointed, we walked out and took our business else were. Today however, we stayed and enjoyed your Beef Brisket. 

Since we didn't get to have a full rack of ribs, we started out with some of your Smoked Chicken Wings. They were slow smoked to perfection and the dry rub flavoring is enough for me. However, I will say the mango, ginger, habanero sauce that comes on the side is your best sauce. 

We both ordered the Beef Brisket Sandwich, one with Home Fries and the other with Man - N - Cheese. Holy Mackerel, Batman that is the best MNC in the city and the only way to improve those Home Fries would be to "Smoother" them. 

Our waiter was friendly and attentive. He even listened to pissy rant about not being able to get our ribs. I am sure once we get to have the STL Spare Ribs, you'll get your other star back.

What can I say that the zillion other reviews haven't noted already? Well, how about noting that this restaurant is one of the top 100 places to eat on Yelp in the country? http://officialblog.yelp.com/2014/02/yelp-data-reveals-top-100-places-to-eat-bookmark-these-babies-now.html *If this article doesn't make you believe in the populartity, than the line winding throughout the business, down the hallway and out the back door probably will. 

We opted for the burnt ends, pulled pork, fried corn and macaroni and cheese. The mac was mighty tasty - as was the pulled pork. I really enjoyed sampling all of the sauces at our table (not that the meat necessarily needed it). I always seem to be searching for a little extra kick of "something". 

Note that the line moves fairly quickly. Although, if given the choice, I would opt for visiting during less popular hours (between lunch and dinner). Carry out is available but it appeared these folks also had to wait in line :(

Café Lift and I did not get off to a good start.

I called ahead to find out the wait for a party of two and was told it would be about 35-40 minutes. Perfect. The plan was to swing by, put our name down and then go buy a bottle of bubbly since it's a BYOB brunch. The only problem was that when we got there, two counter spots were available and my big mouth accidentally mentioned the Champaign run. Due to their seating policy, we wouldn't be able to be added to the list. Their policy isn't my reason for the three stars because it is what it is. Take the policy or leave it. I just feel it is fair to include my entire experience in my review. 

Disappointedly I left figuring we'd try Café Lift another day. My husband was determined though, so we made the bubbly run and came back to give it another try. Upon our return, our wait time was about 30-40 minutes ago. We got to waiting and I was quickly losing my patience which is NEVER a good thing when going to a popular brunch spot. We were practically across the street when my name was called about 20 minutes into the wait. It was probably a good thing because I'm not sure if I was going to come back another day to try again.

It was all up from there. Our server came over fairly quickly and seeing us with a bottle, get us quickly set up for mimosas. Since we had time to review the menu, we were pretty ready to place our order of the special French toast and the Jen's Crespelle. 

The French toast was made with challah bread topped with pumpkin cannoli filling, chipped bittersweet chocolate, and maple-soaked walnuts. The Jen's Crespelle consisted of scrambled eggs, turkey bacon and fontina cheese, rolled in an Italian-style crepe and topped with maple syrup.

The French toast platter was huge so there was more than enough for me to try, and for my husband to still have leftovers. It was almost like eating cake. It was fluffy, sweet and the maple-soaked walnuts were to die for! I couldn't really taste the pumpkin in the cannoli filling though. 

The Jen's Crespelle was the perfect balance for folks who have sweet versus savory decision issues. The crepe was thin but sturdy and housed the egg, bacon and cheese nicely. I typically don't have fontina cheese with my eggs, however it did a great job being melty and blending with the eggs. I couldn't taste any syrup when my platter initially came out, but there was a container on the table so I was able to dress the dish myself. I guess I could do that with any savory dish. I'm storing that trick away for my next brunch outing. There was also a small side of potatoes which were pretty good. They weren't fried and possibly broiled. In any case, they were very fresh. They had a nice, possibly rosemary like seasoning to them and were quite enjoyable.  

As far as the setting, we were seated right behind the hostess booth. There was enough space between us and the next table, however the restaurant was very loud. This could be due to the high ceilings in the building.  I almost felt like I was screaming at my husband to communicate with. 

Despite the initial hiccups, I enjoyed my food and am glad I ended up sticking it out at Café Lift. However with so many top notch brunch spots in the city, I won't be rushing back.

This review is just for drinks at the bar.

Last night after getting dinner close by, myself and four others went over to El Vez to celebrate "National Margarita Day." We found a small space at the bar and ordered some drinks.

The service was good, the bartenders were fast and nice, but I have to say, the margaritas are NOT THAT GREAT!! People always talk about El Vez like it's the be-all and end-all of margaritas, but that's just not the case.

I ordered the pineapple margarita and my husband got the classic. They both were OK, but nothing special. Seriously. Maybe my expectations were just too high going in here, but I certainly won't be making a trip to El Vez just to drink again.

This airport will not give you a headache. It was easy to navigate, with very clear signage. 

I really liked how they had multiple security checkpoints based on the terminal you were heading to. I'm used to one security line for everyone, regardless of what airline they're flying. This meant that we were able to get through security in no time at all. 

There were not a lot of restaurants/food selections (compared to PHL and HJA) but there was a Starbucks, which is probably where I would have ended up going had there been more options, anyway. 

Lastly, there were lots and lots and lots of charging stations.

Bern's Steak House is a Tampa institution and an absolutely stunning fine dining experience. This is a special occasion restaurant, great for a dinner date or business meeting or just getting together with friends to celebrate an amazing evening. Plan on spending some money, especially if you order drinks and a bottle or two of wine, but the base price of your steak dinner with all of the trimmings is certainly reasonable.

Reservations are a must, and it's wise to make them a week or two out -- especially during busy holiday times, or on the eve of a major event in Tampa (football games, Gasparilla, etc.) As a last-minute option, arrive when they first open at 5pm and ask to sit in the lounge area. They'll even let you sit at the bar, but if your cellphone plays an obnoxious electronic song at top volume every time that you get a message, then expect other people to throw their steakhouse mushrooms at you.

Dressing up is also recommended. This is not the place to wear shorts, t-shirts, and flip flops. Save that for your other South Howard hangouts. Show some class and wear long pants, a collared shirt, and even shoes.

If you have a reservation you'll be seated in one of their many dining rooms, and your server will be right over with the menus. The wait staff at Bern's is at the top of their game, and many of these folks have been with the restaurant for a very long time. If you ask, they'll generally explain that they started working at the company's proprietary farm located in NW Hillsborough county (This is where the vegetables such as broccoli, cauliflower, kale and microgreens are grown), after that they rotate through all of the kitchen positions to learn what happens at each station. It often takes a year or more of training before they're allowed out in the dining rooms.

Don't be shy about asking for their recommendations as they truly know their craft. On one of my first trips to the restaurant, my server was a guy named Kurt, and he told all sorts of fascinating stories and made some excellent suggestions that really enhanced our meal. He is one of Bern's veteran servers, and if you end up in his section then you'll be in for a real treat.

On this last trip to Bern's I met my lovely Yelp wife, Anna M, at the bar where Lynn was showing off some amazing mixology skills. I ordered a bourbon Old Fashioned, and we nibbled daintily on the cheese toasts before ordering the tuna tartare appetizer. Very delicious! Since this was our official 'Ring in the Holidays' special occasion dinner, we were able to sit in Jennifer's section and had a marvelous time visiting with her while we ate. Thanks Jen!

You can make your dinner as basic or as complex as you like, and your server will be glad to assist. You can start by ordering any appetizers, caviar, soups, or salads. Then with the assistance of the Bern's sommeliers you can select some incredible wines from their massive cellar. We chose a 2012 Joseph Swan Cuvee' de Trois Pinot Noir from the Russian River Valley this past time. An absolutely outstanding wine!

From there you select your steak or other entrée. Bern's offers six different cuts of steak which are ordered according to overall size and thickness, and then cooked to your specifications. The meat is aged and hand-trimmed, again according to your specifications. Ask your server for help, and don't be afraid to ask a lot of questions. There are all sorts of toppings and sauces that are available, and they'll gladly guide you through the choices.

Your basic meal comes with French onion soup, a tossed greens salad, baked potato, two vegetables of the day, and crispy onion strings -- all for the cost of your steak. Knowing this, a $50 14-ounce Delmonico steaksteak does not seem unreasonable. (Especially considering the potential for leftovers!). Anna and I added the Steakhouse mushrooms and the crispy shiitake mushrooms as a la carte veggies, but otherwise each ordered a big ole honking Delmonico with plans for leftovers the next day.

After Jen boxed up our leftovers, she led us back to the kitchen for the legendary tour of the kitchen and the wine cellar. This is fantastic behind-the-scenes opportunity to see how things are prepared, and ask all the questions that you like. Everyone is more than willing to stop and speak with you, and they are genuinely thankful that you're having dinner in their restaurant.

The wine cellar is jaw-droppingly amazing. You will see bottles of wine costing hundreds of thousands of dollars, and your tour guide will point out some of the more interesting vintages, and answer all of your questions.

From there you climb the stairs to the Harry Waugh Dessert Room where you'll be seated in one of 48 individual cubbyholes built from redwood wine casks to give you a very private and exclusive table. Riley was our waiter, and he talked me into a warm pineapple upside down cake, covered with roasted pineapple ice cream, and rum sauce. YUM!!!

Go there, enjoy the experience!

Yikes, $14 for huevos rancheros. Cold, bland, flour (?!) tortilla, overcooked eggs, and surrounded in black beans. Half the plate was taken up in beans. Not a positive experience this time around, and certainly not worth the money. Stick to the traditional breakfast foods.

Great sports bar! It has the feel of a restaurant with about a million TVs, including a couple huge ones, and not a bad seat in the house. It doesn't have a "bar" feel with cigarette smoke and drunk frat boys - just is a place for people to eat and cheer on their favorite teams. It can get rowdy in there though! 

The menu is big and there are a lot of artery clogging foods to satisfy your palate. I haven't tried the pizza but my sister always gets it and it looks good, with a lot of options for flavored crusts that sounds yummy. I like the mozzarella sticks, the post its, and the cheese fries. All good, rich and fatty. Get ranch to make it even more fattening, therefore better. I liked the post its better with mozzarella cheese than cheddar.

Service has always been quick and efficient. Easy to split checks too. 

Check in on Yelp's mobile app and get 10% off every time. Can't beat that! 

I'm trying to eat healthier, but if I relapse, I'll be back.. heehee.

I came here for the Garden Glow event.  Totally awesome event!  Even though it was freaking cold, it was well worth the visit.  They had fire pits scattered throughout the garden.  At some of the fire pits, you can buy stuff to make smores.  There were volunteers throughout the garden for assistance and to answer any questions.  The light installations were quite beautiful!  Parking can be a problem, but if you arrive about 7ish or 8 pm then you should have no problem.  Other than that, there are more parking lots outside & nearby the garden.  The admission fee was a bit hefty ($16 per person & living in the county), but well worth every single penny!  I have been to the botanical garden several times and am amazed every single time I come here.  I love this place!  This is the perfect place to have a wedding.  If you live outside the county, expect to pay a slightly higher admission fee.

So happy we had a reservation. The list for the people waiting was pretty full as well as when walking through the door, quite craziness. We walked right in, and were able to sit fairly quickly in a good spot that was not too crowded.

It was confusing to figure out our server. It took a while for him to come. Several dim sum carts came before he did and when he did, he only gave half the table water and silverware. He was very MIA, but I guess that was somewhat understandable since it was a very busy New Years Day lunch for all.

We ordered a bunch of dim sum first which is basically the carts that they push around with small plates like Asian tapas.  Among my favorites were Chinese broccoli, tofu and pork rolls, and sesame balls. My least favorite would be chicken feet. That's just not for me but my parents loved it.

We ordered Peking Duck served with pancake(tortillas) which is basically like moo shu. The pancakes which u wrap them in took forever to come after the duck. The Peking duck was a disappointment and not what I thought it would be. 

We also ordered wonton soup, chicken corn chowder, Hong Kong style pan fried noodles, shrimp lo mein. The pan fried noodles would probably be my favorite, but I have had better elsewhere. There also was more noodles than the proteins.

With the service being a hodgepodge and big question mark, I think this restaurant is okay. The food is a modest okay also. I think the prices are not too bad considering the area. The restaurant is modern inside.

I may or may not be back for the many options on the menu, but it may be a while.

In the heart of the Little Saigon quarter of Philadelphia, Nam Phuong stands out above all the other eateries.  It is quietly becoming known all over the east coast and rightly so.

After eating at some very mediocre Vietnamese restaurants in Europe, it was a pleasure for me to get back to real Vietnamese food at Nam Phuong.  Their menu is large and each time I go there I try something different.  And the food doesn't disappoint.  On a recent cold winter's day, I passed over the tempting Pho to indulge in the Broken Rice with a  BBQ Pork Chop, Shredded Pork, Egg Quiche, and salad.  This is a classic Vietnamese broken rice dish and it is prepared here to perfection.  For starters, the jicama rolls delicately wrapped in rice paper really hit the spot - especially with the addition of the accompanying peanut sauce. 

But there are other aspects of Nam Phuong that propel it to five stars.  The service for one - it is friendly and efficient.  My water glass must have been filled more than five times.  You are always served hot Vietnamese tea as soon as you sit down.  And the condiments on the table along with the ubiquitous Vietnamese fish sauce are outstanding.  You have a choice among so many different flavors to add to your dining experience.

Yeah, it was def good to be back eating in Philadelphia's Vietnamese restaurants - and one of the very best ones at that!
I've only been here once, but it seems like a great place for lunch, not to mention the Famous Le Bus Brioche Rolls!:-)  My only complaint is that it's "Cash Only".  Who caries cash anymore???

When you surpass 1300+ reviews its easy to fall back on some much needed updates. While the live from Han Dynasty update was a very suitable update from back in the day, it doesn't hold up to the current standards given that it wasn't even done in the same building!

Since last review Han has gone on to move on to multiple locations including NYC, influence other restaurants like Dan Dan, put together a solid drink menu, partner up with the Electric Factory to an extent, do tasting events that featured members of the Wu-Tang Clan, and put together a not very Fight Club like cooking club that raises money for charity. But despite all those accolades and through thick and thin Han has still managed to be the down to earth, lovable, and unpredictable basketcase that he's always been, and never loses  focus of his restaurant(s). And if you're enough on the in with him, you may even be surprised with something exotic and random like a turtle when you organize a tasting among friends!

But while I've been to other Han Dynasty locations, and almost always come back to my Dan Dan Noodles and pork belly at each one, usually always this Old City location that I come back to! With its huge dining space, supersized bar space, and multiple side locations that are capable of transporting your group away from the other people dining within, its definitely the crown jewel of the all the HD locations. and with the new space, the old city location that started out as a BYOB now includes a well thought out beer menu that always manages to include a few surprises, a dapper cocktail and wine list, and even a couple of strong fishbowl sized cocktails that are fit to be shared. But as always the main even is always the super spicy, chili oil infused, ring sting inducing menu that's perfect for both meat eaters and vegetarians alike!

Great indoor option to bring kids. 

I love the Florida Aquarium. It is indoors so I don't have to worry about weather, other than walking to and from the car, and there is the perfect amount of marine life for my baby to stare at without getting overwhelmed. 

Yes, it may be odd that I bring a five month old to an Aquarium, but he is mesmerized by the fish! We can stand and stare at the tanks for minutes, which is really long for him. I also appreciate how they do special things for members, like members only nights. We went for a holiday members only night and since we got there right when it opened at 5:30 p.m. we were able to wander amongst the fish without him getting overwhelmed.

There is an outdoor area which is pretty neat as well. It's a splash pad which is great for the summer. I can already envision my son running all around that when he is older. They even have an outside bar for the parents! That's where I envision I will be. 

There is a cafe that serves your normal pizza/burger fare. I've never tried it so I can't comment. 

They also have a bird/wildlife area where you see animals that live in the wetlands (like gators, otters, etc.) It's kind of muggy and smelly, but that's real life for ya. 

Final star is for how close the Aquarium is to other things. It is minutes walk to Sparkman's Wharf so if you don't want to eat at Cafe Ray, you can take a short stroll and grab some awesome food. That's what we did and it made for an awesome day. 

I'm pretty sure the Aquarium has won my heart for membership for years to come. It is totally worth it.

I was in town and when I was craving upscale American, my friend suggested Cooper's Hawk. We scored reservations quickly on OpenTable and we were impressed by the space when we walked in. It was PACKED for a Tuesday night! The wine tasting room was cool, but we were there exclusively for dinner. The pretzel bread and butter was to-die-for...I could've eaten about 10 of those. I enjoyed the pork nachos for my entree - quite delicious. My friend got the veggie burger. He requested a side of Asian slaw and no mayo - his burger came with fries and slathered with mayo. Despite the kitchen snafu, our server Linda was PHENOMENAL. She was honestly one of the best servers we have ever had. Friendly, attentive, helpful. We declined to try the wine so she gave my friend a "tea tasting" instead because he was cold and dripping wet after getting caught in a torrential downpour parking the car. Overall, I'd recommend this place for solid food and great service.

IKEA is my favorite furniture store 15 years ago. This Swedish company was originally open their door in America at 1985 in Philadelphia. I first bought their furniture at Houston IKEA when we have vacation there. Soon they open the market in Florida then Tampa. 

IKEA provide nanny care while you are shopping. There also have their restaurant inside the store make shopping or lunch there easy. It is very convenient to many customers for easy strolling and look for the furniture. 

The furniture is great for small apartment. There are many space saving ideal. I would said their furniture required a person can follow the instructions of assembling and time to put it together. Their furniture is good price. Since it requires assembly, some people just don't have the time. But I like it to make it my weekend project. 

I would said their furniture are not great for house moving. Once it assembled, they just need to left it in place. Because once you move it too much, you will damage the furniture assembly Joint or connection. Their furniture do look great. And they are very contemporary and modern look.

My second visit to Cafe Lift was even better than the first. I went with my boyfriend, who lives only a few blocks from Sabrina's. I told him that like Sabrina's, the food would be awesome and creative... and that unlike Sabrina's, there would be no hour-long waits outside, no hosts picking and choosing the next diners based on god-only-knows what criteria, and no elbow pads necessary as there would be ample room between tables. We walked in and sat down immediately. 

Once my coffee was placed on the table, I searched the vicinity like a junkie for Sweet'N Low, but there were no pink packets in sight. Our server saved the day by procuring some from behind a counter. A few minutes later, she dropped off some complimentary chocolate chip bread pudding. I forgot all about that from last time so it was a nice surprise and really good. 

My fritatta special with breakfast sausage, jack cheese and spinach was great. The bf had a panini with prosciutto, sharp provolone and some other items, which he loved. 

Part of me wants to be greedy and not share Cafe Lift with others, but I also want this place to be around for a long, long time so I am obligated to spread the word. Get thyself to brunch!

The Continental Cheeseburger is glorious.  It makes other cheeseburgers very angry and jealous.  The only thing that isn't good about it is that it seems to be only available during brunch/lunch.  

The other menu items are satisfactory, standard Steven Starr fare.

Well worth the drive from the county! What can I say that hasn't been said? I love the custard. The consistency is perfect. It looked like there were a million people there this Friday night, but we got helped immediately and barely had stepped to the side before our orders came out. Lots of interesting combinations but I stuck to my tried and true - vanilla custard with Reese's. YUM.

We came in for lunch and were able to catch the World Cup Germany-Australia game in the bar while we ate.  We were so pleased to know they were showing World Cup games in the bar on 3 TV's.  It seemed the entire staff was into it with us, which was a lot of fun.

The service was just as good if not better than the last time we were here.  The food was also the bomb - good beef hot pot, good pad thai, fresh spring rolls - so that was was on par with my last visit.

So last time I degraded to 3 stars due to price.  But this time confirmed that their serving sizes are always large per my and my husband's appetites...so we've decided to just split a meal next time (assuming they will allow that) and go ahead and bump up from 3 to 4 stars since they got it going on in all other aspects that we look for.

3.5 Stars

Pluses: A really cool space, love what they've done with it, even the bathrooms look great.  Restaurant area felt like sitting in a greenhouse - light, and airy, and comfortable.  My chicken burger was unusual and delicious.  So convenient to be able to make my reservations for lunch through Yelp.

Minuses:  Service.  Our waiter was waaay over his head with all the tables assigned to him.  He absolutely could not keep up.  We managed to get our order in before he was completely swamped, but only because I was able to grab him and tell him that we had a limited time frame.  Even after our food was delivered by someone else, we never saw him again until check time, not even to ask for more ketchup.  Speaking of which, who's bright idea was it that patrons get one measly ounce of ketchup for their fries?  Sheesh!  Finally, I think it is too expensive.  $13 for a  chicken burger and fries, or paying almost $20 for a salad if you want to add chicken or shrimp to it is not reasonable.  

I'll be back for coffee or tea, but only to eat if I can convince someone else to buy. ;-)

My grandfather is a badass Cuban man. He is like 200 years old. He has survived more heart attacks than I've had serious relationships. He came to the USA after the Castro regime took everything from his family. He vacations by working on his ranch in South Carolina. He speaks with a thick accent, a charismatic voice carved from years of toil and adventure.

He is the real life version of that dos equis stooge, "the most interesting man in the world."

It was in Florida that he taught me of Cuban food, the food of my people(Cuban Jews). Throughout my childhood, dinner with grandpa was usually dinner at a Cuban place. He would not take his family to any sucker joint that did not satisfy his discerning palate. It is with this background that I gain the authority to say Alma de Cuba honors legitimate Cuban cuisine and mixes it up with Steven Starr panache...and it is pretty darn delicious.

I like this place. It has become kind of a go-to spot for me when it comes to entertaining business-y guests. The ambiance is elegant and unique without being stuffy. The service has never been poor.

The ceviche here is my favorite in Philadelphia. The Peruvian bass, Rainbow, and shrimp ceviches are all great. You can't go wrong here. Do you want to try a good ceviche? Then just close your eyes and point in the general direction of that part of the menu. Eat that one.

The empanadas and tuna tartare tacos are excellent appetizers.

If you are trying to decide between the honey mustard glazed salmon and the shrimp stew, go with the stew.

The chocolate cigar is a very good dessert. It is a decadent almond cake wrapped in chocolate mousse that works in perfect harmony with dulce de leche ice cream. That being said, keep your expectations humble if you order this. The 5 stars of this review was earned by the ceviche and not the sweet selections.

Furthermore, Alma de Cuba's happy hour offers some really excellent apps and drinks. I like it a lot.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this movie is the OPPOSITE of Batman Forever.

This is a fancy mall in the Bay Area. The mall is all enclose in the AC except the restaurant section. It has good selection of national recognized restaurant chains. Some of the restaurants are Cheese Cake Factory, Capitol Grille, Brio Tuscan Grill, California Pizza Kitchen.

The stores inside the mall include Apple Store I have frequent visit and learn new stuff. My wife likes the H&M. However, H&M report they have lost revenue in U.S. nationwide. She like this store due to the design is from Europe. I have time myself nonstop walking from one end to other end in 10 minutes walk. That is count from Nordstrom to Apple Store. 

I don't like the parking lot arrangement for this mall. Most malls have inner loop and outer loop. This mall cut off each section and only allows going to each section by outer loop. This is very inconvenient.

I have been to Brazilian Steakhouses before, but Texas de Brazil manages to stand apart from it's competitors. The restaurant is gorgeous; very modern with a touch of Latin flair. The dining room has cathedral ceilings and chandeliers.  There is also a very cool wine room and the outdoor patio has huge, comfty wicker chairs.  

The salad bar at Texas de Brazil was excellent and offered numerous choices from soup, salad, olives, antipasta selections and sushi.  If meat on a stick is not your thing there is an option to only eat from the salad bar.  The service was prompt and we were never without a friendly server offering us a different delectable selection of filet mignon, prime rib or bacon wrapped chicken.  The servers take the red and green cards seriously... so when you flip over the card to green be prepared to be overwhelmed with an awesome abundance of meat on a sword.

The food that was most memorable to me was the filet mignon, the lobster bisque, and the cheese stuffed rolls (minature balls of heavenly gooey cheese baked into a small roll).  

For all-you-can-eat meat I recommend trying Texas de Brazil!

I just don't get the hype. I have had pretty much every salad on the menu, and a few of the sandwiches, and all have been relatively disappointing. The cous cous salad was absurdly oily. The only things I think are worth raving about here are the desserts. Their cakes are absolutely delicious. Pretty good cookies, too. But I would never seek them out for salads/sandwiches and I can't figure out why others do, but to each his own I suppose. Just not my thang.

I have a love hate relationship with Wright's.  man, every time I walk in there I blow my diet.  I LOVE their coconut cake. I LOVE their 7 layer bars.

I also love their turkey/pecan salad and usually order a scoop of it on a bed of lettuce (so I can justify ordering a dessert!)

Call ahead or you'll be waiting in line for a long time.

Don't know why I opted for a girls night here but we did. We've never had good service any time we've visited. This visit was the first time in a very long time that we visited here. But decided to give it another chance since my daughter and I were going to have dessert for dinner. I tried calling ahead knowing they'd be busy and the fact that we didn't have that much time between eating and picking up my husband from the airport. They wouldn't take a reservation since my party was only 2 people! And wouldn't take my name for a call ahead despite us only wanting dessert. We'd have to arrive and wait in line. But of course we were told on the phone that they wouldn't be busy around the 8:30 time I was requesting a reservation for. When we arrived, of course the place was packed....it always is.....put in our names for the 20 minute wait. Really no seating available for the people that are waiting.....everyone just stands around or outside. We opted to sit outside on the bench only to be engulfed by smoke from people smoking in the outside eating area. They should really have all areas as non smoking since it's a restaurant area. We were finally buzzed to get our seats....but wait! We handed in our buzzer and had to stand in a separate line for a wait staff to co,e take us to our table. There were 5 parties ahead of us, so another 5 minutes probably. OMG. We were finally seated at the smallest most compact table in the bar area. I totally forgot how cramped the seating is here if you aren't lucky enough to get a booth or private table. The atmosphere is extremely loud ... hard to have a conversation with your table guests.
