And since you sit so close you can pretty much hear your neighbor tables conversation. 

Waiter arrived and we knew what we wanted so placed our drink and order for the Godiva Brownie Sundae. Took forever to get our drinks and even longer to get our dessert. Our waiter wasn't even the one that brought us our sundae......and the ice cream was totally melted. Like it had been just sitting out for a while until it was brought to our table. For an almost $10 dessert I'd expect better. But no sense in trying to flag down our waiter because it'd just melt more since he was nowhere to be found. Didn't even come to check on us. He did make a drive by to quickly place the check on the table though. 

I won't be back here. I'd rather spend my money at a place that gives a crap about their customers despite only ordering dessert. And gives quality with them food and service.

Restaurant week!
Ecuadorian shrimp ceviche was very good.  There was a lot of tomato in there and it worked well for the flavors with the shrimp.  I appreciated that there was only a mild taste of citrus to this, I think a lot of places can over do it with the citrus in ceviche.

Empanadas cubanas were  tasty.  At a lot of places, empanadas just taste like meat, there is too little seasoning.  Not here.  These were small, but tasty beef empandas.  

Shortrib ropa vieja  was my favorite of the entrees that I tasted. The meat was very flavorful, and it was pulled to a nice texture.  Though, I wish that they served this with more than just the white rice.  

Arroz con pollo was a leg of juicy chicken with nice crisp skin served with flavorful yellow rice with peas and olives.  I enjoyed this dish, but definitely thought that the rice stole the show from the chicken leg.  

Cinnamon spiced tapioca pudding with vanilla streusel and rum soaked currants.    I love tapioca, and I enjoyed this.  The streusel and currants were different than what I am used to.  It reminded me of how you might put granola and raisins into your yogurt in the morning.  

Overall, I enjoyed my meal at Alma De Cuba.  Though it does make me wish that Casona and Rosa Blanca were still open.  Alam De Cuba is semi-upscale, I suppose I am looking for Cuban food that is a little more "homey."

I love how old New Orleans is. In a country that's a baby (relative to so many other first-world countries), being in a place that makes you feel its history is a treat. And, in New Orleans... in the French Quarter... that's all around. And since this is an old bar in the French Quarter, space is at a premium. As long as you don't come here in search of spreading your wings and flying away, all should be well.

Plus, it's not like you should need to come here and run all over the damn place. It's an established FQ bar. Sit down. Order some booze. People watch. Repeat. I came here late at night and after some significant drinking. I'm never one to turn down a night cap, but at the hour there was no need to turn up. That's when I discovered it: the frozen Irish Coffee. I shouldn't have been surprised. New Orleans does frozen drinks like none other. Despite having once lived here, this was my first taste of what is a new standard. Creamy, boozy and lusciously-perfect for the last drink of the evening, my coffee warmed me up (despite it being frozen) and tuckered me out (despite it being coffee). Half way through my drink, I noticed that the bar had filled up with sexy patrons. And, for once, I wasn't talking about the one(s) I saw in the mirror across from the wooden bar. 

Given it's proximity to Bourbon Street, I don't know that I could do a prime time visit to Erin Rose. But, as a late night last stop on a Wednesday... yep. It'll do just fine. Just don't sit in my seat.

I hosted a party for a group of 20 at Iron Hill and things went WAY better than ever expected or imagined.

We enjoyed delicious nachos, wings, guacamole, crab quesadilla, cheesesteak egg rolls and a few folks ordered dinners.  There were Salmon, Scallops  - and my 9 year-old demolished a big plate of fettuccine carbonara (Ah to be 9 again and to be able to eat like that). Desserts like cheesecake and the Chocolate Brownie Sundae (it has a special name) were show stoppers. (And many pints of Raspberry Wheat were consumed as well).

We are so pleased and grateful to our server, Megan and all the expediters, servers, bussers and hosts/greeters for a wonderful and fun evening.

I would not hesitate to recommend Iron Hill to friends and colleagues when planning their holiday parties or other group events.

What a great experience.

Brava!

I actually find the Philly airport to be one of the better organized ones I've visited. Really, all I hope for in an airport is fast moving lines, clear signage, and restaurants and shopping that reflect the local area. I think PHL has that all going on. 
Security lines can be a bit long at times which sucks, and the TSA workers seem to enjoy screaming and belittling patrons. That being said the lines move quickly enough so I don't care. 
WiFi usually works well and there are ample amounts of chargers and seats so that bodes well for long layovers. 
I've never really shopped here since I don't need souvenirs from the city I live in, but it looks to be pretty standard fare. 
There's not an over abundance of dining options, but there are Chickie's and Pete's! Which is good enough for me.

One of the best values for lunch anywhere around!

We stopped in for lunch on a Friday for the fish Blue Plate Special.  That included our choice between a sweet or unsweetened iced tea.  The sweet tea was mango today.  Then on to a phenomenal salad with fresh greens, sliced radishes, sliced cucumbers, half a hard-boiled egg, and sliced onion in a light vinaigrette-like dressing with some sort of homemade cracker to start.  Then finally 2 pieces of lightly breaded Fried Grouper, 2 cornbread hushpuppies (which was a little dry but was remedied with one of the sauces), beans with rice, and tartar and cocktail sauce.  For the drink, salad, and entree, it was only $10!  And while we didn't get dessert, there were 3 options, which sounded unique and quite good.

I don't think the regular menu is available for lunch, but I can say our group is looking forward to trying one of the other Blue Plate lunch specials. They have Fried Chicken, Mac & Cheese, & Smashed Taters on Mondays and Bacon Wrapped Meatloaf with Glazed Carrots & Smashed Taters on Wednesdays to name a few.

I have a feeling I could up this rating from 4 to 5 stars on my next visit.

We parked on one of the side streets, but it looked like you could enter the restaurant from the back, so maybe there is some parking back there, too.  This isn't a large location, so I would arrive early, especially if your group is 5 or more.

I am a Jew and John's Roast Pork makes me so happy that I do not keep kosher.  

Seriously guys, swine is awesome, especially if it comes in the form of a roast pork sandwich from this place.  I understand that we developed these culinary rules because our nomadic nature as an infant culture made sedentary animals(like pigs) poor choices for our lifestyle(which is why we preferred sheep and such)...but I have abandoned the ancient ways and I feast upon the flesh of the unclean...or something.  

If God did not want us to eat pork from this restaurant, why did he make it so great?  The meat is wonderfully seasoned and tender.  All you need is roast pork and sharp provolone and you are good to go for lunch.

The cheesesteak is pretty good too.

Protip: Call ahead to place your order.  They might have up to an hour wait before you get your sandwich.

(please don't take this review too seriously)

I've eaten here too many times. Today was underwhelming but it's usually better. It looks and feels like Paris. Sit outside with your pup. Check out the fabulous Rittenhouse Square crowd. Eat great bread and pretty good French food. Escargot is a must. Lots of celebrities, local and afar. See and be seen!

My overall review of this place would be a 3.5, so I decided to round up.  I stopped in on a Friday night after a majority of the dinner rush had subsided.  I was seated quickly, but the side booth areas felt like I was literally eating with some random people at the table next to me.  Our waitress was less than attentive and took a couple of trips back and forth to the table to get our drink orders and deliver our drinks.  Once we ordered the food came out fairly quickly.  I ended up trying the Chicken Vermicelli bowl and it was a generous portion and satisfied my craving for something semi-healthy during this meal.  I'll be back to try the pho, but I hope the service gets a bit better based on my experience.

We came for dinner with two out-of-town friends and we were pleased with our meal. We were seated promptly upstairs and I was reminded of why I love the decor and vibe of Alma de Cuba so much. We started with scallop ceviche and a salad (I can't remember which one) and both were absolutely fantastic. I wasn't super hungry so I decided to go with the vegetarian entree and I was really disappointed. It just wasn't good. At all. My fiance's steak was absolutely delicious and I was quite jealous - I wished I had ordered something else. Our mojitos were OK....my fiance and I started out with the suave, which had nasty, nasty mint. We actually pointed out to the server that the mint just didn't taste fresh so she could tell the bartender (I was actually gagging because it tasted so chemical-y). While our next round tasted, better, I thought it would have been appropriate for her to offer to take those 2 drinks off the tab, but she didn't offer anything. Overall it was a good meal, but I think there are places with better food in the city. But if you're looking for upscale food and a beautiful, fun ambiance, this is a good bet.

So this visit was absolutely perfect for me!

I can for a late lunch, having been out the night before and was absolutely starving since I skipped breakfast. 

Sat at the bar with Melinda, who immediately recognize me and we started chatting. Ordered a glass of prosecco and debated on lunch.

Finally decided on the wood grilled grouper with the habanero tarter sauce and a side arugula salad, also decided to add a lobster tail, like I said, I was starved.

So darn! KItchen messed up, I got the fish, with both the tarter sauce and the mango lime glaze on the side , AND a lobster lunch with broccolini and rice pilaf. Yes, I looked like a hog, but who cared. It was so good! 

THe fish was uber fresh, perfectly cooked, just delicious. THe lobster, perfectly grilled, Both presentations were delicious, especially with the Prosecco. It was a lunch to die for.

Saw my fav server Michael on the way out, who was unfortuntaley working a private party that night, but took the time to come and say hello and chat. 

When I got back to my suite later that night the Pie Fairy had come and left a slice of Key Lime Pie in a bag on my door! Thank you Pie Fairy!!

Another place I'll come back to over and over!!!

Pappy's Smokehouse ranked #20 on Ian Froeb's 2016 STL 100 List. I wouldn't have put them in the top 25, but they have set the standard for many of the BBQ restaurants in the St. Louis area. So, perhaps that alone is reason enough to rank them towards the top. 

My go to order that I usually pick up on my way home from work is a 1/2 slab of ribs. It comes with two sides for $16.50. As a bonus, you can order 1/4 pound of an additional meat for $4. I like this deal, because I can get two meals out of it. I enjoy the ribs and only half of each side and take the additional meat and the remaining sides to work the next day for lunch. For me, this is a winning combination. 

I love the dry rub on the ribs, so for me there is no need for sauce. The only time I use sauce at Pappy's is for the brisket and pulled pork. My two favorite sauces are the original and Holly's Hot Sauce. I really like the extra kick that Holly gives. I enjoy it especially on the Burnt Ends when I can get them. So many times, by the time I get there after work they are sold out. That tells you just how good those damn burnt ends are. 

I always order the same sides. When Pappy first opened, I wasn't a fan of his Baked Beans, but they have won me over and now I order them every time. No matter what meat I am enjoying, the beans are the perfect accompaniment. My second side, I mix it up between Fried Sweet Corn on the Cob and Green Beans. Both are made fresh and taste like they came out of a country kitchen. 

Lines are long, service is friendly, polite and fast. You can not go wrong eating at Pappy's. 

When: Multiple after work visits
Why: Dinner & next days lunch.

This location is a lot better than the old Delmar location.  Perfect location!  Great space & great ambience.  There is a separate small bar on the other side.  I came here tonight for dinner.  The food was delish!  They have this dish, where you cook either beef or shrimp on a metal charcoal grill & make it into spring rolls.  They bring out the rice wrappers, hot water & veggies, & you do all the work.  This was fun & interesting.  I ordered the Vietnamese style grilled chicken with the Mai Lee soy sauce.  Again, very delish!  The only thing that they didn't have was those fruit smoothies.  They also didn't have any desserts.  I wish they did given that it was Chinese New Year today.  Service was a bit slow, but I loved the food.  That's all that matters to me.  :P

All my years living in STL and I finally visited the Post! This is a great place to go and watch a game. I was there a few weeks ago to watch a basketball game and the place was crazy busy! They had lots of specials going on and our server was very attentive. 

Our group was able to walk in and find a table pretty quickly. We were right next to the windows and since it was a nice night out they were propped open which was nice. We had lots of TV's for us to watch and lots of people around us to chat with about the game. We decided to order some food while we were there. I ordered the wings and some waffle fries; my standard game night bar food. The rest of the table ordered either burgers or sandwiches. We opted for a few pitchers of beer and some water as well. 

Our food came out piping hot and looked delicious. My wings were tasty and crisp just like I like them. The waffle fries were good too. I know we all enjoyed our meals since we all finished everything. It was a good meal and the server made sure we had what we needed. When it was time to get the checks she offered to split them and made it easy for us. 

I enjoyed the post and I will go back for another game night. It's a good sports bar and I'm a fan!

You know you are a true Yelper when a restaurant owner sends you a private message telling you about a new item on their menu that they know you will enjoy. Jonathan one of the owners of SWD, sent me a message telling me that they are now making their Biscuits and Gravy with their house made sausage instead Chorizo. This old farm boy who loves B&G's got there as fast as he could. 

I have always been a fan of the sausage patties at SWD. There is just something about a hand pressed, oddly shaped patty, bursting with flavor to make a breakfast complete. Switching their gravy to their own sausage over the Chorizo, is a vast improvement. For a farm boy, pork sausage is the way to go when making gravy to top biscuits. 

This morning we also enjoyed their daily special, "Grits on Fire". I will admit, I am not a fan of grits, but love their Adovado pork, so I gave it a try. It basically was a grit cake topped with the Adovado pork, corn, queso fresco and topped with two fried eggs. It was on fire and so was I the rest of the day, but I didn't mind because it was that good.

However, as I stated earlier I am not a fan of grits and if they offer Grits on Fire again, I think I'll have them hold the grits and put mine on their famous perfectly crispy home fries. As, George O. said, Grits on Fire deserves a place on their permanent menu.

Why 5 stars? Because it's a great place to break up the monotony of your typical grocery stopping.

   ---   ---   ---

I'm very much a creature of habit when it comes to my grocery shopping - I go to the same Publix on the same days of the week and buy all the same stuff. But I've recently finally reached a breaking point where I've had an itch to shake it up and try new things. And new things can absolutely be found here... it's almost a completely different type of business than Publix!

Part of me gets a little annoyed at how there isn't a ton of structure with how the aisles are put together, but part of me kind of likes the mystery involved as you turn every corner. On the top of an aisle with a bunch of frozen meals, they will randomly have various chocolates and candies. It doesn't make a lot of sense, but it certainly forces you to pay attention to every single item so that you don't miss anything.

If you're feeling like you're in a grocery rut, definitely make your way to Trader Joe's, where you can find an unlimited number of meal options, snacks and desserts. I don't live super close by, so my trips will be a bit more rare, but that will make each visit that much more special. On our most recent visit, we racked up about $40 in mostly snacks, but we definitely got our money's worth with a ton of different items! 

I have definitely been to Trader Joe's multiple times before this latest adventure and cannot believe that I never reviewed them until now - it's definitely a great spot!

I was blown away by my meal yesterday.  I brought a friend that has never been here before.  We started off with their wings.  I proclaim them as the best in town, and we were not let down.  They're dry rubbed & smoked with a side of dipping sauce.  For our main course, we selected the meatloaf and duck confit.  The meatloaf had a smokey flavor too.  The duck was fall off the bone and succulent.  The brussels sprouts and mac & cheese were ok.  

Our server's name was Chris also.  He was cool and friendly... and didn't rush us even though we were the last table in the joint.  

This place does simple comfort food extremely well.  And it's a cool spot.  The only downside is it's hard to get a table... they're dining room only has around a dozen or so.

There are few places I visit that just get better and better each time, and HWK is one of them. There are ALSO few places I visit where I feel relaxed and satisfied eating alone, so I'm twice as thankful for this unique Maplewood gem with some talented owners & chefs to boot.

On my most recent trip (a late Saturday afternoon) I enjoyed a never-ending cup of perfectly brewed black coffee and decided to order the soup of the day which was an onion & apple soup. It was the perfect balance of sweet and salty and made the absence of butternut squash on the menu hurt much less! The star of the show, though, was definitely the roasted beet salad. With ricotta, arugula, pumpkin seeds and cider vinaigrette, this thing took fresh and flavorful to a whole new level. It's rare you eat something out that feels light, healthy, and exploding with flavor all at once! There were out of the cheeseburger (one patron was pretty upset about that) and also the apple risotto (I reeeeally wanted that because of the goat cheese) but my menu items ended up compensating completely for their absence!

Seriously... go for lunch alone and sit by the front windows, and tell me you don't leave more relaxed and inspired than when you came in. Better yet, keep the Maplewood awesome-ness going and stop by Tiger Lily, Penzey's, and all the other small shops along Manchester after you're done. 

To Josh Renbarger & Cassie Vires: thank you, thank you, and thank you for bringing Home Wine Kitchen to Maplewood.

I have been going to La Teresita for over 20 years, and have taken all my family, lots of friends & colleagues, and watched them become fans too.  The other reviewers validly note the quality, quantity and low-cost of the varied Cuban/Spanish classic dishes, and the family business has continued to grow from some to-go dishes at the food market, to start the diner on the corner, then build a new 2-story building with sit-down restaurant (CapdeVila), lunch counter, to-go counter, bar, meeting room, upstairs banquet hall, bakery (in the original diner) and now a dance hall/lounge, and beauty shop.   That expansive success is the best indication of how good the food is.
I now live in the W. Columbus Drive area and have systematically eaten at every restaurant in a mile radius.....along Columbus, Dale Mabry, Armenia, Howard, etc......and the one restaurant that keeps drawing me back for repeats at least monthly is La Teresita.

This is honestly my favorite airport.  It may be smaller than some of the truely international ones but traveling is painless here.  The staff are so friendly and the security lines move so quickly.  They have a bunch of dining options and plenty of seating.  They have Suntrust ATMs. They could use more outlets for recharging electronics but they have a lot more outlets then most other airports that I've seen... For its size, it's really wonderful. The highlight is the people- southern hospitality at work here. But of course, if it were to expand- there are a few things they could improve on (more bathrooms, free wifi, more variety in restaurants, more outlets, a monorail, speed walkways, pet relief areas, more shops and things like that) but as is, for its size, it's really great!

We returned for a second visit to Talula's...after the first, we declared it our favorite meal in Philadelphia and promised to return for the next celebration. So we did..our engagement! The service was phenomenal, but the food was not as good as our first visit. Our first course of homemade kale pasta with veal had great flavor, but was heavy on the salt and a very small portion. My duck entree came out lukewarm and while they very graciously took it back to the kitchen, they obviously just reheated the food that was on my first plate and replated it. Even when warm, the duck left something to be desired. Some of the vegetables on my plate were so salty they were inedible. The lamb entree was fantastic - excellent flavor and perfectly cooked. But the table next to us got a much larger portion when they ordered the same dish, which was disappointing. As I said, the service was excellent. They offered us complimentary sorbet and prosecco when I mentioned we were celebrating our engagement, and everyone from the hostess to the manager was so nice.

Impressive array of sugary sweets!

I actually came here for ice cream. We had just eaten a giant lunch at Yummy House South but they were out of egg tarts. They said it would take about 20 minutes to make more (and I bet we sat there for about 19 minutes talking before we decided to leave). Anyways, the point is I didn't get anything sweet to end my meal. 

Now, normally this isn't an issue, but since I'm pregnant I've taken on the viewpoint that I should never be deprived of anything.  I told my husband that I wanted ice cream and who would argue with a pregnant person.  I pulled up Yelp because I don't like going to chain places when I can help it. I saw that Dough was nearby and had ice cream so I pulled it up on maps and we took off.

Spoiler alert, I didn't end up getting ice cream. They only have a couple flavors, which really isn't that big an issue, but none of them appealed to me. I like ice cream that contains different ingredients like nuts, fudge, chocolate chips, etc. Ice cream that is all one consistency doesn't really do it for me. I'm sure having limited options ensures all their choices are spectacular, but I decided to forgo the ice cream.

Luckily, they have a huge selection of doughnuts as well! I think this is actually what Dough is known for. I have a confession to make, I am a huge apple fritter fanatic. There was a time when I was in high school where I wrote into the Houston Chronicle (newspapers were a thing back then) asking for recommendations about where I should go to get an apple fritter. I then dragged three friends to make a forty-minute road trip to get apple fritters at 7 a.m. (I heard they run out fast). When I saw that Dough had apple fritters I was both intrigued and frightened. I already have such a huge bar set for apple fritters was it worth trying it from here and rating the place based on a pastry that is held so dear to my heart?

Yes, I got the apple fritter. I usually like my apple fritters more crispy than doughy, but this one really impressed me. It was doughy but it wasn't dry at all. I'm not about to wax poetics about this apple fritter because it would get weird fast, but just know that Dough does dough well. 

I would definitely suggest coming here and trying something made of dough. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

International Plaza is one of the most glamorous malls I have shopped at!

All of my favorite boutiques and department stores are under one roof (Banana Republic, J Crew, Ann Taylor, and Sephora). The department stores include Nordstroms, Dillards, and Needless Markup... sorry, Neiman Marcus! This mall offers everything from designer clothing, jewelry, electronics, gourmet food, beauty products, and hair salons. This is not the mall to dress down at. The mall is like a huge fashion runway! If you are wondering "what to wear" this season just walk around this mall for a few hours and see all of the latest trends.

The food court inside International Plaza is your typical mall grub, but outside you'll find Blue Martini, Capital Grill, The Cheesecake Factory, and other restaurants. The nightlife isn't too bad either so check out Bay Street at night for some serious people watching and cocktails.

As with most Starr restaurants, I don't know what the hype is about.

Yes, the inside was beautiful - very romantic and sexy.
Yes, the outside was cute - minus the billion flies and bees buzzing around my face.
Yes, the service was impeccable. My water glass was filled about 14 times (perhaps you should consider larger glasses).

However, the food was excessively expensive and the portions were unfairly small. I could come to terms with that fact if it weren't for the fact that the food was just NOT THAT AMAZING!

We started with the pea ravioli and the crab salad. Both were good. Nothing special.

We got Lancaster chicken and salmon as our entrees. Again, not that special. And why was my fish served in a bowl? Weird. On the upside, the salmon skin was cooked to a crispy perfection that just can't be done at home without a torch.

For dessert we got the donuts (which I saw someone raving about on here) and the blueberry cobbler. Truth be told, the sweet corn ice cream that came with the cobbler was the highlight of the night. The donuts were just OK.

I'm appreciative to the person who got us a Starr gift card, but really wasn't impressed with Talula's Garden. Could someone explain the lure to me, please? I certainly didn't see it in the food.

Lastly, the outdoor seating is cramped. I could hear the people next to us very clearly and was reluctant to talk to my husband over our anniversary dinner as I felt the people next to us could hear everything as well.

Bottom line: there are so many better (cheaper) restaurants in the city and there is no one thing drawing me back to this place.

This is one of the best establishments of Tampa.  I know it's part of a chain, but that is not the feeling you will get as you walk in.  It's very eclectic and trendy in decor and atmosphere.  What's more is that any entree is under 475 calories.  Crazy as nothing I've ever had tasted like it was that "healthy."  Anything I've ordered on my visits has been nothing but great in my opinion.  Another unique feature of this place is that their menu is seasonal so it changes every so often.  

The mini desserts also allow you to indulge without totally wrecking your health conscious choices here.  This is definitely not your typical health focused restaurant and if the people you're with aren't into that, don't tell them and they'll never know!

I am a moth to their purple neon.  Seeing it in the distance on Kingshighway just makes me all warm inside.  I came here with a friend last night.  It's one of our favorites.  Since it was nice outside, the inside wasn't near as packed as usual for a Friday night.  We found two spots at the bar.  I could tell that the bartender was contemplating not serving us.  My friend was a little tipsy.  Seeing this, I pulled myself together, and in the most sophisticated fashion, I ordered my usual (and I think everyone elses too), the dark and stormy.  Two simple ingredients... Gosling's Black Seal Rum, and Ginger Beer.  After a night at Taste & Silver Ballroom, my body felt like this drink looks... a haze of blurried fuzziness.

Gulp, gulp, done.  Ok... after NUMEROUS times here, I've never had food here.  I needed food.  After all, I am responsible for getting us home.  Quesadilla and sweet potato chips please.  The bartender was thankful that I ordered food for my friend and I.  

The food was probably just average... but anything tastes much better after a night of cocktails...a la Whities.  I thought the quesadilla was perfect... hot and gooshy... and somehow I kept it all of my shirt.  Slow down, this is getting X-rated.

I -finally- got to enjoy Ulele on my own (well, with the Husbeastie, that is)! I was pleased to be able to visit on a sunny afternoon, so that I could sit outside and enjoy the sun and breeze, and watch the river. 

The service was delightful, our glasses never went empty, and the husband was excited to get to try some of the hand crafted beer that they make on sight.. he opted for the honeymoon beer, flavoured with local strawberries. He said he didn't taste the fruityness of it, but that it was tasty none the less. 

We started our meal with the chicken lollipops and they were just as flavourful as I remember them being. A hint of spice in the sauce that made them sing on the tongue. The slaw that they nested on was made of apples, cabbage and other thinly sliced vegetables, which added to the crunch and made it heavenly!

Our mains were very diversive: I chose the steak and since it was lunch it was only $15 for an 8 oz portion, atop a large mound cheddar mashed potatoes and the vegetable of the day (grilled asparagus) and a garnish of popcorn (I admit, I was confused) The meat was absolutely delicious, tender and grilled to perfection. The seasoning was so good! The potatoes were decadent, buttery and cheesy and NOM! I was slightly disappointed in the serving of the asparagus as I was given three thin spears, and Asparagus is one of my favorite veggies. (sad)

The husband ordered a Chicken corn salad with a lime jalapeno dressing. The corn was straight off the cob, and apparently had been grilled right on it as well. The chicken was juicy and tender, and the dressing was the right amount of tart, but there was very little jalapeno kiss.  He devoured it any way.. loved it.

While we were dining, we noticed the couple next to us getting dessert, a mounded serving of something, we asked the waiter what it was: Candied Duck Maple bacon fried ice cream. That got us wondering.. and so we decided to try it. Our serving was truly epic, it was HUGE, and surrounded by a moat of cream Anglaise. It was DELICIOUS. I admit the flavor of the duck bacon in the ice cream was a bit of a surprise, but it was a welcome one. We did not lick the bowl clean, like the people next to us, but we came close. Oh boy did we come close. 

Oh and as for the pop corn garnish: Apparently the local indian tribe are the ones that figured out that if you add heat to dried corn kernels, you get pop corn. That explains -everything-!

Date night at The Chef's Table was so incredible! There are only a few seats there, so definitely make reservations. (You can't make them online, so just give them a call to request!) 

Tapas are by far my favorite way to dine, and perfect for a romantic meal. Add a front row seat to all of the culinary action, a candlelit space, and you have yourself a pretty special dining experience, one surely to impress!! 

We started with some creative cocktails, but of course. 'Talk To Her', made with butter washed run, and black tea with orange and peychaud bitters was a standout for me. 'Broken Hugs' is delicious too. It's lighter and refreshing. Hubs is a fan of the spicy 'Matador'. The aged manchego with granny apple slices and lavender honey, the mixed olives and the thinly sliced Serrano and jamon were perfect lighter first bites we ordered while sipping. That honey is so delicious and sweet. It balanced the tart apple and savory cheese so well. 

We were given complimentary tuna spread with tasty flat crackers that also started out meal off on the right foot!

*You can't go wrong with one of their three sangrias or imported cava or brut though. 

Must haves are obviously patatas bravas and the gambas al Ajillas (garlic shrimp). Don't be surprised if you find yourself order a second helping of either! Fan favorites for sure! 

Plant based dishes that should NOT be overlooked are the Berenjenas con miel, perfectly fried eggplant fries with rosemary aioli and spiced garlic honey! Holy moly, these are so good!! The Setas, seasonal mixed mushrooms with truffle oil are seemingly simply, but are to die for!! They are absolutely drool-worthy!! 
The Coco de Alfachofas flatbread with artichokes, black truffle and manchego is pretty great too! The truffle was very present! 

The crispy open half shelled lagosta (Maine lobster) and tender vierias (diver scallops) are both excellent mains. Super fresh, well cooked and very tasty! I love and appreciate that can order these half, which gives you the option to taste this, and still have room for other dishes as well. 

For dessert we had a trio sample of their desserts...tres leche, decadent chocolate cream filled cream cakes and a traditional hazelnut cookie. Everything was super delicious but the chocolate, oh, yesssss!! Dreamy! It just oozed our! 

Our service at the counter was stellar!! Between that and basically sitting in the kitchen, seeing it all go down, we felt like royalty. Such a wonderful night!! It cost nothing extra to sit at the chef's seat, just a phone call, and I couldn't recommend it more! Trust me guys, book this as a surprise for her now! 
(We lost count of how many apples one of the chefs cut ever so delicately:)

We cannot thank Chef Jose Garces and his staff enough for this delicious meal and trip back to Spain!!

Why 3 stars? Because it's as generic as they come.

   ---   ---   ---

Philadelphia Airport reminds me of most malls in the country - if you were placed in any mall, it would be tough to really tell it a part from just about any other mall. They are all pretty much the same thing.

Airports, however, are not all pretty much the same thing. Some have lots of character and they can be pretty unique. But Philadelphia seemed to be the average of every airport that I've ever been in. Nothing really stood out. It wasn't really out-dated, but it wasn't super modernized. The Philadelphia Marketplace was kind of neat from afar, but it ended up consisting of a bunch of chains. 

The problem with reviewing airports is that, unless it's your home airport or one you fly into often, you are likely to see only a small percentage of it. I fully admit that's the case here, as I simply flew in and out in the span of a couple of days. But from my limited experience, I didn't see a ton of local restaurants inside, which is something I seek out when visiting a new city/airport for the first time.

Some of my 3-star reviews lean a bit negative, but I hope that's not the case here. I didn't have a bad experience at PHL, just a very average one.

I've got a couple of friends who absolutely adore Piada Italian Street Food, a relatively small chain that has only been around since 2010 that endeavors to weave together healthier culinary options with quicker delivery. 

I must admit that I knew very little about Piada prior to finally visiting this River Crossing location this weekend. I read a couple of reviews, but I still hadn't really checked out their menu and wasn't quite sure what to expect. 

Having never been to Chipotle, I didn't quite get the "Italian Chipotle" references. Essentially, Piada keeps their menu pretty basic including seasonal specials, a variety of piadas (sort of an Italian flatbread, though my impression was more of an Italian burrito). They also offer salads, pastas, a few side options and Italian sodas/teas in addition to the usual soft drink options.

The restaurant here has three accessible parking spots including at least two that are clearly ADA compliant. The sidewalk is level to the ground meaning no curb cut was needed. The front door is a tad heavy - given the layout of the design, you're unlikely to be seen by an employee if help is needed. As you enter, you go right into a line. The line moves at a casual pace - not quickly but also not slowly. However, if you're expecting a super quick take-out you'll be a touch disappointed. Menus are conveniently located in a couple of places along the lines. This helps newcomers, though I did still have a bit of confusion by the time I arrived at the line. You order, in my case a "Tuscan Piada" with an additional upcharge for a handful of ingredients. I also ordered a side of garlic dough because, well, garlic. I love garlic. 

It's definitely possible to eat for under $10 here, though that's without any extras. I think the $10-15 range is more accurate. 

The food is served fairly quickly. I opted to try their Italian iced teas (lemon and peach on this day). The tables and overall interior serve up a sort of Italian villa design with some outdoor dining available. 

The garlic dough was terrific, though not what I expected. The piada is a good-sized serving with obviously quality ingredients. It had more of a kick than I expected, while the chicken tenderloin added was mostly unnecessary. I enjoyed it, but it wasn't something that had me thinking "How have I missed this place all this time?"

The service was fine, though not much above average. Even when I said that this was my first visit, there was no offer of explanation or any other sense of hospitality. The ice dispenser was empty by the time I returned for a refill and there seemed to be no rush to refill it. 

Piada was a fine option in my endeavor to eat healthier. The customers, in particular, were quite friendly and the business at this location obviously attracts a more upscale clientele. So, yeah, I was kind of out of place. 

As I left, I noted that the exit door had a definite stick to it. I had to really push to open it and someone with upper body weakness would likely struggle a bit. 

While I wouldn't argue with a friend wanting to meet here for lunch, Piada is not an establishment that will find a place on my regular rotation.

Went back this Sat, course little later then usual, tried the nutella CREPE, with bananas & Fresh cream..OMG!! Light -unusually , & of course the coffee & service was great!! always a plus. Can't wait to go back try something else .Love it!!!

The drinks are good (although I once asked for a bellini at the indoor bar and received champagne mixed with peach schnapps-- I don't think so!), the food is consistent and tasty, but the rooftop deck has several issues that this cupcake does not love. 

First, the glassware. Or shall I say, plasticware. When I order a ten dollar martini, I do not want to drink it out of room temperature plastic in a martini glass shape. I'm sure the reason behind this decision is so knucklehead drunks don't go throwing things over the ledge... but at the very least, they could serve real glasses to the patrons seated at the bar or at tables having dinner, or save the plastic for after 10 p.m. 

Second, although there were no pools in sight, the entire deck area curiously smelled like one. Musty, chlorine-filled air combining with the scent of prepared foods was not at all appetizing. A rooftop bar in the middle of Philadelphia should not smell like low tide under the boardwalk. Please, Mr. Starr, give this place a good scrub down and replace the flooring with something that doesn't absorb spills. 

I'm sure this wasn't my last visit to the deck at Continental Midtown... but with more bars and restaurants opening outdoor patios and setting up street-side tables, this place won't be topping my list for drinks al fresco.

I have been wanting to try Ella's for a while. I see a lot of great reviews about the place. I finally got to try it for drinks and dessert.
First of all the atmosphere is really cool. The artsy decorations are fun and different. It works well with the high ceilings. There are different booths and tables for everyone to sit at, so it really makes for a nice place to hang out with friends on a Saturday. I notice on Fridays and Sundays they have bands, and I would love to check it out then too.
They have a nice outside area which I will try, and happy to hear that they accept dogs.
Hubby and I kept it simple and ordered a drunken pina colada cake, and chocolate covered bacon. I also got a sangria.  The drunken pina colada cake was our favorite. The chocolate covered bacon was okay, and the sangria was the best. I loved loved it. There is cinnamon in the sangria which I have tried it like that only once at The Mangroves. It really hit the spot.
Our waitress was very cheery, knowledgable and nice.  We will definitely be back to try the diverse menu. Can't wait to try more.

Pat O's is one of the most famous bars in the city. That does not mean that it is one of the best bars in the city, but it is a must see.

There are several different areas within Pat O's and all are somewhat different. One thing that is the same is that all areas are usually jammed packed. The patio area with its flaming fountain is not too bad if you can get a table. A $20 slipped to one of the workers will usually get you put on the top oftheir list.

The piano bar is entertaining, but is the most popular area and will almost always require a wait. 

Pat O's is known for their hurricanes. These fruity drinks are sweet and tasty, but as most professional drinkers know, sweet drinks and alcohol are not a good match.

Because of the history, you must visit this bar at least once. In addition, every tourist and local should own at least one of their signature hurricane glasses.

Although not a classic French institution in the heart of a Parisian city, Parc is a classic Philadelphia institution in the heart of Rittenhouse Square. 

Remorsefully, it's been back burned on my places to go for the last decade. Not that there was anything wrong with it, just that it's not new and shiny. I can't reiterate enough in this review- it's a Philadelphia classic.

It has the Starr touch of gold in terms of hospitality and service. That man would seriously make an (extra) fortune parlaying that info a corporate customer service program.

The food is also top notch. I wouldn't think to rave about a grilled chicken sandwich but the country chicken club seriously has perfect execution. 

I recently had an opportunity to sit outside while enjoying cocktails, meats and cheeses while overlooking Philadelphia's finest parks. Now that's an experience.

A restaurant doesn't become an institution overnight and it's not something merely earned by number of years in the business. Parc is the total package and should be looked at as something other Philly establishments should want to be.

I met Trisha P. at the Royale for a little happy hour action yesterday, and I'll let her speak for herself, but I think it's safe to say we were both pretty pleased! And tipsy, but that's beside the point.

I love this place for a few different reasons, the most obvious being the cocktail selection. If you like beer you're in luck as the list is huge, but if you like a good post-work cocktail, you'll be in heaven at the Royale. I hands down recommend the Butler Miller... it's made up of vodka, fresh lime juice, sugar and Chambord. It's fruity without being too sweet. They are heavy on the pours here, so take it easy, champ...

I spent over a year in Chicago after school and moved there for a new job not knowing a single soul so I learned to really appreciate the smaller neighborhood bars... I would march my then friend-less in Chicago self down the street in the snow and have a drink without feeling like everyone was staring at me because I was alone. It was a lifesaver. The Royale has the same welcoming environment, and the bartenders (and patrons, usually) seem so down to earth and open to all types of people and personalities. You can strike up a conversation with anyone that's sitting around you. Just feels like home!

Every time I go to here I always wonder why I don't go more often. It's kind of a haul down Kingshighway compared to where I live, but it's worth the trip every time! I'm going to try and make that drink at home, though I doubt I can match the guys at the Royale.

Brothers and Sisters, put your hands on the keyboard and repeat after me..... "Sweet Mary, Mother of Jesus, this place rocks!!!!!".  OK, please deposit $5 and make plans to meet me here soon.

Anise Global started as the popular Stinky Bunz food truck around town, and earlier this year settled into the spectacular brick & mortar Gastrobar facility along Ashley Drive in downtown Tampa. The restaurant has a classy European feel with a sleek décor, and a small plates sampling menu combined with crafted cocktails and wines. 

The menu at Anise features the well-known stinky bunz that were such a hit on their food truck. You can order these soft, doughy steamed buns stuffed with crispy shrimp, braised pork belly, red curried crispy chicken, Chinese BBQ pork, or fried zucchini. In addition you'll find a variety of small plates including mini tacos, charcuterie & cheese plate, baked goat cheese, rice bowls, noodle bowls, sandwiches, and salads on their menu.

Anise also has a brunch menu with crab cakes benedict, steak & eggs burritos, sweet & savory pancakes, and pork belly with fried egg & grits. That comes with a do-it-yourself Bloody Mary bar and a variety of fruity mimosas.

I ordered two of the stinky bunz with braised pork belly, and a small plate of duck confit mini tacos. The food was magical, and some of the most unique and delicious lunch fare that I've had in a long time. I plan to return for drinks and a late-night dinner, and will definitely hit this place up for brunch in the near future.

Get yourself down to the corner of Ashley and Zack, and enjoy a very delicious meal at Anise Global Gastrobar.  

Say Hallelujah, and say Amen.

We had an amazingly great time - food and service (by the lovely Maria) with our party of 6.
It was the first day of the "new" OctoberFest menu and we surely enjoyed it.  Mustard Crusted Salmon, Caesar Salad, Chicken and Pork Schnitzel and of course, great beer and beverages.

The only thing preventing a 5 star rating?  Deafeningly loud - as it was quite crowded (Saturday at 1 PM_ and we sat right near the open kitchen.

Service was quick and attentive.

Lovely!

This is a fine zoo for a city of Tampa's size. There's a decent variety of animals, although for many species, there's only one animal. So I feel sorry for the poor tiger and the poor Indian rhino. But there are some larger holdings with elephants, zebras, white rhinos, and giraffes. And the pygmy hippos and orangutans! 

My kids love coming here, mostly to look at the orangutans and then to pester me to do the kiddie rides. There are a decent number of rides that a toddler taller than 36 inches can ride (carousel, truck ride, banana ride, train). But if you have a membership or pay for full priced tickets, you can keep on coming back for the year, so we'll go to the zoo for an hour or two to pass a Saturday and not feel bad that we aren't seeing every exhibit.

A strong 4 stars for Village Whiskey from me!
A good friend and fellow yelper squeaked into the bar at around 8:45 PM on a snowy Tuesday.  There just happened to be 2 great seats waiting for us.  (I don't know if this place is worth a long wait)

Service from Sasha was excellent and she is so friendly and helpful.
We started off with an order of fried pickles and shared the DELICIOUS pickled artichokes.  (These are the best thing I tasted that night and worth a re-order)

My companion had a delectable veggie burger topped with a fried egg (Wowza!) and guacamole.  The lady next to us had a beef burger topped with an egg as well and they sure know how to fry an egg here!
(Incidentally the couple next to us also shared the duckfat fries topped with shortribs and cheese sauce - looked so heavy - like a heart attach on a plate.  I bet it ROCKED!

Anyhow, we continued with an order of "tater tots' that were so rrefined they'd put Ore-Ida to shame.

And an order of pickled golden and red beets that I wound up barely touching and had packed up to go.

The best thing to me?  The delicious lemon oil-scented whipped ricotta that accompaied the pickled dishes.  Also a tasty tapenade and fresh, thin slices of baguette.  Nice!

I will definitely come back here.

What a cute (albeit small) "retro" feeling place.

My review is solely for the dessert room at Berns.  I have been a couple of times, the most recent for a friends birthday celebration.  They do not take reservations for the dessert room, so it's good to go on a low key night and also be prepared to wait for a little bit depending on the size of your party.  Our group of 11 was accommodated after about 15-20 minutes of waiting.

The dessert room is almost always an experience in itself.  Your party is seated in old wine barrels that have been converted into private booths.  Each booth also has a selection of music that you can choose on your own.  Perusing the menu and making a choice will, however, take some time so be prepared to bring your patience.  Our server, April, was quite knowledgeable about the menu and even when we had questions regarding wine.  If there was something we didn't know, she was sure to find out for us.

All 11 of us ordered something unique and none of us were disappointed in our selections.  I had the Peppermint Brownie, which was off the seasonal menu and only available for a limited time.  It was magnificent and rich.  I wouldn't expect anything less from a place of this magnitudes.  Our overall experience while in the dessert room was great.

Be prepared to pay $5 for the valet as it is not complimentary for guests.  There was a lot of confusion going on at the valet as there didn't seem to be any order in a chaotic situation.  They were a bit slow as well so it did leave guests commiserating in front of the restaurant that such a great experience was ending!

My first visit to Besito was a late Saturday lunch with hubs...we shared the guac and grilled fish tacos, along with a marg and mojito. The drinks and chips and salsa were the highlight of our meal (those were awesome). The guac was a disappointment...we sat outside (I assume that's why it wasn't made table side) and despite requesting medium, it had no spice (or flavor for that matter). Fish tacos were a flavorless oily blah. 

Fast forward 6 days when I decided to give Besito another try for a 6-person business lunch. It was packed!!! The experience was much, much better. Tableside guac was quite tasty and my mixed meat skillet tacos were delicious (and definitely cancelled out a week's worth of workouts). 

The service was great on both occasions, very friendly and attentive servers. It is a good place for drinks and an appetizer, or a nicer lunch. I am hopeful that in the future the food will be more like my second visit than my first. Haven't tried it yet for dinner, so can't attest to that.

Not really into the whole cupcake thing, but I will go 3 star here because they're HUGE.  Down in Tampa, all of the gourmet cupcake joints sell regular-sized cupcakes (like you'd make at home) and sell them for $5.  So I suppose if I were to eat a cupcake, it would be from here.

Service was bright and friendly, and the eatery was well-organized and spotless.  They even serve Bud Light!

I have experienced HWK as a single diner. I went to Brunch on April 15th and was to sit at one of the hightop tables in the front window. When I called to make my reservation, Tori the dining room manager answered the phone and was very perky and pleasant. She asked me if the hightop would be acceptable and I responded, yes. When she asked for my name, I admit I did use an alias. I figured they'd be on the alert for a Steven and I did not  want special treatment. Once I gave my name, she commented that she thought I had been there before, but I said "no this will be my first". (I think they knew it was me)

When I arrived that Sunday morning, I was seated at the hightop close to the hostess stand. It was comfortable and I had great light for reading, since I was dining alone. 
I love a Bloody Mary at Brunch, HWK calls them a Bloody Wilbur. Their twist has; Bacon Vodka with tomato juice and garnished with pickled asparagus.  I was famished, so I ordered two entrees; Biscuits and Gravy and Eggs Benedict. 

After I place my order, John the husband of Cassy approached my table and asked me if I were the Steven from Yelp. Yes, I was busted and I wasn't surprised.  Part of being a good Yelper is taking ownership of your reviews, so with a smile I acknowledged who I was. Our conversation was very pleasant and as Cassy (his wife and executive chef) said to me in private messaging they are thankful I brought the single seating to their attention and apologetic my previous experience. 

Now let's talk food, after all that is what restaurant reviews are all about.  I'll break it down item for item. 

Bloody Wilbur: Love the bacon vodka, proving everything is better with bacon. I also enjoyed the the garnish of pickled asparagus. Asparagus is my all-time favorite vegetable so adding it to a brunch cocktail, is A-Okay in my book. Their choice of tomato juice, held this drink back from being spectacular. The juice was weak, a rich and thicker type tomato juice have made this classic brunch cocktail truly pop. 

Biscuits and Gravy: They made this old farm boy proud. These truly were some kick ass, B&G. A picture is suppose to be worth a 1000 words, but B&G do not photograph well. So let me tell you the best I can. When you have buttermilk biscuits with chives and cheddar topped with gravy containing huge chunks of sausage - it does not get any better. These Biscuits and Gravy will be added to my Yelp list of Best B&G. 

Mimosa: Meyer Lemon is a staple in my kitchen/bar at home. So when I saw that they use it for their mimosa, I was already sold. I found the the sparkling wine served with the Meyer Lemon and honey to be a refreshing twist to traditional Mimosa. Two thumbs up and remember I am dining alone. 

Eggs Benedict: No English Muffin, they use a Grits Cake instead which gives an original twist. I'm not a fan of grits and I enjoyed the difference in texture and flavor. The eggs were poached perfectly and the use of Tasso gives it a Cajun kick. They then top it off with a Spicy Hollandaise and Flash Fried Spinach. 

I'm glad I finally got to experience HWK and I'll be back for a lunch soon. My rating is more of a 3 1/2 Star (wish Yelp would let us do 1/2's soon). If Wilbur would have been bloody better, it would of been a 4.

Prohibition Taproom has got personality. Their huge "BAR" sign calls to you, even visible from Spring Garden. This faux-speakeasy's interior fits their name, with a large wooden bar dominating the space, lit by beautiful hanging Victorian bulbs. There's room for a crowd, even in the bathrooms[1]. My only gripe is that the exterior is brighter than it ought to be.

Prohibition opened earlier this month, and as young as they are, the staff was anything but. Brendan, our bartender and a trained chef, kept us happy, making us shots and taking food orders (they have a full menu). We took down gin ($7/shot), Jameson, and pineapple rum shooters[2]. Would have drank more, but conceded, with great lugubriousness, that it was a Monday night.

Stop into Prohibition[3], and tell 'em I sent you[4]!

[1] Their non-unisex bathrooms can fit two comfortably, though most will prefer to go solo. Don't ask how I know.
[2] I asked for a light, random shot, and was pleasantly surprised with the shooters.
[3] Do this!
[4] Don't do that!

When I think of good beer bars in Philly, Monk's automatically comes to the top of my list. 

It's been ages since I've dined there, but I've been there for beverages recently so it's certainly worth reviewing.

The atmosphere is dark and cozy, perhaps the way a bar would feel in Belgium. I have no idea if that's the case, but if I ever go to Belgium, I will certainly be comparing my experience to Monk's. 

I just learned there is a second bar and dining area in the back. The space isn't large but that's great there's more than I initially thought. 

Their bottled beer list is huge and focused on European brews. Understandably a chunk of the selection is Belgian but the US, Denmark, Germany and many other countries are well represented. I know I should be focusing on the foreign beers when I go there for a drink, but it really excites me that they carry Russian River on tap. 

I need to go there for a longer visit to really get my drink on and have some food. Even without having a recent "full experience," I can easily see why it's such a highly touted and well recognized Philly establishment.

This place has so much potential....I want to love it, but I am close to hating it.

#1 - Service is ridiculously awful. The servers are pompous and completely unhelpful. Sorry not sorry I am inconveniencing you by asking for more pita. Snootiness is out of control.
#2 - Speaking of pita, 5 of us ordered the hummus appetizer and we were given 4 mini triangles of pita bread and a giant vat of hummus. Not even enough for one per person! When we asked for more, we were brought 4 more mini triangles....and charged $1. Never got even close to enough pita to finish the hummus.
#3 - The prices. I am happy to pay for good food and service, but I am not happy when the service sucks and therefore I feel like my $13+ chicken burger is a total rip-off. Private events require a $4500 food and beverage minimum, not counting room rental, service fee, etc. 
#4 - The lack of wifi. Don't give some BS about the fact that people should disconnect. I was not happy when I stopped here to get work done when I was early to a meeting. If your goal is to keep out the UT kids who will sit for hours, you are unsuccessful - they just tether from their phones (and sit for hours on their computers anyway).

This place is always busy base on the yelper photo and review. We were there at 5:20 pm and we were second in the line. I guess, this is the best time to visit. The restaurant has very limited space if you decide to dine in. They only can seat 15 the most.

Since they are number 1 in the top 100 list, we decided to try them. They have good selection of taco. We have the ribeye, campechano, shrimp, pastor, carnitas, chorizo, and lengua. This strange name but who care. The most important is they good or not. The lengua is the cow tongue. 

The only complaint I have is they need to caramelized a bit will make it better.  My wife like the most is carnitas. It is sherrard or simmering pork. She indicate to me is better than the mojo pork. 

The food do not require to wait for too long to prepared. It is a bit expensive than most taco place. It is cafeteria service order at the counter and they bring it to you.

I needed to run to the airport post office tonight, and then stop by International Plaza to visit Nordstrom before next week's business trip up to Philadelphia. I parked near the Bay Street (outdoor food court) section of the Mall, and figured that I'd grab something for dinner after I finished shopping. I thought I could find a nice entrée salad or a light pasta dish, and not blow my budget in the process.

As I'm wandering along past all of the eateries and drinking establishments of Bay Street I spotted a long-lost friend at the end of the walkway -- The Cheesecake Factory. I haven't eaten at a CF in ages, but I had heard they now have a "lighter" SkinnyLiscious menu as well as some small plate specials, and I figured that was worth a try. Lots of things looked interesting on their menu, but I ended up with a plate of Sautéed Shrimp served over Angel Hair Pasta. My entrée was 5 large shrimp sautéed with herbs, lemon and garlic, and then plated atop Angel Hair pasta, sun-dried tomatoes and fresh basil. This was teensy bit more than the 450 calorie offerings on the SkinnyLiscious menu, but it was very tasty, and not coated in oil or a heavy sauce.

The menu at the Cheesecake Factory is positively huge with a little bit of everything to appeal to a wide range of tastes. On the weekends the wait to be seated can be up to an hour, and plenty of people are determined to stand there and wait for their table. I can't get excited about waiting that long to get seated in a standard chain restaurant, but that's just my opinion.

Now the main reason that people flock to the Cheesecake Factory is for their desserts, and if you hope to maintain any dignity and self-respect, you'll skip right over this section of the menu and just order a small luncheon salad and a glass of water. Unfortunately, the vast majority of their patrons flip right to the two page listing of the various types of cheesecake (I'm guessing 50 or so), and fixate on dessert as they wolf down their meals.

Not to fear my friends as you can walk to the bakery counter and order your slices of cheesecake to go, and take this delicacy back to your office or to your home, and savor every morsel in complete privacy. Half the fun is watching your fellow diners drooling over all of the choices as they try to decide which one (OK, maybe two) slice(s) will be going home with them.

Thankfully I maintained my composure at dinner and just had the pasta. But I sure would like to know how that to-go bag with a slice of Key Lime pie cheesecake ended up on the front seat of my SUV as I pulled out of the Mall's parking lot....

The crown jewel of Tarpon Springs. 

If you're coming to the sponge docks, make time to visit Hellas too. The food and service are genuinely impeccable. The gyro's are flavourful, the souvlaki is tender and the flaming cheese is, well, in a word  HOT!

You can get all your Greek cuisine favorites like: Skordilla, stuffed grape leaves, Avgolemono soup, spanokipita,Horiatiki Salad, Greek Salad, a broiled octopus and even a whole fish that is then deboned at your table side. 

And while you're there, don't forget to visit the bakery for even more absolutely decadent treats, the bakalava is some of the very best you'll ever eat. 

OPA!

Yelp is the only reason I would have ever even noticed this place, let alone actually stopped in for the food itself.

The place is really tiny inside (Only five tables opposite the counter where you order), the employees are friendly and there are plenty of good Mexican choices.

My order was a Taco Ribeye, a Taco Chorizo and a Sope Chipotle.

This was my first ever sope and it is now in my vocabulary and among my favorites.

Both tacos also were really delicious and fresh and the 50 cent up charge to add cheese was very much worth it.

My wait was not very long and all of my specs on each item (no cilantro, no onions, add lettuce, no sour cream) were accurate.

While I don't agree with Holly H. that these are definitely the "Best Tacos in Tampa," she makes a great point about how the items are not greasy at all and the sauces are very good.

They also feature tortas, quesadillas and tamales to give me something to look forward to on a future visit.

The heart of the Tarpon Springs sponge docks holds Hellas' bakery and Restaurant. It's a great place to dine, to people watch and to grab a cup of coffee and a slab of bakalava. There really isn't anything better to do on a Saturday afternoon, than sit at one of the outside tables, sipping your java and licking honey off your finger tips. The food is fantastic! Opa!

Surprisingly I enjoyed this airport even though I had a layover that was over 3 hours there...I flew into the SW terminal and signage was good and the space was open and airy.

Yes free WIFI which can be spotty depending on where you are. If you go out into the area before security there are a plethora of comfy chairs with charging areas and shopping... 

Security was fast and courteous. Definite a good experience.

At first I thought I knew Philly sushi pretty well. But now that I finally entered Vic Sushi Bar and picked up some rolls I can honestly say that I knew NOTHING beforehand.

I came, I saw, I ordered some spicy tuna and eel and I had them rolled up and ready to go in less than 2 minutes. This is hands down the quickest and freshest sushi that I ever had prepared for me. and the sushi rice was definitely the stickiest too.

The only flaw I can think of is that the room is a little too compact. So it's not a place that you want to go to if you're planning to stick around with a group for awhile. But everything is so traditional (aside from the Buddha riding the dragon statue thats decorated with dollar bills I suppose) that Vic is absolutely worth the visit.

I've been using this airport for many years, since I was a child, and seen it decline into a complete sorry state and then improve a bit into the transitory state it is in now as renovations are underway and all sorts of great promises of wonderful things to come are in the air.  

Unfortunately while the renovations are going on we get to contend with, at least on my recent trip, only having ONE working concourse and on my recent last flight back home to NOLA only ONE luggage carousel was working so everybody from every flight was all mixed together.  There were substantial delays because of the limited number of gates available so hopefully this will be rectified soon!

The business options in the one working concourse area also have limited hours so if you are traveling at odd hours you will have no options for provisions or entertainment.  It is really shameful in the current state and I hope everything gets super improved and gives New Orleans an airport finally worthy of our great city.

If you want a sweet treat in Tarpon Springs you must stop by Hellas Bakery!  As soon as I stepped in I was overwhelmed by the incredible smells of fresh baked bread and sugary, sweet pastries and desserts.  We almost went to the wrong bakery.  Apparently the other bakery on Dodecanese stocks baked goods from Hellas.  Luckily we realized we were in the wrong bakery and found the "real" Hellas further down the same road.

We tried the Greek Cannoli, Strawberry Cheesecake and the Baklava.  All excellent!!!  It took all of my willpower not to take a loaf of bread home as well as every dessert that contained baklava.  

I cannot wait to try more of the Greek treats on my next visit!

I organized a Happy Hour for 7 women and we had a BLAST last night.
Our servers Megan & Jasmine took excellent care of all of us - and even "split off" our bill into different permutations of food and cocktails.

The Happy Hour specials ($6 apps and certain drinks) are a great value.

We had several orders of Tuna & Marlin tacos, Dates wrapped in bacon (so good), Truffled Guac, Empanadas and more.

I even got a side dish of the duck confit "fried" rice.  It came with a scary-looking poached egg on top - but man - once you broke that egg open and savored the rice, pine nuts, currants, duck confit and crunchy goodness - WOW.  It was a flavor blast on so many levels.  For $9 this "side" was more like a meal.

Definitely love the mojitos and alma coladas here.

What a terrific restaurant on all fronts - food, decor and service.  All 5 star.

Douglas - you are a MASTER of your craft.

This airport is easy access. The gate to ground transportation and the baggage claim is a short walk from Southwest terminal. 

When we were at the airport they are running the free luggage tag. This is a Mardi Gras week and they also have the numerous vender provide free gift if you have the purchase or $10 or more. 

The airport security is quick and easy since the line is short. They also have free WIFI if you have to access the internet services. Like most of the major airport, they have the comfortable cushion seat with electrical outlet next to it for you to hook up or chagrin you phone or computer. The restroom is clean generally. 

The rental car return is convenient located at their parking garage next to the terminal. There is a short cover walkway from the garage to the terminal. But they are not fully enclose and it is open air on each side. This is only down side of this airport. If rain with wind, you are more likely get minor wet. I hope they can improve it to fully enclose climate control situation.

The sheer randomness of Franklin Fountain adds to its awesomeness. What's an old-school soda fountain doing in Philadelphia?

They serve ice cream (made fresh on-the-premises I believe) and ice cream sodas. Their flavors range from the typical to the atypical. I asked for a scoop of the ginger ice cream, as recommended by our cool server Jess. The scoop she administered was HUGE - I'd like to think it was just for me, but I think she's supposed to scoop that much for everyone.

When it comes to desserts, I'm usually ambivalent, but I happen to love ice cream as much as Thai food. The ginger ice cream was a treat and I'm making plans to visit again to try their mint chip. Mmmmm.

UPDATE: I came back in April and had the mint chip, which was smoooooth. Also got to meet one of the owners (Ryan Berley), who took the time to talk to us!

If you live in Philly you've either had El Vez or El Rey. 

Yes they're both Stephen Starr but the biggest difference to me of the 2 is price and interior decor/vibes.

El Rey is definitely more casual, a more hole in the wall look while El Vez is flashy, modern decor and outside seating.

But down to the important stuff, the food. I personally think the tacos here are way better but my personal favorite, is the DIY tacos AKA fajitas (Tacos al Carbon). they're fresh and delicious. All of the guac here is also delicious, anything crab is a plus in my book. I'd recommend this place to anyone that is craving Mexican while in Center City but I would never say this place is authentic. 

Overall, this restaurant has great service, food and drinks but it depends what you're craving. Do you want American Mexican food? Then yes, this place is for you!

Came here for lunch and was my first time. Didn't realize this restaurant was so big. Was greeted upon entering and shown to a seat immediately. Waitress came right over with menus and took our drink orders. Service was great -- even was very quick in getting our food. Actually impressed at how fast and fresh the food was. Lunch pricing was good as well.  I love the egg tart and it's always been a favorite of mine so seeing it available on their menu made me happy and I just had to order for the table.  They were served in cute muffin papers and very fresh and yummy, not overly sweet. We also had the Shanghi dumplings and sesame balls -- the dumplings were big and stuffed with meat. There is soy sauce on the table which makes it convenient. I'd definitely order the dumplings again. The walnut chicken was just ok -- comes with their signature white sauce and toasted walnuts, the breading on the chicken is very thick and the dish was just too sweet for me. I could only have like 4 pieces of the chicken.  My friend ordered the sweet and sour chicken which he let me sample and wow that's definitely what I'm ordering next time. It was so good and love that it comes with veggies and pineapples. 

Definitely will be back. Went back to work and did tell my coworkers that we will have to go back.

I've been a fan of La Teresita for many years and all of the times I've been I can't complain about the quality of the food.  From the pulled pork to the Cuban fried rice, everything is well portioned and delicious.  On my most recent visit on a Friday evening it was quite easy to get a table, despite the restaurant being quite busy.  Once seated our server was quick to get drinks, but when asking for some additional explanation on some of the menu items and what they came with, he pretty much just read off what the menu said.  Once our food was out and we were done it took quite some time for him to make his way back, so much so that I ended up walking over to the to go boxes and just grabbing one myself to pack up my leftovers.  Overall a great place to grab some Cuban food, but service can be hit or miss.

Oh hi there, St. Louis! It's only been, what...7 months since I last wrote my review? 

Well, this former St. Louis girl misses her hometown like crazy, and I saw that my review count dropped from 700 to 699 (WTF, Yelp?) so I'm making things right in my world. Trying to, at least. 

Anyway, Sugarfire. Now that I've been a Virginia resident for over half a year, I can say a whole lot of good things about this great state. The scenery is amazing (hellooooo, mountains!). The people are ridiculously nice (and their accents are le cute!). And the weather is pretty flipping fantastic. 

But you know what I miss? BARBECUE. Good, flavorful, St. Louis style BBQ. The stuff here doesn't cut it. Actually, I take that back -- the stuff here very well MAY cut it, but I haven't tried it. 

That's right. I haven't had BBQ in 7 long months. Because I know that whatever I try here won't even begin to hold a flame to the wonderfulness that is SugarFire Smoke House. 

Holy shit I miss this place. 

It's nestled in the suburbs of St. Louis, in a pretty unassuming strip mall. Next door to a Starbucks. And a kinkos (there's a kinkos there, right? Has it been so long that I've forgotten what's in the area? NOOOOOOO!). 

In other words, it's not where I would expect to find good BBQ. 

But boy...once I walked into that place for the first time, all of those preconceived notions were smashed. SMASHED! 

The setup is a bit odd; you start by grabbing a drink. Then you take a look at the menu and order, cafeteria-style. 

I visited SugarFire a few times, and every time, I was blown away by the quality of the food. On separate occasions, I've had their pulled pork, brisket, and ribs. Each item was incredible. The brisket was, hands down, the BEST brisket I've had in my life. Juicy, flavorful, tender. Perfect. 

The sides are also quite amazing. The sides change regularly, but I've had their mac and cheese, baked beans, and potato salad. All amazing. 

If you're going to order dessert here (and you better!) go with any of their boozy shakes and/or the crack pie. Don't ask me what's in the crack pie. I have no idea, but it's super good, whatever it is. I'm pretty sure it consists of 99% sugar. Fine by me! 

The service here is incredible, and the prices are great. 

Don't wait in the long lines at Pappy's or Bogarts. I'm not telling you NOT to visit those places, but go to SugarFire first. 

When I come back to visit STL in August, I'm heading straight from the airport to SugarFire. Do not pass go, do not collect $200. SugarFire will be my FIRST stop. 

You think I'm kidding.

I remember loving this place a few years back but I just hadn't gotten around to stopping in recently. Last night my group was looking for a place to sip a drink and enjoy the outdoors, and the Devil's Alley balcony tables came to mind. There was a table on the street level available when we rolled up so we decided to sit there instead.

I was going to be perfectly content ordering a Tröegs Perpetual IPA for $5.50 until our sever informed us that all bottles were $3 for craft beer Tuesday. Then she pointed out that Victory's Golden Monkey counted towards the special. I love this girl! She then continued to blow our minds with their daily drink specials. I believe it's margarita Monday, craft beer Tuesday, rum punch Wednesday, Jameson Thursday, Absolute Friday, Sangria Saturday and Yuengling Sunday. The prices vary per day but were really excellent based on each beverage.

We weren't planning on eating but then she told us the specials. There was a duck quesadilla with goat cheese and a Mac n Cheese with jalapeño, bacon and crab. Both sounded phenomenal but my friend wanted the Mac n Cheese and I definitely needed an eating buddy since I wasn't even hungry. Amazing call! It was creamy and you got at least some topping in every bite. The jalapeños could have been a little hotter but maybe it was better not to make the dish super-hot. 

Of course inside the restaurant they had the lights and talks trees that make the ambiance cool. I didn't love how the tables overlooked a dying section of Chestnut Street but it's not Devil Alley's fault this once vibrant neighborhood is now a little desolate. 

With such great all day drink specials, I'll absolutely be back soon. Even if it's just for one drink before moving elsewhere, who can resist?

Why 5 stars? Because it's easy to understand the notoriety. 

   ---   ---   ---

I think it's impossible to eat at Commanders Palace and say anything other than, "it's phenomenal." I can understand if maybe you don't think it's quite worth the $$$$, but I think it definitely was.

Spoiler alert: I'm pretty much never going to visit a city without trying a place that possesses 1,000+ reviews and a 4.5 star average. If I had missed out, I definitely would have regretted it.

I was very tempted to go with the shrimp and grits, but I had just satisfied that craving earlier in the day at Surrey's. Come to think of it, with Commanders Palace and Surrey's in the same day, this day might go down as the best foodie day in my life.

So while I did sample my friend's shrimp and grits, I enjoyed the Pecan Crusted Gulf Fish. It was absolutely worth every cent. Bravo CP! But the real star of the show here was the bread pudding souffle. It has ruined all other bread puddings and souffle's for my entire life, as none will ever live up to the magical plate that appears from the kitchen at this fine establishment.

What a cool place. It's so New Orleans, and I loved it.

Cold sesame: very tasty, noodles is very soft, more to sweet, not spicy at all. 

Dan dan : a lot of noodles, you can make several meals from it. Make sure you choose the right spicy level.

Cucumber appetizer : very good and very spicy

As a fan of Parkway I've had way better roast beef at Parasol's or Domilicis. 

I'm the first to be critical of Parkway and I love the place and the owners and they know me but for there own good I must be critical. Let me say 1st that I love the bread the atmosphere the social tables, etc. I took my dad over because we hadn't been in a while and we both had the roast beef poboy. The bread was great and the size was super but the taste, bland to say the least. My father and I both said simultaneously that it was like they just boiled the beef in water with no seasonings. I'm not a mayonnaise fan and had to ask for extra to give the sandwich some taste. The worst thing is to have a lot of something you don't like and unfortunately that was my experience. 

The shrimp and other items are great just I think the roast beef is overrated.
