It is about 4.5 stars. Not yet 5 stars. This is a place that young and beautiful gatherings place. Great to many young people participating the lunch. With University of Tampa next to it, many students eat here. I like this place because it has variety of shops in one place. They have bookstore, champagne bar, coffee bar, the shop, commerce club upstairs. Very interesting to host many variety. 

We enjoy the restaurant area. For lunch, their food selection is flatbread, sandwiches, small plate, breakfast and salad. Simple but elegant. We got the steak sandwich and tomato prosciutto flatbread. The steak sandwich has a sauce along caramelize shallot in it make the tasty. The flat bread prosciutto is chop piece with pesto sauce which is delicious. Our experience is great. Definitely come in the future. Serve is average. Once the server engaged, we have good service.

Stopped in for an early dinner and was fortunate enough to snag a comfy booth.    We used to come here all the time but we have not been as impressed with the food of late and tonight even less so with the service.    The beer here IS good, so if it is the beer you are after you are in the right spot.

We ordered the tuna tartare special as an appetizer to share.   The runner dropped the plate and fled - no sharing plates.    It was delicious but awkward since the plate it came on was quite small.    The waitress stopped by after we were almost done with it but did not noticed or didn't care.

My dining partner ordered the filet medallion special, good but a bit underdone for him.    

I ordered the moules and frites ($16.50).   The broth was great this time, but we were not served any bread.  When we asked for it, there was no butter.   Furthermore, there were a total of 14 mussel shells, two which were broken without any evidence of the pieces that were broken off, i.e. they knew it.   Dead mussels are not a good thing.   Shame on you.... Only two stars for you!

Friendly staff who explained the menu well and gave good recommendations.

White tuna salad: fresh lettuce with melt-in-your-mouth white tuna. 

Naruto roll: fresh fish wrapped in cucumber. Very healthy.

The restaurant itself is very small. 

Definitely come back to try the tuna dumplings.

The gyoza is made in the house

I return tonight for another try at Kona grill with one of my best friends. What can I say we had a terrific time. We tried everything from the smoked gouda fondue, pepperoni flatbread, chicken and shrimp lettuce wraps & the crab crunch roll.
 
Our server could not have been more fantastic. She was always there when we needed her, offering suggestions and very friendly throughout the evening. Thank you so much. The fondue  was absolutely delicious it was served with place granny smith apples and soft, warm,  pretzel bites. Absolutely delicious.
The crab French roll was delicious and I've never had anything quite like it before it was quite remarkable. The pepperoni flatbread was unbelievably good. I am a pizza fanatic  and this hits all of the keynote of a great Pizza.
The chicken and shrimp lettuce wraps were very well made and very tasty. The lettuce for this was nice and fresh and crunchy. Best friends and lettuce mix was full of vegetables and very tasty. The dipping sauce was white spicy and it was a kind of space that give giving and giving and giving. All in all we had an excellent time.

Compare this one is handsome hands above the last visit, which did not impress me at all. This message yep this girls and press and she will be back no doubt about that. A paragraph what's a girl to do? Always give a restaurant  a second chance when the first one doesn't work out.

I love this place!  It's not often that I crave the atmosphere as much as the food, but this place is just fun to go to.  The staff is all smiles, joking with each other, singing out loud some times to the rock-star 80s soundtrack playing overhead.  Great, great music just puts you in a good mood, and when met with a laid-back, smiling server, it's perfect!

I like the 2-egg simple breakfast and the biscuits and gravy (without the green onions) so far!  Menu does tap into "Southwest" and delivers some spicy options, but my tongue can't handle those.  :(  My spicy-lovin' friends say they're delish though.

Highly recommended.

The food here remains consistently good.  Today, we arrived for lunch.   You can get a small cup of soup, a spring roll and one of a wide selection of entrees for only $9.   We shared an appetizer and had two iced coffees for $33.   A great value and still plenty to take home.   Today we had chicken pad Thai and very spicy hot basil fried rice.o

Out of all of the airports I have had the opportunity to travel through, I would say TIA is one of the best domestic airports you will find.  Parking is usually easy and I have never experienced a lengthy wait at check in.  The terminals also have free Wi-Fi, which is always a plus.  All of the terminals are also equipped with a newstand of some sort and at least one restaurant to satisfy any traveller's needs.  

My only grip and reason for not giving 5 stars is that the TSA could operate a bit better at this airport.  There are always lines and there always seem to be detectors that are not being utilized, even when lines are long and there is enough staff to man all of those unused machines.

Hands down the best place for live music. Love the dual piano set-up, and how talented the artists are. All you have to do is write what you wanna hear on a napkin, and hand it to them to play. Home of the hurricane as well. Generous pours and good times.

I have been to La Teresita  Restaurant several time. This restaurant is a Cuban charm in Bay Area. You can be restaurant or cafe side. The also has the bakery and cafe next to it for overflow. 

Food here is affordable. You can enjoy a steak for less than ten dollars. The serving speed is fast and you don't have to wait long and the food is ready. We have the steak Palomilla Steak and the Thursday special Pescado a la Marinera. They give you a big piece of grill steak. If you ask medium rare, they usually mid well because this steak is thin. 

The Pescado a la Marinera is grilled fish in tomato sauce with little shrimp and veggies. Fish is good. Come with two choices of side. 

Food here is reasonable but taste is just average among the Hispanic restaurant. If you like budget and fast, this will be your place.

Anise may be the best offer for food in downtown area. It is very close to library, the park, performance art that make a very easy access and reach. The interior is modern and nice. It has a very nice bar area.  

We were here after a yelp event since it is a walking distance. For Thursday night, they are still a lot of people after 9:30 pm. There is lively of this location. No wonder my friend like it here.

The food is good mix of Asian fusion, Mexican, and American favorite. I have tried the ramen bowl with pork belly. The soup base is pork bone base very close to the tonkutsu of Sapporo Japan.  This bowl is actually reinvented with the ingredient and change from traditional ramen bowl. The pork belly is fried to give more flavor to release to the soup. Usually fried pork belly soak the pork oil. When it mix up with liquid, it release the belly oil into the soup. Clever ideal. I like this bowl and I also prefer the the tradition pork belly. So this ramen has potential. 

Overall the service is good. I like the atmosphere of the restaurant.

My dad is as much of a foodie as me, so when he came in town and wanted to treat me to dinner, Farmhaus was at the top of my list. I hadn't tried it before, but after reading all of the amazing reviews and checking out their menu online, I knew it would be right up our alley. 

I made reservations easily, and we were on our way. 

I'm really glad we made reservations; we wouldn't have gotten a table otherwise! It was quite cozy. Oh, speaking of reservations, they won't accept reservations for parties larger than 4, which I think is incredibly stupid. I discovered that fact when me and some friends (there were 5 of us) tried to make reservations a few months ago and they flat out refused. It was ALMOST enough to deter me from giving it a second try with my dad. 

Anyway, we were seated immediately. We started with the conch fritters, which were deep fried balls of deliciousness. It was served with a sort of spicy jalapeno sauce, which was good. It was hard to taste the conch in the dish, which was a bit disappointing, but they were tasty nonetheless. 

Next up we tried the chilled roast beef. It was served with truffle oil infused whipped cream, horseradish panna cotta, au jus, and lavash. This was delicious. I LOVE horseradish, and the panna cotta was quite amazing. 

For my entree, I went with the bacon wrapped meatloaf, which was fantastic. It was a small portion, but after the two starting plates, it ended up being the perfect amount of food. 

My dad ordered the grouper, which he loved. I had a few bites, and it was extremely delicious. So flavorful, and it had a hint of sweetness that I couldn't quite place. 

The service was attentive without being overbearing, although there was an awkward moment where the waitress assumed that my dad was my BOYFRIEND. Awkward awkward awkward. 

Anyway, it was a delicious meal, and it left both my dad and I very impressed. I look forward to returning.

(4.25) ~ Very good Overall food & Service.  It is expensive, but surprisingly the attire is only casual, which is a good thing, since it's definitely not pretentious;)lol  Note:  They have Valet Parking, as well as, a Parking Garage nearby.

DIY CHEESE BOARD:
** Scharfe Maxx(Cow/Raw) = (4.25) Very good & creamy
** Clyde Weaver Vintage Quebec Cheddar(Cow/Raw) = (4) very good cheddar
* Birchrun Hill Farm "Fat Cat"(Cow/Raw) = (3.75) Good & Local;)
* Jasper Hill Farm "Alpha Tolman"(Cow/Raw) = (3.5) good
* Doe Run Farm "Seven Sisters"(Cow/Raw) = (3.25) pretty good
* Millwood Springs Organic Blue(Cow/Raw) = (3.25) pretty good
* Keswick Creamery Big Hill Cider Tomme(Cow/Raw) = (3) ok

DRINKS:
** The Backpacker(cocktail) = (4.25) Very good
** French Press La Colombe Coffee = (4) very good
* Water(tap) = (3.75) Good

FOOD:
** Warm Brioche w. Herb Butter(Amuse Bouche) = (5) Excellent!
** Tuna Crudo = (4.5) Very Good!
** Sweet Corn Creme Brulee = (4.25) Very good, light & creamy
** Polenta & Fig(side) = (4) very good
** "Steak & Tomato" = (4) very good
** Bread & Crisps(free) = (4) very good
* Smashed & Fried Potatoes in Blue Cheese Dressing = (3.5) good

This place is kind-of a tourist trap and part business-yuppie lunch spot.
They do have decent food, cutesy decor (with swinging chairs at some tables) and over-priced cutesy-named drinks.

They also recently starting hawking 2-bite teeny-weeny desserts served tapas-style.

Whatever.

The "Green Submarine" is a veggie sandwich that I'll get in a pinch at lunch time when I am forced to eat here by co-workers who have no originiality and are too scared to try Matyson.

Amazing!  A hair's breadth away from 5 stars - so I'mma gonna do it and give them all five - and especially Marina our kind, patient server who was so accommodating.

Firstly, my dining companion and I walked in 45 minutes EARLY for our 8 PM res.  This is a hostesses nightmare and we were prepared to be told to "sit at the bar" but we got a table (in the bar area) right away.

I had 2 of the tastiest Arnold Palmers you can imagine - made with the herb-infused house sun tea.

Everything we ate from the fluffy warm brioche rolls with ramp butter to the delicate "handkerchief" pasta (mine with umami rich rabbit, my friends was vegetarian) to the luscious side of garden beets (at least 2 varieties of beet - possibly 3 it was hard to tell) and candied orange peel and a touch of creamy fresh ricotta. - All was wonderful - but the real showpiece was the special of SEASON ONLY squash blossoms (which I love!!!) delicately fried - stuffed with goat cheese and herbs.

Calorie-city!  But so tasty - and we shared an order of 4 - so 2  seemed just about decadently perfect.

We also splurged and shared a Millefuille (more like quatrefuille - please tell me somebody gets my jokes...) of thinly sliced banana, toffee and chocolate served with a rich yet delicate quenelle (aka the Quenelle from hell) of dark chocolate sorbet. 

Wow.

Beets (pun intended) the heck outta Parc.
Similar price points but somehow we spent WAY less (no $60 seafood cocktail tonight, thank you very much).

Dinner for 2 with soft drinks and 1 dessert (no alcohol) was around $75 before tip.

I can't wait to go back.

GO TO TALULA'S. 
Go!
Go!
Go!

And ask for Marina - what a sweetheart.
Tatiana was a doll, too.

Great service, great food, precious decor (a little too cutesy for me, but it's Starry-eyed splendor in the grass.).

You got me!

Top of the mornin' to ya! After a brief visit to an overly packed bar with too much loudness, I determined that morning is actually the best time to visit Erin Ross. 

You are able to grab a seat at the bar and enjoy one of their many breakfast beverage specials. 

Silly me for scoffing at first at the thought of going to an Irish bar in New Orleans. Where else are you going to enjoy a good Irish Coffee? Not a fan of super cold and creamy, I opted for the hot Irish coffee.  It was a mere $4. It was so good I could have been tricked into paying double for it. 

On the Sunday morning, the clientele was calm including a pup named Beignet who was sitting in a bar seat. Talk about hair of the dog!

Erin Ross wasn't my jam for a Saturday evening, but I felt right at home on a Sunday morning.

Roti canai is a must for appetizer. Beef chow fun is good. Seafood noodle soup is good although the squids are chewy. Buddhist delight is on the salty side. Steamed tofu stuffed with shrimp is good although the sauce is salty. Service is great. Portion is big.

Why 4 stars? Because this is another solid Latin eatery in West Tampa.

   ---   ---   ---

Cuenelli's was on my list for quite a while, but I was finally able to make it out. I normally order steak over chicken, but I wanted to try both since the name of the business includes "Peruvian Style Rotisserie Chicken" in it. 

I enjoyed my meal. It wasn't the best I've had in Tampa Bay, but it was a job well done. I thoroughly enjoy anytime I have the chance to gobble up some South or Central American goodness, and this was no exception.

This is a cool restaurant.

I had been waiting for this place to open, and I was so excited when it finally did.  Everything is fantastic.  The atmosphere, the building right on the river, the staff, the food, the drinks.  This is going to be our place to take our out of town guests (after they've experienced Bern's) to show off Tampa.

We started out with the calamari and the tomato and onion salad.  Everything was seasoned perfectly.

For our entrees, I had the pompano, and my husband had the skirt steak.  His was clearly excellent as he cleaned his plate and didn't offer me a bite.  My pompano was huge, and the meat was flaky.  I liked the creamy sundried tomato sauce.

Desserts were awesome.  My husband said the house-made ice cream was the best he's ever had.  I had the key lime ice cream stack, and the meringue was perfect.  The ice cream was frozen a little too hard, but after it thawed, it was delightfully tart.

To drink, we tried the Florida mojito, the Water Works Sunset and the Pisco.  All were really good.  The wine list looked promising, but I was dying for cocktails that night.

The restaurant can be loud, especially by the bar, but if you are seated by the horse, you can have a conversation.

The Post is officially my favorite sports bar... especially after tonight. I'm pretty sure at least half of Cardinal nation was crammed in there wearing their red, screaming like a bunch of freakin' crazy people... So amazing...

There are so many TVs at the Post that there's no way you can't see whatever game you're looking for, and the best part? THEY PLAY SOUND. There's nothing worse than watching a big game and listening to a bunch of top 40's pop hits. The service is steady and friendly, and I've just never had a bad time here. 

The 20% off your food you get when you check in on Yelp doesn't hurt at all, and their menu has something for everybody. Wings, nachos, burgers, chicken fingers, pizza, even a good veggie burger... typical bar food but kicked up a notch. The drinks come strong, as well. The best part about tonight is that the bartender would occasionally pick up the microphone to cheer on our team and bash other ones we didn't want to win... made it fun and pumped everyone up even more.

This is my go-to sports bar, no doubt. And with that I say... WE WON THE NATIONAL LEAGUE WILD CARD!

When you read into the name, put the emphasis on Southwest more than Diner.  Yes, this place is on Southwest street, but when you enter you realize that it's name carries more synergy than the street where they are located.  The place is adorned with all kinds of Southwest art.  I especially liked the mirror that had paitings of their food items hanging about the building.  It look like the group out of the "let's go out to the lobby" movie advertisment.  But substitue eggs and frijoles for hot dogs and popcorn.  

Anyway, the food is good, and the portions are large.  I had the pork adovada.  It had plenty of flavor.  She had the breakfast sandwich.  It was smothered in butter and yummy.  

One downside is that they get busy and the tables are smashed together.  Our service was fine, but the waitress had to stand behind me to take our order and clear our plates.  There was no good way of her getting next to our table.

Another tourist must-do, have a Hurricane at Pat O'Brien's.  The courtyard is a great place to enjoy one too!  Keep in mind that the places gets busy and the wait can get a bit out of hand.  In that case, go to the bar and grab one to go.

One thing that sort of turned me off was their policy around glassware.  Basically, they charge you $3 and will give you return said $3 if you return the glass.  In my mind, they assume I'm going to steal the glass.  I saw several individuals forget their glasses, which I'm sure their waiters loved.  And unless you are getting drinks to go, you have to get them in these glasses.  They will happily box the glass up for you on the way out... why not just sell me a glass on my way out?!?

Excellent shrimp poboy; really fresh shrimp & bread.  Good atmosphere.  Staff was good...sarcastic & diner-ish, the way they are supposed to be.

Minus one star for my sandwich not being made with love. the extra pickles I ordered being in one giant clump.  Really who wants that.

Why 4 stars? Because my expectations were exceeded.

   ---   ---   ---

I admit that I expected a place that I could barely move around in. One that was loud, sweaty, and as crowded as could be.

Instead, Pat O'Brien's was probably the biggest bar I have ever been in. It felt like it never ended. I don't think I even saw half of it. It was infinity. 

Hurricanes are one of those things that's a MUCH better idea before than after, 100% of the time. I tried one just to say I did it, and I don't think I got very far. 

I'm glad I experienced this institution.

Having had a rather busy day at work, I was so happy to be able to sit right down, order myself a hard cider, and take a load off!  My girl got a flatbread pizza with a [rather large] side of fries, which we ended up sharing, and I settled on the baked mac 'n cheese, which came with a delicious blueberry cornbread.  There was New Wave music playing, which definitely earns this bar brownie points, but it was a tad too loud, what with everyone talking and the radio being on at full blast...the one thing I hate most is shouting over all that noise.  Regardless, the waitstaff was prompt and attentive and we left rather full! I would definitely come back, but only with other people!

I hate to do this to you, oh, Saint Louis A! I want to give you 5-stars because for over a decade, dozens of times, I've loved getting off the plane and walking into your airport to the sounds of your music welcoming me to my favorite city. But this past arrival had me less than dazzled (and there was no music welcoming us this time, which made for *motto* sadness).

Let's talk bathrooms...as in, WTF? I've never seen such a lack at an airport before! I can't think of anything you'd need more in an airport (other than a bar, of course). After I left the plane, I looked for one and found one a few feet away. The line was out the door. OK, surely there was one another 25 feet away the way, you know, it is in airports.

 I walked...kept walking...all the way to baggage. Not a bathroom on the way. Halfway through the baggage hall, I decided I needed to find one STAT. There was one tucked behind the stairs...with another long line. CURSES!!!!! I ran up the stairs, no, really, running was now necessary. I found a bathroom...BOARDED UP! WTFF?! 

This is unacceptable! Even the very lacking in amenities Kansas City airport has bathrooms a-plenty. Truly, I'd rank Louis Armstrong as *worse* than LaGuardia in this respect. 

So, beware, my friends and make sure you hit the loo while still a mile high. 

Other than this huge issue, I'll give them an A-OK. Security isn't a nightmare. Airport personnel seem pleasant enough. There's a fair amount of coffee/food/booze options (hello, this is New Orleans, so there better be!) *before* you get past security. I also can't deny that upon landing, the happiness I feel to be back would otherwise eclipse almost any annoyance. 

I bet your wondering about my fate that day...? No, I didn't wet my bloomers. I was able to find another tiny bathroom tucked away...I couldn't tell you where. Suffice to say that it's not that easy to find as it was the only one without a line.

I will admit in advance that I will always have a soft place in my heart for Bern's because we came here the night we got engaged, a little over a year ago.

This place is fantastic.  Between the Farm to Table practice and the extensive and very reasonably priced wine list, the experience is a dream.  Sure, the place is decorated like Disney's Haunted Castle and it's a nightmare actually getting a table, but the food is wonderful.  And the service!  We were served by Matt last night, and he was one of the best waiters I've ever had.  He was warm and friendly but also very knowledgeable about the food.  The sommolier was also really great.  There was nothing pretentious about this place.  

I am biased as a Californian, but it's amazing being able to have a 41 year old Rioja and a beautiful steak cooked for two and very tasty crab cakes for less than $250.  I pay a lot more for a 2005 bottle and mediocre food and crappy service in San Francisco.

We had a wonderful Restaurant Week experience at Amada last night. We were lucky enough to snag a reservation for 4 when someone cancelled the day before. The menu was expansive (I don't think it was limited at all for RW). For the first course, the highlight was the garlic shrimp. For the second course, our favorites were the calamari and beef shortrib flatbread. The chicken breast with truffles was very good flavor, but the chicken was slightly dry. Our least favorite of the evening was the grilled beef brochettes - great flavor, but the meat was REALLY tough. The food was all solid good, but I didn't notice any magnificent flavors that I've never tasted before, which is what I need to taste to give 5 stars. The service was excellent and the decor was really fun. It's definitely a loud restaurant, so don't go expecting intimate conversation.

The best thing here is the guac - not sure which one we got, but it had balsamic glaze and was delicious! $15 for guac is a bit outrageous, but I'd do it again - it was that yummy. We got the tacos for two with chicken and they tasted like pretty basic fajitas. The mojitos were yummy, but not particularly strong. Would I go back? Yes...but I do think it's a bit pricey for what you get (A little over $100 for guac, tacos for 2, and 4 drinks total)
Amazing coconut curry chicken!  It's served on a bed of rice noodles and the chicken is incredibly flavorful and tender.  Plus they can alter the spice level!

Finally a short distance to drive to this BBQ joint. I remember every time I make a trip to Orlando, I have the carry out from this smokehouse BBQ restaurant. Now I can sit and eat the food at the restaurant since they open one in tampa. It Is long wait but worthies for the wait. 

Tonight (Friday night) is one of the longer restaurant hour night that they have until 9 pm. We arrive at 6:27pm and the wait line build up to sidewalk of the restaurant side. The wait on the line is 25 minute. The different of this restaurant is they built their sweet item at different side of the order line. This actually reduce the wait time compare to the one at winter park location. This is a improvement. While we were waiting on the line the server bring up the small ketchup cup size try item six shooter for the taste. 

We have order the Santa Maria Tri-Tip Steak and Smoke Prime Rib. We have added the half pound signature brisket. The side are the collar green, corn, sweet potato smash, and the bacon wrap jalapeño. The taste did not change from the original restaurant (Fairbanks Winter Park). The prime rib is juicy and tender. The brisket is well seasoning that enter to the meat it self. I love their their side because they extra effort to process it. If you fist time here, you should start with their brisket. 

If you come here to have a nice dinner, this is not the place. You should come here just for the food since your food is serve on top of paper on the tray. It is BBQ joint that you need to get down or chow down. Expecting line will build up to the door.

Great lunch here of Asian styles shrimp lettuce wraps with two amazing sauces -sweet peanut and a spicy aioli.   We also ordered the rare roast beef and the smoked salmon sandwich.   Both huge and were absolutely delicious.  Five stars as I would definitely drive out of my way for that for lunch.

Y'know Parkway, I loved your shrimp poboy and really who doesn't like cheese fries...and then I had the caprese poboy.  Beautiful tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, basil all on fresh french bread and then doused with a balsamic dressing.  Delicious and HUGE.  Which was good because my cousin (who is a scary ravenous nursing mother at the moment) attacked my sandwich too.

I must also complement my fellow diners.  A pigeon became trapped on the side porch and when I caught it (I know...I have hidden bird catching skills) they applauded.  Thank you.  No thank you.

Time to update my Parkway review. This place has become a tourist mecca so I try to stay away as much as I can but there are some redeeming qualities to this place other than their tasteless roast beef and their flash fried shrimp that loses its breading. I have two favorites that I have found on their menu that are consistently great. The corned beef poboy dressed is excellent. The corned beef is shipped in from the Fairgrounds old Chicago supplier and brings me back to the old days of the racetrack. Tender perfectly cooked corned beef on toasted french bread dressed, its so good!!! The other favorite of mine is the seasonal Thanksgiving Day poboy served only on Wednesday's in November. House roasted turkey, dressing, cranberry sauce and oh yes extra turkey gravy. Both of those sandwiches are the bomb.

This place has a sound concept with plenty of plasma TVs, which was helpful on a day like today when USA is playing Canada for the Gold Medal.

One of the TVs was even set to closed captioning, which was nice to read what was being said when it got too loud to hear the commentators.  It seems they keep the sound on the games relatively down or mute until a big game is about to air, and they switch to an overhead sound system for the audio.

It does get very noisy, and smoking was allowed everywhere it seemed, but ventilation was decent.

The baked wings were pretty good.  We got them plain with our sauces on the side.  10 wings were about $8.49.  I had a gyro for $8.49, which was good, and normally comes with fries, but I paid $1.29 to get a side salad instead.  My husband had the blackened tuna ($8.99), which he really liked and opted to pay $1.29 extra to get onion rings instead of fries.  Their version of onion rings had a very soft breading (no crispness at all), and we did not prefer them...perhaps others would.

Pluses about the bar.  They have Guiness, Woodchuck Cider, Blue Moon, Coors Light, Fat Tire, Schlafly and Bud products on tap!!!  That's in addition to a healthy bottled beer selection.

Despite being extremely short-handed in the kitchen and crowded to the max with customers, our server had a very good demeanor and attitude.  She was really trying and apologetic about our wait.

If you're trying to get a good seat for the game, I would park myself in front of the newer LG plasmas and not the big-screen projector, because you'll get better color and crispness on the plasmas.  If there are only 2 or 3 of you, grab seats at the bar.  Your drinks will stay full and cold and there are 3 TVs right in front of you.

Spectacular!  I cannot comment on its sandwiches, which most people go there specifically for, but their salads are absolutely marvelous!

First, I have to mention that I cannot offer a stronger suggestion than to use their texting reservation system.  My mom was driving from Orlando and I heard that Datz can be busy on Sunday at lunch.  Originally, we tried to make a reservation through Open Table, but they were booked at the time we wanted and we would have to wait till after 2 p.m. for a reservation!  I went on its website and noticed that I could text them to get on the waiting list for a table.  I did and it said we would have a table in 20 minutes.  My mom was running late so I took us off the list.  I had 30 minutes to put my name back on at the spot I was at!  Long story short, I kept texting to be put back in line and texting to be taken out until we were in front of the restaurant and the moment we walked in, my phone buzzed that our table was ready!  Amazing.

On Sunday they only serve brunch, but there are still a plethora of choices.  My mom got the Figgy Piggy Salad and it was superb!  The dressing is to die for with great chunks of bacon.  I got the High Steaks Caesar.  When it said it came with beef tips, I was thinking strips of beef.  Boy was I wrong.  They were perfectly cooked beef chunks on skewers.  It made the entire salad worth it.  They did not even ask me how I wanted it cooked, they knew to make it medium rare.  Both salads came with delicious looking hunks of bread, but we both abstained since we're going to have to fit into New Year dresses soon.

As people have written, parking is terrible.  There is parking in the back, but it is hardly enough.  While we were there, a man came over the sound system to say that two cars were about to be towed!  Definitely come early if you want a parking spot within walking distance.

I don't get to come here very often any more - but when I do I try to come when the place is DEAD EMPTY - like today - a random Thursday at 2 PM.  Dead.

As a result?  Fan-tabulous service from Stefan (from Serbia) and the lovely bartender (Jamie?  James?).  Seriously - great, great service.

The food - as always - is solid but mabe just a few tweaks could up the game even more.  I especially enjoyed the crab salad (made for the burger of the month - but I asked for a side of it and they were so kind to oblige me).

Jose, baby, you done good!

Particle board city... great if you are a college student or trying to furnish an apartment for cheap, but not the type of furniture I'd buy for my home.  I do love walking through the display areas for decorating ideas.  Wouldn't waste my money on the lamps or pillows... everything feels flimsy.  I would rather go to a big department store sale if I am looking to get bargains.

Wish more parents would take advantage of the hour long, free daycare.  It's hard to check out at a tv stand when a bratty child is jumping up and down on the sofas.

The cafeteria is Ikea's shining point.  Sweedish meatballs, pizza, hotdogs, ice cream cones... all for a few meager dollars.
